sn.def: The fourth letter of the English alphabet, and a vocal consonant. The English letter is from Latin, which is from Greek, which took it from Phœnician, the probable ultimate origin being Egyptian. It is related most nearly to t and th; as, Eng. deep, G. tief; Eng. daughter, G. tochter, Gr. qyga`thr, Skr. duhitr. See Guide to Pronunciation, √178, 179, 229.
The nominal of the second tone in the model major scale (that in C), or of the fourth tone in the relative minor scale of C (that in A minor), or of the key tone in the relative minor of F.
As a numeral D stands for 500. in this use it is not the initial of any word, or even strictly a letter, but one half of the sign � (or � ) the original Tuscan numeral for 1000.

entry.ety: Perh. corrupted fr. adept
entry.def: A skillful hand; a dabster; an expert.
entry.q: One excels at a plan or the titlepage, another works away at the body of the book, and the third is a dab at an index.

entry.ety: Perh. so named from its quickness in diving beneath the sand. Cf. Dabchick
entry.def: A name given to several species of flounders, esp. to the European species, Pleuronectes limanda. The American rough dab is Hippoglossoides platessoides.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Dabbed dăbd; p. pr. & vb. n. Dabbing
entry.ety: OE. dabben to strice; akin to OD. dabben to pinch, knead, fumble, dabble, and perh. to G. tappen to grope

sn.def: To strike or touch gently, as with a soft or moist substance; to tap; hence, to besmear with a dabber.
sn.q: A sore should . . . be wiped . . . only by dabbing it over with fine lint.

sn.def: To strike by a thrust; to hit with a sudden blow or thrust.
sn.q: Todabhim in the neck.

sn.def: A gentle blow with the hand or some soft substance; a sudden blow or hit; a peck.
sn.q: A scratch of her claw, a dab of her beak.

sn.def: A small mass of anything soft or moist.

entry.def: A large, spine-tailed lizard (Uromastix spinipes), found in Egypt, Arabia, and Palestine; -- called also dhobb, and dhubb.
That with which one dabs; hence, a pad or other device used by printers, engravers, etc., as for dabbing type or engraved plates with ink.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Dabbled dăb"b'ld; p. pr. & vb. n. Dabbling dăb"blĭng
entry.ety: Freq. of dab: cf. OD. dabbelen
entry.def: To wet by little dips or strokes; to spatter; to sprinkle; to moisten; to wet.
entry.q: Bright hairdabbledin blood.

sn.def: To play in water, as with the hands; to paddle or splash in mud or water.
sn.q: Where the duck dabbles 'mid the rustling sedge.

sn.def: To work in slight or superficial manner; to do in a small way; to tamper; to meddle.
sn.q: Dabblinghere and there with the text.
During the first year at Dumfries, Burns for the first time began to dabble in politics.

sn.def: One who dabbles.
One who dips slightly into anything; a superficial meddler.
sn.q: ourdabblersin politics.

entry.def: In a dabbling manner.

entry.ety: For dabchick. See Dap Dip, cf. Dipchick
entry.def: A small water bird (Podilymbus podiceps), allied to the grebes, remarkable for its quickness in diving; -- called also dapchick dobchick dipchick didapper dobber devil-diver hell-diver, and pied-billed grebe.
A large and highly venomous Asiatic viper (Daboia xanthica).

entry.note: ☞ Sometimes improperly used for dabbler; as, “I am but a dabster with gentle art”.
entry.ety: Cf. Dab an expert
entry.def: One who is skilled; a master of his business; a proficient; an adept.

entries.entry: Da`ca"po Da`ca"po. It., from [the] head or beginning Mus From the beginning; a direction to return to, and end with, the first strain; -- indicated by the letters D. C. Also, the strain so repeated.

entry.note: ☞ In America the name is given to several related fishes of the genera Squalius Minnilus, etc. The black-nosed dace is Rhinichthys atronasus the horned dace is Semotilus corporalis. For red dace, see Redfin.
entry.ety: Written also dare dart, fr. F. dard dase, dart, of German origin. Dace is for an older darce, fr. an OF. nom. darz. See Dart a javelin
entry.def: A small European cyprinoid fish (Leuciscus leuciscus, formerly Squalius leuciscus or Leuciscus vulgaris); -- called also dare.
a genus of Australasian kingfishers.

entry.ety: Russian
entry.def: a Russian country house, especially a cottage used in the summer.

entry.ety: G., from dachs badger + hund dog
entry.def: One of a breed of small dogs with short crooked legs, and long body; -- called also badger dog. There are two kinds, the rough-haired and the smooth-haired.
Of or pertaining to Dacia or the Dacians.
a natural family comprising the honeycreepers.

entry.ety: Hind. ḍakait ḍākāyat
entry.def: One of a class of robbers, in India and Burma (Myanmar), who act in gangs and are usually armed.
The practice of gang robbery in India; robbery committed by dacoits.

entries.entry: Da*co"tahs n. pl.; sing. Dacotan . Ethnol Same as Dacotas.

entry.ety: Trademark
entry.def: a brand of polyester textile fiber, or the wrinkle-resistant fabric prepared from it.
a genus of evergreen coniferous shrubs or trees of New Zealand to Malaysia and Philippines.
a genus of Australasian evergreen trees or shrubs.
the type genus of the Dacrymycetaceae, consisting of fungi with a bifurcate basidium that lacks septa.

entry.ety: L. dactylus, Gr. da`ktylos a finger, a dactyl. Cf. Digit

sn.def: A poetical foot of three sylables (--- ˘ ˘), one long followed by two short, or one accented followed by two unaccented; as, L. tëgmĭnĕ, E. mer"ciful; -- so called from the similarity of its arrangement to that of the joints of a finger.

sd.def: A finger or toe; a digit.
The claw or terminal joint of a leg of an insect or crustacean.

sn.def: Pertaining to dactyl; dactylic.
Of or pertaining to a finger or toe, or to the claw of an insect crustacean.

entry.ety: Dactyl + -et
entry.def: A dactyl.

entry.ety: L. dactylicus, Gr. daktyliko`s, fr. da`ktylos
entry.def: Pertaining to, consisting chiefly or wholly of, dactyls; as, dactylic verses.

sn.def: A line consisting chiefly or wholly of dactyls; as, these lines are dactylics .
Dactylic meters.

entry.ety: Gr. daktyliogly`fos an engraver of gems; dakty`lios finger ring (fr. da`ktylos finger) + gly`fein to engrave
entry.def: An engraver of gems for rings and other ornaments.
The inscription of the engraver's name on a finger ring or gem.
The art or process of gem engraving.

entry.ety: Gr. dakty`lios finger ring + -graphy
entry.def: The art of writing or engraving upon gems.
In general, the literature or history of the art.

entry.ety: Gr. dakty`lios finger ring + -logy
entry.def: That branch of archæology which has to do with gem engraving.
That branch of archæology which has to do with finger rings.

entry.ety: Gr. dakty`lios + -mancy
entry.def: Divination by means of finger rings.
A writer of dactylic verse.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. da`ktylos finger + -itis
entry.def: An inflammatory affection of the fingers.

entry.note: ☞ There are two different manual alphabets, the one-hand alphabet (which was perfected by Abbé de l'Epée, who died in 1789), and the two-hand alphabet. The latter was probably based on the manual alphabet published by George Dalgarus of Aberdeen, in 1680. See Illustration in Appendix.
entry.ety: Gr. da`ktylos finger + -logy
entry.def: The art of communicating ideas by certain movements and positions of the fingers; -- a method of conversing practiced by the deaf and dumb.
Dactyliomancy.

entry.ety: Gr. da`ktylos finger + no`mos law, distribution
entry.def: The art of numbering or counting by the fingers.

entry.ety: Gr. da`ktylos finger + � wing, fin
entry.def: Having the inferior rays of the pectoral fins partially or entirely free, as in the gurnards.
a natural family of Atlantic fishes comprising the sand stargazers.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. da`ktylos finger, toe + qh`kh case, box
entry.def: The scaly covering of the toes, as in birds.

entry.ety: Gr. da`ktylos finger + E. zooid
entry.def: A kind of zooid of Siphonophora which has an elongated or even vermiform body, with one tentacle, but no mouth. See Siphonophora.

entry.ety: Prob. of Celtic origin; cf. Ir. daid, Gael. daidein, W. tad, OL. tata, Gr. ta`ta te`tta, Skr. tāta
entry.def: Father; -- a word sometimes used by children.
entry.q: I was never so bethumped with words, Since I first called my brother's father dad.

entry.ety: Prob. freq. of dade
entry.def: To toddle; to walk unsteadily, like a child or an old man; hence, to do anything slowly or feebly.

entry.ety: Cf. Prov. E. dad a large piece
entry.def: The rotten body of a tree.
Diminutive of Dad.

entries.entry:
Dad"dy long"legs`. Zoöl An arachnidan of the genus Phalangium, and allied genera, having a small body and four pairs of long legs; -- called also harvestman carter, and grandfather longlegs.
Zoöl A name applied to many species of dipterous insects of the genus Tipula, and allied genera, with slender bodies, and very long, slender legs; the crane fly; -- called also father longlegs.

entry.ety: Of. uncertain origin. Cf. Dandle Daddle
entry.def: To hold up by leading strings or by the hand, as a child while he toddles.
entry.q: Little children when they learn to go By painful mothers daded to and fro.

entry.def: To walk unsteadily, as a child in leading strings, or just learning to walk; to move slowly.
entry.q: No sooner taught to dade, but from their mother trip.

entries.entry:
Da"do n.; pl.Dadoes #. It. dado die, cube, pedestal; of the same origin as E. die n. See Die n.
Arch That part of a pedestal included between the base and the cornice (or surbase); the die. See Illust. of Column. Hence: In any wall, that part of the basement included between the base and the base course. See Base course, under Base. In interior decoration, the lower part of the wall of an apartment when adorned with moldings, or otherwise specially decorated.

entry.ety: L. daedalus cunningly wrought, fr. Gr. �; cf. � to work cunningly. The word also alludes to the mythical Dædalus (Gr. �, lit., the cunning worker)

sn.def: Cunningly or ingeniously formed or working; skillful; artistic; ingenious.
sn.q: Our bodies decked in our dædalian arms.
The dædal hand of Nature.
The doth the dædal earth throw forth to thee, Out of her fruitful, abundant flowers.

sn.def: Crafty; deceitful.

entry.def: Having a variously cut or incised margin; -- said of leaves.
See Demon Demonic.

entry.ety: Cf. Doff
entry.def: To cast aside; to put off; to doff.
entry.q: Canst thou so daff me? Thou hast killed my child.

entry.ety: See Daft
entry.def: A stupid, blockish fellow; a numskull.
To act foolishly; to be foolish or sportive; to toy.
To daunt.

entry.ety: OE. affodylle, prop., the asphodel, fr. LL. affodilluscf. D. affodille or OF. asphodile aphodille, F. asphodèle), L. asphodelus, fr. Gr. 'asfo`delos. The initial d in English is not satisfactorily explained. See Asphodel
entry.def: A plant of the genus Asphodelus.
A plant of the genus Narcissus Narcissus Pseudo-narcissus). It has a bulbous root and beautiful flowers, usually of a yellow hue. Called also daffodilly daffadilly daffadowndilly daffydowndilly, etc.
entry.q: With damask roses and daffadillies set.
Strow me the ground with daffadowndillies, And cowslips, and kingcups, and loved lilies.
A college gown That clad her like an April daffodilly.
And chance-sown daffodil.

entry.ety: OE. daft deft deft, stupid; prob. the same word as E. deft. See Deft

sn.def: Stupid; foolish; idiotic; also, delirious; insane; as, he has gone daft .
sn.q: Let us think no more of this daft business

sn.def: Gay; playful; frolicsome.

entry.def: The quality of being daft.

entry.ety: Cf. F. dague, LL. daga, D. daggefr. French); all prob. fr. Celtic; Cf. Gael. dag a pistol, Armor. dag dagger, W. dager dagr, Ir. daigear. Cf. Dagger

sn.def: A dagger; a poniard.
A large pistol formerly used.
sn.q: The Spaniards discharged their dags, and hurt some.
A sort of pistol, called dag, was used about the same time as hand guns and harquebuts.

sn.def: The unbranched antler of a young deer.

entry.ety: Of Scand. origin; cf. Sw. dagg, Icel. dögg. √71. See Dew
entry.def: A misty shower; dew.

entry.ety: OE. daggecf. Dagger); or cf. AS. dāg what is dangling
entry.def: A loose end; a dangling shred.
entry.q: Daglocks, clotted locks hanging in dags or jags at a sheep's tail.

entry.ety: 1, from Dag dew. 2, from Dag a loose end

sn.def: To daggle or bemire.
To cut into jags or points; to slash; as, to dag a garment.

entry.def: To be misty; to drizzle.
the lemonwood tree Calycophyllum candidissimum); -- it is a tropical American tree which is source of a tough elastic wood.

entry.note: See references to Dagon in the Bible and in the opera Samson et Dalila.
entry.def: the Mesopotanian god of agriculture and earth; it is a counterpart of Phoenician and Philistine Dagon.
in Irish legend, chief god of the Tuatha De Danann; father of Angus Og and Brigit.
a relatively nontoxic South African herb (Leonotis leonurus) smoked like tobacco.
entry.syn: Cape dagga, red dagga, wilde dagga, Leonotis leonurus.

cs.cd: any moth of the genus Apatalea. The larvæ are often destructive to the foliage of fruit trees, etc.
the wooden weapon given to the Vice in the old Moralities.
a mark of reference [‡] which comes next in order after the dagger.
to look or speak fiercely or reproachfully.

entry.ety: Cf. OE. daggen to pierce, F. daguer. See Dag a dagger

sn.def: A short weapon used for stabbing. This is the general term: cf. Poniard Stiletto Bowie knife Dirk Misericorde Anlace.
A mark of reference in the form of a dagger [†]. It is the second in order when more than one reference occurs on a page; -- called also obelisk.

entry.def: To pierce with a dagger; to stab.

entry.ety: Perh. from diagonal
entry.def: A timber placed diagonally in a ship's frame.

entry.ety: OE. See Dag a loose end
entry.def: An ornamental cutting of the edges of garments, introduced about a. d. 1346, according to the Chronicles of St Albans.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Daggled -g'ld; p. pr. & vb. n. Daggling -glĭng
entry.ety: Freq. of dag, v. t., 1
entry.def: To trail, so as to wet or befoul; to make wet and limp; to moisten.
entry.q: The warrior's very plume, I say, Was daggled by the dashing spray.

entry.def: To run, go, or trail one's self through water, mud, or slush; to draggle.
entry.q: Nor, like a puppy [have Idaggled through the town.

entry.def: Having the lower ends of garments defiled by trailing in mire or filth; draggle-tailed.
A slovenly woman; a slattern; a draggle-tail.

entry.ety: Dag a loose end + lock
entry.def: A dirty or clotted lock of wool on a sheep; a taglock.

entries.entry:
Da"go dā"g� n.; pl.Dagos -gōz. Cf. Sp. Diego, E. James
A nickname given to a person of Spanish (or, by extension, Portuguese or Italian) descent. U. S

entry.ety: Singhalese dāgoba
entry.def: A dome-shaped structure built over relics of Buddha or some Buddhist saint.

entry.ety: Heb. Dāgon, fr. dag a fish: cf. Gr. Dagw`n
entry.def: The national god of the Philistines, represented with the face and hands and upper part of a man, and the tail of a fish.
entry.q: This day a solemn feast the people hold To Dagon, their sea idol.
They brought it into the house of Dagon.

entry.ety: See Dag a loose end
entry.def: A slip or piece.

entry.ety: From Dag a loose end?
entry.def: A coarse woolen fabric made of daglocks, or the refuse of wool.
entry.q: Under coverlets made ofdagswain.

entry.ety: Dag a loose end + tail
entry.def: Daggle-tailed; having the tail clogged with daglocks.
entry.q: Dag-tailedsheep.

entry.def: Pertaining to Daguerre, or to his invention of the daguerreotype.

entry.ety: From Daguerre the inventor + -type

sn.def: An early variety of photograph, produced on a silver plate, or copper plate covered with silver, and rendered sensitive by the action of iodine, or iodine and bromine, on which, after exposure in the camera, the latent image is developed by the vapor of mercury.
The process of taking such pictures.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Daguerreotyped -tīpt; p. pr. & vb. n. Daguerreotyping -tī`pĭng

sn.def: To produce or represent by the daguerreotype process, as a picture.
To impress with great distinctness; to imprint; to imitate exactly.

entry.def: One who takes daguerreotypes.
The art or process of producing pictures by method of Daguerre.

entry.ety: Ar
entry.def: A Nile boat constructed on the model of a floating house, having large lateen sails.

entries.entry: Dah"lia däl"yȧ or dāl"yȧ; 277, 106 n.; pl.Dahlias #. Named after Andrew Dahl a Swedish botanist Bot A genus of plants native to Mexico and Central America, of the order Compositæ; also, any plant or flower of the genus. The numerous varieties of cultivated dahlias bear conspicuous flowers which differ in color.

entry.ety: From Dahlia
entry.def: A variety of starch extracted from the dahlia; -- called also inulin. See Inulin.

entry.ety: Origin unknown
entry.def: An evergreen shrub or small tree (Ilex cassine) of the southern United States, bearing red drupes and having soft, white, close-grained wood; -- called also dahoon holly .
a radish of Japan (Raphanus sativus longipinnatus) with a long hard durable root eaten raw or cooked.
the lower house of the parliament of the Republic of Ireland; -- also called the Dail Eirann. From its members is selected the Taoiseach, or prime minister.
Daily occurence.

entry.usage: Daily is Anglo-Saxon, and diurnal is Latin. The former is used in reference to the ordinary concerns of life; as, daily wants, daily cares, daily employments. The latter is appropriated chiefly by astronomers to what belongs to the astronomical day; as, the diurnal revolution of the earth.
entry.ety: AS. dæglīc; dæg day + -līc like. See Day
entry.def: Happening, or belonging to, each successive day; diurnal; as, daily labor; a daily bulletin.
entry.q: Give us this day our daily bread.
Bunyan has told us . . . that in New England his dream was the daily subject of the conversation of thousands.
Man hath his daily work of body or mind Appointed, which declares his dignity, And the regard of Heaven on all his ways.
Half yet remains unsung, but narrower bound Within the visible diurnal sphere.

entries.entry: Dai"ly n.; pl.Dailies. A publication which appears regularly every day; as, the morning dailies .

entry.def: Every day; day by day; as, a thing happens daily .

entries.entry:
Dai"mi*o n.; pl.Daimios #. Jap., fr. Chin. tai ming great name The title of the feudal nobles of Japan.
The daimios, or territorial nobles, resided in Yedo and were divided into four classes.

entry.ety: See Dainty n.
entry.def: Something of exquisite taste; a dainty.
entry.q: To cherish him with diets daint.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Daintified; p. pr. & vb. n. Daintifying
entry.ety: Dainty + -fy
entry.def: To render dainty, delicate, or fastidious.
entry.q: Daintifiedemotion.

entry.def: In a dainty manner; nicely; scrupulously; fastidiously; deliciously; prettily.
The quality of being dainty; nicety; niceness; elegance; delicacy; deliciousness; fastidiousness; squeamishness.
entry.q: The daintiness and niceness of our captains
More notorious for the daintiness of the provision . . . than for the massiveness of the dish.
The duke exeeded in the daintiness of his leg and foot, and the earl in the fine shape of his hands,

entry.ety: From daint or dainty; cf. OF. daintier
entry.def: Adelicacy.

entries.entry:
Dain"ty These words are here compared as denoting articles of food. The term delicacy as applied to a nice article of any kind, and hence to articles of food which are particularly attractive. Dainty is stronger, and denotes some exquisite article of cookery. A hotel may be provided with all the delicacies of the season, and its table richly covered with dainties. n.; pl.Dainties #. OE. deinie dainte deintie deyntee, OF. deintié delicacy, orig., dignity, honor, fr. L. dignitas, fr. dignus worthy. See Deign, and cf. Dignity
Value; estimation; the gratification or pleasure taken in anything. Obs I ne told no deyntee of her love.
That which is delicious or delicate; a delicacy. That precious nectar may the taste renew Of Eden's dainties, by our parents lost.
A term of fondness. Poetic
Dainty Delicacy. These delicacies I mean of taste, sight, smell, herbs, fruits, and flowers, Walks and the melody of birds. A table] furnished plenteously with bread, And dainties, remnants of the last regale.

entry.note: ☞ Hence the proverb “dainty maketh dearth,” i. e., rarity makes a thing dear or precious.

cs.cd: to assume or affect delicacy or fastidiousness.

sn.def: Rare; valuable; costly.
sn.q: Full many a deynté horse had he in stable.

sn.def: Delicious to the palate; toothsome.
sn.q: Dainty bits Make rich the ribs.

sn.def: Nice; delicate; elegant, in form, manner, or breeding; well-formed; neat; tender.
sn.q: Those dainty limbs which nature lent For gentle usage and soft delicacy.
I would be the girdle. About her dainty dainty waist.

sn.def: Requiring dainties. Hence: Overnice; hard to please; fastidious; squeamish; scrupulous; ceremonious.
sn.q: Thew were a fine and dainty people.
And let us not be dainty of leave-taking, But shift away.
Ah ha, my mistresses! which of you all Will now deny to dance? She that makes dainty, She, I'll swear, hath corns.

entry.def: an alcoholic beverage containing rum and lime or lemon juice, usually mixed with a fruit juice or fruit extract and often blended with crushed ice; as, a strawberry daiquiri .

entry.ety: Turk. daire circuit, department, fr. Ar. daïrah circle
entry.def: Any of several valuable estates of the Egyptian khedive or his family. The most important are the Da"i*ra Sa"ni*eh sä"nĭ*ĕ, or Da"i*ra Sa"ni*yeh, and the Da"i*ra Khas"sa, administered by the khedive's European bondholders, and known collectively as the Daira, or the Daira estates.

entries.entry:
Dai"ry ☞ Dairy is much used adjectively or in combination; as, dairy farm, dairy countries, dairy house or dairyhouse, dairyroom, dairywork, etc. dā"r� n.; pl.Dairies -rĭz. OE. deierie, from deie daie, maid; of Scand. origin; cf. Icel. deigja maid, dairymaid, Sw. deja, orig., a baking maid, fr. Icel. deig. √66. See Dough
The place, room, or house where milk is kept, and converted into butter or cheese. What stores my dairies and my folds contain.
That department of farming which is concerned in the production of milk, and its conversion into butter and cheese. Grounds were turned much in England either to feeding or dairy; and this advanced the trade of English butter.
A dairy farm. R

entry.def: The business of conducting a dairy.
A female servant whose business is the care of the dairy.

entries.entry: Dai"ry*man n.; pl.Dairymen. A man who keeps or takes care of a dairy.
Dai"ry*wom`an n.; pl.Dairywomen. A woman who attends to a dairy.

entry.ety: OE. deis des, table, dais, OF. deis table, F. dais a canopy, L. discus a quoit, a dish (from the shape), LL., table, fr. Gr. � a quoit, a dish. See Dish

sn.def: The high or principal table, at the end of a hall, at which the chief guests were seated; also, the chief seat at the high table.
A platform slightly raised above the floor of a hall or large room, giving distinction to the table and seats placed upon it for the chief guests.
A canopy over the seat of a person of dignity.

entry.def: Full of daisies; adorned with daisies.
entry.q: Thedaisiedgreen.
The grass all deep and daisied.

entries.entry:
Dai"sy ☞ The word daisy is also used for composite plants of other genera, as Erigeron, or fleabane.
Michaelmas daisy Bot any plant of the genus Aster, of which there are many species. Oxeye daisy Bot the whiteweed. See Daisy.
dā"z� n.; pl.Daisies dā"zĭz. OE. dayesye, AS. dæges-eáge day's eye, daisy. See Day, and Eye
Bot A genus of low herbs (Bellis), belonging to the family Compositæ. The common English and classical daisy is Bellis perennis, which has a yellow disk and white or pinkish rays. The whiteweed (Chrysanthemum Leucanthemum), the plant commonly called daisy in North America; -- called also oxeye daisy. See Whiteweed.

entry.def: any of various mostly Australian attractively shaped shrubs of the genus Olearia grown for their handsome and sometimes fragrant evergreen foliage and profusion of daisy flowers with white or purple or blue rays.

cs.cd: a mail boat.
a traveler's rest-house at the end of a dak stage.
to travel by relays of palanquins or other carriage, as fast as the post along a road.

entry.ety: Hind. ḍāk
entry.def: Post; mail; also, the mail or postal arrangements; -- spelt also dawk, and dauk.

entry.ety: See Dicker
entry.def: A measure of certain commodities by number, usually ten or twelve, but sometimes twenty; as, a daker of hides consisted of ten skins; a daker of gloves of ten pairs.

entries.entry: Da"ker hen`. Perh. fr. W. crecial the daker hen; crec a sharp noise (creg harsh, hoarse, crechian to scream) + iar hen; or cf. D. duiken to dive, plunge Zoöl The corncrake or land rail.

entry.def: See Dacoit Dacoity.

entries.entry: Da*ko"ta group`. Geol A subdivision at the base of the cretaceous formation in Western North America; -- so named from the region where the strata were first studied.

Da*ko"tas n. pl.; sing. Dacota . Ethnol An extensive race or stock of Indians, including many tribes, mostly dwelling west of the Mississippi River; -- also, in part, called Sioux.
Dacotahs

entry.ety: Hind
entry.def: Split pulse, esp. of Cajanus Indicus.
a large genus of tropical trees having pinnate leaves and paniculate flowers and cultivated commercially for their dramatically grained and colored timbers.

entry.ety: AS. dæl; akin to LG., D., Sw., Dan., OS., & Goth. dal, Icel. dalr, OHG. tal, G. thal, and perh. to Gr. qo`los a rotunda, Skr. dhāra depth. Cf. Dell

sn.def: A low place between hills; a vale or valley.
sn.q: Where mountaines rise, umbrageous dales descend.

sn.def: A trough or spout to carry off water, as from a pump.

entry.def: a genus of plants including the indigo bush.

entries.entry: Dales"man dālz"m�n n.; pl.Dalesmen dālz"m�n. One living in a dale; -- a term applied particularly to the inhabitants of the valleys in the north of England, Norway, etc.

entry.def: the fourth letter of the Hebrew alphabet.
imp. of Delve.

entry.ety: F. dalle a tube, gutter, trough
entry.def: A rapid, esp. one where the channel is narrowed between rock walls.
entry.q: The place below, where the compressed river wound like a silver thread among the flat black rocks, was the far-famed Dalles of the Columbia.

entry.ety: From Dally

sn.def: The act of dallying, trifling, or fondling; interchange of caresses; wanton play.
sn.q: Look thou be true, do not give dalliance Too much the rein.
O, the dalliance and the wit, The flattery and the strife!

sn.def: Delay or procrastination.
Entertaining discourse.

entry.def: One who fondles; a trifler; as, dalliers with pleasant words.
a tall tufted perennial tropical American grass (Paspalum dilatatum) naturalized as pasture and forage grass in the southern U.S.

entry.ety: Etymol. unknown
entry.def: A tuft or clump.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Dallied dăl"lĭd; p. pr. & vb. n. Dallying
entry.ety: OE. dalien dailien; cf. Icel. pylja to talk, G. dallen dalen dahlen, to trifle, talk nonsense, OSw. tule a droll or funny man; or AS. dol foolish, E. dull

sn.def: To waste time in effeminate or voluptuous pleasures, or in idleness; to fool away time; to delay unnecessarily; to tarry; to trifle.
sn.q: We have trifled too long already; it is madness to dally any longer.
We have put off God, and dallied with his grace.

sn.def: To interchange caresses, especially with one of the opposite sex; to use fondling; to wanton; to sport.
sn.q: Not dallying with a brace of courtesans.
Our aerie . . . dallies with the wind.

entry.def: To delay unnecessarily; to while away.
entry.q: Dallying off the time with often skirmishes.

entry.ety: From Dalman, the geologist
entry.def: A genus of trilobites, of many species, common in the Upper Silurian and Devonian rocks.
Same as Dalmania.

cs.cd: a carriage dog, shaped like a pointer, and having black or bluish spots on a white ground; the coach dog.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to Dalmatia.

entry.ety: LL. dalmatica: cf. F. dalmatique

sn.def: A vestment with wide sleeves, and with two stripes, worn at Mass by deacons, and by bishops at pontifical Mass; -- imitated from a dress originally worn in Dalmatia.
A robe worn on state ocasions, as by English kings at their coronation.

entry.def: a herb of the Pacific islands (Colocasia esculenta) grown throughout the tropics for its edible root and in temperate areas as an ornamental for its large glossy leaves.
entry.syn: taro, taro plant, dasheen, Colocasia esculenta.

entries.entry: Dal` se"gno Dal` se"gno. It., from the sign Mus A direction to go back to the sign � and repeat from thence to the close. See Segno.

entry.def: John Dalton, scientist, born 1766, died 1844.

entry.note: Molecular weights are often expressed as dimensionless units, the unit being understood (in chemistry) to be the atomic mass unit with carbon equal to 14. Thus having a “molecular weight of 255” means the same as each molecule having a mass of 255 daltons.
entry.ety: from the chemist John Dalton, proponent of the modern atomic theory of matter
entry.def: a unit of mass, approximately 1.66 x 10-24 grams; -- it is approximately equal to the mass of one hydrogen atom, but the exact value differs slightly as used in physics and chemistry. It is used mostly to describe the size of proteins and nucleic acids in biochemistry.
One afflicted with color blindness.
Inability to perceive or distinguish certain colors, esp. red; color blindness. It has various forms and degrees. So called from the chemist Dalton, who had this infirmity.

entry.ety: OE. dame mistress, lady; also, mother, dam. See Dame

sn.def: A female parent; -- used of beasts, especially of quadrupeds; sometimes applied in contempt to a human mother.
sn.q: Our sire and dam, now confined to horses, are a relic of this age (13th century) . . . .Dame is used of a hen; we now make a great difference between dame and dam.
The dam runs lowing up and down, Looking the way her harmless young one went.

sn.def: A king or crowned piece in the game of draughts.

cs.cd: an iron plate in front of the dam, to strengthen it.

entry.ety: Akin to OLG., D., & Dan. dam, G. & Sw. damm, Icel. dammr, and AS. fordemman to stop up, Goth. Faúrdammjan

sn.def: A barrier to prevent the flow of a liquid; esp., a bank of earth, or wall of any kind, as of masonry or wood, built across a water course, to confine and keep back flowing water.
A firebrick wall, or a stone, which forms the front of the hearth of a blast furnace.

cs.cd: to keep out by means of a dam.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Dammed dămd; p. pr. & vb. n. Damming

sn.def: To obstruct or restrain the flow of, by a dam; to confine by constructing a dam, as a stream of water; -- generally used with in or up.
sn.q: I'll have the current in this place dammed up.
A weight of earth that dams in the water.

sn.def: To shut up; to stop up; to close; to restrain.
sn.q: The strait pass was dammed With dead men hurt behind, and cowards.

entry.def: a genus of deer including the Eurasian fallow deer, Dama dama.

entry.note: ☞ In common-law actions, the jury are the proper judges of damages.
entry.cs:
Consequential damage. See under Consequential. Exemplary damages Law damages imposed by way of example to others. Similar in purpose to vindictive damages, below. Nominal damages Law those given for a violation of a right where no actual loss has accrued.
vindictive damagesorpunitive damages
those given specially for the punishment of the wrongdoer.
entry.ety: OF. damage domage, F. dommage, fr. assumed LL. damnaticum, from L. damnum damage. See Damn

sn.def: Injury or harm to person, property, or reputation; an inflicted loss of value; detriment; hurt; mischief.
sn.q: He that sendeth a message by the hand of a fool cutteth off the feet and drinketh damage.
Great errors and absurdities many commit for want of a friend to tell them of them, to the great damage both of their fame and fortune.

sn.def: The estimated reparation in money for detriment or injury sustained; a compensation, recompense, or satisfaction to one party, for a wrong or injury actually done to him by another.
sn.syn: Mischief; injury; harm; hurt; detriment; evil; ill. See Mischief.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Damaged dăm"�jd; p. pr. & vb. n. Damaging dăm"�*jĭng
entry.ety: Cf. OF. damagier domagier. See Damage n.
entry.def: To occasion damage to the soundness, goodness, or value of; to hurt; to injure; to impair.
entry.q: He . . . came up to the English admiral and gave him a broadside, with which he killed many of his men and damaged the ship.

entry.def: To receive damage or harm; to be injured or impaired in soundness or value; as, some colors in cloth damage in sunlight.

entry.ety: Cf. OF. damageable, F. dommageable for sense 2

sn.def: Capable of being injured or impaired; liable to, or susceptible of, damage; as, a damageable cargo.
Hurtful; pernicious.
sn.q: That it be not damageable unto your royal majesty.

entry.sn: changed so as to reduce value, function, or other desirable trait; -- usually not used of persons. Opposite of undamaged.Narrower terms: battered, beat-up, beaten-up, bedraggled, broken-down, dilapidated, ramshackle, tumble-down, unsound; bent, crumpled, dented; blasted, rent, ripped, torn; broken-backed; burned-out(prenominal), burned out(predicate), burnt-out(prenominal), burnt out(predicate; burst, ruptured; corroded; cracked, crackled, crazed; defaced, marred; hurt, weakened; knocked-out(prenominal), knocked out; mangled, mutilated; peeling; scraped, scratched; storm-beaten Also See blemished broken damaged destroyed impaired injured unsound.

Rendered imperfect by impairing the integrity of some part, or by breaking. Opposite of unbroken.Narrower terms: busted; chipped; cracked; crumbled, fragmented; crushed, ground; dissolved; fractured; shattered, smashed, splintered; split; unkept, violated Also See: damaged imperfect injured unsound. broken.

sn.def: being unjustly brought into disrepute; as, her damaged reputation.
made to appear imperfect; -- especially of reputation; as, the senator's seriously damaged reputation.
sn.syn: besmirched, flyblown, spotted, stained, sullied, tainted, tarnished.

entries.entry:
Dam"age fea`sant. OF. damage + F. faisant doing, p. pr. See Feasible
Law Doing injury; trespassing, as cattle.

entry.def: a sum of money paid in compensation for an injury or wrong.

sn.def: causing harm or injury; as, damaging to career and reputation.
designed or tending to discredit, especially without positive or helpful suggestions.

entry.def: a genus of African antelopes including the sassaby, Damaliscus lunatus.

A small herbivorous mammal of the genus Hyrax. The species found in Palestine and Syria is Hyrax Syriacus; that of Northern Africa is Hyrax Brucei; -- called also ashkoko dassy, and rock rabbit. See Cony, and Hyrax.
See Dammar.

entry.ety: The name is supposed to be from Hottentot dama vanquished
entry.def: A native of Damaraland, German Southwest Africa. The Damaras include an important and warlike Bantu tribe, and the Hill Damaras, who are Hottentots and mixed breeds hostile to the Bantus.

entry.ety: L. Damascenus of Damascus, fr. Damascus the city, Gr. Damasko`s. See Damask, and cf. Damaskeen Damaskin Damson
entry.def: Of or relating to Damascus.
A kind of plum, now called damson. See Damson.
Same as Damask, or Damaskeen v. t.
entry.q: Damascenedarmor.
Cast anddamascenedsteel.

entry.def: decorated or inlaid with a wavy pattern of different (especially precious) metals; -- of metallic objects; as, a damascened sword.

entry.cs:
Damascus blade a sword or scimiter, made chiefly at Damascus, having a variegated appearance of watering, and proverbial for excellence.
Damascus ironorDamascus twist
metal formed of thin bars or wires of iron and steel elaborately twisted and welded together; used for making gun barrels, etc., of high quality, in which the surface, when polished and acted upon by acid, has a damask appearance. Damascus steel. See Damask steel, under Damask a.
entry.ety: L
entry.def: A city of Syria.

entries.entry: Da*mas"cus steel. See Damask steel, under Damask.

entry.ety: From the city Damascus, L. Damascus, Gr. Damasko`s, Heb. Dammesq, Ar. Daemeshq; cf. Heb. d'meseq damask; cf. It. damasco, Sp. damasco, F. damas. Cf. Damascene DamassÉ

sn.def: Damask silk; silk woven with an elaborate pattern of flowers and the like.
sn.q: A bed of ancientdamask.

sn.def: Linen so woven that a pattern in produced by the different directions of the thread, without contrast of color.
A heavy woolen or worsted stuff with a pattern woven in the same way as the linen damask; -- made for furniture covering and hangings.
Damask or Damascus steel; also, the peculiar markings or “water” of such steel.
A deep pink or rose color.

entry.cs:
Damask color a deep rose-color like that of the damask rose. Damask plum a small dark-colored plum, generally called damson. Damask rose Bot a large, pink, hardy, and very fragrant variety of rose (Rosa damascena) from Damascus. “Damask roses have not been known in England above one hundred years.” Bacon.
Damask steelorDamascus steel
steel of the kind originally made at Damascus, famous for its hardness, and its beautiful texture, ornamented with waving lines; especially, that which is inlaid with damaskeening; -- formerly much valued for sword blades, from its great flexibility and tenacity.

sn.def: Pertaining to, or originating at, the city of Damascus; resembling the products or manufactures of Damascus.
Having the color of the damask rose.
sn.q: But let concealment, like a worm i' the bud, Feed on her damask cheek.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Damasked; p. pr. & vb. n. Damasking
entry.def: To decorate in a way peculiar to Damascus or attributed to Damascus; particularly: with flowers and rich designs, as silk; with inlaid lines of gold, etc., or with a peculiar marking or “water,” as metal. See Damaskeen.
entry.q: Mingled metal damasked o'er with gold.
On the soft, downy bank, damasked with flowers.

entry.ety: F. damaschinare. See Damascene v.
entry.def: To decorate, as iron, steel, etc., with a peculiar marking or “water” produced in the process of manufacture, or with designs produced by inlaying or incrusting with another metal, as silver or gold, or by etching, etc., to damask.
entry.q: Damaskeening is is partly mosaic work, partly engraving, and partly carving.

entry.ety: Cf. F. damasquin, adj., It. damaschino, Sp. damasquino. See Damaskeen
entry.def: A sword of Damask steel.
entry.q: No old Toledo blades or damaskins.

entry.ety: F. damassé, fr. damas. See Damask
entry.def: Woven like damask.

def2.def: A damassé fabric, esp. one of linen.

entry.ety: F., fr. damas. See Damask
entry.def: A kind of modified damask or brocade.

entry.ety: Cf. F. dambonite
entry.def: A white, crystalline, sugary substance obtained from an African caoutchouc.
A crystalline variety of fruit sugar obtained from dambonite.

entry.ety: F. dame, LL. domna, fr. L. domina mistress, lady, fem. of dominus master, ruler, lord; akin to domare to tame, subdue. See Tame, and cf. Dam a mother, Dan Danger Dungeon Dominie Don n. Duenna

sn.def: A mistress of a family, who is a lady; a woman in authority; especially, a lady.
sn.q: Then shall these lords do vex me half so much, As that proud dame, the lord protector's wife.

sn.def: The mistress of a family in common life, or the mistress of a common school; as, a dame's school.
sn.q: In the dame's classes at the village school.

sn.def: A woman in general, esp. an elderly woman.
A mother; -- applied to human beings and quadrupeds.

entry.def: A cruciferrous plant (Hesperis matronalis), remarkable for its fragrance, especially toward the close of the day; -- called also rocket and dame's violet.

entry.note: ☞ There are several varieties derived from different plants, esp. from a species of Turnera and from Bigelovia veneta. Wood & Bache.
entry.ety: NL.; of uncertain origin
entry.def: A Mexican drug, used as an aphrodisiac.
A follower of Damian, patriarch of Alexandria in the 6th century, who held heretical opinions on the doctrine of the Holy Trinity.

cs.cd: a tree of the Moluccas (Agathis orientalis syn. Dammara orientalis), yielding dammar.

entry.ety: Jav. & Malay. damar
entry.def: An oleoresin used in making varnishes; dammar gum; dammara resin. It is obtained from certain resin trees indigenous to the East Indies, esp. Shorea robusta and the dammar pine.
A large tree of the order Coniferæ, indigenous to the East Indies and Australasia; -- called also Agathis. There are several species.

entry.note: ☞ Damn is sometimes used interjectionally, imperatively, and intensively.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Damned dămd or dăm"nĕd; p. pr. & vb. n. Damning dăm"ĭng or dăm"nĭng
entry.ety: OE. damnen dampnen (with excrescent p), OF. damner dampner, F. damner, fr. L. damnare damnatum, to condemn, fr. damnum damage, a fine, penalty. Cf. Condemn Damage

sn.def: To condemn; to declare guilty; to doom; to adjudge to punishment; to sentence; to censure.
sn.q: He shall not live; look, with a spot I damn him.

sn.def: To doom to punishment in the future world; to consign to perdition; to curse.
To condemn as bad or displeasing, by open expression, as by denuciation, hissing, hooting, etc.
sn.q: You are not so arrant a critic as to damn them [the works of modern poets] . . . without hearing.
Damn with faint praise, assent with civil leer, And without sneering teach the rest to sneer.

entry.def: To invoke damnation; to curse.
entry.q: While I inwardlydamn.

entry.def: The quality of being damnable; damnableness.

entry.ety: L. damnabilis, fr. damnare: cf. F. damnable. See Damn

sn.def: Liable to damnation; deserving, or for which one deserves, to be damned; of a damning nature.
sn.q: A creature unprepared unmeet for death, And to transport him in the mind he is, Were damnable.

sn.def: Odious; pernicious; detestable.
sn.q: Begin, murderer; . . . leave thy damnable faces.

entry.def: The state or quality of deserving damnation; execrableness.
entry.q: The damnableness of this most execrable impiety.

sn.def: In a manner to incur severe censure, condemnation, or punishment.
Odiously; detestably; excessively.

entry.ety: F. damnation, L. damnatio, fr. damnare. See Damn

sn.def: The state of being damned; condemnation; openly expressed disapprobation.
Condemnation to everlasting punishment in the future state, or the punishment itself.
sn.q: How can ye escape the damnation of hell?
Wickedness is sin, and sin is damnation.

sn.def: A sin deserving of everlasting punishment.
sn.q: The deep damnation of his taking-off.

entry.ety: L. damnatorius, fr. damnator a condemner
entry.def: Dooming to damnation; condemnatory.
entry.q: Damnatoryinvectives.

sn.def: Sentenced to punishment in a future state; condemned; consigned to perdition.
Hateful; detestable; abominable.
sn.q: But, O, what damned minutes tells he o'er Who doats, yet doubts, suspects, yet strongly loves.

entry.ety: L. damnificus; damnum damage, loss + facere to make. See Damn
entry.def: Procuring or causing loss; mischievous; injurious.

entry.ety: LL. damnificatio
entry.def: That which causes damage or loss.

entry.ety: LL. damnificare, fr. L. damnificus: cf. OF. damnefier. See Damnific
entry.def: To cause loss or damage to; to injure; to impair.
entry.q: This work will ask as many more officials to make expurgations and expunctions, that the commonwealth of learning be not damnified.

entry.def: That damns; damnable; as, damning evidence of guilt.
Tendency to bring damnation.

entry.ety: L
entry.def: Harm; detriment, either to character or property.
See Damsel.

entry.ety: Ater the French chemist Damour
entry.def: A kind of Muscovite, or potash mica, containing water.

cs.cd: a damp consisting principally of carbonic acid gas; -- so called from its extinguishing flame and animal life. See Carbonic acid, under Carbonic.
a curtain in a mine gallery to direct air currents and prevent accumulation of gas.
a damp consisting chiefly of light carbureted hydrogen; -- so called from its tendence to explode when mixed with atmospheric air and brought into contact with flame.

entry.ety: Akin to LG., D., & Dan. damp vapor, steam, fog, G. dampf, Icel. dampi, Sw. damb dust, and to MNG. dimpfen to smoke, imp. dampf

sn.def: Moisture; humidity; fog; fogginess; vapor.
sn.q: Night . . . with black air Accompanied, with damps and dreadful gloom.

sn.def: Dejection; depression; cloud of the mind.
sn.q: Even now, while thus I stand blest in thy presence, A secret damp of grief comes o'er my soul.
It must have thrown a damp over your autumn excursion.

sn.def: A gaseous product, formed in coal mines, old wells, pints, etc.
Being in a state between dry and wet; moderately wet; moist; humid.
sn.q: O'erspread with a damp sweat and holy fear.

sn.def: Dejected; depressed; sunk.
sn.q: All these and more came flocking, but with looks Downcast and damp.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Damped; p. pr. & vb. n. Damping
entry.ety: OE. dampen to choke, suffocate. See Damp n.

sn.def: To render damp; to moisten; to make humid, or moderately wet; to dampen; as, to damp cloth.
To put out, as fire; to depress or deject; to deaden; to cloud; to check or restrain, as action or vigor; to make dull; to weaken; to discourage.
sn.q: Todampyour tender hopes.
Usury dulls and damps all industries, improvements, and new inventions, wherein money would be stirring if it were not for this slug.
How many a day has been damped and darkened by an angry word!
The failure of his enterprise damped the spirit of the soldiers.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. dampened dămp"'nd; p. pr. & vb. n. dampening

sn.def: To make damp or moist; to make slightly wet.
To depress; to check; to make dull; to lessen.
sn.q: In a way that considerably dampened our enthusiasm.

entry.def: To become damp; to deaden.
the act or process of making something slightly wet.
That which damps or checks;
A valve or movable plate in the flue or other part of a stove, furnace, etc., used to check or regulate the draught of air.
A contrivance, as in a pianoforte, to deaden vibrations; or, as in other pieces of mechanism, to check some action at a particular time.
entry.q: Nor did Sabrina's presence seem to act as any damper at the modest little festivities.

entry.def: Moderately damp or moist.
To damn.
Moderate humidity; moisture; fogginess; moistness.

entries.entry: Damp" off`. To decay and perish through excessive moisture.

sn.def: Somewhat damp.
Dejected; gloomy; sorrowful.
sn.q: Dispeldampythroughts.

entry.ety: OE. damosel damesel damisel, damsel, fr. OF. damoisele damisele, gentlewoman, F. demoiselle young lady; cf. OF. damoisel young nobleman, F. damoiseau; fr. LL. domicella dominicella, fem., domicellus dominicellus, masc., dim. fr. L. domina dominus. See Dame, and cf. Demoiselle Doncella

sn.def: A young person, either male or female, of noble or gentle extraction; as, Damsel Pepin; Damsel Richard, Prince of Wales.
A young unmarried woman; a girl; a maiden.
sn.q: With her train of damsels she was gone, In shady walks the scorching heat to shun.
Sometimes a troop of damsels glad, . . . Goes by to towered Camelot.

sn.def: An attachment to a millstone spindle for shaking the hopper.

entry.def: small brilliantly colored tropical marine fishes of coral reefs.
a slender nonstinging insect similar to but smaller than the dragonfly but having wings folded when at rest.

entry.ety: OE. damasin the Damascus plum, fr. L. Damascenus. See Damascene
entry.def: A small oval plum of a blue color, the fruit of a variety of the Prunus domestica; -- called also damask plum.

entry.ety: OE. dan danz, OF. danzprop. only nom.), dan, master, fr. L. dominus. See Dame
entry.def: A title of honor equivalent to master, or sir.
entry.q: Old Dan Geoffry, in gently spright The pure wellhead of poetry did dwell.
What time Dan Abraham left the Chaldee land.

entry.ety: Etymol. uncertain
entry.def: A small truck or sledge used in coal mines.
a small natural family of usually tropical butterflies, including the monarch butterflies.

entry.ety: From the mythical Danaides, who were condemned to fill with water a vessel full of holes
entry.def: A water wheel having a vertical axis, and an inner and outer tapering shell, between which are vanes or floats attached usually to both shells, but sometimes only to one.

entry.ety: Named after J. Freeman Dana
entry.def: A cobaltiferous variety of arsenopyrite.

entry.ety: Named after James Dwight Dana
entry.def: A mineral occuring in octahedral crystals, also massive, of a reddish color. It is a silicate of iron, zinc manganese, and glucinum, containing sulphur.
the type genus of the Danaidae, including the monarch butterfly, Danaus plexippus.
A borosilicate of lime, first found at Danbury, Conn. It is near the topaz in form.

cs.mcol: To dance on a ropeorTo dance on nothing
cs.cd: to be hanged.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Danced; p. pr. & vb. n. Dancing
entry.ety: F. danser, fr. OHG. dansōn to draw; akin to dinsan to draw, Goth. apinsan, and prob. from the same root (meaning to stretch) as E. thin. See Thin

sn.def: To move with measured steps, or to a musical accompaniment; to go through, either alone or in company with others, with a regulated succession of movements, (commonly) to the sound of music; to trip or leap rhythmically.
sn.q: Jack shall pipe and Gill shall dance.
Good shepherd, what fair swain is this Which dances with your daughter?

sn.def: To move nimbly or merrily; to express pleasure by motion; to caper; to frisk; to skip about.
sn.q: Then, 'tis time to dance off.
More dances my rapt heart Than when I first my wedded mistress saw.
Shadows in the glassy waters dance.
Where rivulets dance their wayward round.

cs.cd: to come and go obsequiously; to be or remain in waiting, at the beck and call of another, with a view to please or gain favor.

entry.def: To cause to dance, or move nimbly or merrily about, or up and down; to dandle.
entry.q: To dance our ringlets to the whistling wind.
Thy grandsire loved thee well; Many a time he danced thee on his knee.
A man of his place, and so near our favor, To dance attendance on their lordships' pleasure.

entry.note: ☞ The word dance was used ironically, by the older writers, of many proceedings besides dancing.
entry.cs: Dance of Death Art an allegorical representation of the power of death over all, -- the old, the young, the high, and the low, being led by a dancing skeleton. Morris dance. See Morris. To lead one a dance to cause one to go through a series of movements or experiences as if guided by a partner in a dance not understood.
entry.ety: F. danse, of German origin. See Dance v. i.

sn.def: The leaping, tripping, or measured stepping of one who dances; an amusement, in which the movements of the persons are regulated by art, in figures and in accord with music.
A tune by which dancing is regulated, as the minuet, the waltz, the cotillon, etc.
sn.q: Of remedies of love she knew parchance For of that art she couth the olde dance.

cs.cd: beams of the northern lights when they rise and fall alternately without any considerable change of length. See Aurora borealis, under Aurora.

entry.def: One who dances or who practices dancing.
A female dancer.

entry.ety: Cf. F. danché dancetté, dent tooth
entry.def: Deeply indented; having large teeth; thus, a fess dancetté has only three teeth in the whole width of the escutcheon.

cs.cd: one of the women in the East Indies whose profession is to dance in the temples, or for the amusement of spectators. There are various classes of dancing girls.
a teacher of dancing.
a school or place where dancing is taught.

entry.def: from Dance.
Same as Dancetté.

entry.ety: F. dent de lion lion's tooth, fr. L. dens tooth + leo lion. See Tooth n., and Lion
entry.def: A well-known plant of the genus Taraxacum Taraxacum officinale, formerly called Taraxacum Dens-leonis and Leontodos Taraxacum) bearing large, yellow, compound flowers, and deeply notched leaves.

entry.ety: Corrupted from dandruff

sn.def: Dandruff or scurf on the head.
Anger or vexation; rage.

entry.ety: See Dandle
entry.def: To wander about; to saunter; to talk incoherently.

entry.ety: Hind. ḍānḍi, fr. ḍānḍ an oar
entry.def: A boatman; an oarsman.
One of a breed of small terriers; -- called also Dandie Dinmont.

sn.def: In Scott's “Guy Mannering”, a Border farmer of eccentric but fine character, who owns two terriers claimed to be the progenitors of the Dandie Dinmont terriers.
One of a breed of terriers with short legs, long body, and rough coat, originating in the country about the English and Scotch border.

entry.def: Made up like a dandy; having the dress or manners of a dandy; buckish.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Dandified; p. pr. & vb. n. Dandifying
entry.ety: Dandy + -fy
entry.def: To cause to resemble a dandy; to make dandyish.

entry.ety: Dandy + brat child

sn.def: A little fellow; -- in sport or contempt.
sn.q: Adandiprathop-thumb.

sn.def: A small coin.
sn.q: Henry VII. stamped a small coin called dandiprats.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Dandled; p. pr. & vb. n. Dandling
entry.ety: Cf. G. dändeln to trifly, dandle, OD. & Prov. G. danten, G. tand trifly, prattle; Scot. dandill dander, to go about idly, to trifly

sn.def: To move up and down on one's knee or in one's arms, in affectionate play, as an infant.
sn.q: Ye shall be dandled . . . upon her knees.

sn.def: To treat with fondness, as if a child; to fondle; to toy with; to pet.
sn.q: They have put me in a silk gown and gaudy fool's cap; I as ashamed to be dandled thus.
The book, thus dandled into popularity by bishops and good ladies, contained many pieces of nursery eloquence.

sn.def: To play with; to put off or delay by trifles; to wheedle.
sn.q: Captains do so dandle their doings, and dally in the service, as it they would not have the enemy subdued.

entry.def: One who dandles or fondles.
See Dandruff.

entry.ety: Prob. from W. toncrust, peel, skin + AS. drōf dirty, draffy, or W. drwg bad: cf. AS. tan a letter, an eruption. √240
entry.def: A scurf which forms on the head, and comes off in small scales or particles.

entries.entry:
Dan"dy
Dandy brush a yard whalebone brush. Dandy fever. See Dengue. Dandy line a kind of fishing line to which are attached several crosspieces of whalebone which carry a hook at each end. Dandy roller a roller sieve used in machines for making paper, to press out water from the pulp, and set the paper.
dăn"d� n.; pl.Dandies dăn"dĭz. Cf. F. dandin, ninny, silly fellow, dandiner to waddle, to play the fool; prob. allied to E. dandle. Senses 2 & 3 are of uncertain etymology
One who affects special finery or gives undue attention to dress; a fop; a coxcomb.
Naut
A sloop or cutter with a jigger on which a lugsail is set.
A small sail carried at or near the stern of small boats; -- called also jigger, and mizzen.
A dandy roller. See below.

entry.ety: See Dandy
entry.def: A bantam fowl.
Like a dandy.
The manners and dress of a dandy; foppishness.
To make, or to act, like a dandy; to dandify.

entry.ety: Dandy + -ling
entry.def: A little or insignificant dandy; a contemptible fop.

entry.cs: Great Dane. Zoöl See Danish dog, under Danish.
entry.ety: LL. Dani: cf. AS. Dene
entry.def: A native, or a naturalized inhabitant, of Denmark.

entry.ety: AS. danegeld. See Dane, and Geld n.
entry.def: An annual tax formerly laid on the English nation to buy off the ravages of Danish invaders, or to maintain forces to oppose them. It afterward became a permanent tax, raised by an assessment, at first of one shilling, afterward of two shillings, upon every hide of land throughout the realm.

A fetid European species of elder (Sambucus Ebulus); dwarf elder; wallwort; elderwort; -- called also Daneweed Dane's weed, and Dane's-blood. Said to grow on spots where battles were fought against the Danes
imp. of Ding.

entry.ety: Cf. Ding
entry.def: To dash.
entry.q: Till she, o'ercome with anguish, shame, and rage,Danged down to hell her loathsome carriage.

cs.cd: in one's power; liable to a penalty to be inflicted by him. Obs This sense is retained in the proverb, “Out of debt out of danger.”
cs.q: Those rich man in whose debt and danger they be not.
cs.cd: to cause danger.

entry.usage: Danger Peril Hazard Risk Jeopardy. Danger is the generic term, and implies some contingent evil in prospect. Peril is instant or impending danger; as, in peril of one's life. Hazard arises from something fortuitous or beyond our control; as, the hazard of the seas. Risk is doubtful or uncertain danger, often incurred voluntarily; as, to risk an engagement. Jeopardy is extreme danger. Danger of a contagious disease; the perils of shipwreck; the hazards of speculation; the risk of daring enterprises; a life brought into jeopardy.
entry.ety: OE. danger daunger, power, arrogance, refusal, difficulty, fr. OF. dagier dongierwith same meaning), F. danger danger, fr. an assumed LL. dominiarium power, authority, from L. dominium power, property. See Dungeon Domain Dame

sn.def: Authority; jurisdiction; control.
sn.q: In dangerhad he . . . the young girls.

entry.sn: Power to harm; subjection or liability to penalty. Obs See In one's danger, below.You stand within his danger, do you not? Covetousness of gains hath brought [them] in dangerof this statute.

sn.def: Exposure to injury, loss, pain, or other evil; peril; risk; insecurity.
Difficulty; sparingness.
Coyness; disdainful behavior.

entry.def: To endanger.
Full of danger; dangerous.
Free from danger.

entry.ety: OE., haughty, difficult, dangerous, fr. OF. dangereus, F. dangereux. See Danger

sn.def: Attended or beset with danger; full of risk; perilous; hazardous; unsafe.
sn.q: Our troops set forth to-morrow; stay with us; The ways are dangerous.
It is dangerous to assert a negative.

sn.def: Causing danger; ready to do harm or injury.
sn.q: If they incline to think you dangerous To less than gods.

sn.def: In a condition of danger, as from illness; threatened with death.
Hard to suit; difficult to please.
sn.q: My wages ben full strait, and eke full small; My lord to me is hard and dangerous.

sn.def: Reserved; not affable.
sn.q: Of his speechdangerous.

cs.cd: to hang upon importunately; to court the favor of; to beset.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Dangled; p. pr. & vb. n. Dangling
entry.ety: Akin to Dan. dangle, dial. Sw. dangla, Dan. dingle, Sw. dingla, Icel. dingla; perh. from E. ding
entry.def: To hang loosely, or with a swinging or jerking motion.
entry.q: He'd rather on a gibbet dangle Than miss his dear delight, to wrangle.
From her lifted handDangled a length of ribbon.
The Presbyterians, and other fanatics that dangle after them, are well inclined to pull down the present establishment.

entry.def: To cause to dangle; to swing, as something suspended loosely; as, to dangle the feet.
entry.q: And the bridegroom stood dangling his bonnet and plume.

entry.def: A dark blue, edible berry with a white bloom, and its shrub (Gaylussacia frondosa) closely allied to the common huckleberry. The bush is also called blue tangle, and is found from New England to Kentucky, and southward.
One who dangles about or after others, especially after women; a trifler.
entry.q: Danglersat toilets.

entry.def: A Hebrew prophet distinguished for sagacity and ripeness of judgment in youth; hence, a sagacious and upright judge.
entry.q: A Daniel come to judgment.

cs.cd: one of a large and powerful breed of dogs reared in Denmark; -- called also great Dane. See Illustration in Appendix.

entry.ety: See Dane
entry.def: Belonging to the Danes, or to their language or country.

sn.def: A descendant of Dan; an Israelite of the tribe of Dan.

sn.ety: So called in remembrance of the prophecy in Gen. xlix. 17, “Dan shall be a serpent by the way,” etc
sn.def: One of a secret association of Mormons, bound by an oath to obey the heads of the church in all things.

entry.ety: Cf. dial, Sw. dank a moist place in a field, Icel. dökk pit, pool; possibly akin to E. damp or to daggle dew
entry.def: Damp; moist; humid; wet.
entry.q: Now that the fields are dank and ways are mire.
Cheerless watches on the cold, dank ground.

entry.def: Moisture; humidity; water.
A small silver coin current in Persia.
Somewhat dank.
entry.q: In a dark and dankish vault at home.

cs.cd: an ancient Danish order of knighthood.

entry.def: The ancient battle standard of Denmark, bearing figures of cross and crown.

entry.ety: F., fr. danser to dance
entry.def: A professional female dancer; a woman who dances at a public exhibition as in a ballet.

entry.ety: Dan
entry.def: Danish.
A Dane.
entry.q: Inquire me first what Danskers are in Paris.

entry.def: Relating to, emanating from or resembling, the poet Dante or his writings.

entry.ety: Cf. It. Dantesco
entry.def: Dantelike; Dantean.
Pertaining to, or bordering on, the river Danube.

entry.ety: Cf. Dip
entry.def: To drop the bait gently on the surface of the water.
entry.q: To catch a club by dapping with a grasshoper.

entry.ety: L. dapaticus, fr. daps feast
entry.def: Sumptuous in cheer.

entry.ety: L., a laurel tree, from Gr. da`fnh

sn.def: A genus of diminutive Shrubs, mostly evergreen, and with fragrant blossoms.
A nymph of Diana, fabled to have been changed into a laurel tree.

entry.def: A colorless crystalline substance, C9H6O4, extracted from daphnin.

entry.ety: NL
entry.def: A genus of the genus Daphnia.

entry.ety: Cf. F. daphnine
entry.def: A dark green bitter resin extracted from the mezereon (Daphne mezereum) and regarded as the essential principle of the plant.
A white, crystalline, bitter substance, regarded as a glucoside, and extracted from Daphne mezereum and Daphne alpina.

entry.ety: Gr. da`fnh the laurel + -mancy
entry.def: Divination by means of the laurel.

entry.ety: L., daps a feast + ferre to bear
entry.def: One who brings meat to the table; hence, in some countries, the official title of the grand master or steward of the king's or a nobleman's household.

entry.ety: OE. daper; prob. fr. D. dapper brave, valiant; akin to G. tapfer brave, OHG. taphar heavy, weighty, OSlav. dobrŭ good, Russ. dobrui. Cf. Deft
entry.def: Little and active; spruce; trim; smart; neat in dress or appearance; lively.
entry.q: He wondered how so many provinces could be held in subjection by such a dapper little man.
The dapper ditties that I wont devise.
Sharp-nosed, dapper steam yachts.

entry.def: A dwarf; a dandiprat.

entry.ety: Cf. Icel. depill a spot, a dot, a dog with spots over the eyes, dapi a pool, and E. dimple
entry.def: One of the spots on a dappled animal.
entry.q: He has . . . as many eyes on his body as my gray mare hath dapples.

entry.note: ☞ The word is used in composition to denote that some color is variegated or marked with spots; as, dapple-bay; dapple-gray.
entry.def: Marked with spots of different shades of color; spotted; variegated; as, a dapple horse.
entry.q: Some dapple mists still floated along the peaks.
His steed was all dapple-gray.
O, swiftly can speed my dapple-gray steed.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Dappled; p. pr. & vb. n. Dappling
entry.def: To variegate with spots; to spot.
entry.q: The gentle day, . . . Dapples the drowsy east with spots of gray.
The dappled pink and blushing rose.

entry.note: ☞ In “The Steel Glass” by Gascoigne, printed in 1576, occurs the line “To binde such babes in father Derbies bands.”
entry.def: Manacles; handcuffs.
entry.q: Jem Clink will fetch you the darbies.

entry.def: A plasterer's float, having two handles; -- used in smoothing ceilings, etc.
One of the Plymouth Brethren, or of a sect among them; -- so called from John N. Darby, one of the leaders of the Brethren.

sn.def: the strait between the Aegean and the Sea of Marmara that separates European from Asian Turkey.
the unsuccessful campaign in World War I (1915) by the English and French to open a passage for aid to Russia; defeated by the Turks.

entry.ety: From L. Dardania, poetic name of Troy
entry.def: Trojan.

entry.note: ☞ The present tense, I dare, is really an old past tense, so that the third person is he dare, but the form he dares is now often used, and will probably displace the obsolescent he dare, through grammatically as incorrect as he shalls or he cans.
☞ Formerly durst was also used as the present. Sometimes the old form dare is found for durst or dared.
entry.vmorph: imp. Durst dûrst or Dared dârd; p. p. Dared; p. pr. & vb. n. Daring
entry.ety:
OE. I dar dear, I dare, imp. dorste durste, AS. ic dear I dare, imp. dorste. inf. durran; akin to OS. gidar gidorsta gidurran, OHG. tar torsta turran, Goth. gadar gadaúrsta, Gr. tharsei^n
tharrei^n , to be bold, tharsy`s bold, Skr. Dhrsh to be bold. √70
entry.def: To have adequate or sufficient courage for any purpose; to be bold or venturesome; not to be afraid; to venture.
entry.q: I dare do all that may become a man; Who dares do more is none.
Why then did not the ministers use their new law? Bacause they durst not, because they could not.
Who dared to sully her sweet love with suspicion.
The tie of party was stronger than the tie of blood, because a partisan was more ready to dare without asking why.
The pore dar plede (the poor man dare plead).
You know one dare not discover you.
The fellow dares not deceive me.
Here boldly spread thy hands, no venom'd weedDares blister them, no slimy snail dare creep.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Dared; p. pr. & vb. n. Daring

sn.def: To have courage for; to attempt courageously; to venture to do or to undertake.
sn.q: What high concentration of steady feeling makes men dare every thing and do anything?
To wrest it from barbarism, to dare its solitudes.

sn.def: To challenge; to provoke; to defy.
sn.q: Time, I dare thee to discover Such a youth and such a lover.

sn.def: The quality of daring; venturesomeness; boldness; dash.
sn.q: It lends a luster . . . A large dare to our great enterprise.

sn.def: Defiance; challenge.
sn.q: Childish, unworthy dares Are not enought to part our powers.
Sextus Pompeius Hath given the dare to Cæsar.

entry.ety: OE. darien, to lie hidden, be timid
entry.def: To lurk; to lie hid.

cs.cd: to catch them by producing terror through to use of mirrors, scarlet cloth, a hawk, etc., so that they lie still till a net is thrown over them.

entry.def: To terrify; to daunt.
entry.q: For I have done those follies, those mad mischiefs, Would dare a woman.

entry.ety: See Dace
entry.def: A small fish; the dace.
A reckless fellow. Also used adjectively; as, dare-devil excitement.
entry.q: A humorous dare-devilthe very man To suit my prpose.

entries.entry: Dare"-dev`il*try n; pl.Dare-deviltries. Reckless mischief; the action of a dare-devil.

entry.def: Full of daring or of defiance; adventurous.
One who dares or defies.

entry.ety: Scot., contr. fr. day work
entry.def: A day's work; also, a fixed amount of work, whether more or less than that of a day.

entry.ety: Gr. dareiko`s, of Persian origin

sd.def: A gold coin of ancient Persia, weighing usually a little more than 128 grains, and bearing on one side the figure of an archer.
A silver coin of about 86 grains, having the figure of an archer, and hence, in modern times, called a daric.

sn.def: Any very pure gold coin.

entry.def: Boldness; fearlessness; adventurousness; also, a daring act.
Bold; fearless; adventurous; as, daring spirits.

entry.ety: F

sn.def: A crustade.
A shell or cup of pastry filled with custard, whipped cream, crushed macaroons, etc.

entry.note: ☞ Dark is sometimes used to qualify another adjective; as, dark blue, dark green, and sometimes it forms the first part of a compound; as, dark-haired, dark-eyed, dark-colored, dark-seated, dark-working.
entry.cs:
A dark horse in racing or politics, a horse or a candidate whose chances of success are not known, and whose capabilities have not been made the subject of general comment or of wagers. Colloq
Dark house Dark room
a house or room in which madmen were confined. Obs Shak. Dark lantern. See Lantern.The Dark Ages a period of stagnation and obscurity in literature and art, lasting, according to Hallam, nearly 1000 years, from about 500 to about 1500 A. D.. See Middle Ages, under Middle. The Dark and Bloody Ground a phrase applied to the State of Kentucky, and said to be the significance of its name, in allusion to the frequent wars that were waged there between Indians. The dark day a day (May 19, 1780) when a remarkable and unexplained darkness extended over all New England. To keep dark to reveal nothing. Low
entry.ety: OE. dark derk deork, AS. dearc deorc; cf. Gael. & Ir. dorch dorcha, dark, black, dusky

sn.def: Destitute, or partially destitute, of light; not receiving, reflecting, or radiating light; wholly or partially black, or of some deep shade of color; not light-colored; as, a dark room; a dark day; dark cloth; dark paint; a dark complexion.
sn.q: O dark dark dark, amid the blaze of noon, Irrecoverably dark, total eclipse Without all hope of day!
In the dark and silent grave.

sn.def: Not clear to the understanding; not easily seen through; obscure; mysterious; hidden.
sn.q: The dark problems of existence.
What may seem dark at the first, will afterward be found more plain.
What's your dark meaning, mouse, of this light word?

sn.def: Destitute of knowledge and culture; in moral or intellectual darkness; unrefined; ignorant.
sn.q: The age wherein he lived was dark, but he Could not want light who taught the world to see.
The tenth century used to be reckoned by mediæval historians as the darkest part of this intellectual night.

sn.def: Evincing black or foul traits of character; vile; wicked; atrocious; as, a dark villain; a dark deed.
sn.q: Left him at large to his own dark designs.

sn.def: Foreboding evil; gloomy; jealous; suspicious.
sn.q: More dark and dark our woes.
A deep melancholy took possesion of him, and gave a dark tinge to all his views of human nature.
There is, in every true woman-s heart, a spark of heavenly fire, which beams and blazes in the dark hour of adversity.

sn.def: Deprived of sight; blind.
sn.q: He was, I think, at this time quite dark, and so had been for some years.

sn.def: Absence of light; darkness; obscurity; a place where there is little or no light.
sn.q: Here stood he in the dark, his sharp sword out.

sn.def: The condition of ignorance; gloom; secrecy.
sn.q: Look, what you do, you do it still i' th' dark.
Till we perceive by our own understandings, we are as much in the dark, and as void of knowledge, as before.

sn.def: A dark shade or dark passage in a painting, engraving, or the like; as, the light and darks are well contrasted.
sn.q: The lights may serve for a repose to the darks, and the darks to the lights.

entry.def: To darken; to obscure.
of a color similar to that of a clear unclouded sky.
of a color similar to that of wood or earth.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Darkened -'nd; p. pr. & vb. n. Darkening -n*ĭng
entry.ety: AS. deorcian. See Dark a.

sn.def: To make dark or black; to deprive of light; to obscure; as, a darkened room.
sn.q: They [locusts] covered the face of the whole earth, so that the land was darkened.
So spake the Sovran Voice; and clouds began To darken all the hill.

sn.def: To render dim; to deprive of vision.
sn.q: Let their eyes be darkened, that they may not see.

sn.def: To cloud, obscure, or perplex; to render less clear or intelligible.
sn.q: Such was his wisdom that his confidence did seldom darkenhis foresight.
Who is this that darkeneth counsel by words without knowledge?

sn.def: To cast a gloom upon.
sn.q: With these forced thoughts, I prithee, darken not The mirth of the feast.

sn.def: To make foul; to sully; to tarnish.
sn.q: I must not think there are Evils enough to darken all his goodness.

entry.def: To grow or darker.
overtaken by night or darkness.
One who, or that which, darkens.
Twilight; gloaming.
Full of darkness.
similar to the color of fresh grass.
same as brunet; as, a dark-haired beauty.
a black person; an African-American; -- an older term now considered offensive.
Somewhat dark; dusky.

entry.ety: Freq. of dark
entry.def: To grow dark; to show indistinctly.

entry.ety: Dark + the adverbial suffix -ling
entry.def: In the dark.
entry.q: So, out went the candle, and we were left darkling.
As the wakeful bird Sings darkling.

sn.def: Becoming dark or gloomy; frowing.
sn.q: His honest brows darkling as he looked towards me.

sn.def: Dark; gloomy.
sn.q: Thedarklingprecipice.

sn.def: With imperfect light, clearness, or knowledge; obscurely; dimly; blindly; uncertainly.
sn.q: What fame to future times conveys but darkly down.
so softly dark and darkly pure.

sn.def: With a dark, gloomy, cruel, or menacing look.
sn.q: Looking darkly at the clerguman.

entry.cs: Prince of darkness the Devil; Satan. “In the power of the Prince of darkness.” Locke.
entry.usage: Darkness arises from a total, and dimness from a partial, want of light. A thing is obscure when so overclouded or covered as not to be easily perceived. As tha shade or obscurity increases, it deepens into gloom. What is dark is hidden from view; what is obscure is difficult to perceive or penetrate; the eye becomes dim with age; an impending storm fills the atmosphere with gloom. When taken figuratively, these words have a like use; as, the darkness of ignorance; dimness of discernment; obscurity of reasoning; gloom of superstition.

sn.def: The absence of light; blackness; obscurity; gloom.
sn.q: And darkness was upon the face of the deep.

sn.def: A state of privacy; secrecy.
sn.q: What I tell you in darkness, that speak ye in light.

sn.def: A state of ignorance or error, especially on moral or religious subjects; hence, wickedness; impurity.
sn.q: Men loved darkness rather than light, because their deeds were evil.
Pursue these sons of darkness: drive them out From all heaven's bounds.

sn.def: Want of clearness or perspicuity; obscurity; as, the darkness of a subject, or of a discussion.
A state of distress or trouble.
sn.q: A day of clouds and of thick darkness.

entry.sn: same as colored.Narrower terms: black (vs. white colored, coloured.

sn.def: having a dark color; -- of skin color.

entry.def: Dark; gloomy; obscure; shaded; cheerless.
entry.q: He brought him through a darksome narrow pass To a broad gate, all built of beaten gold.

entry.def: a negro; an African-American; -- an older term now considered offensive.

entry.ety: OE. derling deorling, AS. deórling; deóre dear + -ling. See Dear, and -ling
entry.def: One dearly beloved; a favorite.
entry.q: And can do naught but wail her darling's loss.

entry.def: Dearly beloved; regarded with especial kindness and tenderness; favorite.
entry.q: Somedarlingscience.
Darlingsin.

entry.ety: NL. Named after Dr. William Darlington, a botanist of West Chester, Penn
entry.def: A genus of California pitcher plants consisting of a single species. The long tubular leaves are hooded at the top, and frequently contain many insects drowned in the secretion of the leaves.
a genus consisting of one species.

entry.cs: Darning last. See under Last. Darning needle. A long, strong needle for mending holes or rents, especially in stockings. Zoöl Any species of dragon fly, having a long, cylindrical body, resembling a needle. These flies are harmless and without stings. In this sense, usually written with a hyphen Called also devil's darning-needle.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Darned därnd; p. pr. & vb. n. Darning
entry.ety: OE. derne, prob. of Celtic origin; cf. W. darnio to piece, break in pieces, W. & Arm. to E. tear. Cf. Tear v. t.
entry.def: To mend as a rent or hole, with interlacing stitches of yarn or thread by means of a needle; to sew together with yarn or thread.
entry.q: He spent every day ten hours in his closet, in darning his stockings.

entry.def: A place mended by darning.
A colloquial euphemism for Damn.
an intensifying expletive; a eupehmism for damned; as, for no darned reason at all.
entry.syn: blasted, blessed, damn, damned, deuced, goddam, goddamn, goddamned, gosh-darned.

entry.note: ☞ Under darnel our early herbalists comprehended all kinds of cornfield weeds.
entry.ety: OE. darnel dernel, of uncertain origin; cf. dial. F. darnelle, Sw. dår-repe; perh. named from a supposed intoxicating quality of the plant, and akin to Sw. dåra to infatuate, OD. door foolish, G. thor fool, and Ee. dizzy
entry.def: Any grass of the genus Lolium, esp. the Lolium temulentumbearded darnel), the grains of which have been reputed poisonous. Other species, as Lolium perennerye grass or ray grass), and its variety Lolium ItalicumItalian rye grass), are highly esteemed for pasture and for making hay.
One who mends by darning.
Same as Dornick.
The Egyptian sycamore (Ficus Sycamorus). See Sycamore.
The European black tern.

entry.ety: OF. deraisnier to explain, defend, to maintain in legal action by proof and reasonings, LL. derationare; de- + rationare to discourse, contend in law, fr. L. ratio reason, in LL., legal cause. Cf. Arraign, and see Reason

sn.def: To make ready to fight; to array.
sn.q: Darrain your battle, for they are at hand.

sn.def: To fight out; to contest; to decide by combat.
sn.q: Todarrainthe battle.

entry.ety: OF. darrein darrain, fr. an assumed LL. deretranus; L. de + retro back, backward
entry.def: Last; as, darrein continuance, the last continuance.

cs.cd: a sac connected with the reproductive organs of land snails, which contains a dart, or arrowlike structure.

entry.ety: OF. dart, of German origin; cf. OHG. tart javelin, dart, AS. darað daroð, Sw. dart dagger, Icel. darraðr dart

sn.def: A pointed missile weapon, intended to be thrown by the hand; a short lance; a javelin; hence, any sharp-pointed missile weapon, as an arrow.
sn.q: And he [Joab] took three darts in his hand, and thrust them through the heart of Absalom.

sn.def: Anything resembling a dart; anything that pierces or wounds like a dart.
sn.q: The artful inquiry, whose venomed dart Scarce wounds the hearing while it stabs the heart.

sn.def: A spear set as a prize in running.
A fish; the dace. See Dace.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Darted; p. pr. & vb. n. Darting

sn.def: To throw with a sudden effort or thrust, as a dart or other missile weapon; to hurl or launch.
To throw suddenly or rapidly; to send forth; to emit; to shoot; as, the sun darts forth his beams.
sn.q: Or what ill eyes malignant glances dart?

sn.def: To fly or pass swiftly, as a dart.
To start and run with velocity; to shoot rapidly along; as, the deer darted from the thicket.

entry.ety: F. dartre eruption, dandruff. √240
entry.def: A kind of scab or ulceration on the skin of lambs.
a circular board of wood or cork used as the target in the game of darts. It may have any of several patterns on it, such as concentric circles, or a central circle with rays.

sn.def: One who darts, or who throw darts; that which darts.
The snakebird, a water bird of the genus Plotus; -- so called because it darts out its long, snakelike neck at its prey. See Snakebird.
A small fresh-water etheostomoid fish. The group includes numerous genera and species, all of them American. See Etheostomoid.

entry.def: Like a dart; rapidly.
To pierce or shoot through; to dart repeatedly: -- frequentative of dart.
entry.q: My star that dartles the red and the blue.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to the dartos.

entry.ety: Dartos + -oid
entry.def: Like the dartos; dartoic; as, dartoid tissue.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. � flayed
entry.def: A thin layer of peculiar contractile tissue directly beneath the skin of the scrotum.

cs.cd: A morbid condition of the system predisposing to the development of certain skin diseases, such as eczema, psoriasis, and pityriasis. Also called rheumic diathesis, and herpetism.

entry.ety: F. dartreux. See Dartars
