entry.def: Relating to, or partaking of the nature of, the disease called tetter; herpetic.

entry.note: ☞ This theory was put forth by Darwin in 1859 in a work entitled “The Origin of species by Means of Natural Selection.” The author argues that, in the struggle for existence, those plants and creatures best fitted to the requirements of the situation in which they are placed are the ones that will live; in other words, that Nature selects those which are to survive. This is the theory of natural selection or the survival of the fittest. He also argues that natural selection is capable of modifying and producing organisms fit for their circumstances. See Development theory, under Development.
entry.ety: From the name of Charles Darwin, an English scientist
entry.def: Pertaining to Darwin; as, the Darwinian theory, a theory of the manner and cause of the supposed development of living things from certain original forms or elements.
An advocate of Darwinism.
Darwinism.
The theory or doctrines put forth by Darwin. See above.
See Daze.

entry.ety: OE. dasewen daswen; cf. AS. dysegian to be foolish
entry.def: To become dim-sighted; to become dazed or dazzled.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Dashed; p. pr. & vb. n. Dashing
entry.ety: Of. Scand. origin; cf. Dan daske to beat, strike, Sw. & Icel. daska, Dan. & Sw. dask blow

sn.def: To throw with violence or haste; to cause to strike violently or hastily; -- often used with against.
sn.q: If you dash a stone against a stone in the botton of the water, it maketh a sound.

sn.def: To break, as by throwing or by collision; to shatter; to crust; to frustrate; to ruin.
sn.q: Thou shalt dash them in pieces like a potter's vessel.
A brave vessel, . . . Dashed all to pieces.
To perplex and dash Maturest counsels.

sn.def: To put to shame; to confound; to confuse; to abash; to depress.
sn.q: Dash the proud gamester in his gilded car.

sn.def: To throw in or on in a rapid, careless manner; to mix, reduce, or adulterate, by throwing in something of an inferior quality; to overspread partially; to bespatter; to touch here and there; as, to dash wine with water; to dash paint upon a picture.
sn.q: I take care to dash the character with such particular circumstance as may prevent ill-natured applications.
The very source and fount of day Is dashed with wandering isles of night.

sn.def: To form or sketch rapidly or carelessly; to execute rapidly, or with careless haste; -- with off; as, to dash off a review or sermon.
To erase by a stroke; to strike out; knock out; -- with out; as, to dash out a word.

entry.def: To rush with violence; to move impetuously; to strike violently; as, the waves dash upon rocks.
entry.q: Hedashed through thick and thin.
On each hand the gushing waters play, And down the rough cascade all dashing fall.

sn.def: Violent striking together of two bodies; collision; crash.
A sudden check; abashment; frustration; ruin; as, his hopes received a dash .
A slight admixture, infusion, or adulteration; a partial overspreading; as, wine with a dash of water; red with a dash of purple.
sn.q: Innocence when it has in it a dash of folly.

sn.def: A rapid movement, esp. one of short duration; a quick stroke or blow; a sudden onset or rush; as, a bold dash at the enemy; a dash of rain.
sn.q: She takes upon her bravely at first dash.

sn.def: Energy in style or action; animation; spirit.
A vain show; a blustering parade; a flourish; as, to make or cut a great dash .

A mark or line [--], in writing or printing, denoting a sudden break, stop, or transition in a sentence, or an abrupt change in its construction, a long or significant pause, or an unexpected or epigrammatic turn of sentiment. Dashes are also sometimes used instead of marks or parenthesis.

sd.def: The sign of staccato, a small mark [�] denoting that the note over which it is placed is to be performed in a short, distinct manner.
The line drawn through a figure in the thorough bass, as a direction to raise the interval a semitone.

sn.def: A short, spirited effort or trial of speed upon a race course; -- used in horse racing, when a single trial constitutes the race.
A board placed on the fore part of a carriage, sleigh, or other vehicle, to intercept water, mud, or snow, thrown up by the heels of the horses; -- in England commonly called splashboard.

sd.def: The float of a paddle wheel.
A screen at the bow af a steam launch to keep off the spray; -- called also sprayboard.

sn.def: an instrument panel beneath the front window of a motor vehicle (such as an automobile or truck), containing indicating gauges and dials, such as the speedometer and fuel gauges, and sometimes certain control knobs or other devices.

A tropical aroid (of the genus Caladium, syn. Colocasia) having an edible farinaceous root. It is related to the taro and to the tanier, but is much superior to it in quality and is as easily cooked as the potato. It is a staple food plant of the tropics, being prepared like potatoes, and has been introduced into the Southern United States.
a herb of the Pacific islands grown throughout the tropics for its edible root and in temperate areas as an ornamental for its large glossy leaves.
sn.syn: taro, taro plant, dalo, Colocasia esculenta.

sn.def: the edible starchy tuberous root of taro plants.
a tropical starchy tuberous root.
That which dashes or agitates; as, the dasher of a churn.
A dashboard or splashboard.
One who makes an ostentatious parade.

entry.def: Bold; spirited; showy.
entry.q: The dashing and daring spirit is preferable to the listless.

entry.def: Conspicuously; showily.
entry.q: A dashingly dressed gentleman.

entry.def: The character of making ostentatious or blustering parade or show.
entry.q: He must fight a duel before his claim to . . . dashism can be universally allowed.

entry.note: ☞ It consists of a chamber, containing air or a liquid, in which a piston (a), attached to the weight, falls freely until it enters a space (as below the openings, b) from which the air or liquid can escape but slowly (as through cock c), when its fall is gradually checked.

☞ It consists of a chamber, containing air or a liquid, in which a piston (a), attached to the weight, falls freely until it enters a space (as below the openings, b) from which the air or liquid can escape but slowly (as through cock c), when its fall is gradually checked.
A cataract of an engine is sometimes called a dashpot.
entry.def: a mechanical damping device containing a piston that moves in a fluid-filled chamber to serve as a pneumatic or hydraulic cushion for a falling weight, as in the valve gear of a steam engine, to prevent shock.

entry.ety: From Dash
entry.def: Calculated to arrest attention; ostentatiously fashionable; showy.

entry.ety: Prob. from Icel. dæstr exhausted. breathless, p. p. of dæsa to groan, lose one's breath; cf. dasask to become exhausted, and E. daze
entry.def: One who meanly shrinks from danger; an arrant coward; a poltroon.
entry.q: You are all recreants and dashtards, and delight to live in slavery to the nobility.

entry.def: Meanly shrinking from danger; cowardly; dastardly.
entry.q: Theirdastardsouls.

entry.def: To dastardize.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Dastardized; p. pr. & vb. n. Dastardizing
entry.def: To make cowardly; to intimidate; to dispirit; as, to dastardize my courage.
The quality of being dastardly; cowardice; base fear.
Meanly timid; cowardly; base; as, a dastardly outrage.
Dastardliness.
Base timidity; cowardliness.
See Dasewe

entry.ety: Gr. dasy`s rough, thick + -meter
entry.def: An instrument for testing the density of gases, consisting of a thin glass globe, which is weighed in the gas or gases, and then in an atmosphere of known density.
Dasypædic.

entry.ety: NL., from Gr. dasy`s hairy, shaggy + � �, a child

Pertaining to the Dasypædes; ptilopædic.
a natural family including the agoutis and pacas.
the type genus of the Dasypodidae.
a natural family including the dasyures, native cats, pouched mice, banded anteaters, and Tasmanian devils.

entry.ety: Gr. dasy`s thick, shaggy + o'yra` tail: cf. F. dasyure

sn.def: A carnivorous catlike marsupial quadruped of Australia, belonging to the genus Dasyurus, called also native cat. There are several species.
any of several related animals, such as the Tasmanian devil; -- called also ursine dasyure.

entry.def: Pertaining to, or like, the dasyures.
the type genus of the family Dasyuridae: native cats.

entry.ety: acronym, from Digital AudioTape
entry.def: digital audiotape, a digitally encoded tape recording of sound; -- in contrast to the usual analog audio tape.

entry.note: The term in this sense is used especially in reference to experimental observations collected in the course of a controlled scientific investigation.
entry.ety: L. pl. of datum

sn.def: See Datum.

a collection of facts, observations, or other information related to a particular question or problem; as, the historical data show that the budget deficit is only a small factor in determining interest rates.

information, most commonly in the form of a series of binary digits, stored on a physical storage medium for manipulation by a computer program. It is contrasted with the program which is a series of instructions used by the central processing unit of a computer to manipulate the data. In some conputers data and execuatble programs are stored in separate locations.

entry.def: an organized body of related information.
relying on observation or experiment.
That may be dated; having a known or ascertainable date.
entry.q: Datablealmost to a year.

entry.ety: LL., fr. L. datum given
entry.def: Formerly, a part of the Roman chancery; now, a separate office from which are sent graces or favors, cognizable in foro externo, such as appointments to benefices. The name is derived from the word datum, given or dated (with the indications of the time and place of granting the gift or favor).

entry.ety: LL. datarius. See Dataria

sn.def: An officer in the pope's court, having charge of the Dataria.
The office or employment of a datary.

entry.note: ☞ This fruit is somewhat in the shape of an olive, containing a soft pulp, sweet, esculent, and wholesome, and inclosing a hard kernel.

cs.cd: the genus of palms which bear dates, of which common species is Phœnix dactylifera. See Illust.
the fruit of several species of Diospyros, including the American and Japanese persimmons, and the European lotus (Diospyros Lotus).
a bivalve shell, or its inhabitant, of the genus Pholas, and allied genera. See Pholas.

entry.ety: F. datte, L. dactylus, fr. Gr. �, prob. not the same word as da`ktylos finger, but of Semitic origin
entry.def: The fruit of the date palm; also, the date palm itself.

cs.cd: to have the date named on the face of it; -- said of a writing.

entry.ety: F. date, LL. data, fr. L. datus given, p. p. of dare to give; akin to Gr. �, OSlaw. dati, Skr. dā. Cf. Datum Dose Dato Die

sn.def: That addition to a writing, inscription, coin, etc., which specifies the time (as day, month, and year) when the writing or inscription was given, or executed, or made; as, the date of a letter, of a will, of a deed, of a coin. etc.
sn.q: And bonds without a date, they say, are void.

sn.def: The point of time at which a transaction or event takes place, or is appointed to take place; a given point of time; epoch; as, the date of a battle.
sn.q: He at once, Down the long series of eventful time, So fixed the dates of being, so disposed To every living soul of every kind The field of motion, and the hour of rest.

sn.def: Assigned end; conclusion.
sn.q: What Time would spare, from Steel receives its date.

sn.def: Given or assigned length of life; dyration.
sn.q: Good luck prolonged hath thy date.
Through his life's whole date.

entry.note: ☞ We may say dated at or from a place.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Dated; p. pr. & vb. n. Dating
entry.ety: Cf. F. dater. See 2d Date

sn.def: To note the time of writing or executing; to express in an instrument the time of its execution; as, to date a letter, a bond, a deed, or a charter.
To note or fix the time of, as of an event; to give the date of; as, to date the building of the pyramids.
sn.q: The letter is dated at Philadephia.
You will be suprised, I don't question, to find among your correspondencies in foreign parts, a letter dated from Blois.
In the countries of his jornal seems to have been written; parts of it are dated from them.

entry.def: To have beginning; to begin; to be dated or reckoned; -- with from.
entry.q: The Batavian republic dates from the successes of the French arms.

entries.entry: dateable adj. that can be given a date. Opposite of undatable.Narrower terms: dated datable. a concrete and dateable happening C. W. Shumaker

sn.def: marked by features of the immediate and usually discounted past.
bearing a date; as, dated and stamped documents.
Without date; having no fixed time.
not having a social companion for an occasion; as, to be dateless for the prom.

entries.entry: Date line ☞ Speaking generally, the date line coincides with the meridian 180° from Greenwich. It deflects between north latitudes 80° and 45°, so that all Asia lies to the west, all North America, including the Aleutian Islands, to the east of the line; and between south latitudes 12° and 56°, so that Chatham Island and the Tonga group lie to the west of it. A vessel crossing this line to the westward sets the date forward by one day, as from Sunday to Monday. A vessel crossing the line to the eastward sets the date back by one day, as from Monday to Sunday. Hawaii has the same day name as San Francisco; Manila, the same day name as Australia, and this is one day later than the day of Hawaii. Thus when it is Monday May 1st at San Francisco it is Tuesday may 2d at Manila.. The hypothetical line on the surface of the earth fixed by international or general agreement as a boundary on one side of which the same day shall have a different name and date in the calendar from its name and date on the other side. Also called International Date Line.

entry.def: One who dates.
A white crystalline glucoside extracted from the bastard hemp (Datisca cannabina).

cs.cd: one appointed by the judge of probate, his office answering to that of an administrator.

entry.ety: L. dativus appropriate to giving, fr. dare to give. See 2d Date

sn.def: Noting the case of a noun which expresses the remoter object, and is generally indicated in English by to or for with the objective.

sd.def: In one's gift; capable of being disposed of at will and pleasure, as an office.
Removable, as distinguished from perpetual; -- said of an officer.
Given by a magistrate, as distinguished from being cast upon a party by the law.

entry.ety: L. dativus
entry.def: The dative case. See Dative a., 1.
As a gift.

entry.ety: From. Gr. � to divide + -lite; in allusion to the granular structure of a massive variety
entry.def: A borosilicate of lime commonly occuring in glassy,, greenish crystals.
an analgesic derived from acetanolide; also used as an antipyretic; Datril and Tylenol are trademarks of brands of acetaminophen tablets. See acetaminophen.

entries.entry:
Da"tum Da"tum
Datum line Surv the horizontal or base line, from which the heights of points are reckoned or measured, as in the plan of a railway, etc.
n.; pl.Data #. L. See 2d Date
Something given or admitted; a fact or principle granted; that upon which an inference or an argument is based; -- used chiefly in the plural. Any writer, therefore, who . . . furnishes us with data sufficient to determine the time in which he wrote.
a single piece of information; a fact; especially a piece of information obtained by observation or experiment; -- used mostly in the plural.
pl. Math The quantities or relations which are assumed to be given in any problem.
Surveying a point, line, or level surface used as a reference in measuring elevations. RHUD

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Daubed; p. pr. & vb. n. Daubing
entry.ety: OE. dauben to smear, OF. dauber to plaster, fr. L. dealbare to whitewash, plaster; de- + albare to whiten, fr. albus white, perh. also confused with W. dwb plaster, dwbio to plaster, Ir. & OGael. dob plaster. See Alb, and cf. Dealbate

sn.def: To smear with soft, adhesive matter, as pitch, slime, mud, etc.; to plaster; to bedaub; to besmear.

sn.q: So smooth he daubed his vice with show of virtue.

sn.def: To flatter excessively or glossy.

sn.def: To put on without taste; to deck gaudily.
sn.q: Let him be daubed with lace.

entry.def: To smear; to play the flatterer.
entry.q: His conscience . . . will not daub nor flatter.

Daugh"ter

n.; pl.Daughters #; obs. pl. Daughtren #. Skr. duh to milk. √68, 245

entries.entry:
Da"vy Jones"
Davy Jones's Locker the ocean, or bottom of the ocean. Gone to Davy Jones's Locker dead, and buried in the sea; thrown overboard. . The spirit of the sea; sea devil; -- a term used by sailors. This same Davy Jones, according to the mythology of sailors, is the fiend that presides over all the evil spirits of the deep, and is seen in various shapes warning the devoted wretch of death and woe.
