entry.cs:
Anniversary day. See Anniversary n.
Astronomical day a period equal to the mean solar day, but beginning at noon instead of at midnight, its twenty-four hours being numbered from 1 to 24; also, the sidereal day, as that most used by astronomers. Born days. See under Born. Canicular days. See Dog day. Civil day the mean solar day, used in the ordinary reckoning of time, and among most modern nations beginning at mean midnight; its hours are usually numbered in two series, each from 1 to 12. This is the period recognized by courts as constituting a day. The Babylonians and Hindoos began their day at sunrise, the Athenians and Jews at sunset, the ancient Egyptians and Romans at midnight. Day blindness. Med See Nyctalopia.
Day by dayorDay after day
daily; every day; continually; without intermission of a day. See under By. “Day by day we magnify thee.” Book of Common Prayer. Days in bank Eng. Law certain stated days for the return of writs and the appearance of parties; -- so called because originally peculiar to the Court of Common Bench, or Bench (bank) as it was formerly termed. Burrill. Day in court a day for the appearance of parties in a suit. Days of devotion R. C. Ch certain festivals on which devotion leads the faithful to attend mass. Shipley. Days of grace. See Grace. Days of obligation R. C. Ch festival days when it is obligatory on the faithful to attend Mass. Shipley. Day owl Zoöl an owl that flies by day. See Hawk owl. Day rule Eng. Law an order of court (now abolished) allowing a prisoner, under certain circumstances, to go beyond the prison limits for a single day. Day school one which the pupils attend only in daytime, in distinction from a boarding school. Day sight. Med See Hemeralopia. Day's work Naut the account or reckoning of a ship's course for twenty-four hours, from noon to noon. From day to day as time passes; in the course of time; as, he improves from day to day . Jewish day the time between sunset and sunset. Mean solar day Astron the mean or average of all the apparent solar days of the year.
One day One of these days
at an uncertain time, usually of the future, rarely of the past; sooner or later. “Well, niece, I hope to see you one day fitted with a husband.” Shak. Only from day to day without certainty of continuance; temporarily. Bacon. Sidereal day the interval between two successive transits of the first point of Aries over the same meridian. The Sidereal day is 23 h. 56 m. 4.09 s. of mean solar time. To win the day to gain the victory, to be successful. S. Butler. Week day any day of the week except Sunday; a working day. Working day. A day when work may be legally done, in distinction from Sundays and legal holidays. The number of hours, determined by law or custom, during which a workman, hired at a stated price per day, must work to be entitled to a day's pay.
entry.ety: OE. day dai dei, AS. dæg; akin to OS., D., Dan., & Sw. dag, G. tag, Icel. dagr, Goth. dags; cf. Skr. dahfor dhagh ?) to burn. √69. Cf. Dawn

sn.def: The time of light, or interval between one night and the next; the time between sunrise and sunset, or from dawn to darkness; hence, the light; sunshine; -- also called daytime.

The period of the earth's revolution on its axis. -- ordinarily divided into twenty-four hours. It is measured by the interval between two successive transits of a celestial body over the same meridian, and takes a specific name from that of the body. Thus, if this is the sun, the day (the interval between two successive transits of the sun's center over the same meridian) is called a solar day; if it is a star, a sidereal day; if it is the moon, a lunar day. See Civil day Sidereal day, below.
Those hours, or the daily recurring period, allotted by usage or law for work.
A specified time or period; time, considered with reference to the existence or prominence of a person or thing; age; time.
sn.q: A man who was great among the Hellenes of his day.
If my debtors do not keep their day, . . . I must with patience all the terms attend.

sn.def: Preceded by the) Some day in particular, as some day of contest, some anniversary, etc.
sn.q: The field of Agincourt, Fought on the day of Crispin Crispianus.
His name struck fear, his conduct won the day.

entry.def: See Dyaks.
same as around-the-clock.

sn.def: an armless couch; a seat by day and a bed by night.
a long chair; for reclining.

entry.def: a schoolchild at a boarding school who has meals at school but sleeps at home.
A journal of accounts; a primary record book in which are recorded the debts and credits, or accounts of the day, in their order, and from which they are transferred to the journal.
a day boarder who is a boy.
The time of the first appearance of light in the morning.
The upper stratum of coal, as nearest the light or surface.
A vain fancy speculation; a reverie; a castle in the air; unfounded hope.
entry.q: Mrs. Lambert's little daydream was over.

entry.def: One given to daydreams.
A genus consisting mostly of tropical perennial herbs (Commelina), having ephemeral flowers.

A neuropterous insect of the genus Ephemera and related genera, of many species, and inhabiting fresh water in the larval state; the ephemeral fly; -- so called because it commonly lives but one day in the winged or adult state. See Ephemeral fly, under Ephemeral.
Labor hired or performed by the day.
One who works by the day; -- usually applied to a farm laborer, or to a workman who does not work at any particular trade.

sn.def: The light of day as opposed to the darkness of night; the light of the sun, as opposed to that of the moon or to artificial light.
The eyes.

entries.entry:
day" lil`y day"lil`y
lĭl`�. Bot any plant of a genus of plants (Hemerocallis) closely resembling true lilies, but having tuberous rootstocks instead of bulbs. The common species have long narrow leaves and either yellow or tawny-orange flowers, which often bloom for only one day. A genus of plants (Funkia) differing from the last in having ovate veiny leaves, and large white or blue flowers.

entry.def: A dairymaid.

entry.ety: Day + mare incubus
entry.def: A kind of incubus which occurs during wakefulness, attended by the peculiar pressure on the chest which characterizes nightmare.
A net for catching small birds.
The dawn.

entry.ety: From day in the sense of day fixed for trial
entry.def: An umpire or arbiter; a mediator.
entry.q: Neither is there any daysman betwixt us.

entry.def: The beginning of the day, or first appearance of light; the dawn; hence, the beginning.
entry.q: The tender mercy of our God; whereby the dayspring from on high hath visited us.

sn.def: The morning star; the star which ushers in the day; -- usually the planet Venus, when seen before and just after sunrise.
sn.q: A dark place, until the day dawn, and the day-star arise in your hearts.

sn.def: The sun, as the orb of day.
sn.q: So sinks the day-star in the ocean bed, And yet anon repairs his drooping head, And tricks his beams, and with new-spangled ore Flames in the forehead of the morning sky.

entry.def: The time during which there is daylight, as distinguished from the night; same as day, 1; as, during the daytime .
occurring every day.
A dairymaid.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Dazed dāzd; p. pr. & vb. n. Dazing
entry.ety: OE. dasen, prob. from Icel. dasask to become weary, a reflexive verb; cf. Sw. dasa to lie idle, and OD. daesen to be foolish, insane, daes dwaes, D. dwaas, foolish, insane, AS. dwǣs dysig, stupid. √71. Cf. Dizzy Doze
entry.def: To stupefy with excess of light; with a blow, with cold, or with fear; to confuse; to benumb.
entry.q: While flashing beams do daze his feeble eyen.
Such souls, Whose sudden visitations daze the world.
He comes out of the room in a dazed state, that is an odd though a sufficient substitute for interest.

sn.def: The state of being dazed; as, he was in a daze .
A glittering stone.
stupefied; conscious but unable to think clearly; -- usually caused by a blow or other shock.
stunned from or as if from repeated blows.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Dazzled; p. pr. & vb. n. Dazzling
entry.ety: Freq. of daze

sn.def: To overpower with light; to confuse the sight of by brilliance of light.
sn.q: Those heavenly shapes Will dazzle now the earthly, with their blaze Insufferably bright.
An unreflected light did never yetDazzle the vision feminine.

sn.def: To bewilder or surprise with brilliancy or display of any kind.
sn.q: Dazzledand drove back his enemies.

sn.def: To be overpoweringly or intensely bright; to excite admiration by brilliancy.
sn.q: Ah, friend! to dazzle, let the vain design.

sn.def: To be overpowered by light; to be confused by excess of brightness.
sn.q: An overlight maketh the eyes dazzle.
I dare not trust these eyes; They dance in mists, and dazzle with surprise.

entry.def: A light of dazzling brilliancy.
Dazzling flash, glare, or burst of light.
In a dazzling manner.

entry.ety: acronym from DataBase Management System
entry.def: a database management system, a software system that facilitates the creation and maintenance and use of an electronic database.

sn.def: the day designated for the beginning of a planned attack by a military force; in communications the day is often otherwise unspecified for security reasons; as, the day before D-day the troops will move into position.
6 June 1944, the day of the landing in France, by troops allied against the Germans in World War II.
the day for commencement or execution of any elaborate planned activity; -- often used jocosely.

entries.entry: De-. A prefix from Latin de down, from, away; as in debark, decline, decease, deduct, decamp. In words from the French it is equivalent to Latin dis- apart, away; or sometimes to de. Cf. Dis-. It is negative and opposite in derange, deform, destroy, etc. It is intensive in deprave, despoil, declare, desolate, etc.

entry.def: to sell or otherwise give up ownership; -- used mostly of artworks in museums.

entry.note: The word appears to have been coined as a euphemism to avoid the negative connotations of the word “sell”, particularly for works donated by benefactors. The practise is justified as a means of acquiring funds for purchase of more valuable artworks.
entry.ety: de- + accession. Ca. 1970
entry.def: to sell (artwork); -- used of sales of art by museums.

entry.ety: OE. diakne deakne deken, AS. diacon deacon, L. diaconus, fr. Gr. dia`konos a servant or minister, a minister of the church; of uncertain origin. In sense 2 prob. confused with dean

sn.def: An officer in Christian churches appointed to perform certain subordinate duties varying in different communions. In the Roman Catholic and Episcopal churches, a person admitted to the lowest order in the ministry, subordinate to the bishops and priests. In Presbyterian churches, he is subordinate to the minister and elders, and has charge of certain duties connected with the communion service and the care of the poor. In Congregational churches, he is subordinate to the pastor, and has duties as in the Presbyterian church.
The chairman of an incorporated company.

entry.note: ☞ The expression is derived from a former custom in the Congregational churches of New England. It was part of the office of a deacon to read aloud the psalm given out, one line at a time, the congregation singing each line as soon as read; -- called, also, lining out the psalm.
entry.sn: To read aloud each line of (a psalm or hymn) before singing it, -- usually with off. Colloq. New. Eng See Line v. t.

sn.def: With humorous reference to hypocritical posing: To pack (fruit or vegetables) with the finest specimens on top; to alter slyly the boundaries of (land); to adulterate or doctor (an article to be sold), etc.

entries.entry: Dea"con*ess n. Eccl A female deacon; as: Primitive Ch One of an order of women whose duties resembled those of deacons. Ch. of Eng. and Prot. Epis. Ch A woman set apart for church work by a bishop. A woman chosen as a helper in church work, as among the Congregationalists.

entry.def: The state of being a deacon; office of a deacon; deaconship.
See Deaconship.
The office or ministry of a deacon or deaconess.

entry.note: The deactivation of a machine or device is usually a reversible process; switching off an electrical device may be referred to as deactivation. To render an enzyme or catalyst ineffective is more commonly referred to as to inactivate.

sn.def: To make inactive; to render ineffective; as, to deactivate a bomb; to deactivate a machine; to deactivate the alarm.
To disband (a military unit, or other group); to discontinue (a group activity); as, to deactivate the regiment; to deactivate the investigation.

entry.def: The act or process of deactivating.

entry.cs:
Dead ahead Naut directly ahead; -- said of a ship or any object, esp. of the wind when blowing from that point toward which a vessel would go. Dead angle Mil an angle or space which can not be seen or defended from behind the parapet. Dead block either of two wooden or iron blocks intended to serve instead of buffers at the end of a freight car. Dead calm Naut no wind at all.
Dead centerorDead point
Mach either of two points in the orbit of a crank, at which the crank and connecting rod lie a straight line. It corresponds to the end of a stroke; as, A and B are dead centers of the crank mechanism in which the crank C drives, or is driven by, the lever L. Dead color Paint a color which has no gloss upon it. Dead coloring Oil paint the layer of colors, the preparation for what is to follow. In modern painting this is usually in monochrome. Dead door Shipbuilding a storm shutter fitted to the outside of the quarter-gallery door. Dead flat Naut the widest or midship frame. Dead freight Mar. Law a sum of money paid by a person who charters a whole vessel but fails to make out a full cargo. The payment is made for the unoccupied capacity. Abbott. Dead ground Mining the portion of a vein in which there is no ore. Dead hand a hand that can not alienate, as of a person civilly dead. “Serfs held in dead hand.” Morley. See Mortmain. Dead head Naut a rough block of wood used as an anchor buoy. Dead heat a heat or course between two or more race horses, boats, etc., in which they come out exactly equal, so that neither wins. Dead horse an expression applied to a debt for wages paid in advance. Law Dead language a language which is no longer spoken or in common use by a people, and is known only in writings, as the Hebrew, Greek, and Latin.
Dead letter. A letter which, after lying for a certain fixed time uncalled for at the post office to which it was directed, is then sent to the general post office to be opened. That which has lost its force or authority; as, the law has become a dead letter. Dead-letter office a department of the general post office where dead letters are examined and disposed of. Dead level a term applied to a flat country. Dead lift a direct lift, without assistance from mechanical advantage, as from levers, pulleys, etc.; hence, an extreme emergency. “(As we say) at a dead lift.” Robynson (More's Utopia). Weighlifting The lifting of a weight from the ground, without raising it to the shoulders. Dead line Mil a line drawn within or around a military prison, to cross which involves for a prisoner the penalty of being instantly shot. Dead load Civil Engin a constant, motionless load, as the weight of a structure, in distinction from a moving load, as a train of cars, or a variable pressure, as of wind. Dead march Mus a piece of solemn music intended to be played as an accompaniment to a funeral procession. Dead nettle Bot a harmless plant with leaves like a nettle (Lamium album). Dead oil Chem the heavy oil obtained in the distillation of coal tar, and containing phenol, naphthalus, etc.
Dead plate Mach a solid covering over a part of a fire grate, to prevent the entrance of air through that part. Dead pledge a mortgage. See Mortgage. Dead point. Mach See Dead center. Dead reckoning Naut the method of determining the place of a ship from a record kept of the courses sailed as given by compass, and the distance made on each course as found by log, with allowance for leeway, etc., without the aid of celestial observations. Dead rise the transverse upward curvature of a vessel's floor. Dead rising an elliptical line drawn on the sheer plan to determine the sweep of the floorheads throughout the ship's length. Dead-Sea apple. See under Apple. Dead set. See under Set. Dead shot. An unerring marksman. A shot certain to be made. Dead smooth the finest cut made; -- said of files. Dead wall Arch a blank wall unbroken by windows or other openings. Dead water Naut the eddy water closing in under a ship's stern when sailing. Dead weight. A heavy or oppressive burden. Dryden. Shipping A ship's lading, when it consists of heavy goods; or, the heaviest part of a ship's cargo. Railroad The weight of rolling stock, the live weight being the load. Knight. Dead wind Naut a wind directly ahead, or opposed to the ship's course. To be dead to die. Obs I deme thee, thou must algate be dead. Chaucer.
entry.ety: OE. ded dead deed, AS. deád; akin to OS. dōd, D. dood, G. todt tot, Icel. dauðr, Sw. & Dan. död, Goth. daubs; prop. p. p. of an old verb meaning to die. See Die, and cf. Death

sn.def: Deprived of life; -- opposed to alive and living; reduced to that state of a being in which the organs of motion and life have irrevocably ceased to perform their functions; as, a dead tree; a dead man.
sn.q: The queen, my lord, isdead.
The crew, all except himself, were dead of hunger.
Seek him with candle, bring him dead or living.

sn.def: Destitute of life; inanimate; as, dead matter.
Resembling death in appearance or quality; without show of life; deathlike; as, a dead sleep.
Still as death; motionless; inactive; useless; as, dead calm; a dead load or weight.
So constructed as not to transmit sound; soundless; as, a dead floor.
Unproductive; bringing no gain; unprofitable; as, dead capital; dead stock in trade.
Lacking spirit; dull; lusterless; cheerless; as, dead eye; dead fire; dead color, etc.
Monotonous or unvaried; as, a dead level or pain; a dead wall.
sn.q: The ground is adeadflat.

sn.def: Sure as death; unerring; fixed; complete; as, a dead shot; a dead certainty.
sn.q: I had them a dead bargain.

sn.def: Bringing death; deadly.
Wanting in religious spirit and vitality; as, dead faith; dead works.
sn.q: Deadin trespasses.

sd.def: Flat; without gloss; -- said of painting which has been applied purposely to have this effect.
Not brilliant; not rich; thus, brown is a dead color, as compared with crimson.

sn.def: Cut off from the rights of a citizen; deprived of the power of enjoying the rights of property; as, one banished or becoming a monk is civilly dead .
Not imparting motion or power; as, the dead spindle of a lathe, etc. See Spindle.
Carrying no current, or producing no useful effect; -- said of a conductor in a dynamo or motor, also of a telegraph wire which has no instrument attached and, therefore, is not in use.
Out of play; regarded as out of the game; -- said of a ball, a piece, or a player under certain conditions in cricket, baseball, checkers, and some other games.
sn.q: In golf], a ball is said to lie dead when it lies so near the hole that the player is certain to hole it in the next stroke.

cs.cd: so drunk as to be unconscious.

entry.def: To a degree resembling death; to the last degree; completely; wholly.
entry.q: I was tired of reading, and dead sleepy.

sn.def: The most quiet or deathlike time; the period of profoundest repose, inertness, or gloom; as, the dead of winter.
sn.q: When the drum beat at dead of night.

sn.def: One who is dead; -- commonly used collectively.
sn.q: And Abraham stood up from before his dead.

entry.def: To make dead; to deaden; to deprive of life, force, or vigor.
entry.q: Heaven's stern decree, With many an ill, hath numbed and deaded me.

entry.def: To die; to lose life or force.
entry.q: So iron, as soon as it is out of the fire, deadeth straightway.

entries.entry:
dead` beat" dĕd`bēt" dead"beat`
dĕd"bēt`. a loafer, sponger, or swindler; especially, one who does not pay his debts. Same as Beat n., 7. Low, U.S

entry.cs: Deadbeat escapement. See under Escapement.
entry.def: Making a beat without recoil; giving indications by a single beat or excursion; -- said of galvanometers and other instruments in which the needle or index moves to the extent of its deflection and stops with little or no further oscillation.
Stillborn.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Deadened dĕd"'nd; p. pr. & vb. n. Deadening
entry.ety: From Dead; cf. AS. d�dan to kill, put to death. See Dead a.

sn.def: To make as dead; to impair in vigor, force, activity, or sensation; to lessen the force or acuteness of; to blunt; as, to deaden the natural powers or feelings; to deaden a sound.
sn.q: As harper lays his open palm Upon his harp, to deaden its vibrations.

sn.def: To lessen the velocity or momentum of; to retard; as, to deaden a ship's headway.
To make vapid or spiritless; as, to deaden wine.
To deprive of gloss or brilliancy; to obscure; as, to deaden gilding by a coat of size.
To render impervious to sound, as a wall or floor; to deafen.

entry.def: One who, or that which, deadens or checks.

entry.ety: p. pr. of verb deaden3}
entry.def: Rendering less lively, intense, or vigorous; as, the deadening effect of some routine tasks.

sn.def: So lacking in interest as to cause mental weariness; as, the deadening effect of some routine tasks.
sn.syn: boring, dreary, ho-hum, irksome, tedious, tiresome, wearisome.

entry.def: The act of making something futile and useless (as by routine).

A round, flattish, wooden block, encircled by a rope, or an iron band, and pierced with three holes to receive the lanyard; -- used to extend the shrouds and stays, and for other purposes. Called also deadman's eye.

sn.def: One who receives free tickets for theaters, public conveyances, etc.
A buoy. See under Dead a.

entry.def: Having a dull, faint heart; spiritless; listless.
A morgue; a place for the temporary reception and exposure of dead bodies.
Somewhat dead, dull, or lifeless; deathlike.
entry.q: The lips put on a deadish paleness.

entry.def: A kind of latch whose bolt may be so locked by a detent that it can not be opened from the inside by the handle, or from the outside by the latch key.
A strong shutter, made to fit open ports and keep out water in a storm.
State of the dead.
The quality of being deadly.

sn.def: A lock which is not self-latching, but requires a key to throw the bolt forward.
A counteraction of things, which produces an entire stoppage; a complete obstruction of action.
sn.q: Things are at a deadlock.
The Board is much more likely to be at a deadlock of two to two.

entry.def: at a complete standstill because of opposition of two unrelenting forces or factions.

cs.cd: a poisonous plant; belladonna. See under Nightshade.

sn.def: Capable of causing death; mortal; fatal; destructive; certain or likely to cause death; as, a deadly blow or wound.
Aiming or willing to destroy; implacable; desperately hostile; flagitious; as, deadly enemies.
sn.q: Thy assailant is quick, skillful, and deadly.

sn.def: Subject to death; mortal.
sn.q: The image of a deadly man.

sn.def: In a manner resembling, or as if produced by, death; deathly.
sn.q: Deadlypale.

sn.def: In a manner to occasion death; mortally.
sn.q: The groanings of a deadly wounded man.

sn.def: In an implacable manner; destructively.
Extremely.
sn.q: Deadlyweary.
Sodeadlycunning a man.

entry.def: The state of being destitute of life, vigor, spirit, activity, etc.; dullness; inertness; languor; coldness; vapidness; indifference; as, the deadness of a limb, a body, or a tree; the deadness of an eye; deadness of the affections; the deadness of beer or cider; deadness to the world, and the like.
precisely accurate and to the point; as, a dead-on feel for characterization.
entry.q: She avoids big scenes . . . preferring to rely on small gestures and dead-on dialogue.

entry.def: Pay drawn for soldiers, or others, really dead, whose names are kept on the rolls.
entry.q: O you commanders, That, like me, have no dead-pays.

entry.def: See under Dead a.
The substances which inclose the ore on every side.

cs.cd: a power hammer having a spring interposed between the driving mechanism and the hammer head, or helve, to lessen the recoil of the hammer and reduce the shock upon the mechanism.

entry.def: Making a stroke without recoil; deadbeat.

sn.def: A mass of timbers built into the bow and stern of a vessel to give solidity.
Dead trees or branches; useless material.
People who are unproductive; -- used especially in reference to employees.

entry.def: The parts of a ship above the water when she is laden.

entry.ety: OE. def deaf deef, AS. deáf; akin to D. doof, G. taub, Icel. daufr, Dan. döv, Sw. döf, Goth. daubs, and prob. to E. dumbthe original sense being, dull as applied to one of the senses), and perh. to Gr. tyflo`sfor qyflo`s) blind, ty^fos smoke, vapor, folly, and to G. toben to rage. Cf. Dumb

sn.def: Wanting the sense of hearing, either wholly or in part; unable to perceive sounds; hard of hearing; as, a deaf man.
sn.q: Come on my right hand, for this ear is deaf.

sn.def: Unwilling to hear or listen; determinedly inattentive; regardless; not to be persuaded as to facts, argument, or exhortation; -- with to; as, deaf to reason.
sn.q: O, that men's ears should be To counsel deaf, but not to flattery!

sn.def: Deprived of the power of hearing; deafened.
sn.q: Deaf with the noise, I took my hasty flight.

sn.def: Obscurely heard; stifled; deadened.
sn.q: A deaf murmur through the squadron went.

sn.def: Decayed; tasteless; dead; as, a deaf nut; deaf corn.
sn.q: If the season be unkindly and intemperate, they [peppers] will catch a blast; and then the seeds will be deaf, void, light, and naught.

entry.def: To deafen.
an electronic device which amplifies sound and is worn to compensate for poor hearing.
both deaf and unable to speak; without the sense of hearing or the faculty of speech. Same as Deaf-mute.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Deafened; p. pr. & vb. n. Deafening
entry.ety: From Deaf

sn.def: To make deaf; to deprive of the power of hearing; to render incapable of perceiving sounds distinctly.
sn.q: Deafened and stunned with their promiscuous cries.

sn.def: To render impervious to sound, as a partition or floor, by filling the space within with mortar, by lining with paper, etc.

entry.def: rendered deaf.
The act or process of rendering impervious to sound, as a floor or wall; also, the material with which the spaces are filled in this process; pugging; sound insulation.
extremely loud; so loud as to cause deafness; as, a disco with rock music played at a deafening volume.
Without sense of sounds; obscurely.
Lonely; solitary.
A person who is deaf and dumb; one who, through deprivation or defect of hearing, has either failed the acquire the power of speech, or has lost it.
entry.q: Deaf-mutes are still so called, even when, by artificial methods, they have been taught to speak imperfectly.

entry.def: the condition of being a deaf-mute; a congenital deafness that results in inability to speak.

cs.cd: a variety of deafness dependent upon morbid change in some portion of the nervous system, especially the auditory nerve.

sn.def: Incapacity of perceiving sounds; the state of the organs which prevents the impression which constitute hearing; want of the sense of hearing.
Unwillingness to hear; voluntary rejection of what is addressed to the understanding.

entry.note: ☞ It was formerly limited by some every never a a thousand, etc.; as, some deal; but these are now obsolete or vulgar. In general, we now qualify the word with great or good, and often use it adverbially, by being understood; as, a great deal of time and pains; a greator good deal better or worse; that is, better by a great deal, or by a great part or difference.
☞ Whole deal is a general term for planking one and one half inches thick.

cs.cd: a fir tree.

entry.ety: OE. del deel, part, AS. dǣl; akin to OS. dēl, D. & Dan. deel, G. theil teil, Icel. deild, Sw. del, Goth. dails. √65. Cf. 3d Dole

sn.def: A part or portion; a share; hence, an indefinite quantity, degree, or extent, degree, or extent; as, a deal of time and trouble; a deal of cold.
sn.q: Three tenth dealsparts of an ephah] of flour.
As an object of science it [the Celtic genius] may count for a good deal . . . as a spiritual power.
She was resolved to be a good deal more circumspect.

sn.def: The process of dealing cards to the players; also, the portion disturbed.
sn.q: The deal, the shuffle, and the cut.

sn.def: Distribution; apportionment.
An arrangement to attain a desired result by a combination of interested parties; -- applied to stock speculations and political bargains.

sn.ety: Prob. from D. deel a plank, threshing floor. See Thill
sn.def: The division of a piece of timber made by sawing; a board or plank; particularly, a board or plank of fir or pine above seven inches in width, and exceeding six feet in length. If narrower than this, it is called a batten; if shorter, a deal end.
Wood of the pine or fir; as, a floor of deal .

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Dealt dĕlt; p. pr. & vb. n. Dealing
entry.ety: OE. delen, AS. dǣlan, fr. dǣl share; akin to OS. dēlian, D. deelen, G. theilen teilen, Icel. deila, Sw. dela, Dan. dele, Goth. dailjan. See Deal n.

sn.def: To divide; to separate in portions; hence, to give in portions; to distribute; to bestow successively; -- sometimes with out.
sn.q: Is it not to deal thy bread to the hungry?
And Rome deals out her blessings and her gold.
The nightly mallet deals resounding blows.
Hissing through the skies, the feathery deaths were dealt.

sn.def: Specifically: To distribute, as cards, to the players at the commencement of a game; as, to deal the cards; to deal one a jack.

entry.cs: To deal by to treat, either well or ill; as, to deal well by servants. “Such an one deals not fairly by his own mind.” Locke. To deal in. To have to do with; to be engaged in; to practice; as, they deal in political matters. To buy and sell; to furnish, as a retailer or wholesaler; as, they deal in fish. To deal with. To treat in any manner; to use, whether well or ill; to have to do with; specifically, to trade with. “Dealing with witches.” Shak. To reprove solemnly; to expostulate with.

sn.def: To make distribution; to share out in portions, as cards to the players.
To do a distributing or retailing business, as distinguished from that of a manufacturer or producer; to traffic; to trade; to do business; as, he deals in flour.
sn.q: They buy and sell, they deal and traffic.
This is to drive to wholesale trade, when all other petty merchants deal but for parcels.

sn.def: To act as an intermediary in business or any affairs; to manage; to make arrangements; -- followed by between or with.
sn.q: Sometimes he that deals between man and man, raiseth his own credit with both, by pretending greater interest than he hath in either.

sn.def: To conduct one's self; to behave or act in any affair or towards any one; to treat.
sn.q: If he will deal clearly and impartially, . . . he will acknowledge all this to be true.

sn.def: To contend (with); to treat (with), by way of opposition, check, or correction; as, he has turbulent passions to deal with.
sn.q: The deacons of his church, who, to use their own phrase, “dealt with him” on the sin of rejecting the aid which Providence so manifestly held out.
Return . . . and I will deal well with thee.

entry.ety: L. dealbatus, p. p. of dealbare. See Daub
entry.def: To whiten.

entry.ety: L. dealbatio: cf. F. déalbation
entry.def: Act of bleaching; a whitening.

sn.def: One who deals; one who has to do, or has concern, with others; esp., a trader, a trafficker, a shopkeeper, a broker, or a merchant; as, a dealer in dry goods; a dealer in stocks; a retail dealer.
One who distributes cards to the players.

entry.ety: From deal a long, narrow plank
entry.def: A long, thin fish of the arctic seas (Trachypterus arcticus).

cs.cd: insincere, treacherous dealing; duplicity.
fair, sincere, honorable dealing; honest, outspoken expression of opinion.

entry.def: The act of one who deals; distribution of anything, as of cards to the players; method of business; traffic; intercourse; transaction; as, to have dealings with a person.
Share dealt.

entry.ety: L. deambulare deambulatum; de- + ambulare to walk
entry.def: To walk abroad.

entry.ety: L. deambulatio
entry.def: A walking abroad; a promenading.

entry.ety: Cf. LL. deambulator a traveler
entry.def: Going about from place to place; wandering; of or pertaining to a deambulatory.
entry.q: Deambulatoryactors.

entry.ety: L. deambulatorium
entry.def: A covered place in which to walk; an ambulatory.

cs.cd: the chief officer of a chapter; he is an ecclesiastical magistrate next in degree to bishop, and has immediate charge of the cathedral and its estates.
a dean holding a preferment which has some peculiarity relative to spiritual superiors and the jurisdiction exercised in it.
one having, under the bishop, the especial care and inspection of the clergy within certain parishes or districts of the diocese.

entry.cs:
Cardinal dean the senior cardinal bishop of the college of cardinals at Rome. Shipley. Dean and chapter the legal corporation and governing body of a cathedral. It consists of the dean, who is chief, and his canons or prebendaries. Dean of arches the lay judge of the court of arches. Dean of faculty the president of an incorporation or barristers; specifically, the president of the incorporation of advocates in Edinburgh. Dean of guild a magistrate of Scotch burghs, formerly, and still, in some burghs, chosen by the Guildry, whose duty is to superintend the erection of new buildings and see that they conform to the law.
Dean of a monastery Monastic dean
a monastic superior over ten monks. Dean's stall. See Decanal stall, under Decanal.
entry.ety: OE. dene deene, OF. deien dien, F. doyen, eldest of a corporation, a dean, L. decanus the chief of ten, one set over ten persons, e. g., over soldiers or over monks, from decem ten. See Ten, and cf. Decemvir

sn.def: A dignitary or presiding officer in certain ecclesiastical and lay bodies; esp., an ecclesiastical dignitary, subordinate to a bishop.
The collegiate officer in the universities of Oxford and Cambridge, England, who, besides other duties, has regard to the moral condition of the college.
The head or presiding officer in the faculty of some colleges or universities.
A registrar or secretary of the faculty in a department of a college, as in a medical, or theological, or scientific department.
The chief or senior of a company on occasion of ceremony; as, the dean of the diplomatic corps; -- so called by courtesy.

entries.entry:
Dean"er*y n.; pl.Deaneries.
The office or the revenue of a dean. See the Note under Benefice n., 3.
The residence of a dean.
The territorial jurisdiction of a dean. Each archdeaconry is divided into rural deaneries, and each deanery is divided into parishes.

entry.def: The office of a dean.
entry.q: I dont't value your deanship a straw.

entry.amorph: Compar. Dearer dēr"ẽr; superl. Dearest dēr"ĕst
entry.ety: OE. dere deore, AS. deóre; akin to OS. diuri, D. duur, OHG. tiuri, G. theuer teuer, Icel. dȳrr, Dan. & Sw. dyr. Cf. Darling Dearth

sn.def: Bearing a high price; high-priced; costly; expensive.
sn.q: The cheapest of us is ten groats too dear.

sn.def: Marked by scarcity or dearth, and exorbitance of price; as, a dear year.
Highly valued; greatly beloved; cherished; precious.
sn.q: Hear me,dearlady.
Neither count I my life dear unto myself.
And the last joy was dearer than the rest.
Dear as remember'd kisses after death.

sn.def: Hence, close to the heart; heartfelt; present in mind; engaging the attention.

sd.def: Of agreeable things and interests.
sd.q: I'll] leave you to attend him: some dear cause Will in concealment wrap me up awhile.
His dearest wish was to escape from the bustle and glitter of Whitehall.

sd.def: Of disagreeable things and antipathies.
sd.q: In our dear peril.
Would I had met my dearest foe in heaven Or ever I had seen that day.

entry.def: A dear one; lover; sweetheart.
entry.q: That kiss I carried from thee, dear.

entry.def: Dearly; at a high price.
entry.q: If thou attempt it, it will cost thee dear.

entry.def: To endear.
A four-wheeled carriage, with curtained sides.
Bought at a high price; as, dear-bought experience.
variant of Dere v. t. & n.
Same as Deary.
A darling.
Greatly beloved.

sn.def: In a dear manner; with affection; heartily; earnestly; as, to love one dearly .
At a high rate or price; grievously.
sn.q: He buys his mistress dearly with his throne.

sn.def: Exquisitely.

entry.ety: AS. derne dyrne dierne, hidden, secret. Cf. Derne
entry.def: Secret; lonely; solitary; dreadful.
Same as Darn.

sn.def: The quality or state of being dear; costliness; excess of price.
sn.q: The dearness of corn.

sn.def: Fondness; preciousness; love; tenderness.
sn.q: The dearness of friendship.

entry.ety: OE. derthe, fr. dere. See Dear
entry.def: Scarcity which renders dear; want; lack; specifically, lack of food on account of failure of crops; famine.
entry.q: There came a dearth over all the land of Egypt.
He with her press'd, she faint with dearth.
Dearth of plot, and narrowness of imagination.

entry.def: To disjoint.

entry.ety: See Derworth
entry.def: Precious.
A dear; a darling.
See Dais.

entry.note: ☞ Local death is going on at all times and in all parts of the living body, in which individual cells and elements are being cast off and replaced by new; a process essential to life. General death is of two kinds; death of the body as a whole (somatic or systemic death), and death of the tissues. By the former is implied the absolute cessation of the functions of the brain, the circulatory and the respiratory organs; by the latter the entire disappearance of the vital actions of the ultimate structural constituents of the body. When death takes place, the body as a whole dies first, the death of the tissues sometimes not occurring until after a considerable interval. Huxley.

☞ Death is much used adjectively and as the first part of a compound, meaning, in general, of or pertaining to death causing or presaging death; as, deathbed or death bed; deathblow or death blow, etc.
entry.cs: Black death. See Black death, in the Vocabulary. Civil death the separation of a man from civil society, or the debarring him from the enjoyment of civil rights, as by banishment, attainder, abjuration of the realm, entering a monastery, etc. Blackstone. Death adder. Zoöl A kind of viper found in South Africa (Acanthophis tortor); -- so called from the virulence of its venom. A venomous Australian snake of the family Elapidæ, of several species, as the Hoplocephalus superbus and Acanthopis antarctica. Death bell a bell that announces a death. The death bell thrice was heard to ring. Mickle. Death candle a light like that of a candle, viewed by the superstitious as presaging death. Death damp a cold sweat at the coming on of death. Death fire a kind of ignis fatuus supposed to forebode death. And round about in reel and rout, The death fires danced at night. Coleridge. Death grapple a grapple or struggle for life. Death in life a condition but little removed from death; a living death. Poetic “Lay lingering out a five years' death in life.” Tennyson. Death rate the relation or ratio of the number of deaths to the population. At all ages the death rate is higher in towns than in rural districts. Darwin. Death rattle a rattling or gurgling in the throat of a dying person. Death's door the boundary of life; the partition dividing life from death. Death stroke a stroke causing death. Death throe the spasm of death. Death token the signal of approaching death. Death warrant. Law An order from the proper authority for the execution of a criminal. That which puts an end to expectation, hope, or joy. Death wound. A fatal wound or injury. Naut The springing of a fatal leak. Spiritual death Scripture the corruption and perversion of the soul by sin, with the loss of the favor of God. The gates of death the grave. Have the gates of death been opened unto thee? Job xxxviii. 17. The second death condemnation to eternal separation from God. Rev. ii. 11. To be the death of to be the cause of death to; to make die. “It was one who should be the death of both his parents.” Milton.
entry.usage: Death applies to the termination of every form of existence, both animal and vegetable; the other words only to the human race. Decease is the term used in law for the removal of a human being out of life in the ordinary course of nature. Demise was formerly confined to decease of princes, but is now sometimes used of distinguished men in general; as, the demise of Mr. Pitt. Departure and release are peculiarly terms of Christian affection and hope. A violent death is not usually called a decease. Departure implies a friendly taking leave of life. Release implies a deliverance from a life of suffering or sorrow.
entry.ety: OE. deth deað, AS. deáð; akin to OS. dōð, D. dood, G. tod, Icel. dauði, Sw. & Dan. död, Goth. dauþus; from a verb meaning to die. See Die v. i., and cf. Dead

sn.def: The cessation of all vital phenomena without capability of resuscitation, either in animals or plants.
Total privation or loss; extinction; cessation; as, the death of memory.
sn.q: The death of a language can not be exactly compared with the death of a plant.

sn.def: Manner of dying; act or state of passing from life.
sn.q: A death that I abhor.
Let me die the death of the righteous.

sn.def: Cause of loss of life.
sn.q: Swiftly flies the feathered death.
He caught his death the last county sessions.

sn.def: Personified: The destroyer of life, -- conventionally represented as a skeleton with a scythe.
sn.q: Death! great proprietor of all.
And I looked, and behold a pale horse; and his name that sat on him was Death.

sn.def: Danger of death.
sn.q: Indeathsoft.

sn.def: Murder; murderous character.
sn.q: Not to suffer a man of death to live.

sn.def: Loss of spiritual life.
sn.q: To be carnally minded is death.

sn.def: Anything so dreadful as to be like death.
sn.q: It was death to them to think of entertaining such doctrines.
And urged him, so that his soul was vexed unto death.

entry.def: The bed in which a person dies; hence, the closing hours of life of one who dies by sickness or the like; the last sickness.
entry.q: That often-quoted passage from Lord Hervey in which the Queen's deathbed is described.

entry.def: Tengmalm's or Richardson's owl (Nyctale Tengmalmi); -- so called from a superstition of the North American Indians that its note presages death.
A mortal or crushing blow; a stroke or event which kills or destroys.
entry.q: The deathblow of my hope.

sn.def: Full of death or slaughter; murderous; destructive; bloody.
sn.q: These eyes behold The deathful scene.

sn.def: Liable to undergo death; mortal.
sn.q: The deathless gods and deathful earth.

entry.def: Appearance of death.

sn.def: A stroke or tolling of a bell, announcing a death; a knell{1}.
A sign or harbinger of the end, death, or passing away of anything.

entry.def: Not subject to death, destruction, or extinction; immortal; undying; imperishable; as, deathless beings; deathless fame.

sn.def: Resembling death.
sn.q: A deathlike slumber, and a dead repose.

sn.def: Deadly.
sn.q: Deathlikedragons.

entry.def: The quality of being deathly; deadliness.
Deadly; fatal; mortal; destructive.
Deadly; as, deathly pale or sick.
a list of persons killed in a war or other disaster.

cs.cd: a very large European moth (Acherontia atropos), so called from a figure resembling a human skull on the back of the thorax; -- called also death's-head sphinx.

entry.def: A naked human skull as the emblem of death; the head of the conventional personification of death.
entry.q: I had rather be married to a death's-head with a bone in his mouth.

entry.def: The deadly nightshade (Atropa belladonna).
An executioner; a headsman or hangman.
Toward death.

sd.def: A small beetle (Anobium tessellatum and other allied species). By forcibly striking its head against woodwork it makes a ticking sound, which is a call of the sexes to each other, but has been imagined by superstitious people to presage death.
A small wingless insect, of the family Psocidæ, which makes a similar but fainter sound; -- called also deathtick.
sd.q: She is always seeing apparitions and hearing deathwatches.
I did not hear the dog howl, mother, or the deathwatch beat.

sn.def: The guard set over a criminal before his execution.

entry.ety: L. deauratus, p. p. of deaurare to gild; de- + aurum gold
entry.def: Gilded.
To gild.
Act of gilding.

entry.ety: See Deafen
entry.def: To stun or stupefy with noise; to deafen.

entry.ety: L. debacchatus, p. p. of debacchari to rage; de- + bacchari to rage like a bacchant
entry.def: To rave as a bacchanal.

entry.ety: L. debacchatio
entry.def: Wild raving or debauchery.

entry.ety: F. débâcle, fr. débâcler to unbar, break loose; pref. dé-prob. = L. dis) + bâcler to bolt, fr. L. baculum a stick

sn.def: A breaking or bursting forth; a violent rush or flood of waters which breaks down opposing barriers, and hurls forward and disperses blocks of stone and other débris.
A sudden breaking up or breaking loose; a violent dispersion or disruption; impetuous rush; outburst.
a complete and ludicrous failure; a rout, as of an army; a great disaster; a fiasco.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Debarred; p. pr. & vb. n. Debarring
entry.ety: Pref. de- + bar
entry.def: To cut off from entrance, as if by a bar or barrier; to preclude; to hinder from approach, entry, or enjoyment; to shut out or exclude; to deny or refuse; -- with from, and sometimes with of.
entry.q: Yet not so strictly hath our Lord imposed Labor, as to debar us when we need Refreshment.
Their wages were so low as to debar them, not only from the comforts but from the common decencies of civilized life.

entry.ety: Pref. de- + L. barba beard
entry.def: To deprive of the beard.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Debarked; p. pr. & vb. n. Debarking
entry.ety: F. débarquer; pref. dé-L. dis-) + barque. See Bark the vessel, and cf. Disbark
entry.def: To go ashore from a ship or boat; to disembark; to put ashore.
Disembarkation.
entry.q: The debarkation, therefore, had to take place by small steamers.

entry.def: Hindrance from approach; exclusion.

entry.ety: Cf. F. débarrasser. See Embarrass
entry.def: To disembarrass; to relieve.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Debased; p. pr. & vb. n. Debasing
entry.ety: Pref. de- + base. See Base a., and cf. Abase
entry.def: To reduce from a higher to a lower state or grade of worth, dignity, purity, station, etc.; to degrade; to lower; to deteriorate; to abase; as, to debase the character by crime; to debase the mind by frivolity; to debase style by vulgar words.
entry.q: The coin which was adulterated and debased.
It is a kind of taking God's name in vain to debase religion with such frivolous disputes.
And to debase the sons, exalts the sires.

entry.def: Turned upside down from its proper position; inverted; reversed.
The act of debasing or the state of being debased.
One who, or that which, debases.
In a manner to debase.

cs.cd: a tract of land between the Esk and the Sark, claimed by both England and Scotland; the Batable Ground.

entry.ety: Cf. OF. debatable. See Debate
entry.def: Liable to be debated; disputable; subject to controversy or contention; open to question or dispute; as, a debatable question.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Debated; p. pr. & vb. n. Debating
entry.ety: OF. debatre, F. débattre; L. de + batuere to beat. See Batter v. t., and cf. Abate

sn.def: To engage in combat for; to strive for.
sn.q: Volunteers . . . thronged to serve under his banner, and the cause of religion was debated with the same ardor in Spain as on the plains of Palestine.

sn.def: To contend for in words or arguments; to strive to maintain by reasoning; to dispute; to contest; to discuss; to argue for and against.
sn.q: A wise council . . . that did debate this business.
Debate thy cause with thy neighbor himself.
sn.syn: To argue; discuss; dispute; controvert. See Argue, and Discuss.

sn.def: To engage in strife or combat; to fight.
sn.q: Well could he tourney and in lists debate.

sn.def: To contend in words; to dispute; hence, to deliberate; to consider; to discuss or examine different arguments in the mind; -- often followed by on or upon.
sn.q: He presents that great soul debating upon the subject of life and death with his intimate friends.

entry.ety: F. débat, fr. débattre. See Debate v. t.

sn.def: A fight or fighting; contest; strife.
sn.q: On the day of the Trinity next ensuing was a great debate . . . and in that murder there were slain . . . fourscore.
But question fierce and proud reply Gave signal soon of dire debate.

sn.def: Contention in words or arguments; discussion for the purpose of elucidating truth or influencing action; strife in argument; controversy; as, the debates in Parliament or in Congress.
sn.q: Heard, noted, answer'd, as in full debate.

sn.def: Subject of discussion.
sn.q: Statutes and edicts concerning this debate.

entry.def: Full of contention; contentious; quarrelsome.
With contention.

entry.ety: Cf. OF. debatement a beating
entry.def: Controversy; deliberation; debate.
entry.q: A serious question and debatement with myself.

entry.def: One who debates; one given to argument; a disputant; a controvertist.
entry.q: Debate where leisure serves with dull debaters.

cs.cd: a society or club for the purpose of debate and improvement in extemporaneous speaking.

entry.def: The act of discussing or arguing; discussion.
In the manner of a debate.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Debauched; p. pr. & vb. n. Debauching
entry.ety: F. débaucher, prob. originally, to entice away from the workshop; pref. dé-L. dis- or de) + OF. bauche bauge, hut, cf. F. bauge lair of a wild boar; prob. from G. or Icel., cf. Icel. bālkr. See Balk n.
entry.def: To lead away from purity or excellence; to corrupt in character or principles; to mar; to vitiate; to pollute; to seduce; as, to debauch one's self by intemperance; to debauch a woman; to debauch an army.
entry.q: Learning not debauched by ambition.
A man must have got his conscience thoroughly debauched and hardened before he can arrive to the height of sin.
Her pride debauched her judgment and her eyes.

entry.ety: Cf. F. débauche

sn.def: Excess in eating or drinking; intemperance; drunkenness; lewdness; debauchery.
sn.q: The first physicians by debauch were made.

sn.def: An act or occasion of debauchery.
sn.q: Silenus, from his night's debauch, Fatigued and sick.

entry.def: Dissolute; dissipated.
entry.q: A coarse anddebauchedlook.

entry.def: In a profligate manner.
The state of being debauched; intemperance.

entry.ety: F. débauché n., properly p. p. of débaucher. See Debauch v. t.
entry.def: One who is given to intemperance or bacchanalian excesses; a man habitually lewd; a libertine.
One who debauches or corrupts others; especially, a seducer to lewdness.

entries.entry:
De*bauch"er*y n.; pl.Debaucheries.
Corruption of fidelity; seduction from virtue, duty, or allegiance. The republic of Paris will endeavor to complete the debauchery of the army.
Excessive indulgence of the appetites; especially, excessive indulgence of lust; intemperance; sensuality; habitual lewdness. Oppose . . . debauchery by temperance.

entry.def: The act of corrupting; the act of seducing from virtue or duty.
Debauchedness.

entry.ety: F. de of + beige the natural color of wool
entry.def: A kind of woolen or mixed dress goods.

entry.ety: Cf. F. débeller. See Debellate
entry.def: To conquer.

entry.ety: L. debellatus, p. p. of debellare to subdue; de- + bellum war
entry.def: To subdue; to conquer in war.

entry.ety: LL. debellatio
entry.def: The act of conquering or subduing.

entries.entry: De be"ne es"se De be"ne es"se. L Law Of well being; of formal sufficiency for the time; conditionally; provisionally.

entry.note: It is applied in England to deeds of mortgage given by railway companies for borrowed money; also to municipal and other bonds and securities for money loaned.
entry.ety: L. debentur they are due, fr. debere to owe; cf. F. debentur. So called because these receipts began with the words Debentur mihi

sn.def: A writing acknowledging a debt; a writing or certificate signed by a public officer, as evidence of a debt due to some person; the sum thus due.
A customhouse certificate entitling an exporter of imported goods to a drawback of duties paid on their importation.

Any of various instruments issued, esp. by corporations, as evidences of debt. Such instruments (often called debenture bonds) are generally, through not necessarily, under seal, and are usually secured by a mortgage or other charge upon property; they may be registered or unregistered. A debenture secured by a mortgage on specific property is called a mortgage debenture; one secured by a floating charge (which see), a floating debenture; one not secured by any charge a naked debenture. In general the term debenture in British usage designates any security issued by companies other than their shares, including, therefore, what are in the United States commonly called bonds. When used in the United States debenture generally designates an instrument secured by a floating charge junior to other charges secured by fixed mortgages, or, specif., one of a series of securities secured by a group of securities held in trust for the benefit of the debenture holders.

entry.def: Entitled to drawback or debenture; as, debentured goods.

entries.entry: Debenture stock. Finance The debt or series of debts, collectively, represented by a series of debentures; a debt secured by a trust deed of property for the benefit of the holders of shares in the debt or of a series of debentures. By the terms of much debenture stock the holders are not entitled to demand payment until the winding up of the company or default in payment; in the case of railway debentures, they cannot demand payment of the principal, and the debtor company cannot redeem the stock, except by authority of an act of Parliament. Eng

entry.ety: L. debilis: cf. F. débile. See Debility
entry.def: Weak.

entry.ety: L. debilitants, p. pr
entry.def: Diminishing the energy of organs; reducing excitement; as, a debilitant drug.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Debilitated; p. pr. & vb. n. Debilitating
entry.ety: L. debilitatus, p. p. of debilitare to debilitate, fr. debilis. See Debility
entry.def: To impair the strength of; to weaken; to enfeeble; as, to debilitate the body by intemperance.
entry.q: Various ails debilitate the mind.
The debilitated frame of Mr. Bertram was exhausted by this last effort.

sn.def: lacking strength or vigor; weakened.
weakened due to illness.

entry.def: causing weakness. Opposite of invigorating.

entries.entry: debilitative adj. causing weakness.Narrower terms: debilitating (vs. invigorating enervating, enfeebling, weakening.

entry.ety: L. debilitatio: cf. F. débilitation
entry.def: The act or process of debilitating, or the condition of one who is debilitated; weakness.

entry.usage: An infirmity belongs, for the most part, to particular members, and is often temporary, as of the eyes, etc. Debility is more general, and while it lasts impairs the ordinary functions of nature. Imbecility attaches to the whole frame, and renders it more or less powerless. Debility may be constitutional or may be the result or superinduced causes; Imbecility is always constitutional; infirmity is accidental, and results from sickness or a decay of the frame. These words, in their figurative uses, have the same distinctions; we speak of infirmity of will, debility of body, and an Imbecility which affects the whole man; but Imbecility is often used with specific reference to feebleness of mind.
entry.ety: L. debilitas, fr. debilis weak, prob. fr. de- + habilis able: cf. F. débilité. See Able a.
entry.def: The state of being weak; weakness; feebleness; languor.
entry.q: The inconveniences of too strong a perspiration, which are debility, faintness, and sometimes sudden death.

entry.ety: L. debitum what is due, debt, from debere to owe: cf. F. débit. See Debt
entry.def: A debt; an entry on the debtor (Dr.) side of an account; -- mostly used adjectively; as, the debit side of an account.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Debited; p. pr. & vb. n. Debiting

sn.def: To charge with debt; -- the opposite of, and correlative to, credit; as, to debit a purchaser for the goods sold.
To enter on the debtor (Dr.) side of an account; as, to debit the amount of goods sold.

entry.ety: See debit
entry.def: a small usually plastic card with a magnetic coded number, similar to a credit card, which is used to pay for purchases by the electronic deduction of a sum of money (a debit) directly from the card-holder's bank account. Such cards do not require the establishment of a credit line, and such transactions do not incur any interest payments.

entry.ety: L. See Debtor
entry.def: A debtor.
The act of depriving of bitumen.
To deprive of bitumen.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: The cavity from which the earth for parapets, etc. (remblai), is taken.

entry.ety: OE. debonere, OF. de bon aire debonaire, of good descent or lineage, excellent, debonair, F. débonnaire debonair; de of (L. de) + bon good (L. bonus) + aire. See Air, and Bounty, and cf. Bonair
entry.def: Characterized by courteousness, affability, or gentleness; of good appearance and manners; graceful; complaisant.
entry.q: Was never prince so meek and debonair.

entry.ety: OF. debonaireté, F. débonnaireté
entry.def: Debonairness.
Courteously; elegantly.
The quality of being debonair; good humor; gentleness; courtesy.

entry.ety: Old form of debauch
entry.def: To debauch.
entry.q: Adeboshedlady.

entry.def: Debauchment.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Debouched; p. pr. & vb. n. Debouching
entry.ety: F. déboucher; pref. dé-L. dis- or de) + boucher to stop up, fr. bouche mouth, fr. L. bucca the cheek. Cf. Disembogue
entry.def: To march out from a wood, defile, or other confined spot, into open ground; to issue.
entry.q: Battalions debouching on the plain.

sn.def: To issue; -- said of a stream passing from a gorge out into an open valley or a plain.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: A place for exit; an outlet; hence, a market for goods.
entry.q: The débouchés were ordered widened to afford easy egress.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: The outward opening of a river, of a valley, or of a strait.

to interrogate (a person) who has recently experienced an event, to obtain information about that experience; -- used especially of military pilots or diplomatic agents who have just returned from a mission.
to remove (e. g., dead tissue) surgically from a wound.
the surgical excision of dead, contaminated, or damaged tissue, and foreign matter, especially from a wound.

entry.ety: F., fr. pref. dé-L. dis) + briser to break, shatter; perh. of Celtic origin

sn.def: Broken and detached fragments, taken collectively; especially, fragments detached from a rock or mountain, and piled up at the base.
Rubbish, especially such as results from the destruction of anything; remains; ruins.

entry.ety: Cf. OF. debruisier to shatter, break. Cf. Bruise
entry.def: Surmounted by an ordinary; as, a lion is debruised when a bend or other ordinary is placed over it, as in the cut.
entry.q: The lion of England and the lilies of France without the baton sinister, under which, according to the laws of heraldry, they where debruised in token of his illegitimate birth.

cs.cd: etc. See under Bond Book, etc.
death.

entry.ety: OE. dette, F. dette, LL. debita, fr. L. debitus owed, p. p. of debere to owe, prop., to have on loan; de- + habere to have. See Habit, and cf. Debit Due

sn.def: That which is due from one person to another, whether money, goods, or services; that which one person is bound to pay to another, or to perform for his benefit; thing owed; obligation; liability.
sn.q: Your son, my lord, has paid a soldier's debt.
When you run in debt, you give to another power over your liberty.

sn.def: A duty neglected or violated; a fault; a sin; a trespass.
sn.q: Forgive us ourdebts.

sn.def: An action at law to recover a certain specified sum of money alleged to be due.

entry.def: Indebted; obliged to.
entry.q: I stand debted to this gentleman.

entry.def: One to whom a debt is due; creditor; -- correlative to debtor.
Free from debt.

entry.ety: OE. dettur dettour, OF. detor detur detour, F. débiteur, fr. L. debitor, fr. debere to owe. See Debt
entry.def: One who owes a debt; one who is indebted; -- correlative to creditor.
entry.q: I 'll] bring your latter hazard back again, And thankfully rest debtor for the first.
In Athens an insolvent debtor became slave to his creditor.
Debtors for our lives to you.

entry.ety: Pref. dé- + L. bullire to boil
entry.def: To boil over.

entry.ety: See Debulliate
entry.def: A bubbling or boiling over.

entry.ety: Pref. de + L. bursa purse
entry.def: To disburse.

entry.ety: From the inventor, Debus, a French optician + -scope
entry.def: A modification of the kaleidoscope; -- used to reflect images so as to form beautiful designs.

entries.entry: Dé`but"‖n. F. début, prop., the first cast or throw at play, fr. but aim, mark. See Butt an end A beginning or first attempt; hence, a first appearance before the public, as of an actor or public speaker.

‖Dé`bu`tant" n.; fem. Dé`bu`tante" . F., p. pr. of débuter to have the first throw, to make one's début. See Début
A person who makes his (or her) first appearance before the public.

entry.def: A young woman making her first appearance in society, especially one who is one of the honorees at a debutante cotillion. See cotillion4}.

entries.entry:
Dec"a-. pref. Cf. Ten
A prefix, from Gr. de`ka, signifying ten; specifically Metric System a prefix signifying the weight or measure that is ten times the principal unit.

De*cac`e*ra"ta‖n. pl. NL., fr. Gr. de`ka ten + ke`ras a horn Zoöl The division of Cephalopoda which includes the squids, cuttlefishes, and others having ten arms or tentacles; -- called also Decapoda. Decacera See Dibranchiata.

entry.ety: Gr. deka`chordos tenstringed; de`ka ten + chordj` a string

sn.def: An ancient Greek musical instrument of ten strings, resembling the harp.
Something consisting of ten parts.

entry.ety: L. decacuminare to cut off the top. See Cacuminate
entry.def: Having the point or top cut off.
A decade.
entry.q: Averill was a decad and a half his elder.

entry.def: Pertaining to ten; consisting of tens.

entry.ety: F. décade, L. decas -adis, fr. Gr. �, fr. de`ka ten. See Ten
entry.def: A group or division of ten; esp., a period of ten years; a decennium; as, a decade of years or days; a decade of soldiers; the second decade of Livy.
entry.q: During this notable decade of years.

entry.ety: LL. decadentia; L. de- + cadere to fall: cf. F. décadence. See Decay
entry.def: A falling away; decay; deterioration; declension. “The old castle, where the family lived in their decadence.”
Decaying; deteriorating.

One that is decadent, or deteriorating; esp., one characterized by, or exhibiting, the qualities of those who are degenerating to a lower type; -- specif. applied to a certain school of modern French writers.
entry.q: The decadents and æsthetes, and certain types of realists.
The business men of a great State allow their State to be represented in Congress by “decadents”.

entry.def: A writer of a book divided into decades; as, Livy was a decadist .

entry.ety: Pref. deca- + Gr. � a corner or angle: cf. F. décagone
entry.def: A plane figure having ten sides and ten angles; any figure having ten angles. A regular decagon is one that has all its sides and angles equal.
Pertaining to a decagon; having ten sides.

entry.ety: F. décagramme; Gr. de`ka ten + F. gramme. See Gram
entry.def: A weight of the metric system; ten grams, equal to about 154.32 grains avoirdupois.

entries.entry: Dec`a*gyn"i*a‖n. pl. NL., fr. Gr. de`ka ten + � a woman, a female Bot A Linnæan order of plants characterized by having ten styles.

entry.ety: Cf. F. décagyne
entry.def: Belonging to the Decagynia; having ten styles.
Having ten sides.

entries.entry:
Dec`a*he"dron n.; pl. E. Decahedrons #, L. Decahedra #. Pref. deca- + Gr. 'e`dra a seat, a base, fr. 'e`zesthai to sit: cf. F. décaèdre
Geom A solid figure or body inclosed by ten plane surfaces.
decaedron

entry.def: The removal of calcareous matter.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Decalcified; p. pr. & vb. n. Decalcifying
entry.def: To deprive of calcareous matter; thus, to decalcify bones is to remove the stony part, and leave only the gelatin.

entry.ety: F. décalcomanie
entry.def: The art or process of transferring pictures and designs to china, glass, marble, etc., and permanently fixing them thereto.

entry.ety: F. décalitre; Gr. de`ka ten + F. litre. See Liter
entry.def: A measure of capacity in the metric system; a cubic volume of ten liters, equal to about 610.24 cubic inches, that is, 2.642 wine gallons.
Decalogue.
One who explains the decalogue.

entry.ety: F. décalogue, L. decalogus, fr. Gr. �; de`ka ten + � speech, � to speak, to say. See Ten
entry.def: The Ten Commandments or precepts given by God to Moses on Mount Sinai, and originally written on two tables of stone.

entry.ety: It. decamerone, fr. Gr. de`ka ten + � part; though quite generally supposed to be derived from "hme`ra day: cf. F. décaméron
entry.def: A celebrated collection of tales, supposed to be related in ten days; -- written in the 14th century, by Boccaccio, an Italian.

entry.ety: F. décamètre; Gr. de`ka ten + mètre. See Meter
entry.def: A measure of length in the metric system; ten meters, equal to about 393.7 inches.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Decamped ?; 215; p. pr. & vb. n. Decamping
entry.ety: F. décamper; pref. dé-L. dis) + camp camp. See Camp

sn.def: To break up a camp; to move away from a camping ground, usually by night or secretly.
Hence, to depart suddenly; to run away; -- generally used disparagingly.
sn.q: The fathers were ordered to decamp, and the house was once again converted into a tavern.

entry.ety: Cf. F. décampement
entry.def: Departure from a camp; a marching off.

the stall allotted to the dean in the choir, on the right or south side of the chancel.

entry.ety: Cf. F. décanal. See Dean
entry.def: Pertaining to a dean or deanery.
entry.q: His rectorial as well as decanal residence.

entries.entry: De*can"dri*a‖n. pl. NL., fr. Gr. de`ka ten + �, �, a man Bot A Linnæan class of plants characterized by having ten stamens.

entry.ety: Cf. F. décandre
entry.def: Belonging to the Decandria; having ten stamens.

entry.ety: See Deca-
entry.def: A liquid hydrocarbon, C10H22, of the paraffin series, including several isomeric modifications.

entry.ety: Pref. deca- + angular
entry.def: Having ten angles.

entry.ety: L., lit., of the dean
entry.def: Used of the side of the choir on which the dean's stall is placed; decanal; -- correlative to cantoris; as, the decanal, or decani, side.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Decanted; p. pr. & vb. n. Decanting

entry.def: To pour off gently, as liquor, so as not to disturb the sediment; or to pour from one vessel into another; as, to decant wine.
To decant.

entry.ety: Cf. F. décantation
entry.def: The act of pouring off a clear liquor gently from its lees or sediment, or from one vessel into another.

sn.def: A vessel used to decant liquors, or for receiving decanted liquors; a kind of glass bottle used for holding wine or other liquors, from which drinking glasses are filled.
One who decants liquors.

entry.ety: Pref. deca- + Gr. � leaf: cf. F. décaphylle
entry.def: Having ten leaves.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Decapitated; p. pr. & vb. n. Decapitating
entry.ety: LL. decapitatus, p. p. of decapitare; L. de- + caput head. See Chief

sn.def: To cut off the head of; to behead.
To remove summarily from office.

entry.def: having had the head cut off.

entry.ety: LL. decapitatio: cf. F. décapitation
entry.def: The act of beheading; beheading.

entry.ety: Cf. F. décapode
entry.def: A crustacean with ten feet or legs, as a crab; one of the Decapoda. Also used adjectively, as a decapod crustacean.

entry.note: ☞ They have a carapace, covering and uniting the somites of the head and thorax and inclosing a gill chamber on each side, and usually have five (rarely six) pairs of legs. They are divided into two principal groups: Brachyura and Macrura. Some writers recognize a third (Anomura) intermediate between the others.
entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. de`ka ten + poy`s podo`s, foot

sn.def: The order of Crustacea which includes the shrimps, lobsters, crabs, etc.
A division of the dibranchiate cephalopods including the cuttlefishes and squids. See Decacera.

entry.def: Belonging to the decapods; having ten feet; ten-footed.
To deprive of carbonic acid.
The action or process of depriving a substance of carbon.

entry.cs: Decarbonized iron. See Malleable iron. Decarbonized steel homogenous wrought iron made by a steel process, as that of Bessemer; ingot iron.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Decarbonized; p. pr. & vb. n. Decarbonizing
entry.def: To deprive of carbon; as, to decarbonize steel; to decarbonize the blood.
He who, or that which, decarbonizes a substance.
The act, process, or result of decarburizing.
To deprive of carbon; to remove the carbon from.
To discard.
entry.q: You have cast those by, decarded them.

entry.def: To depose from the rank of cardinal.

entry.ety: L. décastère; Gr. de`ka ten + F. stère a stere
entry.def: A measure of capacity, equal to ten steres, or ten cubic meters.

entry.ety: Pref. deca- + Gr. sti`chos a row, a line of writing, a verse
