A deerlike, or thin, ill-formed neck, as of a horse.
any of various tall perennial herbs constituting the genus Frasera; it is widely distributed in warm dry upland areas of the US Pacific states.
entry.syn: columbo, American columbo, deer's-ears, pyramid plant, American gentian.

entry.def: The skin of a deer, or the leather which is made from it.

sn.def: One who practices deerstalking.

A close-fitting cap, usually woolen, such as is worn in deerstalking, having a low crown and visors both in front and back, and having earflaps which are usually worn tied together over the top; also called fore-and-after deerstalker hat and deerstalker cap; a hunter's cap; formerly also used for any stiff, round hat.

entry.def: The hunting of deer on foot, by stealing upon them unawares.
A plant (Liatris odoratissima) whose fleshy leaves give out a fragrance compared to vanilla.
an electrode with a large interior cavity, shaped like the letter "D", used in opposed pairs to accelerate particles in a cyclotron.
Dice.
A dais.
to reduce in intensity (a crisis or a war).
a reduction in intensity (of a crisis or a war).

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. de`hsis supplication
entry.def: An invocation of, or address to, the Supreme Being.

entry.ety: F. déesse, fem. of dieu god
entry.def: A goddess.
See Dev.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Defaced d�*fāst"; p. pr. & vb. n. Defacing
entry.ety: OE. defacen to disfigure, efface, OF. desfacier; L. dis- + facies face. See Face, and cf. Efface

sn.def: To destroy or mar the face or external appearance of; to disfigure; to injure, spoil, or mar, by effacing or obliterating important features or portions of; as, to deface a monument; to deface an edifice; to deface writing; to deface a note, deed, or bond; to deface a record.
sn.q: This high facedefaced.
So by false learning is good sense defaced.

sn.def: To destroy; to make null.
sn.q: Profane scoffing] doth . . . deface the reverence of religion.
For all his power was utterly defaste defaced].

entry.def: having the external appearance impaired, usually deliberately.

sn.def: The act of defacing, or the condition of being defaced; injury to the surface or exterior; obliteration.
That which mars or disfigures.

entry.def: One who, or that which, defaces or disfigures.

entries.entry: De` fac"to De` fac"to. L Actually; in fact; in reality; as, a king de facto, -- distinguished from a king de jure, or by right.

entry.ety: F. défaillir to fail; pref. dé-L. de) + faillir. See Fail, and cf. Default
entry.def: To cause to fail.

entry.ety: F. défaillance
entry.def: Failure; miscarriage.
entry.q: Possibility of defailance in degree or continuance.

entry.def: Failure.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Defalcated; p. pr. & vb. n. Defalcating
entry.ety: LL. defalcatus, p. p. of defalcare to deduct, orig., to cut off with a sickle; L. de- + falx falcis, a sickle. See Falchion
entry.def: To cut off; to take away or deduct a part of; -- used chiefly of money, accounts, rents, income, etc.
entry.q: To show what may be practicably and safely defalcated from them [the estimates].

entry.def: To commit defalcation; to embezzle money held in trust.
entry.q: Some partnerdefalcating, or the like.

entry.ety: LL. defalcatio: cf. F. défalcation

sn.def: A lopping off; a diminution; abatement; deficit. Specifically: Reduction of a claim by deducting a counterclaim; set- off.
That which is lopped off, diminished, or abated.
An abstraction of money, etc., by an officer or agent having it in trust; an embezzlement.

entry.def: A defaulter or embezzler.

entry.ety: F. défalquer. See Defalcate
entry.def: To lop off; to abate.

entry.note: ☞ In modern usage, written defamation bears the title of libel, and oral defamation that of slander.
entry.ety: OE. diffamacioun, F. diffamation. See Defame
entry.def: Act of injuring another's reputation by any slanderous communication, written or oral; the wrong of maliciously injuring the good name of another; slander; detraction; calumny; aspersion.
Containing defamation; injurious to reputation; calumnious; slanderous; as, defamatory words; defamatory writings.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Defamed; p. pr. & vb. n. Defaming
entry.ety: OE. defamen diffamen, from F. diffamer, or OF. perh. defamer, fr. L. diffamarecf. defamatus infamous); dis-in this word confused with de) + fama a report. See Fame

sn.def: To harm or destroy the good fame or reputation of; to disgrace; especially, to speak evil of maliciously; to dishonor by slanderous reports; to calumniate; to asperse.
To render infamous; to bring into disrepute.
sn.q: My guilt thy growing virtues did defame; My blackness blotted thy unblemish'd name.

sn.def: To charge; to accuse.
sn.q: Rebecca is . . . defamed of sorcery practiced on the person of a noble knight.
sn.syn: To asperse; slander; calumniate; vilify. See Asperse.

entry.def: Dishonor.
One who defames; a slanderer; a detractor; a calumniator.
In a defamatory manner.
Defamatory.

entry.ety: See Defatigate
entry.def: Capable of being wearied or tired out.

entry.ety: L. defatigatus, p. p. of defatigare; de- + fatigare to weary. See Fatigue
entry.def: To weary or tire out; to fatigue.

entry.ety: L. defatigatio
entry.def: Weariness; fatigue.

cs.cd: in case of failure or lack of.
cs.q: Cooks could make artificial birds and fishes in default of the real ones.
cs.cd: to permit an action to be called without appearing to answer.

entry.ety: OE. defaute, OF. defaute defalte, fem., F. défaut, masc., LL. defalta, fr. a verb meaning, to be deficient, to want, fail, fr. L. de- + fallere to deceive. See Fault

sn.def: A failing or failure; omission of that which ought to be done; neglect to do what duty or law requires; as, this evil has happened through the governor's default .
Fault; offense; ill deed; wrong act; failure in virtue or wisdom.
sn.q: And pardon craved for his so rash default.
Regardless of our merit or default.

sn.def: A neglect of, or failure to take, some step necessary to secure the benefit of law, as a failure to appear in court at a day assigned, especially of the defendant in a suit when called to make answer; also of jurors, witnesses, etc.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Defaulted; p. pr. & vb. n. Defaulting

sn.def: To fail in duty; to offend.
sn.q: That he gainst courtesy so foully did default.

sn.def: To fail in fulfilling a contract, agreement, or duty.
To fail to appear in court; to let a case go by default.
To fail to perform or pay; to be guilty of neglect of; to omit; as, to default a dividend.
sn.q: What they have defaulted towards him as no king.

sn.def: To call a defendant or other party whose duty it is to be present in court, and make entry of his default, if he fails to appear; to enter a default against.
To leave out of account; to omit.
sn.q: Defaulting unnecessary and partial discourses.

sn.def: One who makes default; one who fails to appear in court when court when called.
One who fails to perform a duty; a delinquent; particularly, one who fails to account for public money intrusted to his care; a peculator; a defalcator.

entry.note: ☞ Mortgages were usually made in this manner in former times, but the modern practice is to include the conveyance and the defeasance in the same deed.
entry.ety: OF. defesance, fr. defesant, F. défaisant, p. pr. of defaire, F. défaire, to undo. See Defeat

sn.def: A defeat; an overthrow.
sn.q: After his foes' defeasance.

sn.def: A rendering null or void.

A condition, relating to a deed, which being performed, the deed is defeated or rendered void; or a collateral deed, made at the same time with a feoffment, or other conveyance, containing conditions, on the performance of which the estate then created may be defeated.

entry.def: Liable to defeasance; capable of being made void or forfeited.

entry.ety: See Defeasance
entry.def: Capable of being annulled or made void; as, a defeasible title.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Defeated; p. pr. & vb. n. Defeating
entry.ety: From F. défait, OF. desfait, p. p. ofe défaire, OF. desfaire, to undo; L. dis- + facere to do. See Feat Fact, and cf. Disfashion

sn.def: To undo; to disfigure; to destroy.
sn.q: His unkindness may defeat my life.

sn.def: To render null and void, as a title; to frustrate, as hope; to deprive, as of an estate.
sn.q: He finds himself naturally to dread a superior Being that can defeat all his designs, and disappoint all his hopes.
The escheators . . . defeated the right heir of his succession.
In one instance he defeated his own purpose.

sn.def: To overcome or vanquish, as an army; to check, disperse, or ruin by victory; to overthrow.
To resist with success; as, to defeat an assault.
sn.q: Sharp reasons to defeat the law.

entry.ety: Cf. F. défaite, fr. défaire. See Defeat v.

sn.def: An undoing or annulling; destruction.
sn.q: Upon whose property and most dear life A damned defeat was made.

sn.def: Frustration by rendering null and void, or by prevention of success; as, the defeat of a plan or design.
An overthrow, as of an army in battle; loss of a battle; repulse suffered; discomfiture; -- opposed to victory.

entry.def: acceptance of the inevitability of defeat.

entry.ety: OF. desfaiture a killing, disguising, prop., an undoing. See Defeat, and cf. Disfeature

sn.def: Overthrow; defeat.
sn.q: Nothing but loss in theirdefeature.

sn.def: Disfigurement; deformity.
sn.q: Strangedefeaturesin my face.

entry.def: Changed in features; deformed.
entry.q: Features when defeatured in the . . . way I have described.

entry.ety: L. defaecatus, p. p. of defaecare to defecate; de- + faex faecis, dregs, lees
entry.def: Freed from anything that can pollute, as dregs, lees, etc.; refined; purified.
entry.q: Till the soul be defecate from the dregs of sense.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Defecated; p. pr. & vb. n. Defecating

sn.def: To clear from impurities, as lees, dregs, etc.; to clarify; to purify; to refine.
sn.q: To defecate the dark and muddy oil of amber.

sn.def: To free from extraneous or polluting matter; to clear; to purify, as from that which materializes.
sn.q: We defecate the notion from materiality.
Defecated from all the impurities of sense.

sn.def: To become clear, pure, or free.
To void excrement.

entry.ety: L. defaecatio: cf. F. défécation

sn.def: The act of separating from impurities, as lees or dregs; purification.
The act or process of voiding excrement.

entry.def: That which cleanses or purifies; esp., an apparatus for removing the feculencies of juices and sirups.

entry.ety: L. defectus, fr. deficere defectum, to desert, fail, be wanting; de- + facere to make, do. See Fact Feat, and cf. Deficit

sn.def: Want or absence of something necessary for completeness or perfection; deficiency; -- opposed to superfluity.
sn.q: Errors have been corrected, and defects supplied.

sn.def: Failing; fault; imperfection, whether physical or moral; blemish; as, a defect in the ear or eye; a defect in timber or iron; a defect of memory or judgment.
sn.q: Trust not yourself; but, your defects to know, Make use of every friend -- and every foe.
Among boys little tenderness is shown to personal defects.

entry.def: To fail; to become deficient.
entry.q: Defectedhonor.

sn.def: to abandon one country or faction, and join another.

entry.def: To injure; to damage.
entry.q: None can my lifedefect.

entry.def: Deficiency; imperfection.
Liable to defect; imperfect.
entry.q: Adefectibleunderstanding.

entry.ety: L. defectio: cf. F. défection. See Defect
entry.def: Act of abandoning a person or cause to which one is bound by allegiance or duty, or to which one has attached himself; desertion; failure in duty; a falling away; apostasy; backsliding.
entry.q: Defectionand falling away from God.
The general defection of the whole realm.

entry.def: One who advocates or encourages defection.
Having defects; imperfect.
entry.q: Some onedefectiouspiece.

entry.ety: L. defectivus: cf. F. défectif. See Defect

sn.def: Wanting in something; incomplete; lacking a part; deficient; imperfect; faulty; -- applied either to natural or moral qualities; as, a defective limb; defective timber; a defective copy or account; a defective character; defective rules.
Lacking some of the usual forms of declension or conjugation; as, a defective noun or verb.

entry.note: ☞ Under the term defectives are included deaf-mutes, the blind, the feeble-minded, the insane, and sometimes, esp. in criminology, criminals and paupers.

sn.def: Anything that is defective or lacking in some respect.
One who is lacking physically or mentally.

entry.ety: Cf. F. défectuosité
entry.def: Great imperfection.

entry.ety: Cf. F. défectueux
entry.def: Full of defects; imperfect.

entry.ety: L. defoedare defoedatum, to defile; de- + foedare to foul, foedus foul
entry.def: The act of making foul; pollution.
See Defense.
same as defenseless; as, a defenceless child.

entry.usage: To defend is literally to ward off; to protect is to cover so as to secure against approaching danger. We defend those who are attacked; we protect those who are liable to injury or invasion. A fortress is defended by its guns, and protected by its wall.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Defended; p. pr. & vb. n. Defending
entry.ety: F. défendre, L. defendere; de- + fendereonly in comp.) to strike; perh. akin to Gr. qei`nein to strike, and E. dint. Cf. Dint Defense Fend

sn.def: To ward or fend off; to drive back or away; to repel.
sn.q: Th' other strove for to defend The force of Vulcan with his might and main.

sn.def: To prohibit; to forbid.
sn.q: Which God defend that I should wring from him.

sn.def: To repel danger or harm from; to protect; to secure against attack; to maintain against force or argument; to uphold; to guard; as, to defend a town; to defend a cause; to defend character; to defend the absent; -- sometimes followed by from or against; as, to defend one's self from, or against, one's enemies.
sn.q: The lord mayor craves aid . . . to defend the city.
God defend the right!
A village near it was defended by the river.

sn.def: To deny the right of the plaintiff in regard to (the suit, or the wrong charged); to oppose or resist, as a claim at law; to contest, as a suit.
sn.q: As birds flying, so will the Lord of hosts defend Jerusalem; defending also he will deliver it.
Leave not the faithful side That gave thee being, still shades thee and protects.

entry.ety: Cf. F. défendable
entry.def: Capable of being defended; defensible.

entry.ety: F. défendant, p. pr. of défendre. See Defend

sn.def: Serving, or suitable, for defense; defensive.
sn.q: With men of courage and with means defendant.

sn.def: Making defense.

entry.note: ☞ The term is applied to any party of whom a demand is made in court, whether the party denies and defends the claim, or admits it, and suffers a default; also to a party charged with a criminal offense.

sn.def: One who defends; a defender.
sn.q: The rampiers and ditches which the defendants had cast up.

sn.def: A person required to make answer in an action or suit; -- opposed to plaintiff.

entry.def: One who is defended.

entry.ety: Cf. Fender
entry.def: One who defends; one who maintains, supports, protects, or vindicates; a champion; an advocate; a vindicator.
entry.q: Provinces . . . left without their ancient and puissant defenders.

entry.def: A female defender.
entry.q: Defendress of the faith.

entry.def: to throw (something or someone) out of a window.
the act of throwing (something or someone) out of a window.

entry.ety: L. defensare defensatum, to defend diligently, intens. of defendere. See Defend
entry.def: That which serves to protect or defend.

entry.ety: F. défense, OF. defense, fem., defens, masc., fr. L. defensacf. LL. defensum), from defendere. See Defend, and cf. Fence

sn.def: The act of defending, or the state of being defended; protection, as from violence or danger.
sn.q: In cases of defense 't is best to weigh The enemy more mighty than he seems.

sn.def: That which defends or protects; anything employed to oppose attack, ward off violence or danger, or maintain security; a guard; a protection.
sn.q: War would arise in defense of the right.
God, the widow's champion and defense.

sn.def: Protecting plea; vindication; justification.
sn.q: Men, brethren, and fathers, hear ye my defense.

sn.def: The defendant's answer or plea; an opposing or denial of the truth or validity of the plaintiff's or prosecutor's case; the method of proceeding adopted by the defendant to protect himself against the plaintiff's action.
Act or skill in making defense; defensive plan or policy; practice in self defense, as in fencing, boxing, etc.
sn.q: A man of great defense.
By how much defense is better than no skill.

sn.def: Prohibition; a prohibitory ordinance.
sn.q: Severe defenses . . . against wearing any linen under a certain breadth.

entry.def: To furnish with defenses; to fortify.
entry.q: Better manned and more strongly defensed.

entry.def: Destitute of defense; unprepared to resist attack; unable to oppose; unprotected.

sn.def: unarmed; used of persons or the military.

entry.ety: Cf. F. défenseur, L. defensor. Cf. Defensor
entry.def: Defender.
Capability of being defended.

entry.ety: Cf. F. défensable, LL. defensabilis defensibilis. See Defense, and cf. Defendable

sn.def: Capable of being defended; as, a defensible city, or a defensible cause.
Capable of offering defense.

entry.def: Capability of being defended; defensibility.

entry.ety: Cf. F. défensif

sn.def: Serving to defend or protect; proper for defense; opposed to offensive; as, defensive armor.
sn.q: A moat defensive to a house.

sn.def: Carried on by resisting attack or aggression; -- opposed to offensive; as, defensive war.
In a state or posture of defense.

cs.cd: to be or stand in a state or posture of defense or resistance, in opposition to aggression or attack.

entry.def: That which defends; a safeguard.
entry.q: Wars preventive, upon just fears, are true defensives.

entry.def: On the defensive.

entry.ety: L. See Defenser

sn.def: A defender.
A defender or an advocate in court; a guardian or protector.
The patron of a church; an officer having charge of the temporal affairs of a church.

entry.ety: L. defensorius
entry.def: Tending to defend; defensive; as, defensory preparations.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Deferred; p. pr. & vb. n. Deferring
entry.ety: OE. differren, F. différer, fr. L. differre to delay, bear different ways; dis- + ferre to bear. See Bear to support, and cf. Differ Defer to offer
entry.def: To put off; to postpone to a future time; to delay the execution of; to delay; to withhold.
entry.q: Defer the spoil of the city until night.
God . . . will not long defer To vindicate the glory of his name.

entry.def: To put off; to delay to act; to wait.
entry.q: Pius was able to defer and temporize at leisure.

entry.ety: F. déférer to pay deference, to yield, to bring before a judge, fr. L. deferre to bring down; de- + ferre to bear. See Bear to support, and cf. Defer to delay, Delate

sn.def: To render or offer.
sn.q: Worship deferred to the Virgin.

sn.def: To lay before; to submit in a respectful manner; to refer; -- with to.
sn.q: Hereupon the commissioners . . . deferred the matter to the Earl of Northumberland.

entry.def: To yield deference to the wishes of another; to submit to the opinion of another, or to authority; -- with to.
entry.q: The house, deferring to legal right, acquiesced.

entry.usage: Deference marks an inclination to yield one's opinion, and to acquiesce in the sentiments of another in preference to one's own. Respect marks the estimation that we have for another, which makes us look to him as worthy of high confidence for the qualities of his mind and heart. Reverence denotes a mingling of fear with a high degree of respect and esteem. Age, rank, dignity, and personal merit call for deference; respect should be paid to the wise and good; reverence is due to God, to the authors of our being, and to the sanctity of the laws.
entry.ety: F. déférence. See 3d Defer
entry.def: A yielding of judgment or preference from respect to the wishes or opinion of another; submission in opinion; regard; respect; complaisance.
entry.q: Deference to the authority of thoughtful and sagacious men.
Deference is the most complicate, the most indirect, and the most elegant of all compliments.

entry.ety: L. deferens, p. pr. of deferre. See 3d Defer
entry.def: Serving to carry; bearing.
entry.q: Bodiesdeferent.

sn.def: That which carries or conveys.
sn.q: Though air be the most favorable deferent of sounds.

sn.def: An imaginary circle surrounding the earth, in whose periphery either the heavenly body or the center of the heavenly body's epicycle was supposed to be carried round.

entry.ety: See Deference
entry.def: Expressing deference; accustomed to defer.
With deference.

entry.ety: See 1st Defer
entry.def: The act of delaying; postponement.
entry.q: My grief, joined with the instant business, Begs a deferment.

entry.def: One who defers or puts off.

entry.ety: L. defervescere to grow cool

sn.def: A subsiding from a state of ebullition; loss of heat; lukewarmness.
sn.q: A defervescency in holy actions.

sn.def: The subsidence of a febrile process; as, the stage of defervescence in pneumonia.

entry.def: To deprive of the feudal character or form.

cs.cd: to defy; to disregard recklessly or contemptuously.

entry.ety: OF. defiance desfiance, challenge, fr. desfier to challenge, F. défier. See Defy

sn.def: The act of defying, putting in opposition, or provoking to combat; a challenge; a provocation; a summons to combat.
sn.q: A war without a just defiance made.
Stood for her cause, and flung defiance down.

sn.def: A state of opposition; willingness to flight; disposition to resist; contempt of opposition.
sn.q: He breathed defiance to my ears.

sn.def: A casting aside; renunciation; rejection.
sn.q: Defianceto thy kindness.

entry.ety: Cf. F. défiant, p. pr. of défier. See Defy
entry.def: Full of defiance; bold; insolent; as, a defiant spirit or act.
entry.q: In attitude stern and defiant.

entry.ety: See Defy
entry.def: Bidding or manifesting defiance.
To deprive of fibrin, as fresh blood or lymph by stirring with twigs.
The act or process of depriving of fibrin.
To defibrinate.
Same as Deficiency.
entry.q: Thou in thyself art perfect, and in thee Is no deficience found.

entries.entry:
De*fi"cien*cy
Deficiency of a curve Geom the amount by which the number of double points on a curve is short of the maximum for curves of the same degree.
n.; pl.Deficiencies #. See Deficient
The state of being deficient; inadequacy; want; failure; imperfection; shortcoming; defect. Adeficiencyof blood. Marlborough] was so miserably ignorant, that his deficiencies made him the ridicule of his contemporaries.

entry.cs: Deficient number. Arith See under Abundant.
entry.ety: L. deficiens -entis, p. pr. of deficere to be wanting. See Defect
entry.def: Wanting, to make up completeness; wanting, as regards a requirement; not sufficient; inadequate; defective; imperfect; incomplete; lacking; as, deficient parts; deficient estate; deficient strength; deficient in judgment.
entry.q: The style was indeed deficient in ease and variety.

entry.ety: Lit., it is wanting, 3d person pres. indic. of L. deficere, cf. F. déficit. See Defect
entry.def: Deficiency in amount or quality; a falling short; lack; as, a deficit in taxes, revenue, etc.

entry.ety: See Defy
entry.def: One who dares and defies; a contemner; as, a defier of the laws.
Disfiguration; mutilation.

entry.ety: Pref. de-intens.) + figure
entry.def: To delineate.
entry.q: These two stones as they are here defigured.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Defiladed; p. pr. & vb. n. Defilading
entry.ety: Cf. F. défiler to defile, and défilade act of defiling. See 1st Defile
entry.def: To raise, as a rampart, so as to shelter interior works commanded from some higher point.

The art or act of determining the directions and heights of the lines of rampart with reference to the protection of the interior from exposure to an enemy's fire from any point within range, or from any works which may be erected.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Defiled d�*fīld"; p. pr. & vb. n. Defiling
entry.ety: F. défiler; pref. dé-, for des-L. dis-) + file a row or line. See File a row
entry.def: To march off in a line, file by file; to file off.
Same as Defilade.

entry.ety: Cf. F. défilé, fr. défiler to defile

sn.def: Any narrow passage or gorge in which troops can march only in a file, or with a narrow front; a long, narrow pass between hills, rocks, etc.
The act of defilading a fortress, or of raising the exterior works in order to protect the interior. See Defilade.

entry.ety: OE. defoulen -foilen, to tread down, OF. defouler; de- + fouler to trample (see Full v. t.), and OE. defoulen to foul (influenced in form by the older verb defoilen). See File to defile, Foul Defoul

sn.def: To make foul or impure; to make filthy; to dirty; to befoul; to pollute.
sn.q: They that touch pitch will be defiled.

sn.def: To soil or sully; to tarnish, as reputation; to taint.
sn.q: He is . . . among the greatest prelates of this age, however his character may be defiled by . . . dirty hands.

sn.def: To injure in purity of character; to corrupt.
sn.q: Defile not yourselves with the idols of Egypt.

sn.def: To corrupt the chastity of; to debauch; to violate; to rape.
sn.q: The husband murder'd and the wife defiled.

sn.def: To make ceremonially unclean; to pollute.
sn.q: That which dieth of itself, or is torn with beasts, he shall not eat to defile therewith.

sn.def: morally blemished.
ritually unclean. Opposite of clean.

entry.ety: Cf. F. défilement. See Defile
entry.def: The protection of the interior walls of a fortification from an enfilading fire, as by covering them, or by a high parapet on the exposed side.

entry.ety: From 3d Defile
entry.def: The act of defiling, or state of being defiled, whether physically or morally; pollution; foulness; dirtiness; uncleanness.
entry.q: Defilements of the flesh.
The chaste can not rake into such filth without danger of defilement.

entry.def: One who defiles; one who corrupts or violates; that which pollutes.

entry.ety: L. de- + filius son
entry.def: Abstraction of a child from its parents.

entry.ety: From Define
entry.def: Capable of being defined, limited, or explained; determinable; describable by definition; ascertainable; as, definable limits; definable distinctions or regulations; definable words.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Defined; p. pr. & vb. n. Defining
entry.ety: OE. definer, usually, to end, to finish, F. définir to define, L. definire to limit, define; de- + finire to limit, end, finis boundary, limit, end. See Final Finish

sn.def: To fix the bounds of; to bring to a termination; to end.
sn.q: Todefinecontroversies.

sn.def: To determine or clearly exhibit the boundaries of; to mark the limits of; as, to define the extent of a kingdom or country.
To determine with precision; to mark out with distinctness; to ascertain or exhibit clearly; as, the defining power of an optical instrument.
sn.q: Rings . . . very distinct and well defined.

sn.def: To determine the precise signification of; to fix the meaning of; to describe accurately; to explain; to expound or interpret; as, to define a word, a phrase, or a scientific term.
sn.q: They define virtue to be life ordered according to nature.

entry.def: To determine; to decide.
The act of defining; definition; description.
One who defines or explains.

entry.cs: Definite article Gram the article the, which is used to designate a particular person or thing, or a particular class of persons or things; -- also called a definitive. See Definitive n. - - Definite inflorescence. Bot See Determinate inflorescence, under Determinate. Law of definite proportions Chem the essential law of chemical combination that every definite compound always contains the same elements in the same proportions by weight; and, if two or more elements form more than one compound with each other, the relative proportions of each are fixed. Compare Law of multiple proportions, under Multiple.
entry.ety: L. definitis, p. p. of definire: cf. F. défini. See Define

sn.def: Having certain or distinct; determinate in extent or greatness; limited; fixed; as, definite dimensions; a definite measure; a definite period or interval.
sn.q: Elements combine in definite proportions.

sn.def: Having certain limits in signification; determinate; certain; precise; fixed; exact; clear; as, a definite word, term, or expression.
Determined; resolved.
Serving to define or restrict; limiting; determining; as, the definite article.

entry.def: A thing defined or determined.
In a definite manner; with precision; precisely; determinately.
The state of being definite; determinateness; precision; certainty.

entry.usage: A definition is designed to settle a thing in its compass and extent; an explanation is intended to remove some obscurity or misunderstanding, and is therefore more extended and minute; a description enters into striking particulars with a view to interest or impress by graphic effect. It is not therefore true, though often said, that description is only an extended definition. “Logicians distinguish definitions into essential and accidental. An essential definition states what are regarded as the constituent parts of the essence of that which is to be defined; and an accidental definition lays down what are regarded as circumstances belonging to it, viz., properties or accidents, such as causes, effects, etc.”
entry.ety: L. definitio: cf. F. définition

sn.def: The act of defining; determination of the limits; as, a telescope accurate in definition .

Act of ascertaining and explaining the signification; a description of a thing by its properties; an explanation of the meaning of a word or term; as, the definition of “circle;” the definition of “wit;” an exact definition; a loose definition.
sn.q: Definition being nothing but making another understand by words what the term defined stands for.

sn.def: Description; sort.
sn.q: A new creature of anotherdefinition.

sn.def: An exact enunciation of the constituents which make up the logical essence.
Distinctness or clearness, as of an image formed by an optical instrument; precision in detail.

entry.def: Relating to definition; of the nature of a definition; employed in defining.

entry.ety: L. definitivus: cf. F. définitif

sn.def: Determinate; positive; final; conclusive; unconditional; express.
sn.q: A strict and definitive truth.
Some definitive . . . scheme of reconciliation.

sn.def: Limiting; determining; as, a definitive word.
Determined; resolved.

entry.note: ☞ Definitives . . . are commonly called by grammarians articles. . . . They are of two kinds, either those properly and strictly so called, or else pronominal articles, such as this that any other some all no none, etc.
entry.def: A word used to define or limit the extent of the signification of a common noun, such as the definite article, and some pronouns.
In a definitive manner.
The quality of being definitive.
Definiteness.
entry.q: Definitude . . . is a knowledge of minute differences.

entry.ety: L. defixus, p. p. of defigere to fix; de- + figere to fix
entry.def: To fix; to fasten; to establish.
entry.q: Todefixtheir princely seat . . . in that extreme province.

entry.def: The state or quality of being deflagrable.
entry.q: The ready deflagrability . . . of saltpeter.

entry.ety: See Deflagrate
entry.def: Burning with a sudden and sparkling combustion, as niter; hence, slightly explosive; liable to snap and crackle when heated, as salt.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Deflagrated; p. pr. & vb. n. Deflagrating
entry.ety: L. deflagratus, p. p. of deflagrare to burn up; de- + flagrare to flame, burn
entry.def: To burn with a sudden and sparkling combustion, as niter; also, to snap and crackle with slight explosions when heated, as salt.
To cause to burn with sudden and sparkling combustion, as by the action of intense heat; to burn or vaporize suddenly; as, to deflagrate refractory metals in the oxyhydrogen flame.

entry.ety: L. deflagratio: cf. F. déflagration

sn.def: A burning up; conflagration.
sn.q: Innumerable deluges anddeflagrations.

sn.def: The act or process of deflagrating.

entry.def: A form of the voltaic battery having large plates, used for producing rapid and powerful combustion.

entry.ety: Pref. de- down + L. flare flatus to blow
entry.def: To reduce from an inflated condition; used literally and metaphorically; as, to deflate a tire; to deflate expectations.

sn.def: brought low in spirit.
sn.illu: left us fatigued and deflated spiritually

sn.def: the act or process of deflating.
a fall in the average prices of goods and services; -- usually associated with contraction of economic activity. Opposite of inflation. Compare disinflation.
the reduction of available credit or a contraction of economic activity resulting from or associated with a decline of prices.
the act of letting the air out of something.
the erosion of land structures such as sand or soil due to the action of wind.
of or pertaining to deflation; as, deflationary signs.
associated with or tending to cause decreases in consumer prices or increases in the purchasing power of money; as, deflationary measures. Opposite of inflationary.

entry.def: a statistical factor designed to remove the effect of inflation; inflation adjusted variables are in constant dollars; as, the GNP deflator..

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Deflected; p. pr. & vb. n. Deflecting
entry.ety: L. deflectere; de- + flectere to bend or turn. See Flexible
entry.def: To cause to turn aside; to bend; as, rays of light are often deflected; to deflect a punch; to deflect criticism by acknowledging a mistake.
entry.q: Sitting with their knees deflected under them.

entry.def: To turn aside; to deviate from a right or a horizontal line, or from a proper position, course or direction; to swerve.
entry.q: At some part of the Azores, the needle deflecteth not, but lieth in the true meridian.
To deflect from the line of truth and reason.

entry.def: Capable of being deflected.

sn.def: Turned aside; deviating from a direct line or course.
Bent downward; deflexed.

entry.ety: L. deflexio, fr. deflectere: cf. F. déflexion

sn.def: The act of turning aside, or state of being turned aside; a turning from a right line or proper course; a bending, esp. downward; deviation.
sn.q: The other leads to the same point, through certain deflections.

sn.def: The deviation of a shot or ball from its true course.
A deviation of the rays of light toward the surface of an opaque body; inflection; diffraction.
The bending which a beam or girder undergoes from its own weight or by reason of a load.

entry.def: The act of freeing from inflections.
To free from inflections.
entry.q: Deflectionized languages are said to be analytic.

cs.cd: forces that cause a body to deviate from its course.

entry.def: Causing deflection.
That which deflects, as a diaphragm in a furnace, or a cone in a lamp (to deflect and mingle air and gases and help combustion).
Bent abruptly downward.
See Deflection.

entry.ety: From L. deflectere deflexum. See Deflect
entry.def: A bending or turning aside; deflection.

entry.ety: LL. defloratus, p. p. of deflorare. See Deflour
entry.def: Past the flowering state; having shed its pollen.

entry.ety: LL. defloratio: cf. F. défloration

sn.def: The act of deflouring; as, the defloration of a virgin.
That which is chosen as the flower or choicest part; careful culling or selection.
sn.q: The laws of Normandy are, in a great measure, the defloration of the English laws.

entry.ety: Pref. de- + flower
entry.def: Same as Deflower.
entry.q: He died innocent and before the sweetness of his soul was defloured and ravished from him.

entry.def: See Deflowerer.

entry.ety: Pref. de- + flow: cf. L. defluere
entry.def: To flow down.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Deflowered; p. pr. & vb. n. Deflowering
entry.ety: F. déflorer, LL. deflorare; L. de- + flos floris, flower. See Flower, and cf. Deflorate

sn.def: To deprive of flowers.
sn.q: An earthquake . . . deflowering the gardens.

sn.def: To take away the prime beauty and grace of; to rob of the choicest ornament.
To deprive of virginity, as a woman; to violate; to ravish; also, to seduce.
sn.q: If a man had deflowered a virgin.

entry.def: One who deflowers; a ravisher.

entry.ety: L. defluus, fr. defluere to flow down; de- + fluere to flow
entry.def: Flowing down; falling off.

entry.ety: L. defluxus, fr. defluere defluxum
entry.def: Downward flow.

entry.ety: L. defluxio
entry.def: A discharge or flowing of humors or fluid matter, as from the nose in catarrh; -- sometimes used synonymously with inflammation.
Deftly.
Defedation.
Deprived of leaves, as by their natural fall.

sn.def: of or pertaining to deformation (in all senses).

entry.ety: LL. defoliare, to shed leaves; L. de- + folium leaf: cf. F. défoliation
entry.def: to cause (a plant) to shed its leaves.

entry.note: The deliberate defoliation of plants has been used in war (as in Vietnam) to deprive an enemy of cover and allow attack from the air; also, to destroy narcotic-producing plants as a tactic against illegal drug production. The chemical defoliating agents are often sprayed over large areas from airplanes.
entry.ety: LL. defoliare defoliatum, to shed leaves; L. de- + folium leaf: cf. F. défoliation
entry.def: The separation of ripened leaves from a branch or stem; the falling or shedding of the leaves.

sn.def: the act or process of causing plants to lose their leaves, especially by application of a chemical agent.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Deforced; p. pr. & vb. n. Deforcing
entry.ety: OF. deforcier; de- or des-L. de or dis-) + forcier, F. forcer. See Force v.
entry.def: To keep from the rightful owner; to withhold wrongfully the possession of, as of lands or a freehold.
To resist the execution of the law; to oppose by force, as an officer in the execution of his duty.

entry.ety: OF
entry.def: A keeping out by force or wrong; a wrongful withholding, as of lands or tenements, to which another has a right.
Resistance to an officer in the execution of law.
Same as Deforciant.

entry.ety: OF. deforciant, p. pr. of deforcier. See Deforce
entry.def: One who keeps out of possession the rightful owner of an estate.
One against whom a fictitious action of fine was brought.
Same as Deforcement n.
To clear of forests; to disforest.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Deformed; p. pr. & vb. n. Deforming
entry.ety: L. deformare; de- + formare to form, shape, fr. forma: cf. F. déformer. See Form

sn.def: To spoil the form of; to mar in form; to misshape; to disfigure.
sn.q: Deformed, unfinished, sent before my time Into this breathing world.

sn.def: To render displeasing; to deprive of comeliness, grace, or perfection; to dishonor.
sn.q: Above those passions that this world deform.

entry.ety: L. deformis; de- + forma form: cf. OF. deforme, F. difforme. Cf. Difform
entry.def: Deformed; misshapen; shapeless; horrid.
entry.q: Sight so deform what heart of rock could long Dry-eyed behold?

entry.ety: L. deformatio: cf. F. déformation

sn.def: The act of deforming, or state of anything deformed.
Transformation; change of shape.

entry.def: Unnatural or distorted in form; having a deformity; misshapen; disfigured; as, a deformed person; a deformed head.
One who deforms.

entries.entry:
De*form"i*ty n.; pl.Deformities #. L. deformitas, fr. deformis: cf. OF. deformeté deformité, F. difformité. See Deform v. & a., and cf. Disformity
The state of being deformed; want of proper form or symmetry; any unnatural form or shape; distortion; irregularity of shape or features; ugliness. To make an envious mountain on my back, Where sits deformity to mock my body.
Anything that destroys beauty, grace, or propriety; irregularity; absurdity; gross deviation from order or the established laws of propriety; as, deformity in an edifice; deformity of character.
Confounded, that her Maker's eyes Should look so near upon her foul deformities.

entry.ety: From Deforce
Written also deforsor
entry.def: A deforciant.

entry.ety: See Defile v. t.

sn.def: To tread down.
To make foul; to defile.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Defrauded; p. pr. & vb. n. Defrauding
entry.ety: L. defraudare; de- + fraudare to cheat, fr. fraus fraudis, fraud: cf. OF. defrauder. See Fraud
entry.def: To deprive of some right, interest, or property, by a deceitful device; to withhold from wrongfully; to injure by embezzlement; to cheat; to overreach; as, to defraud a servant, or a creditor, or the state; -- with of before the thing taken or withheld.
entry.q: We have defrauded no man.
Churches seem injured and defrauded of their rights.

entry.ety: L. defraudatio: cf. F. défraudation
entry.def: The act of defrauding; a taking by fraud.
One who defrauds; a cheat; an embezzler; a peculator.

entry.ety: Cf. OF. defraudement
entry.def: Privation by fraud; defrauding.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Defrayed; p. pr. & vb. n. Defraying
entry.ety: F. défrayer; pref. dé-L. de or dis-) + frais expense, fr. LL. fredum fridum, expense, fine by which an offender obtained peace from his sovereign, or more likely, atoned for an offense against the public peace, fr. OHG. fridu peace, G. friede. See Affray

sn.def: To pay or discharge; to serve in payment of; to provide for, as a charge, debt, expenses, costs, etc.
sn.q: For the discharge of his expenses, and defraying his cost, he allowed him . . . four times as much.

sn.def: To avert or appease, as by paying off; to satisfy; as, to defray wrath.

entry.def: The act of defraying; payment; as, the defrayal of necessary costs.
One who pays off expenses.
Payment of charges.
To divest of the frock, i. e. to deprive (a priest, minister, etc.) of official ecclesiastical authority; -- of church officials.
To remove the frost or ice from; as, to defrost the car window; to defrost a refrigerator.

sn.def: To become free of frost or ice; as, it took four hours for the refrigerator to defrost .
To thaw; -- used especially of items removed from a freezer, such as frozen foods.

entry.def: A device that removes ice or frost (as from a windshield or a refrigerator or the wings of an airplane).

entry.ety: OE. daft deft, becoming, mild, gentle, stupid (cf. OE. daffe deffe, fool, coward), AS. dæftin derivatives only) mild, gentle, fitting, seasonable; akin to dafen gedafen, becoming, fit, Goth. gadaban to be fit. Cf. Daft Daff Dapper

sn.def: Apt; fit; spruce; neat.
sn.q: Thedeftestway.
Deftestfeats.
Let me be deft and debonair.

sn.def: dexterous; clever; handy; as, a deft feat of legerdemain.
sn.q: The limping god, so deft at his new ministry.

entry.ety: Cf. Defly
entry.def: Aptly; fitly; dexterously; neatly.
entry.q: Deftlydancing.
Thyself and office deftly show.

entry.def: The quality of being deft.

entries.entry:
De*funct" d�*fŭṉkt". a. L. defunctus, p. p. of defungi to acquit one's self of, to perform, finish, depart, die; de + fungi to perform, discharge: cf. F. défunt. See Function
Having finished the course of life; dead; deceased.
Defunctorgans. The boar, defunct, lay tripped up, near.
No longer in effect or use; no longer operating; as, a defunct business; a defunct law.

entry.def: A dead person; one deceased.

entry.ety: L. defunctio performance, death
entry.def: Death.
entry.q: After defunction of King Pharamond.

entry.def: Funereal.
entry.q: Defunctivemusic.

entry.ety: Cf. Diffuse

sn.def: To disorder; to make shapeless.
To remove the fuse from; to deactivate (a bomb or other explosive device) or make it ineffective.
To make less dangerous; as, to defuse a tense confrontation between demonstrators and police.
The act of deactivating or making ineffective (as a bomb).

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Defied d�*fīd"; p. pr. & vb. n. Defying
entry.ety: F. défier, OF. deffier desfier, LL. disfidare to disown faith or fidelity, to dissolve the bond of allegiance, as between the vassal and his lord; hence, to challenge, defy; fr. L. dis- + fides faith. See Faith, and cf. Diffident Affiance

sn.def: To renounce or dissolve all bonds of affiance, faith, or obligation with; to reject, refuse, or renounce.
sn.q: I defy the surety and the bond.
For thee I have defied my constant mistress.

sn.def: To provoke to combat or strife; to call out to combat; to challenge; to dare; to brave; to set at defiance; to treat with contempt; as, to defy an enemy; to defy the power of a magistrate; to defy the arguments of an opponent; to defy public opinion.
sn.q: I once againDefy thee to the trial of mortal fight.
I defy the enemies of our constitution to show the contrary.

entry.def: A challenge.

entries.entry:
dé`ga`gé"‖a. F., p. p. of dégager to disengage. See De-, 1st Gage, and cf. Disgage
Unconstrained; easy; free. A graceful and dégagé manner.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. degarnished; p. pr. & vb. n. degarnishing
entry.ety: F. dégarnir; pref. dé- des-L. dis-) + garnir to furnish. See Garnish, and cf. Disgarnish

sn.def: To strip or deprive of entirely, as of furniture, ornaments, etc.; to disgarnish; as, to degarnish a house, etc.
To deprive of a garrison, or of troops necessary for defense; as, to degarnish a city or fort.

entry.def: The act of depriving, as of furniture, apparatus, or a garrison.

sn.def: To make a (steel) ship's hull nonmagnetic by applying an opposing magnetic field.
To remove irregular magnetization in (the electron gun of a cathode-ray tube); -- used to improve picture quality, especially in computer monitors.

entry.def: the process of making a (steel) ship's hull nonmagnetic by producing an opposing magnetic field.

entry.ety: See Degenerate
entry.def: To degenerate.
entry.q: Degenderingto hate.
He degenereth into beastliness.

entry.ety: From Degenerate a.

sn.def: The act of becoming degenerate; a growing worse.
sn.q: Willful degeneracy from goodness.

sn.def: The state of having become degenerate; decline in good qualities; deterioration; meanness.
sn.q: Degeneracy of spirit in a state of slavery.
To recover mankind out of their universal corruption and degeneracy.

entry.ety: L. degeneratus, p. p. of degenerare to degenerate, cause to degenerate, fr. degener base, degenerate, that departs from its race or kind; de- + genus race, kind. See Kin relationship
entry.def: Having become worse than one's kind, or one's former state; having declined in worth; having lost in goodness; deteriorated; degraded; unworthy; base; low.
entry.q: Faint-hearted and degenerate king.
A degenerate and degraded state.
Degenerate from their ancient blood.
These degenerate days.
I had planted thee a noble vine . . . : how then art thou turned into the degenerate plant of a strange vine unto me?

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Degenerated; p. pr. & vb. n. Degenerating

sn.def: To be or grow worse than one's kind, or than one was originally; hence, to be inferior; to grow poorer, meaner, or more vicious; to decline in good qualities; to deteriorate.
sn.q: When wit transgresseth decency, it degenerates into insolence and impiety.

sn.def: To fall off from the normal quality or the healthy structure of its kind; to become of a lower type.

a person who has declined from a high standard, especially a sexual deviate; -- usually used disparagingly or opprobriously of persons whose sexual behavior does not conform to the norms of accepted morals.
a person or thing that has fallen from a higher to a lower state, or reverted to an earlier type or stage of development or culture.

entry.def: In a degenerate manner; unworthily.
Degeneracy.

cs.cd: See under Amyloid Caseous, etc.

entry.ety: Cf. F. dégénération

sn.def: The act or state of growing worse, or the state of having become worse; decline; degradation; debasement; degeneracy; deterioration.
sn.q: Our degeneration and apostasy.

sn.def: That condition of a tissue or an organ in which its vitality has become either diminished or perverted; a substitution of a lower for a higher form of structure; as, fatty degeneration of the liver.
A gradual deterioration, from natural causes, of any class of animals or plants or any particular organ or organs; hereditary degradation of type.
The thing degenerated.
sn.q: Cockle, aracus, . . . and other degenerations.

entry.def: A believer in the theory of degeneration, or hereditary degradation of type; as, the degenerationists hold that savagery is the result of degeneration from a superior state.
Undergoing or producing degeneration; tending to degenerate.

entry.ety: L. degener. See Degenerate
entry.def: Degenerate; base.
entry.q: Degenerouspassions.
Degenerouspractices.

entry.def: Basely.
To extract the germs from, as from wheat grains.
A machine for breaking open the kernels of wheat or other grain and removing the germs.
To remove the glaze from, as pottery or porcelain, so as to give a dull finish.
The process of giving a dull or ground surface to glass by acid or by mechanical means.
Deprived of glory; dishonored.
entry.q: With thornsdegloried.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Deglutinated; p. pr. & vb. n. Deglutinating
entry.ety: L. deglutinatus, p. p. of deglutinare to deglutinate; de- + glutinare to glue, gluten glue
entry.def: To loosen or separate by dissolving the glue which unties; to unglue.
The act of ungluing.

entry.ety: L. deglutire to swallow down; de- + glutire to swallow: cf. F. déglutition. See Glut
entry.def: The act or process of swallowing food; the power of swallowing.
entry.q: The muscles employed in the act of deglutition.

entry.def: Pertaining to deglutition.
Serving for, or aiding in, deglutition.

cs.cd: the transformation of energy into some form in which it is less available for doing work.

entry.ety: LL. degradatio, from degradare: cf. F. dégradation. See Degrade

sn.def: The act of reducing in rank, character, or reputation, or of abasing; a lowering from one's standing or rank in office or society; diminution; as, the degradation of a peer, a knight, a general, or a bishop.
sn.q: He saw many removes and degradations in all the other offices of which he had been possessed.

sn.def: The state of being reduced in rank, character, or reputation; baseness; moral, physical, or intellectual degeneracy; disgrace; abasement; debasement.
sn.q: The . . . degradation of a needy man of letters.
Deplorable is the degradation of our nature.
Moments there frequently must be, when a sinner is sensible of the degradation of his state.

sn.def: Diminution or reduction of strength, efficacy, or value; degeneration; deterioration.
sn.q: The development and degradation of the alphabetic forms can be traced.

sn.def: A gradual wearing down or wasting, as of rocks and banks, by the action of water, frost etc.
The state or condition of a species or group which exhibits degraded forms; degeneration.
sn.q: The degradation of the species man is observed in some of its varieties.

sn.def: Arrest of development, or degeneration of any organ, or of the body as a whole.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Degraded; p. pr. & vb. n. Degrading
entry.ety: F. dégrader, LL. degradare, fr. L. de- + gradus step, degree. See Grade, and cf. Degree

sn.def: To reduce from a higher to a lower rank or degree; to lower in rank; to deprive of office or dignity; to strip of honors; as, to degrade a nobleman, or a general officer.
sn.q: Prynne was sentenced by the Star Chamber Court to be degraded from the bar.

sn.def: To reduce in estimation, character, or reputation; to lessen the value of; to lower the physical, moral, or intellectual character of; to debase; to bring shame or contempt upon; to disgrace; as, vice degrades a man.
sn.q: O miserable mankind, to what fallDegraded, to what wretched state reserved!
Yet time ennobles or degrades each line.
Her pride . . . struggled hard against this degrading passion.

sn.def: To reduce in altitude or magnitude, as hills and mountains; to wear down.
sn.syn: To abase; demean; lower; reduce. See Abase.

entry.def: To degenerate; to pass from a higher to a lower type of structure; as, a family of plants or animals degrades through this or that genus or group of genera.

sn.def: Reduced in rank, character, or reputation; debased; sunken; low; base.
sn.q: The Netherlands . . . were reduced practically to a very degraded condition.

sn.def: Having the typical characters or organs in a partially developed condition, or lacking certain parts.
sn.q: Some families of plants are degraded dicotyledons.

sn.def: Having steps; -- said of a cross each of whose extremities finishes in steps growing larger as they leave the center; -- termed also on degrees.

entry.def: Deprivation of rank or office; degradation.
causing humiliation or degradation; as, a degrading surrender.
In a degrading manner.

entry.ety: F.; cf. F. gras, a. & n., fat
entry.def: A semisolid emulsion produced by the treatment of certain skins with oxidized fish oil, which extracts their soluble albuminoids. It was formerly solely a by-product of chamois leather manufacture, but is now made for its own sake, being valuable as a dressing for hides.

entry.ety: L. degravare degravatum, to make heavy. See Grave a.
entry.def: The act of making heavy.
To remove grease or fatty matter from, as wool or silk.

entry.note: ☞ In the United States diplomas are usually given as the evidence of a degree conferred. In the humanities the first degree is that of bachelor of artsB. A. or A. B.); the second that of master of artsM. A. or A. M.). The degree of bachelor of arts science divinity law, etc.) is conferred upon those who complete a prescribed course of undergraduate study. The first degree in medicine is that of doctor of medicineM. D.). The degrees of master and doctor are also conferred, in course, upon those who have completed certain prescribed postgraduate studies, as doctor of philosophyPh. D.); the degree of doctor is also conferred as a complimentary recognition of eminent services in science or letters, or for public services or distinction (as doctor of lawsLL. D.) or doctor of divinityD. D.), when they are called honorary degrees.
☞ The short lines and their spaces are added degrees.
entry.cs:
Accumulation of degrees. Eng. Univ See under Accumulation. By degrees step by step; by little and little; by moderate advances. “I'll leave it by degrees.” Shak.
Degree of a curveorDegree of a surface
Geom the number which expresses the degree of the equation of the curve or surface in rectilinear coördinates. A straight line will, in general, meet the curve or surface in a number of points equal to the degree of the curve or surface and no more. Degree of latitude Geog on the earth, the distance on a meridian between two parallels of latitude whose latitudes differ from each other by one degree. This distance is not the same on different parts of a meridian, on account of the flattened figure of the earth, being 68.702 statute miles at the equator, and 69.396 at the poles. Degree of longitude the distance on a parallel of latitude between two meridians that make an angle of one degree with each other at the poles -- a distance which varies as the cosine of the latitude, being at the equator 69.16 statute miles. To a degree to an extreme; exceedingly; as, mendacious to a degree .
entry.ety: F. degré, OF. degret, fr. LL. degradare. See Degrade

sn.def: A step, stair, or staircase.
sn.q: By ladders, or else by degree.

sn.def: One of a series of progressive steps upward or downward, in quality, rank, acquirement, and the like; a stage in progression; grade; gradation; as, degrees of vice and virtue; to advance by slow degrees; degree of comparison.
The point or step of progression to which a person has arrived; rank or station in life; position.
sn.q: A dame of highdegree.
A knight is yourdegree.
Lord or lady of highdegree.

sn.def: Measure of advancement; quality; extent; as, tastes differ in kind as well as in degree .
sn.q: The degree of excellence which proclaims genius, is different in different times and different places.

sn.def: Grade or rank to which scholars are admitted by a college or university, in recognition of their attainments; also, informal the diploma provided by an educational institution attesting to the achievement of that rank; as, the degree of bachelor of arts, master, doctor, etc.; to hang one's degrees on the office wall.
sn.q: The youth attained his bachelor's degree, and left the university.

sn.def: A certain distance or remove in the line of descent, determining the proximity of blood; one remove in the chain of relationship; as, a relation in the third or fourth degree .
sn.q: In the 11th century an opinion began to gain ground in Italy, that third cousins might marry, being in the seventh degree according to the civil law.

sn.def: Three figures taken together in numeration; thus, 140 is one degree, 222,140 two degrees.

State as indicated by sum of exponents; more particularly, the degree of a term is indicated by the sum of the exponents of its literal factors; thus, a2b3c is a term of the sixth degree. The degree of a power, or radical, is denoted by its index, that of an equation by the greatest sum of the exponents of the unknown quantities in any term; thus, ax4 + bx2 = c, and mx2y2 + nyx = p, are both equations of the fourth degree.
A 360th part of the circumference of a circle, which part is taken as the principal unit of measure for arcs and angles. The degree is divided into 60 minutes and the minute into 60 seconds.
A division, space, or interval, marked on a mathematical or other instrument, as on a thermometer.
A line or space of the staff.
sn.q: It has been said that Scotsmen . . . are . . . grave to a degree on occasions when races more favored by nature are gladsome to excess.

entries.entry: de*greed" d�*grēd",a. possessing a college degree or degrees.

sn.def: going down by steps.
gradually decreasing in rate on sums below a certain amount.

entry.ety: Native name
entry.def: A small South American rodent (Octodon Cumingii), of the family Octodontidæ.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Degummed; p. pr. & vb. n. Degumming
entry.def: To deprive of, or free from, gum; as, to degum ramie.

entry.ety: L. degustare: cf. F. déguster. See Gust to taste
entry.def: To taste.

entry.ety: L. degustatio: cf. F. dégustation
entry.def: Tasting; the appreciation of sapid qualities by the taste organs.

entry.ety: L. dehiscere; de- + hiscere to gape
entry.def: To gape; to open by dehiscence.

entry.ety: Cf. F. déhiscence

sn.def: The act of gaping.

A gaping or bursting open along a definite line of attachment or suture, without tearing, as in the opening of pods, or the bursting of capsules at maturity so as to emit seeds, etc.; also, the bursting open of follicles, as in the ovaries of animals, for the expulsion of their contents.

entry.ety: L. dehiscens -entis, p. pr. Cf. F. déhiscent
entry.def: Characterized by dehiscence; opening in some definite way, as the capsule of a plant.

entry.ety: L. dehonestatus, p. p. of dehonestare to dishonor; de- + honestare to make honorable. Cf. Dishonest, and see Honest
entry.def: To disparage.

entry.ety: L. dehonestatio
entry.def: A dishonoring; disgracing.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Dehorned; p. pr. & vb. n. Dehorning
entry.def: To deprive of horns; to prevent the growth of the horns of (cattle) by burning their ends soon after they start. See Dishorn.
entry.q: Dehorningcattle.

entry.ety: F., outside
entry.def: Out of; without; foreign to; out of the agreement, record, will, or other instrument.
All sorts of outworks in general, at a distance from the main works; any advanced works for protection or cover.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Dehorted; p. pr. & vb. n. Dehorting
entry.ety: L. dehortari; de- + hortari to urge, exhort
entry.def: To urge to abstain or refrain; to dissuade.
entry.q: The apostles vehemently dehort us from unbelief.
“Exhort” remains, but dehort, a word whose place neither “dissuade” nor any other exactly supplies, has escaped us.

entry.ety: L. dehortatio
entry.def: Dissuasion; advice against something.
Dissuasive.

entry.ety: L. dehortatorius
entry.def: Fitted or designed to dehort or dissuade.
A dissuader; an adviser to the contrary.
To divest of human qualities, such as pity, tenderness, etc.; as, dehumanizing influences.
to remove the moisture from (air or another gas); to reduce the humidity of; as, The air conditioner dehumidifies the air in the summer.
To remove the husk from.
entry.q: Wheatdehuskedupon the floor.

entry.def: To deprive of water; to render free from water; as, to dehydrate alcohol; to dehydrate food for preservation.

sn.def: to lose water or moisture.
to lose sufficent water to cause physiological distress; -- of living organisms; as, victims trapped in the earthquake rubble may dehydrate if not found quickly.
thoroughly dried out.
suffering from fluid deprivation; as, to become deydrated from overexertion on a hot day.

entry.def: The act or process of freeing from water; also, the condition of a body from which the water has been removed.
To deprive of, or free from, hydrogen.
The act or process of freeing from hydrogen; also, the condition resulting from the removal of hydrogen.
to remove ice or frost from.
a devie that removes ice or frost (as from a windshield or a refrigerator or the wings of an airplane).

entry.ety: L. deicida a deicide (in sense 2); deus god + cædere to cut, kill: cf. F. déicide

sn.def: The act of killing a being of a divine nature; particularly, the putting to death of Jesus Christ.
sn.q: Earth profaned, yet blessed, with deicide.

sn.def: One concerned in putting Christ to death.

entry.ety: Gr. deiktiko`s serving to show or point out, fr. deikny`nai to show

sn.def: Direct; proving directly; -- applied to reasoning, and opposed to elenchtic or refutative.

showing or pointing to directly; pertaining to deixis; -- used to designate words that specify identity, location, or time from the perspective of one of the participants in a discourse, using the surrounding context as reference; as, the words this that these those here there now then we you they the former, and the latter serve a deictic function.

entry.def: In a manner to show or point out; directly; absolutely; definitely.
entry.q: When Christ spake it deictically.

entry.ety: L. deificus; deus god + facere to make: cf. F. déifique
entry.def: Making divine; producing a likeness to God; god-making.
entry.q: Adeificalcommunion.

entry.ety: LL. deificare to deify: cf. F. déification. See Deify
entry.def: The act of deifying; exaltation to divine honors; apotheosis; excessive praise.
Honored or worshiped as a deity; treated with supreme regard; godlike.
One who deifies.

entry.ety: L. deus a god + -form

sn.def: Godlike, or of a godlike form.
Conformable to the will of God.

entry.def: Likeness to deity.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Deified; p. pr. & vb. n. Deifying
entry.ety: F. déifier, LL. deificare, fr. L. deificus. See Deific Deity -fy

sn.def: To make a god of; to exalt to the rank of a deity; to enroll among the deities; to apotheosize; as, Julius Cæsar was deified .
To praise or revere as a deity; to treat as an object of supreme regard; as, to deify money.
sn.q: He did again so extol and deify the pope.

sn.def: To render godlike.
sn.q: By our own spirits are we deified.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Deigned dānd; p. pr. & vb. n. Deigning
entry.ety: OE. deinen deignen, OF. degner deigner daigner, F. daigner, fr. L. dignari to deem worthy, deign, fr. dignus worthy; akin to decere to be fitting. See Decent, and cf. Dainty Dignity Condign Disdain

sn.def: To esteem worthy; to consider worth notice; -- opposed to disdain.
sn.q: I fear my Julia would not deign my lines.

sn.def: To condescend to give or bestow; to stoop to furnish; to vouchsafe; to allow; to grant.
sn.q: Nor would we deign him burial of his men.

entry.note: In early English deign was often used impersonally.
entry.def: To think worthy; to vouchsafe; to condescend; - - followed by an infinitive.
entry.q: O deign to visit our forsaken seats.
Yet not Lord Cranstone deigned she greet.
Round turned he, as not deigning Those craven ranks to see.
Him deyneth not to set his foot to ground.

entry.ety: For disdeignous, OF. desdeignos desdaigneus, F. dédaigneux. See Disdain
entry.def: Haughty; disdainful.

entry.cs: Deil's buckie. See under Buckie.
entry.def: Devil; -- spelt also deel.

entry.ety: NL
entry.def: See Dinoceras.

entry.ety: NL
entry.def: See Dinornis.

entry.ety: NL
entry.def: See Dinosaur.

entry.ety: NL
entry.def: See Dinotherium.

entry.ety: L. deintegrare to impair; de- + integrare to make whole
entry.def: To disintegrate.
Rare; excellent; costly.
an enzyme that removes the iodine radical.
to remove iodine from.
removing iodine from.
the removal of iodine atoms from organic compounds.
to remove ions from.
the act or process of removing ions.

sn.def: to remove ions from (a solution).
to reassociate the ions of (an ionized gas).

entry.note: In chemistry and biochemistry, experiments often require water free from contaminating ions, and the ordinary distilled water may be subjected to a process of deionization in order to render the ion content sufficiently low so as not to interfere with the investigation.
entry.def: freed from ions by a process of deionization; as, deionized water.

entry.note: In chemistry and biochemistry, experiments often require water free from contaminating ions, and ordinary distilled water may be further purified by passing through a deionizer in order to render the ion content sufficiently low so as not to interfere with the investigation.
entry.def: an apparatus used to remove ions from a solution; a common variant contains a mixture of cation exchange resin in the acid form and anion exchange resin in the hydroxyl form inside a replaceable cartridge; ions in aqueous solution are exchanged for the elements of water by passing the solution through the mixed resin.

entry.ety: L. deus a god + parere to bring forth
entry.def: Bearing or bringing forth a god; -- said of the Virgin Mary.

entry.ety: Gr. deipnosofisth`s; dei^pnon a meal + sofisth`s a wise man, sophist
entry.def: One of an ancient sect of philosophers, who cultivated learned conversation at meals.
See Dais.

entry.note: ☞ Deism is the belief in natural religion only, or those truths, in doctrine and practice, which man is to discover by the light of reason, independent of any revelation from God. Hence, deism implies infidelity, or a disbelief in the divine origin of the Scriptures.
entry.ety: L. deus god: cf. F. déisme. See Deity
entry.def: The doctrine or creed of a deist; the belief or system of those who acknowledge the existence of one God, but deny revelation.

entry.note: ☞ A deist, as denying a revelation, is opposed to a Christian; as, opposed to the denier of a God, whether atheist or pantheist, a deist is generally denominated theist.
entry.ety: L. deus god: cf. F. déiste. See Deity
entry.def: One who believes in the existence of a God, but denies revealed religion; a freethinker.
Pertaining to, savoring of, or consisting in, deism; as, a deistic writer; a deistical book.
entry.q: The deistical or antichristian scheme.

entry.def: After the manner of deists.
State of being deistical.
Deified.

entries.entry:
De"i*ty
The Deity God, the Supreme Being.
dē"ĭ*t� n.; pl.Deities dē"ĭ*tĭz. OE. deite, F. déité, fr. L. deitas, fr. deus a god; akin to divus divine, Jupiter, gen. Jovis, Jupiter, dies day, Gr. di^os divine, Zey`s, gen. Dio`s, Zeus, Skr. dēva divine, as a noun, god, daiva divine, dyō sky, day, hence, the sky personified as a god, and to the first syllable of E. Tuesday, Gael. & Ir. dia God, W. duw. Cf. Divine Journey Journal Tuesday
The collection of attributes which make up the nature of a god; divinity; godhead; as, the deity of the Supreme Being is seen in his works. They declared with emphasis the perfect deity and the perfect manhood of Christ.
A god or goddess; a heathen god. To worship calves, the deities Of Egypt. This great poet and philosopher [Simonides], the more he contemplated the nature of the Deity, found that he waded but the more out of his depth.

entry.def: the function or operation of a deictic word; the function of pointing or specifying from the perspective of a participant in an act of speech or writing; aspects of a communication whose interpretation depends on knowledge of the context in which the communication occurs.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Dejected; p. pr. & vb. n. Dejecting
entry.ety: L. dejectus, p. p. of dejicere to throw down; de- + jacere to throw. See Jet a shooting forth

sn.def: To cast down.
sn.q: Christ dejected himself even unto the hells.
Sometimes she dejects her eyes in a seeming civility; and many mistake in her a cunning for a modest look.

sn.def: To cast down the spirits of; to dispirit; to discourage; to dishearten.
sn.q: Nor think, to die dejects my lofty mind.

entry.ety: L. dejectus, p. p
entry.def: Dejected.

entry.ety: NL., neut. pl. from L. dejectus, p. p
entry.def: Excrements; as, the dejecta of the sick.
Cast down; afflicted; low-spirited; sad; as, a dejected look or countenance.
One who casts down, or dejects.

entry.ety: L. dejectio a casting down: cf. F. déjection

sn.def: A casting down; depression.
The act of humbling or abasing one's self.
sn.q: Adoration implies submission and dejection.

sn.def: Lowness of spirits occasioned by grief or misfortune; mental depression; melancholy.
sn.q: What besides, Of sorrow, and dejection, and despair, Our frailty can sustain, thy tidings bring.

sn.def: A low condition; weakness; inability.
sn.q: A dejection of appetite.

sd.def: The discharge of excrement.
Fæces; excrement.

entry.def: Dejectedly.

entry.ety: L. dejector a dejecter

sn.def: Having power, or tending, to cast down.
Promoting evacuations by stool.

entry.def: That which is voided; excrements.

entry.ety: L. dejeratus, p. p. of dejerare to swear; de- + jurare to swear
entry.def: To swear solemnly; to take an oath.

entry.ety: L. dejeratio
entry.def: The act of swearing solemnly.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: A déjeuner.
entry.q: Take a déjeuné of muskadel and eggs.

entry.ety: F. déjeuner breakfast, as a verb, to breakfast. Cf. Dinner
entry.def: A breakfast; sometimes, also, a lunch or collation.

entries.entry: De` ju"re De` ju"re. L By right; of right; by law; -- often opposed to de facto.
Dek"a-. Metric System A prefix signifying ten. See Deca-.

entry.def: A Decembrist.
Same as Decagram.
Same as Decaliter.
Same as Decameter.
Same as Decastere.
See Deckle.

entry.ety: See Deal n.
entry.def: Share; portion; part.

a differential operator which, operating on a function of several variables, gives the sum of the partial derivatives of the function with respect to the three orthogonal spatial coordinates; -- also called the gradient or grad. It is represented by an inverted Greek capital delta (∇), and is thus because of its shape also called nabla, meaning harp in Hebrew.

entry.ety: L. delacerare delaceratum, to tear in pieces. See Lacerate
entry.def: A tearing in pieces.

entry.ety: L. delacrimatio, fr. delacrimare to weep. See Lachrymation
entry.def: An involuntary discharge of watery humors from the eyes; wateriness of the eyes.

entry.ety: Pref. de- + L. lactare to suck milk, from lac milk
entry.def: The act of weaning.

entry.ety: See Muslin delaine, under Muslin
entry.def: A kind of fabric for women's dresses.

entry.note: ☞ This process consists of a concentric splitting of the cells of the blastosphere into an outer layer (epiblast) and an inner layer (hypoblast). By the perforation of the resultant two-walled vesicle, a gastrula results similar to that formed by the process of invagination.
entry.def: Formation and separation of laminæ or layers; one of the methods by which the various blastodermic layers of the ovum are differentiated.
See Delapsion.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Delapsed; p. pr. & vb. n. Delapsing
entry.ety: L. delapsus, p. p. of delabi to fall down; de- + labi to fall or side
entry.def: To pass down by inheritance; to lapse.
entry.q: Which Anne derived alone the right, before all other, Of the delapsed crown from Philip.

entry.def: A falling down, or out of place; prolapsion.

entry.ety: L. delassare delassatum, to tire out; de- + lassare to tire
entry.def: Fatigue.
entry.q: Able to continue without delassation.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Delated; p. pr. & vb. n. Delating
entry.ety: L. delatus, used as p. p. of deferre. See Tolerate, and cf. 3d Defer Delay v.

sn.def: To carry; to convey.
sn.q: Try exactly the time wherein sound is delated.

sn.def: To carry abroad; to spread; to make public.
sn.q: When the crime is delated or notorious.

sn.def: To carry or bring against, as a charge; to inform against; to accuse; to denounce.
sn.q: As men were delated, they were marked down for such a fine.

sn.def: To carry on; to conduct.

entry.def: To dilate.

entry.ety: L. delatio accusation: cf. F. délation

sn.def: Conveyance.
sn.q: In delation of sounds, the inclosure of them preserveth them.

sn.def: Accusation by an informer.

entry.ety: L
entry.def: An accuser; an informer.

sn.def: one of the thirteen original states of the United States of America.
An American grape, with compact bunches of small, amber-colored berries, sweet and of a good flavor.

entry.def: a resident of Delaware.
a resident of Delaware.

entries.entry: Del"a*wares dĕl"ȧ*wârz n. pl.; sing. Delaware. Ethnol A tribe of Indians formerly inhabiting the valley of the Delaware River, but now mostly located in the Indian Territory.

De*lay" n.; pl.Delays #. F. délai, fr. OF. deleer to delay, or fr. L. dilatum, which, though really from a different root, is used in Latin only as a p. p. neut. of differre to carry apart, defer, delay. See Tolerate, and cf. Differ Delay v.
A putting off or deferring; procrastination; lingering inactivity; stop; detention; hindrance. Without any delay, on the morrow I sat on the judgment seat. The government ought to be settled without the delay of a day.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Delayed; p. pr. & vb. n. Delaying
entry.ety: OF. deleer delaier, fr. the noun délai, or directly fr. L. dilatare to enlarge, dilate, in LL., to put off. See Delay n., and cf. Delate, 1st Defer Dilate

sn.def: To put off; to defer; to procrastinate; to prolong the time of or before.
sn.q: My lord delayeth his coming.

sn.def: To retard; to stop, detain, or hinder, for a time; to retard the motion, or time of arrival, of; as, the mail is delayed by a heavy fall of snow.
sn.q: Thyrsis! whose artful strains have oft delayed The huddling brook to hear his madrigal.

sn.def: To allay; to temper.
sn.q: The watery showers delay the raging wind.

entry.def: To move slowly; to stop for a time; to linger; to tarry.
entry.q: There seem to be certain bounds to the quickness and slowness of the succession of those ideas, . . . beyond which they can neither delay nor hasten.

entry.def: One who delays; one who lingers.
By delays.
Hindrance.

entries.entry: Del` cred"er*e Del` cred"er*e. It., of belief or trust Mercantile Law An agreement by which an agent or factor, in consideration of an additional premium or commission (called a del credere commission), engages, when he sells goods on credit, to insure, warrant, or guarantee to his principal the solvency of the purchaser, the engagement of the factor being to pay the debt himself if it is not punctually discharged by the buyer when it becomes due.

De"le imperative sing. of L. delere to destroy. Cf. Delete
Print Erase; remove; -- a direction to cancel something which has been put in type; usually expressed by a peculiar form of d, thus: �.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Deled; p. pr. & vb. n. Deleing
entry.ety: From the preceding word
entry.def: To erase; to cancel; to delete; to mark for omission.

entry.ety: See Deal
entry.def: To deal; to divide; to distribute.

entry.ety: L. delebilis. See 1st Dele
entry.def: Capable of being blotted out or erased.
entry.q: An impression easilydeleble.

entry.ety: OF. delitable, OF. delitable, F. délectable, fr. L. delectabilis, fr. delectare to delight. See Delight

sn.def: Highly pleasing; delightful.
sn.q: Delectable both to behold and taste.

sn.def: extremely pleasing to the sense of taste; same as luscious, 1.
sn.syn: delicious, luscious, pleasant-tasting, scrumptious, toothsome, yummy.

entry.ety: L. delectatus, p. p. of delectare. See Delight
entry.def: To delight; to charm.

entry.ety: L. delectatio: cf. F. délectation
entry.def: Great pleasure; delight.

entry.ety: L., selection, from deligere delectum, to select
entry.def: A name given to an elementary book for learners of Latin or Greek.

entry.ety: From Delegate a.

sn.def: The act of delegating, or state of being delegated; deputed power.
sn.q: By way of delegacy or grand commission.

sn.def: A body of delegates or commissioners; a delegation.

cs.cd: formerly, the great court of appeal from the archbishops' courts and also from the court of admiralty. It is now abolished, and the privy council is the immediate court of appeal in such cases.

entry.ety: L. delegatus, p. p. of delegare to send, delegate; de- + legare to send with a commission, to depute. See Legate

sn.def: Any one sent and empowered to act for another; one deputed to represent; a chosen deputy; a representative; a commissioner; a vicar.

sd.def: One elected by the people of a territory to represent them in Congress, where he has the right of debating, but not of voting.
One sent by any constituency to act as its representative in a convention; as, a delegate to a convention for nominating officers, or for forming or altering a constitution.

entry.ety: L. delegatus, p. p
entry.def: Sent to act for or represent another; deputed; as, a delegate judge.
entry.q: Delegatepower.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Delegated; p. pr. & vb. n. Delegating

sn.def: To send as one's representative; to empower as an ambassador; to send with power to transact business; to commission; to depute; to authorize.
To intrust to the care or management of another; to transfer; to assign; to commit.
sn.q: The delegated administration of the law.
Delegated executive power.
The power exercised by the legislature is the people's power, delegated by the people to the legislative.

entry.def: the act or process of authorizing subordinates to make certain decisions.

entry.ety: L. delegatio: cf. F. délégation

sn.def: The act of delegating, or investing with authority to act for another; the appointment of a delegate or delegates.

One or more persons appointed or chosen, and commissioned to represent others, as in a convention, in Congress, etc.; the collective body of delegates; as, the delegation from Massachusetts; a deputation.
A kind of novation by which a debtor, to be liberated from his creditor, gives him a third person, who becomes obliged in his stead to the creditor, or to the person appointed by him.

entry.ety: L. delegatorius pert. to an assignment
entry.def: Holding a delegated position.

entry.ety: L., fr. delere to destroy
entry.def: Things to be erased or blotted out.

entry.ety: L. delenificus; delenire to soothe + facere to make. See Lenient
entry.def: Assuaging pain.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Deleted; p. pr. & vb. n. Deleting
entry.ety: L. deletus, p. p. of delere to destroy. Cf. 1st Dele
entry.def: To blot out; to erase; to expunge; to dele; to omit.
entry.q: I have, therefore, . . . inserted eleven stanzas which do not appear in Sir Walter Scott's version, and have deleted eight.

entry.ety: LL. deleterius noxious, Gr. dhlhth`rios, fr. dhlei^sqai to hurt, damage; prob. akin to L. delere to destroy
entry.def: Hurtful; noxious; destructive; pernicious; as, a deleterious plant or quality; a deleterious example.

entry.ety: LL. deleterius: cf. F. délétère
entry.def: Destructive; poisonous.
entry.q: Deleterymedicines.

entry.def: That which destroys.
