entry.q: They [the Scriptures] are the only deletery of heresies.

entry.ety: L. deletio, fr. delere. See Delete
entry.def: Act of deleting, blotting out, or erasing; destruction.
entry.q: A total deletion of every person of the opposing party.

entry.ety: L. deleticius
entry.def: Of such a nature that anything may be erased from it; -- said of paper.
Adapted to destroy or obliterate.

entry.ety: See Delete
entry.def: That which blots out.
entry.q: Adeletoryof sin.

entry.ety: AS. delf a delving, digging. See Delve
entry.def: A mine; a quarry; a pit dug; a ditch.
entry.q: The delfts would be so flown with waters, that no gins or machines could . . . keep them dry.

entry.def: Same as Delftware.
Same as Delftware.
Pottery made at the city of Delft in Holland; hence:
Earthenware made in imitation of the above; any glazed earthenware made for table use, and the like.

entry.ety: L. delibatus, p. p. of delibare to taste; de- + libare to taste
entry.def: To taste; to take a sip of; to dabble in.

entry.ety: L. delibatio: cf. F. délibation
entry.def: Act of tasting; a slight trial.
To deliberate.

entry.ety: L. deliberatus, p. p. of deliberare to deliberate; de- + librare to weigh. See Librate

sn.def: Weighing facts and arguments with a view to a choice or decision; carefully considering the probable consequences of a step; circumspect; slow in determining; -- applied to persons; as, a deliberate judge or counselor.
sn.q: Thesedeliberatefools.

sn.def: Formed with deliberation; well-advised; carefully considered; not sudden or rash; as, a deliberate opinion; a deliberate measure or result.
sn.q: Settled visage and deliberate word.

sn.def: Not hasty or sudden; slow.
sn.q: His enunciation was so deliberate.

sn.def: having awareness of the likely consequences; intentional.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Deliberated; p. pr. & vb. n. Deliberating
entry.def: To weigh in the mind; to consider the reasons for and against; to consider maturely; to reflect upon; to ponder; as, to deliberate a question.
To take counsel with one's self; to weigh the arguments for and against a proposed course of action; to reflect; to consider; to hesitate in deciding; -- sometimes with on upon about concerning.
entry.q: The woman that deliberates is lost.

entry.def: With careful consideration, or deliberation; circumspectly; warily; not hastily or rashly; slowly; as, a purpose deliberately formed.
The quality of being deliberate; calm consideration; circumspection.

entry.ety: L. deliberatio: cf. F. délibération

sn.def: The act of deliberating, or of weighing and examining the reasons for and against a choice or measure; careful consideration; mature reflection.
sn.q: Choosing the fairest way with a calm deliberation.

sn.def: Careful discussion and examination of the reasons for and against a measure; as, the deliberations of a legislative body or council.

entry.ety: L. deliberativus: cf. F. délibératif
entry.def: Pertaining to deliberation; proceeding or acting by deliberation, or by discussion and examination; deliberating; as, a deliberative body.
entry.q: A consummate work of deliberative wisdom.
The court of jurisdiction is to be distinguished from the deliberative body, the advisers of the crown.

sn.def: A discourse in which a question is discussed, or weighed and examined.
A kind of rhetoric employed in proving a thing and convincing others of its truth, in order to persuade them to adopt it.

entry.def: In a deliberative manner; circumspectly; considerately.
One who deliberates.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Delibrated; p. pr. & vb. n. Delibrating
entry.ety: L. delibratus, p. p. of delibrare to delibrate; de from + liber bark
entry.def: To strip off the bark; to peel.
The act of stripping off the bark.

entries.entry:
Del"i*ca*cy n.; pl.Delicacies #. From Delicate a.
The state or condition of being delicate; agreeableness to the senses; delightfulness; as, delicacy of flavor, of odor, and the like. What choice to choose for delicacy best.
Nicety or fineness of form, texture, or constitution; softness; elegance; smoothness; tenderness; and hence, frailty or weakness; as, the delicacy of a fiber or a thread; delicacy of a hand or of the human form; delicacy of the skin; delicacy of frame.
Nice propriety of manners or conduct; susceptibility or tenderness of feeling; refinement; fastidiousness; and hence, in an exaggerated sense, effeminacy; as, great delicacy of behavior; delicacy in doing a kindness; delicacy of character that unfits for earnest action.
You know your mother's delicacy in this point.
Addiction to pleasure; luxury; daintiness; indulgence; luxurious or voluptuous treatment. And to those dainty limbs which Nature lent For gentle usage and soft delicacy?
Nice and refined perception and discrimination; critical niceness; fastidious accuracy. That Augustan delicacy of taste which is the boast of the great public schools of England.
The state of being affected by slight causes; sensitiveness; as, the delicacy of a chemist's balance.
That which is alluring, delicate, or refined; a luxury or pleasure; something pleasant to the senses, especially to the sense of taste; a dainty; as, delicacies of the table. The merchants of the earth are waxed rich through the abundance of her delicacies.
Pleasure; gratification; delight. Obs He Rome brent for his delicacie. See Dainty.

entry.ety: L. delicatus pleasing the senses, voluptuous, soft and tender; akin to deliciae delight: cf. F. délicat. See Delight

sn.def: Addicted to pleasure; luxurious; voluptuous; alluring.
sn.q: Dives, for his delicate life, to the devil went.
Haarlem is a very delicate town.

sn.def: Pleasing to the senses; refinedly agreeable; hence, adapted to please a nice or cultivated taste; nice; fine; elegant; as, a delicate dish; delicate flavor.
Slight and shapely; lovely; graceful; as, “a delicate creature.”
Fine or slender; minute; not coarse; -- said of a thread, or the like; as, delicate cotton.
Slight or smooth; light and yielding; -- said of texture; as, delicate lace or silk.
Soft and fair; -- said of the skin or a surface; as, a delicate cheek; a delicate complexion.
Light, or softly tinted; -- said of a color; as, a delicate blue.
Refined; gentle; scrupulous not to trespass or offend; considerate; -- said of manners, conduct, or feelings; as, delicate behavior; delicate attentions; delicate thoughtfulness.
Tender; not able to endure hardship; feeble; frail; effeminate; -- said of constitution, health, etc.; as, a delicate child; delicate health.
sn.q: A delicate and tender prince.

sn.def: Requiring careful handling; not to be rudely or hastily dealt with; nice; critical; as, a delicate subject or question.
sn.q: There are some things too delicate and too sacred to be handled rudely without injury to truth.

sn.def: Of exacting tastes and habits; dainty; fastidious.
Nicely discriminating or perceptive; refinedly critical; sensitive; exquisite; as, a delicate taste; a delicate ear for music.
Affected by slight causes; showing slight changes; as, a delicate thermometer.
A choice dainty; a delicacy.
sn.q: With abstinence all delicates he sees.

sn.def: A delicate, luxurious, or effeminate person.
sn.q: All the vessels, then, which our delicates have, -- those I mean that would seem to be more fine in their houses than their neighbors, -- are only of the Corinth metal.

entry.def: In a delicate manner.
The quality of being delicate.

entry.ety: G., fr. F. délicatesse
entry.sn: Relishes for the table; dainties; delicacies. A dealer indelicatessen .G. H. Putnam.

sn.def: ready-to-eat foods, such as cold cuts, cooked meats, and prepared salads.

entry.sn: sing.; pl.delicatessens. a store or section of a store where delicatessen{2} is sold. Get a sandwich for lunch at thedelicatessencounter.

entry.ety: F. délices, fr. L. deliciae
entry.def: Delicacies; delights.
entry.q: Daintydelices.

entry.def: To delight one's self; to indulge in feasting; to revel.

entry.usage: Delicious refers to the pleasure derived from certain of the senses, particularly the taste and smell; as, delicious food; a delicious fragrance. Delightful may also refer to most of the senses (as, delightful music; a delightful prospect; delightful sensations), but has a higher application to matters of taste, feeling, and sentiment; as, a delightful abode, conversation, employment; delightful scenes, etc.
entry.ety: OF. delicieus, F. délicieux, L. deliciosus, fr. deliciae delight, fr. delicere to allure. See Delight

sn.def: Affording exquisite pleasure; delightful; most sweet or grateful to the senses, especially to the taste; charming.
sn.q: Some delicious landscape.
One draught of spring's delicious air.
Were not his words delicious?

sn.def: Addicted to pleasure; seeking enjoyment; luxurious; effeminate.
sn.q: Others, lastly, of a more delicious and airy spirit, retire themselves to the enjoyments of ease and luxury.
Like the rich fruit he sings, delicious in decay.
No spring, nor summer, on the mountain seen, Smiles with gay fruits or with delightful green.

entry.def: Delightfully; as, to feed deliciously; to be deliciously entertained.

sn.def: The quality of being delicious; as, the deliciousness of a repast.
Luxury.
sn.q: To drive away all superfluity anddeliciousness.

entry.ety: L. delictum fault
entry.def: An offense or transgression against law; Scots Law an offense of a lesser degree; a misdemeanor.
entry.q: Every regulation of the civil code necessarily implies a delict in the event of its violation.

entry.ety: L. deligatus, p. p. of deligare to bind up; de- + ligare to bind
entry.def: To bind up; to bandage.

entry.ety: Cf. F. déligation
entry.def: A binding up; a bandaging.

entry.ety: OE. delit, OF. delit deleit, fr. delitier, to delight. See Delight v. t.

sn.def: A high degree of gratification of mind; a high- wrought state of pleasurable feeling; lively pleasure; extreme satisfaction; joy.
sn.q: Sounds and sweet airs, that give delight and hurt not.
A fool hath no delight in understanding.

sn.def: That which gives great pleasure or delight.
sn.q: Heaven's last, best gift, my ever new delight.

sn.def: Licentious pleasure; lust.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Delighted; p. pr. & vb. n. Delighting
entry.ety: OE. deliten, OF. delitier deleitier, F. délecter, fr. L. delectare to entice away, to delight (sc. by attracting or alluring), intens. of delicere to allure, delight; de- + lacere to entice, allure; cf. laqueus a snare. Cf. Delectate Delicate Delicious Dilettante Elicit Lace
entry.def: To give delight to; to affect with great pleasure; to please highly; as, a beautiful landscape delights the eye; harmony delights the ear.
entry.q: Inventions to delight the taste.
Delight our souls with talk of knightly deeds.

entry.def: To have or take great delight or pleasure; to be greatly pleased or rejoiced; -- followed by an infinitive, or by in.
entry.q: Love delights in praises.
I delight to do thy will, O my God.

entry.ety: See Delectable
entry.def: Capable of delighting; delightful.
entry.q: Many a spice delightable.

entry.def: Endowed with delight.
entry.q: If virtue no delighted beauty lack.

entry.def: With delight; gladly.
One who gives or takes delight.
Highly pleasing; affording great pleasure and satisfaction.
entry.q: Delightfulbowers.
Delightfulfruit.

entry.def: Giving delight; gladdening.
Void of delight.

entry.ety: OF. delitos
entry.def: Delightful.
Very pleasing; delightful.
entry.q: Delightsomevigor.
Ye shall be a delightsome land, . . . saith the Lord.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Delignated; p. pr. & vb. n. Delignating
entry.ety: Pref. de- + L. lignum wood

sn.def: To clear or strip of wood (by cutting down trees).
To strip or remove the wood from; as, to delignate ramie, in the preparation of ribbons of the fiber for further working.

entry.def: The mistress of Samson, who betrayed him (Judges xvi.); hence, a harlot; a temptress.
entry.q: Other Delilahs on a smaller scale Burns met with during his Dumfries sojourn.

entry.ety: L. delimitare: cf. F. délimiter
entry.def: To fix the limits of; to demarcate; to bound.

sn.def: to determine the essential quality of.
to set, mark, or draw the boundaries of something.

entry.ety: L. delimitatio: cf. F. délimitation
entry.def: The act or process of fixing limits or boundaries; limitation.

sn.def: To delineate.
To mark out.

entry.def: Capable of being, or liable to be, delineated.

entry.ety: See Delineate
entry.def: Delineation; sketch.

entry.ety: L. delineatus, p. p. of delineare to delineate; de- + lineare to draw, fr. linea line. See Line
entry.def: Delineated; portrayed.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Delineated; p. pr. & vb. n. Delineating

sn.def: To indicate by lines drawn in the form or figure of; to represent by sketch, design, or diagram; to sketch out; to portray; to picture; in drawing and engraving, to represent in lines, as with the pen, pencil, or graver; hence, to represent with accuracy and minuteness. See Delineation.
sn.q: Adventurous to delineate nature's form.

sn.def: To portray to the mind or understanding by words; to set forth; to describe.
sn.q: Customs or habits delineated with great accuracy.

entry.sn: represented accurately or precisely.Narrower terms: diagrammatic, diagrammatical; drawn; painted

sn.def: described in words with sharpness and detail or with vivid imagery. Opposite of undelineated.

entry.ety: L. delineatio: cf. F. délinéation

sn.def: The act of representing, portraying, or describing, as by lines, diagrams, sketches, etc.; drawing an outline; as, the delineation of a scene or face; in drawing and engraving, representation by means of lines, as distinguished from representation by means of tints and shades; accurate and minute representation, as distinguished from art that is careless of details, or subordinates them excessively.
A delineated picture; representation; sketch; description in words.
sn.q: Their softest delineations of female beauty.

sn.def: One who, or that which, delineates; a sketcher.
A perambulator which records distances and delineates a profile, as of a road.

entry.def: That delineates; descriptive; drawing the outline; delineating.
Delineation.

entry.ety: L. delinere to smear. See Liniment
entry.def: A smearing.

entries.entry:
De*lin"quen*cy n.; pl.Delinquencies #. L. delinquentia, fr. delinquens
Failure or omission of duty; a fault; a misdeed; an offense; a misdemeanor; a crime. The delinquencies of the little commonwealth would be represented in the most glaring colors.

entry.ety: L. delinquens -entis, p. pr. of delinquere to fail, be wanting in one's duty, do wrong; de- + linquere to leave. See Loan n.
entry.def: Failing in duty; offending by neglect of duty.
One who fails or neglects to perform his duty; an offender or transgressor; one who commits a fault or a crime; a culprit.
entry.q: A delinquent ought to be cited in the place or jurisdiction where the delinquency was committed.

entry.def: So as to fail in duty.

entry.ety: L. deliquatus, p. p. of deliquare to clear off, de- + liquare to make liquid, melt, dissolve
entry.def: To melt or be dissolved; to deliquesce.
To cause to melt away; to dissolve; to consume; to waste.
entry.q: Dilapidating, or rather deliquating, his bishopric.

entry.def: A melting.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Deliquesced; p. pr. & vb. n. Deliquescing
entry.ety: L. deliquescere to melt, dissolve; de- + liquescere to become fluid, melt, fr. liquere to be fluid. See Liquid
entry.def: To dissolve gradually and become liquid by attracting and absorbing moisture from the air, as certain salts, acids, and alkalies.
entry.q: In very moist air crystals of strontites deliquesce.

entry.ety: Cf. F. déliquescence
entry.def: The act of deliquescing or liquefying; process by which anything deliquesces; tendency to melt.

entry.ety: L. deliquescens -entis, p. pr. of deliquescere: cf. F. déliquescent

sn.def: Dissolving; liquefying by contact with the air; capable of attracting moisture from the atmosphere and becoming liquid; as, deliquescent salts.
Branching so that the stem is lost in branches, as in most deciduous trees.

entry.ety: L. deliquia a flowing off, a gutter, deliquium a flowing down, fr. deliquare. See Deliquate
entry.def: To melt and become liquid by absorbing water from the air; to deliquesce.
The act of deliquiating.

entry.ety: L. See Deliquiate

sn.def: A melting or dissolution in the air, or in a moist place; a liquid condition; as, a salt falls into a deliquium .
A sinking away; a swooning.
A melting or maudlin mood.

entry.ety: See Delirate
entry.def: Delirium.

entry.ety: L. deliramentum, fr. delirare. See Delirium
entry.def: A wandering of the mind; a crazy fancy.
Delirium.

entry.ety: L. delirans - antis, p. pr. of delirare. See Delirium
entry.def: Delirious.

entry.ety: L. deliratus, p. p. of delirare. See Delirium
entry.def: To madden; to rave.
entry.q: An infatuating and delirating spirit in it.

entry.ety: L. deliratio
entry.def: Aberration of mind; delirium.
entry.q: Deliration or alienation of the understanding.

entry.ety: See Delirium
entry.def: A poison which occasions a persistent delirium, or mental aberration (as belladonna).

entry.ety: Delirium + L. faciens -entis, p. pr. of facere to make
entry.def: Producing, or tending to produce, delirium.

def2.def: Any substance which tends to cause delirium.

entry.ety: From Delirium
entry.def: Having a delirium; wandering in mind; light-headed; insane; raving; wild; as, a delirious patient; delirious fancies.

entry.cs:
Delirium tremens. L., trembling delirium Med a violent delirium induced by the excessive and prolonged use of intoxicating liquors.
Traumatic delirium Med a variety of delirium following injury.
entry.ety: L., fr. delirare to rave, to wander in mind, prop., to go out of the furrow in plowing; de- + lira furrow, track; perh. akin to G. geleise track, rut, and E. last to endure

sn.def: A state in which the thoughts, expressions, and actions are wild, irregular, and incoherent; mental aberration; a roving or wandering of the mind, -- usually dependent on a fever or some other disease, and so distinguished from mania, or madness.
Strong excitement; wild enthusiasm; madness.
sn.q: The popular deliriumof the French Revolution] at first caught his enthusiastic mind.
The delirium of the preceding session (of Parliament).
sn.syn: Insanity; frenzy; madness; derangement; aberration; mania; lunacy; fury. See Insanity.

entry.def: Delight.
Delightful; delectable.

entry.ety: See Delitescent

sn.def: Concealment; seclusion; retirement.
sn.q: The delitescence of mental activities.

sn.def: The sudden disappearance of inflammation.

entry.def: Concealment; seclusion.
entry.q: The mental organization of the novelist must be characterized, to speak craniologically, by an extraordinary development of the passion for delitescency.

entry.ety: L. delitescens -entis, p. pr. of delitescere to lie hid
entry.def: Lying hid; concealed.

entry.ety: L. delitigare to rail. See Litigate
entry.def: To chide; to rail heartily.
Chiding; brawl.

entry.usage: Deliver denotes, literally, to set free. Hence the term is extensively applied to cases where a thing is made to pass from a confined state to one of greater freedom or openness. Hence it may, in certain connections, be used as synonymous with any or all of the above-mentioned words, as will be seen from the following examples: One who delivers a package gives it forth; one who delivers a cargo discharges it; one who delivers a captive liberates him; one who delivers a message or a discourse utters or pronounces it; when soldiers deliver their fire, they set it free or give it forth.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Delivered; p. pr. & vb. n. Delivering
entry.ety: F. délivrer, LL. deliberare to liberate, give over, fr. L. de + liberare to set free. See Liberate

sn.def: To set free from restraint; to set at liberty; to release; to liberate, as from control; to give up; to free; to save; to rescue from evil actual or feared; -- often with from or out of; as, to deliver one from captivity, or from fear of death.
sn.q: He that taketh warning shall deliver his soul.
Promise was that I Should Israel from Philistian yoke deliver.

sn.def: To give or transfer; to yield possession or control of; to part with (to); to make over; to commit; to surrender; to resign; -- often with up or over to or into.
sn.q: Thou shalt deliver Pharaoh's cup into his hand.
The constables have delivered her over.
The exalted mind All sense of woe delivers to the wind.

sn.def: To make over to the knowledge of another; to communicate; to utter; to speak; to impart.
sn.q: Till he these words to him deliver might.
Whereof the former delivers the precepts of the art, and the latter the perfection.

sn.def: To give forth in action or exercise; to discharge; as, to deliver a blow; to deliver a broadside, or a ball.
sn.q: Shaking his head and delivering some show of tears.
An uninstructed bowler . . . thinks to attain the jack by delivering his bowl straightforward upon it.

sn.def: To free from, or disburden of, young; to relieve of a child in childbirth; to bring forth; -- often with of.
sn.q: She was delivered safe and soon.
Tully was long ere he could be delivered of a few verses, and those poor ones.

sn.def: To discover; to show.
sn.q: I 'll deliver Myself your loyal servant.

sn.def: To deliberate.
To admit; to allow to pass.
sn.syn: To Deliver Give Forth Discharge Liberate Pronounce Utter.

entry.ety: OF. delivre free, unfettered. See Deliver v. t.
entry.def: Free; nimble; sprightly; active.
entry.q: Wonderly deliver and great of strength.

entry.def: Capable of being, or about to be, delivered; necessary to be delivered.

entry.note: ☞ In this and in the preceding sense delivery is the word more commonly used.
entry.ety: F. délivrance, fr. délivrer

sn.def: The act of delivering or freeing from restraint, captivity, peril, and the like; rescue; as, the deliverance of a captive.
sn.q: He hath sent me to heal the broken-hearted, to preach deliverance to the captives.
One death or one deliverance we will share.

sn.def: Act of bringing forth children.
Act of speaking; utterance.
The state of being delivered, or freed from restraint.
sn.q: I do desire deliverance from these officers.

sn.def: Anything delivered or communicated; esp., an opinion or decision expressed publicly.
Any fact or truth which is decisively attested or intuitively known as a psychological or philosophical datum; as, the deliverance of consciousness.
One who delivers or rescues; a preserver.
One who relates or communicates.

entry.def: A female deliverer.
Actively; quickly; nimbly.
entry.q: Swim with your bodies, And carry it sweetly and deliverly.

entry.def: Nimbleness; agility.

entries.entry:
De*liv"er*y n.; pl.Deliveries.
The act of delivering from restraint; rescue; release; liberation; as, the delivery of a captive from his dungeon.
The act of delivering up or over; surrender; transfer of the body or substance of a thing; distribution; as, the delivery of a fort, of hostages, of a criminal, of goods, of letters.
The act or style of utterance; manner of speaking; as, a good delivery; a clear delivery.
The act of giving birth; parturition; the expulsion or extraction of a fetus and its membranes.
The act of exerting one's strength or limbs. Neater limbs and freer delivery.
The act or manner of delivering a ball; as, the pitcher has a swift delivery .

entry.ety: AS. del, akin to E. dale; cf. D. delle del, low ground. See Dale

sn.def: A small, retired valley; a ravine.
sn.q: In dells and dales, concealed from human sight.

sn.def: A young woman; a wench.
sn.q: Sweet doxies and dells.

entries.entry: Del"la Crus"ca Del"la Crus"ca ☞ The Accademia della Crusca (literally, academy of the bran or chaff) was so called in allusion to its chief object of bolting or purifying the national language.. A shortened form of Accademia della Crusca, an academy in Florence, Italy, founded in the 16th century, especially for conserving the purity of the Italian language.

cs.cd: a name given in satire to a class of affected English writers, most of whom lived in Florence, about a. d. 1785.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to the Accademia della Crusca in Florence.
The duykerbok.

entry.ety: Prob. of Arabic or Bedouin origin
entry.def: A special breed of the dromedary used for rapid traveling; the swift camel; -- called also herire, and maharik.
Delftware.
entry.q: Five nothings in five plates of delph.

entry.def: The drain on the land side of a sea embankment.
Delphic.

entry.ety: L. Delphicus, fr. Gr. Delfiko`s, fr. Delfoi`, L. Delphi, a town of Phocis, in Greece, now Kastri

sn.def: Of or relating to Delphi, or to the famous oracle of that place.
Ambiguous; mysterious.
sn.q: If he is silent ordelphic.

entry.ety: See Dauphin
entry.def: Pertaining to the dauphin of France; as, the Delphin classics, an edition of the Latin classics, prepared in the reign of Louis XIV., for the use of the dauphin (in usum Delphini).

entry.ety: L. delphinus a dolphin
entry.def: A fatty substance contained in the oil of the dolphin and the porpoise; -- called also phocenin.

entry.ety: L. delphinus a dolphin, Gr. delfi`s delfi`n
entry.def: Pertaining to the dolphin, a genus of fishes.

entry.cs: Delphinic acid. Chem See Valeric acid, under Valeric. Obs
entry.ety: See Delphin n.
entry.def: Pertaining to, or derived from, the dolphin; phocenic.

entry.ety: From NL. Delphinium, the name of the genus
entry.def: Pertaining to, or derived from, the larkspur; specifically, relating to the stavesacre (Delphinium staphisagria).

entry.ety: Cf. F. delphinine
entry.def: A poisonous alkaloid extracted from the stavesacre (Delphinium staphisagria), as a colorless amorphous powder.

entry.ety: L. delphinus a dolphin + -oid
entry.def: Pertaining to, or resembling, the dolphin.

entry.ety: NL
entry.def: The division of Cetacea which comprises the dolphins, porpoises, and related forms.

entry.ety: L., a dolphin, fr. Gr. delfi`s delfi`n

sn.def: A genus of Cetacea, including the dolphin. See Dolphin, 1.
The Dolphin, a constellation near the equator and east of Aquila.

entries.entry: Del*sarte" n.orDelsarte system . A system of calisthenics patterned on the theories of François Delsarte (1811 -- 71), a French teacher of dramatic and musical expression.

Del"ta n.; pl.Deltas #. Gr. de`lta, the name of the fourth letter of the Greek alphabet (the capital form of which is Δ, Eng. D), from the Phœnician name of the corresponding letter. The Greeks called the alluvial deposit at the mouth of the Nile, from its shape, the Delta of the Nile
The fourth letter of the Greek alphabet (Δ δ), corresponding to D. Hence, an object having the shape of the capital Δ.
A tract of land shaped like the letter delta (Δ), especially when the land is alluvial and inclosed between two or more mouths of a river; as, the delta of the Ganges, of the Nile, or of the Mississippi.
Elec The closed figure produced by connecting three coils or circuits successively, end for end, esp. in a three-phase system; -- often used attributively, as delta winding, delta connection (which see), etc.

Delta connection. Elec One of the usual forms or methods for connecting apparatus to a three-phase circuit, the three corners of the delta or triangle, as diagrammatically represented, being connected to the three wires of the supply circuit.
Delta current. Elec The current flowing through a delta connection.

entry.ety: Delta + L. facere to make
entry.def: The formation of a delta or of deltas.
Relating to, or like, a delta.

cs.cd: one of the divisions of the Upper Silurian rocks in New York.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. de`lta the name of the letter Δ + thy`ra door
entry.def: A name formerly given to certain Silurian brachiopod shells of the genus Spirifer.
Deltaic.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. de`lta, the letter Δ
entry.def: The triangular space under the beak of many brachiopod shells.

entry.ety: Gr. de`lta, the letter Δ + 'e`dra seat, base
entry.def: A solid bounded by twelve quadrilateral faces. It is a hemihedral form of the isometric system, allied to the tetrahedron.

cs.cd: a leaf in the form of a triangle with the stem inserted at the middle of the base.
a large triangular muscle covering the shoulder joint, which serves to raise the arm directly upward.

entry.ety: Gr. deltoeidh`s delta- shaped; de`lta the name of the letter Δ + e'i^dos form: cf. F. deltoïde. See Delta

sn.def: Shaped like the Greek Δ (delta); delta-shaped; triangular.
of or pertaining to the deltoid muscle.

entry.ety: see deltoid a.
entry.def: the deltoid muscle.
The deltoid muscles; -- a contraction used by body-building and health enthusiasts. Used similarly to abs and pecs. See deltoid muscle.
Capable of being deluded; liable to be imposed on; gullible.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Deluded; p. pr. & vb. n. Deluding
entry.ety: L. deludere delusum; de- + ludere to play, make sport of, mock. See Ludicrous

sn.def: To lead from truth or into error; to mislead the mind or judgment of; to beguile; to impose on; to dupe; to make a fool of.
sn.q: To delude the nation by an airy phantom.

sn.def: To frustrate or disappoint.
sn.q: It deludes thy search.
sn.syn: To mislead; deceive; beguile; cajole; cheat; dupe. See Deceive.

entry.def: One who deludes; a deceiver; an impostor.

entry.ety: F. déluge, L. diluvium, fr. diluere wash away; di- = dis- + luere, equiv. to lavare to wash. See Lave, and cf. Diluvium

sn.def: A washing away; an overflowing of the land by water; an inundation; a flood; specifically, The Deluge, the great flood in the days of Noah (Gen. vii.).
Fig.: Anything which overwhelms, or causes great destruction.
sn.q: Thedelugeof summer.
A fiery deluge fed With ever-burning sulphur unconsumed.
As I grub up some quaint old fragment of a [London] street, or a house, or a shop, or tomb or burial ground, which has still survived in the deluge.
After me the deluge.Aprés moi le déluge

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Deluged; p. pr. & vb. n. Deluging

sn.def: To overflow with water; to inundate; to overwhelm.
sn.q: The deluged earth would useless grow.

sn.def: To overwhelm, as with a deluge; to cover; to overspread; to overpower; to submerge; to destroy; as, the northern nations deluged the Roman empire with their armies; the land is deluged with woe.
sn.q: At length corruption, like a general flood . . . Shall deluge all.

entry.ety: Native name
entry.def: An East Indian carnivorous mammal (Prionodon gracilis), resembling the civets, but without scent pouches. It is handsomely spotted.

entry.usage: These words both imply some deception practiced upon the mind. Delusion is deception from want of knowledge; illusion is deception from morbid imagination. An illusion is a false show, a mere cheat on the fancy or senses. It is, in other words, some idea or image presented to the bodily or mental vision which does not exist in reality. A delusion is a false judgment, usually affecting the real concerns of life. Or, in other words, it is an erroneous view of something which exists indeed, but has by no means the qualities or attributes ascribed to it. Thus we speak of the illusions of fancy, the illusions of hope, illusive prospects, illusive appearances, etc. In like manner, we speak of the delusions of stockjobbing, the delusions of honorable men, delusive appearances in trade, of being deluded by a seeming excellence. “A fanatic, either religious or political, is the subject of strong delusions; while the term illusion is applied solely to the visions of an uncontrolled imagination, the chimerical ideas of one blinded by hope, passion, or credulity, or lastly, to spectral and other ocular deceptions, to which the word delusion is never applied.” Whately.
entry.ety: L. delusio, fr. deludere. See Delude

sn.def: The act of deluding; deception; a misleading of the mind.
The state of being deluded or misled.
That which is falsely or delusively believed or propagated; false belief; error in belief.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to delusions; as, delusional monomania.

entry.ety: See Delude
entry.def: Apt or fitted to delude; tending to mislead the mind; deceptive; beguiling; delusory; as, delusive arts; a delusive dream.
entry.q: Delusive and unsubstantial ideas.

entry.def: Delusive; fallacious.

sn.def: impressively expensive; notably exceeding typical price or quality.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Delved; p. pr. & vb. n. Delving
entry.ety: AS. delfan to dig; akin to OS. bidelban to bury, D. delven to dig, MHG. telben, and possibly to E. dale. Cf. Delf a mine

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Demanded; p. pr. & vb. n. Demanding
entry.ety: F. demander, LL. demandare to demand, summon, send word, fr. L. demandare to give in charge, intrust; de- + mandare to commit to one's charge, commission, order, command. Cf. Mandate Commend

entry.note: ☞ The demise of the crown is a transfer of the crown, royal authority, or kingdom, to a successor. Thus, when Edward IV. was driven from his throne for a few months by the house of Lancaster, this temporary transfer of his dignity was called a demise. Thus the natural death of a king or queen came to be denominated a demise, as by that event the crown is transferred to a successor.

entries.entry:
De*moc"ra*cy d�*mŏk"rȧ*s� n.; pl.Democracies d�*mŏk"rȧ*sĭz. F. démocratie, fr. Gr. dhmokrati`a; dh^mos the people + kratei^n to be strong, to rule, kra`tos strength
Government by the people; a form of government in which the supreme power is retained and directly exercised by the people.
Government by popular representation; a form of government in which the supreme power is retained by the people, but is indirectly exercised through a system of representation and delegated authority periodically renewed; a constitutional representative government; a republic.
Collectively, the people, regarded as the source of government.

sn.q: Whatever they call him, what care I, Aristocrat, democrat, autocrat.

cs.cd: the name of one of the chief political parties in the United States.
cs.note: Presidents of the United States who belonged to the Democratic party in the twentieth century were Woodrow Wilson Franklin D. Roosevelt Harry Truman John F. Kennedy Lyndon B. Johnson Jimmy Carter, and Bill Clinton.

entry.ety: Gr. �: cf. F. démocratique

Befitting the common people; -- opposed to aristocratic.

entry.ety: First mentioned by Lutatius, or Lactantius Placidus, the scholiast on Statius, perh. fr. Gr. dai`mwn god, deity + gorgo`s fierce, terrible

entry.q: Orcus and Ades, and the dreaded name Of Demogorgon.

entry.def: of or pertaining to demography; as, demographic surveys.

entry.ety: Gr. dh^mos the people + -graphy
entry.def: The study of vital statistics, such as births, deaths, marriages, mortality, health, etc., in populations and subgroups of populations.

entry.ety: F. See Damsel

sn.def: A young lady; a damsel; a lady's maid.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Demolished; p. pr. & vb. n. Demolishing
entry.ety: F. démolir, fr. L. demoliri, p. p. demolitus; de- + moliri to set a thing in motion, to work, construct, from moles a huge mass or structure. See Mole a mound, and Finish
entry.def: To throw or pull down; to raze; to destroy the fabric of; to pull to pieces; to ruin; as, to demolish an edifice, or a wall.
entry.q: I expected the fabric of my book would long since have been demolished, and laid even with the ground.
entry.syn: To Demolish Overturn Destroy Dismantle Raze. That is overturned or overthrown which had stood upright; that is destroyed whose component parts are scattered; that is demolished which had formed a mass or structure; that is dismantled which is stripped of its covering, as a vessel of its sails, or a fortress of its bastions, etc.; that is razed which is brought down smooth, and level to the ground. An ancient pillar is overturned or overthrown as the result of decay; a city is destroyed by an invasion of its enemies; a monument, the walls of a castle, a church, or any structure, real or imaginary, may be demolished; a fortress may be dismantled from motives of prudence, in order to render it defenseless; a city may be razed by way of punishment, and its ruins become a memorial of vengeance.

entry.def: One who, or that which, demolishes; as, a demolisher of towns.
Demolition.

entry.ety: L. demolitio, fr. demoliri: cf. F. démolition. See Demolish
entry.def: The act of overthrowing, pulling down, or destroying a pile or structure; destruction by violence; utter overthrow; -- opposed to construction; as, the demolition of a house, of military works, of a town, or of hopes.
A demolisher.

entry.ety: F. démon, L. daemon a spirit, an evil spirit, fr. Gr. dai`mwn a divinity; of uncertain origin

same as demonetization.

entry.q: They [gold mohurs] have been completely demonetized by the [East India] Company.

entry.ety: L. daemoniacus, fr. daemon; cf. F. démoniaque. See Demon

entry.def: A believer in, or worshiper of, demons.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Demonized; p. pr. & vb. n. Demonizing
entry.ety: Cf. LL. daemonizare to be possessed by a demon, Gr. �

entry.def: The worship of demons.
One versed in demonology.

entry.ety: Cf. F. démonologique
entry.def: Of or pertaining to demonology.
One who writes on, or is versed in, demonology.

entry.ety: Demon + -logy: cf. F. démonologie
entry.def: A treatise on demons; a supposititious science which treats of demons and their manifestations.

entry.ety: Gr. dai`mwn demon + magei`a magic
entry.def: Magic in which the aid of demons is invoked; black or infernal magic.

entry.ety: Demon + mania
entry.def: A form of madness in which the patient conceives himself possessed of devils.
One in subjection to a demon, or to demons.

entry.ety: Gr. dai`mwn demon + no`mos law
entry.def: The dominion of demons.
Demoniacal influence or possession.
The state of a demon.
The quality of being demonstrable; demonstrableness.

entry.ety: L. demonstrabilis: cf. OF. demonstrable, F. démontrable

sn.def: Capable of being demonstrated; that can be proved beyond doubt or question.
sn.q: The grand articles of our belief are as demonstrable as geometry.

sn.def: Proved; apparent.

entry.def: The quality of being demonstrable; demonstrability.
In a demonstrable manner; incontrovertibly; clearly.
entry.q: Cases that demonstrably concerned the public cause.

entry.ety: OF. demonstrance
entry.def: Demonstration; proof.

entry.ety: L. demonstratus, p. p. of demonstrare to demonstrate; de- + monstrare to show. See Monster

sn.def: To point out; to show; to exhibit; to make evident.
To show, or make evident, by reasoning or proof; to prove by deduction; to establish so as to exclude the possibility of doubt or denial.
sn.q: We can not demonstrate these things so as to show that the contrary often involves a contradiction.

sn.def: To exhibit and explain (a dissection or other anatomical preparation).

entry.def: having been proved or verified beyond doubt; proved by demonstration.
See Demonstrator.

entry.cs:
Direct demonstrationorPositive demonstration, Logic & Math one in which the correct conclusion is the immediate sequence of reasoning from axiomatic or established premises; -- opposed to Indirect demonstrationorNegative demonstration
called also reductio ad absurdum), in which the correct conclusion is an inference from the demonstration that any other hypothesis must be incorrect.
entry.ety: L. demonstratio: cf. F. démonstration

sn.def: The act of demonstrating; an exhibition; proof; especially, proof beyond the possibility of doubt; indubitable evidence, to the senses or reason.
sn.q: Those intervening ideas which serve to show the agreement of any two others are called “proofs;” and where agreement or disagreement is by this means plainly and clearly perceived, it is called demonstration.

sn.def: An expression, as of the feelings, by outward signs; a manifestation; a show. See also sense 7 for a more specific related meaning.
sn.q: Did your letters pierce the queen to any demonstration of grief?
Loyal demonstrations toward the prince.

sn.def: The exhibition and explanation of a dissection or other anatomical preparation.
Mil.) a decisive exhibition of force, or a movement indicating an attack.
The act of proving by the syllogistic process, or the proof itself.
A course of reasoning showing that a certain result is a necessary consequence of assumed premises; -- these premises being definitions, axioms, and previously established propositions.

a public gathering of people to express some sentiment or feelings by explicit means, such as picketing, parading, carrying signs or shouting, usually in favor of or opposed to some action of government or of a business.

the act of showing how a certain device, machine or product operates, or how a procedure is performed; -- usually done for the purpose of inducing prospective customers to buy a product; as, a demonstration of the simple operation of a microwave oven.

cs.cd: a pronoun distinctly designating that to which it refers.

entry.ety: F. démonstratif, L. demonstrativus

sn.def: Having the nature of demonstration; tending to demonstrate; making evident; exhibiting clearly or conclusively.
sn.q: Demonstrativefigures.
An argument necessary and demonstrative.

sn.def: Expressing, or apt to express, much; displaying feeling or sentiment; as, her nature was demonstrative .
Consisting of eulogy or of invective.
sn.q: Demonstrativeeloquence.

entry.def: A demonstrative pronoun; as, “this” and “that” are demonstratives .
In a manner fitted to demonstrate; clearly; convincingly; forcibly.
The state or quality of being demonstrative.

entry.ety: L.: cf. F. démonstrateur

sn.def: One who demonstrates;

sd.def: one who proves anything with certainty, or establishes it by indubitable evidence.
one who shows how a certain device operates or a procedure is performed.

sn.def: A teacher of practical anatomy.
a person who participates in a demonstration{7}.

entry.def: Tending to demonstrate; demonstrative.
Demurrage.

entry.ety: Cf. F. démoralisation
entry.def: The act of corrupting or subverting morals. Especially: The act of corrupting or subverting discipline, courage, hope, etc., or the state of being corrupted or subverted in discipline, courage, etc.; as, the demoralization of an army or navy.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Demoralized; p. pr. & vb. n. Demoralizing
entry.ety: F. démoraliser; pref. dé-L. dis- or de) + moraliser. See Moralize
entry.def: To corrupt or undermine in morals; to destroy or lessen the effect of moral principles on; to render corrupt or untrustworthy in morals, in discipline, in courage, spirit, etc.; to weaken in spirit or efficiency.
entry.q: The demoralizing example of profligate power and prosperous crime.
The vices of the nobility had demoralized the army.

entry.def: made less hopeful or enthusiastic; rendered pessimistic; as, the demoralized Iraqi ground troops put up little resistance.

sn.def: discouraging. Opposite of encouraging.

entry.def: a famous Grecian orator, born circa 385 BC, died circa 322 BC.

entry.ety: L. Demosthenicus: cf. F. Démosthénique
entry.def: Pertaining to, or in the style of, Demosthenes, the Grecian orator.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Demoted; p. pr. & vb. n. Demoting
entry.ety: Pref. de- + mote, as in promote; cf. L. demovere to remove
entry.def: To reduce to a lower grade or rank, as in the military, one's employment, or in school; to assign to a lower position.
entry.syn: bump, relegate, kick downstairs, break one's rank.

cs.cd: a form of writing used in Egypt after six or seven centuries before Christ, for books, deeds, and other such writings; a simplified form of the hieratic character; -- called also epistolographic character, and enchorial character. See Enchorial.

entry.ety: Gr. dhmotiko`s, fr. dh^mos the people: cf. F. démotique
entry.def: Of or pertaining to the people; popular; common.
The department of knowledge relative to the care and culture of the people; sociology in its broadest sense; -- in library cataloguing.
To dismount.

entry.ety: See De-; Mount
entry.def: Capable of being dismounted; -- said of a form of rim, for an automobile wheel, which can be removed with its tire from the wheel.
To damn; to condemn.

entry.ety: See Deemster

sn.def: A deemster.
An officer whose duty it was to announce the doom or sentence pronounced by the court.

entry.ety: L. demulcere; de- + mulcere to stroke, soothe
entry.def: To soothe; to mollify; to pacify; to soften.

entry.ety: L. demulcens, p. pr. of demulcere
entry.def: Softening; mollifying; soothing; assuasive; as, oil is demulcent .

A substance, usually of a mucilaginous or oily nature, supposed to be capable of soothing an inflamed nervous membrane, or protecting it from irritation. Gum Arabic, glycerin, olive oil, etc., are demulcents.
The act of soothing; that which soothes.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Demurred; p. pr. & vb. n. Demurring
entry.ety: OF. demurer demorer demourer, to linger, stay, F. demeurer, fr. L. demorari; de- + morari to delay, tarry, stay, mora delay; prob. originally, time for thinking, reflection, and akin to memor mindful. See Memory

sn.def: To linger; to stay; to tarry.
sn.q: Yet durst not demur nor abide upon the camp.

sn.def: To delay; to pause; to suspend proceedings or judgment in view of a doubt or difficulty; to hesitate; to put off the determination or conclusion of an affair.
sn.q: Upon this rub, the English embassadors thought fit to demur.

sn.def: To scruple or object; to take exception, especailly on the basis of scruple or modesty; as, I demur to that statement; they wanted to make him president, but he demurred .
sn.q: When introduced as the world's smartest man, he was not inclined to demur.

sn.def: To interpose a demurrer. See Demurrer, 2.
To suspend judgment concerning; to doubt of or hesitate about.
sn.q: The latter I demur, for in their looks Much reason, and in their actions, oft appears.

sn.def: To cause delay to; to put off.
sn.q: He demands a fee, And then demurs me with a vain delay.

entry.ety: OF. demor demore, stay, delay. See Demur v. i.
entry.def: Stop; pause; hesitation as to proceeding; suspense of decision or action; scruple.
entry.q: All my demurs but double his attacks; At last he whispers, “Do; and we go snacks.”

entry.ety: Perh. from OF. de mursi. e., de bonnes murs of good manners); de of + murs mours meurs mors, F. m�urs, fr. L. moressing. mos) manners, morals (see Moral); or more prob. fr. OF. meür, F. mûr mature, ripe (see Mature) in a phrase preceded by de as de mûre conduite of mature conduct

sn.def: Of sober or serious mien; composed and decorous in bearing; of modest look; staid; grave.
sn.q: Sober, steadfast, and demure.
Nan was very much delighted in her demure way, and that delight showed itself in her face and in her clear bright eyes.

sn.def: Affectedly modest, decorous, or serious; making a show of gravity.
sn.q: A cat lay, and looked so demure, as if there had been neither life nor soul in her.
Miss Lizzy, I have no doubt, would be as demure and coquettish, as if ten winters more had gone over her head.

entry.def: To look demurely.
In a demure manner; soberly; gravely; -- now, commonly, with a mere show of gravity or modesty.
entry.q: They . . . looked as demurely as they could; for 't was a hanging matter to laugh unseasonably.

entry.def: The state of being demure; gravity; the show of gravity or modesty.
Demureness; also, one who is demure.
That may be demurred to.

entry.note: ☞ The term is also applied to similar delays and allowances in land carriage, by wagons, railroads, etc.
entry.ety: Cf. OF. demorage delay. See Demur
entry.def: The detention of a vessel by the freighter beyond the time allowed in her charter party for loading, unloading, or sailing.
The allowance made to the master or owner of the ship for such delay or detention.
entry.q: The claim for demurrage ceases as soon as the ship is cleared out and ready for sailing.

entry.def: Demur; delay in acting or deciding.
entry.q: The same causes of demurral existed which prevented British troops from assisting in the expulsion of the French from Rome.

cs.cd: an exception taken by a party to the evidence offered by the opposite party, and an objecting to proceed further, on the allegation that such evidence is not sufficient in law to maintain the issue, and a reference to the court to determine the point.

sn.def: One who demurs.

A stop or pause by a party to an action, for the judgment of the court on the question, whether, assuming the truth of the matter alleged by the opposite party, it is sufficient in law to sustain the action or defense, and hence whether the party resting is bound to answer or proceed further.

entries.entry:
De*my" n.; pl.Demies #. See Demi-
A printing and a writing paper of particular sizes. See under Paper.
A half fellow at Magdalen College, Oxford.
demi
He was elected into Magdalen College as a demy; a term by which that society denominates those elsewhere called “scholars,” young men who partake of the founder's benefaction, and succeed in their order to vacant fellowships.

entry.def: Pertaining to, or made of, the size of paper called demy; as, a demy book.
same as demythologization.
the restatement of a message (as a religious one) in rational terms.
to remove the mythical elements from; -- of writings, such as the Bible.
having mythical elements removed.

entry.ety: AS. denn; perh. akin to G. tenne floor, thrashing floor, and to AS. denu valley

sn.def: A small cavern or hollow place in the side of a hill, or among rocks; esp., a cave used by a wild beast for shelter or concealment; as, a lion's den; a den of robbers.
A squalid place of resort; a wretched dwelling place; a haunt; as, a den of vice.
sn.q: Those squaliddens, which are the reproach of great capitals.

sn.def: Any snug or close retreat where one goes to be alone.
A narrow glen; a ravine; a dell.

entry.def: To live in, or as in, a den.
entry.q: The sluggish salvages that den below.

sn.def: The native name for Mount McKinley in Alaska, translated as the great one.
a national park in Alaska in which Mount McKinley is located.

entry.def: To deprive of narcotine; as, to denarcotize opium.

entries.entry:
De*na"ri*us De*na"ri*us n.; pl.Denarii #. L. See 2d Denier
A Roman silver coin of the value of about fourteen cents; the “penny” of the New Testament; -- so called from being worth originally ten of the pieces called as.

entry.ety: L. denarius. See 2d Denier
entry.def: Containing ten; tenfold; proceeding by tens; as, the denary, or decimal, scale.

sn.def: The number ten; a division into ten.
A coin; the Anglicized form of denarius.

entry.def: same as denationalization.

entry.ety: Cf. F. dénationalisation
entry.def: The act or process of denationalizing.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Denationalized; p. pr. & vb. n. Denationalizing
entry.ety: Cf. F. dénationaliser

sn.def: To divest or deprive of national character or rights.
sn.q: Bonaparte's decree denationalizes, as he calls it, all ships that have touched at a British port.
An expatriated, denationalized race.

sn.def: to change (something, as an industry or business) from state to private ownership or control; as, the British denationalization of steel.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Denaturalized; p. pr. & vb. n. Denaturalizing
entry.ety: Cf. F. dénaturaliser

sn.def: To render unnatural; to alienate from nature.
To renounce the natural rights and duties of; to deprive of citizenship; to denationalize.
sn.q: They also claimed the privilege, when aggrieved, of denaturalizing themselves, or, in other words, of publicly renouncing their allegiance to their sovereign, and of enlisting under the banners of his enemy.

sn.def: same as denature.

entry.note: Bioactive macromolecules such as enzymes or DNA may be denatured by heat, acid, alkali, or solvent treatment; the extent of such treatment required to denature a molecule varies with the specific compound. In some cases the denatured molecules may regain their original properties (renature) by other treatments. Denaturation may also cause a change in the physical properties of such molecules, e.g. proteins may become insoluble in water.
entry.ety: De- + nature
entry.def: To deprive of its natural qualities; change the nature of.

sn.def: to render (ethyl alcohol) unfit to drink by adding in toxic or unpalatable substances (such as benzene or pyridine) which nevertherless permit alcohol to be used as a solvent.
modify the tertiary structure of (a protein or nucleic acid) so as to reduce or destroy its characteristic biological activity.

entry.def: To become denatured.
changed in nature or natural quality.

entry.ety: See Deny
entry.def: To deny.
entry.q: That with great rage he stoutly doth denay.

entry.def: Denial; refusal.

entry.ety: L. dendrachates; Gr. de`ndron a tree + � agate: cf. F. dendrachate dendragate
entry.def: Arborescent or dendritic agate.
a genus comprising plants often included in the genus Chrysanthemum.
a genus of African snakes comprising the mambas.

entry.ety: Gr. de`ndron tree + -form
entry.def: Resembling in structure a tree or shrub; having a branching shape.
entry.syn: arboreal, arboreous, arborescent, arboresque, arboriform, dendroid, dendroidal, treelike, tree-shaped.

entry.ety: Gr. dendri`ths, fem. dendri^tis, of a tree, fr. de`ndron a tree: cf. F. dendrite
entry.def: A stone or mineral on or in which are branching figures resembling shrubs or trees, produced by a foreign mineral, usually an oxide of manganese, as in the moss agate; also, a crystallized mineral having an arborescent form, e. g., gold or silver; an arborization.
Pertaining to a dendrite, or to arborescent crystallization; having a form resembling a shrub or tree; arborescent.
a genus of African snakes comprising the mambas.

entries.entry: Den`dro*cœ"la‖n. pl. NL., fr. Gr. de`ndron tree + koi^los hollow Zoöl A division of the Turbellaria in which the digestive cavity gives off lateral branches, which are often divided into smaller branchlets.

entry.ety: Gr. � treelike; de`ndron tree + e'i^dos form: cf. F. dendroïde
entry.def: Resembling a shrub or tree in form; treelike; branching.
entry.syn: arboreal, arboreous, arborescent, arboresque, arboriform, dendriform, treelike, tree-shaped.

entry.def: a genus comprising the tree wallabies.

entry.ety: Gr. de`ndron tree + -lite: cf. F. dendrolithe
entry.def: A petrified or fossil shrub, plant, or part of a plant.
One versed in the natural history of trees.
Relating to dendrology.

entry.ety: Gr. de`ndron tree + -logy: cf. F. dendrologie

sn.def: the branch of botany studying trees and shrubs; the natural history of trees.
A discourse or treatise on trees.

entry.def: a genus having only one species, the bush poppy.

entry.ety: Gr. de`ndron tree + -meter: cf. F. dendromètre
entry.def: An instrument to measure the height and diameter of trees.

entry.ety: L. denegatus, p. p. of denegare. See Deny
entry.def: To deny.

entry.ety: Cf. F. dénégation
entry.def: Denial.

entry.note: ☞ This disease, when it first appeared in the British West India Islands, was called the dandy fever, from the stiffness and constraint which it grave to the limbs and body. The Spaniards of the neighboring islands mistook the term for their word dengue, denoting prudery, which might also well express stiffness, and hence the term dengue became, as last, the name of the disease. Tully.
entry.ety: See Note, below
entry.def: A specific epidemic disease attended with high fever, cutaneous eruption, and severe pains in the head and limbs, resembling those of rheumatism; -- called also breakbone fever. It occurs in India, Egypt, the West Indies, etc., is of short duration, and rarely fatal.

entry.ety: See Deny
entry.def: Capable of being, or liable to be, denied.

cs.cd: a declining of some gratification; restraint of one's appetites or propensities; self-denial.

entry.ety: See Deny

sn.def: The act of gainsaying, refusing, or disowning; negation; -- the contrary of affirmation.
sn.q: You ought to converse with so much sincerity that your bare affirmation or denial may be sufficient.

sn.def: A refusal to admit the truth of a statement, charge, imputation, etc.; assertion of the untruth of a thing stated or maintained; a contradiction.
A refusal to grant; rejection of a request.
sn.q: The commissioners, . . . to obtain from the king's subjects as much as they would willingly give, . . . had not to complain of many peremptory denials.

sn.def: A refusal to acknowledge; disclaimer of connection with; disavowal; -- the contrary of confession; as, the denial of a fault charged on one; a denial of God.

entry.def: Denial.
One who denies; as, a denier of a fact, or of the faith, or of Christ.

entry.ety: F. denier, fr. L. denarius a Roman silver coin orig. equiv. to ten asses, later, a copper, fr. deni ten by ten, fr. the root of decem ten; akin to E. ten. See Ten, and cf. Denary Dinar
entry.def: A small copper coin of insignificant value.
entry.q: My dukedom to a beggarly denier.

entry.ety: L. denigrare; de- + nigrare to blacken, niger black

sn.def: To blacken thoroughly; to make very black.
Fig.: To blacken or sully; to defame.
sn.q: To denigrate the memory of Voltaire.

entry.def: harmful and often untrue; tending to discredit or malign; -- used of statements.
entry.syn: calumniatory, calumnious, defamatory, denigrative, libellous, libelous, slanderous.

entry.ety: L. denigratio

sn.def: The act of making black.
Fig.: A blackening; defamation.
sn.q: The vigorous denigration of science.

entry.def: One who, or that which, blackens.
same as denigrating.

entry.ety: Of uncertain origin
entry.def: A coarse cotton drilling used for overalls, etc.

entry.ety: Pref. de- + nitrate
entry.def: A disengaging, or removal, of nitric acid.
The act or process of freeing from nitrogen; also, the condition resulting from the removal of nitrogen.

entry.ety: Pref. de- + nitrogen + -fy
entry.def: To deprive of, or free from, nitrogen.
The act of making one a denizen or adopted citizen; naturalization.
To make a denizen; to confer the rights of citizenship upon; to naturalize.
entry.q: There was a private act made for denizing the children of Richard Hills.

entry.ety: OF. denzein deinzein, prop., one living (a city or country); opposed to forain foreign, and fr. denz within, F. dans, fr. L. de intus, prop., from within, intus being from in in. See In, and cf. Foreign

sn.def: A dweller; an inhabitant.
sn.q: Denizensof air.
Denizens of their own free, independent state.

sn.def: One who is admitted by favor to all or a part of the rights of citizenship, where he did not possess them by birth; an adopted or naturalized citizen.
One admitted to residence in a foreign country.
sn.q: Ye gods, Natives, or denizens, of blest abodes.

sn.def: To constitute (one) a denizen; to admit to residence, with certain rights and privileges.
sn.q: As soon as denizened, they domineer.

sn.def: To provide with denizens; to populate with adopted or naturalized occupants.
sn.q: There [islets] were at once denizened by various weeds.

entry.def: Denization; denizening.
To constitute (one) a denizen; to denizen.
State of being a denizen.

entries.entry: Den"mark sat"in. See under Satin.

entry.def: A light, open, two-wheeled carriage for one horse; a kind of gig.
Capable of being denominated or named.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Denominated; p. pr. & vb. n. Denominating
entry.ety: L. denominatus, p. p. of denominare to name; de- + nominare to call by name. See Nominate
entry.def: To give a name to; to characterize by an epithet; to entitle; to name; to designate.
entry.q: Passions commonly denominating selfish.

entry.ety: L. denominatus, p. p
entry.def: Having a specific name or denomination; specified in the concrete as opposed to abstract; thus, 7 feet is a denominate quantity, while 7 is mere abstract quantity or number. See Compound number, under Compound.

entry.ety: L. denominatio metonymy: cf. F. dénomination a naming

sn.def: The act of naming or designating.

That by which anything is denominated or styled; an epithet; a name, designation, or title; especially, a general name indicating a class of like individuals; a category; as, the denomination of units, or of thousands, or of fourths, or of shillings, or of tons.
sn.q: Those [qualities] which are classed under the denomination of sublime.

sn.def: A class, or society of individuals, called by the same name; a sect; as, a denomination of Christians.

entry.def: Pertaining to a denomination, especially to a sect or society.
entry.q: Denominationaldifferences.

entry.def: A denominational or class spirit or policy; devotion to the interests of a sect or denomination.
One imbued with a denominational spirit.
In a denominational manner; by denomination or sect.

entry.ety: Cf. F. dénominatif

sn.def: Conferring a denomination or name.
Connotative; as, a denominative name.
Possessing, or capable of possessing, a distinct denomination or designation; denominable.
sn.q: The least denominative part of time is a minute.

sn.def: Derived from a substantive or an adjective; as, a denominative verb.

entry.def: A denominative name or term; denominative verb.
By denomination.

entry.note: ☞ Thus, in 3/5, 5 is the denominator, showing that the integer is divided into five parts; and the numerator, 3, shows how many parts are taken.
☞ In this sense, the denominator is not necessarily a number, but may be any expression, either positive or negative, real or imaginary.

cs.cd: a number which can divide either of two or more other numbers without leaving a remainder in any of the divisions; as, 2 and 4 are common denominators of 12 and 28..
the largest common denominator of two or more numbers; as, 9 is the greatest common denominator of 18 and 27..

entry.ety: Cf. F. dénominateur

sn.def: One who, or that which, gives a name; origin or source of a name.
sn.q: This opinion that Aram . . . was the father and denomination of the Syrians in general.

sn.def: That number placed below the line in common fractions which shows into how many parts the integer or unit is divided.
That part of any expression under a fractional form which is situated below the horizontal line signifying division.

entry.ety: From Denote
entry.def: Capable of being denoted or marked.
the actual object referred to by a linguistic expression.

entry.ety: L. denotatus, p. p. of denotare
entry.def: To mark off; to denote.
entry.q: These terms denotate a longer time.
What things should be denotated and signified by the color.

entry.ety: L. denotatio: cf. F. dénotation
entry.def: The marking off or separation of anything.
Having power to denote; designating or marking off.
entry.q: Proper names are preëminently denotative; telling us that such as object has such a term to denote it, but telling us nothing as to any single attribute.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Denoted; p. pr. & vb. n. Denoting
entry.ety: L. denotare; de- + notare to mark, nota mark, sign, note: cf. F. dénoter. See Note

sn.def: To mark out plainly; to signify by a visible sign; to serve as the sign or name of; to indicate; to point out; as, the hands of the clock denote the hour.
sn.q: The better to denote her to the doctor.

sn.def: To be the sign of; to betoken; to signify; to mean.
sn.q: A general expression to denote wickedness of every sort.

entry.note: ☞ A word found in some editions of Shakespeare.
entry.def: Sign; indication.
Serving to denote.

entry.ety: F. dénouement, fr. dénouer to untie; pref. dé-L. dis-) + nouer to tie, fr. L. nodus knot, perh. for gnodus and akin to E. knot

sn.def: The unraveling or discovery of a plot; the catastrophe, especially of a drama or a romance.
The solution of a mystery; issue; outcome.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Denounced; p. pr. & vb. n. Denouncing
entry.ety: F. dénoncer, OF. denoncier, fr. L. denuntiare denunciare; de- + nunciare nuntiare, to announce, report, nuntius a messenger, message. See Nuncio, and cf. Denunciate

sn.def: To make known in a solemn or official manner; to declare; to proclaim (especially an evil).
sn.q: Denouncing wrath to come.
I denounce unto you this day, that ye shall surely perish.

sn.def: To proclaim in a threatening manner; to threaten by some outward sign or expression.
sn.q: His look denounced desperate.

sn.def: To point out as deserving of reprehension or punishment, etc.; to accuse in a threatening manner; to invoke censure upon; to stigmatize.
sn.q: Denounced for a heretic.
To denounce the immoralities of Julius Cæsar.

entry.ety: Cf. OF. denoncement
entry.def: Solemn, official, or menacing announcement; denunciation.
entry.q: False is the reply of Cain, upon the denouncement of his curse.

entry.def: One who denounces, or declares, as a menace.
entry.q: Here comes the sad denouncer of my fate.

entry.ety: L. densus; akin to Gr. � thick with hair or leaves: cf. F. dense

sn.def: Having the constituent parts massed or crowded together; close; compact; thick; containing much matter in a small space; heavy; opaque; as, a dense crowd; a dense forest; a dense fog.
sn.q: All sorts of bodies, firm and fluid, dense and rare.
To replace the cloudy barrier dense.

sn.def: Stupid; gross; crass; as, dense ignorance.

entry.note: ☞ For gases the standard substance is hydrogen, at a temperature of 0° Centigrade and a pressure of 760 millimeters. For liquids and solids the standard is water at a temperature of 4° Centigrade. The density of solids and liquids is usually called specific gravity, and the same is true of gases when referred to air as a standard.

entry.note: ☞ We deny what another says, or we deny the truth of an assertion, the force of it, or the assertion itself.

To some men, it is more agreeable to deny a vicious inclination, than to gratify it.

sn.def: To disclaim connection with, responsibility for, and the like; to refuse to acknowledge; to disown; to abjure; to disavow.

Let him deny himself, and take up his cross.

entry.def: To answer in ��� negative; to declare an assertion not to be true.

entry.def: In the manner of one denies a request.
To remove obstructions or impediments in; to clear from anything that hinders the passage of fluids; as, to deobstruct the pores or lacteals.
Removing obstructions; having power to clear or open the natural ducts of the fluids and secretions of the body; aperient.

def2.def: A medicine which removes obstructions; an aperient.

entry.note: ☞ Deodands are unknown in American law, and in 1846 were abolished in England.
entry.ety: LL. deodandum, fr. L. Deo dandum to be given to God
entry.def: A personal chattel which had caused the death of a person, and for that reason was given to God, that is, forfeited to the crown, to be applied to pious uses, and distributed in alms by the high almoner. Thus, if a cart ran over a man and killed him, it was forfeited as a deodand.

entry.ety: Native name, fr. Skr. dēvadāru, prop., timber of the gods
entry.def: A kind of cedar (Cedrus Deodara), growing in India, highly valued for its size and beauty as well as for its timber, and also grown in England as an ornamental tree.

Pertaining to deontology.
One versed in deontology.

To deoxidize.
The act or process of reducing from the state of an oxide.
Deoxidation.

That which removes oxygen; hence, a reducing agent; as, nascent hydrogen is a deoxidizer .
To deoxidize.
The act or operation of depriving of oxygen.
To deoxidize.

entry.note: ☞ The monomer units making up the DNA each contain one of four heterocyclic bases: thymine, adenine, cytosine, or guanine. The genetic information is contained in the precise sequence of these monomer units, which ultimately specify the sequence of proteins to be made by the organism's biosynthetic processes, mediated through the synthesis of RNA having a base sequence corresponding to that of the DNA. The DNA sequence also specifies the sequence of the various RNA molecules the RNA base sequence being a copy of that on one of the DNA strands. Most of the RNA synthesized is involved in protein synthesis. In the double-helical form of DNA, the thymine on one strand is paired with the adenine on the opposite strand, and cytosine of one strand is paired with guanine on the opposite strand. There is in DNA also certain controlling information concerning the timing and amount of RNA to be made, encoded within the sequence of the DNA in ways that are still being elucidated. When this structure is replicated in the course of cell multiplication, two identical double-helical molecules are formed, each containing one strand from the original molecule. Each resulting molecule is distributred to either the parent or progeny organism, and this is the basic mechanism for transmission of hereditary information. In RNA-based viruses, or those having single strands of DNA (as certain viruses), the genetic information transmission occurs through a double-stranded intermediate by a similar mechanism. In some organisms slight modifications of the bases of DNA are found, such as methylcytosine or, in some viruses, uracil or hydroxymethyluracil; these unusual bases act analogously to the normal bases in their genetic coding function. A small percentage of methylcytosine is found in many organisms, and it serves in some cases as a special signal, as for restriction enzymes.
entry.def: a nucleic acid, usually of very high molecular weight, consisting of a linear sequence of monomer units of deoxyribonucleotides, occurring in most organisms in pairs of strands, wound together in the form of a double helix; it is the main component of chromosomes and contains the genetic information which is the basis of heredity, transmitted from parent to progeny, and found in all living organisms except for certain viruses which have RNA as their basic genetic material; -- usually referred to by the acronym DNA.

an organic molecule consisting of a hereocyclic base attached to the 1-carbon of a deoxyribose ring, with a phosphate group esterified at the 5 position of the deoxyribose. Deoxyribonuceotides are the monomer units which make up deoxyribonucleic acid, the molecule carrying the hereditary information in most organisms. The most common forms of deoxyribonuceotide are thymidine-5′-phosphateabbreviated TMP), deoxyadenosine-5′-phosphateabbreviated dAMP), deoxyguanosine-5′-phosphateabbreviated dGMP), and deoxycytidine-5′-phosphateabbreviated dCMP).

a pentose (C5H10O4) in which one of the hydroxyl groups of ribose has been replaced by a hydrogen. In deoxyribonucleic acids, the deoxyribose is D-2-deoxyribose, in which the hydroxyl at the 2 position of ribose is the one which is replaced by hydrogen.
same as deoxyribonucleic acid.

entry.ety: F. dépeint, p. p. of dépeindre to paint, fr. L. depingere. See Depict p. p.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Departed; p. pr. & vb. n. Departing
entry.ety: OE. departen to divide, part, depart, F. départir to divide, distribute, se départir to separate one's self, depart; pref. dé-L. de) + partir to part, depart, fr. L. partire partiri, to divide, fr. pars part. See Part

sn.def: To part; to divide; to separate.

He which hath no stomach to this fight, Let him depart.

sn.def: To forsake; to abandon; to desist or deviate (from); not to adhere to; -- with from; as, we can not depart from our rules; to depart from a title or defense in legal pleading.

sn.def: A going away; departure; hence, death.

entry.def: Divisible.
someone who is no longer alive; as, let us pray for the departed .
entry.syn: dead person, dead soul, deceased person, deceased, decedent.

dead; as, our dear departed parents.

sn.def: Act of departing; departure.

sn.def: A part, portion, or subdivision.

sn.def: Subdivision of business or official duty; especially, one of the principal divisions of executive government; as, the treasury department; the war department ; also, in a university, one of the divisions of instruction; as, the medical department; the department of physics.

A territorial division; a district; esp., in France, one of the districts composed of several arrondissements into which the country is divided for governmental purposes; as, the Department of the Loire.
A military subdivision of a country; as, the Department of the Potomac.

entry.def: Pertaining to a department or division.

entries.entry: De*part"ment store. A store keeping a great variety of goods which are arranged in several departments.

entry.note: ☞ Since the meridians sensibly converge, the departure in navigation is not measured from the beginning nor from the end of the ship's course, but is regarded as the total easting or westing made by the ship or person as he travels over the course.

cs.cd: to ascertain, usually by taking bearings from a landmark, the position of a vessel at the beginning of a voyage as a point from which to begin her dead reckoning; as, the ship took her departure from Sandy Hook.

entry.ety: From Depart

sn.def: Division; separation; putting away.
sn.q: No other remedy . . . but absolute departure.

sn.def: Separation or removal from a place; the act or process of departing or going away.
sn.q: Departure from this happy place.

sn.def: Removal from the present life; death; decease.

His timely departure . . . barred him from the knowledge of his son's miseries.

sn.def: Deviation or abandonment, as from or of a rule or course of action, a plan, or a purpose.

sn.def: The desertion by a party to any pleading of the ground taken by him in his last antecedent pleading, and the adoption of another.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Depended; p. pr. & vb. n. Depending
entry.ety: F. dépendre, fr. L. depend�re; de- + pend�re to hang. See Pendant

sn.def: To hang down; to be sustained by being fastened or attached to something above.

sn.def: To rely for support; to be conditioned or contingent; to be connected with anything, as a cause of existence, or as a necessary condition; -- followed by on or upon, formerly by of.
sn.q: The truth of God's word dependeth not of the truth of the congregation.

sn.def: To trust; to rest with confidence; to rely; to confide; to be certain; -- with on or upon; as, we depend on the word or assurance of our friends; we depend on the mail at the usual hour.
sn.q: But if you 're rough, and use him like a dog,Depend upon it -- he 'll remain incog.

sn.def: To serve; to attend; to act as a dependent or retainer.

entry.def: the trait of being dependable or reliable.
Worthy of being depended on; trustworthy.
entry.q: Dependablefriendships.

entry.note: ☞ The forms dependant dependance dependancy are from the French; the forms dependent, etc., are from the Latin. Some authorities give preference to the form dependant when the word is a noun, thus distinguishing it from the adjective, usually written dependent.
entry.def: See Dependent Dependence Dependency.

entry.ety: LL. dependentia, fr. L. dependens. See Dependent, and cf. Dependance

sn.def: The act or state of depending; state of being dependent; a hanging down or from; suspension from a support.
The state of being influenced and determined by something; subjection (as of an effect to its cause).
sn.q: The cause of effects, and the dependence of one thing upon another.

sn.def: Mutual connection and support; concatenation; systematic inter-relation.

sn.def: Subjection to the direction or disposal of another; inability to help or provide for one's self; a lack of independence or self-sufficiency.
sn.q: Reduced to a servile dependence on their mercy.

sn.def: A resting with confidence; reliance; trust.

sn.q: Like a large cluster of black grapes they show And make a large dependence from the bough.

sn.def: A matter depending, or in suspense, and still to be determined; ground of controversy or quarrel.

entries.entry:
De*pend"en*cy ☞ Dependence is more used in the abstract, and dependency in the concrete. The latter is usually restricted in meaning to 3 and 4. n.; pl.Dependencies.
State of being dependent; dependence; state of being subordinate; subordination; concatenation; connection; reliance; trust. Any long series of action, the parts of which have very much dependency each on the other.
So that they may acknowledge their dependency on the crown of England.
A thing hanging down; a dependence.
That which is attached to something else as its consequence, subordinate, satellite, and the like. This earth and its dependencies. Modes I call such complex ideas which . . . are considered as dependencies on or affections of substances.
A territory remote from the kingdom or state to which it belongs, but subject to its dominion; a colony; as, Great Britain has its dependencies in Asia, Africa, and America.

cs.cd: one not binding until some connecting stipulation is performed.
a varying quantity whose changes are arbitrary, but are regarded as produced by changes in another variable, which is called the independent variable.

entry.ety: L. dependens -entis, p. pr. dependere. See Depend, and cf. Dependant

sn.def: Hanging down; as, a dependent bough or leaf.

entry.sn: Relying on, or subject to, something else for support; not able to exist, or sustain itself, or to perform anything, without the will, power, or aid of something else; not self-sustaining; subordinate; -- often with on or upon; as, dependent on God; dependent upon friends. Opposite of independent.Narrower terms: interdependent, mutualist, mutually beneficial; parasitic, parasitical, leechlike, bloodsucking; subordinate; underage; myrmecophilous; symbiotic Also See: unfree. England, long dependent and degraded, was again a power of the first rank.

sn.def: conditional; contingent or conditioned. Opposite of unconditional.
addicted to drugs.

entry.note: ☞ See the Note under Dependant.

sn.def: One who depends; one who is sustained by another, or who relies on another for financial support or favor; a hanger-on; a retainer; as, a numerous train of dependents .

sn.def: That which depends; corollary; consequence.

One who depends; a dependent.
As having dependence.
To depopulate.

entry.ety: LL. deperditum, fr. L. deperditus, p. p. of deperdere; de- + perdere to lose, destroy

Hopelessly; despairingly; in the manner of one ruined; as, deperditely wicked.

entry.ety: Cf. F. déperdition

entry.ety: See Depart
entry.def: Divisible.
To put out of phase, as two parts of a single alternating current.

entry.ety: Pref. de- + phlegm water; cf. F. déphlegmer déflegmer
entry.def: To rid of phlegm or water; to dephlegmate.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Dephlegmated; p. pr. & vb. n. Dephlegmating
entry.ety: See Dephlegm
entry.def: To deprive of superabundant water, as by evaporation or distillation; to clear of aqueous matter; to rectify; -- used of spirits and acids.

entry.ety: Cf. F. déflegmation
entry.def: The operation of separating water from spirits and acids, by evaporation or repeated distillation; -- called also concentration, especially when acids are the subject of it.
An instrument or apparatus in which water is separated by evaporation or distillation; the part of a distilling apparatus in which the separation of the vapors is effected.
Pertaining to, or producing, dephlegmation.
A state of being freed from water.

cs.cd: oxygen gas; -- so called by Dr. Priestly and others of his time.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Dephlogisticated; p. pr. & vb. n. Dephlogisticating

entry.ety: L. depictus, p. p. of depingere to depict; de- + pingere to paint. See Paint, and cf. Depaint p. p.
entry.def: Depicted.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Depicted; p. pr. & vb. n. Depicting

sn.def: To form a colored likeness of; to represent by a picture; to paint; to portray.
sn.q: His arms are fairly depicted in his chamber.

entry.def: represented graphically by sketch or design or lines.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Depictured; p. pr. & vb. n. Depicturing
entry.def: To make a picture of; to paint; to picture; to depict.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Depilated; p. pr. & vb. n. Depilating
