entry.def: Act of pulling out or removing the hair; unhairing.

entry.ety: Cf. F. dépilatoire

def2.def: An application used to take off hair.

entry.ety: Pref. de- + pilous: cf. L. depilis
entry.def: Hairless.

entry.ety: L. deplanetus, p. p. of deplanare to make level. See Plane v. t.
entry.def: Flattened; made level or even.

entry.ety: Cf. F. déplantation

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Depleted; p. pr. & vb. n. Depleting
entry.ety: From L. deplere to empty out; de- + plere to fill. Forined like replete complete. See Fill Full a.

sn.def: To empty or unload, as the vessels of human system, by bloodletting or by medicine.
To reduce by destroying or consuming the vital powers of; to exhaust, as a country of its strength or resources, a treasury of money, etc.
no longer sufficient; as, our funds are depleted .
having resources completely depleted.

entry.ety: Cf. F. déplétion

the act or process of diminishing the quantity of fluid in the vessels by bloodletting or otherwise; also excessive evacuation, as in severe diarrhea.

entry.ety: Cf. F. déplétif
entry.def: Able or fitted to deplete.

entry.ety: Cf. F. déplorable

entry.ety: L. deploratus, p. p. of deplorare. See Deplore

entry.ety: L. deploratio: cf. F. déploration

entry.usage: Mourn is the generic term, denoting a state of grief or sadness. To lament is to express grief by outcries, and denotes an earnest and strong expression of sorrow. To deplore marks a deeper and more prolonged emotion. To bewail and to bemoan are appropriate only to cases of poignant distress, in which the grief finds utterance either in wailing or in moans and sobs. A man laments his errors, and deplores the ruin they have brought on his family; mothers bewail or bemoan the loss of their children.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Deplored; p. pr. & vb. n. Deploring
entry.ety: L. deplorare; de- + plorare to cry out, wail, lament; prob. akin to pluere to rain, and to E. flow: cf. F. déplorer. Cf. Flow

sn.def: To feel or to express deep and poignant grief for; to bewail; to lament; to mourn; to sorrow over.
sn.q: To find her, or forever to deplore Her loss.
As some sad turtle his lost love deplores.

sn.def: To complain of.
To regard as hopeless; to give up.
sn.syn: To Deplore Mourn Lament Bewail Bemoan.

entry.def: To lament.
Lamentably.
The state of being deplored or deplorable.
Deploration.
One who deplores.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Deployed; p. pr. & vb. n. Deploying

entry.def: To open out; to unfold; to spread out (a body of troops) in such a way that they shall display a wider front and less depth; -- the reverse of ploy; as, to deploy a column of troops into line of battle.
To place (people or other resources) into a position so as to be ready to for action or use.
The act of deploying; a spreading out of a body of men in order to extend their front.

entry.def: the arrangement or distribution (of resources such as people or equipment), in preparation for battle or work.

entry.ety: LL. diplumatus, p. p. of deplumare. See Deplume

cs.cd: a change in the plane of polarization of rays, especially by a crystalline medium, such that the light which had been extinguished by the analyzer reappears as if the polarization had been anulled. The word is inappropriate, as the ray does not return to the unpolarized condition.

entry.ety: Cf. F. dépolarisation
entry.def: The act of depriving of polarity, or the result of such action; reduction to an unpolarized condition.

entry.note: ☞ This word has been inaccurately applied in optics to describe the effect of a polarizing medium, as a crystalline plate, in causing the reappearance of a ray, in consequence of a change in its plane of polarization, which previously to the change was intercepted by the analyzer.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Depolarized; p. pr. & vb. n. Depolarizing
entry.ety: Pref. de- + polarize: cf. F. dépolarizer

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Deponed -pōnd"; p. pr. & vb. n. Deponing

entry.usage: These are legal terms describing a person who makes a written declaration under oath, with a view to establish certain facts. An affiant is one who makes an affidavit, or declaration under oath, in order to establish the truth of what he says. A deponenet is one who makes a deposition, or gives written testimony under oath, to be used in the trial of some case before a court of justice. See under Deposition.

sn.def: One who deposes or testifies under oath; one who gives evidence; usually, one who testifies in writing.

entry.ety: L. deponens -entis, laying down (its proper passive meaning), p. pr. of deponere: cf. F. déponent. See Depone

entry.note: ☞ It is not synonymous with laying waste or destroying, being limited to the loss of inhabitants; as, an army or a famine may depopulate a country. It rarely expresses an entire loss of inhabitants, but often a great diminution of their numbers; as, the deluge depopulated the earth.

sn.def: To lay up or away for safe keeping; to put up; to store; as, to deposit goods in a warehouse.

entry.cs:
Bank of deposit. See under Bank.
In deposit, or On deposit
in trust or safe keeping as a deposit; as, coins were received on deposit .
entry.ety: L. depositum, fr. depositus, p. p. of deponere: cf. F. dépôt, OF. depost. See Deposit v. t., and cf. Depot

sn.def: That which is deposited, or laid or thrown down; as, a deposit in a flue; especially, matter precipitated from a solution (as the siliceous deposits of hot springs), or that which is mechanically deposited (as the mud, gravel, etc., deposits of a river).

That which is placed anywhere, or in any one's hands, for safe keeping; something intrusted to the care of another; esp., money lodged with a bank or banker, subject to order; anything given as pledge or security.

sd.def: A bailment of money or goods to be kept gratuitously for the bailor.
Money lodged with a party as earnest or security for the performance of a duty assumed by the person depositing.

entries.entry:
De*pos"i*ta*ry n.; pl.Depositaries #. L. depositarius, fr. deponere. See Deposit
One with whom anything is lodged in the trust; one who receives a deposit; -- the correlative of depositor. I . . . made you my guardians, my depositaries. The depositaries of power, who are mere delegates of the people.
A storehouse; a depository.
Law One to whom goods are bailed, to be kept for the bailor without a recompense.

entry.note: ☞ A deposition differs from an abdication, an abdication being voluntary, and a deposition compulsory.
entry.usage: Affidavit is the wider term. It denotes any authorized ex parte written statement of a person, sworn to or affirmed before some competent magistrate. It is made without cross-examination, and requires no notice to an opposing party. It is generally signed by the party making it, and may be drawn up by himself or any other person. A deposition is the written testimony of a witness, taken down in due form of law, and sworn to or affirmed by the deponent. It must be taken before some authorized magistrate, and upon a prescribed or reasonable notice to the opposing party, that may attend and cross-examine. It is generally written down from the mouth of the witness by the magistrate, or some person for him, and in his presence.
entry.ety: L. depositio, fr. deponere: cf. F. déposition. See Deposit

sn.def: The act of depositing or deposing; the act of laying down or thrown down; precipitation.
sn.q: The deposition of rough sand and rolled pebbles.

sn.def: The act of bringing before the mind; presentation.
sn.q: The influence of princes upon the dispositions of their courts needs not the deposition of their examples, since it hath the authority of a known principle.

sn.def: The act of setting aside a sovereign or a public officer; deprivation of authority and dignity; displacement; removal.
That which is deposited; matter laid or thrown down; sediment; alluvial matter; as, banks are sometimes depositions of alluvial matter.
An opinion, example, or statement, laid down or asserted; a declaration.

The act of laying down one's testimony in writing; also, testimony laid or taken down in writing, under oath or affirmation, before some competent officer, and in reply to interrogatories and cross-interrogatories.

entry.ety: L., fr. deponere. See Depone
entry.def: One who makes a deposit, especially of money in a bank; -- the correlative of depository.

entries.entry:
De*pos"i*to*ry -t�*r� n.; pl.Depositories -rĭz.
A place where anything is deposited for sale or keeping; as, warehouse is a depository for goods; a clerk's office is a depository for records.
One with whom something is deposited; a depositary. I am the sole depository of my own secret, and it shall perish with me.

entry.ety: L
entry.def: Deposit.
The act of depositing; deposition.

entry.ety: F. dépôt, OF. depost, fr. L. depositum a deposit. See Deposit n.

sn.def: A place of deposit for the storing of goods; a warehouse; a storehouse.
sn.q: The islands of Guernsey and Jersey are at present the great depots of this kingdom.

sd.def: A military station where stores and provisions are kept, or where recruits are assembled and drilled.

The headquarters of a regiment, where all supplies are received and distributed, recruits are assembled and instructed, infirm or disabled soldiers are taken care of, and all the wants of the regiment are provided for.

sn.def: A railway station; a building for the accommodation and protection of railway passengers or freight.

entry.def: Deeper.

entry.ety: L. depravitio, from depravare: cf. F. dépravation. See Deprave

sn.def: Detraction; depreciation.
sn.q: To stubborn critics, apt, without a theme, For depravation.

sn.def: The act of depraving, or making anything bad; the act of corrupting.
The state of being depraved or degenerated; degeneracy; depravity.
sn.q: The depravation of his moral character destroyed his judgment.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Depraved d�*prāvd"; p. pr. & vb. n. Depraving
entry.ety: L. depravare depravatum; de- + pravus crooked, distorted, perverse, wicked

sn.def: To speak ill of; to depreciate; to malign; to revile.
sn.q: And thou knowest, conscience, I came not to chide Nor deprave thy person with a proud heart.

sn.def: To make bad or worse; to vitiate; to corrupt.
sn.q: Whose pride depraves each other better part.

entry.def: In a depraved manner.
Depravity.
Depravity.
One who depraves or corrupts.
In a depraving manner.

entry.cs: Total depravity. See Original sin, and Calvinism.
entry.usage: Depravity Depravation Corruption. Depravilty is a vitiated state of mind or feeling; as, the depravity of the human heart; depravity of public morals. Depravation points to the act or process of making depraved, and hence to the end thus reached; as, a gradual depravation of principle; a depravation of manners, of the heart, etc. Corruption is the only one of these words which applies to physical substances, and in reference to these denotes the process by which their component parts are dissolved. Hence, when figuratively used, it denotes an utter vitiation of principle or feeling. Depravity applies only to the mind and heart: we can speak of a depraved taste, or a corrupt taste; in the first we introduce the notion that there has been the influence of bad training to pervert; in the second, that there is a want of true principle to pervert; in the second, that there is a want of true principles to decide. The other two words have a wider use: we can speak of the depravation or the corruption of taste and public sentiment. Depravity is more or less open; corruption is more or less disguised in its operations. What is depraved requires to be reformed; what is corrupt requires to be purified.
entry.ety: From Deprave: cf. L. pravitas crookedness, perverseness
entry.def: The state of being depraved or corrupted; a vitiated state of moral character; general badness of character; wickedness of mind or heart; absence of religious feeling and principle.
entry.syn: Corruption; vitiation; wickedness; vice; contamination; degeneracy.

entry.ety: L. deprecabilis exorable

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Deprecated -kā`tĕd; p. pr. & vb. n. Deprecating -kā`tĭng

entry.def: To pray against, as an evil; to seek to avert by prayer; to seek deliverance from; to express deep regret for; to desire the removal of.

entry.def: In a deprecating manner.

An imprecation or curse.
A strong expression of disapprobation; an expression of a low opinion.

entry.syn: belittling, derogatory, pejorative, disparaging, depreciative, deprecatory, depreciatory, detractive, detracting, slighting, denigratory, uncomplimentary.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Depreciated d�*prē"shĭ*ā`tĕd; p. pr. & vb. n. Depreciating d�*prē"shĭ*ā`tĭng
entry.ety: L. depretiatus depreciatus, p. p. of depretiare -ciare, to depreciate; de- + pretiare to prize, fr. pretium price. See Price
entry.def: To lessen in price or estimated value; to lower the worth of; to represent as of little value or claim to esteem; to undervalue.
entry.q: Which . . . some over-severe philosophers may look upon fastidiously, or undervalue and depreciate.
To prove that the Americans ought not to be free, we are obliged to depreciate the value of freedom itself.
entry.syn: To decry; disparage; traduce; lower; detract; underrate. See Decry.

entry.def: To fall in value; to become of less worth; to sink in estimation; as, a paper currency will depreciate, unless it is convertible into specie.

entry.ety: Cf. F. dépréciation

sn.def: The act of lessening, or seeking to lessen, price, value, or reputation.

the state of being depreciated.

entry.def: Tending, or intended, to depreciate; expressing depreciation; undervaluing.

entry.ety: L
entry.def: One who depreciates.
Tending to depreciate; undervaluing; depreciative.
entry.syn: belittling, depreciative, deprecatory, depreciatory, derogatory, detractive, detracting, slighting, pejorative, denigratory.

entry.ety: Pref. de-intensive) + predicate
entry.def: To proclaim; to celebrate.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Deprehended; p. pr. & vb. n. Deprehending
entry.ety: L. deprehendere deprehensum; de- + prehendere to lay hold of, seize. See Prehensile

sn.def: To take unawares or by surprise; to seize, as a person commiting an unlawful act; to catch; to apprehend.

cs.cd: to cause the sidereal pole to appear lower or nearer the horizon, as by sailing toward the equator.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Depressed; p. pr. & vb. n. Depressing
entry.ety: L. depressus, p. p. of deprimere; de- + premere to press. See Press

sn.def: To press down; to cause to sink; to let fall; to lower; as, to depress the muzzle of a gun; to depress the eyes.
sn.q: With lipsdepressed.

sn.def: To bring down or humble; to abase, as pride.
To cast a gloom upon; to sadden; as, his spirits were depressed .
To lessen the activity of; to make dull; embarrass, as trade, commerce, etc.
To lessen in price; to cause to decline in value; to cheapen; to depreciate.
To reduce (an equation) in a lower degree.
sn.syn: To sink; lower; abase; cast down; deject; humble; degrade; dispirit; discourage.

entry.ety: L. depressus, p. p
entry.def: Having the middle lower than the border; concave.
entry.q: If the seal be depress or hollow.

entry.def: An agent or remedy which lowers the vital powers.

sn.def: Pressed or forced down; lowed; sunk; dejected; dispirited; sad; humbled.

sd.def: Concave on the upper side; -- said of a leaf whose disk is lower than the border.
Lying flat; -- said of a stem or leaf which lies close to the ground.

sn.def: Having the vertical diameter shorter than the horizontal or transverse; -- said of the bodies of animals, or of parts of the bodies.

entry.def: In a depressing manner.

entry.cs: Angle of depression Geod one which a descending line makes with a horizontal plane. Depression of the dewpoint Meteor the number of degrees that the dew-point is lower than the actual temperature of the atmosphere. Depression of the pole its apparent sinking, as the spectator goes toward the equator. Depression of the visible horizon. Astron Same as Dip of the horizon, under Dip.
entry.ety: L. depressio: cf. F. dépression

sn.def: The act of depressing.
The state of being depressed; a sinking.
A falling in of the surface; a sinking below its true place; a cavity or hollow; as, roughness consists in little protuberances and depressions .
Humiliation; abasement, as of pride.
Dejection; despondency; lowness.
sn.q: In a great depression of spirit.

sn.def: Diminution, as of trade, etc.; inactivity; dullness.
The angular distance of a celestial object below the horizon.
The operation of reducing to a lower degree; -- said of equations.
A method of operating for cataract; couching. See Couch v. t., 8.
sn.syn: Abasement; reduction; sinking; fall; humiliation; dejection; melancholy.

entry.def: Able or tending to depress or cast down.
Depressing or diminishing the capacity for movement, as depressomotor nerves, which lower or inhibit muscular activity.

def2.def: Any agent that depresses the activity of the motor centers, as bromides, etc.

cs.cd: a nerve which lowers the activity of an organ; as, the depressor nerve of the heart.

sn.def: One who, or that which, presses down; an oppressor.
A muscle that depresses or tends to draw down a part.

entry.ety: L. deprimens, p. pr. of deprimere. See Depress
entry.def: Serving to depress.
entry.q: Deprimentmuscles.

entry.ety: F. dépriser to undervalue; pref. dé-L. dis-) + priser to prize, fr. prix price, fr. L. pretium. See Dispraise
entry.def: Low estimation; disesteem; contempt.
Capable of being, or liable to be, deprived; liable to be deposed.
entry.q: Kings of Spain . . . deprivable for their tyrannies.

entry.note: ☞ Deprivation may be a beneficio or ab officio; the first takes away the living, the last degrades and deposes from the order.
entry.ety: LL. deprivatio

sn.def: The act of depriving, dispossessing, or bereaving; the act of deposing or divesting of some dignity.
The state of being deprived; privation; loss; want; bereavement.
the taking away from a clergyman his benefice, or other spiritual promotion or dignity.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Deprived; p. pr. & vb. n. Depriving
entry.ety: LL. deprivare deprivatium, to divest of office; L. de- + privare to bereave, deprive: cf. OF. depriver. See Private

sn.def: To take away; to put an end; to destroy.
sn.q: 'Tis honor to deprive dishonored life.

sn.def: To dispossess; to bereave; to divest; to hinder from possessing; to debar; to shut out from; -- with a remoter object, usually preceded by of.
sn.q: God hath deprived her of wisdom.
It was seldom that anger deprived him of power over himself.

sn.def: To divest of office; to depose; to dispossess of dignity, especially ecclesiastical.
sn.q: A minister deprived for inconformity.

entry.def: marked by deprivation especially of the necessities of life or healthful environmental or social influences; as, a childhood that was unhappy and deprived, the family living off charity; boys from a deprived environment, wherein the family life revealed a pattern of neglect, moral degradation, and disregard for law.
Deprivation.
One who, or that which, deprives.
Fully prostrate; humble; low; rude.
entry.q: How may weak mortal ever hope to file His unsmooth tongue, and his deprostrate style.

entry.def: To divest of provincial quality or characteristics.

cs.cd: the extent of a square sail from the head rope to the foot rope; the length of the after leach of a staysail or boom sail; -- commonly called the drop of a sail.

entry.ety: From Deep; akin to D. diepte, Icel. dȳpt dȳpð, Goth. diupiþa

sn.def: The quality of being deep; deepness; perpendicular measurement downward from the surface, or horizontal measurement backward from the front; as, the depth of a river; the depth of a body of troops.
Profoundness; extent or degree of intensity; abundance; completeness; as, depth of knowledge, or color.
sn.q: Mindful of that heavenly love Which knows no end in depth or height.

sn.def: Lowness; as, depth of sound.
That which is deep; a deep, or the deepest, part or place; the deep; the middle part; as, the depth of night, or of winter.
sn.q: From you unclouded depth above.
The depth closed me round about.

sn.def: The number of simple elements which an abstract conception or notion includes; the comprehension or content.
A pair of toothed wheels which work together.
The perpendicular distance from the chord to the farthest point of an arched surface.
the maximum number of times a type of procedure is reiteratively called before the last call is exited; -- of subroutines or procedures which are reentrant; -- used of call stacks.

entry.def: To deepen.

sn.def: Having no depth; shallow.
Of measureless depth; unfathomable.
sn.q: In clouds of depthless night.

entry.ety: L. de + LL. pucella virgin, F. pucelle: cf. F. dépuceler
entry.def: To deflour; to deprive of virginity.

entry.ety: L. depudicatus, p. p. of depudicare
entry.def: To deflour; to dishonor.

entry.ety: L. depulsus, p. p. of depellere to drive out; de- + pellere to drive
entry.def: To drive away.

entry.ety: L. depulsio
entry.def: A driving or thrusting away.

entry.ety: L. depulsorius
entry.def: Driving or thrusting away; averting.
Depurative.

entry.ety: LL. depuratus, p. p. of depurare to purify; L. de- + purare to purify, purus clean, pure. Cf. Depure
entry.def: Depurated; cleansed; freed from impurities.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Depurated; p. pr. & vb. n. Depurating
entry.def: To free from impurities, heterogeneous matter, or feculence; to purify; to cleanse.
entry.q: To depurate the mass of blood.

entry.ety: Cf. F. dépuration
entry.def: The act or process of depurating or freeing from foreign or impure matter, as a liquid or wound.

entry.ety: Cf. F. dépuratif
entry.def: Purifying the blood or the humors; depuratory.

def2.def: A depurative remedy or agent; or a disease which is believed to be depurative.

entry.def: One who, or that which, cleanses.

entry.ety: Cf. F. dépuratoire
entry.def: Depurating; tending to depurate or cleanse; depurative.

entry.ety: F. dépurer. See Depurate
entry.def: To depurate; to purify.
entry.q: He shall first be depured and cleansed before that he shall be laid up for pure gold in the treasures of God.

entry.def: Serving to purge; tending to cleanse or purify.
See Depuration.
Fit to be deputed; suitable to act as a deputy.

cs.cd: by delegated authority; as substitute; through the medium of a deputy.

entry.ety: Cf. F. députation. See Depute

sn.def: The act of deputing, or of appointing or commissioning a deputy or representative; office of a deputy or delegate; vicegerency.
sn.q: The authority of conscience stands founded upon its vicegerency and deputation under God.

sn.def: The person or persons deputed or commissioned by another person, party, or public body to act in his or its behalf; delegation; as, the general sent a deputation to the enemy to propose a truce.
sn.q: Say to great Cæsar this: In deputation I kiss his conquering hand.

entry.def: One who deputes, or makes a deputation.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Deputed; p. pr. & vb. n. Deputing
entry.ety: F. députer, fr. L. deputare to esteem, consider, in LL., to destine, allot; de- + putare to clean, prune, clear up, set in order, reckon, think. See Pure

sn.def: To appoint as deputy or agent; to commission to act in one's place; to delegate.
sn.q: There is no man deputed of the king to hear thee.
Some persons, deputed by a meeting.

sn.def: To appoint; to assign; to choose.
sn.q: The most conspicuous places in cities are usually deputed for the erection of statues.

entry.def: A person deputed; a deputy.
same as deputize.
To appoint as one's deputy; to empower to act in one's stead; to appoint as one's substitute; to depute.

entries.entry:
dep"u*ty ☞ Deputy is used in combination with the names of various executive officers, to denote an assistant empowered to act in their name; as, deputy collector, deputy marshal, deputy sheriff.
Chamber of Deputies one of the two branches of the French legislative assembly; -- formerly called Corps Législatif. Its members, called deputies, are elected by the people voting in districts.
dĕp"�*t� n.; pl.Deputies dĕp"�*tĭz. F. député, fr. LL. deputatus. See Depute
One appointed as the substitute of another, and empowered to act for him, in his name or his behalf; a substitute in office; a lieutenant; a representative; a delegate; a vicegerent; as, the deputy of a prince, of a sheriff, of a township, etc.
There was then [in the days of Jehoshaphat] no king in Edom; a deputy was king. God's substitute, His deputy anointed in His sight.
A member of the Chamber of Deputies. France Substitute; representative; legate; delegate; envoy; agent; factor.

entry.ety: L. de- + quantitas -atis. See Quantity
entry.def: To diminish the quantity of; to disquantity.
To remove the queen from (a hive of bees).

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Deracinated d�*răs"ĭ*nā`tĕd; p. pr. & vb. n. Deracinating d�*răs"ĭ*nā`tĭng
entry.ety: F. déraciner; pref. dé-L. dis) + racine root, fr. an assumed LL. radicina, fr. L. radix radicis, root
entry.def: To pluck up by the roots; to extirpate.
entry.q: While that the colter rusts That should deracinate such savagery.

entry.def: The act of pulling up by the roots; eradication.

entry.ety: See Darraign
entry.def: To prove or to refute by proof; to clear (one's self).

entry.ety: See Darraign

sn.def: The act of deraigning.
The renunciation of religious or monastic vows.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Derailed; p. pr. & vb. n. Derailing
entry.def: To cause to run off from the rails of a railroad, as a locomotive.
The act of going off, or the state of being off, the rails of a railroad.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Deranged; p. pr. & vb. n. Deranging
entry.ety: F. déranger; pref. dé- = dés-L. dis) + ranger to range. See Range, and cf. Disarrange Disrank

sn.def: To put out of place, order, or rank; to disturb the proper arrangement or order of; to throw into disorder, confusion, or embarrassment; to disorder; to disarrange; as, to derange the plans of a commander, or the affairs of a nation.
To disturb in action or function, as a part or organ, or the whole of a machine or organism.
sn.q: A sudden fall deranges some of our internal parts.

sn.def: To disturb in the orderly or normal action of the intellect; to render insane.
sn.syn: To disorder; disarrange; displace; unsettle; disturb; confuse; discompose; ruffle; disconcert.

entry.def: Disordered; especially, disordered in mind; crazy; insane.
entry.q: The story of a poor deranged parish lad.

entry.ety: Cf. F. dérangement
entry.def: The act of deranging or putting out of order, or the state of being deranged; disarrangement; disorder; confusion; especially, mental disorder; insanity.
entry.syn: Disorder; confusion; embarrassment; irregularity; disturbance; insanity; lunacy; madness; delirium; mania. See Insanity.

entry.def: One who deranges.

entry.ety: OF. derroi desroi desrei; pref. des-L. dis-) + roi rei rai, order. See Array
entry.def: Disorder; merriment.
A large European food fish (Lichia glauca).

cs.cd: the day of the annual race for the Derby stakes, -- Wednesday of the week before Whitsuntide.

sn.def: A race for three-old horses, run annually at Epsom (near London), for the Derby stakes. It was instituted by the 12th Earl of Derby, in 1780.
A stiff felt hat with a dome-shaped crown.

entries.entry: Der"by*shire spar". Min A massive variety of fluor spar, found in Derbyshire, England, and wrought into vases and other ornamental work.

entry.ety: See Dere v. t.
entry.def: Doing daring or chivalrous deeds.
entry.q: Inderdoingarms.

entry.ety: AS. derian to hurt
entry.def: To hurt; to harm; to injure.
Harm.

entry.ety: Sp. derecho straight
entry.def: A straight wind without apparent cyclonic tendency, usually accompanied with rain and often destructive, common in the prairie regions of the United States.
Same as Darraign.

entry.ety: L. derelictus, p. p. of derelinquere to forsake wholly, to abandon; de- + relinquere to leave. See Relinquish

sn.def: Given up or forsaken by the natural owner or guardian; left and abandoned; as, derelict lands.
sn.q: The affections which these exposed or derelict children bear to their mothers, have no grounds of nature or assiduity but civility and opinion.

sn.def: Lost; adrift; hence, wanting; careless; neglectful; unfaithful.
sn.q: They easily prevailed, so as to seize upon the vacant, unoccupied, and derelict minds of his [Chatham's] friends; and instantly they turned the vessel wholly out of the course of his policy.
A government which is either unable or unwilling to redress such wrongs is derelict to its highest duties.

entry.def: A thing voluntary abandoned or willfully cast away by its proper owner, especially a ship abandoned at sea.
A tract of land left dry by the sea, and fit for cultivation or use.

entry.ety: L. derelictio

sn.def: The act of leaving with an intention not to reclaim or resume; an utter forsaking abandonment.
sn.q: Cession or dereliction, actual or tacit, of other powers.

sn.def: A neglect or omission as if by willful abandonment.
sn.q: A total dereliction of military duties.

sn.def: The state of being left or abandoned.
A retiring of the sea, occasioning a change of high-water mark, whereby land is gained.

entry.def: To make irreligious; to turn from religion.
entry.q: He would dereligionize men beyond all others.

entry.def: Darling.
Darling.

entry.note: In the process of pharmaceutical screening (testing a large number of substances to find those having desirable pharmacological activity), the testing of samples of substances extracted from living organisms (plants, microorganisms, etc.) often detects substances already detected in prior screening. Such “known” or “replicate” activities must be recognized at an early stage to avoid duplicating previous efforts at purification and structural identification. The process of testing an sample which is active in a primary screen, to determine if the activity is due to a previously known substance, is called dereplication or counterscreening.
entry.def: the process of testing samples of mixtures which are active in a screening process, so as to recognize and eliminate from consideration those active substances already studied; -- a stage subsequent to the preliminary screening in the process of discovery of new pharmacologically active substances in mixtures of natural products; -- also called counterscreening. See screening.

entry.ety: Icel. djafr
entry.def: Strong; powerful; fierce.

entry.usage: To Deride Ridicule Mock Taunt. A man may ridicule without any unkindness of feeling; his object may be to correct; as, to ridicule the follies of the age. He who derides is actuated by a severe a contemptuous spirit; as, to deride one for his religious principles. To mock is stronger, and denotes open and scornful derision; as, to mock at sin. To taunt is to reproach with the keenest insult; as, to taunt one for his misfortunes. Ridicule consists more in words than in actions; derision and mockery evince themselves in actions as well as words; taunts are always expressed in words of extreme bitterness.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Derided; p. pr. & vb. n. Deriding
entry.ety: L. deridere derisum; de- + rid�re to laugh. See Ridicule
entry.def: To laugh at with contempt; to laugh to scorn; to turn to ridicule or make sport of; to mock; to scoff at.
entry.q: And the Pharisees, also, . . . derided him.
Sport that wrinkled Care derides. And Laughter holding both his sides.
entry.syn: To mock; laugh at; ridicule; insult; taunt; jeer; banter; rally.

entry.def: One who derides, or laughs at, another in contempt; a mocker; a scoffer.
By way of derision or mockery.

entries.entry:
De ri`gueur" De ri`gueur". F. See 2d Rigor
According to strictness (of etiquette, rule, or the like); obligatory; strictly required.

entry.ety: L. derisio: cf. F. dérision. See Deride

sn.def: The act of deriding, or the state of being derided; mockery; scornful or contemptuous treatment which holds one up to ridicule.
sn.q: He that sitteth in the heavens shall laugh; the Lord shall have them in derision.
Satan beheld their plight, And to his mates thus in derision called.

sn.def: An object of derision or scorn; a laughing-stock.
sn.q: I was a derision to all my people.

entry.def: Expressing, serving for, or characterized by, derision.
entry.q: Derisivetaunts.

entry.ety: L. derisorius: cf. F. dérisoire
entry.def: Derisive; mocking.

entry.ety: From Derive
entry.def: That can be derived; obtainable by transmission; capable of being known by inference, as from premises or data; capable of being traced, as from a radical; as, income is derivable from various sources.
entry.q: All honor derivable upon me.
The exquisite pleasure derivable from the true and beautiful relations of domestic life.
The argument derivable from the doxologies.

entry.def: By derivation.
Derivation.
entry.q: The derival of e from a.

entry.ety: L. derivatus, p. p. of derivare. See Derive
entry.def: Derived; derivative.
To derive.

entry.ety: L. derivatio: cf. F. dérivation. See Derive

sn.def: A leading or drawing off of water from a stream or source.
The act of receiving anything from a source; the act of procuring an effect from a cause, means, or condition, as profits from capital, conclusions or opinions from evidence.
sn.q: As touching traditional communication, . . . I do not doubt but many of those truths have had the help of that derivation.

sn.def: The act of tracing origin or descent, as in grammar or genealogy; as, the derivation of a word from an Aryan root.
The state or method of being derived; the relation of origin when established or asserted.
That from which a thing is derived.
That which is derived; a derivative; a deduction.
sn.q: From the Euphrates into an artificial derivation of that river.

sn.def: The operation of deducing one function from another according to some fixed law, called the law of derivation, as the operation of differentiation or of integration.
A drawing of humors or fluids from one part of the body to another, to relieve or lessen a morbid process.
The formation of a word from its more original or radical elements; also, a statement of the origin and history of a word.

entry.def: Relating to derivation.

cs.cd: a modification of the circulation found in some parts of the body, in which the arteries empty directly into the veins without the interposition of capillaries.

entry.ety: L. derivativus: cf. F. dérivatif
entry.def: Obtained by derivation; derived; not radical, original, or fundamental; originating, deduced, or formed from something else; secondary; as, a derivative conveyance; a derivative word.

sn.def: Hence, unoriginal (said of art or other intellectual products.

entry.note: ☞ Except in the mode of derivation the derivative is the same as the differential coefficient. See Differential coefficient, under Differential.

sn.def: That which is derived; anything obtained or deduced from another.
A word formed from another word, by a prefix or suffix, an internal modification, or some other change; a word which takes its origin from a root.
A chord, not fundamental, but obtained from another by inversion; or, vice versa, a ground tone or root implied in its harmonics in an actual chord.
An agent which is adapted to produce a derivation (in the medical sense).
A derived function; a function obtained from a given function by a certain algebraic process.

A substance so related to another substance by modification or partial substitution as to be regarded as derived from it; thus, the amido compounds are derivatives of ammonia, and the hydrocarbons are derivatives of methane, benzene, etc.

entry.def: to alter the chemical composition [of a compound] by a chemical reaction which changes some part of the molecule, leaving most of the molecule unchanged; to prepare a derivative{6} from.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Derived; p. pr. & vb. n. Deriving
entry.ety: F. dériver, L. derivare; de- + rivus stream, brook. See Rival

sn.def: To turn the course of, as water; to divert and distribute into subordinate channels; to diffuse; to communicate; to transmit; -- followed by to into on upon.
sn.q: For fear it [water] choke up the pits . . . they [the workmanderive it by other drains.
Her due loves derived to that vile witch's share.
Derived to us by tradition from Adam to Noah.

sn.def: To receive, as from a source or origin; to obtain by descent or by transmission; to draw; to deduce; -- followed by from.
To trace the origin, descent, or derivation of; to recognize transmission of; as, he derives this word from the Anglo-Saxon.
sn.q: From these two causes . . . an ancient set of physicians derived all diseases.

sn.def: To obtain one substance from another by actual or theoretical substitution; as, to derive an organic acid from its corresponding hydrocarbon.

entry.def: To flow; to have origin; to descend; to proceed; to be deduced.
entry.q: Power from heavenDerives, and monarchs rule by gods appointed.

entry.def: That which is derived; deduction; inference.
entry.q: I offer these derivements from these subjects.

entry.def: One who derives.
Dark.

-derm. See Derm n.

a genus comprising vectors of important diseases of man and animals.

sn.def: To annul in part; to repeal partly; to restrict; to limit the action of; -- said of a law.

entry.ety: L. derogatus, p. p

entry.ety: L. derogatio: cf. F. dérogation

sn.def: The act of derogating, partly repealing, or lessening in value; disparagement; detraction; depreciation; -- followed by of from, or to.
sn.q: I hope it is no derogation to the Christian religion.
He counted it no derogation of his manhood to be seen to weep.

sn.def: An alteration of, or subtraction from, a contract for a sale of stocks.

entry.def: Derogatory.
entry.syn: belittling, depreciative, deprecatory, depreciatory, derogatory, detractive, detracting, slighting, pejorative, denigratory.

entry.ety: L
entry.def: A detractor.
In a derogatory manner; disparagingly.
Quality of being derogatory.

cs.cd: a sentence of secret character inserted by the testator alone, of which he reserves the knowledge to himself, with a condition that no will he may make thereafter shall be valid, unless this clause is inserted word for word; -- a precaution to guard against later wills extorted by violence, or obtained by suggestion.

entry.def: Tending to derogate, or lessen in value; expressing a low opinion; expressing derogation; detracting; injurious; -- with from to, or unto.
entry.syn: belittling, depreciative, deprecatory, depreciatory, derogatory, detractive, detracting, slighting, pejorative, denigratory.
entry.q: Acts of Parliament derogatory from the power of subsequent Parliaments bind not.
His language was severely censured by some of his brother peers as derogatory to their other.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. de`ros skin + �, �, hole
entry.def: The tribe of aquatic Amphibia which includes Amphiuma, Menopoma, etc. They have permanent gill openings, but no external gills; -- called also Cryptobranchiata.
Dearer.

cs.cd: a combination of the derrick and the crane, having facility for hoisting and also for swinging the load horizontally.

entry.ety: Orig., a gallows, from a hangman named Derrick. The name is of Dutch origin; D. Diederik Dierryk, prop. meaning, chief of the people; cf. AS. peódric, E. Theodoric, G. Dietrich. See Dutch, and Rich

sn.def: A mast, spar, or tall frame, supported at the top by stays or guys, and usually pivoted at the base, with suitable tackle for hoisting heavy weights, such as stones in building.
The pyramidal structure or tower over a deep drill hole, such as that of an oil well (also called an oil derrick .

entry.def: Daring or warlike.
entry.q: Drad for his derring doe and bloody deed.

entry.def: brave and heroic deeds.

entry.ety: From the American inventor
entry.def: A kind of short-barreled pocket pistol, of very large caliber, often carrying a half-ounce ball.
Dearth; scarcity.

entries.entry: Der`tro*the"ca‖n. NL., fr. Gr. � beak + � box, case Zoöl The horny covering of the end of the bill of birds.

entry.ety: Per. derwēsch, fr. OPer. derew to beg, ask alms: cf. F. derviche

sn.def: A Turkish or Persian monk, especially one who professes extreme poverty and leads an austere life.
One of the fanatical followers of the Mahdi, in the Sudan, in the 1880's.

in modern times, a member of an ascetic Mohammedan sect notable for its devotional exercises, which include energetic chanting or shouting and rhythmic bodily movement, such as whirling, leading to a trance-like state or ecstasy. From these exercises the phrase whirling dervish is derived.
figuratively, a person who whirls or engages in frenzied activity reminiscent of the dervish{3} dancing.

entry.ety: AS. deórwurþe, lit., dearworth
entry.def: Precious.

entry.note: several processes are in comon use for desalinating sea water. Distillation is effective, but expensive. Reverse osmosis is more economical.
entry.def: to remove the salt from, especially from water; as, it is necessary to desalinate sea water to make it fit to drink.
same as desalinization.
same as desalinization.
the removal of salt (especially from sea water); the act or process of desalinating.
same as desalinate.

entry.note: This term is used in a more general sense than desalinate, which usually refers to the removal of common salt (sodium chloride) from a water solution, such as sea water. Desalt is commonly used to refer to any laboratory or industrial process in which any salt may be removed from a mixture of substances dssolved in a solvent, usually water. It is thus used as a method of purification in chemical processes. The methods for desalting are very varied.
entry.def: to remove the salt from (a solution of salt).
to remove the scales from; -- e.g. of fish, or water boilers.

entry.note: ☞ The term has also been used synonymously with counterpoint, or polyphony, which developed out of the French déchant, of the 12th century.
entry.ety: OF. descant deschant, F. déchant discant, LL. discantus, fr. L. dis + cantus singing, melody, fr. canere to sing. See Chant, and cf. Descant v. i. Discant

sd.def: Originally, a double song; a melody or counterpoint sung above the plain song of the tenor; a variation of an air; a variation by ornament of the main subject or plain song.
The upper voice in part music.
The canto cantus, or soprano voice; the treble.
sd.q: Twenty doctors expound one text twenty ways, as children make descant upon plain song.
She [the nightingale] all night long her amorous descant sung.

sn.def: A discourse formed on its theme, like variations on a musical air; a comment or comments.
sn.q: Upon that simplest of themes how magnificent a descant!

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Descanted; p. pr. & vb. n. Descanting
entry.ety: From descant; n.; or directly fr. OF. descanter deschanter; L. dis- + cantare to sing

sn.def: To sing a variation or accomplishment.
To comment freely; to discourse with fullness and particularity; to discourse at large.
sn.q: A virtuous man should be pleased to find people descanting on his actions.

entry.def: One who descants.
René Descartes, a French philosopher and mathematician, born 159, died 1650. See biography, below.
entry.bio: Descartes, René (Latinized Renatus Cartesius). Born at La Haye, Touraine, France, March 31, 1596: died at Stockholm, Feb. 11, 1650. A. celebrated French philosopher, founder of Cartesianism and of modern philosophy in general. He was graduated at seventeen from the Jesuit college of La Flèche, spent five years in Paris (1613-18), and then roamed about in search of knowledge in Germany, Italy, Holland, and Poland. In 1628 he attended the siege of La Rochelle as a volunteer. From 1629 to 1649 he led a retired life in Holland, spreading and defending his philosophical ideas. He finally went to Stockholm on the invitation of Queen Christina of Sweden; five months later he died there of pneumonia. The work that has made him famous as a philosopher is a short treatise entitled "Discours de la méthode" (Leyden, 1637). It was published in French together with three essays in support of his theories, "La dioptrique," "Les météores," and "La géométrie." In it he revolutionized the science of thought. Descartes himself published during his lifetime "Meditationes de prima philosophia "(Paris, 1641; Amsterdam, 1642; translated into French, 1647), "Principia philosophiae" (Amsterdam, 1644), "Traité des passions de l'âme" (Amsterdam, 1649), and a polemic pamphlet entitled "Epistola Renati Descartes ad Gisbertum Voëitum" (Amsterdam, 1643). After his death his friends published his "De l'homme" (1664), "Traité de la formation du foetus" (1664), "Le monde ou traité de la lumière de Descartes" (1664), "Lettres" (1657-67), and "Opuscula posthuma, physica et mathematica" (Amsterdam, 1701). Descartes ranked among the foremost mathematicians of his day. A separate reprint was made of his geometry, and the work itself was translated into Latin in 1649, and reëdited in 1659 with notes and comments. In this form it constituted a classic standard throughout Europe, and presented an entirely new basis for the study of algebra and geometry.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Descended; p. pr. & vb. n. Descending
entry.ety: F. descendre, L. descendere descensum; de- + scandere to climb. See Scan

sn.def: To pass from a higher to a lower place; to move downwards; to come or go down in any way, as by falling, flowing, walking, etc.; to plunge; to fall; to incline downward; -- the opposite of ascend.
sn.q: The rain descended, and the floods came.
We will here descend to matters of later date.

sn.def: To enter mentally; to retire.
sn.q: He] with holiest meditations fed, Into himself descended.

sn.def: To make an attack, or incursion, as if from a vantage ground; to come suddenly and with violence; -- with on or upon.
sn.q: And on the suitors let thy wrath descend.

sn.def: To come down to a lower, less fortunate, humbler, less virtuous, or worse, state or station; to lower or abase one's self; as, he descended from his high estate.
To pass from the more general or important to the particular or less important matters to be considered.

To come down, as from a source, original, or stock; to be derived; to proceed by generation or by transmission; to fall or pass by inheritance; as, the beggar may descend from a prince; a crown descends to the heir.
To move toward the south, or to the southward.
To fall in pitch; to pass from a higher to a lower tone.

entry.def: To go down upon or along; to pass from a higher to a lower part of; as, they descended the river in boats; to descend a ladder.
entry.q: But never tears his cheek descended.

entry.ety: F. descendant, p. pr. of descendre. Cf. Descendent
entry.def: Descendent.

entry.def: all of the offspring of a given progenitor.

entry.ety: L. descendens -entis, p. pr. of descendre. Cf. Descendant
entry.def: Descending; falling; proceeding from an ancestor or source.
entry.q: More than mortal grace Speaks thee descendent of ethereal race.

The quality of being descendible; capability of being transmitted from ancestors; as, the descendibility of an estate.

sn.def: Admitting descent; capable of being descended.

that point in a planet's orbit where it intersects the ecliptic in passing southward.

the degree or arc of the equator which descends below the horizon of a right sphere at the same time with the object.

entry.ety: F. descente, fr. descendre; like vente, from vendre. See Descend

Derivation, as from an ancestor; procedure by generation; lineage; birth; extraction.
Transmission of an estate by inheritance, usually, but not necessarily, in the descending line; title to inherit an estate by reason of consanguinity.
Inclination downward; a descending way; inclined or sloping surface; declivity; slope; as, a steep descent .
That which is descended; descendants; issue.

entry.def: That can be described; capable of description.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Described; p. pr. & vb. n. Describing

S. congress, prohibiting segregation by governmental agencies and in places of public accommodation, which resulteo in widospread besegregotion of schools and places of business. entry.ety: OF. deserte desserte, merit, recompense, fr. deservir desservir, to merit. See Deserve

entry.ety: Cf. L. desertus, p. p. of deserere, and F. désert. See 2d Desert

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Deserted; p. pr. & vb. n. Deserting

sn.def: To leave (especially something which one should stay by and support); to leave in the lurch; to abandon; to forsake; -- implying blame, except sometimes when used of localities; as, to desert a friend, a principle, a cause, one's country.

entry.note: In this sense, the label implies some level of dependence of the person(s) being deserted on those deserting them.

sn.def: having no residents; as, deserted villages.
no longer used by people.
remote from civilization; as, the victim was lured to a deserted spot.

entry.def: One who forsakes a duty, a cause or a party, a friend, or any one to whom he owes service; especially, a soldier or a seaman who abandons the service without leave; one guilty of desertion.

sn.def: To earn by service; to be worthy of (something due, either good or evil); to merit; to be entitled to; as, the laborer deserves his wages; a work of value deserves praise.

variant spelling of desiccate.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Desiccated; p. pr. & vb. n. Desiccating

entry.def: The act of desiccating, or the state of being desiccated.

Anything desired; that of which the lack is felt; a want generally felt and acknowledge.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Designed; p. pr. & vb. n. Designing
entry.ety: F. désigner to designate, cf. F. dessiner to draw, dessin drawing, dessein a plan or scheme; all, ultimately, from L. designare to designate; de- + signare to mark, mark out, signum mark, sign. See Sign, and cf. Design n. Designate

sn.def: To draw preliminary outline or main features of; to sketch for a pattern or model; to delineate; to trace out; to draw.
To mark out and exhibit; to designate; to indicate; to show; to point out; to appoint.
sn.q: We shall see Justice design the victor's chivalry.
Meet me to-morrow where the master And this fraternity shall design.

sn.def: To create or produce, as a work of art; to form a plan or scheme of; to form in idea; to invent; to project; to lay out in the mind; as, a man designs an essay, a poem, a statue, or a cathedral.
To intend or purpose; -- usually with for before the remote object, but sometimes with to.
sn.q: Ask of politicians the end for which laws were originally designed.
He was designed to the study of the law.
sn.syn: To sketch; plan; purpose; intend; propose; project; mean.

entry.cs: Design for to intend to go to. Obs “From this city she designed for Collin [Cologne].” Evelyn.
entry.def: To form a design or designs; to plan.

cs.cd: those into which the designing of artistic forms and figures enters as a principal part, as architecture, painting, engraving, sculpture.
one in which are taught the invention and delineation of artistic or decorative figures, patterns, and the like.

entry.usage: Design Intention Purpose. Design has reference to something definitely aimed at. Intention points to the feelings or desires with which a thing is sought. Purpose has reference to a settled choice or determination for its attainment. “I had no design to injure you,” means it was no part of my aim or object. “I had no intention to injure you,” means, I had no wish or desire of that kind. “My purpose was directly the reverse,” makes the case still stronger.
entry.ety: Cf. dessein dessin

sn.def: A preliminary sketch; an outline or pattern of the main features of something to be executed, as of a picture, a building, or a decoration; a delineation; a plan.

A plan or scheme formed in the mind of something to be done; preliminary conception; idea intended to be expressed in a visible form or carried into action; intention; purpose; -- often used in a bad sense for evil intention or purpose; scheme; plot.
sn.q: The vast design and purpos� of the King.
The leaders of that assembly who withstood the designs of a besotted woman.
A . . . settled design upon another man's life.
How little he could guess the secret designs of the court!

sn.def: Specifically, intention or purpose as revealed or inferred from the adaptation of means to an end; as, the argument from design .

The realization of an inventive or decorative plan; esp., a work of decorative art considered as a new creation; conception or plan shown in completed work; as, this carved panel is a fine design, or of a fine design .
The invention and conduct of the subject; the disposition of every part, and the general order of the whole.
sn.syn: Intention; purpose; scheme; project; plan; idea.
sn.q: Is he a prudent man . . . that lays designs only for a day, without any prospect to the remaining part of his life?
I wish others the same intention, and greater successes.
It is the purpose that makes strong the vow.

entry.def: Capable of being designated or distinctly marked out; distinguishable.

entry.ety: L. designatus, p. p. of designare. See Design v. t.
entry.def: Designated; appointed; chosen.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Designated; p. pr. & vb. n. Designating

sn.def: To mark out and make known; to point out; to name; to indicate; to show; to distinguish by marks or description; to specify; as, to designate the boundaries of a country; to designate the rioters who are to be arrested.
To call by a distinctive title; to name.
To indicate or set apart for a purpose or duty; -- with to or for; as, to designate an officer for or to the command of a post or station.
sn.syn: To name; denominate; style; entitle; characterize; describe.

entry.ety: L. designatio: cf. F. désignation

sn.def: The act of designating; a pointing out or showing; indication.
Selection and appointment for a purpose; allotment; direction.
That which designates; a distinguishing mark or name; distinctive title; appellation.
sn.q: The usual designation of the days of the week.

sn.def: Use or application; import; intention; signification, as of a word or phrase.
sn.q: Finite and infinite seem . . . to be attributed primarily, in their first designation, only to those things which have parts.

entry.ety: Cf. F. désignatif
entry.def: Serving to designate or indicate; pointing out.

entry.ety: L

sn.def: An officer who assigned to each his rank and place in public shows and ceremonies.
One who designates.

entry.def: Serving to designate; designative; indicating.
By design; purposely; intentionally; -- opposed to accidentally ignorantly, or inadvertently.

sn.def: One who designs, marks out, or plans; a contriver.
One who produces or creates original works of art or decoration.
A plotter; a schemer; -- used in a bad sense.

entry.def: Full of design; scheming.
Intriguing; artful; scheming; as, a designing man.
The act of making designs or sketches; the act of forming designs or plans.
Without design.

sn.def: Delineation; sketch; design; ideal; invention.
sn.q: For though that some mean artist's skill were shown In mingling colors, or in placing light, Yet still the fair designment was his own.

sn.def: Design; purpose; scheme.

entry.def: To deprive of silver; as, to desilver lead.
The act or the process of freeing from silver; also, the condition resulting from the removal of silver.
To deprive, or free from, silver; to remove silver from.

entry.ety: Cf. F. désinence
entry.def: Termination; ending.

entry.ety: L. desinens, p. pr. of desinere desitum, to leave off, cease; de- + sinere to let, allow
entry.def: Ending; forming an end; lowermost.
entry.q: Theirdesinentparts, fish.

entry.ety: Cf. F. désinentiel
entry.def: Terminal.
entry.q: Furthermore, b, as a desinential element, has a dynamic function.

entry.ety: L. desipiens, p. pr. of desipere to be foolish; de- + sapere to be wise
entry.def: Foolish; silly; trifling.
The state or quality of being desirable; desirableness.

entry.ety: F. désirable, fr. L. desiderabilis. See Desire v. t.
entry.def: Worthy of desire or longing; fitted to excite desire or a wish to possess; pleasing; agreeable.
entry.q: All of them desirable young men.
As things desirable excite Desire, and objects move the appetite.

entry.def: The quality of being desirable.
entry.q: The desirableness of the Austrian alliance.

entry.def: In a desirable manner.

entry.usage: To Desire Wish. In desire the feeling is usually more eager than in wish. “I wish you to do this” is a milder form of command than “I desire you to do this,” though the feeling prompting the injunction may be the same. C. J. Smith.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Desired; p. pr. & vb. n. Desiring
entry.ety: F. désirer, L. desiderare, origin uncertain, perh. fr. de- + sidus star, constellation, and hence orig., to turn the eyes from the stars. Cf. Consider, and Desiderate, and see Sidereal

sn.def: To long for; to wish for earnestly; to covet.
sn.q: Neither shall any man desire thy land.
Ye desire your child to live.

sn.def: To express a wish for; to entreat; to request.
sn.q: Then she said, Did I desire a son of my lord?
Desire him to go in; trouble him no more.

sn.def: To require; to demand; to claim.
sn.q: A doleful case desires a doleful song.

sn.def: To miss; to regret.
sn.q: She shall be pleasant while she lives, and desired when she dies.
sn.syn: To long for; hanker after; covet; wish; ask; request; solicit; entreat; beg.

entry.ety: F. désir, fr. désirer. See Desire v. t.

sn.def: The natural longing that is excited by the enjoyment or the thought of any good, and impels to action or effort its continuance or possession; an eager wish to obtain or enjoy.
sn.q: Unspeakable desire to see and know.

sn.def: An expressed wish; a request; petition.
sn.q: And slowly was my mother brought To yield consent to my desire.

sn.def: Anything which is desired; an object of longing.
sn.q: The Desire of all nations shall come.

sn.def: Excessive or morbid longing; lust; appetite.
Grief; regret.
sn.syn: Wish; appetency; craving; inclination; eagerness; aspiration; longing.

entry.def: Filled with desire; eager.
entry.q: The desireful troops.

entry.def: The state of being desireful; eagerness to obtain and possess.
entry.q: The desirefulness of our minds much augmenteth and increaseth our pleasure.

entry.def: Free from desire.
One who desires, asks, or wishes.

entry.ety: F. désireux, OF. desiros, fr. desir. See Desire n.
entry.def: Feeling desire; eagerly wishing; solicitous; eager to obtain; covetous.
entry.q: Jesus knew that they were desirous to ask him.
Be not desirous of his dainties.

entry.def: With desire; eagerly.
The state of being desirous.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Desisted; p. pr. & vb. n. Desisting
entry.ety: L. desistere; de- + sistere to stand, stop, fr. stare to stand: cf. F. désister. See Stand
entry.def: To cease to proceed or act; to stop; to forbear; -- often with from.
entry.q: Never desisting to do evil.
To desist from his bad practice.
Desistthou art discern'd, And toil'st in vain).

entry.ety: Cf. F. desistance
entry.def: The act or state of desisting; cessation.
entry.q: If fatigue of body or brain were in every case followed by desistance . . . then would the system be but seldom out of working order.

entry.ety: See Desist
entry.def: Final; conclusive; ending.

entry.ety: See Desinent
entry.def: An end or ending.
Final; serving to complete; conclusive.
entry.q: Desitivepropositions.

entry.def: A proposition relating to or expressing an end or conclusion.

entry.ety: OE. deske, the same word as dish disk. See Dish, and cf. Disk

sn.def: A table, frame, or case, usually with sloping top, but often with flat top, for the use writers and readers. It often has a drawer or repository underneath.

A reading table or lectern to support the book from which the liturgical service is read, differing from the pulpit from which the sermon is preached; also (esp. in the United States), a pulpit. Hence, used symbolically for “the clerical profession.”

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Desked; p. pr. & vb. n. Desking
entry.def: To shut up, as in a desk; to treasure.
Work done at a desk, as by a clerk or writer.

entry.ety: Cf. Sw. desman musk
entry.def: An amphibious, insectivorous mammal found in Russia (Myogale moschata). It is allied to the moles, but is called muskrat by some English writers.

entry.ety: Gr. desmo`s chain + e'i^dos form
entry.def: A microscopic plant of the family Desmidiæ, a group of unicellular algæ in which the species have a greenish color, and the cells generally appear as if they consisted of two coalescing halves.

entry.ety: Gr. de`smh desmo`s, bundle, fr. dei^n to bind
entry.def: Same as Stilbite. It commonly occurs in bundles or tufts of crystals.

entry.ety: Gr. desmo`s bond + E. bacteria
entry.def: See Microbacteria.
a natural family comprisng the true vampire bats.
the type genus of the Desmodontidae, consisting of vampire bats.

entry.ety: Gr. desmo`s bond + 'odoy`s 'odo`ntos, tooth
entry.def: A member of a group of South American blood-sucking bats, of the genera Desmodus and Diphylla. See Vampire.

entry.ety: Gr. desmo`s bond + gna`qos jaw
entry.def: Having the maxillo-palatine bones united; -- applied to a group of carinate birds (Desmognathæ), including various wading and swimming birds, as the ducks and herons, and also raptorial and other kinds.

entry.ety: Gr. desmo`s ligament + -oid
entry.def: Resembling, or having the characteristics of, a ligament; ligamentous.

entry.ety: Gr. desmo`s ligament + -logy
entry.def: The science which treats of the ligaments.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. � bond + � muscle
entry.def: The division of Tunicata which includes the Salpæ. See Salpa.

entry.ety: L. desolatus, p. p. of desolare to leave alone, forsake; de- + solare to make lonely, solus alone. See Sole a.

sn.def: Destitute or deprived of inhabitants; deserted; uninhabited; hence, gloomy; as, a desolate isle; a desolate wilderness; a desolate house.
sn.q: I will make Jerusalem . . . a den of dragons, and I will make the cities of Judah desolate, without an inhabitant.
And the silvery marish flowers that throng The desolate creeks and pools among.

sn.def: Laid waste; in a ruinous condition; neglected; destroyed; as, desolate altars.
Left alone; forsaken; lonely; comfortless.
sn.q: Have mercy upon, for I am desolate.
Voice of the poor and desolate.

sn.def: Lost to shame; dissolute.
Destitute of; lacking in.
sn.q: I were right now of tales desolate.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Desolated; p. pr. & vb. n. Desolating

sn.def: To make desolate; to leave alone; to deprive of inhabitants; as, the earth was nearly desolated by the flood.
To lay waste; to ruin; to ravage; as, a fire desolates a city.
sn.q: Constructed in the very heart of a desolating war.

entry.def: reduced to a barren and lifeless state.
entry.syn: blasted, desolate, devastated, ravaged, ruined, wasted.

entry.def: In a desolate manner.
The state of being desolate.
One who, or that which, desolates or lays waste.

entry.ety: F. désolation, L. desolatio

sn.def: The act of desolating or laying waste; destruction of inhabitants; depopulation.
sn.q: Unto the end of the war desolations are determined.

sn.def: The state of being desolated or laid waste; ruin; solitariness; destitution; gloominess.
sn.q: You would have sold your king to slaughter, . . . And his whole kingdom into desolation.

sn.def: A place or country wasted and forsaken.
sn.q: How is Babylon become a desolation!
sn.syn: Waste; ruin; destruction; havoc; devastation; ravage; sadness; destitution; melancholy; gloom; gloominess.

entry.ety: L
entry.def: Same as Desolater.

entry.ety: L. desolatorius
entry.def: Causing desolation.
To clear from sophism or error.

entry.ety: F. pref. des- from + E. oxalic
entry.def: Made or derived from oxalic acid; as, desoxalic acid.
same as deoxyribonucleic acid.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Despaired; p. pr. & vb. n. Despairing
entry.ety: OE. despeiren dispeiren, OF. desperer, fr. L. desperare; de- + sperare to hope; akin to spes hope, and perh. to spatium space, E. space speed; cf. OF. espeir hope, F. espoir. Cf. Prosper Desperate
entry.def: To be hopeless; to have no hope; to give up all hope or expectation; -- often with of.
entry.q: We despaired even of life.
Never despair of God's blessings here.

sn.def: To give up as beyond hope or expectation; to despair of.
sn.q: I would not despair the greatest design that could be attempted.

sn.def: To cause to despair.

entry.ety: Cf. OF. despoir, fr. desperer

sn.def: Loss of hope; utter hopelessness; complete despondency.
sn.q: We in dark dreams are tossing to and fro, Pine with regret, or sicken with despair.
Before he [Bunyan] was ten, his sports were interrupted by fits of remorse and despair.

sn.def: That which is despaired of.
sn.q: The meredespairof surgery he cures.

entry.def: One who despairs.
Hopeless.
Feeling or expressing despair; hopeless.

entry.ety: OF. desparpeillier
entry.def: To scatter; to disparkle.
Same as Dispatch.

entry.ety: Pref. de-intens.) + specificate
entry.def: To discriminate; to separate according to specific signification or qualities; to specificate; to desynonymize.
entry.q: Inaptitude and ineptitude have been usefully despecificated.

entry.def: Discrimination.

entry.ety: L. despectus, fr. despicere. See Despite n.
entry.def: Contempt.

entry.ety: L. despectio
entry.def: A looking down; a despising.
To send hastily.
entry.q: Despeeded certain of their crew.

entry.def: To spend; to squander. See Dispend.
entry.q: Some noble men in Spain can despend £50,000.

entries.entry:
Des`per*a"do n.; pl.Desperadoes #. OSp. desperado, p. p. of desperar, fr. L. desperare. See Desperate
A reckless, furious man; a person urged by furious passions, and regardless of consequence; a wild ruffian.

entry.ety: L. desperatus, p. p. of desperare. See Despair, and cf. Desperado

sn.def: Without hope; given to despair; hopeless.
sn.q: I am desperate of obtaining her.

sn.def: Beyond hope; causing despair; extremely perilous; irretrievable; past cure, or, at least, extremely dangerous; as, a desperate disease; desperate fortune.
Proceeding from, or suggested by, despair; without regard to danger or safety; reckless; furious; as, a desperate effort.
sn.q: Desperateexpedients.

sn.def: Extreme, in a bad sense; outrageous; -- used to mark the extreme predominance of a bad quality.
sn.q: A desperate offendress against nature.
The most desperate of reprobates.
sn.syn: Hopeless; despairing; desponding; rash; headlong; precipitate; irretrievable; irrecoverable; forlorn; mad; furious; frantic.

entry.def: One desperate or hopeless.
In a desperate manner; without regard to danger or safety; recklessly; extremely; as, the troops fought desperately .
entry.q: She fell desperately in love with him.

entry.def: Desperation; virulence.

entry.ety: L. desperatio: cf. OF. desperation

sn.def: The act of despairing or becoming desperate; a giving up of hope.
sn.q: This desperation of success chills all our industry.

sn.def: A state of despair, or utter hopeless; abandonment of hope; extreme recklessness; reckless fury.
sn.q: In the desperation of the moment, the officers even tried to cut their way through with their swords.

entry.def: Despicableness.

entry.ety: L. despicabilis, fr. despicari to despise; akin to despicere. See Despise
entry.def: Fit or deserving to be despised; contemptible; mean; vile; worthless; as, a despicable man; despicable company; a despicable gift.
entry.syn: Contemptible; mean; vile; worthless; pitiful; paltry; sordid; low; base. See Contemptible.

entry.def: The quality of being despicable; meanness; vileness; worthlessness.
In a despicable or mean manner; contemptibly; as, despicably stingy.

entry.ety: L. despicientia. See Despise
entry.def: A looking down; despection.

entry.ety: Cf. OF. despisable
entry.def: Despicable; contemptible.
A despising; contempt.
entry.q: A despisal of religion.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Despised; p. pr. & vb. n. Despising
entry.ety: OF. despis-, in some forms of despire to despise, fr. L. despicere despectum, to look down upon, despise; de- + spicere specere, to look. See Spy, and cf. Despicable Despite
entry.def: To look down upon with disfavor or contempt; to contemn; to scorn; to disdain; to have a low opinion or contemptuous dislike of.
entry.q: Fools despise wisdom and instruction.
Men naturally despise those who court them, but respect those who do not give way to them.
entry.syn: To contemn; scorn; disdain; slight; undervalue. See Contemn.

entry.def: The state of being despised.
A despising.
One who despises; a contemner; a scorner.
Contemptuously.

entry.cs: In despite in defiance of another's power or inclination. In despite of in defiance of; in spite of. See under Spite. “Seized my hand in despite of my efforts to the contrary.” W. Irving. In your despite in defiance or contempt of you; in spite of you. Obs
entry.ety: OF. despit, F. dépit, fr. L. despectus contempt, fr. despicere. See Despise, and cf. Spite Despect

sn.def: Malice; malignity; spite; malicious anger; contemptuous hate.
sn.q: With all thy despite against the land of Israel.

sn.def: An act of malice, hatred, or defiance; contemptuous defiance; a deed of contempt.
sn.q: A despite done against the Most High.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Despited; p. pr. & vb. n. Despiting
entry.ety: OF. despitier, fr. L. despectare, intens. of despicere. See Despite n.
entry.def: To vex; to annoy; to offend contemptuously.
In spite of; against, or in defiance of; notwithstanding; as, despite his prejudices.

entry.ety: See Despite, and cf. Spiteful
entry.def: Full of despite; expressing malice or contemptuous hate; malicious.
entry.q: Haters of God, despiteful, proud, boasters.
Pray for them which despitefully use you.
Let us examine him with despitefulness and fortune.

entry.ety: OE. despitous, OF. despiteus, fr. despit; affected in form by E. piteous. See Despite
entry.def: Feeling or showing despite; malicious; angry to excess; cruel; contemptuous.
entry.q: Despiteousreproaches.

entry.def: Despitefully.
Despiteous; very angry; cruel.
entry.q: He was to sinful man not despitous.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Despoiled; p. pr. & vb. n. Despoiling
entry.ety: OF. despoiller, F. dépouiller, L. despoliare despoliatum; de- + spoliare to strip, rob, spolium spoil, booty. Cf. Spoil Despoliation

sn.def: To strip, as of clothing; to divest or unclothe.
To deprive for spoil; to plunder; to rob; to pillage; to strip; to divest; -- usually followed by of.
sn.q: The clothed earth is then bare,Despoiled is the summer fair.
A law which restored to them an immense domain of which they had been despoiled.
Despoiled of innocence, of faith, of bliss.
sn.syn: To strip; deprive; rob; bereave; rifle.

entry.def: Spoil.
having been robbed and destroyed by force and violence.
One who despoils.
Despoliation.
the daughter of Zeus and Demeter; made queen of the underworld by Pluto in ancient mythology; identified with Roman Proserpina.

entry.ety: L. despoliatio. See Despoil
entry.def: A stripping or plundering; spoliation.

entry.usage: Despair implies a total loss of hope, which despond does not, at least in every case; yet despondency is often more lasting than despair, or than desperation, which impels to violent action.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Desponded; p. pr. & vb. n. Desponding
entry.ety: L. despondēre desponsum, to promise away, promise in marriage, give up, to lose (courage); de- + spondēre to promise solemnly. See Sponsor
entry.def: To give up the will, courage, or spirit; to be thoroughly disheartened; to lose all courage; to become dispirited or depressed; to take an unhopeful view.
entry.q: I should despair, or at least despond.
Others depress their own minds, [anddespond at the first difficulty.
We wish that . . . desponding patriotism may turn its eyes hitherward, and be assured that the foundations of our national power still stand strong.

entry.def: Despondency.
entry.q: The slough of despond.

entry.def: Despondency.
entry.q: The people, when once infected, lose their relish for happiness [and] saunter about with looks of despondence.

entry.def: The state of desponding; loss of hope and cessation of effort; discouragement; depression or dejection of the mind.
entry.q: The unhappy prince seemed, during some days, to be sunk in despondency.

entry.ety: L. despondens -entis, p. pr. of despondēre
entry.def: Marked by despondence; given to despondence; low-spirited; as, a despondent manner; a despondent prisoner.
One who desponds.
In a desponding manner.

entry.ety: From L. desponsus, p. p. See Despond
entry.def: Betrothal.
entry.q: Ethelbert . . . went peaceably to King Offa for desponsage of Athilrid, his daughter.

entry.ety: L. desponsatus, p. p. of desponsare, intens. of despondere to betroth. See Despond
entry.def: To betroth.

entry.ety: L. desponsatio: cf. OF. desponsation
entry.def: A betrothing; betrothal.
entry.q: For all this desponsation of her . . . she had not set one step toward the consummation of her marriage.

entries.entry: De*spon"so*ry n.; pl.Desponsories. A written pledge of marriage.

entry.def: See Disport.

entry.ety: F. despote, LL. despotus, fr. Gr. despo`ths master, lord, the second part of which is akin to po`sis husband, and L. potens. See Potent

sn.def: A master; a lord; especially, an absolute or irresponsible ruler or sovereign.
sn.q: Irresponsible power in human hands so naturally leads to it, that cruelty has become associated with despot and tyrant.

sn.def: One who rules regardless of a constitution or laws; a tyrant.

entry.ety: Cf. F. despotat
entry.def: The station or government of a despot; also, the domain of a despot.

entry.ety: Gr. despotiko`s: cf. F. despotique
entry.def: Having the character of, or pertaining to, a despot; absolute in power; possessing and abusing unlimited power; evincing despotism; tyrannical; arbitrary.

entry.ety: Cf. F. despotisme

sn.def: The power, spirit, or principles of a despot; absolute control over others; tyrannical sway; tyranny.
sn.q: Thedespotismof vice.

sn.def: A government which is directed by a despot; a despotic monarchy; absolutism; autocracy.
sn.q: Despotism . . . is the only form of government which may with safety to itself neglect the education of its infant poor.

entry.def: A supporter of despotism.
To act the despot.
See Dispread.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Despumated; p. pr. & vb. n. Despumating
entry.ety: L. despumatus, p. p. of despumare to despume; de- + spumare to foam, froth, spuma froth, scum
entry.def: To throw off impurities in spume; to work off in foam or scum; to foam.

entry.ety: L. despumatio: cf. F. despumation
entry.def: The act of throwing up froth or scum; separation of the scum or impurities from liquids; scumming; clarification.

entry.ety: Cf. F. despumer. See Despumate
entry.def: To free from spume or scum.
entry.q: If honey be despumed.

entry.ety: L. desquamatus, p. p. of desquamare to scale off; de- + squama scale
entry.def: To peel off in the form of scales; to scale off, as the skin in certain diseases.

entry.ety: Cf. F. desquamation
entry.def: The separation or shedding of the cuticle or epidermis in the form of flakes or scales; exfoliation, as of bones.
Of, pertaining to, or attended with, desquamation.
An instrument formerly used in removing the laminæ of exfoliated bones.
Dais.

cs.cd: a spoon used in eating dessert; a spoon intermediate in size between a teaspoon and a tablespoon.
as much as a dessert spoon will hold, usually reckoned at about two and a half fluid drams.

entry.ety: F., fr. desservir to remove from table, to clear the table; pref. des-L. dis-) + servir to serve, to serve at table. See Serve
entry.def: A service of pastry, fruits, or sweetmeats, at the close of a feast or entertainment; pastry, fruits, etc., forming the last course at dinner.
entry.q: “An 't please your honor,” quoth the peasant, “This same dessert is not so pleasant.”

entry.ety: Cf. F. détrempe, fr. détremper
entry.def: A kind of painting. See Distemper.

entry.ety: Cf. F. destin
entry.def: Destiny.

entry.ety: Cf. OF. destinable
entry.def: Determined by destiny; fated.
In a destinable manner.
Determined by destiny; fated.
entry.q: The orderdestinal.

entry.ety: L. destinatus, p. p. of destinare. See Destine
entry.def: Destined.
entry.q: Destinateto hell.

entry.def: To destine, design, or choose.
entry.q: That name that God . . . diddestinate.

entry.ety: L. destinatio determination: cf. F. destination destination

sn.def: The act of destining or appointing.
Purpose for which anything is destined; predetermined end, object, or use; ultimate design.
The place set for the end of a journey, or to which something is sent; place or point aimed at.
sn.syn: Appointment; design; purpose; intention; destiny; lot; fate; end.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Destined; p. pr. & vb. n. Destining
entry.ety: F. destiner, L. destinare; de + the root of stare to stand. See Stand, and cf. Obstinate
entry.def: To determine the future condition or application of; to set apart by design for a future use or purpose; to fix, as by destiny or by an authoritative decree; to doom; to ordain or preordain; to appoint; -- often with the remoter object preceded by to or for.
entry.q: We are decreed, Reserved, and destined to eternal woe.
Till the loathsome opposite Of all my heart had destined, did obtain.
Not enjoyment and not sorrow Is our destined end or way.
entry.syn: To design; mark out; determine; allot; choose; intend; devote; consecrate; doom.

entry.def: A believer in destiny; a fatalist.

entries.entry:
Des"ti*ny
The Destinies Anc. Myth the three Parcæ, or Fates; the supposed powers which preside over human life, and determine its circumstances and duration.
n.; pl.Destinies #. OE. destinee destene, F. destinée, from destiner. See Destine
That to which any person or thing is destined; predetermined state; condition foreordained by the Divine or by human will; fate; lot; doom. Thither he Will come to know his destiny. No man of woman born, Coward or brave, can shun his destiny.
The fixed order of things; invincible necessity; fate; a resistless power or agency conceived of as determining the future, whether in general or of an individual. But who can turn the stream of destiny? Fame comes only when deserved, and then is as inevitable as destiny, for it is destiny. Marked by the Destinies to be avoided.

entry.ety: L. destituens, p. pr. of destituere
entry.def: Deficient; wanting; as, a destituent condition.

entry.ety: L. destitutus, p. p. of destituere to set away, leave alone, forsake; de + statuere to set. See Statute

sn.def: Forsaken; not having in possession (something necessary, or desirable); deficient; lacking; devoid; -- often followed by of.
sn.q: In thee is my trust; leave not my soul destitute.
Totally destitute of all shadow of influence.

sn.def: Not possessing the necessaries of life; in a condition of want; needy; without possessions or resources; very poor.
sn.q: They wandered about in sheepskins and goatskins; being destitute, afflicted, tormented.

sn.def: To leave destitute; to forsake; to abandon.
sn.q: To forsake or destitute a plantation.

sn.def: To make destitute; to cause to be in want; to deprive; -- followed by of.
sn.q: Destituted of all honor and livings.

sn.def: To disappoint.
sn.q: When his expectation is destituted.

entry.def: In destitution.
Destitution.

entry.ety: L. destitutio a forsaking
entry.def: The state of being deprived of anything; the state or condition of being destitute, needy, or without resources; deficiency; lack; extreme poverty; utter want; as, the inundation caused general destitution .
