entry.ety: OF. destrier, fr. L. dextra on the right side. The squire led his master's horse beside him, on his right hand. Skeat
entry.def: A war horse.
To destroy.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Destroyed; p. pr. & vb. n. Destroying
entry.ety: OE. destroien destruien destrien, OF. destruire, F. détruire, fr. L. destruere destructum; de + struere to pile up, build. See Structure

sn.def: To unbuild; to pull or tear down; to separate virulently into its constituent parts; to break up the structure and organic existence of; to demolish.
sn.q: But ye shall destroy their altars, break their images, and cut down their groves.

sn.def: To ruin; to bring to naught; to put an end to; to annihilate; to consume.
sn.q: I will utterly pluck up and destroy that nation.

sn.def: To put an end to the existence, prosperity, or beauty of; to kill.
sn.q: If him by force he can destroy, or, worse, By some false guile pervert.
sn.syn: To demolish; lay waste; consume; raze; dismantle; ruin; throw down; overthrow; subvert; desolate; devastate; deface; extirpate; extinguish; kill; slay. See Demolish.

entry.def: Destructible.
entry.q: Plants . . . scarcely destroyable by the weather.

entry.sn: p. p. of destroy.Narrower terms: annihilated, exterminated, wiped out(predicate; blasted, desolate, desolated, devastated, ravaged, ruined, wasted; blighted, spoilt; blotted out, obliterate, obliterated; demolished, dismantled, razed; done for(predicate), kaput(predicate), gone(prenominal), lost, finished(predicate; extinguished; ruined, wiped out(predicate), impoverished; totaled, wrecked; war-torn, war-worn; despoiled, pillaged, raped, ravaged, sacked Also See: damaged. Antonym: preserved

sn.def: destroyed physically or morally.

entry.ety: Cf. OF. destruior

sn.def: One who destroys, ruins, kills, or desolates.

a small fast warship used primarily as an escort to larger vessels and typically armed with a combination of 5-inch guns, torpedos, depth charges, and missiles; formerly identical to the Torpedo-boat destroyer.

entry.ety: L. destructus, p. p. of destruere. See Destroy
entry.def: To destroy.

entry.ety: Cf. F. destructibilité
entry.def: The quality of being capable of destruction; destructibleness.

entry.ety: L. destructibilis
entry.def: Liable to destruction; capable of being destroyed.
The quality of being destructible.

entry.ety: L. destructio: cf. F. destruction. See Destroy

sn.def: The act of destroying; a tearing down; a bringing to naught; subversion; demolition; ruin; slaying; devastation.
sn.q: The Jews smote all their enemies with the stroke of the sword, and slaughter, and destruction.
'Tis safer to be that which we destroy Than by destruction dwell in doubtful joy.
Destruction of venerable establishment.

sn.def: The state of being destroyed, demolished, ruined, slain, or devastated.
sn.q: This town came to destruction.
Thou castedst them down into destruction.

sn.def: A destroying agency; a cause of ruin or of devastation; a destroyer.
sn.q: The destruction that wasteth at noonday.
sn.syn: Demolition; subversion; overthrow; desolation; extirpation; extinction; devastation; downfall; extermination; havoc; ruin.

sn.def: One who delights in destroying that which is valuable; one whose principles and influence tend to destroy existing institutions; a destructive.
One who believes in the final destruction or complete annihilation of the wicked; -- called also annihilationist.

entry.cs: Destructive distillation. See Distillation. Destructive sorties Logic a process of reasoning which involves the denial of the first of a series of dependent propositions as a consequence of the denial of the last; a species of reductio ad absurdum. Whately.
entry.ety: L. destructivus: cf. F. destructif
entry.def: Causing destruction; tending to bring about ruin, death, or devastation; ruinous; fatal; productive of serious evil; mischievous; pernicious; -- often with of or to; as, intemperance is destructive of health; evil examples are destructive to the morals of youth.
entry.q: Time's destructive power.
entry.syn: Mortal; deadly; poisonous; fatal; ruinous; malignant; baleful; pernicious; mischievous.

entry.def: One who destroys; a radical reformer; a destructionist.
In a destructive manner.
energy-releasing (prenominal); same as catabolic.

sn.def: The quality of destroying or ruining.
The faculty supposed to impel to the commission of acts of destruction; propensity to destroy.

entry.ety: L., from destruere. See Destroy, and cf. Destroyer

sn.def: A destroyer.
sn.q: Fire, the destructor and the artificial death of things.

entry.sn: A furnace or oven for the burning or carbonizing of refuse; specif. Sewage Disposal a furnace (called in full refuse destructor) in which the more solid constituents of sewage are burnt. Destructors are often so constructed as to utilize refuse as fuel.

sn.def: in object-oriented programming, a function which destroys an object which was previously created by a different function.

entry.def: To destroy.

entry.ety: L. desudatio, fr. desudare to sweat greatly; de + sudare to sweat
entry.def: A sweating; a profuse or morbid sweating, often succeeded by an eruption of small pimples.

entry.ety: L. desuetus, p. p. of desuescere to disuse
entry.def: Disused; out of use.

entry.ety: L. desuetudo, from desuescere, to grow out of use, disuse; de + suescere to become used or accustomed: cf. F. désuétude. See Custom
entry.def: The cessation of use; disuse; discontinuance of practice, custom, or fashion.
entry.q: The desuetude abrogated the law, which, before, custom had established.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Desulphurated; p. pr. & vb. n. Desulphurating
entry.def: To deprive of sulphur.

entry.ety: Cf. F. désulfuration
entry.def: The act or process of depriving of sulphur.
To desulphurate; to deprive of sulphur.
In a desultory manner; without method; loosely; immethodically.
The quality of being desultory or without order or method; unconnectedness.
entry.q: The seeming desultoriness of my method.

entry.def: Desultory.

entry.ety: L. desultorius, fr. desultor a leaper, fr. desilire desultum, to leap down; de + salire to leap. See Saltation

sn.def: Leaping or skipping about.
sn.q: I shot at it [a bird], but it was so desultory that I missed my aim.

sn.def: Jumping, or passing, from one thing or subject to another, without order or rational connection; without logical sequence; disconnected; immethodical; aimless; as, desultory minds.
sn.q: He [Goldsmith] knew nothing accurately; his reading had been desultory.

sn.def: Out of course; by the way; as a digression; not connected with the subject; as, a desultory remark.
sn.syn: Rambling; roving; immethodical; discursive; inconstant; unsettled; cursory; slight; hasty; loose.

entry.ety: L. desumere; de + sumere to take
entry.def: To select; to borrow.
to cause a process to occur at times or in cycles independent of another process.
a process causing an absence of synchronization; the relation that exists when things occur at unrelated times; as, the stimulus produced a desynchronizing of the brain waves.
The act of desynonymizing.
To deprive of synonymous character; to discriminate in use; -- applied to words which have been employed as synonyms.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Detached; p. pr. & vb. n. Detaching
entry.ety: F. détachercf. It. distaccare staccare); pref. déL. dis) + the root found also in E. attach. See Attach, and cf. Staccato

sn.def: To part; to separate or disunite; to disengage; -- the opposite of attach; as, to detach the coats of a bulbous root from each other; to detach a man from a leader or from a party.
To separate for a special object or use; -- used especially in military language; as, to detach a ship from a fleet, or a company from a regiment.
sn.syn: To separate; disunite; disengage; sever; disjoin; withdraw; draw off. See Detail.

entry.def: To push asunder; to come off or separate from anything; to disengage.
entry.q: A vapordetaching, fold by fold, From those still heights.

entry.def: That can be detached.

entry.cs: Detached escapement. See Escapement.
entry.def: Separate; unconnected, or imperfectly connected; as, detached parcels.
entry.q: Extensive anddetachedempire.

entry.ety: Cf. F. détachement

sn.def: The act of detaching or separating, or the state of being detached.
That which is detached; especially, a body of troops or part of a fleet sent from the main body on special service.
sn.q: Troops . . . widely scattered in little detachments.

sn.def: Abstraction from worldly objects; renunciation.
sn.q: A trial which would have demanded of him a most heroic faith and the detachment of a saint.

cs.cd: a drawing of the full size, or on a large scale, of some part of a building, machine, etc.
in subdivisions; part by part; item by item; circumstantially; with particularity.

entry.ety: F. détail, fr. détailler to cut in pieces, tell in detail; pref. dé-L. de or dis-) + tailler to cut. See Tailor

sn.def: A minute portion; one of the small parts; a particular; an item; -- used chiefly in the plural; as, the details of a scheme or transaction.
sn.q: The details of the campaign in Italy.

sn.def: A narrative which relates minute points; an account which dwells on particulars.
The selection for a particular service of a person or a body of men; hence, the person or the body of men so selected.

sd.def: A minor part, as, in a building, the cornice, caps of the buttresses, capitals of the columns, etc., or (called larger details) a porch, a gable with its windows, a pavilion, or an attached tower.
A detail drawing.
sd.syn: Account; relation; narrative; recital; explanation; narration.

entry.usage: Detail respects the act of individualizing the person or body that is separated; detach, the removing for the given end or object.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Detailed; p. pr. & vb. n. Detailing
entry.ety: Cf. F. détailler to cut up in pieces, tell in detail. See Detail n.

sn.def: To relate in particulars; to particularize; to report minutely and distinctly; to enumerate; to specify; as, he detailed all the facts in due order.
To tell off or appoint for a particular service, as an officer, a troop, or a squadron.
To provide with fine or intricate added decoration.
Developed or executed with care and in minute detail; as, a detailed plan.
Containing details; containing subordinate parts as well as more general discussion; -- of a discourse; as, a specific and detailed account of the accident. Opposite of sketchy general vague.
having fine or intricate added decoration.

entry.def: One who details.

sn.def: description of something in detail.
Thorough cleaning, esp. of the interior of automobiles.

entry.def: confidential information.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Detained; p. pr. & vb. n. Detaining
entry.ety: F. détenir, L. detinere detentum; de + tenere to hold. See Tenable

sn.def: To keep back or from; to withhold.
sn.q: Detain not the wages of the hireling.

sn.def: To restrain from proceeding; to stay or stop; to delay; as, we were detained by an accident.
sn.q: Let us detain thee, until we shall have made ready a kid for thee.

sn.def: To hold or keep in custody.
sn.syn: To withhold; retain; stop; stay; arrest; check; retard; delay; hinder.

entry.def: Detention.
A writ. See Detinue.

sn.def: One who detains.

sd.def: The keeping possession of what belongs to another; detention of what is another's, even though the original taking may have been lawful. Forcible detainer is indictable at common law.
A writ authorizing the keeper of a prison to continue to keep a person in custody.

entry.ety: Cf. OF. detenement
entry.def: Detention.

entry.ety: L. detectus, p. p. of detegere to uncover, detect; de + tegere to cover. See Tegument
entry.def: Detected.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Detected; p. pr. & vb. n. Detecting

sn.def: To uncover; to discover; to find out; to bring to light; as, to detect a crime or a criminal; to detect a mistake in an account.
sn.q: Plain good intention . . . is as easily discovered at the first view, as fraud is surely detected at last.
Like following life through creatures you dissect, You lose it in the moment you detect.

sn.def: To inform against; to accuse.
sn.q: He was untruly judged to have preached such articles as he was detected of.
sn.syn: To discover; find out; lay bare; expose.

entry.def: Capable of being detected or found out; as, parties not detectable .
entry.q: Errorsdetectibleat a glance.

entry.def: One who, or that which, detects or brings to light; one who finds out what another attempts to conceal; a detector.

entry.ety: L. detectio an uncovering, revealing
entry.def: The act of detecting; the laying open what was concealed or hidden; discovery; as, the detection of a thief; the detection of fraud, forgery, or a plot.
entry.q: Such secrets of guilt are never from detection.

entry.def: Fitted for, or skilled in, detecting; employed in detecting crime or criminals; as, a detective officer.
One who business it is so detect criminals or discover matters of secrecy.

entry.cs: Bank-note detector a publication containing a description of genuine and counterfeit bank notes, designed to enable persons to discriminate between them. Detector lock. See under Lock.
entry.ety: L., a revealer
entry.def: One who, or that which, detects; a detecter.
entry.q: A deathbed's detector of the heart.

sd.def: An indicator showing the depth of the water in a boiler.
A galvanometer, usually portable, for indicating the direction of a current.
Any of various devices for detecting the presence of electric waves.

entries.entry: De*tect"or bar. Railroads A bar, connected with a switch, longer than the distance between any two consecutive wheels of a train (45 to 50 feet), laid inside a rail and operated by the wheels so that the switch cannot be thrown until all the train is past the switch.

entry.ety: L. de + tenebrare to make dark, fr. tenebrae darkness
entry.def: To remove darkness from.

entry.ety: F. détente, fr. détendre to unbend, relax; pref. dé-L. dis- or de) + tendre to stretch. See Distend
entry.def: That which locks or unlocks a movement; a catch, pawl, or dog; especially, in clockwork, the catch which locks and unlocks the wheelwork in striking.
the easing of tensions or strained relations (especially between nations), as by agreement, negotiation, or tacit understandings.

entry.ety: L. detentio: cf. F. détention. See Detain

sn.def: The act of detaining or keeping back; a withholding.
The state of being detained (stopped or hindered); delay from necessity.
Confinement; restraint; custody.
sn.q: The archduke Philip . . . found himself in a sort of honorable detention at Henry's court.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Deterred; p. pr. & vb. n. Deterring
entry.ety: L. deterrere; de + terrere to frighten, terrify. See Terror
entry.def: To prevent by fear; hence, to hinder or prevent from action by fear of consequences, or difficulty, risk, etc.
entry.q: Potent enemies tempt and deter us from our duty.
My own face deters me from my glass.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Deterged; p. pr. & vb. n. Deterging
entry.ety: L. detergere detersum; de + tergere to rub or wipe off: cf. F. déterger
entry.def: To cleanse; to purge away, as foul or offending matter from the body, or from an ulcer.
A cleansing quality or power.

entry.ety: L. detergens -entis, p. pr. of detergere: cf. F. détergent
entry.def: Cleansing; purging.

def2.def: A substance which cleanses the skin, as water or soap; a medicine to cleanse wounds, ulcers, etc.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Deteriorated d�*tē"rĭ*�*rā`tĕd; p. pr. & vb. n. Deteriorating d�*tē"rĭ*�*rā`tĭng
entry.ety: L. deterioratus, p. p. of deteriorare to deteriorate, fr. deterior worse, prob. a comparative fr. de down, away
entry.def: To make worse; to make inferior in quality or value; to impair; as, to deteriorate the mind.
entry.q: The art of war . . . was greatly deteriorated.

entry.def: To grow worse; to be impaired in quality; to degenerate.
entry.q: Under such conditions, the mind rapidly deteriorates.

entry.def: going from better to worse.

entry.ety: LL. deterioratio: cf. F. détérioration
entry.def: The process of growing worse, or the state of having grown worse.

entry.ety: L. deterior worse. See Deteriorate
entry.def: Worse state or quality; inferiority.
entry.q: Thedeteriorityof the diet.

entry.ety: From Deter
entry.def: The act of deterring; also, that which deters.
The quality of being determinable; determinableness.

entry.ety: L. determinabilis finite. See Determine v. t.
entry.def: Capable of being determined, definitely ascertained, decided upon, or brought to a conclusion.
entry.q: Not wholly determinable from the grammatical use of the words.

entry.def: Capability of being determined; determinability.
Determinateness.

entry.ety: L. determinans, p. pr. of determinare: cf. F. déterminant
entry.def: Serving to determine or limit; determinative.

entry.note:
thus, the determinant of the nine numbers
a, b, c,
a', b', c',
a'', b'', c'',
is a b' c'' - a b'' c' + a' b'' c] - a' b c'' + a'' b' c. The determinant is written by placing the numbers from which it is formed in a square between two vertical lines. The theory of determinants forms a very important branch of modern mathematics.

sn.def: That which serves to determine; that which causes determination.

entry.sn: Math The sum of a series of products of several numbers, these products being formed according to certain specified laws;

sn.def: A mark or attribute, attached to the subject or predicate, narrowing the extent of both, but rendering them more definite and precise.

cs.cd: that in which the flowering commences with the terminal bud of a stem, which puts a limit to its growth; -- also called centrifugal inflorescence.
a problem which admits of a limited number of solutions.
those that are finite in the number of values or solutions, that is, in which the conditions of the problem or equation determine the number.

entry.ety: L. determinatus, p. p. of determinare. See Determine

sn.def: Having defined limits; not uncertain or arbitrary; fixed; established; definite.
sn.q: Quantity of words and a determinate number of feet.

sn.def: Conclusive; decisive; positive.
sn.q: The determinate counsel and foreknowledge of God.

sn.def: Determined or resolved upon.
sn.q: My determinate voyage.

sn.def: Of determined purpose; resolute.
sn.q: More determinate to do than skillful how to do.

entry.def: To bring to an end; to determine. See Determine.
entry.q: The sly, slow hours shall not determinate The dateless limit of thy dear exile.

sn.def: In a determinate manner; definitely; ascertainably.
sn.q: The principles of religion are already either determinately true or false, before you think of them.

sn.def: Resolutely; unchangeably.
sn.q: Being determinately . . . bent to marry.

entry.def: State of being determinate.

entry.ety: L. determinatio boundary, end: cf. F. détermination

sn.def: The act of determining, or the state of being determined.
Bringing to an end; termination; limit.
sn.q: A speedy determination of that war.

sn.def: Direction or tendency to a certain end; impulsion.
sn.q: Remissness can by no means consist with a constant determination of the will . . . to the greatest apparent good.

sn.def: The quality of mind which reaches definite conclusions; decision of character; resoluteness.
sn.q: He only is a well-made man who has a good determination.

sn.def: The state of decision; a judicial decision, or ending of controversy.
That which is determined upon; result of deliberation; purpose; conclusion formed; fixed resolution.
sn.q: So bloodthirsty a determination to obtain convictions.

sn.def: A flow, rush, or tendency to a particular part; as, a determination of blood to the head.

The act, process, or result of any accurate measurement, as of length, volume, weight, intensity, etc.; as, the determination of the ohm or of the wave length of light; the determination of the salt in sea water, or the oxygen in the air.

sd.def: The act of defining a concept or notion by giving its essential constituents.
The addition of a differentia to a concept or notion, thus limiting its extent; -- the opposite of generalization.

sn.def: The act of determining the relations of an object, as regards genus and species; the referring of minerals, plants, or animals, to the species to which they belong; classification; as, I am indebted to a friend for the determination of most of these shells.
sn.syn: Decision; conclusion; judgment; purpose; resolution; resolve; firmness. See Decision.

cs.cd: tables presenting the specific character of minerals, plants, etc., to assist in determining the species to which a specimen belongs.

entry.ety: Cf. F. déterminatif
entry.def: Having power to determine; limiting; shaping; directing; conclusive.
entry.q: Incidents . . . determinative of their course.

entry.def: That which serves to determine.
entry.q: Explanatory determinatives . . . were placed after words phonetically expressed, in order to serve as an aid to the reader in determining the meaning.

entry.ety: L
entry.def: One who determines.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Determined; p. pr. & vb. n. Determining
entry.ety: F. déterminer, L. determinare determinatum; de + terminare limit, terminus limit. See Term

sn.def: To fix the boundaries of; to mark off and separate.
sn.q: God] hath determined the times before appointed.

sn.def: To set bounds to; to fix the determination of; to limit; to bound; to bring to an end; to finish.
sn.q: The knowledge of men hitherto hath been determined by the view or sight.
Now, where is he that will not stay so long Till his friend sickness hath determined me?

sn.def: To fix the form or character of; to shape; to prescribe imperatively; to regulate; to settle.
sn.q: The character of the soul is determined by the character of its God.
Something divinely beautiful . . . that at some time or other might influence or even determine her course of life.

sn.def: To fix the course of; to impel and direct; -- with a remoter object preceded by to; as, another's will determined me to this course.
To ascertain definitely; to find out the specific character or name of; to assign to its true place in a system; as, to determine an unknown or a newly discovered plant or its name.
To bring to a conclusion, as a question or controversy; to settle authoritative or judicial sentence; to decide; as, the court has determined the cause.
To resolve on; to have a fixed intention of; also, to cause to come to a conclusion or decision; to lead; as, this determined him to go immediately.
To define or limit by adding a differentia.
To ascertain the presence, quantity, or amount of; as, to determine the parallax; to determine the salt in sea water.
To come to an end; to end; to terminate.
sn.q: He who has vented a pernicious doctrine or published an ill book must know that his life determine not together.
Estates may determine on future contingencies.

sn.def: To come to a decision; to decide; to resolve; -- often with on.
sn.q: Determineon some course.
He shall pay as the judges determine.

entry.def: Decided; resolute.
entry.q: Adeterminedfoe.

entry.def: In a determined manner; with determination.
One who, or that which, determines or decides.
The doctrine that the will is not free, but is inevitably and invincibly determined by motives, preceding events, and natural laws.
entry.q: Its superior suitability to produce courage, as contrasted with scientific physical determinism, is obvious.

entry.def: One who believes in determinism. Also adj.; as, determinist theories.

sn.def: of or pertaining to determinism; as, deterministic theories.
causally determined and not subject to random chance.

entry.ety: L. de + terra earth: cf. F. déterrer to unearth
entry.def: The uncovering of anything buried or covered with earth; a taking out of the earth or ground.
That which deters; a deterrent; a hindrance.

entry.ety: L. deterrens, p. pr. of deterrere. See Deter
entry.def: Serving to deter.
entry.q: Thedeterrentprinciple.

entry.def: That which deters or prevents.

entry.ety: Cf. F. détersion. See Deterge
entry.def: The act of deterging or cleansing, as a sore.

entry.ety: Cf. détersif
entry.def: Cleansing; detergent.
In a way to cleanse.
The quality of cleansing.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Detested; p. pr. & vb. n. Detesting
entry.ety: L. detestare detestatum, and detestari, to curse while calling a deity to witness, to execrate, detest; de + testari to be a witness, testify, testis a witness: cf. F. détester. See Testify

sn.def: To witness against; to denounce; to condemn.
sn.q: The heresy of Nestorius . . . was detested in the Eastern churches.
God hath detested them with his own mouth.

sn.def: To hate intensely; to abhor; to abominate; to loathe; as, we detest what is contemptible or evil.
sn.q: Who dares think one thing, and another tell, My heart detests him as the gates of hell.
sn.syn: To abhor; abominate; execrate. See Hate.

entry.def: Capacity of being odious.

entry.ety: L. detestabilis: cf. F. détestable
entry.def: Worthy of being detested; abominable; extremely hateful; very odious; deserving abhorrence; as, detestable vices.
entry.q: Thou hast defiled my sanctuary will all thy detestable things, and with all thine abominations.

entry.def: The quality or state of being detestable.
In a detestable manner.
To detest.

entry.ety: L. detestatio: cf. F. détestation
entry.def: The act of detesting; extreme hatred or dislike; abhorrence; loathing.
entry.q: We are heartily agreed in our detestation of civil war.

entry.def: One who detests.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Dethroned d�*thrōnd"; p. pr. & vb. n. Dethroning
entry.ety: Pref. de- + throne: cf. F. détrôner; pref. dé-L. dis-) + trône throne. See Throne
entry.def: To remove or drive from a throne; to depose; to divest of supreme authority and dignity.
entry.q: The Protector wasdethroned.

entry.ety: Cf. F. détrônement
entry.def: Deposal from a throne; deposition from regal power.
One who dethrones.
Dethronement.

entry.ety: Cf. LL. dethronizare
entry.def: To dethrone or unthrone.

entries.entry:
Det"i*nue
Writ of detinue Law one that lies against him who wrongfully detains goods or chattels delivered to him, or in possession, to recover the thing itself, or its value and damages, from the detainer. It is now in a great measure superseded by other remedies.
?; 277 n. OF. detinu detenu, p. p. of detenir to detain. See Detain
A person or thing detained; Law A form of action for the recovery of a personal chattel wrongfully detained.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Detonated; p. pr. & vb. n. Detonating
entry.ety: L. detonare, v. i., to thunder down; de + tonare to thunder; akin to E. thunder. See Thunder, and cf. Detonize
entry.def: To explode with a sudden report; as, niter detonates with sulphur.
To cause to explode; to cause to burn or inflame with a sudden report.

cs.cd: a mixture of two volumes of hydrogen with one volume of oxygen, which explodes with a loud report upon ignition.
any powder or solid substance, as fulminate of mercury, which when struck, explodes with violence and a loud report.
a primer exploded by a fuse; -- used to explode gun cotton in blasting operations.

a strong tube of glass, usually graduated, closed at one end, and furnished with two wires passing through its sides at opposite points, and nearly meeting, for the purpose of exploding gaseous mixtures by an electric spark, as in gas analysis, etc.

entry.def: from Detonate.

entry.ety: Cf. F. détonation
entry.def: An explosion or sudden report made by the instantaneous decomposition or combustion of unstable substances; as, the detonation of gun cotton.

entries.entry: Det"o*na`tor dĕt"�*nā`tẽr n. One that detonates; specif.: An explosive whose action is practically instantaneous. Something used to detonate a charge, as a detonating fuse. A case containing detonating powder, the explosion of which serves as a signal, as on railroads. A gun fired by a percussion cap. Obs

entry.def: The act of detonizing; detonation.

entry.ety: See Detonate
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Detonized #; p. pr. & vb. n. Detonizing
entry.def: To explode, or cause to explode; to burn with an explosion; to detonate.
Same as Detortion.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Detorted; p. pr. & vb. n. Detorting
entry.ety: L. detortus, p. p. of detorquere to turn away; de + torquere to turn about, twist: cf. F. détorquer détordre
entry.def: To turn form the original or plain meaning; to pervert; to wrest.
The act of detorting, or the state of being detorted; a twisting or warping.

entry.ety: F. détour, fr. détourner to turn aside; pref. dé-L. dis-) + tourner to turn. See Turn
entry.def: A turning; a circuitous route; a deviation from a direct course; as, the detours of the Mississippi.

sn.def: the hospital ward or clinic in which patients are detoxified; -- often used attributively.
detoxification.

entry.def: to detoxify.
to remove poison from.

sn.def: to remove poison from; to rid of the effects of poison.
to render (a poisonous substance) non-toxic or harmless.
a medically supervised treatment for addiction to drugs or alcohol intended to rid the body of the addictive substances.
treatment for poisoning by counteracting its toxic properties.
conversion (of a poisonous substance) to a non-toxic or harmless state.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Detracted; p. pr. & vb. n. Detracting
entry.ety: L. detractus, p. p. of detrahere to detract; de + trahere to draw: cf. F. détracter. See Trace

sn.def: To take away; to withdraw.
sn.q: Detract much from the view of the without.

sn.def: To take credit or reputation from; to defame.
sn.q: That calumnious critic . . . Detracting what laboriously we do.
sn.syn: To derogate; decry; disparage; depreciate; asperse; vilify; defame; traduce. See Decry.

entry.def: To take away a part or something, especially from one's credit; to lessen reputation; to derogate; to defame; -- often with from.
entry.q: It has been the fashion to detract both from the moral and literary character of Cicero.

entry.def: One who detracts; a detractor.
entry.q: Other detracters and malicious writers.

entry.def: In a detracting manner.

entry.ety: F. détraction, L. detractio

sn.def: A taking away or withdrawing.
sn.q: The detraction of the eggs of the said wild fowl.

sn.def: The act of taking away from the reputation or good name of another; a lessening or cheapening in the estimation of others; the act of depreciating another, from envy or malice; calumny.
sn.syn: Depreciation; disparagement; derogation; slander; calumny; aspersion; censure.

entry.def: Containing detraction; detractory.

sn.def: Tending to detractor draw.
Tending to lower in estimation; depreciative.

entry.def: The quality of being detractive.

entry.ety: L.: cf. F. détracteur
entry.def: One who detracts; a derogator; a defamer.
entry.q: His detractors were noisy and scurrilous.

entry.def: Defamatory by denial of desert; derogatory; calumnious.
A female detractor.
To alight, or to cause to alight, from a railway train.

entry.ety: L. detrectare; de + tractare, intens. of trahere to draw
entry.def: To refuse; to decline.
entry.q: Todetrectthe battle.

entry.def: same as detribalization.
the act of causing tribal people to abandon their customs and adopt urban ways of living.
to cause (members of a tribe) to lose their cultural identity and adopt other customs.

entry.ety: L. detrimentum, fr. deterere detritum, to rub or wear away; de + terere to rub: cf. F. détriment. See Trite

sn.def: That which injures or causes damage; mischief; harm; diminution; loss; damage; -- used very generically; as, detriments to property, religion, morals, etc.
sn.q: I can repair That detriment, if such it be.

sn.def: A charge made to students and barristers for incidental repairs of the rooms they occupy.
sn.syn: Injury; loss; damage; disadvantage; prejudice; hurt; mischief; harm.

entry.def: To do injury to; to hurt.
entry.q: Other might be determined thereby.

entry.def: Causing detriment; injurious; hurtful.
entry.q: Neither dangerous nor detrimental to the donor.
entry.syn: Injurious; hurtful; prejudicial; disadvantageous; mischievous; pernicious.

entry.def: The quality of being detrimental; injuriousness.
Pertaining to, or composed of, detritus.

entry.ety: L. detritus, p. p
entry.def: Worn out.

entry.ety: LL. detritio. See Detriment
entry.def: A wearing off or away.
entry.q: Phonograms which by process long-continued detrition have reached a step of extreme simplicity.

entry.note: ☞ For large portions, the word débris is used.
entry.ety: F. détritus, fr. L. detritus, p. p. of deterere. See Detriment

sn.def: A mass of substances worn off from solid bodies by attrition, and reduced to small portions; as, diluvial detritus .
Hence: Any fragments separated from the body to which they belonged; any product of disintegration.
sn.q: The mass of detritus of which modern languages are composed.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Detruded; p. pr. & vb. n. Detruding
entry.ety: L. detrudere detrusum; de + trudere to thrust, push
entry.def: To thrust down or out; to push down with force.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Detruncated; p. pr. & vb. n. Detruncating
entry.ety: L. detruncatus, p. p. of detruncare to cut off; de + truncare to maim, shorten, cut off. See Truncate
entry.def: To shorten by cutting; to cut off; to lop off.

entry.ety: L. detruncatio: cf. F. détroncation
entry.def: The act of lopping or cutting off, as the head from the body.

entry.ety: L. detrusio. See Detrude
entry.def: The act of thrusting or driving down or outward; outward thrust.
Debt.
Free from debt.

entry.ety: L. detumescere to cease swelling; de + tumescere tumere, to swell
entry.def: Diminution of swelling; subsidence of anything swollen.

entry.ety: L. detur let it be given
entry.def: A present of books given to a meritorious undergraduate student as a prize.

entry.ety: L. deturbare
entry.def: To throw down.

entry.ety: LL. deturbatus, p. p. of deturbare, fr. L. deturbare to thrust down
entry.def: To evict; to remove.
The act of deturbating.

entry.ety: Pref. de- + turn. Cf. Detour
entry.def: To turn away.

entry.ety: L. deturpare; de + turpare to make ugly, defile, turpis ugly, foul
entry.def: To defile; to disfigure.
A making foul.

entry.ety: F. deux two, OF. deus, fr. L. duo. See Two

sn.def: Two; a card or a die with two spots; as, the deuce of hearts.

A condition of the score beginning whenever each side has won three strokes in the same game (also reckoned “40 all”), and reverted to as often as a tie is made until one of the sides secures two successive strokes following a tie or deuce, which decides the game.

entry.ety: Cf. LL. dusius, Armor, dus teûz, phantom, specter; Gael. taibhs taibhse, apparition, ghost; or fr. OF. deus God, fr. L. deuscf. Deity)
entry.def: The devil; a demon.
Devilish; excessive; extreme.

entry.mhw: Deuse dūs n.; Deu"sed dū"sĕd a.
entry.def: See Deuce Deuced.

entry.ety: Gr. � second + E. canonical
entry.def: Pertaining to a second canon, or ecclesiastical writing of inferior authority; -- said of the Apocrypha, certain Epistles, etc.

entry.ety: See Deuterogamy
entry.def: One who marries the second time.

entry.ety: Gr. �; � second + � wedding, marriage
entry.def: A second marriage, after the death of the first husband of wife; -- in distinction from bigamy, as defined in the old canon law. See Bigamy.

entry.ety: Gr. � second + root of � to be born
entry.def: Of secondary origin; -- said of certain rocks whose material has been derived from older rocks.
The writer of Deuteronomy.

entry.ety: Gr. �; � second + � law: cf. L. Deuteronomium
entry.def: The fifth book of the Pentateuch, containing the second giving of the law by Moses.

entry.ety: NL. deuteropathia, fr. Gr. � second + � suffering, fr. �, �, to suffer: cf. F. deutéropathie
entry.def: A sympathetic affection of any part of the body, as headache from an overloaded stomach.
Pertaining to deuteropathy; of the nature of deuteropathy.

entry.ety: Gr. � second + -scopy

sn.def: Second sight.
sn.q: I felt by anticipation the horrors of the Highland seers, whom their gift of deuteroscopy compels to witness things unmeet for mortal eye.

sn.def: That which is seen at a second view; a meaning beyond the literal sense; the second intention; a hidden signification.

entry.ety: Gr. � second + E. zooid
entry.def: One of the secondary, and usually sexual, zooids produced by budding or fission from the primary zooids, in animals having alternate generations. In the tapeworms, the joints are deuterozooids.
Same as Deutohydroguret.

entry.ety: Contr. from Gr. dey`teros second
entry.def: A prefix which formerly properly indicated the second in a regular series of compound in the series, and not to its composition, but which is now generally employed in the same sense as bi- or di-, although little used.

entry.ety: Pref. deut- deuto- + hydroguret
entry.def: A compound containing in the molecule two atoms of hydrogen united with some other element or radical.

entry.ety: Pref. deuto- + Gr. � form
entry.def: The lifeless food matter in the cytoplasm of an ovum or a cell, as distinguished from the active or true protoplasm; yolk substance; yolk.

entry.ety: Pref. deuto- + Gr. � plastic
entry.def: Pertaining to, or composed of, deutoplasm.

entry.ety: Pref. deuto- + sulphuret
entry.def: A disulphide.

entry.ety: Pref. deut- + oxide
entry.def: A compound containing in the molecule two atoms of oxygen united with some other element or radical; -- usually called dioxide, or less frequently, binoxide.

entries.entry: Deut"zi*a‖n. NL. Named after Jan Deutz of Holland Bot A genus of shrubs with pretty white flowers, much cultivated.

entry.ety: Skr. d�va. Cf. Deity
entry.def: A god; a deity; a divine being; an idol; a king.

entry.ety: Skr. dēvanāgarī; dēva god + nagara city, i. e., divine city
entry.def: The script or characters in which Sanskrit and Hindi are written.
The change of vapor into water, as in the formation of rain.

entry.ety: Cf. F. dévaster. See Devastate
entry.def: To devastate.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Devastated; p. pr. & vb. n. Devastating
entry.ety: L. devastatus, p. p. of devastare to devastate; de + vastare to lay waste, vastus waste. See Vast
entry.def: To lay waste; to ravage; to desolate.
entry.q: Whole countries . . . were devastated.
entry.syn: To waste; ravage; desolate; destroy; demolish; plunder; pillage.

entry.def: same as desolated.
entry.syn: blasted, desolate, desolated, ravaged, ruined, wasted.

sn.def: highly critical; making light of; as, a devastating portrait of human folly.
causing or capable of causing complete destruction; as, a devastating hurricane.

entry.ety: Cf. F. dévastation

sn.def: The act of devastating, or the state of being devastated; a laying waste.
sn.q: Even now the devastation is begun, And half the business of destruction done.

sn.def: Waste of the goods of the deceased by an executor or administrator.
sn.syn: Desolation; ravage; waste; havoc; destruction; ruin; overthrow.

entry.ety: L
entry.def: One who, or that which, devastates.

entry.ety: L., he has wasted
entry.def: Waste or misapplication of the assets of a deceased person by an executor or an administrator.

entry.ety: Hind., fr. Skr. d�va god
entry.def: A deity; a divine being; a good spirit; an idol.

entry.ety: See Deaf
entry.def: Deaf.
The European swift.

cs.col: To develop a curved surface on a plane
cs.cd: to produce on the plane an equivalent surface, as if by rolling the curved surface so that all parts shall successively touch the plane.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Developed; p. pr. & vb. n. Developing
entry.ety: F. déveloper; dé-L. dis-) + OF. voluper voleper, to envelop, perh. from L. volup agreeably, delightfully, and hence orig., to make agreeable or comfortable by enveloping, to keep snug (cf. Voluptuous); or. perh. fr. a derivative of volvere volutum, to roll (cf. Devolve). Cf. Envelop

sn.def: To free from that which infolds or envelops; to unfold; to lay open by degrees or in detail; to make visible or known; to disclose; to produce or give forth; as, to develop theories; a motor that develops 100 horse power.
sn.q: These serve to develop its tenets.
The 20th was spent in strengthening our position and developing the line of the enemy.

sn.def: To unfold gradually, as a flower from a bud; hence, to bring through a succession of states or stages, each of which is preparatory to the next; to form or expand by a process of growth; to cause to change gradually from an embryo, or a lower state, to a higher state or form of being; as, sunshine and rain develop the bud into a flower; to develop the mind.
sn.q: The sound developed itself into a real compound.
All insects . . . acquire the jointed legs before the wings are fully developed.

sn.def: To advance; to further; to prefect; to make to increase; to promote the growth of.
sn.q: We must develop our own resources to the utmost.

sn.def: To change the form of, as of an algebraic expression, by executing certain indicated operations without changing the value.
To cause to become visible, as an invisible or latent image upon plate, by submitting it to chemical agents; to bring to view.
sn.syn: To uncover; unfold; evolve; promote; project; lay open; disclose; exhibit; unravel; disentangle.

sn.def: To go through a process of natural evolution or growth, by successive changes from a less perfect to a more perfect or more highly organized state; to advance from a simpler form of existence to one more complex either in structure or function; as, a blossom develops from a bud; the seed develops into a plant; the embryo develops into a well-formed animal; the mind develops year by year.
sn.q: Nor poets enough to understand That life develops from within.

sn.def: To become apparent gradually; as, a picture on sensitive paper develops on the application of heat; the plans of the conspirators develop.

cs.cd: a surface described by a moving right line, and such that consecutive positions of the generator intersect each other. Hence, the surface can be developed into a plane.

entry.def: Capable of being developed.

entry.sn: being changed over time so as to be e.g. stronger or more complete or more useful; as, the developed qualities of the Hellenic outlook; the state's well-developed industries. Oppositre of undeveloped.Narrower terms: formulated; mature

sn.def: made more useful and profitable as by building or laying out roads; -- of real estate.
sn.illu: new houses are springing up on the developed tract of land near the river

sn.def: not industrialized but undergoing industrialization; -- sometimes used as a euphemism for "undeveloped"; -- of nations.
becoming or arising; as, the rushing yellow of the developing day.

entry.def: the process of treating a photosensitive material with chemicals in order to make a latent image visible.

entry.note: By the action of the developer, the latent image on a photographic plate or film, not perceptible to the eye after exposure in the camera, is developed and becomes visible.

sn.def: One who, or that which, develops.
A chemical bath or reagent used in developing photographs.
A reagent used to produce an ingrain color by its action upon some substance on the fiber.
a corporation or individual who finances or organizes a real estate development{5}.

cs.cd: the doctrine that animals and plants possess the power of passing by slow and successive stages from a lower to a higher state of organization, and that all the higher forms of life now in existence were thus developed by uniform laws from lower forms, and are not the result of special creative acts. See the Note under Darwinian.

entry.ety: Cf. F. développement

sn.def: The act of developing or disclosing that which is unknown; a gradual unfolding process by which anything is developed, as a plan or method, or an image upon a photographic plate; gradual advancement or growth through a series of progressive changes; also, the result of developing, or a developed state.
sn.q: A new development of imagination, taste, and poetry.

sn.def: The series of changes which animal and vegetable organisms undergo in their passage from the embryonic state to maturity, from a lower to a higher state of organization.

sd.def: The act or process of changing or expanding an expression into another of equivalent value or meaning.
The equivalent expression into which another has been developed.

sn.def: The elaboration of a theme or subject; the unfolding of a musical idea; the evolution of a whole piece or movement from a leading theme or motive.

A tract of land on which a number of buildings have been constructed; -- especially used for tract on which from two to hundreds of houses have been constructed by a commercial developer{4} for sale to individuals.
sn.syn: Unfolding; disclosure; unraveling; evolution; elaboration; growth.

entry.def: Pertaining to, or characteristic of, the process of development; as, the developmental power of a germ.

entry.ety: L. devenustatus, p. p. of devenustare to disfigure; de + venustus lovely, graceful
entry.def: To deprive of beauty or grace.
See Divergence.

entry.note: ☞ This word is now generally written divest, except in the legal sense.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Devested; p. pr. & vb. n. Devesting
entry.ety: L. devestire to undress; de + vestire to dress: cf. OF. devestir, F. dévêtir. Cf. Divest

sn.def: To divest; to undress.
To take away, as an authority, title, etc., to deprive; to alienate, as an estate.

entry.def: To be taken away, lost, or alienated, as a title or an estate.

entry.ety: L. devexus, from devehere to carry down
entry.def: Bending down; sloping.
Devexity.

entry.ety: L. devexitas, fr. devexus. See Devex a.
entry.def: A bending downward; a sloping; incurvation downward; declivity.
; fem. of Deva. A goddess.

sn.def: an aberrant state or condition.
deviate behavior.
Deviating.
having behavior or characteristics differing from that which is normal or expected, especially in an undesirable or socially disapproved manner; as, deviant behavior.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Deviated; p. pr. & vb. n. Deviating
entry.ety: L. deviare to deviate; de + viare to go, travel, via way. See Viaduct
entry.def: To go out of the way; to turn aside from a course or a method; to stray or go astray; to err; to digress; to diverge; to vary.
entry.q: Thus Pegasus, a nearer way to take, May boldly deviate from the common track.
entry.syn: To swerve; stray; wander; digress; depart; deflect; err.

entry.def: To cause to deviate.
entry.q: To deviate a needle.

entry.def: having behavior differing from that which is normal or expected, especially in an undesirable or socially disapproved manner; as, deviate behavior.
a person having behavior differing from that which is normal or socially acceptable; -- used especially to characterize persons whose sexual behavior is considered morally unacceptable.

cs.cd: that deviation from a strictly vertical line of descent which occurs in a body falling freely, in consequence of the rotation of the earth.
the angle which the needle of a ship's compass makes with the magnetic meridian by reason of the magnetism of the iron parts of the ship.
cs.col: Deviation of the line of the vertical
cs.cd: the difference between the actual direction of a plumb line and the direction it would have if the earth were a perfect ellipsoid and homogeneous, -- caused by the attraction of a mountain, or irregularities in the earth's density.

entry.ety: LL. deviatio: cf. F. déviation

sn.def: The act of deviating; a wandering from the way; variation from the common way, from an established rule, etc.; departure, as from the right course or the path of duty.
The state or result of having deviated; a transgression; an act of sin; an error; an offense.
The voluntary and unnecessary departure of a ship from, or delay in, the regular and usual course of the specific voyage insured, thus releasing the underwriters from their responsibility.
the difference between an expected value of an observation or measurement and the actual value.

entry.ety: L., a forsaker
entry.def: One who, or that which, deviates.
Tending to deviate; devious; as, deviatory motion.

entry.usage: Device Contrivance. Device implies more of inventive power, and contrivance more of skill and dexterity in execution. A device usually has reference to something worked out for exhibition or show; a contrivance usually respects the arrangement or disposition of things with reference to securing some end. Devices were worn by knights-errant on their shields; contrivances are generally used to promote the practical convenience of life. The word device is often used in a bad sense; as, a crafty device ; contrivance is almost always used in a good sense; as, a useful contrivance .
entry.ety: OE. devis devise, will, intention, opinion, invention, fr. F. devis architect's plan and estimates (in OF., division, plan, wish), devise device (in sense 3), in OF. also, division, wish, last will, fr. deviser. See Devise v. t., and cf. Devise n.

sn.def: That which is devised, or formed by design; a contrivance; an invention; a project; a scheme; often, a scheme to deceive; a stratagem; an artifice.
sn.q: His device in against Babylon, to destroy it.
Their recent device of demanding benevolences.
He disappointeth the devices of the crafty.

sn.def: Power of devising; invention; contrivance.
sn.q: I must have instruments of my own device.

sd.def: An emblematic design, generally consisting of one or more figures with a motto, used apart from heraldic bearings to denote the historical situation, the ambition, or the desire of the person adopting it. See Cognizance.
Improperly, an heraldic bearing.
sd.q: Knights-errant used to distinguish themselves by devices on their shields.
A banner with this strange device - Excelsior.

sn.def: Anything fancifully conceived.
A spectacle or show.
Opinion; decision.
any artifactual object designed to perform an action or process, with or without an operator in attendance.
sn.syn: Contrivance; invention; design; scheme; project; stratagem; shift.

entry.def: Full of devices; inventive.
entry.q: A carpet, rich, and of deviceful thread.

entry.def: In a deviceful manner.

entry.cs:
Blue devils. See under Blue. Cartesian devil. See under Cartesian. Devil bird Zoöl one of two or more South African drongo shrikes (Edolius retifer, and Edolius remifer), believed by the natives to be connected with sorcery. Devil may care reckless, defiant of authority; -- used adjectively. Longfellow. Devil's apron Bot the large kelp (Laminaria saccharina, and Laminaria longicruris) of the Atlantic ocean, having a blackish, leathery expansion, shaped somewhat like an apron. Devil's coachhorse. Zoöl The black rove beetle (Ocypus olens). Eng A large, predacious, hemipterous insect (Prionotus cristatus); the wheel bug. U.S Devil's darning-needle. Zoöl See under Darn v. t.
Devil's fingers Devil's hand
Zoöl the common British starfish (Asterias rubens); -- also applied to a sponge with stout branches. Prov. Eng., Irish & Scot Devil's riding-horse Zoöl the American mantis (Mantis Carolina). The Devil's tattoo a drumming with the fingers or feet. “Jack played the Devil's tattoo on the door with his boot heels.” F. Hardman (Blackw. Mag.). Devil worship worship of the power of evil; -- still practiced by barbarians who believe that the good and evil forces of nature are of equal power. Printer's devil the youngest apprentice in a printing office, who runs on errands, does dirty work (as washing the ink rollers and sweeping), etc. “Without fearing the printer's devil or the sheriff's officer.” Macaulay. Tasmanian devil Zoöl a very savage carnivorous marsupial of Tasmania (Dasyurus ursinus syn. Diabolus ursinus). To play devil with to molest extremely; to ruin. Low
entry.ety: AS. deófol deóful; akin to G. �eufel, Goth. diabaúlus; all fr. L. diabolus the devil, Gr. � the devil, the slanderer, fr. � to slander, calumniate, orig., to throw across; � across + � to throw, let fall, fall; cf. Skr. gal to fall. Cf. Diabolic

sn.def: The Evil One; Satan, represented as the tempter and spiritual of mankind.
sn.q: Jesus] being forty days tempted of the devil.
That old serpent, called the Devil, and Satan, which deceiveth the whole world.

entry.ety: L. devitare to avoid; de + vitare to shun, avoid

The act or process of devitrifying, or the state of being devitrified. Specifically, the conversion of molten glassy matter into a stony mass by slow cooling, the result being the formation of crystallites, microbites, etc., in the glassy base, which are then called devitrification products.
To deprive of glasslike character; to take away vitreous luster and transparency from.
To make toneless; to deprive of vowel quality.
entry.q: If we take a high vowel, such as (i) [= nearly i of bit], and devocalize it, we obtain a hiss which is quite distinct enough to stand for a weak (jh).

entry.ety: L. devocare to call off or away; de + vocare to call

entry.ety: F., fr. L. debere to owe. See Due
entry.def: Duty; service owed; hence, due act of civility or respect; -- now usually in the plural; as, they paid their devoirs to the ladies.

sn.def: To transfer from one person to another; to deliver over; to hand down; -- generally with upon, sometimes with to or into.

entry.def: To pass by transmission or succession; to be handed over or down; -- generally with on or upon, sometimes with to or into; as, after the general fell, the command devolved upon (or on) the next officer in rank.
entry.q: His estate . . . devolved to Lord Somerville.

entry.def: The act or process of devolving;; devolution.

One of a breed of hardy cattle originating in the country of Devon, England. Those of pure blood have a deep red color. The small, longhorned variety, called North Devons, is distinguished by the superiority of its working oxen.

cs.cd: the age next older than the Carboniferous and later than the Silurian; -- called also the Age of fishes. The various strata of this age compose the Devonian formation or system, and include the old red sandstone of Great Britain. They contain, besides plants and numerous invertebrates, the bony portions of many large and remarkable fishes of extinct groups. See the Diagram under Geology.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to Devon or Devonshire in England; as, the Devonian rocks, period, or system.
The Devonian age or formation.

entry.ety: L. devoratio. See Devour

sn.def: To appropriate by vow; to set apart or dedicate by a solemn act; to consecrate; also, to consign over; to doom; to evil; to devote one to destruction; the city was devoted to the flames.

entries.entry: Dew"ar dū"ẽr Dew"ar ves`sel Dew"ar flask . After Sir James Dewar, British physicist A double-walled glass vessel for holding liquid air, liquid nitrogen, etc., having the space between the walls exhausted so as to prevent conduction of heat, and sometimes having the glass silvered to prevent absorption of radiant heat; -- called also, according to the particular shape, Dewar bulb Dewar tube, etc.

Skillful in contrivance; quick at inventing expedients; expert; as, a dexterous manager.
sn.q: Dexterous the craving, fawning crowd to quit.

sn.def: Done with dexterity; skillful; artful; as, dexterous management.
sn.q: Dexteroussleights of hand.
sn.syn: Adroit; active; expert; skillful; clever; able; ready; apt; handy; versed.

entry.def: In a dexterous manner; skillfully.
The quality of being dexterous; dexterity.

entry.ety: L. dextra the right hand + ad to
entry.def: Toward the right side; dextrally.

cs.cd: a spiral shell the whorls of which turn from left right, or like the hands of a watch when the apex of the spire is toward the eye of the observer.

entry.ety: From Dexter
entry.def: Right, as opposed to sinistral, or left.
The state of being on the right-hand side; also, the quality of being right-handed; right-handedness.
Towards the right; as, the hands of a watch rotate dextrally .
A war horse; a destrer.
entry.q: By him baiteth hisdextrer.

entry.ety: Cf. F. dextrine, G. dextrin. See Dexter
entry.def: A translucent, gummy, amorphous substance, nearly tasteless and odorless, used as a substitute for gum, for sizing, etc., and obtained from starch by the action of heat, acids, or diastase. It is of somewhat variable composition, containing several carbohydrates which change easily to their respective varieties of sugar. It is so named from its rotating the plane of polarization to the right; -- called also British gum Alsace gum gommelin leiocome, etc. See Achroödextrin, and Erythrodextrin.

entries.entry: Dex"tro-. A prefix, from L. dexter, meaning, pertaining to, or toward, the right ; Chem. & Opt having the property of turning the plane of polarized light to the right; as, dextrotartaric acid.

entry.def: See Dextrogyrate.

entry.ety: Dextro- + glucose
entry.def: Same as Dextrose.

entry.ety: Dextro- + gyrate
entry.def: Same as Dextrorotatory.

cs.cd: a sirupy substance obtained by the partial oxidation of various carbohydrates, as dextrose, etc.

entry.def: Pertaining to, or derived from, dextrose; as, dextronic acid.
See Dextrotatory.

entry.ety: Dextro- + rotatory
entry.def: Turning, or causing to turn, toward the right hand; esp., turning the plane of polarization of luminous rays toward the right hand; as, dextrorotatory crystals, sugars, etc. Cf. Levorotatory.

entry.note: ☞ At present scientists predicate dextrorse or sinistrorse quality of the plant regarded objectively; formerly the plant was regarded subjectively, and what is now called dextrorse was then considered sinistrorse.
entry.ety: L. dextrorsum, contr. fr. dextrovorsum dextroversum, toward the right side; dexter right + versus vorsus, p. p. of vertere vortere, to turn
entry.def: Turning from the left to the right, in the ascending line, as in the spiral inclination of the stem of the common morning-glory; as, dextrorse vines.

entry.note: ☞ The solid products are known to the trade as grape sugar; the sirupy products as glucose, or mixing sirup. These are harmless, but are only about half as sweet as cane sugar or sucrose.
entry.ety: See Dexter
entry.def: A sirupy, or white crystalline, variety of sugar, C6H12O6so called from turning the plane of polarization to the right), occurring in many ripe fruits, and also called glucose. Dextrose and levulose are obtained by the inversion of cane sugar or sucrose, and hence the mixture is called called invert sugar. Dextrose is chiefly obtained by the action of heat and acids on starch, and hence called also starch sugar. It is also formed from starchy food by the action of the amylolytic ferments of saliva and pancreatic juice.
Same as Dexterous Dexterously, etc.

entry.ety: See Dairy
entry.def: A servant who has charge of the dairy; a dairymaid.

entries.entry:
Dey n.; pl.Deys #. Turk. dāi, orig., a maternal uncle, then a friendly title formerly given to middle-aged or old people, especially among the Janizaries; and hence, in Algiers, consecrated at length to the commanding officer of that corps, who frequently became afterward pasha or regent of that province; hence the European misnomer of dey, as applied to the latter: cf. F. dey
The governor of Algiers; -- so called before the French conquest in 1830.

entry.def: To die.
See Dainty.
The act or process of freeing from zinc; also, the condition resulting from the removal of zinc.

entry.ety: Pref. de- + zinc + -fy
entry.def: To deprive of, or free from, zinc.
the basic principles of the cosmos; also: an ancient sage in Hindu mythology worshipped as a god by some lower castes;.
a mountain in Nepal, 26,810 feet high.
A fierce, wild dog (Canis Dukhunensis), found in the mountains of India. It is remarkable for its propensity to hunt the tiger and other wild animals in packs.
A Ceylonese boat. See Doni.
Indian millet. See Durra.

entry.ety: Ar. dāo?
entry.def: A coasting vessel of Arabia, East Africa, and the Indian Ocean. It has generally but one mast and a lateen sail.

entries.entry:
Di-. Gr. di`s- twice; akin to � two, L. bis twice. See Two, and cf. Bi- Dia-. The L. pref. dis- sometimes assumes the form di-. See Dis-
A prefix, signifying twofold double twice ; Chem denoting two atoms, radicals, groups, or equivalents, as the case may be. See Bi-, 2.

Di"a- Di- . Gr. dia` through; orig., dividing into two parts; akin to � two. See Two, and cf. 1st Di-
A prefix denoting through; also, between apart asunder across. Before a vowel dia- becomes di-; as, diactinic; dielectric, etc.

entry.ety: F. diabase, fr. Gr. � a crossing or passing over, fr. �; � + � to go; -- so called by Brongniart, because it passes over to diorite
entry.def: A basic, dark-colored, holocrystalline, igneous rock, consisting essentially of a triclinic feldspar and pyroxene with magnetic iron; -- often limited to rocks pretertiary in age. It includes part of what was early called greenstone.

entry.ety: Gr. � � (sc. �) offerings before crossing the border, fr. � to pass over. See Diabase
entry.def: Passing over the borders.
involving a transfer of heat.

entry.note: ☞ The two major subtypes recognized are diabetes insipidus and diabetes mellitus. In diabetes insipidus there is excretion of large amounts of urine of relatively low density, accompanied by extreme thirst, but the urine contains no abnormal constituent. The more serious form diabetes mellitusfrom Latin mellitus, sweetened with honey) is a metabolic disease in which the utilization of carbohydrate is reduced and that of lipids and proteins is increased. This form is caused by a deficiency in insulin (which is mostly formed in the pancreas), and may be accompanied by glucosuria, hyperglycemia, elecrolyte loss, ketoacidosis, and sometimes coma. It has severe long-term effects, including damage to the nerves, the retina, and the kidney, and degeneration of blood vessels which may lead to poor circulation, especially in the limbs, subsequent infection, and eventual loss of limbs. Diabetes mellitus itself has recognized variants, being divided into insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus and non-insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus. Non-insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus is also called adult-onset diabetesabbreviated NIDDM), and is the less severe form of diabetes mellitus, occurring mostly in obese individuals over the age of 35. It may be treated by diet and oral hypoglycemic agents, though occasionally serious degenerative effects may develop. Insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus (abbreviated IDDM), also called type I diabetes, is a severe form of the disease, usually starting when the affected person is young (hence also called juvenile-onset diabetes). In addition to the increased urine (polyuria) common to all forms of diabetes, this form is characterized by low levels of insulin in the blood, ketoacidosis, increased appetite, and increased fluid intake, and may lead to weight loss and eventually the severe degenerative effects mentioned above. Treatment requires administration of insulin and careful regulation of the diet.

cs.cd: that form of diabetes in which the urine contains saccharine matter.
the form of diabetes in which the urine contains no abnormal constituent.

entry.ety: NL., from Gr. �, fr. � to pass or cross over. See Diabase
entry.def: Any of several diseases which is attended with a persistent, excessive discharge of urine; when used without qualification, the term usually refers to diabetes mellitus. The most common form is diabetes mellitus, in which the urine is not only increased in quantity, but contains saccharine matter, and the condition if untreated is generally fatal.

entry.cs: Diabetic sugar. Chem Same as Dextrose.
entry.def: Pertaining to diabetes; as, diabetic or diabetical treatment.

entry.ety: F. diablerie, fr. diable devil, L. diabolus. See Devil
entry.def: Devilry; sorcery or incantation; a diabolical deed; mischief.

entry.ety: L. diabolicus, Gr. � devilish, slanderous: cf. F. diabolique. See Devil

sn.def: Pertaining to the devil; resembling, or appropriate, or appropriate to, the devil; befitting hell or satan; devilish; infernal; impious; as, a diabolic or diabolical temper or act; the diabolical expression on his face; fires lit up a diabolic scene.
sn.q: Diabolicpower.
Thediabolicalinstitution.

sn.def: showing a wicked cunning or ingenuity; as, the cold calculation and diabolic art of some statesmen.
extremely evil or cruel; atrocious; outrageously wicked; as, diabolical sorcerers under the influence of devils; diabolical torturers taking pleasure in their craft.
sn.syn: demonic, fiendish, hellish, infernal, nefarious, satanic.

entry.ety: L. diabolus devil + -fy
entry.def: To ascribed diabolical qualities to; to change into, or to represent as, a devil.

sn.def: Character, action, or principles appropriate to the devil.
Possession by the devil.

entry.def: To render diabolical.

An old game or sport (revived under this name) consisting in whirling on a string, fastened to two sticks, a small somewhat spool-shaped object (called the diabolo) so as to balance it on a string, toss it in the air and catch it, etc.

entry.ety: Pref. dia- + catholicon

entry.ety: Pref. dia- + caustic
entry.def: Pertaining to, or possessing the properties of, a species of caustic curves formed by refraction. See Caustic surface, under Caustic.

sn.def: That which burns by refraction, as a double convex lens, or the sun's rays concentrated by such a lens, sometimes used as a cautery.
A curved formed by the consecutive intersections of rays of light refracted through a lens.

entry.ety: NL. diachylum, fr. Gr. � very juicy; dia` thoroughly + � juice

entry.ety: Pref. di- + acid

entry.ety: L., from Gr. � � from poppy heads; dia` through, from + � head, a poppy head

entry.ety: L., fr. Gr. � a cutting in two; dia` through + �

entry.ety: Cf. F. diacoustique
entry.def: That branch of natural philosophy which treats of the properties of sound as affected by passing through different mediums; -- called also diaphonics. See the Note under Acoustics.

entry.ety: Gr. �, fr. � to separate, distinguish; dia` through + � to separate. See Critic
entry.def: That separates or distinguishes; -- applied to points or marks used to distinguish letters of similar form, or different sounds of the same letter, as, ā, ă, ä, ō, ŏ, etc.
entry.q: Diacriticalpoints.
A glance at this typography will reveal great difficulties, which diacritical marks necessarily throw in the way of both printer and writer.

entry.ety: Pref. di- + actinic
entry.def: Capable of transmitting the chemical or actinic rays of light; as, diactinic media.

entries.entry: Di`a*del"phi*a‖n. pl. NL., fr. Gr. di- = di`s- twice + � brother Bot A Linnæan class of plants whose stamens are united into two bodies or bundles by their filaments.

entry.ety: Cf. F. diadelphe
entry.def: Of or pertaining to the class Diadelphia; having the stamens united into two bodies by their filaments (said of a plant or flower); grouped into two bundles or sets by coalescence of the filaments (said of stamens).

entry.cs: Diadem lemur. Zoöl See Indri. Diadem spider Zoöl the garden spider.
entry.ety: F. diadème, L. diadema, fr. Gr. �, fr. � to bind round; dia` through, across + � to bind; cf. Skr. dā to bind

sn.def: Originally, an ornamental head band or fillet, worn by Eastern monarchs as a badge of royalty; hence (later), also, a crown, in general.
sn.q: The regaldiadem.

sn.def: Regal power; sovereignty; empire; -- considered as symbolized by the crown.
An arch rising from the rim of a crown (rarely also of a coronet), and uniting with others over its center.

entry.def: To adorn with a diadem; to crown.
entry.q: Not so, when diadem'd with rays divine.
To terminate the evil, To diadem the right.

entry.ety: Gr. � a running through; dia` through + �, used as inf. aor. of � to run
entry.def: A complete course or vibration; time of vibration, as of a pendulum.

entries.entry:
Di*ær"e*sis Di*er"e*sis
?; 277 n.; pl.DiæresesorDiereses #. L. diaeresis, Gr. �, fr. � to divide; dia` through, asunder + � to take. See Heresy

entry.ety: Gr. � dividing
entry.def: Caustic.

entry.ety: Gr. dia` through, at variance + � earth + � turning

The tendency of organs (as roots) of plants to assume a position oblique or transverse to a direction towards the center of the earth.

entry.ety: Gr. � to engrave; dia` through + � to carve
entry.def: An intaglio.
Represented or formed by depressions in the general surface; as, diaglyphic sculpture or engraving; -- opposed to anaglyphic.
To ascertain by diagnosis; to diagnosticate. See Diagnosticate.
the act or process of identifying the nature or cause of some phenomenon.

entries.entry:
Di`ag*no"sis
Differential diagnosis Med the determination of the distinguishing characteristics as between two similar diseases or conditions.
n.; pl.Diagnoses #. NL., fr. Gr. �, fr. � to distinguish; dia` through, asunder + � to know. See Know
Med The art or act of recognizing the presence of disease from its signs or symptoms, and deciding as to its character; also, the decision arrived at.
Hence, the act or process of identifying the nature or cause of some phenomenon, especially the abnormal behavior of an animal or artifactual device; as, diagnosis of a vibration in an automobile; diagnosis of the failure of a sales campaign; diagnosis of a computer malfunction.
Scientific determination of any kind; the concise description of characterization of a species.
Critical perception or scrutiny; judgment based on such scrutiny; esp., perception of, or judgment concerning, motives and character. The quick eye for effects, the clear diagnosis of men's minds, and the love of epigram. My diagnosis of his character proved correct.

entry.ety: Gr. � able to distinguish, fr. �: cf. F. diagnostique
entry.def: Pertaining to, or furnishing, a diagnosis; indicating the nature of a disease.
The mark or symptom by which one disease is known or distinguished from others.

entry.ety: From Diagnostic
entry.def: To make a diagnosis of; to recognize by its symptoms, as a disease.
That part of medicine which has to do with ascertaining the nature of diseases by means of their symptoms or signs.
entry.q: His rare skill in diagnostics.

entry.ety: Gr. � to transmit + -meter
entry.def: A sort of electroscope, invented by Rousseau, in which the dry pile is employed to measure the amount of electricity transmitted by different bodies, or to determine their conducting power.

entry.cs:
Diagonal bond Masonry herringbone work. See Herringbone a.
Diagonal built Shipbuilding built by forming the outer skin of two layers of planking, making angles of about 45° with the keel, in opposite directions. Diagonal cleavage. See under Cleavage. Diagonal molding Arch a chevron or zigzag molding. Diagonal rib. Arch See Cross-springer. Diagonal scale a scale which consists of a set of parallel lines, with other lines crossing them obliquely, so that their intersections furnish smaller subdivisions of the unit of measure than could be conveniently marked on a plain scale. Diagonal stratification. Geol Same as Cross bedding, under Cross a.
entry.ety: L. diagonalis, fr. Gr. � from to angle; dia` through + � an angle; perh. akin to E. knee: cf. F. diagonal
entry.def: Joining two not adjacent angles of a quadrilateral or multilateral figure; running across from corner to corner; crossing at an angle with one of the sides.

sn.def: A right line drawn from one angle to another not adjacent, of a figure of four or more sides, and dividing it into two parts.
A member, in a framed structure, running obliquely across a panel.
A diagonal cloth; a kind of cloth having diagonal stripes, ridges, or welts made in the weaving.

entry.def: able to be diagonalized; -- of a matrix.
to transform a matrix to a diagonal matrix.
In a diagonal direction.
Diagonal; diametrical; hence; diametrically opposed.
entry.q: Sin can have no tenure by law at all, but is rather an eternal outlaw, and in hostility with law past all atonement; both diagonal contraries, as much allowing one another as day and night together in one hemisphere.

entry.cs: Indicator diagram. Steam Engine See Indicator card, under indicator
entry.ety: Gr. �, fr. � to mark out by lines; dia` through + � to draw, write: cf. F. diagramme. See Graphic

sn.def: A figure or drawing made to illustrate a statement, or facilitate a demonstration; a plan.
Any simple drawing made for mathematical or scientific purposes, or to assist a verbal explanation which refers to it; a mechanical drawing, as distinguished from an artistical one.

entry.def: To put into the form of a diagram.
Pertaining to, or of the nature of, a diagram; showing by diagram.

entry.ety: Gr. � to draw: cf. F. diagraphe. See Diagram
entry.def: A drawing instrument, combining a protractor and scale.

entry.ety: Cf. F. diagraphique
entry.def: Descriptive.
The art or science of descriptive drawing; especially, the art or science of drawing by mechanical appliances and mathematical rule.

entry.ety: Gr. � through, at variance + � sun + � turning
entry.def: Relating or, or manifesting, diaheliotropism.
A tendency of leaves or other organs of plants to have their dorsal surface faced towards the rays of light.

cs.cd: an Indian bird (Copsychus saularius), allied to the European robin. The name is also given to other related species.
a lock provided with one or more plates having numbers or letters upon them. These plates must be adjusted in a certain determined way before the lock can be operated.
the plane or disk of a dial or timepiece on which lines and figures for indicating the time are placed.

entry.ety: LL. dialis daily, fr. L. dies day. See Deity

sn.def: An instrument, formerly much used for showing the time of day from the shadow of a style or gnomon on a graduated arc or surface; esp., a sundial; but there are lunar and astral dials. The style or gnomon is usually parallel to the earth's axis, but the dial plate may be either horizontal or vertical.
The graduated face of a timepiece, on which the time of day is shown by pointers or hands.
A miner's compass.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Dialed or Dialled; p. pr. & vb. n. Dialing or Dialling

sn.def: To measure with a dial.
sn.q: Hours of that true time which is dialed in heaven.

sn.def: To survey with a dial.

entry.ety: F. dialecte, L. dialectus, fr. Gr. �, fr. � to converse, discourse. See Dialogue

sn.def: Means or mode of expressing thoughts; language; tongue; form of speech.
sn.q: This book is writ in such a dialect As may the minds of listless men affect.Bunyan. The universal dialect of the world.

sn.def: The form of speech of a limited region or people, as distinguished from ether forms nearly related to it; a variety or subdivision of a language; speech characterized by local peculiarities or specific circumstances; as, the Ionic and Attic were dialects of Greece; the Yorkshire dialect; the dialect of the learned.
sn.q: In the midst of this Babel of dialects there suddenly appeared a standard English language.
Charles V.] could address his subjects from every quarter in their native dialect.
sn.syn: Language; idiom; tongue; speech; phraseology. See Language, and Idiom.

entry.def: Relating to a dialect; dialectical; as, a dialectical variant.
Same as Dialectics.
entry.q: Plato placed his dialectic above all sciences.

entry.ety: L. dialecticus, Gr. �: cf. F. dialectique. See Dialect

sn.def: Pertaining to dialectics; logical; argumental.
Pertaining to a dialect or to dialects.

entry.def: In a dialectical manner.

entry.ety: Cf. F. dialecticien
entry.def: One versed in dialectics; a logician; a reasoner.

entry.note: ☞ Dialectics was defined by Aristotle to be the method of arguing with probability on any given problem, and of defending a tenet without inconsistency. By Plato, it was used in the following senses: Discussion by dialogue as a method of scientific investigation. The method of investigating the truth by analysis. The science of ideas or of the nature and laws of being -- higher metaphysics. By Kant, it was employed to signify the logic of appearances or illusions, whether these arise from accident or error, or from those necessary limitations which, according to this philosopher, originate in the constitution of the human intellect.
entry.ety: L. dialecticasc. ars), Gr. � (sc. �): cf. F. dialectique
entry.def: That branch of logic which teaches the rules and modes of reasoning; the application of logical principles to discursive reasoning; the science or art of discriminating truth from error; logical discussion.

entry.ety: Dialect + -logy
entry.def: That branch of philology which is devoted to the consideration of dialects.
One skilled in dialectics.

sn.def: The art of constructing dials; the science which treats of measuring time by dials.
A method of surveying, especially in mines, in which the bearings of the courses, or the angles which they make with each other, are determined by means of the circumferentor.

entry.def: A maker of dials; one skilled in dialing.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. � interchange, change, fr. � to interchange
entry.def: A figure by which arguments are placed in various points of view, and then turned to one point.

entry.ety: Gr. � change, alluding to the change and inequality of luster between the natural joints of the mineral
entry.def: A dark green or bronze-colored laminated variety of pyroxene, common in certain igneous rocks.

entry.ety: Gr. � crossing

A volatile, pungent, liquid hydrocarbon, C6H10, consisting of two allyl radicals.

entry.ety: Gr. � belonging to discourse

entry.def: An imaginary speech or discussion between two or more; dialogue.

entry.ety: From Gr. � an arguing
entry.def: Native carbonate of manganese; rhodochrosite.

entry.ety: Gr. �: cf. F. dialogiser
entry.def: To discourse in dialogue.

entry.ety: OE. dialogue, L. dialogus, fr. Gr. �, fr. � to converse, dia` through + � to speak: cf. F. dialogue. See Legend

sn.def: A conversation between two or more persons; particularly, a formal conservation in theatrical performances or in scholastic exercises.
A written composition in which two or more persons are represented as conversing or reasoning on some topic; as, the Dialogues of Plato.

entry.ety: Cf. F. dialoguer
entry.def: To take part in a dialogue; to dialogize.
To express as in dialogue.
entry.q: And dialogued for him what he would say.

entry.ety: Gr. dia` through, asunder + � to loose + � leaf
entry.def: Having separate petals; polypetalous.

entries.entry:
Di*al"y*sis Di*al"y*sis n.; pl.Dialyses #. L., separation, fr. Gr. �, fr. � to part asunder, dissolve; dia` through + � to loose

Rhet Same as Asyndeton.
Med
Debility.
A solution of continuity; division; separation of parts.
Chem The separation of different substances in solution, as crystalloids and colloids, by means of their unequal diffusion, especially through natural or artificial membranes.

cs.cd: an achromatic telescope in which the colored dispersion produced by a single object lens of crown glass is corrected by a smaller concave lens, or combination of lenses, of high dispersive power, placed at a distance in the narrower part of the converging cone of rays, usually near the middle of the tube.

entry.ety: Gr. �, fr. �. See Dialysis

The material subjected to dialysis.
The act or process of dialysis.

Prepared by diffusion through an animal membrane; as, dialyzed iron.
