The true poet is not an eccentric creature, not a mere artist living only for art, not a dreamer or a dilettante, sipping the nectar of existence, while he keeps aloof from its deeper interests.

entry.def: Somewhat like a dilettante.
The state or quality of being a dilettante; the desultory pursuit of art, science, or literature.
Dilettanteish.
Same as Dilettanteism.

cs.cd: to exert one's self; to make interested and earnest endeavor.

entry.ety: F. diligence, L. diligentia

sn.def: The quality of being diligent; carefulness; careful attention; -- the opposite of negligence.
Interested and persevering application; devoted and painstaking effort to accomplish what is undertaken; assiduity in service.
sn.q: That which ordinary men are fit for, I am qualified in; and the best of me is diligence.

sn.def: Process by which persons, lands, or effects are seized for debt; process for enforcing the attendance of witnesses or the production of writings.
sn.q: And each of them doth all his diligence To do unto the festé reverence.
sn.syn: Attention; industry; assiduity; sedulousness; earnestness; constancy; heed; heedfulness; care; caution.Diligence Industry. Industry has the wider sense of the two, implying an habitual devotion to labor for some valuable end, as knowledge, property, etc. Diligence denotes earnest application to some specific object or pursuit, which more or less directly has a strong hold on one's interests or feelings. A man may be diligent for a time, or in seeking some favorite end, without meriting the title of industrious. Such was the case with Fox, while Burke was eminent not only for diligence, but industry; he was always at work, and always looking out for some new field of mental effort.
sn.q: The sweat of industry would dry and die, But for the end it works to.
Diligence and accuracy are the only merits which an historical writer ascribe to himself.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: A four-wheeled public stagecoach, used in France.

entry.ety: L. diligentia
entry.def: Diligence; care; persevering endeavor.

entry.ety: F. diligent, L. diligens -entis, p. pr. of diligere dilectum, to esteem highly, prefer; di- = dis- + legere to choose. See Legend

sn.def: Prosecuted with careful attention and effort; careful; painstaking; not careless or negligent.
sn.q: The judges shall make diligent inquisition.

sn.def: Interestedly and perseveringly attentive; steady and earnest in application to a subject or pursuit; assiduous; industrious.
sn.q: Seest thou a man diligent in his business? he shall stand before kings.
Diligent cultivation of elegant literature.
sn.syn: Active; assiduous; sedulous; laborious; persevering; attentive; industrious.

entry.def: In a diligent manner; not carelessly; not negligently; with industry or assiduity.
entry.q: Ye diligently keep commandments of the Lord your God.

entry.ety: AS dile; akin to D. dille, OHG. tilli, G. dill dille, Sw. dill, Dan. dild
entry.def: An herb (Peucedanum graveolens), the seeds of which are moderately warming, pungent, and aromatic, and were formerly used as a soothing medicine for children; -- called also dillseed.

entry.ety: OE. dillen, fr. dul dull, a.
entry.def: To still; to calm; to soothe, as one in pain.
any of several evergreen trees or shrubs of the genus Dillenia grown for their foliage and nodding magnolialike flowers which are followed by fruit that is used in curries and jellies and preserves.
a natural family of chiefly tropical shrubs and trees and climbers having leathery leaves or flattened leaflike stems, including the genera Dillenia and Hibbertia .

a group of families of more or less advanced trees and shrubs and herbs having either polypetalous or gamopetalous corollas and often with ovules attached to the walls of the ovary; it contains 69 families including Ericaceae and Cruciferae and Malvaceae; it is sometimes classified as a superorder.
A darling; a favorite.
entry.q: Whilst the birds billing, Each one with his dilling.

entry.def: A process of sorting ore by washing in a hand sieve.

entry.ety: Contr. fr. diligence
entry.def: A kind of stagecoach.
entry.q: The Derbydilly.

entry.def: something remarkable, highly unusual, or exceptionally effective; as, a dilly of a movie; when I make a mistake, it's a dilly .

entry.ety: See Dally
entry.def: To loiter or trifle; to waste time.
Ambiguous; of double meaning.

entries.entry: Dil"o*gy n.; pl.Dilogies #. L. dilogia, Gr. �, fr. � doubtful; di- = di`s- twice + � to speak Rhet An ambiguous speech; a figure in which a word is used an equivocal sense. R

entry.ety: L. dilucidus, fr. dilucere to be light enough to distinguish objects apart. See Lucid
entry.def: Clear; lucid.

entry.ety: L. dilucidatus, p. p. of dilucidare
entry.def: To elucidate.

entry.ety: L. dilucidatio
entry.def: The act of making clear.

entry.ety: L. diluens, p. pr. diluere. See Dilute
entry.def: Diluting; making thinner or weaker by admixture, esp. of water.

sn.def: That which dilutes.
An agent used for effecting dilution of the blood; a weak drink.
sn.q: There is no real diluent but water.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Diluted; p. pr. & vb. n. Diluting
entry.ety: L. dilutus, p. p. of diluere to wash away, dilute; di- = dis- + luere, equiv. to lavare to wash, lave. See Lave, and cf. Deluge

sn.def: To make thinner or more liquid by admixture with something; to thin and dissolve by mixing.
sn.q: Mix their watery store. With the chyle's current, and dilute it more.

sn.def: To diminish the strength, flavor, color, etc., of, by mixing; to reduce, especially by the addition of water; to temper; to attenuate; to weaken.
sn.q: Lest these colors should be diluted and weakened by the mixture of any adventitious light.

entry.def: To become attenuated, thin, or weak; as, it dilutes easily.

entry.ety: L. dilutus, p. p
entry.def: Diluted; thin; weak.
entry.q: A dilute and waterish exposition.

entry.def: Reduced in strength; thin; weak.
The quality or state of being dilute.
One who, or that which, dilutes or makes thin, more liquid, or weaker.

entry.ety: Cf. F. dilution
entry.def: The act of diluting, or the state of being diluted.

entry.ety: L. diluvialis. fr. diluvium

sn.def: Of or pertaining to a flood or deluge, esp. to the great deluge in the days of Noah; diluvian.

Effected or produced by a flood or deluge of water; -- said of coarse and imperfectly stratified deposits along ancient or existing water courses. Similar unstratified deposits were formed by the agency of ice. The time of deposition has been called the Diluvian epoch.

entry.def: One who explains geological phenomena by the Noachian deluge.

entry.ety: Cf. F. diluvien
entry.def: Of or pertaining to a deluge, esp. to the Noachian deluge; diluvial; as, of diluvian origin.

entry.ety: L. diluviare
entry.def: To run as a flood.

entries.entry:
Di*lu"vi*um ☞ The accumulation of matter by the ordinary operation of water is termed alluvium. n.; pl. E. Diluviums #, L. Diluvia #. L. diluvium. See Dilute Deluge
Geol A deposit of superficial loam, sand, gravel, stones, etc., caused by former action of flowing waters, or the melting of glacial ice.

entry.note: ☞ Obvious compounds: dim-eyed; dim-sighted, etc.
entry.ety: AS. dim; akin to OFries. dim, Icel. dimmr: cf. MHG. timmer timber; of uncertain origin

sn.def: Not bright or distinct; wanting luminousness or clearness; obscure in luster or sound; dusky; darkish; obscure; indistinct; overcast; tarnished.
sn.q: The dim magnificence of poetry.
How is the gold become dim!
I never saw The heavens so dim by day.
Three sleepless nights I passed in sounding on, Through words and things, a dim and perilous way.

sn.def: Of obscure vision; not seeing clearly; hence, dull of apprehension; of weak perception; obtuse.
sn.q: Mine eye also is dim by reason of sorrow.
The understanding is dim.
sn.syn: Obscure; dusky; dark; mysterious; imperfect; dull; sullied; tarnished.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Dimmed; p. pr. & vb. n. Dimming

sn.def: To render dim, obscure, or dark; to make less bright or distinct; to take away the luster of; to darken; to dull; to obscure; to eclipse.
sn.q: A king among his courtiers, who dims all his attendants.
Now set the sun, and twilight dimmed the ways.

sn.def: To deprive of distinct vision; to hinder from seeing clearly, either by dazzling or clouding the eyes; to darken the senses or understanding of.
sn.q: Her starry eyes were dimmed with streaming tears.

entry.def: To grow dim.

entry.ety: Prob. orig., a cavity, and the same word as dimple. See Dimple
entry.def: A bower; a dingle.

cs.cd: a novel, commonly sensational and trashy, which is sold for a dime, or ten cents; -- they were popular from ca. 1850 to ca. 1920. Sometimes the term is still applied to any novel of the type, though the price has greatly increased.

entry.ety: F. dîme tithe, OF. disme, fr. L. decimus the tenth, fr. decem ten. See Decimal
entry.def: A silver coin of the United States, of the value of ten cents; the tenth of a dollar.

cs.cd: extension that has length but no breadth or thickness; a straight or curved line.
extension which has length and breadth, but no thickness; a plane or curved surface.
extension which has length, breadth, and thickness; a solid.

as imaginary kind of extension, which is assumed to have length, breadth, thickness, and also a fourth imaginary dimension. Space of five or six, or more dimensions is also sometimes assumed in mathematics.

entry.note: Thus, since the unit of velocity varies directly as the unit of length and inversely as the unit of time, the dimensions of velocity are said to be length ÷ time; the dimensions of work are mass × (length2 ÷ (time2 ; the dimensions of density are mass ÷ (length3 .

cs.mcol: Dimensional lumber Dimension lumber Dimension scantlingorDimension stock
cs.cd: lumber for building, etc., cut to the sizes usually in demand, or to special sizes as ordered.
stone delivered from the quarry rough, but brought to such sizes as are requisite for cutting to dimensions given.

entry.ety: L. dimensio, fr. dimensus, p. p. of dimetiri to measure out; di- = dis- + metiri to measure: cf. F. dimension. See Measure

sn.def: Measure in a single line, as length, breadth, height, thickness, or circumference; extension; measurement; -- usually, in the plural, measure in length and breadth, or in length, breadth, and thickness; extent; size; as, the dimensions of a room, or of a ship; the dimensions of a farm, of a kingdom.
sn.q: Gentlemen of more than ordinary dimensions.

sn.def: Extent; reach; scope; importance; as, a project of large dimensions .
The degree of manifoldness of a quantity; as, time is quantity having one dimension; volume has three dimensions, relative to extension.

A literal factor, as numbered in characterizing a term. The term dimensions forms with the cardinal numbers a phrase equivalent to degree with the ordinal; thus, a2b2c is a term of five dimensions, or of the fifth degree.
The manifoldness with which the fundamental units of time, length, and mass are involved in determining the units of other physical quantities.

entry.def: Pertaining to dimension.
Having dimensions.
Without dimensions; having no appreciable or noteworthy extent.
Dimension.
Without dimensions; marking dimensions or the limits.
entry.q: Who can draw the soul's dimensive lines?

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. di- = di`s- twice + � part
entry.def: A division of Coleoptera, having two joints to the tarsi.
A division of the Hemiptera, including the aphids.
One of the Dimera.

entry.note: ☞ A dimerous flower has two sepals, two petals, two stamens, and two pistils.
entry.ety: Gr. di- = di`s- twice + � part
entry.def: Composed of, or having, two parts of each kind.

entry.ety: L. dimeter, Gr. �; di- = di`s- twice + � measure
entry.def: Having two poetical measures or meters.

entry.ety: Pref. di- + methyl
entry.def: Ethane; -- sometimes so called because regarded as consisting of two methyl radicals. See Ethane.

entry.ety: See Dimeter a.
entry.def: Same as Tetragonal.

entry.ety: L. dimicatio, fr. dimicare to fight
entry.def: A fight; contest.

entry.ety: L. dimidiatus, p. p. of dimidiare to halve, fr. dimidius half. See Demi-

sn.def: Divided into two equal parts; reduced to half in shape or form.

sd.def: Consisting of only one half of what the normal condition requires; having the appearance of lacking one half; as, a dimidiate leaf, which has only one side developed.
Having the organs of one side, or half, different in function from the corresponding organs on the other side; as, dimidiate hermaphroditism.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Dimidiated; p. pr. & vb. n. Dimidiating

sn.def: To divide into two equal parts.
To represent the half of; to halve.

entry.ety: L. dimidiatio
entry.def: The act of dimidiating or halving; the state of being dimidiate.

cs.cd: one whose upper diameter is less than the lower.
a scale of gradation used in finding the different points for drawing the spiral curve of the volute.
a board cut with a concave edge, for fixing the entasis and curvature of a shaft.
a stile which is narrower in one part than in another, as in many glazed doors.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Diminished; p. pr. & vb. n. Diminishing
entry.ety: Pref. di-= L. dis-) + minish: cf. L. diminuere, F. diminuer, OE. diminuen. See Dis-, and Minish

sn.def: To make smaller in any manner; to reduce in bulk or amount; to lessen; -- opposed to augment or increase.
sn.q: Not diminish, but rather increase, the debt.

sn.def: To lessen the authority or dignity of; to put down; to degrade; to abase; to weaken.
sn.q: This doth nothing diminish their opinion.
I will diminish them, that they shall no more rule over the nations.
O thou . . . at whose sight all the stars Hide their diminished heads.

sn.def: To make smaller by a half step; to make (an interval) less than minor; as, a diminished seventh.
To take away; to subtract.
sn.q: Neither shall ye diminish aught from it.
sn.syn: To decrease; lessen; abate; reduce; contract; curtail; impair; degrade. See Decrease.

entry.def: To become or appear less or smaller; to lessen; as, the apparent size of an object diminishes as we recede from it.
Capable of being diminished or lessened.
One who, or that which, diminishes anything.
In a manner to diminish.
Diminution.

entry.ety: It., p. pr. of diminuere to diminish
entry.def: In a gradually diminishing manner; with abatement of tone; decrescendo; -- expressed on the staff by Dim., or Dimin., or the sign.

entry.ety: L. diminuens, p. pr. of diminuere. See Diminish
entry.def: Lessening.
Indicating or causing diminution.
Small; diminished; diminutive.
Diminutively.

entry.ety: L. diminutio, or perh. rather deminutio: cf. F. diminution. See Diminish

sn.def: The act of diminishing, or of making or becoming less; state of being diminished; reduction in size, quantity, or degree; -- opposed to augmentation or increase.
The act of lessening dignity or consideration, or the state of being deprived of dignity; a lowering in estimation; degradation; abasement.
sn.q: The world's opinion or diminution of me.
Nor thinks it diminution to be ranked In military honor next.

sn.def: Omission, inaccuracy, or defect in a record.
In counterpoint, the imitation of, or reply to, a subject, in notes of half the length or value of those the subject itself.
sn.syn: Decrease; decay; abatement; reduction; deduction; decrement.

entries.entry:
Di*min`u*ti"val a. Indicating diminution; diminutive.
Diminutivalformsof words].Earle.
n. A diminutive. Earle.

entry.ety: Cf. L. deminutivus, F. diminutif

sn.def: Below the average size; very small; little.
Expressing diminution; as, a diminutive word.
Tending to diminish.
sn.q: Diminutive of liberty.

entry.note: ☞ The word sometimes denotes a derivative verb which expresses a diminutive or petty form of the action, as scribble.

sn.def: Something of very small size or value; an insignificant thing.
sn.q: Such water flies, diminutives of nature.

sn.def: A derivative from a noun, denoting a small or a young object of the same kind with that denoted by the primitive; as, gosling eaglet lambkin .
sn.q: Babyisms and dear diminutives.

entry.def: In a diminutive manner.
The quality of being diminutive; smallness; littleness; minuteness.
See Dimmish.

entry.ety: L. dimissio. See Dimit, and cf. Dismission
entry.def: Leave to depart; a dismissing.

cs.cd: letters given by a bishop dismissing a person who is removing into another diocese, and recommending him for reception there.

entry.ety: L. dimissorius: cf. F. dimissoire. See Dimit
entry.def: Sending away; dismissing to another jurisdiction; granting leave to depart.

entry.ety: L. dimittere to send away, le� go; di- = dis- + mittere to send. See Dismiss
entry.def: To dismiss, let go, or release.

entry.ety: Prob. fr. Gr. � of double thread, dimity; di- = di`s- twice + � a thread of the warp; prob. through D. diemet, of F. dimite démitte. Cf. Samite
entry.def: A cotton fabric employed for hangings and furniture coverings, and formerly used for women's under-garments. It is of many patterns, both plain and twilled, and occasionally is printed in colors.
In a dim or obscure manner; not brightly or clearly; with imperfect sight.
Somewhat dim; as, dimmish eyes.
entry.q: Dimmyclouds.

entry.ety: AS. dimness

sn.def: The state or quality � being dim; lack of brightness, clearness, or distinctness; dullness; obscurity.
Dullness, or want of clearness, of vision or of intellectual perception.

entry.ety: Gr. � two-formed; di`s- twice (see Di-) + morfh` form
entry.def: Either one of the two forms of a dimorphous substance; as, calcite and aragonite are dimorphs .
Having the property of dimorphism; dimorphous.

entry.ety: Cf. F. dimorphisme

sn.def: Difference of form between members of the same species, as when a plant has two kinds of flowers, both hermaphrodite (as in the partridge berry), or when there are two forms of one or both sexes of the same species of butterfly.
sn.q: Dimorphism is the condition of the appearance of the same species under two dissimilar forms.

sn.def: Crystallization in two independent forms of the same chemical compound, as of calcium carbonate as calcite and aragonite.

entry.ety: Cf. F. dimorphe

sn.def: Characterized by dimorphism; occurring under two distinct forms, not dependent on sex; dimorphic.
Crystallizing under two forms fundamentally different, while having the same chemical composition.

entry.ety: Prob. a nasalized dim. of dip. See Dip, and cf. Dimble

sn.def: A slight natural depression or indentation on the surface of some part of the body, esp. on the cheek or chin.
sn.q: The dimple of her chin.

sn.def: A slight indentation on any surface.
sn.q: The garden pool's dark surface . . . Breaks into dimples small and bright.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Dimpled; p. pr. & vb. n. Dimpling
entry.def: To form dimples; to sink into depressions or little inequalities.
entry.q: And smiling eddies dimpled on the main.

entry.def: To mark with dimples or dimplelike depressions.
The state of being dimpled, or marked with gentle depressions.
entry.q: The ground's most gentle dimplement.

entry.def: Full of dimples, or small depressions; dimpled; as, the dimply pool.
Having dim sight; lacking perception.
mentally retarded; relatively slow in mental function.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. � = � + � to close
entry.def: An order of lamellibranchiate mollusks having an anterior and posterior adductor muscle, as the common clam. See Bivalve.
Like or pertaining to the Dimya.
Same as Dimyarian.

entry.ety: AS. dyne dyn; akin to Icel. dynr, and to AS. dynian to resound, Icel. dynja to pour down like hail or rain; cf. Skr. dhuni roaring, a torrent, dhvan to sound. Cf. Dun to ask payment
entry.def: Loud, confused, harsh noise; a loud, continuous, rattling or clanging sound; clamor; roar.
entry.q: Think you a little din can daunt mine ears?
He knew the battle's din afar.
The dust and din and steam of town.

cs.cd: to fix in the mind of another by frequent and noisy repetitions.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Dinned; p. pr. & vb. n. Dinning
entry.ety: AS. dynian. See Din n.

sn.def: To strike with confused or clanging sound; to stun with loud and continued noise; to harass with clamor; as, to din the ears with cries.
To utter with a din; to repeat noisily; to ding.
sn.q: This hath been often dinned in my ears.

entry.def: To sound with a din; a ding.
entry.q: The gay viol dinning in the dale.

entry.ety: Pref. di- + naphthylene
entry.def: A colorless, crystalline hydrocarbon, C20H14, obtained from naphthylene, and consisting of a doubled naphthylene radical.

entry.ety: Ar. dīnār, from Gr. dhna`rion, fr. L. denarius. See Denier

sn.def: A petty money of accounts of Persia; 100 dinars consituted a rial.
An ancient gold coin of the East, issued by various Islamic countries.
the unit of currency of Yugoslavia. One dinar equals 100 paras. Abbreviated Din.

entry.def: See Diarchy.

cs.cd: to go without dinner; -- a phrase common in Elizabethan literature, said to be from the practice of the poor gentry, who beguiled the dinner hour by a promenade near the tomb of Humphrey, Duke of Gloucester, in Old Saint Paul's.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Dined; p. pr. & vb. n. Dining
entry.ety: F. dîner, OF. disner, LL. disnare, contr. fr. an assumed disjunare; dis- + an assumed junareOF. juner) to fast, for L. jejunare, fr. jejunus fasting. See Jejune, and cf. Dinner D�jeuner
entry.def: To eat the principal regular meal of the day; to take dinner.
entry.q: Now can I break my fast, dine, sup, and sleep.

sn.def: To give a dinner to; to furnish with the chief meal; to feed; as, to dine a hundred men.
sn.q: A table massive enough to have dined Johnnie Armstrong and his merry men.

sn.def: To dine upon; to have to eat.
sn.q: What will yedine.

entry.def: One who dines.
One who often takes his dinner away from home, or in company.
entry.q: A brilliant diner-out, though but a curate.

entry.ety: Gr. � to whirl round
entry.def: Revolving on an axis.

cs.cd: to impress one by noisy repetition, as if by hammering.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Dinged Dang Obs.), or Dung Obs.); p. pr. & vb. n. Dinging
entry.ety: OE. dingen dengen; akin to AS. dencgan to knock, Icel. dengja to beat, hammer, Sw. dänga, G. dengeln

sn.def: To dash; to throw violently.
sn.q: To ding the book a coit's distance from him.

sn.def: To cause to sound or ring.
To strike; to thump; to pound.
sn.q: Diken, or delven, or dingen upon sheaves.

sn.def: To sound, as a bell; to ring; to clang.
sn.q: The fretful tinkling of the convent bell evermore dinging among the mountain echoes.

sn.def: To talk with vehemence, importunity, or reiteration; to bluster.

entry.def: A thump or stroke, especially of a bell.
a stupid or foolish person; -- used in a deprecatory or contemptuous sense.

entry.ety: See Ding

sn.def: The sound of, or as of, repeated strokes on a metallic body, as a bell; a repeated and monotonous sound.
An attachment to a clock by which the quarter hours are struck upon bells of different tones.
a stupid or foolish person; -- used in a deprecatory or contemptuous sense.

entries.entry: Ding"dong` the"o*ry. Philol The theory which maintains that the primitive elements of language are reflex expressions induced by sensory impressions; that is, as stated by Max Müller, the creative faculty gave to each general conception as it thrilled for the first time through the brain a phonetic expression; -- jocosely so called from the analogy of the sound of a bell induced by the stroke of the clapper.

entry.ety: Bengalee dingi

sn.def: a small boat propelled by oars or sails, used in the East Indies, in sheltered waters.
a small boat intended to be used as a tender or lifeboat, carried or towed by a ship. It may be propelled by oars, sail, or a motor.
a small boat of shallow draft with cross thwarts for seats and rowlocks for oars with which it is propelled.

entry.def: In a dingy manner.
Quality of being dingy; a dusky hue.

entry.ety: Of uncertain origin: cf. AS. ding prison; or perh. akin to dimble
entry.def: A narrow dale; a small dell; a small, secluded, and embowered valley.
In a dangling manner.
A wild dog found in Australia, but supposed to have introduced at a very early period. It has a wolflike face, bushy tail, and a reddish brown color.
A spendthrift.
entry.q: Wilt thou, therefore, a drunkard be, A dingthrift and a knave?

entry.ety: Prob. fr. dung. Cf. Dungy
entry.def: Soiled; sullied; of a dark or dusky color; dark brown; dirty.
entry.q: Scraps ofdingypaper.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. � terrible + � fish
entry.def: A genus of large extinct Devonian ganoid fishes. In some parts of Ohio remains of the Dinichthys are abundant, indicating animals twenty feet in length.

entry.note: ☞ Used either adjectively or as the first part of a compound; as, dining hall or dining-hall, dining room, dining table, etc.
entry.def: from Dine a.
a large room at a college or university, used especially for dining.
a room used for dining. In a residence, it usually contains a dining table and some furniture, such as a buffet or sideboard, for storing tableware and dining utensils.

entry.ety: Etymol. uncertain
entry.def: Trim; neat.
To deck; -- often with out or up.

entry.ety: ca. 1985, acronym from double income no kids
entry.def: either of a married couple who both are employed and have no children. The term is often used as the prototype of midde-class persons with higher-than-average disposable income.
a ball hit softly that falls to the ground just beyond the net.
an Asian person, especially a Vietnamese; -- used contemptuously, considered disparaging and offensive.
a Nilotic language.

sn.def: small and insignificant; shabby or unimpressive; as, he drove to work in a dinky old Volkswagen; we stayed in a dinky little hotel.
pretty and neat; fashionable or well-dressed; as, what a dinky little hat.

entry.def: A wether sheep between one and two years old.

entry.note: ☞ Dinner is much used, in an obvious sense, either adjectively or as the first part of a compound; as, dinner time, or dinner-time, dinner bell, dinner hour, etc.
entry.ety: F. dîner, fr. dîner to dine. See Dine

sn.def: The principal meal of the day, eaten in some countries about midday, but in others (especially in the U. S. and in large cities) at a later hour.
An entertainment; a feast.
sn.q: A grand political dinner.

entry.def: Having no dinner; as, the naughty child was sent to bed dinnerless .
Of or pertaining to dinner.
entry.q: The dinnerly officer.

entry.def: the time when people eat dinner, usually the time for the evening meal.

entry.note: ☞ They were herbivorous, and remarkable for three pairs of hornlike protuberances on the skull. The males were armed with a pair of powerful canine tusks.
entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. � terrible + �, �, horn
entry.def: A genus of large extinct Eocene mammals from Wyoming; -- called also Uintatherium . See Illustration in Appendix.
a small order of primitive ungulates of the Paleocene and Eocene.

and order of plankton, in some classifications it is considered a phylum of the kingdom Protista; in others it is included in the plant phylum Pyrrophyta. Its members usually have two flagella, one of which extends from its center.
a member of the Dinoflagellata, chiefly marine protozoa having two flagella. The dinoflagellates form a chief constituent of plankton.

entries.entry:
Di*nor"nis‖n. NL., fr. Gr. � terrible + � bird Paleon A genus of extinct, ostrichlike birds of gigantic size, which formerly inhabited New Zealand. See Moa.
Deinornis

entry.ety: Gr. � terrible + � lizard
entry.def: One of the Dinosauria.

entries.entry: Di`no*sau"ri*a‖n. pl. NL., fr. Gr. � terrible + � lizard Paleon An order of extinct mesozoic reptiles, mostly of large size (whence the name). Notwithstanding their size, they present birdlike characters in the skeleton, esp. in the pelvis and hind limbs. Some walked on their three-toed hind feet, thus producing the large “bird tracks,” so-called, of mesozoic sandstones; others were five-toed and quadrupedal. See Illust. of Compsognathus, also Illustration of Dinosaur in Appendix.

entry.ety: NL. dinotherium, fr. Gr. deino`s terrible + qhri`on beast
entry.def: A large extinct proboscidean mammal from the miocene beds of Europe and Asia. It is remarkable for a pair of tusks directed downward from the decurved apex of the lower jaw.
Same as Dioxide.
Full of din.

entry.ety: OE. dint dent dunt, a blow, AS. dynt; akin to Icel. dyntr a dint, dynta to dint, and perh. to L. fenderein composition). Cf. 1st Dent Defend

sn.def: A blow; a stroke.
sn.q: Mortaldint.
Like thunder'sdint.

sn.def: The mark left by a blow; an indentation or impression made by violence; a dent.
sn.q: Every dint a sword had beaten in it [the shield].

sn.def: Force; power; -- esp. in the phrase by dint of.
sn.q: Now you weep; and, I perceive, you feel The dint of pity.
It was by dint of passing strength That he moved the massy stone at length.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Dinted; p. pr. & vb. n. Dinting
entry.def: To make a mark or cavity on or in, by a blow or by pressure; to dent.

entry.ety: L. dinumeratio; di- = dis- + numerare to count, fr. numerus number
entry.def: Enumeration.

entry.ety: LL. dioecesanus: cf. F. diocésain
entry.def: Of or pertaining to a diocese; as, diocesan missions.

sn.def: A bishop, viewed in relation to his diocese; as, the diocesan of New York.
The clergy or the people of a diocese.

entries.entry:
Di"o*cese n.; pl.Dioceses #. OE. diocise, OF. diocise, F. diocése, L. dioecesis, fr. Gr. � housekeeping, administration, a province, a diocese, fr. � to keep house, manage; dia` through + � to manage a household, � a house. See Economy
Eccl The circuit or extent of a bishop's jurisdiction; the district in which a bishop exercises his ecclesiastical authority.
diocess

entry.def: One who belongs to a diocese.

entry.ety: Gr. di- = di`s- twice + 'odoy`s 'odo`ntos, a tooth: cf. F. diodon

sn.def: A genus of spinose, plectognath fishes, having the teeth of each jaw united into a single beaklike plate. They are able to inflate the body by taking in air or water, and, hence, are called globefishes swellfishes, etc. Called also porcupine fishes, and sea hedgehogs.
A genus of whales.

entry.def: Like or pertaining to the genus Diodon.

def2.def: A fish of the genus Diodon, or an allied genus.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. di = di`s twice + o'i^kos a house

sn.def: A Linnæan class of plants having the stamens and pistils on different plants.
A subclass of gastropod mollusks in which the sexes are separate. It includes most of the large marine species, like the conchs, cones, and cowries.

entry.def: Having the sexes in two separate individuals; -- applied to plants in which the female flowers occur on one individual and the male flowers on another of the same species, and to animals in which the ovum is produced by one individual and the sperm cell by another; -- opposed to monœcious.

cs.cd: having flowers structurally perfect, but practically diœcious, -- those on one plant producing no pollen, and those on another no ovules.

entry.def: In a diœcious manner.
The state or quality of being diœcious.
The condition of being diœcious.
in a period of sexual inactivity; -- of animals that have several estrous cycles in one breeding season.

cs.cd: a species of terrestrial hermit crabs (Cenobita Diogenes), abundant in the West Indies and often destructive to crops.
the tub which the philosopher Diogenes is said to have carried about with him as his house, in which he lived.

entry.def: A Greek Cynic philosopher (412?-323 B. C.) who lived much in Athens and was distinguished for contempt of the common aims and conditions of life, and for sharp, caustic sayings.
See Diœcious.

entry.ety: NL
entry.def: A genus of large sea birds, including the albatross. See Albatross.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. � a name of Aphrodite
entry.def: An insectivorous plant. See Venus's flytrap.

entry.ety: L., fr. Gr. �
entry.def: Any of the festivals held in honor of the Olympian god Dionysus. They correspond to the Roman Bacchanalia; the greater Dionysia were held at Athens in March or April, and were celebrated with elaborate performances of both tragedies and comedies.
Of or pertaining to Dionysus or to the Dionysia; Bacchic; as, a Dionysiac festival; the Dionysiac theater at Athens.

cs.cd: a period of 532 years, depending on the cycle of the sun, or 28 years, and the cycle of the moon, or 19 years; -- sometimes called the Greek paschal cycle, or Victorian period.

entry.def: Relating to Dionysius, a monk of the 6th century; as, the Dionysian, or Christian, era.

cs.cd: that branch of indeterminate analysis which has for its object the discovery of rational values that satisfy given equations containing squares or cubes; as, for example, to find values of x and y which make x2 + y2 an exact square.

entry.def: Originated or taught by Diophantus, the Greek writer on algebra.

entry.ety: Gr. di- = di`s- twice + � a sight, fr. the root of � I shall see: cf. F. diopside
entry.def: A crystallized variety of pyroxene, of a clear, grayish green color; mussite.

entry.ety: Gr. � = dia` through + � to see: cf. F. dioptase
entry.def: A hydrous silicate of copper, occurring in emerald-green crystals.

entry.ety: L. dioptra, fr. Gr. �. See 2d Dioptric
entry.def: An optical instrument, invented by Hipparchus, for taking altitudes, leveling, etc.

entry.ety: F. See 2d Dioptric
entry.def: A unit employed by oculists in numbering glasses according to the metric system; a refractive power equal to that of a glass whose principal focal distance is one meter.
Of or pertaining to the dioptre, or to the metric system of numbering glasses.

cs.cd: a Cartesian oval. See under Cartesian.

entry.ety: Gr. � belonging to the use of the �; � = dia` through + the root of � I shall see: cf. F. dioptrique
entry.def: Of or pertaining to dioptrics; assisting vision by means of the refraction of light; refractive; as, the dioptric system; a dioptric glass or telescope.
entry.q: Dioptricalprinciples.

entry.ety: Gr. � �: cf. F. dioptrique
entry.def: The science of the refraction of light; that part of geometrical optics which treats of the laws of the refraction of light in passing from one medium into another, or through different mediums, as air, water, or glass, and esp. through different lenses; -- distinguished from catoptrics, which refers to reflected light.
A dioptre.

entry.ety: Gr. � to see through; � = dia` through + � to see; cf. � that which is seen, a sight: cf. F. diorama. Cf. Panorama

sn.def: A mode of scenic representation, invented by Daguerre and Bouton, in which a painting is seen from a distance through a large opening. By a combination of transparent and opaque painting, and of transmitted and reflected light, and by contrivances such as screens and shutters, much diversity of scenic effect is produced.
A building used for such an exhibition.

entry.def: Pertaining to a diorama.

entry.ety: Gr. �, fr. � to distinguish; � = dia` through + � to divide from, fr. � a boundary
entry.def: Definition; logical direction.

entry.ety: Gr. �
entry.def: Distinguishing; distinctive; defining.

entry.ety: Cf. F. diorite. See Diorism
entry.def: An igneous, crystalline in structure, consisting essentially of a triclinic feldspar and hornblende. It includes part of what was called greenstone.
Containing diorite.

entry.ety: Gr. �; � = � + � to set straight
entry.def: Relating to the correcting or straightening out of something; corrective.

entry.ety: NL. Named after Dioscorides the Greek physician
entry.def: A genus of plants, the roots of which are eaten as yams. See Yam.

sn.def: a natural family of tuberous plants including the yams.

entry.ety: L., fr. Gr. � two-handled; di- = di`s- twice + �, �, ear, handle
entry.def: A vase or drinking cup having two handles or ears.

entry.cs: Carbon dioxide. See Carbonic acid, under Carbonic.
entry.ety: Pref. di- + oxide
entry.def: An oxide containing two atoms of oxygen in each molecule; binoxide.
An oxide containing but one atom or equivalent of oxygen to two of a metal; a suboxide.

entry.ety: Pref. di- + oxygen + indol
entry.def: A white, crystalline, nitrogenous substance obtained by the reduction of isatin. It is a member of the indol series; -- hence its name.

cs.cd: a candle made by repeatedly dipping a wick in melted tallow.
to take snuff by rubbing it on the gums and teeth.
to lower the colors and return them to place; -- a form of naval salute.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Dipped or Dipt�); p. pr. & vb. n. Dipping
entry.ety: OE. dippen duppen, AS. dyppan; akin to Dan. dyppe, Sw. doppa, and to AS. d�pan to baptize, OS. d�pian, D. doopen, G. taufen, Sw. döpa, Goth. daupjan, Lith. dubus deep, hollow, OSlav. dupl� hollow, and to E. dive. Cf. Deep Dive

sn.def: To plunge or immerse; especially, to put for a moment into a liquid; to insert into a fluid and withdraw again.
sn.q: The priest shall dip his finger in the blood.
Wat'ry fowl] now dip their pinions in the briny deep.
While the prime swallow dips his wing.

sn.def: To immerse for baptism; to baptize by immersion.
To wet, as if by immersing; to moisten.
sn.q: A cold shuddering dewDips me all o'er.

sn.def: To plunge or engage thoroughly in any affair.
sn.q: He was . . . dipt in the rebellion of the Commons.

sn.def: To take out, by dipping a dipper, ladle, or other receptacle, into a fluid and removing a part; -- often with out; as, to dip water from a boiler; to dip out water.
To engage as a pledge; to mortgage.
sn.q: Live on the use and never dip thy lands.

sn.def: To immerse one's self; to become plunged in a liquid; to sink.
sn.q: The sun's rim dips; the stars rush out.

sn.def: To perform the action of plunging some receptacle, as a dipper, ladle. etc.; into a liquid or a soft substance and removing a part.
sn.q: Whoever dips too deep will find death in the pot.

sn.def: To pierce; to penetrate; -- followed by in or into.
sn.q: When I dipt into the future.

sn.def: To enter slightly or cursorily; to engage one's self desultorily or by the way; to partake limitedly; -- followed by in or into.
sn.q: Dippedinto a multitude of books.

sn.def: To incline downward from the plane of the horizon; as, strata of rock dip .
To dip snuff.

cs.cd: the angular depression of the seen or visible horizon below the true or natural horizon; the angle at the eye of an observer between a horizontal line and a tangent drawn from the eye to the surface of the ocean.
the angle formed, in a vertical plane, by a freely suspended magnetic needle, or the line of magnetic force, with a horizontal line; -- called also inclination.
its greatest angle of inclination to the horizon, or that of a line perpendicular to its direction or strike; -- called also the pitch.

sn.def: The action of dipping or plunging for a moment into a liquid.
sn.q: Thedipof oars in unison.

sn.def: Inclination downward; direction below a horizontal line; slope; pitch.
a hollow or depression in a surface, especially in the ground.
A liquid, as a sauce or gravy, served at table with a ladle or spoon.
A dipped candle.

A gymnastic exercise on the parallel bars in which the performer, resting on his hands, lets his arms bend and his body sink until his chin is level with the bars, and then raises himself by straightening his arms.
In the turpentine industry, the viscid exudation, which is dipped out from incisions in the trees; as, virgin dipthe runnings of the first year), yellow dipthe runnings of subsequent years.
A sudden drop followed by a climb, usually to avoid obstacles or as the result of getting into an airhole.
a liquid, in which objects are soaked by dipping; e.g., a parasiticide or insecticide solution into which animals are dipped (see sheep-dip).
a sauce into which foods are dipped to enhance the flavor; e. g., an onion dip made from sour cream and dried onions, into which potato chips are dipped.
a pickpocket.

entry.ety: Pref. di- + paschal
entry.def: Including two passovers.
See Dabchick.

entry.ety: Pref. di- + petalous
entry.def: Having two petals; two-petaled.

entry.ety: Pref. di- + phenyl
entry.def: A white crystalline substance, C6H5.C6H5, obtained by leading benzene through a heated iron tube. It consists of two benzene or phenyl radicals united.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. � leather (hence taken in the sense of membrane): cf. � to make soft, L. depsere to knead
entry.def: A very dangerous contagious disease in which the air passages, and especially the throat, become coated with a false membrane, produced by the solidification of an inflammatory exudation. Cf. Group.
Relating to diphtheria; diphtheritic.

sn.def: Pertaining to, or connected with, diphtheria.
Having characteristics resembling those of diphtheria; as, diphtheritic inflammation of the bladder.

entry.ety: L. diphthongus, Gr. �; di- = di`s- twice + � voice, sound, fr. � to utter a sound: cf. F. diphthongue
entry.def: A coalition or union of two vowel sounds pronounced in one syllable; as, ou in out oi in noise; -- called a proper diphthong.
A vowel digraph; a union of two vowels in the same syllable, only one of them being sounded; as, ai in rain eo in people; -- called an improper diphthong.
To form or pronounce as a diphthong; diphthongize.
Relating or belonging to a diphthong; having the nature of a diphthong.
To make into a diphthong; to pronounce as a diphthong.
See Diphthongization.
Of the nature of diphthong; diphthongal.
The act of changing into a diphthong.
To change into a diphthong, as by affixing another vowel to a simple vowel.
entry.q: Thediphthongizedlong vowels.

entry.ety: Gr. difyh`s double (di- = di`s- twice + fy`ein to produce) + ke`rkos tail
entry.def: Having the tail fin divided into two equal parts by the notochord, or end of the vertebral column; protocercal. See Protocercal.

entry.ety: Gr. difyh`s of double form + -genic
entry.def: Having two modes of embryonic development.

entry.ety: Gr. di- = di`s- twice + fy`llon leaf: cf. F. diphylle
entry.def: Having two leaves, as a calyx, etc.

entry.ety: Gr. � double (di- = di`s- twice + � to produce) + 'odoy`s 'odo`ntos, tooth
entry.def: Having two successive sets of teeth (deciduous and permanent), one succeeding the other; as, a diphyodont mammal; diphyodont dentition; -- opposed to monophyodont.

def2.def: An animal having two successive sets of teeth.

entry.ety: Gr. � of double from + E. zooid
entry.def: One of the free-swimming sexual zooids of Siphonophora.

entry.ety: Pref. di- + plane
entry.def: Of or pertaining to two planes.

entry.ety: Gr. � double + � image + -scope
entry.def: An instrument for determining the time of apparent noon. It consists of two mirrors and a plane glass disposed in the form of a prism, so that, by the reflections of the sun's rays from their surfaces, two images are presented to the eye, moving in opposite directions, and coinciding at the instant the sun's center is on the meridian.

entry.ety: Pref. di- + -plex, as in duplex
entry.def: Pertaining to the sending of two messages in the same direction at the same time. Diplex and contraplex are the two varieties of duplex.

entry.ety: Gr. � doublet + -blast + -ic
entry.def: Characterizing the ovum when it has two primary germinal layers.

entry.ety: Gr. � double + E. cardiac
entry.def: Having the heart completely divided or double, one side systemic, the other pulmonary.

entries.entry: Dip`lo*coc"cus Dip`lo*coc"cus n.; pl.Diplococci #. NL., fr. Gr. diplo`os twofold + ko`kkos grain, seed Biol A form of micrococcus in which cocci are united in a binary manner. See Micrococcus.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. � fold, fr. � twofold, double
entry.def: The soft, spongy, or cancellated substance between the plates of the skull.
Diploic.

entry.ety: Gr. � double + the root of � to produce
entry.def: Partaking of the nature of two bodies; producing two substances.

entry.ety: Gr. � double + -graph
entry.def: An instrument used for double writing, as one for producing embossed writing for the blind and ordinary writing at the same time.
Of or pertaining to the diploë.

entry.ety: Gr. diplo`os twofold + -oid

sn.def: A solid bounded by twenty-four similar quadrilateral faces. It is a hemihedral form of the hexoctahedron.
a cell or organism having a number of chromosomes corresponding to two copies of each chromosome; a diploid cell or organism.
sn.q: A: I'm not interested in diploids. B: Oh, how I wish your parents had felt the same way!

entry.note: in diploid cells, although the number of chromosomes is double that in haploid cells, it is not always true that there are two copies of every chromosome, since the two sex chromosomes in males will differ from each other. In females, and for other chromosomes, however, there are generally two copies of each, giving rise to the classical hereditary and sorting patterns of Mendelian genetics.
entry.ety: Gr. diplo`os twofold + -oid
entry.def: having a number of chromosomes corresponding to two copies of each chromosome; having double the basic number of chromosomes, as seen in a haploid cell. Contrasted to haploid and polyploid.

entries.entry:
Di*plo"ma n.; pl.Diplomas #. L., fr. Gr. �, fr. � to double, fr. diplo`os twofold. See Double
A letter or writing, usually under seal, conferring some privilege, honor, or power; a document bearing record of a degree conferred by a literary society or educational institution.

entry.ety: F. diplomatie. This word, like supremacy, retains the accent of its original. See Diploma

sn.def: The art and practice of conducting negotiations between nations (particularly in securing treaties), including the methods and forms usually employed.
Dexterity or skill in securing advantages; tact.
The body of ministers or envoys resident at a court; the diplomatic body.

entry.ety: F. diplomate
entry.def: A diplomatist.
To invest with a title or privilege by diploma.
Diplomatic.

entry.ety: Cf. diplomatique

sn.def: Pertaining to diplomacy; relating to the foreign ministers at a court, who are called the diplomatic body.
Characterized by tact and shrewdness; dexterous; artful; as, diplomatic management.
Pertaining to diplomatics; paleographic.

entry.def: A minister, official agent, or envoy to a foreign court; a diplomatist.
According to the rules of diplomacy; in the manner of a diplomatist; artfully.
The science of diplomas, or the art of deciphering ancient writings, and determining their age, authenticity, etc.; paleography.
Diplomacy.

entry.ety: Cf. F. diplomatiste a student of diplomatics
entry.def: A person employed in, or skilled in, diplomacy; a diplomat.
entry.q: In ability, Avaux had no superior among the numerous able diplomatists whom his country then possessed.

entry.note: ☞ In crossed or heteronymous diplopia the image seen by the right eye is upon the left hand, and that seen by the left eye is upon the right hand. In homonymous diplopia the image seen by the right eye is on the right side, that by the left eye on the left side. In vertical diplopia one image stands above the other.
entry.ety: NL. diplopia, from Gr. � double + the root of � sight: cf. F. diplopie
entry.def: The act or state of seeing double.
One of the Diplopoda.

entry.ety: Gr. � double + -poda
entry.def: An order of myriapods having two pairs of legs on each segment; the Chilognatha.

entry.ety: Gr. � double + � the warp, a thread

The condition of being diplostemonous.
the fourth stage of the prophase of meiosis, when the paired chromosomes being to separate. This stage follows the pachytene.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. � = � lung
entry.def: A group of spiders having only two lunglike organs.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. � � with two breathing apertures; di- = di`s- twice + � breath
entry.def: A group of ganoid fishes, including the living genera Ceratodus and Lepidosiren, which present the closest approximation to the Amphibia. The air bladder acts as a lung, and the nostrils open inside the mouth. See Ceratodus, and Illustration in Appendix.

entry.note: An Australian rodent of the genus Notomys is also referred to as a kangaroo rat, as is the potoroo. See kangaroo rat
entry.def: a genus of rodents of the family Heteromyidae, comprising the genus of kangaroo rats which live in arid regions of Mexico and the western U. S.
a genus of plants consisting of one species, the Australian pea.

entries.entry: Dip"o*dy n.; pl.Dipodies #. Gr. �, fr. � two-footed; di- = di`s- twice + �, �, foot Pros Two metrical feet taken together, or included in one measure. Trochaic, iambic, and anapestic verses . . . are measured by dipodies.

entry.ety: Pre. di- + polar. Cf. Bipolar
entry.def: Having two poles, as a magnetic bar.
having an abnormal sagging of the spine, especially in horses.

entries.entry: Dip"pel's oil`. Chem From the name of the inventor See Bone oil, under Bone.

cs.cd: the seven principal stars in the constellation of the Great Bear; popularly so called from their arrangement in the form of a dipper; -- called also Charles's Wain. See Ursa Major, under Ursa.

sn.def: One who, or that which, dips; especially, a vessel used to dip water or other liquid; a ladle.

sd.def: A small grebe; the dabchick.
The buffel duck.
The water ouzel (Cinolus aquaticus) of Europe.
The American dipper or ouzel (Cinclus Mexicanus).

The act of lifting or moving a liquid with a dipper, ladle, or the like.

The practice of taking snuff by rubbing the teeth or gums with a stick or brush dipped in snuff.

entry.ety: Prefix di- + prismatic
entry.def: Doubly prismatic.

entry.ety: Prefix di- + propargyl
entry.def: A pungent, mobile, volatile liquid, C6H6, produced artificially from certain allyl derivatives. Though isomeric with benzine, it is very different in its chemical relations. Called also dipropinyl.

entry.def: An extinct Quaternary marsupial from Australia, about as large as the hippopotamus; -- so named because of its two large front teeth. See Illustration in Appendix.

A genus of harmless colubrine snakes.

Deep-sea; as, a dipsey line; a dipsy lead.

sn.def: A sinker attached to a fishing line; also, a line having several branches, each with such a sinker, used in deep-sea fishing.
A deep-sea lead.

Of or pertaining to dipsomania.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. � thirst

a graduated rod dipped into a container to indicate the fluid level; as, to check the oil level in a car with a dipstick .

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. � with two wings, di- = di`s- twice + � feather, wing: cf. F. diptère
entry.def: An extensive order of insects having only two functional wings and two balancers, as the house fly, mosquito, etc. They have a suctorial proboscis, often including two pairs of sharp organs (mandibles and maxillæ) with which they pierce the skin of animals. They undergo a complete metamorphosis, their larvæ (called maggots) being usually without feet.

sn.def: Having two wings only; belonging to the order Diptera.
Having a double row of columns on each on the flanks, as well as in front and rear; -- said of a temple.

entry.def: An insect of the order Diptera.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. � with two wings + � fruit
entry.def: A genus of trees found in the East Indies, some species of which produce a fragrant resin, other species wood oil. The fruit has two long wings.

sn.def: Having two wings, as certain insects; belonging to the order Diptera.
Having two wings; two-winged.

entry.ety: Gr. di- = di`s- twice + � a fin, dim. of � wing
entry.def: Having two dorsal fins; -- said of certain fishes.
a genus of tropical American trees which produce a black seed called the tonka bean.

entry.ety: Gr. �; di- = di`s- twice + � falling, fr. � to fall: cf. F. diptote
entry.def: A noun which has only two cases.

entry.ety: L. diptycha, pl., fr. Gr. � folded, doubled; di- = di`s- twice + � to fold, double up
entry.sn:
Anything consisting of two leaves. Especially: Roman Antiq A writing tablet consisting of two leaves of rigid material connected by hinges and shutting together so as to protect the writing within.
A picture or series of pictures painted on two tablets connected by hinges. See Triptych.

sn.def: A double catalogue, containing in one part the names of living, and in the other of deceased, ecclesiastics and benefactors of the church; a catalogue of saints.

entry.ety: Gr. di- = di`s- twice fire
entry.def: A mineral of the scapolite group; -- so called from the double effect of fire upon it, in fusing it, and rendering it phosphorescent.

entry.ety: Pref. di- + pyridine + -yl

entry.ety: Pref. di- + radiation
entry.def: The emission and diffusion of rays of light.

entry.ety: L. dirus; of uncertain origin

sn.def: Ill-boding; portentous; as, dire omens.
Evil in great degree; dreadful; dismal; horrible; terrible; lamentable.
sn.q: Dire was the tossing, deep the groans.
Gorgons and hydras and chimeras dire.

entry.cs: Direct action. Mach See Direct-acting. Trade unions See Syndicalism, below.]Direct discourse Gram the language of any one quoted without change in its form; as, he said “I can not come;” -- correlative to indirect discourse, in which there is change of form; as, he said that he could not come. They are often called respectively by their Latin names, oratio directa, and oratio obliqua. Direct evidence Law evidence which is positive or not inferential; -- opposed to circumstantial evidence, or indirect evidence. -- This distinction, however, is merely formal, since there is no direct evidence that is not circumstantial, or dependent on circumstances for its credibility. Wharton. Direct examination Law the first examination of a witness in the orderly course, upon the merits. Abbott. Direct fire Mil fire, the direction of which is perpendicular to the line of troops or to the parapet aimed at. Direct process Metal one which yields metal in working condition by a single process from the ore. Knight. Direct tax a tax assessed directly on lands, etc., and polls, distinguished from taxes on merchandise, or customs, and from excise.
entry.ety: L. directus, p. p. of dirigere to direct: cf. F. direct. See Dress, and cf. Dirge

sn.def: Straight; not crooked, oblique, or circuitous; leading by the short or shortest way to a point or end; as, a direct line; direct means.
sn.q: What is direct to, what slides by, the question.

sn.def: Straightforward; not of crooked ways, or swerving from truth and openness; sincere; outspoken.
sn.q: Be even and direct with me.

sn.def: Immediate; express; plain; unambiguous.
sn.q: He nowhere, that I know, says it in direct words.
A direct and avowed interference with elections.

sn.def: In the line of descent; not collateral; as, a descendant in the direct line.
In the direction of the general planetary motion, or from west to east; in the order of the signs; not retrograde; -- said of the motion of a celestial body.
Pertaining to, or effected immediately by, action of the people through their votes instead of through one or more representatives or delegates; as, direct nomination, direct legislation.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Directed; p. pr. & vb. n. Directing

sn.def: To arrange in a direct or straight line, as against a mark, or towards a goal; to point; to aim; as, to direct an arrow or a piece of ordnance.
To point out or show to (any one), as the direct or right course or way; to guide, as by pointing out the way; as, he directed me to the left-hand road.
sn.q: The Lord direct your into the love of God.
The next points to which I will direct your attention.

sn.def: To determine the direction or course of; to cause to go on in a particular manner; to order in the way to a certain end; to regulate; to govern; as, to direct the affairs of a nation or the movements of an army.
sn.q: I will direct their work in truth.

sn.def: To point out to with authority; to instruct as a superior; to order; as, he directed them to go.
sn.q: I 'll first direct my men what they shall do.

sn.def: To put a direction or address upon; to mark with the name and residence of the person to whom anything is sent; to superscribe; as, to direct a letter.
sn.syn: To guide; lead; conduct; dispose; manage; regulate; order; instruct; command.

entry.def: To give direction; to point out a course; to act as guide.
entry.q: Wisdom is profitable to direct.

entry.def: A character, thus [�], placed at the end of a staff on the line or space of the first note of the next staff, to apprise the performer of its situation.

cs.cd: one in which motion is transmitted to the crank without the intervention of a beam or lever; -- also called direct-action steam engine.
one in which the steam piston rod is directly connected with the pump rod; -- also called direct-action steam pump.

entry.def: Acting directly, as one part upon another, without the intervention of other working parts.

cs.cd: an antenna connected electrically with one point of a closed oscillation circuit in syntony with it and earthed.

entry.def: Coupled without intermediate connections, as an engine and a dynamo.

entries.entry:
Direct current. Elec A current flowing in one direction only; -- distinguished from alternating current. When steady and not pulsating a direct current is often called a continuous current.
A direct induced current, or momentary current of the same direction as the inducing current, produced by stopping or removing the latter; also, a similar current produced by removal of a magnet.

sn.def: having a specified direction; often used in combination; as, goal-directed .
marked with a destination; -- of mail or parcels; as, I throw away all mail directed to `resident'. Opposite of unaddressed.

cs.cd: the plane to which all right-lined elements in a warped surface are parallel.

entry.def: One who directs; a director.

entry.usage: Direction Control Command Order. These words, as here compared, have reference to the exercise of power over the actions of others. Control is negative, denoting power to restrain; command is positive, implying a right to enforce obedience; directions are commands containing instructions how to act. Order conveys more prominently the idea of authority than the word direction. A shipmaster has the command of his vessel; he gives orders or directions to the seamen as to the mode of sailing it; and exercises a due control over the passengers.
entry.ety: L. directio: cf. F. direction

sn.def: The act of directing, of aiming, regulating, guiding, or ordering; guidance; management; superintendence; administration; as, the direction o� public affairs or of a bank.
sn.q: I do commit his youth To your direction.
All nature is but art, unknown to thee; ll chance, direction, which thou canst not see.

sn.def: That which is imposed by directing; a guiding or authoritative instruction; prescription; order; command; as, he grave directions to the servants.
sn.q: The princes digged the well . . . by the direction of the law giver.

sn.def: The name and residence of a person to whom any thing is sent, written upon the thing sent; superscription; address; as, the direction of a letter.

The line or course upon which anything is moving or aimed to move, or in which anything is lying or pointing; aim; line or point of tendency; direct line or course; as, the ship sailed in a southeasterly direction .
The body of managers of a corporation or enterprise; board of directors.
The pointing of a piece with reference to an imaginary vertical axis; -- distinguished from elevation. The direction is given when the plane of sight passes through the object.
sn.syn: Administration; guidance; management; superintendence; oversight; government; order; command; guide; clew.

sn.def: of or pertaining to direction (definition 2).
serving to indicate direction.

transmitting radio signals in a specific direction, or receiving signals only from a narrow angle of directions, thus serving to indicate the direction from which radio signals are coming. Used of antennas; as, a directional antenna.

entry.def: the property of a microphone or antenna of being more sensitive to signal arriving from one direction than from another.

sn.def: purposeless. Opposite of purposeful.
sn.syn: adrift(predicate), afloat(predicate), aimless, planless, rudderless, undirected.

entry.ety: LL. directivus: cf. F. directif

sn.def: Having power to direct; tending to direct, guide, or govern; showing the way.
sn.q: The precepts directive of our practice in relation to God.

sn.def: Able to be directed; manageable.
sn.q: Swords and bowsDirective by the limbs.

entry.def: the property of a microphone or antenna of being more sensitive to sounds coming from one direction than from another.

entry.note: ☞ This use of the word is common in England, especially in colloquial speech, but it can hardly be regarded as a well-sanctioned or desirable use.

cs.cd: proportional in the order of the terms; increasing or decreasing together, and with a constant ratio; -- opposed to inversely proportional.

entry.usage: Directly Immediately Instantly Instantaneously. Directly denotes, without any delay or diversion of attention; immediately implies, without any interposition of other occupation; instantly implies, without any intervention of time. Hence, “I will do it directly,” means, “I will go straightway about it.” “I will do it immediately,” means, “I will do it as the very next thing.” “I will do it instantly,” allows not a particle of delay. Instantaneously, like instantly, marks an interval too small to be appreciable, but commonly relates to physical causes; as, the powder touched by fire instantaneously exploded.

sn.def: In a direct manner; in a straight line or course.
sn.q: To rundirectlyon.
Indirectly and directly too Thou hast contrived against the very life Of the defendant.

sn.def: In a straightforward way; without anything intervening; not by secondary, but by direct, means.
Without circumlocution or ambiguity; absolutely; in express terms.
sn.q: No man hath hitherto been so impious as plainly and directly to condemn prayer.

sn.def: Exactly; just.
sn.q: Stand you directly in Antonius' way.

sn.def: Straightforwardly; honestly.
sn.q: I have dealt most directly in thy affair.

sn.def: Manifestly; openly.
sn.q: Desdemona is directly in love with him.

sn.def: Straightway; next in order; without delay; immediately.
sn.q: Will she go now to bed?' �Directly.'

sn.def: Immediately after; as soon as.
sn.q: Directly he stopped, the coffin was removed.
sn.syn: Immediately; forthwith; straightway; instantly; instantaneously; soon; promptly; openly; expressly.

entry.def: The quality of being direct; straightness; straightforwardness; immediateness.

entries.entry: Direct nomination. Political Science The nomination or designation of candidates for public office by direct popular vote rather than through the action of a convention or body of elected nominating representatives or delegates. The term is applied both to the nomination of candidates without any nominating convention, and, loosely, to the nomination effected, as in the case of candidates for president or senator of the United States, by the election of nominating representatives pledged or instructed to vote for certain candidates dssignated by popular vote.
Di`rec`toire" style. Dressmaking A style of dress prevalent at the time of the French Directory, characterized by great extravagance of design and imitating the Greek and Roman costumes.

entry.ety: Cf. F. directeur

sn.def: One who, or that which, directs; one who regulates, guides, or orders; a manager or superintendent.
sn.q: In all affairs thou sole director.

sn.def: One of a body of persons appointed to manage the affairs of a company or corporation; as, the directors of a bank, insurance company, or railroad company.
sn.q: What made directors cheat in South-Sea year?

sn.def: A part of a machine or instrument which directs its motion or action.
A slender grooved instrument upon which a knife is made to slide when it is wished to limit the extent of motion of the latter, or prevent its injuring the parts beneath.

entry.ety: Cf. F. directorat
entry.def: The office of director; also, a body of directors taken jointly.

entry.ety: Cf. F. directorial

sn.def: Having the quality of a director, or authoritative guide; directive.
Pertaining to: director or directory; specifically, relating to the Directory of France under the first republic. See Directory, 3.
sn.q: Whoever goes to the directorial presence under this passport.

entry.def: The condition or office of a director; directorate.

entry.ety: L. directorius
entry.def: Containing directions; enjoining; instructing; directorial.

entries.entry:
Di*rect"o*ry n.; pl.Directories.
A collection or body of directions, rules, or ordinances; esp., a book of directions for the conduct of worship; as, the Directory used by the nonconformists instead of the Prayer Book.
A book containing the names and residences of the inhabitants of any place, or of classes of them; an address book; as, a business directory .
Cf. F. directoire
A body of directors; board of management; especially, a committee which held executive power in France under the first republic.
Direction; guide. R
Direct primary. Political Science A primary by which direct nominations of candidates for office are made.

entry.def: A woman who directs.

entries.entry:
Di*rect"rix n.; pl. E. Directrixes, L. Directrices.
A directress. R
Geom
A line along which a point in another line moves, or which in any way governs the motion of the point and determines the position of the curve generated by it; the line along which the generatrix moves in generating a surface.
A straight line so situated with respect to a conic section that the distance of any point of the curve from it has a constant ratio to the distance of the same point from the focus.

entry.ety: Dire + -ful
entry.def: Dire; dreadful; terrible; calamitous; woeful; as, a direful fiend; a direful day.

entry.ety: L. diremptus, p. p. of dirimere to take apart, separate; di- = dis- + emere to buy, orig., to take
entry.def: Divided; separated.
To separate by force; to tear apart.

entry.ety: L. diremptio
entry.def: A tearing apart; violent separation.

entry.ety: Dire- + -ness
entry.def: Terribleness; horror; woefulness.

entry.ety: L. direptio, fr. diripere to tear asunder, plunder; di- = dis- + rapere to seize and carry off
entry.def: The act of plundering, despoiling, or snatching away.
Characterized by direption.
With plundering violence; by violent injustice.

entry.ety: Contraction of Lat. dirige, direct thou (imperative of dirigere), the first word of a funeral hymn (Lat. transl. of Psalm v. 8) beginning, “Dirige Domine in conspectu tuo vitam meam.” See Direct a., and cf. Dirige

entry.q: The raven croaked, and hollow shrieks of owls Sung dirges at her funeral.

entry.def: Funereal; moaning.

The line of motion along which a describent line or surface is carried in the genesis of any plane or solid figure; a directrix.
Capable of being directed; steerable; as, a dirigible balloon.

entry.ety: L. dirigere to direct
entry.def: The practice or inclination to direct (activities) by a central authority; as, the linguistic dirigisme of prescriptivists clashes with the modern tendency toward acceptance of multiculturalism. See also dirigiste.

To darken.
Darkness.

entry.cs: Dirt bed Geom a layer of clayey earth forming a stratum in a geological formation. Dirt beds are common among the coal measures. Dirt eating. The use of certain kinds of clay for food, existing among some tribes of Indians; geophagism. Humboldt. Med Same as Chthonophagia. Dirt pie clay or mud molded by children in imitation of pastry. Otway (1684). To eat dirt to submit in a meanly humble manner to insults; to eat humble pie.
entry.ety: OE. drit; kin to Icel. drit excrement, drīta to dung, OD. drijten to dung, AS. gedrītan

sn.q: Honors . . . thrown away upon dirt and infamy.

sn.def: In placer mining, earth, gravel, etc., before washing.

costing much less than standard price; as, the store went out of business and sold their remaining stock for dirt-cheap prices.
In a dirty manner; foully; nastily; filthily; meanly; sordidly.
The state of being dirty; filthiness; foulness; nastiness; baseness; sordidness.

sn.def: Defiled with dirt; foul; nasty; filthy; not clean or pure; serving to defile; as, dirty hands; dirty water; a dirty white.

Sordid; base; groveling; as, a dirty fellow.

entry.note: ☞ Walker's rule of pronouncing this prefix is, that the s ought always to be pronounced like z, when the next syllable is accented and begins with “a flat mute [b d v g z], a liquid [l m n r], or a vowel; as, disable disease disorder disuse disband disdain disgrace disvalue disjoin dislike dislodge dismay dismember dismiss dismount disnatured disrank disrelish disrobe.” Dr. Webster's example in disapproving of Walker's rule and pronouncing dis-as diz in only one (disease) of the above words, is followed by recent orthoëpists. See Disable Disgrace, and the other words, beginning with dis-, in this Dictionary.

sn.def: A prefix from the Latin, whence F. dés, or sometimes dé- dis-. The Latin dis-appears as di-before b d g l m n r v, becomes dif-before f, and either dis-or di- before j. It is from the same root as bis twice, and duo, E. two. See Two, and cf. Bi- Di- Dia-. Dis- denotes separation a parting from, as in distribute, disconnect; hence it often has the force of a privative and negative, as in disarm, disoblige, disagree. Also intensive, as in dissever.
A prefix from Gr. di`s- twice. See Di-.

entry.ety: L
entry.def: The god Pluto, god of the underworld; also called Dis Pater.

entry.ety: shortened from disrespect
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. dissed; p. pr. & vb. n. dissing
entry.def: to treat in a disrespectful manner; to insult, disparage or belittle.
any orchid of the genus Disa, a genus of beautiful orchids with dark green leaves and usually hooded flowers; -- they are much prized as emblematic flowers in their native regions.

entries.entry:
dis`a*bil"i*ty
Disability Inability. Inability is an inherent want of power to perform the thing in question; disability arises from some deprivation or loss of the needed competency. One who becomes deranged is under a disability of holding his estate; and one who is made a judge, of deciding in his own case. A man may decline an office on account of his inability to discharge its duties; he may refuse to accept a trust or employment on account of some disability prevents him from entering into such engagements. n.; pl.Disabilities.
State of being disabled; deprivation or want of ability; absence of competent physical, intellectual, or moral power, means, fitness, and the like. Grossest faults, or disabilities to perform what was covenanted. Chatham refused to see him, pleading his disability.
Want of legal qualification to do a thing; legal incapacity or incompetency. The disabilities of idiocy, infancy, and coverture. Weakness; inability; incompetence; impotence; incapacity; incompetency; disqualification.

entry.def: Lacking ability; unable.
entry.q: Ourdisableand unactive force.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Disabled; p. pr. & vb. n. Disabling

sn.def: To render unable or incapable; to destroy the force, vigor, or power of action of; to deprive of competent physical or intellectual power; to incapacitate; to disqualify; to make incompetent or unfit for service; to impair.
sn.q: A Christian's life is a perpetual exercise, a wrestling and warfare, for which sensual pleasure disables him.
And had performed it, if my known offense Had not disabled me.
I have disabled mine estate.

sn.def: To deprive of legal right or qualification; to render legally incapable.
sn.q: An attainder of the ancestor corrupts the blood, and disables his children to inherit.

sn.def: To deprive of that which gives value or estimation; to declare lacking in competency; to disparage; to undervalue.
sn.q: Hedisabledmy judgment.

sn.def: injured so as to be unable to function; as, disabled veterans.
sn.syn: hors de combat, out of action.

sn.def: unable to function at normal capacity.

entry.def: Deprivation of ability; incapacity.

sn.def: causing or having caused disability; rendering disabled; as, disabling injury.
depriving of legal right; rendering legally disqualified; as, certain disabling restrictions disqualified him for citizenship.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Disabused; p. pr. & vb. n. Disabusing
entry.ety: Pref. dis- + abuse; cf. F. désabuser
entry.def: To set free from mistakes; to undeceive; to disengage from fallacy or deception; to set right; -- often used with of; as, to disabuse one of his illusions.
entry.q: To undeceive and disabuse the people.
If men are now sufficiently enlightened to disabuse themselves or artifice, hypocrisy, and superstition, they will consider this event as an era in their history.

entry.ety: Pref. dis- + accommodate
entry.def: To put to inconvenience; to incommode.
A state of being unaccommodated or unsuited.

entry.ety: Cf. F. désaccorder to cause discord
entry.def: To refuse to assent.
Disagreement.
Not accordant.

entry.ety: Cf. F. désaccoutumer
entry.def: To destroy the force of habit in; to wean from a custom.
To free from acid.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Disacknowledged; p. pr. & vb. n. Disacknowledging
entry.def: To refuse to acknowledge; to deny; to disown.

entry.ety: Pref. dis- + acquaint: cf. OF. desacointier
entry.def: To render unacquainted; to make unfamiliar.
entry.q: While my sick heart With dismal smart Is disacquainted never.

entry.def: Neglect of disuse of familiarity, or familiar acquaintance.

entry.ety: Pref. dis-Gr. di`s- twice) + acrolein + -yl
entry.def: A white amorphous substance obtained as a polymeric modification of acrolein.
To deprive of ornaments.

entry.ety: Pref. dis- + advance: cf. OF. desavancier
entry.def: To draw back, or cause to draw back.

entry.ety: Cf. F. désavantage

sn.def: Deprivation of advantage; unfavorable or prejudicial quality, condition, circumstance, or the like; that which hinders success, or causes loss or injury.
sn.q: I was brought here under the disadvantage of being unknown by sight to any of you.
Abandoned by their great patron, the faction henceforward acted at disadvantage.

sn.def: Loss; detriment; hindrance; prejudice to interest, fame, credit, profit, or other good.
sn.q: They would throw a construction on his conduct, to his disadvantage before the public.

entry.ety: Cf. F. désavantager
entry.def: To injure the interest of; to be detrimental to.
Injurious; disadvantageous.

entry.ety: Cf. F. désavantageux
entry.def: Attended with disadvantage; unfavorable to success or prosperity; inconvenient; prejudicial; -- opposed to advantageous; as, the situation of an army is disadvantageous for attack or defense.
entry.q: Even in the disadvantageous position in which he had been placed, he gave clear indications of future excellence.

entry.ety: Pref. dis- + adventure: cf. OF. desaventure
entry.def: Misfortune; mishap.
Unprosperous; unfortunate.
To advise against; to dissuade from.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Disaffected; p. pr. & vb. n. Disaffecting

sn.def: To alienate or diminish the affection of; to make unfriendly or less friendly; to fill with discontent and unfriendliness.
sn.q: They had attempted to disaffect and discontent his majesty's late army.

sn.def: To disturb the functions of; to disorder.
sn.q: It disaffects the bowels.

sn.def: To lack affection for; to be alienated from, or indisposed toward; to dislike.

entry.def: Alienated in feeling; not wholly loyal.

sn.def: State of being disaffected; alienation or want of affection or good will, esp. toward those in authority; unfriendliness; dislike.
sn.q: In the making laws, princes must have regard to . . . the affections and disaffections of the people.

sn.def: Disorder; bad constitution.
sn.syn: Dislike; disgust; discontent; unfriendliness; alienation; disloyalty; hostility.

entry.def: Not disposed to affection; unfriendly; disaffected.

sn.def: To assert the contrary of; to contradict; to deny; -- said of that which has been asserted.
To refuse to confirm; to annul, as a judicial decision, by a contrary judgment of a superior tribunal.
The act of disaffirming; denial; negation.
Overthrow or annulment by the decision of a superior tribunal; as, disaffirmance of judgment.

entry.def: The act of disaffirming; negation; refutation.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Disafforested; p. pr. & vb. n. Disafforesting
entry.ety: Pref. dis- + afforest: cf. OF. desaforester
entry.def: To reduce from the privileges of a forest to the state of common ground; to exempt from forest laws.
entry.q: By charter 9 Henry III. many forests were disafforested.

entry.def: To destroy the aggregation of; to separate into component parts, as an aggregate mass.

entry.ety: Cf. F. désagrégation
entry.def: The separation of an aggregate body into its component parts.

entry.note: ☞ Usually followed by with, sometimes by to, rarely by from; as, I disagree to your proposal.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Disagreed dĭs`ȧ*grēd"; p. pr. & vb. n. Disagreeing
entry.ety: Pref. dis- + agree: cf. F. désagréer to displease

sn.def: To fail to accord; not to agree; to lack harmony; to differ; to be unlike; to be at variance.
sn.q: They reject the plainest sense of Scripture, because it seems to disagree with what they call reason.

sn.def: To differ in opinion; to hold discordant views; to be at controversy; to quarrel.
sn.q: Who shall decide, when doctors disagree?

sn.def: To be unsuited; to have unfitness; as, medicine sometimes disagrees with the patient; food often disagrees with the stomach or the taste.

entry.ety: Cf. F. désagréable

sn.def: Not agreeable, conformable, or congruous; contrary; unsuitable.
sn.q: Preach you truly the doctrine which you have received, and each nothing that is disagreeable thereunto.

sn.def: Exciting repugnance; offensive to the feelings or senses; displeasing; unpleasant.
sn.q: That which is disagreeable to one is many times agreeable to another, or disagreeable in a less degree.

entry.def: The state or quality of being; disagreeable; unpleasantness.
In a disagreeable manner; unsuitably; offensively.
Disagreement.

entry.ety: Cf. F. désagrément disagreeable circumstance, disagreeableness

sn.def: The state of disagreeing; a being at variance; dissimilitude; diversity.
Unsuitableness; unadaptedness.
Difference of opinion or sentiment.
A falling out, or controversy; difference.
sn.syn: Difference; diversity; dissimilitude; unlikeness; discrepancy; variance; dissent; misunderstanding; dissension; division; dispute; jar; wrangle; discord.

entry.def: One who disagrees.
To alienate from allegiance.

entry.note: ☞ This verb was sometimes followed by of; as, “What follows, if we disallow of this?” Shak. See Allow.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Disallowed; p. pr. & vb. n. Disallowing
entry.ety: Pref. dis- + allow: cf. OF. desalouer desloer, to blame, dissuade
entry.def: To refuse to allow; to deny the force or validity of; to disown and reject; as, the judge disallowed the executor's charge.
entry.q: To whom coming, as unto a living stone, disallowed indeed of men, but chosen of God.
That the edicts of Cæsar we may at all times disallow, but the statutes of God for no reason we may reject.

entry.def: Not allowable; not to be suffered.
The act of disallowing; refusal to admit or permit; rejection.

entry.ety: Pref. dis- + ally: cf. F. désaltier
entry.def: To part, as an alliance; to sunder.
entry.q: Disalliedtheir nuptials.

entry.ety: Pref. dis- + anchor: cf. F. désancrer
entry.def: To raise the anchor of, as a ship; to weigh anchor.
Not angelical.
entry.q: Disangelicalnature.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Disanimated; p. pr. & vb. n. Disanimating

sn.def: To deprive of life.
To deprive of spirit; to dishearten.
Privation of life.
The state of being disanimated or discouraged; depression of spirits.

entry.def: To disunite; to undo or repeal the annexation of.
