entry.note: ☞ The prefix in this word an its derivatives is intensive, and not negative.
entry.def: To annul completely; to render void or of no effect.
entry.q: For the Lord of hosts hath purposed, and who shall disannul it?

entry.def: One who disannuls.
Complete annulment.
To invalidate the consecration of; as, to disanoint a king.

entry.ety: See Apparel v. t.
Pref. dis- + apparel: cf. OF. desapareiller
entry.def: To disrobe; to strip of apparel; to make naked.
entry.q: Drink disapparels the soul.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Disappeared; p. pr. & vb. n. Disappearing

sn.def: To cease to appear or to be perceived; to pass from view, gradually or suddenly; to vanish; to be no longer seen; as, darkness disappears at the approach of light; a ship disappears as she sails from port.
To cease to be or exist; as, the epidemic has disappeared .

entry.def: The act of disappearing; cessation of appearance; removal from sight; vanishing.

cs.cd: a carriage for heavy coast guns on which the gun is raised above the parapet for firing and upon discharge is lowered behind the parapet for protection. The standard type of disappearing carriage in the coast artillery of the United States army is the Buffington-Crozier carriage , in which the gun trunnions are secured at the upper and after ends of a pair of heavy levers, at the lower ends of which is attached a counterweight of lead. The levers are pivoted at their middle points, which are, with the top carriage, permitted restrained motion along the slightly inclined chassis rails. The counterweight is held in place by a pawl and ratchet. When the gun is loaded the pawl is released and the counterweight sinks, raising the gun to the firing position above the parapet. The recoil following the discharge returns the gun to the loading position, the counterweight rising until the pawl engages the ratchet.

entry.def: p. pr. & vb. n. of Disappear.
A detachment or separation from a former connection.
Freed from a former connection or dependence; disconnected.

entry.note: ☞ Disappointed of a thing not obtained; disappointed in a thing obtained.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Disapointed; p. pr. & vb. n. Disappointing
entry.ety: OF. desapointier, F. désappointer; pref. des-L. dis-) + apointier, F. appointier, to appoint. See Appoint

sn.def: To defeat of expectation or hope; to hinder from the attainment of that which was expected, hoped, or desired; to balk; as, a man is disappointed of his hopes or expectations, or his hopes, desires, intentions, expectations, or plans are disappointed; a bad season disappoints the farmer of his crops; a defeat disappoints an enemy of his spoil.
sn.q: I was disappointed, but very agreeably.

sn.def: To frustrate; to fail; to hinder of result.
sn.q: His retiring foe Shrinks from the wound, and disappoints the blow.
sn.syn: To tantalize; fail; frustrate; balk; baffle; delude; foil; defeat. See Tantalize.

sn.def: Defeated of expectation or hope; balked; as, a disappointed person or hope.
Unprepared; unequipped.
sn.q: Cut off even in the blossoms of my sin, Unhouseled, disappointed, unaneled.

entry.def: defeating one's expectations or hopes; failing to fulfill one's expectations or hopes; as, a disappointing result; a disappointing crop yield.
the act of disappointing someone.

entry.ety: Cf. F. désappointement

sn.def: The act of disappointing, or the state of being disappointed; defeat or failure of expectation or hope; miscarriage of design or plan; frustration.
sn.q: If we hope for things of which we have not thoroughly considered the value, our disappointment will be greater than our pleasure in the fruition of them.
In disappointment thou canst bless.

sn.def: That which disappoints.

entry.ety: See Appreciate
entry.def: To undervalue; not to esteem.

entry.ety: Pref. dis- + approbation: cf. F. désapprobation. Cf. Disapprove
entry.def: The act of disapproving; mental condemnation of what is judged wrong, unsuitable, or inexpedient; feeling of censure.
entry.q: We have ever expressed the most unqualified disapprobation of all the steps.

entry.def: Containing disapprobation; serving to disapprove.
Severed from the appropriation or possession of a spiritual corporation.
entry.q: The appropriation may be severed, and the church become disappropriate, two ways.

sn.def: To release from individual ownership or possession.
To sever from appropriation or possession a spiritual corporation.
sn.q: Appropriations of the several parsonages . . . would heave been, by the rules of the common law, disappropriated.

entry.def: The act of disappropriating.
Disapprobation; dislike; censure; adverse judgment.

entry.note: ☞ This verb is often followed by of; as, to disapprove of an opinion, of such conduct. See Approve.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Disapproved; p. pr. & vb. n. Disapproving
entry.ety: Pref. dis- + approve: cf. F. déapprouver. Cf. Disapprobation

sn.def: To pass unfavorable judgment upon; to condemn by an act of the judgment; to regard as wrong, unsuitable, or inexpedient; to censure; as, to disapprove the conduct of others.
To refuse official approbation to; to disallow; to decline to sanction; as, the sentence of the court-martial was disapproved by the commander in chief.

entry.def: One who disapproves.
expressing disapproval.
In a disapproving manner.
See Dizzard.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Disarming; p. pr. & vb. n. Disarming
entry.ety: OE. desarmen, F. désarmer; pref. dés-L. dis-) + armer to arm. See Arm

sn.def: To deprive of arms; to take away the weapons of; to deprive of the means of attack or defense; to render defenseless.
sn.q: Security disarms the best-appointed army.
The proud was half disarmed of pride.

sn.def: To deprive of the means or the disposition to harm; to render harmless or innocuous; as, to disarm a man's wrath.

entry.ety: Cf. F. désarmement
entry.def: The act of disarming.

entry.ety: Pref. dis- + armature
entry.def: The act of divesting of armature.

sn.def: Deprived of arms.
Deprived of claws, and teeth or beaks.

entry.def: One who disarms.

sn.def: capable of allaying suspicion or hostility and inspiring confidence; as, a disarming smile.
capable of allaying hostility.

entry.def: act of reducing or depriving of weapons.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Disarranged; p. pr. & vb. n. Disarranging
entry.ety: Pref. dis- + arrange: cf. F. désarranger
entry.def: To unsettle or disturb the order or due arrangement of; to throw out of order.
having the arrangement disturbed; not put in order; as, her disarranged hair. Opposite of arranged.
The act of disarranging, or the state of being disarranged; confusion; disorder.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Disarrayed; p. pr. & vb. n. Disarraying
entry.ety: Pref. dis- + array, v.: cf. OF. desarroyer desarreier

sn.def: To throw into disorder; to break the array of.
sn.q: Who with fiery steeds Oft disarrayed the foes in battle ranged.

sn.def: To take off the dress of; to unrobe.
sn.q: So, as she bade, the witch they disarrayed.

entry.ety: Cf. F. désarroi

sn.def: Want of array or regular order; disorder; confusion.
sn.q: Disrank the troops, set all in disarray.

sn.def: Confused attire; undress.

entry.def: Disorder.
To sunder; to separate, as joints.
One who disarticulates and prepares skeletons.

sn.def: to take apart; to disconnect the parts of; to convert a whole into its constituent pieces.
to convert a computer program in machine language into an equivalent assembly-language file.

entry.def: to be able to come apart easily; to be converted into constituent parts; as, the rifle disassembles into small pieces for concealment.
a computer program that takes as input a computer program in machine language and produces an equivalent assembly-language file.
To dissent.
Dissent.
One who disassents; a dissenter.
Want of assiduity or care.
To subject to disassimilation.

The decomposition of complex substances, within the organism, into simpler ones suitable only for excretion, with evolution of energy, -- a normal nutritional process the reverse of assimilation; downward metabolism; -- now more commonly called catabolism.
entry.q: The breaking down of already existing chemical compounds into simpler ones, sometimes called disassimilation.

entry.def: Having power to disassimilate; of the nature of disassimilation.
entry.q: Disassimilative processes constitute a marked feature in the life of animal cells.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Disassociated; p. pr. & vb. n. Disassociating
entry.def: To disconnect from things associated; to disunite; to dissociate.

entry.ety: F. désastre; pref. dés-L. dis-) + astre star, fr. L. astrum; a word of astrological origin. See Aster Astral Star

sn.def: An unpropitious or baleful aspect of a planet or star; malevolent influence of a heavenly body; hence, an ill portent.
sn.q: Disasters in the sun.

sn.def: An adverse or unfortunate event, esp. a sudden and extraordinary misfortune; a calamity; a serious mishap.
sn.q: But noble souls, through dust and heat, Rise from disaster and defeat The stronger.
sn.syn: Calamity; misfortune; mishap; mischance; visitation; misadventure; ill luck. See Calamity.

sn.def: To blast by the influence of a baleful star.
To bring harm upon; to injure.

entry.def: Disastrously.

entry.ety: Cf. F. désastreux. See Disaster

sn.def: Full of unpropitious stellar influences; unpropitious; ill-boding.
sn.q: The moon In dim eclipse, disastrous twilight sheds.

sn.def: Attended with suffering or disaster; very unfortunate; calamitous; ill-fated; ending in utter failure or ruin; as, a disastrous day; a disastrous termination of an undertaking.
sn.q: Wherein I spake of most disastrous chances.

entry.ety: Pref. dis- + attire: cf. OF. desatirier
entry.def: To unrobe; to undress.
To diminish.
To deprive of credit or authority; to discredit.

entry.ety: Cf. Disadvance
entry.def: To retard; to repel; to do damage to.

entry.ety: See Disadventure Adventure
entry.def: Misfortune.
Misadventurous; unfortunate.

entry.ety: Pref. dis- + avouch. Cf. Disavow
entry.def: To disavow.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Disavowed; p. pr. & vb. n. Disavowing
entry.ety: F. désavouer; pref. dés-L. dis-) + avouer to avow. See Avow, and cf. Disavouch

sn.def: To refuse strongly and solemnly to own or acknowledge; to deny responsibility for, approbation of, and the like; to disclaim; to disown; as, he was charged with embezzlement, but he disavows the crime.
sn.q: A solemn promise made and disavowed.

sn.def: To deny; to show the contrary of; to disprove.
sn.q: Yet can they never Toss into air the freedom of my birth, Or disavow my blood Plantagenet's.

entry.def: able to be disavowed.
The act of disavowing, disclaiming, or disowning; rejection and denial.
entry.q: An earnest disavowal of fear often proceeds from fear.

entry.def: Disavowal.
One who disavows.
Disavowal.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Disbanded; p. pr. & vb. n. Disbanding
entry.ety: Pref. dis- + band: cf. OF. desbander, F. débander, to unbind, unbend. See Band, and cf. Disbend Disbind

sn.def: To loose the bands of; to set free; to disunite; to scatter; to disperse; to break up the organization of; especially, to dismiss from military service; as, to disband an army.
sn.q: They disbanded themselves and returned, every man to his own dwelling.

sn.def: To divorce.
sn.q: And therefore . . . she ought to be disbanded.

entry.def: To become separated, broken up, dissolved, or scattered; especially, to quit military service by breaking up organization.
entry.q: When both rocks and all things shall disband.
Human society would in a short space disband.

entry.def: The act of disbanding.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Disbarred; p. pr. & vb. n. Disbarring
entry.def: To expel from the bar, or the legal profession; to deprive (an attorney, barrister, or counselor) of his status and privileges as such.

entry.ety: Pref. dis- + bark a small ship: cf. OF. desbarquer, F. débarquer. Cf. Debark Disembark
entry.def: To disembark.

entry.ety: Pref. dis- + bark rind
entry.def: To strip of bark; to bark.
Act of disbarring.

entry.ety: Cf. Debase
entry.def: To debase or degrade.
entry.q: Nor you nor your house were so much as spoken of before I disbased myself.

entry.def: To misbecome.
The act of disbelieving;; a state of the mind in which one is fully persuaded that an opinion, assertion, or doctrine is not true; refusal of assent, credit, or credence; denial of belief.
entry.q: Our belief or disbelief of a thing does not alter the nature of the thing.
No sadder proof can be given by a man of his own littleness that disbelief in great men.
entry.syn: Distrust; unbelief; incredulity; doubt; skepticism.Disbelief Unbelief. Unbelief is a mere failure to admit; disbelief is a positive rejection. One may be an unbeliever in Christianity from ignorance or want of inquiry; a unbeliever has the proofs before him, and incurs the guilt of setting them aside. Unbelief is usually open to conviction; disbelief is already convinced as to the falsity of that which it rejects. Men often tell a story in such a manner that we regard everything they say with unbelief. Familiarity with the worst parts of human nature often leads us into a disbelief in many good qualities which really exist among men.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Disbelieved; p. pr. & vb. n. Disbelieving
entry.def: Not to believe; to refuse belief or credence to; to hold not to be true or actual.
entry.q: Assertions for which there is abundant positive evidence are often disbelieved, on account of what is called their improbability or impossibility.

entry.def: One who disbelieves, or refuses belief; an unbeliever. Specifically, one who does not believe the Christian religion.

sn.def: To drive from a bench or seat.
To deprive (a bencher) of his privileges.

entry.def: To unbend.

entry.ety: Cf. Disband
entry.def: To unbind; to loosen.

entry.ety: OE. desblamen, OF. desblasmer; pref. des-L. dis-) + blasmer, F. blâmer, to blame
entry.def: To clear from blame.
Disembodied.

entry.ety: Pref. dis- + F. bosquet grove
entry.def: Converting forest land into cleared or arable land; removal of a forest.

entry.ety: See Bowel v. t.
entry.def: To disembowel.

entry.ety: See Branch v.
entry.def: To divest of a branch or branches; to tear off.

entry.ety: See Bud v.
entry.def: To deprive of buds or shoots, as for training, or economizing the vital strength of a tree.

entry.ety: See Burden v. t.
Cf. Disburthen
entry.def: To rid of a burden; to free from a load borne or from something oppressive; to unload; to disencumber; to relieve.
entry.q: He did it to disburden a conscience.
My mediations . . . will, I hope, be more calm, being thus disburdened.

entry.def: To relieve one's self of a burden; to ease the mind.
To strip of burgeons or buds; to disbud.

cs.cd: an officer in any department of the public service who is charged with the duty of paying out public money.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Disbursed; p. pr. & vb. n. Disbursing
entry.ety: OF. desbourser, F. débourser; pref. des-L. dis-) + bourse purse. See Burse, and cf. Dispurse
entry.def: To pay out; to expend; -- usually from a public fund or treasury.
entry.q: The duty of collecting and disbursing his revenues.

entry.ety: Cf. F. déboursement

sn.def: The act of disbursing or paying out.
sn.q: The disbursement of the public moneys.

sn.def: That which is disbursed or paid out; as, the annual disbursements exceed the income.

entry.def: One who disburses money.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Disburthened; p. pr. & vb. n. Disburthening
entry.ety: Cf. Disburden
entry.def: To disburden; to relieve of a load.

entries.entry:
Disc dĭsk n. See Disk Dish
A flat round plate; Biol A circular structure either in plants or animals; as, a blood disc, a germinal disc, etc. Same as Disk.

entry.def: To uncage.
Pertaining to, or resembling, a disk; as, discal cells.

entry.ety: L. discalceatus unshod; dis- + calceus shoe
entry.def: To pull off shoes or sandals from.
Deprived off shoes or sandals; unshod; discalced.
The act of pulling off the shoes or sandals.
Unshod; barefooted; -- in distinction from calced.
entry.q: The foundation of houses ofdiscalcedfriars.

entry.ety: See Decamp
entry.def: To drive from a camp.
To melt; to dissolve; to thaw.
See Descant n.
To deprive of capacity; to incapacitate.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Discarded; p. pr. & vb. n. Discarding

sn.def: To throw out of one's hand, as superfluous cards; to lay aside (a card or cards).
To cast off as useless or as no longer of service; to dismiss from employment, confidence, or favor; to discharge; to turn away.
sn.q: They blame the favorites, and think it nothing extraordinary that the queen should . . . resolve to discard them.

sn.def: To put or thrust away; to reject.
sn.q: A man discards the follies of boyhood.

entry.def: To make a discard.
The act of discarding; also, the card or cards discarded.
Rejection; dismissal.

entry.ety: L. dis- + carnatus fleshy, fr. caro carnis, flesh
entry.def: Stripped of flesh.
entry.q: Discarnatebones.

entry.def: To strip; to undress.

entry.ety: L. discedere; dis- + cedere to yield
entry.def: To yield or give up; to depart.
entry.q: I dare not discede from my copy a tittle.

entry.ety: L. disceptare
entry.def: To debate; to discuss.
entry.q: One dissertates, he is candid; Two must discept, -- has distinguished.

entry.ety: L. disceptatio
entry.def: Controversy; disputation; discussion.
entry.q: Verbose janglings and endless disceptations.

entry.ety: L
entry.def: One who arbitrates or decides.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Discerned; p. pr. & vb. n. Discerning
entry.ety: F. discerner, L. discernere discretum; dis- + cernere to separate, distinguish. See Certain, and cf. Discreet

sn.def: To see and identify by noting a difference or differences; to note the distinctive character of; to discriminate; to distinguish.
sn.q: To discern such buds as are fit to produce blossoms.
A counterfeit stone which thine eye can not discern from a right stone.

sn.def: To see by the eye or by the understanding; to perceive and recognize; as, to discern a difference.
sn.q: And [I] beheld among the simple ones, I discerned among the youths, a young man void of understanding.
Our unassisted sight . . . is not acute enough to discern the minute texture of visible objects.
I wake, and I discern the truth.
sn.syn: To perceive; distinguish; discover; penetrate; discriminate; espy; descry; detect. See Perceive.

sn.def: To see or understand the difference; to make distinction; as, to discern between good and evil, truth and falsehood.
sn.q: More than sixscore thousand that cannot discern between their right hand their left.

sn.def: To make cognizance.

entry.def: Discernment.
One who, or that which, discerns, distinguishes, perceives, or judges; as, a discerner of truth, of right and wrong.
entry.q: A great observer and discerner of men's natures.

entry.ety: L. discernibilis
entry.def: Capable of being discerned by the eye or the understanding; as, a star is discernible by the eye; the identity of difference of ideas is discernible by the understanding.
entry.q: The effect of the privations and sufferings . . . was discernible to the last in his temper and deportment.
entry.syn: Perceptible; distinguishable; apparent; visible; evident; manifest.

entry.def: The quality of being discernible.
In a manner to be discerned; perceptibly; visibly.
Acute; shrewd; sagacious; sharp-sighted.
In a discerning manner; with judgment; judiciously; acutely.

entry.ety: Cf. F. discernement

sn.def: The act of discerning.

The power or faculty of the mind by which it distinguishes one thing from another; power of viewing differences in objects, and their relations and tendencies; penetrative and discriminate mental vision; acuteness; sagacity; insight; as, the errors of youth often proceed from the want of discernment .
sn.syn: Judgment; acuteness; discrimination; penetration; sagacity; insight.Discernment Penetration Discrimination. Discernment is keenness and accuracy of mental vision; penetration is the power of seeing deeply into a subject in spite of everything that intercepts the view; discrimination is a capacity of tracing out minute distinctions and the nicest shades of thought. A discerning man is not easily misled; one of a penetrating mind sees a multitude of things which escape others; a discriminating judgment detects the slightest differences.

entry.ety: L. discerpere discerptum; dis- + carpere to pluck

sn.def: To tear in pieces; to rend.
To separate; to disunite.

entry.def: Capability or liableness to be discerped.

entry.ety: See Discerp
entry.def: Capable of being discerped.

entry.ety: L. discerptio
entry.def: The act of pulling to pieces, or of separating the parts.
Tending to separate or disunite parts.

entry.ety: L. discessio, fr. discedere discessum. See Discede
entry.def: Departure.

cs.cd: an arch over a door, window, or other opening, to distribute the pressure of the wall above. See Illust. of Lintel.
a piece set to carry thrust or weight to a solid point of support.
a bent wire, with knobs at both ends, and insulated by a glass handle. It is employed for discharging a Leyden jar or an electrical battery. See Discharger.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Discharged; p. pr. & vb. n. Discharging
entry.ety: OE. deschargen dischargen, OF. deschargier, F. décharger; pref. des-L. dis) + chargier, F. charger. See Charge

sn.def: To relieve of a charge, load, or burden; to empty of a load or cargo; to unburden; to unload; as, to discharge a vessel.

To free of the missile with which anything is charged or loaded; to let go the charge of; as, to discharge a bow, catapult, etc.; especially, said of firearms, -- to fire off; to shoot off; also, to relieve from a state of tension, as a Leyden jar.
sn.q: The galleys also did oftentimes, out of their prows, discharge their great pieces against the city.
Feeling in other cases discharges itself in indirect muscular actions.

sn.def: To of something weighing upon or impeding over one, as a debt, claim, obligation, responsibility, accusation, etc.; to absolve; to acquit; to clear.
sn.q: Discharged of business, void of strife.
In one man's fault discharge another man of his duty.

sn.def: To relieve of an office or employment; to send away from service; to dismiss.
sn.q: Discharge the common sort With pay and thanks.
Grindal . . . was discharged the government of his see.

sn.def: To release legally from confinement; to set at liberty; as, to discharge a prisoner.
To put forth, or remove, as a charge or burden; to take out, as that with which anything is loaded or filled; as, to discharge a cargo.
To let fly, as a missile; to shoot.
sn.q: They do discharge their shot of courtesy.

sn.def: To set aside; to annul; to dismiss.
sn.q: We say such an order was “discharged on appeal.”
The order for Daly's attendance was discharged.

sn.def: To throw off the obligation of, as a duty or debt; to relieve one's self of, by fulfilling conditions, performing duty, trust, and the like; hence, to perform or execute, as an office, or part.
sn.q: Had I a hundred tongues, a wit so large As could their hundred offices discharge.

sn.def: To send away (a creditor) satisfied by payment; to pay one's debt or obligation to.
sn.q: If he had The present money to discharge the Jew.

sn.def: To give forth; to emit or send out; as, a pipe discharges water; to let fly; to give expression to; to utter; as, to discharge a horrible oath.
To prohibit; to forbid.
To bleach out or to remove or efface, as by a chemical process; as, to discharge the color from a dyed fabric in order to form light figures on a dark ground.

entry.def: To throw off or deliver a load, charge, or burden; to unload; to emit or give vent to fluid or other contents; as, the water pipe discharges freely.
entry.q: The cloud, if it were oily or fatty, would not discharge.

entry.cs:
Charge and discharge. Equity Practice See under Charge n.
Paralytic discharge Physiol the increased secretion from a gland resulting from the cutting of all of its nerves.
entry.ety: Cf. F. décharge. See Discharge v. t.

sn.def: The act of discharging; the act of relieving of a charge or load; removal of a load or burden; unloading; as, the discharge of a ship; discharge of a cargo.
Firing off; explosive removal of a charge; explosion; letting off; as, a discharge of arrows, of artillery.
Act of relieving of something which oppresses or weighs upon one, as an obligation, liability, debt, accusation, etc.; acquittance; as, the discharge of a debtor.
Act of removing, or getting rid of, an obligation, liability, etc.; fulfillment, as by the payment of a debt, or the performance of a trust or duty.
sn.q: Indefatigable in the discharge of business.
Nothing can absolve us from the discharge of those duties.

sn.def: Release or dismissal from an office, employment, etc.; dismission; as, the discharge of a workman by his employer.
Legal release from confinement; liberation; as, the discharge of a prisoner.
The state of being discharged or relieved of a debt, obligation, office, and the like; acquittal.
sn.q: Too secure of our discharge From penalty.

sn.def: That which discharges or releases from an obligation, liability, penalty, etc., as a price of ransom, a legal document.
sn.q: Death, who sets all free, Hath paid his ransom now and full discharge.

sn.def: A flowing or issuing out; emission; vent; evacuation; also, that which is discharged or emitted; as, a rapid discharge of water from the pipe.
sn.q: The hemorrhage being stopped, the next occurrence is a thin serous discharge.

sn.def: The equalization of a difference of electric potential between two points. The character of the discharge is mostly determined by the nature of the medium through which it takes place, the amount of the difference of potential, and the form of the terminal conductors on which the difference exists. The discharge may be alternating, continuous, brush, connective, disruptive, glow, oscillatory, stratified, etc.

entry.def: One who, or that which, discharges. Specifically, in electricity, an instrument for discharging a Leyden jar, or electrical battery, by making a connection between the two surfaces; a discharging rod.
Disheveled.
To deprive of status as a church, or of membership in a church.

entry.ety: L. discidere; dis- + caedere to cut
entry.def: To divide; to cleave in two.

entry.ety: Disc- + -ferous
entry.def: Bearing disks.

entry.ety: See Disk, and Floral
entry.def: Bearing the stamens on a discoid outgrowth of the receptacle; -- said of a subclass of plants. Cf. Calycifloral.
Discoid.

entry.ety: NL., fr. L. discus disk, Gr. �
entry.def: A genus of Branchiopoda, having a disklike shell, attached by one valve, which is perforated by the peduncle.

entry.ety: L. discinctus, p. p. of discingere to ungird; dis- + cingere to gird
entry.def: Ungirded; loosely dressed.

entry.ety: L. discindere; dis- + scindere to cut, split
entry.def: To part; to divide.

entry.cs:
The disciplesorThe twelve disciples
the twelve selected companions of Jesus; -- also called the apostles. Disciples of Christ. See Christian n., 3, and Campbellite.
entry.ety: OE. disciple deciple, OF. disciple, fr. L. discipulus, fr. discere to learn (akin to docere to teach; see Docile) + prob. a root meaning to turn or drive, as in L. pellere to drive (see Pulse)
entry.def: One who receives instruction from another; a scholar; a learner; especially, a follower who has learned to believe in the truth of the doctrine of his teacher; an adherent in doctrine; as, the disciples of Plato; the disciples of our Savior.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Discipled; p. pr. & vb. n. Discipling

sn.def: To teach; to train.
sn.q: That better were in virtues discipled.

sn.def: To punish; to discipline.
To make disciples of; to convert to doctrines or principles.
sn.q: Sending missionaries to disciple all nations.

entry.def: The state of being a disciple or follower in doctrines and precepts.
A female disciple.

entry.ety: Cf. F. disciplinable. See Discipline

sn.def: Capable of being disciplined or improved by instruction and training.
Liable or deserving to be disciplined; subject to disciplinary punishment; as, a disciplinable offense.

entry.def: The quality of being improvable by discipline.
Relating to discipline.

entry.ety: See Discipline
entry.def: A flagellant. See Flagellant.
Pertaining to discipline.
entry.q: Displinariansystem.

sn.def: One who disciplines; one who excels in training, especially with training, especially with regard to order and obedience; one who enforces rigid discipline; a stickler for the observance of rules and methods of training; as, he is a better disciplinarian than scholar.
A Puritan or Presbyterian; -- because of rigid adherence to religious or church discipline.

entry.ety: LL. disciplinarius flogging: cf. F. disciplinaire
entry.def: Pertaining to discipline; intended for discipline; corrective; belonging to a course of training.
entry.q: Those canons . . . were only disciplinary.
The evils of the . . . are disciplinary and remedial.

entry.ety: F. discipline, L. disciplina, from discipulus. See Disciple

sn.def: The treatment suited to a disciple or learner; education; development of the faculties by instruction and exercise; training, whether physical, mental, or moral.
sn.q: Wife and children are a kind of discipline of humanity.
Discipline aims at the removal of bad habits and the substitution of good ones, especially those of order, regularity, and obedience.

sn.def: Training to act in accordance with established rules; accustoming to systematic and regular action; drill.
sn.q: Their wildness lose, and, quitting nature's part, Obey the rules and discipline of art.

sn.def: Subjection to rule; submissiveness to order and control; habit of obedience.
sn.q: The most perfect, who have their passions in the best discipline, are yet obliged to be constantly on their guard.

sn.def: Severe training, corrective of faults; instruction by means of misfortune, suffering, punishment, etc.
sn.q: A sharp discipline of half a century had sufficed to educate us.

sn.def: Correction; chastisement; punishment inflicted by way of correction and training.
sn.q: Giving her the discipline of the strap.

sn.def: The subject matter of instruction; a branch of knowledge.
The enforcement of methods of correction against one guilty of ecclesiastical offenses; reformatory or penal action toward a church member.
Self-inflicted and voluntary corporal punishment, as penance, or otherwise; specifically, a penitential scourge.
A system of essential rules and duties; as, the Romish or Anglican discipline .
sn.syn: Education; instruction; training; culture; correction; chastisement; punishment.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Disciplined; p. pr. & vb. n. Disciplining
entry.ety: Cf. LL. disciplinarian to flog, fr. L. disciplina discipline, and F. discipliner to discipline

sn.def: To educate; to develop by instruction and exercise; to train.

To accustom to regular and systematic action; to bring under control so as to act systematically; to train to act together under orders; to teach subordination to; to form a habit of obedience in; to drill.
sn.q: Ill armed, and worse disciplined.
His mind . . . imperfectly disciplined by nature.

sn.def: To improve by corrective and penal methods; to chastise; to correct.
sn.q: Has he disciplined Aufidius soundly?

sn.def: To inflict ecclesiastical censures and penalties upon.
sn.syn: To train; form; teach; instruct; bring up; regulate; correct; chasten; chastise; punish.

entry.def: One who disciplines.
a person who plays records or compact disks of recorded music;

a person who selects and plays recorded music for broadcast over the radio, often making comments about the music or other topics and also announcing commercial advertising messages; also, one who plays recorded music at a dance or social gathering, especially as a profession.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Disclaimed; p. pr. & vb. n. Disclaiming

sn.def: To renounce all claim to deny; ownership of, or responsibility for; to disown; to disavow; to reject.
sn.q: He calls the gods to witness their offense;Disclaims the war, asserts his innocence.
He disclaims the authority of Jesus.

sn.def: To deny, as a claim; to refuse.
sn.q: The payment was irregularly made, if not disclaimed.

sn.def: To relinquish or deny having a claim; to disavow another's claim; to decline accepting, as an estate, interest, or office.

entry.cs:
Disclaim in Disclaim from
to disown; to disavow. Obs “Nature disclaims in thee.” Shak.
entry.def: To disavow or renounce all part, claim, or share.

sn.def: One who disclaims, disowns, or renounces.
A denial, disavowal, or renunciation, as of a title, claim, interest, estate, or trust; relinquishment or waiver of an interest or estate.
A public disavowal, as of pretensions, claims, opinions, and the like.

entry.def: A disavowing or disowning.
To disclaim; to expel.
entry.q: Money did lovedisclame.

entry.ety: From OE. disclaundre n., for sclandre esclandre, OF. esclandre. See Sclaundre Slander
entry.def: To injure one's good name; to slander.
To take off a cloak from; to uncloak.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Disclosed; p. pr. & vb. n. Disclosing
entry.ety: OE. desclosen disclosen, fr. disclos desclos, not shut in, open, OF. desclos, p. p. of desclore to open, F. déclore; pref. des-L. dis-) + clore to shut, fr. L. claudere to shut. See Close, and cf. Disclusion

sn.def: To unclose; to open; -- applied esp. to eggs in the sense of to hatch.
sn.q: The ostrich layeth her eggs under sand, where the heat of the discloseth them.

sn.def: To remove a cover or envelope from;; to set free from inclosure; to uncover.
sn.q: The shells being broken, . . . the stone included in them is thereby disclosed and set at liberty.

sn.def: To lay open or expose to view; to cause to appear; to bring to light; to reveal.
sn.q: How softly on the Spanish shore she plays,Disclosing rock, and slope, and forest brown!
Her lively looks a sprightly mind disclose.

sn.def: To make known, as that which has been kept secret or hidden; to reveal; to expose; as, events have disclosed his designs.
sn.q: If I disclose my passion, Our friendship 's an end.
sn.syn: To uncover; open; unveil; discover; reveal; divulge; tell; utter.

entry.def: Disclosure.
Represented with wings expanded; -- applied to doves and other birds not of prey.
One who discloses.

entry.ety: See Disclose v. t., and cf. Closure

sn.def: The act of disclosing, uncovering, or revealing; bringing to light; exposure.
sn.q: He feels it [his secret] beating at his heart, rising to his throat, and demanding disclosure.

sn.def: That which is disclosed or revealed.
sn.q: Were the disclosures of 1695 forgotten?

entry.def: To clear from clouds.
To divest of a clout.

entry.ety: L. disclusio, fr. discludere disclusum, to separate. See Disclose
entry.def: A shutting off; exclusion.

entry.ety: Pref. dis- + coast: cf. It. discostare
entry.def: To depart; to quit the coast (that is, the side or border) of anything; to be separated.
entry.q: As far as heaven and earth discoasted lie.
To discoast from the plain and simple way of speech.

entry.ety: Gr. � disk + � to grow
entry.def: Applied to a form of egg cleavage seen in osseous fishes, which occurs only in a small disk that separates from the rest of the egg.

entries.entry: Dis*cob"o*lus Dis*cob"o*lus ☞ The Discobolus of Myron was a famous statue of antiquity, and several copies or imitations of it have been preserved. n.; pl.Discoboli #. L., fr. Gr. �; � a discu + � to throw Fine Arts A thrower of the discus. A statue of an athlete holding the discus, or about to throw it.

entry.ety: See Discodactylia
entry.def: One of the tree frogs.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. � disk + � finger
entry.def: A division of amphibians having suctorial disks on the toes, as the tree frogs.
Having sucking disks on the toes, as the tree frogs.
Incoherent.

cs.cd: a compound flower, consisting of tubular florets only, as a tansy, lacking the rays which are seen in the daisy and sunflower.

entry.ety: Gr. � quoit-shaped, � a round plate, quoit + e'i^dos form, shape: cf. F. discoïde. See Disk
entry.def: Having the form of a disk, as those univalve shells which have the whorls in one plane, so as to form a disk, as the pearly nautilus.
Anything having the form of a discus or disk; particularly, a discoid shell.

entry.ety: Cf. F. discoïdal
entry.def: Disk-shaped; discoid.

entry.ety: Gr. � a round plate + -lith
entry.def: One of a species of coccoliths, having an oval discoidal body, with a thick strongly refracting rim, and a thinner central portion. One of them measures about 1/50000 of an inch in its longest diameter.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Discolored; p. pr. & vb. n. Discoloring
entry.ety: OE. descolouren, OF. descolorer, F. décolorer, fr. L. dis- + cololare coloratum, to color, color color. See Color

sn.def: To alter the natural hue or color of; to change to a different color; to stain; to tinge; as, a drop of wine will discolor water; silver is discolored by sea water.
To alter the true complexion or appearance of; to put a false hue upon.
sn.q: To discolor all your ideas.

entry.def: To discolor.

entry.ety: Cf. F. decoloration

sn.def: The act of discoloring, or the state of being discolored; alteration of hue or appearance.
A discolored spot; a stain.
Altered in color; stained; spotted or streaked with foreign matter.
Variegated; of divers colors.
sn.q: That ever wore discolored arms.

entry.def: same as discolor.
same as discolored; as, discoloured paneling.
to cause to be confused; confuse emotionally.
entry.syn: confuse, flurry, consternate, disconcert, put off, bewilder, bemuse, throw.

entry.def: confused; upset; as, the hecklers pelted the discombobulated speaker with anything that came to hand.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Discomfited; p. pr. & vb. n. Discomfiting
entry.ety: OF. desconfit, p. p. of desconfire, F. déconfire; fr. L. dis- + conficere to make ready, prepare, bring about. See Comfit Fact

sn.def: To scatter in fight; to put to rout; to defeat.
sn.q: And his proud foes discomfit in victorious field.

sn.def: To break up and frustrate the plans of; to balk� to throw into perplexity and dejection; to disconcert.
sn.q: Well, go with me and be not so discomfited.
sn.syn: To defeat; overthrow; overpower; vanquish; conquer; baffle; frustrate; confound; discourage.

entry.def: Discomfited; overthrown.
Rout; overthrow; discomfiture.
entry.q: Such a discomfit as shall quite despoil him.

sn.def: thwarted; -- used especially of feelings of defeat and discouragement.
same as discombobulated.

entry.def: people who are defeated.

entry.ety: OF. desconfiture, F. déconfiture. See Discomfort v. t., and cf. Comfiture
entry.def: The act of discomfiting, or the state of being discomfited; rout; overthrow; defeat; frustration; confusion and dejection.
entry.q: Every man's sword was against his fellow, and there was a very great discomfiture.
A hope destined to end . . . in discomfiture and disgrace.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Discomforted; p. pr. & vb. n. Discomforting
entry.ety: OF. desconforter, F. déconforter, to discourage; pref. des-L dis-) + conforter. See Comfort

sn.def: To discourage; to deject.
sn.q: His funeral shall not be in our camp, Lest it discomfort us.

sn.def: To destroy or disturb the comfort of; to deprive of quiet enjoyment; to make uneasy; to pain; as, a smoky chimney discomforts a family.

entry.ety: OF. desconfort, F. déconfort. See Discomfort v. t.

sn.def: Discouragement.
Want of comfort; uneasiness, mental or physical; disturbance of peace; inquietude; pain; distress; sorrow.
sn.q: An age of spiritualdiscomfort.
Strive against all the discomforts of thy sufferings.

entry.ety: Cf. OF. desconfortable

sn.def: Causing discomfort; occasioning uneasiness; making sad.
Destitute of comfort; uncomfortable.
sn.q: A labyrinth of little discomfortable garrets.

sn.def: To mention with disapprobation; to blame; to disapprove.
sn.q: By commending something in him that is good, and discommending the same fault in others.

sn.def: To expose to censure or ill favor; to put out of the good graces of any one.
sn.q: A compliance will discommend me to Mr. Coventry.

entry.def: Deserving, disapprobation or blame.
Blame; censure; reproach.
One who discommends; a dispraiser.
To deprive of a commission or trust.

entry.ety: L. dis- + commodatus, p. p. of commodare to make fit or suitable, fr. commodus fit, commodious. See Commodious, and cf. Discommode
entry.def: To discommode.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Discommoded; p. pr. & vb. n. Discommoding
entry.ety: See Discommodate
entry.def: To put inconvenience; to incommode; to trouble.
Inconvenient; troublesome; incommodious.
Disadvantage; inconvenience.

sn.def: To deprive of the right of common.
To deprive of privileges.
To deprive of commonable quality, as lands, by inclosing or appropriating.

entry.def: A lack of common possessions, properties, or relationship.
entry.q: Community of embryonic structure reveals community of descent; but dissimilarity of embryonic development does not prove discommunity of descent.

entry.def: To free from company; to dissociate.
entry.q: It she be alone now, and discompanied.

entry.def: To change the complexion or hue of.
Failure or refusal to comply; noncompliance.
entry.q: A compliance will discommend me to Mr. Coventry, and a discompliance to my lord chancellor.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Discomposed; p. pr. & vb. n. Discomposing
entry.ety: Pref. dis- + compose: cf. OF. decomposer, F. décomposer

sn.def: To disarrange; to interfere with; to disturb; to disorder; to unsettle; to break up.
sn.q: Or discomposed the headdress of a prude.

sn.def: To throw into disorder; to ruffle; to destroy the composure or equanimity; to agitate.
sn.q: Opposition . . . discomposeth the mind's serenity.

sn.def: To put out of place or service; to discharge; to displace.
sn.syn: To disorder; derange; unsettle; disturb; disconcert; agitate; ruffle; fret; vex.

entry.def: Disordered; disturbed; disquieted.
Inconsistency; discordance.

sn.def: The state of being discomposed; disturbance; disorder; agitation; perturbation.
sn.q: No discomposure stirred her features.

sn.def: Discordance; disagreement of parts.

entry.ety: See Discount
entry.def: To discount. See Discount.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Disconcerted; p. pr. & vb. n. Disconcerting
entry.ety: Pref. dis- + concert: cf. OF. desconcerter, F. déconcerter

sn.def: To break up the harmonious progress of; to throw into disorder or confusion; as, the emperor disconcerted the plans of his enemy.
To confuse the faculties of; to disturb the composure of; to discompose; to abash.
sn.q: The embrace disconcerted the daughter-in-law somewhat, as the caresses of old gentlemen unshorn and perfumed with tobacco might well do.
sn.syn: To discompose; derange; ruffle; confuse; disturb; defeat; frustrate.

entry.def: Want of concert; disagreement.
hard to deal with; causing uncertainty or confusion about how to act or react.
entry.syn: awkward, embarrassing, off-putting, sticky, tight, unenviable.

entry.def: The act of disconcerting, or state of being disconcerted; discomposure; perturbation.
Not conductive; impeding; disadvantageous.
Not conformable.
entry.q: Disconformable in religion from us.

entry.def: Want of conformity or correspondence; inconsistency; disagreement.
entry.q: Those . . . in some disconformity to ourselves.
Disagreement and disconformity betwixt the speech and the conception of the mind.

entry.def: Incongruity; disagreement; unsuitableness.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Disconnected; p. pr. & vb. n. Disconnecting
entry.def: To dissolve the union or connection of; to disunite; to sever; to separate; to disperse.
entry.q: The commonwealth itself would . . . be disconnected into the dust and powder of individuality.
This restriction disconnects bank paper and the precious metals.

entry.sn: marked by or composed of disconnected parts or sounds.Narrower terms: staccato (vs. legato abrupt, broken off(predicate).
not switched on or not connected to a power source; -- of electrical equipment.Narrower terms: off-line (vs. on-line), offline, off line(predicate; unplugged not ready, off.

sn.def: noncontinuous; not continuing in time or space. Opposite of continuous.
unconnected, detached. Opposite of connected.
lacking orderly continuity; illogical or seemingly irrational; as, disconnected fragments of a story.
sn.syn: confused, disjointed, disordered, disorganized, desultory, garbled, illogical, rambling, scattered, unconnected.

entry.def: the state of being disconnected.
The act of disconnecting, or state of being disconnected; separation; want of union.
entry.q: Nothing was therefore to be left in all the subordinate members but weakness, disconnection, and confusion.

entry.def: To deprive of consecration or sacredness.
To differ; to disagree; to dissent.
The state of being disconsolate.
Disconsolateness.

entry.ety: LL. disconsolatus; L. dis- + consolatus, p. p. of consolari to console. See Console v. t.

sn.def: Destitute of consolation; deeply dejected and dispirited; hopelessly sad; comfortless; filled with grief; as, a bereaved and disconsolate parent.
sn.q: One morn a Peri at the gate Of Eden stood disconsolate.
The ladies and the knights, no shelter nigh, Were dropping wet, disconsolate and wan.

sn.def: Inspiring dejection; saddening; cheerless; as, the disconsolate darkness of the winter nights.
sn.syn: Forlorn; melancholy; sorrowful; desolate; woeful; hopeless; gloomy.

entry.def: Disconsolate.
entry.q: A poor, disconsolated, drooping creature.

entry.def: Dejection; grief.
Not content; discontented; dissatisfied.
entry.q: Passion seemed to be much discontent, but Patience was very quiet.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Discontented; p. pr. & vb. n. Discontenting
entry.def: To deprive of content; to make uneasy; to dissatisfy.

sn.def: Want of content; uneasiness and inquietude of mind; dissatisfaction; disquiet.
sn.q: Now is the winter of our discontent Made glorious summer by this sun of York.
The rapacity of his father's administration had excited such universal discontent.

sn.def: A discontented person; a malcontent.
sn.q: Thus was the Scotch nation full of discontents.

entry.def: Discontent.
Dissatisfied; uneasy in mind; malcontent.
entry.q: And every one that was in distress, and every one that was in debt, and every one that was discontented, gathered themselves unto him.

entry.def: Full of discontent.

sn.def: Discontented.
Causing discontent; dissatisfying.

entry.def: Relating or tending to discontent.
entry.q: Pride is everdiscontentive.

entry.def: The state of being discontented; uneasiness; inquietude.
Admitting of being discontinued.

sn.def: The act of discontinuing, or the state of being discontinued; want of continued connection or continuity; breaking off; cessation; interruption; as, a discontinuance of conversation or intercourse; discontinuance of a highway or of travel.

sd.def: A breaking off or interruption of an estate, which happened when an alienation was made by a tenant in tail, or other tenant, seized in right of another, of a larger estate than the tenant was entitled to, whereby the party ousted or injured was driven to his real action, and could not enter. This effect of such alienation is now obviated by statute in both England and the United States.
The termination of an action in practice by the voluntary act of the plaintiff; an entry on the record that the plaintiff discontinues his action.

That technical interruption of the proceedings in pleading in an action, which follows where a defendant does not answer the whole of the plaintiff's declaration, and the plaintiff omits to take judgment for the part unanswered.
sd.syn: Cessation; intermission; discontinuation; separation; disunion; disjunction; disruption; break.

entry.ety: Cf. F. discontinuation
entry.def: Breach or interruption of continuity; separation of parts in a connected series; discontinuance.
entry.q: Upon any discontinuation of parts, made either by bubbles or by shaking the glass, the whole mercury falls.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Discontinued; p. pr. & vb. n. Discontinuing
entry.ety: Cf. F. discontinuer
entry.def: To interrupt the continuance of; to intermit, as a practice or habit; to put an end to; to cause to cease; to cease using, to stop; to leave off.
entry.q: Set up their conventicles again, which had been discontinued.
I have discontinued school Above a twelvemonth.
Taught the Greek tongue, discontinued before in these parts the space of seven hundred years.
They modify and discriminate the voice, without appearing to discontinue it.

sn.def: To lose continuity or cohesion of parts; to be disrupted or broken off.
To be separated or severed; to part.
sn.q: Thyself shalt discontinue from thine heritage.

entry.def: One whose possession of an estate is broken off, or discontinued; one whose estate is subject to discontinuance.
One who discontinues, or breaks off or away from; an absentee.
entry.q: He was no gadder abroad, not discontinuer from his convent for a long time.

entry.def: Want of continuity or cohesion; disunion of parts.
entry.q: Discontinuityof surface.

entry.def: One who deprives another of the possession of an estate by discontinuance. See Discontinuance, 2.

cs.cd: a function which for certain values or between certain values of the variable does not vary continuously as the variable increases. The discontinuity may, for example, consist of an abrupt change in the value of the function, or an abrupt change in its law of variation, or the function may become imaginary.

sn.def: Not continuous; interrupted; broken off.
sn.q: A path that is zigzag, discontinuous, and intersected at every turn by human negligence.

sn.def: Exhibiting a dissolution of continuity; gaping.
sn.q: Discontinuouswound.

entry.def: Unsuitableness; incongruity.
Not convenient or congruous; unsuitable; ill-adapted.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. � disk + � to bear
entry.def: A division of acalephs or jellyfishes, including most of the large disklike species.

entry.cs: Apple of discord. See under Apple.
entry.ety: OE. discord descord, OF. discorde descorde, F. discorde, from L. discordia, fr. discors -cordis, discordant, disagreeable; dis- + cor cordis, heart; cf. F. discord n., and OF. descorder discorder, F. discorder, to discord, L. discordare, from discors. See Heart, and cf. Discord v. i.

sn.def: Want of concord or agreement; absence of unity or harmony in sentiment or action; variance leading to contention and strife; disagreement; -- applied to persons or to things, and to thoughts, feelings, or purposes.
sn.q: A false witness that speaketh lies, and he that soweth discord among brethren.
Peace to arise out of universal discord fomented in all parts of the empire.

sn.def: Union of musical sounds which strikes the ear harshly or disagreeably, owing to the incommensurability of the vibrations which they produce; want of musical concord or harmony; a chord demanding resolution into a concord.
sn.q: For a discord itself is but a harshness of divers sounds m���ing.
sn.syn: Variance; difference; opposition; contrariety; clashing; dissension; contention; strife; disagreement; dissonance.

entry.ety: OE. discorden descorden, from the French. See Discord n.
entry.def: To disagree; to be discordant; to jar; to clash; not to suit.
entry.q: The one discording with the other.

entry.ety: Cf. OF. descordable
entry.def: That may produce discord; disagreeing; discordant.

entry.ety: Cf. F. discordance
entry.def: State or quality of being discordant; disagreement; inconsistency.
entry.q: There will arise a thousand discordances of opinion.

entry.ety: OE. discordant descordaunt, OF. descordant discordant, F. discordant, p. pr. of discorder, OF. also, descorder. See Discord n.

sn.def: Disagreeing; incongruous; being at variance; clashing; opposing; not harmonious.
sn.q: The discordant elements out of which the emperor had compounded his realm did not coalesce.

sn.def: Dissonant; not in harmony or musical concord; harsh; jarring; as, discordant notes or sounds.
sn.q: For still their music seemed to startDiscordant echoes in each heart.

sn.def: Said of strata which lack conformity in direction of bedding, either as in unconformability, or as caused by a fault.
sn.syn: Disagreeing; incongruous; contradictory; repugnant; opposite; contrary; inconsistent; dissonant; harsh; jarring; irreconcilable.

entry.def: Full of discord; contentious.
entry.q: Hisdiscordfuldame.

entry.def: Full of discord.
Deprived of the privileges or form of a body corporate.
Incongruous.
Same as Discoast.

entry.ety: Pref. dis- + counsel: cf. OF. desconseiller
entry.def: To dissuade.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Discounted; p. pr. & vb. n. Discounting
entry.ety: OF. desconter descompter, to deduct, F. décompter to discount; pref. des-L. dis-) + conter compter. See Count v.

sn.def: To deduct from an account, debt, charge, and the like; to make an abatement of; as, merchants sometimes discount five or six per cent for prompt payment of bills.
To lend money upon, deducting the discount or allowance for interest; as, the banks discount notes and bills of exchange.
sn.q: Discount only unexceptionable paper.

sn.def: To take into consideration beforehand; to anticipate and form conclusions concerning (an event).
To leave out of account; to take no notice of.
sn.q: Of the three opinions (I discount Brown's).

entry.def: To lend, or make a practice of lending, money, abating the discount; as, the discount for sixty or ninety days.

cs.cd: below par, or below the nominal value; hence, colloquially, out of favor; poorly esteemed; depreciated.
a sum equal to the interest at a given rate on the principal (face) of a bill or note from the time of discounting until it become due.
one who makes a business of discounting commercial paper; a bill broker.
a particular day of the week when a bank discounts bills.
the interest which, added to a principal, will equal the face of a note when it becomes due. The principal yielding this interest is the present value of the note.

entry.ety: Cf. F. décompte. See Discount v. t.

sn.def: A counting off or deduction made from a gross sum on any account whatever; an allowance upon an account, debt, demand, price asked, and the like; something taken or deducted.
A deduction made for interest, in advancing money upon, or purchasing, a bill or note not due; payment in advance of interest upon money.
The rate of interest charged in discounting.

entry.def: Capable of being, or suitable to be, discounted; as, certain forms are necessary to render notes discountable at a bank.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Discountenanced; p. pr. & vb. n. Discountenancing
entry.ety: Pref. dis- + countenance: cf. OF. descontenancer, F. décontenancer

sn.def: To ruffle or discompose the countenance of; to put of countenance; to put to shame; to abash.
sn.q: How would one look from his majestic brow . . . Discountenance her despised!
The hermit was somewhat discountenanced by this observation.

sn.def: To refuse to countenance, or give the support of one's approval to; to give one's influence against; to restrain by cold treatment; to discourage.
sn.q: A town meeting was convened to discountenance riot.

entry.def: Unfavorable aspect; unfriendly regard; cold treatment; disapprobation; whatever tends to check or discourage.
entry.q: He thought a little discountenance on those persons would suppress that spirit.

entry.def: One who discountenances; one who disfavors.
One who discounts; a discount broker.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Discouraged; p. pr. & vb. n. Discouraging
entry.ety: Pref. dis- + courage: cf. OF. descoragier, F. décourager: pref. des-L. dis-) + corage, F. courage. See Courage

sn.def: To extinguish the courage of; to dishearten; to depress the spirits of; to deprive of confidence; to deject; -- the opposite of encourage; as, he was discouraged in his undertaking; he need not be discouraged from a like attempt.
sn.q: Fathers, provoke not your children to anger, lest they be discouraged.

sn.def: To dishearten one with respect to; to discountenance; to seek to check by disfavoring; to deter one from; as, they discouraged his efforts.
sn.syn: To dishearten; dispirit; depress; deject; dissuade; disfavor.

entry.def: Lack of courage; cowardliness.
Capable of being discouraged; easily disheartened.

entry.ety: Cf. OF. descouragement, F. découragement

sn.def: The act of discouraging, or the state of being discouraged; depression or weakening of confidence; dejection.

That which discourages; that which deters, or tends to deter, from an undertaking, or from the prosecution of anything; a determent; as, the revolution was commenced under every possible discouragement .
sn.q: Discouragementsfrom vice.

entry.def: One who discourages.
entry.q: The promoter of truth and the discourager of error.

entry.def: Causing or indicating discouragement.
To discover.
entry.q: That none might her discoure.

entry.ety: L. discursus a running to and fro, discourse, fr. discurrere discursum, to run to and fro, to discourse; dis- + currere to run: cf. F. discours. See Course

sn.def: The power of the mind to reason or infer by running, as it were, from one fact or reason to another, and deriving a conclusion; an exercise or act of this power; reasoning; range of reasoning faculty.
sn.q: Difficult, strange, and harsh to the discourses of natural reason.
Sure he that made us with such large discourse, Looking before and after, gave us not That capability and godlike reason To fust in us unused.

sn.def: Conversation; talk.
sn.q: In their discourses after supper.
Filling the head with variety of thoughts, and the mouth with copious discourse.

sn.def: The art and manner of speaking and conversing.
sn.q: Of excellent breeding, admirable discourse.

sn.def: Consecutive speech, either written or unwritten, on a given line of thought; speech; treatise; dissertation; sermon, etc.; as, the preacher gave us a long discourse on duty.
Dealing; transaction.
sn.q: Good Captain Bessus, tell us the discourse Betwixt Tigranes and our king, and how We got the victory.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Discoursed; p. pr. & vb. n. Discoursing

sn.def: To exercise reason; to employ the mind in judging and inferring; to reason.
sn.q: Have sense or candiscourse.

sn.def: To express one's self in oral discourse; to expose one's views; to talk in a continuous or formal manner; to hold forth; to speak; to converse.
sn.q: Bid me discourse, I will enchant thine ear.

sn.def: To relate something; to tell.
To treat of something in writing and formally.
To treat of; to expose or set forth in language.
sn.q: The life of William Tyndale . . . is sufficiently and at large discoursed in the book.

sn.def: To utter or give forth; to speak.
sn.q: It will discourse most eloquent music.

sn.def: To talk to; to confer with.
sn.q: I have spoken to my brother, who is the patron, to discourse the minister about it.

sn.def: One who discourse; a narrator; a speaker; an haranguer.
sn.q: In his conversation he was the most clear discourser.

sn.def: The writer of a treatise or dissertation.
sn.q: Philologers and critical discoursers.

entry.ety: See Discursive

sn.def: Reasoning; characterized by reasoning; passing from premises to consequences; discursive.
Containing dialogue or conversation; interlocutory.
sn.q: The epic is everywhere interlaced with dialogue or discoursive scenes.

sn.def: Inclined to converse; conversable; communicative; as, a discoursive man.

entry.def: The state or quality of being discoursive or able to reason.

entry.ety: Pref. dis- + courteous: cf. OF. discortois
entry.def: Uncivil; rude; wanting in courtesy or good manners; uncourteous.

entry.ety: Pref. dis- + courtesy: cf. OF. descourtoisie
entry.def: Rudeness of behavior or language; ill manners; manifestation of disrespect; incivility.
entry.q: Be calm in arguing; for fierceness makes Error a fault, and truth discourtesy.

entry.def: Want of courtesy.

entry.ety: L. discus disk. See Disk
entry.def: Disklike; discoid.
To dissolve covenant with.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Discovered; p. pr. & vb. n. Discovering
entry.ety: OE. discoveren discuren descuren, OF. descovrir descouvrir, F. découvrir; des-L. dis-) + couvrir to cover. See Cover

sn.def: To uncover.
sn.q: Whether any man hath pulled down or discovered any church.

sn.def: To disclose; to lay open to view; to make visible; to reveal; to make known; to show (what has been secret, unseen, or unknown).
sn.q: Go, draw aside the curtains, and discover The several caskets to this noble prince.
Prosperity doth best discover vice; but adversity doth best discover virtue.
We will discover ourselves unto them.
Discover not a secret to another.

sn.def: To obtain for the first time sight or knowledge of, as of a thing existing already, but not perceived or known; to find; to ascertain; to espy; to detect.
sn.q: Some to discover islands far away.

sn.def: To manifest without design; to show.
sn.q: The youth discovered a taste for sculpture.

sn.def: To explore; to examine.
sn.syn: To disclose; bring out; exhibit; show; manifest; reveal; communicate; impart; tell; espy; find; out; detect. -- To Discover Invent. We discover what existed before, but remained unknown; we invent by forming combinations which are either entirely new, or which attain their end by means unknown before. Columbus discovered America; Newton discovered the law of gravitation; Whitney invented the cotton gin; Galileo invented the telescope.

entry.def: To discover or show one's self.
entry.q: This done, they discover.
Nor was this the first time that they discovered to be followers of this world.

entry.def: The quality of being discoverable.
Capable of being discovered, found out, or perceived; as, many minute animals are discoverable only by the help of the microscope; truths discoverable by human industry.

sn.def: One who discovers; one who first comes to the knowledge of something; one who discovers an unknown country, or a new principle, truth, or fact.
sn.q: The discoverers and searchers of the land.

sn.def: A scout; an explorer.

entry.def: Discovery.

entry.ety: Cf. F. découvert uncovered, OF. descovert. See Discover Covert
entry.def: Not covert; not within the bonds of matrimony; unmarried; -- applied either to a woman who has never married or to a widow.

cs.cd: uncovered.

entry.def: An uncovered place or part.

entry.ety: Pref. dis- + coverture: cf. OF. descoverture

sn.def: Discovery.
A state of being released from coverture; freedom of a woman from the coverture of a husband.

entries.entry:
Dis*cov"er*y n.; pl.Discoveries.
The action of discovering; exposure to view; laying open; showing; as, the discovery of a plot.
A making known; revelation; disclosure; as, a bankrupt is bound to make a full discovery of his assets. In the clear discoveries of the next [world].
Finding out or ascertaining something previously unknown or unrecognized; as, Harvey's discovery of the circulation of the blood. A brilliant career of discovery and conquest. We speak of the “invention” of printing, the discovery of America.
That which is discovered; a thing found out, or for the first time ascertained or recognized; as, the properties of the magnet were an important discovery .
Exploration; examination. Obs
Dis*cov"er*y Day. same as Columbus Day, above.

entry.def: To take from a cradle.
entry.q: This airy apparition first discradled From Tournay into Portugal.

entry.ety: Cf. F. discrédit

sn.def: The act of discrediting or disbelieving, or the state of being discredited or disbelieved; as, later accounts have brought the story into discredit .
Hence, some degree of dishonor or disesteem; ill repute; reproach; -- applied to persons or things.
sn.q: It is the duty of every Christian to be concerned for the reputation or discredit his life may bring on his profession.
sn.syn: Disesteem; disrepute; dishonor; disgrace; ignominy; scandal; disbelief; distrust.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Discredited; p. pr. & vb. n. Discrediting
entry.ety: Cf. F. discréditer

sn.def: To refuse credence to; not to accept as true; to disbelieve; as, the report is discredited .
To deprive of credibility; to destroy confidence or trust in; to cause disbelief in the accuracy or authority of.
sn.q: An occasion might be given to the . . . papists of discrediting our common English Bible.

sn.def: To deprive of credit or good repute; to bring reproach upon; to make less reputable; to disgrace.
sn.q: He. . . least discredits his travels who returns the same man he went.

entry.def: Not creditable; injurious to reputation; disgraceful; disreputable.

sn.def: being brought into disrepute; as, a discredited politician.
suffering shame.
having been shown to be incorrect; as, a discredited theory or policy.

entry.def: One who discredits.

entry.ety: F. discret, L. discretus separated (whence the meaning reserved prudent), p. p. of discernere. See Discern, and cf. Discrete

sn.def: Possessed of discernment, especially in avoiding error or evil, and in the adaptation of means to ends; prudent; sagacious; judicious; not rash or heedless; cautious.
sn.q: It is the discreet man, not the witty, nor the learned, nor the brave, who guides the conversation, and gives measures to society.
Satire 's my weapon, but I 'm too discreet To run amuck, and tilt at all I meet.
The sea is silent, the sea is discreet.

sn.def: Differing; distinct.

entries.entry:
Dis*crep"ance ?; 277 Dis*crep"an*cy, n.; pl.-ances # -ancies #. L. disrepantia: cf. OF. discrepance. See Discrepant
The state or quality of being discrepant; disagreement; variance; discordance; dissimilarity; contrariety. There hath been ever a discrepance of vesture of youth and age, men and women. There is no real discrepancy between these two genealogies.

entry.ety: L. discrepans -antis, p. pr. of discrepare to sound differently or discordantly; dis- + crepare to rattle, creak: cf. OF. discrepant. See Crepitate
entry.def: Discordant; at variance; disagreeing; contrary; different.
entry.q: The Egyptians were . . . the most oddly discrepant from the rest in their manner of worship.

entry.def: A dissident.

entry.cs:
Discrete movement. See Concrete movement of the voice, under Concrete a.
Discrete proportion proportion where the ratio of the means is different from that of either couplet; as, 3:6::8:16, 3 bearing the same proportion to 6 as 8 does to 16. But 3 is not to 6 as 6 to 8. It is thus opposed to continued or continual proportion; as, 3:6::12:24. Discrete quantity that which must be divided into units, as number, and is opposed to continued quantity, as duration, or extension.
entry.ety: L. discretus, p. p. of discernere. See Discreet

sn.def: Separate; distinct; disjunct.
Disjunctive; containing a disjunctive or discretive clause; as, “I resign my life, but not my honor,” is a discrete proposition.
Separate; not coalescent; -- said of things usually coalescent.

entry.def: To separate.
Separately; disjunctively.

cs.cd: without conditions or stipulations.

entry.ety: F. discrétion, L. discretio separation, difference, discernment, fr. discernere discretum. See Discreet Discern

sn.def: Disjunction; separation.
The quality of being discreet; wise conduct and management; cautious discernment, especially as to matters of propriety and self-control; prudence; circumspection; wariness.
sn.q: The better part of valor is discretion.
The greatest parts without discretion may be fatal to their owner.

sn.def: Discrimination.
sn.q: Well spoken, with good accent and good discretion.

sn.def: Freedom to act according to one's own judgment; unrestrained exercise of choice or will.

entry.ety: Cf. F. discrétionnaire
entry.def: Left to discretion; unrestrained except by discretion or judgment; as, an ambassador with discretionary powers.
At discretion; according to one's discretion or judgment.

cs.cd: one that expresses distinction, opposition, or variety, by means of discretive particles, as but though yet, etc.; as, travelers change their climate, but not their temper.

entry.ety: L. discretivus. See Discrete
entry.def: Marking distinction or separation; disjunctive.
In a discretive manner.
Capable of being discriminated.

entry.ety: L. discriminalis serving to divide
entry.def: In palmistry, applied to the line which marks the separation between the hand and the arm.

entry.ety: L. discriminans, p. pr. of discriminare
entry.def: The eliminant of the n partial differentials of any homogenous function of n variables. See Eliminant.

entry.ety: L. discriminatus, p. p. of discriminare to divide, separate, fr. discrimen division, distinction, decision, fr. discernere. See Discern, and cf. Criminate
entry.def: Having the difference marked; distinguished by certain tokens.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Discriminated; p. pr. & vb. n. Discriminating
entry.def: To set apart as being different; to mark as different; to separate from another by discerning differences; to distinguish.
entry.q: To discriminate the goats from the sheep.

sn.def: To make a difference or distinction; to distinguish accurately; as, in judging of evidence, we should be careful to discriminate between probability and slight presumption.

sd.def: To treat unequally.
To impose unequal tariffs for substantially the same service.

entry.def: In a discriminating manner; distinctly.
The state of being discriminated; distinctness.

sn.def: Marking a difference; distinguishing.
sn.q: And finds with keen discriminating sight, Black's not so black; -- nor white so very white.

sn.def: making careful or fine distinctions, especially as to quality or accuracy; as, a discriminating observer.
having a refined taste or excellent judgment; as, a discriminating taste.

entry.ety: L. discriminatio the contrasting of opposite thoughts

sn.def: The act of discriminating, distinguishing, or noting and marking differences.
sn.q: To make an anxious discrimination between the miracle absolute and providential.

sn.def: The state of being discriminated, distinguished, or set apart.
The arbitrary imposition of unequal tariffs for substantially the same service.
sn.q: A difference in rates, not based upon any corresponding difference in cost, constitutes a case of discrimination.

sn.def: The quality of being discriminating; faculty of nicely distinguishing; acute discernment; as, to show great discrimination in the choice of means.
That which discriminates; mark of distinction.
sn.syn: Discernment; penetration; clearness; acuteness; judgment; distinction. See Discernment.

sn.def: Marking a difference; distinguishing; distinctive; characteristic.
sn.q: That peculiar and discriminative form of life.

sn.def: Observing distinctions; making differences; discriminating.
sn.q: Discriminativecensure.
DiscriminativeProvidence.

entry.def: With discrimination or distinction.

entry.ety: LL
entry.def: One who discriminates.
Discriminative.

entry.ety: LL. discriminosus, fr. L. discrimen the dangerous, decisive moment. See Discriminate a.
entry.def: Hazardous; dangerous.

entry.ety: OF. descrivre. See Describe
entry.def: To describe.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Discrowned; p. pr. & vb. n. Discrowning
entry.def: To deprive of a crown.
entry.q: The end had crowned the work; it not unreasonably discrowned the workman.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Discruciated; p. pr. & vb. n. Discruciating
entry.ety: L. discruciatus, p. p. of discruciare. See Cruciate
entry.def: To torture; to excruciate.
entry.q: Discruciate a man in deep distress.

entry.ety: L. discumbere discubitum, to lie down, recline at table; dis- + cumberein comp.) to lie down
entry.def: Leaning; fitted for a reclining posture.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Disculpated; p. pr. & vb. n. Disculpating
entry.ety: LL. disculpatus, p. p. of disculpare to disculpate; dis- + L. culpare to blame, culpa fault
entry.def: To free from blame or the imputation of a fault; to exculpate.
entry.q: I almost fear you think I begged it, but I can disculpate myself.

entry.ety: Cf. F. disculpation
entry.def: Exculpation.
Tending to exculpate; exculpatory.

entry.ety: From L. discumbens, p. pr. of discumbere. See Discubitory
entry.def: The act of reclining at table according to the manner of the ancients at their meals.

entry.ety: Pref. dis- + cumber: cf. OF. descombrer
entry.def: To free from that which cumbers or impedes; to disencumber.

entry.ety: See Discover
entry.def: To discover; to reveal; to discoure.
entry.q: I will, if please you it discure, assay To ease you of that ill, so wisely as I may.

entry.def: Not current or free to circulate; not in use.

entry.ety: LL. discursio a running different ways. See Discourse
entry.def: The act of discoursing or reasoning; range, as from thought to thought.
A discourser.

entry.ety: Cf. F. discursif. See Discourse, and cf. Discoursive

sn.def: Passing from one thing to another; ranging over a wide field; roving; digressive; desultory.
sn.q: Discursivenotices.
The power he [Shakespeare] delights to show is not intense, but discursive.
A man rather tacit than discursive.

sn.def: Reasoning; proceeding from one ground to another, as in reasoning; argumentative.
sn.q: Reason is her being,Discursive or intuitive.

entry.def: Argumentative; discursive; reasoning.

entry.ety: L
entry.def: Argumentation; ratiocination; discursive reasoning.

entries.entry:
Dis"cus ☞ This among the Greeks was one of the chief gymnastic exercises and was included in the Pentathlon (the contest of the five exercises). The chief contest was that of throwing the discus to the greatest possible distance. n.; pl. E. Discuses #, L. Disci #. L. See Disk
A quoit; a circular plate of some heavy material intended to be pitched or hurled as a trial of strength and skill.
The exercise with the discus.
A disk. See Disk.

entry.note: This usage is preserved only in the word discussive.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Discussed; p. pr. & vb. n. Discussing
entry.ety: L. discussus, p. p. of discutere to strike asunder (hence came the sense to separate mentally distinguish); dis- + quatere to shake, strike. See Quash

sn.def: To break to pieces; to shatter.
To break up; to disperse; to scatter; to dissipate; to drive away; -- said especially of tumors.
sn.q: Many arts were used to discuss the beginnings of new affection.
A pomade . . . of virtue to discuss pimples.

sn.def: To shake; to put away; to finish.
sn.q: All regard of shame she had discussed.

sn.def: To examine in detail or by disputation; to reason upon by presenting favorable and adverse considerations; to debate; to sift; to investigate; to ventilate.
sn.q: We sat and . . .discussedthe farm . . . and the price of grain.
Todiscussquestions of taste.

sn.def: To deal with, in eating or drinking.
sn.q: We sat quietly down and discussed a cold fowl that we had brought with us.

sn.def: To examine or search thoroughly; to exhaust a remedy against, as against a principal debtor before proceeding against the surety.
sn.syn: To Discuss Examine Debate. We speak of examining a subject when we ponder it with care, in order to discover its real state, or the truth respecting it. We speak of discussing a topic when we examine it thoroughly in its distinct parts. The word is very commonly applied to matters of opinion. We may discuss a subject without giving in an adhesion to any conclusion. We speak of debating a point when we examine it in mutual argumentation between opposing parties. In debate we contend for or against some conclusion or view.

entry.def: a participant in a discussion, especially a member of a panel.
One who discusses; one who sifts or examines.

cs.mcol: Discussion of a problemorDiscussion of an equation
cs.cd: the operation of assigning different reasonable values to the arbitrary quantities and interpreting the result.

entry.ety: L. discussio a shaking, examination, discussion: cf. F. discussion

sn.def: The act or process of discussing by breaking up, or dispersing, as a tumor, or the like.
The act of discussing or exchanging reasons; examination by argument; debate; disputation; agitation.
sn.q: The liberty of discussion is the great safeguard of all other liberties.

entry.def: Pertaining to discussion.

entry.ety: Cf. F. discussif

sn.def: Able or tending to discuss or disperse tumors or coagulated matter; discutient.
Doubt-dispelling; decisive.
sn.q: A kind of peremptory and discussive voice.

entry.def: A medicine that discusses or disperses morbid humors; a discutient.

entry.ety: L. discutiens, p. pr. of discutere. See Discuss
entry.def: Serving to disperse morbid matter; discussive; as, a discutient application.
entry.def2: n. An agent (as a medicinal application) which serves to disperse morbid matter. “Foment with discutiens.”

entry.note: Often implying an idea of haughtiness.
entry.ety: OE. desdain disdein, OF. desdein desdaing, F. dédain, fr. the verb. See Disdain v. t.

sn.def: A feeling of contempt and aversion; the regarding anything as unworthy of or beneath one; scorn.
sn.q: How my soul is moved with just disdain!
Disdain and scorn ride sparkling in her eyes.

sn.def: That which is worthy to be disdained or regarded with contempt and aversion.
sn.q: Most loathsome, filthy, foul, and full of vile disdain.

sn.def: The state of being despised; shame.
sn.syn: Haughtiness; scorn; contempt; arrogance; pride. See Haughtiness.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Disdained; p. pr. & vb. n. Disdaining
entry.ety: OE. disdainen desdainen, OF. desdeigner desdaigner, F. dédaigner; des-L. dis-) + daigner to deign, fr. L. dignari to deem worthy. See Deign

sn.def: To think unworthy; to deem unsuitable or unbecoming; as, to disdain to do a mean act.
sn.q: Disdaining . . . that any should bear the armor of the best knight living.

sn.def: To reject as unworthy of one's self, or as not deserving one's notice; to look with scorn upon; to scorn, as base acts, character, etc.
sn.q: When the Philistine . . . saw David, he disdained him; for he was but a youth.
'T is great, 't is manly to disdain disguise.
sn.syn: To contemn; despise; scorn. See Contemn.

entry.def: To be filled with scorn; to feel contemptuous anger; to be haughty.
entry.q: And when the chief priests and scribes saw the marvels that he did . . . they disdained.

entry.def: Disdainful.
entry.q: Revenge the jeering and disdained contempt Of this proud king.

entry.def: Full of disdain; expressing disdain; scornful; contemptuous; haughty.
entry.q: From these Turning disdainful to an equal good.

entry.def: Disdainfully.

entry.ety: OF. desdeignos desdaigneux, F. dédaigneux
entry.def: Disdainful.
Disdainfully.
To divest or deprive of deity or of a deific rank or condition.
To disdain.
entry.q: Guyon much disdeigned so loathly sight.

entry.ety: Gr. di`s- twice + diakla^n to break in twain; dia` through + kla^n to break
entry.def: One of the dark particles forming the doubly refracting disks of muscle fibers.

entry.ety: Pref. dis-Gr. �) + diapason
entry.def: An interval of two octaves, or a fifteenth; -- called also bisdiapason. Compare diapason{1.

entry.cs: Disease germ. See under Germ.
entry.ety: OE. disese, OF. desaise; des-L. dis-) + aise ease. See Ease

sn.def: Lack of ease; uneasiness; trouble; vexation; disquiet.
sn.q: So all that night they passed in great disease.
To shield thee from diseases of the world.

sn.def: An alteration in the state of the body or of some of its organs, interrupting or disturbing the performance of the vital functions, and causing or threatening pain and weakness; malady; affection; illness; sickness; disorder; -- applied figuratively to the mind, to the moral character and habits, to institutions, the state, etc.
sn.q: Diseases desperate grown, By desperate appliances are relieved.
