The instability, injustice, and confusion introduced into the public counsels have, in truth, been the mortal diseases under which popular governments have every where perished.
sn.syn: Distemper; ailing; ailment; malady; disorder; sickness; illness; complaint; indisposition; affection.Disease Disorder Distemper Malady Affection. Disease is the leading medical term. Disorder mean� much the same, with perhaps some slight reference to an irregularity of the system. Distemper is now used by physicians only of the diseases of animals. Malady is not a medical term, and is less used than formerly in literature. Affection has special reference to the part, organ, or function disturbed; as, his disease is an affection of the lungs. A disease is usually deep-seated and permanent, or at least prolonged; a disorder is often slight, partial, and temporary; malady has less of a technical sense than the other terms, and refers more especially to the suffering endured. In a figurative sense we speak of a disease mind, of disordered faculties, and of mental maladies.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Diseased; p. pr. & vb. n. Diseasing

sn.def: To deprive of ease; to disquiet; to trouble; to distress.
sn.q: His double burden did him sore disease.

sn.def: To derange the vital functions of; to afflict with disease or sickness; to disorder; -- used almost exclusively in the participle diseased.
sn.q: He was diseased in body and mind.

entry.def: Afflicted with disease.
entry.q: It is my own diseased imagination that torments me.

entry.def: The state of being diseased; a morbid state; sickness.

sn.def: Causing uneasiness.
sn.q: Disgraceful to the king and diseaseful to the people.

sn.def: Abounding with disease; producing diseases; as, a diseaseful climate.

entry.def: The quality of being diseaseful; trouble; trial.
Uneasiness; inconvenience.
To deprive of an edge; to blunt; to dull.
entry.q: Served a little to disedge The sharpness of that pain about her heart.

entry.def: To fail of edifying; to injure.
To deprive of an elder or elders, or of the office of an elder.

entry.ety: Pref. di- + selenide
entry.def: A selenide containing two atoms of selenium in each molecule.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Disembarked; p. pr. & vb. n. Disembarking
entry.ety: Pref. dis- + embark: cf. F. désembarquer
entry.def: To remove from on board a vessel; to put on shore; to land; to debark; as, the general disembarked the troops.
entry.q: Go to the bay, and disembark my coffers.

entry.def: To go ashore out of a ship or boat; to leave a ship; to debark.
entry.q: And, making fast their moorings, disembarked.

entry.def: The act of disembarking.
Disembarkation.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Disembarrassed; p. pr. & vb. n. Disembarrassing
entry.ety: Pref. dis- + embarrass: cf. F. désembarasser
entry.def: To free from embarrassment, or perplexity; to clear; to extricate.
entry.q: To disembarrass himself of his companion.

entry.def: Freedom or relief from impediment or perplexity.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Disembayed; p. pr. & vb. n. Disembaying
entry.ety: Pref. dis- + embay
entry.def: To clear from a bay.

entry.ety: Pref. dis- + embellish: cf. F. désembellir
entry.def: To deprive of embellishment; to disadorn.
To free from
Divested of a body; ceased to be corporal; incorporeal.
entry.q: The disembodied spirits of the dead.

entry.def: The act of disembodying, or the state of being disembodied.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Disembodied; p. pr. & vb. n. Disembodying

sn.def: To divest of the body or corporeal existence.
sn.q: Devils embodied and disembodied.

sn.def: To disarm and disband, as a body of soldiers.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Disembogued; p. pr. & vb. n. Disemboguing
entry.ety: Sp. desembocar; pref. des-L. dis-) + embocar to put into the mouth, fr. enL. in) + boca mouth, fr. L. bucca cheek. Cf. Debouch Embogue

sn.def: To pour out or discharge at the mouth, as a stream; to vent; to discharge into an ocean, a lake, etc.
sn.q: Rolling down, the steep Timavus raves, And through nine channels disembogues his waves.

sn.def: To eject; to cast forth.

entry.def: To become discharged; to flow out; to find vent; to pour out contents.
entry.q: Volcanos bellow ere they disembogue.

entry.def: The act of disemboguing; discharge.
To separate from the bosom.

entry.ety: See Embowel

sn.def: To take or let out the bowels or interior parts of; to eviscerate.
sn.q: Soon after their death, they are disemboweled.
Roaring floods and cataracts that sweep From disemboweled earth the virgin gold.

sn.def: To take or draw from the body, as the web of a spider.
sn.q: Herdisemboweledweb.

entry.def: The act of disemboweling, or state of being disemboweled; evisceration.
Deprived of, or removed from, a bower.

entry.ety: Pref. dis- + em = enL. in) + brangle
entry.def: To free from wrangling or litigation.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Disembroiled; p. pr. & vb. n. Disembroiling
entry.ety: Pref. dis- + embroil
entry.def: To disentangle; to free from perplexity; to extricate from confusion.
entry.q: Vaillant has disembroiled a history that was lost to the world before his time.

entry.def: To throw out of employment.
The state of being disemployed, or deprived of employment.
entry.q: This glut of leisure and disemployment.

entry.def: To deprive of power; to divest of strength.

entry.ety: Pref. dis- + enable
entry.def: To disable; to disqualify.
entry.q: The sight of it might damp me and disenable me to speak.

entry.def: To free from the captivity of love.
Freed from restraint; unrestrained.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Disenchanted; p. pr. & vb. n. Disenchanting
entry.ety: Pref. dis- + enchant: cf. F. désenchanter

sn.def: To free from enchantment; to deliver from the power of charms or spells.
sn.q: Haste to thy work; a noble stroke or two Ends all the charms, and disenchants the grove.

sn.def: to free (a person) from fascination or delusion; to destroy the false hopes or overoptimistic expectations of (a person); to disillusion; -- used with people or events as the agent (subject); as, the candidate was disenchanted by the low turnout at the rally.

entry.def: One who, or that which, disenchants.
freeing from illusion, credulity, overoptimism, or false belief.

entry.ety: Pref. dis- + enchantment: cf. F. désenchantement
entry.def: The act of disenchanting, or state of being disenchanted.

entry.ety: Pref. dis- + enL. in) + charm
entry.def: To free from the influence of a charm or spell; to disenchant.
See Disinclose.
Discouragement.

entry.ety: Pref. dis- + OE. encrese, E. increase
entry.def: To decrease.
Decrease.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Disencumbered; p. pr. & vb. n. Disencumbering
entry.ety: Pref. dis- + encumber: cf. F. désencombrer
entry.def: To free from encumbrance, or from anything which clogs, impedes, or obstructs; to disburden.
entry.q: I have disencumbered myself from rhyme.

entry.def: Freedom or deliverance from encumbrance, or anything burdensome or troublesome.
To deprive of an endowment, as a church.
The act of depriving of an endowment or endowments.
entry.q: Thedisendowment of the Irish Church.

entry.def: To disfranchise; to deprive of the rights of a citizen.
deprived of the rights of citizenship, especially the right to vote. Opposite of enfranchised.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Disengaged #; p. pr. & vb. n. Disengaging
entry.ety: Pref. dis- + engage: cf. F. désengager
entry.def: To release from that with which anything is engaged, engrossed, involved, or entangled; to extricate; to detach; to set free; to liberate; to clear; as, to disengage one from a party, from broils and controversies, from an oath, promise, or occupation; to disengage the affections a favorite pursuit, the mind from study.
entry.q: To disengage him and the kingdom, great sums were to be borrowed.
Caloric and light must be disengaged during the process.
entry.syn: To liberate; free; loose; extricate; clear; disentangle; detach; withdraw; wean.

entry.def: To release one's self; to become detached; to free one's self.
entry.q: From a friends's grave how soon we disengage!

entry.def: Not engaged; free from engagement; at leisure; free from occupation or care; vacant.

entry.ety: Pref. dis- + engagement: cf. F. désengagement

sn.def: The act of disengaging or setting free, or the state of being disengaged.
sn.q: It is easy to render this disengagement of caloric and light evident to the senses.
A disengagement from earthly trammels.

sn.def: Freedom from engrossing occupation; leisure.
sn.q: Disengagement is absolutely necessary to enjoyment.

entry.cs: Disengaging machinery. See under Engaging.
entry.def: Loosing; setting free; detaching.
To deprive of that which ennobles; to degrade.
entry.q: An unworthy behavior degrades and disennobles a man.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Disenrolled; p. pr. & vb. n. Disenrolling
entry.def: To erase from a roll or list.

entry.ety: Pref. dis- + enL. in) + sanity
entry.def: Insanity; folly.
entry.q: What tediosity and disensanity Is here among!

entry.def: Freed from a shroudlike covering; unveiled.
entry.q: The disenshrouded statue.

entry.def: To free from bondage or slavery; to disenthrall.
entry.q: He shall disenslave and redeem his soul.

entry.def: To free from entailment.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Disentangled; p. pr. & vb. n. Disentangling

sn.def: To free from entanglement; to release from a condition of being intricately and confusedly involved or interlaced; to reduce to orderly arrangement; to straighten out; as, to disentangle a skein of yarn.
To extricate from complication and perplexity; disengage from embarrassing connection or intermixture; to disembroil; to set free; to separate.
sn.q: To disentangle truth from error.
To extricate and disentangle themselves out of this labyrinth.
A mind free and disentangled from all corporeal mixtures.
sn.syn: To loose; extricate; disembarrass; disembroil; clear; evolve; disengage; separate; detach.

sn.def: freed from an entanglement; -- of people or agents.
straightened out.

entry.def: The act of disentangling or clearing from difficulties.
See Disinter.

entry.ety: See Enthrall
entry.def: To release from thralldom or slavery; to give freedom to; to disinthrall.
Liberation from bondage; emancipation; disinthrallment.
To dethrone; to depose from sovereign authority.
To deprive of title or claim.
entry.q: Every ordinary offense does not disentitle a son to the love of his father.

entry.def: To take out from a tomb; a disinter.
To disembowel; to let out or draw forth, as the entrails.
entry.q: As if he thought her soul to disentrail.

entry.def: To awaken from a trance or an enchantment.
To free from being entwined or twisted.

entry.ety: Pref. di- + sepalous
entry.def: Having two sepals; two-sepaled.

entry.ety: L. disertus, for dissertus, p. p.: cf. F. disert. See Dissert
entry.def: Eloquent.

entry.ety: L. disertitud�
entry.def: Eloquence.
Expressly; clearly; eloquently.
To release from espousal or plighted faith.
To unsettle; to break up (anything established); to deprive, as a church, of its connection with the state.

sn.def: The act or process of unsettling or breaking up that which has been established; specifically, the withdrawal of the support of the state from an established church; as, the disestablishment and disendowment of the Irish Church by Act of Parliament.
The condition of being disestablished.

entries.entry: dis`es*tab`lish*men*ta"ri*an*ism n. The doctrine or political position that advocates abrogating the establishment of a church as the official state religion..Prior to the Puritans, very few earlier believers contended for any form of disestablishmentarianism.

entry.def: Want of esteem; low estimation, inclining to dislike; disfavor; disrepute.
entry.q: Disesteem and contempt of the public affairs.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Disesteemed; p. pr. & vb. n. Disesteeming

sn.def: To feel an absence of esteem for; to regard with disfavor or slight contempt; to slight.
sn.q: But if this sacred gift you disesteem.
Qualities which society does not disesteem.

sn.def: To deprive of esteem; to bring into disrepute; to cause to be regarded with disfavor.
sn.q: What fables have you vexed, what truth redeemed, Antiquities searched, opinions disesteemed?

entry.def: One who disesteems.
Disesteem.
To deprive of exercise; to leave untrained.
entry.q: By disexercising and blunting our abilities.

entry.def: Disrepute.
To dislike.

entry.ety: Pref. dis- + fashion. See Fashion, and cf. Defeat
entry.def: To disfigure.

entry.ety: Pref. dis- + favor: cf. OF. disfaveur, F. défaveur

sn.def: Want of favor of favorable regard; disesteem; disregard.
sn.q: The people that deserved my disfavor.
Sentiment of disfavor against its ally.

sn.def: The state of not being in favor; a being under the displeasure of some one; state of unacceptableness; as, to be in disfavor at court.
An unkindness; a disobliging act.
sn.q: He might dispense favors and disfavors.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Disfavored; p. pr. & vb. n. Disfavoring

sn.def: To withhold or withdraw favor from; to regard with disesteem; to show disapprobation of; to discountenance.
sn.q: Countenanced or disfavored according as they obey.

sn.def: To injure the form or looks of.

entry.ety: Cf. F. défavorable
entry.def: Unfavorable.
Unpropitiously.
One who disfavors.

entry.ety: Cf. Defeature
entry.def: To deprive of features; to mar the features of.

entry.ety: See Fellowship v. t.
entry.def: To exclude from fellowship; to refuse intercourse with, as an associate.
entry.q: An attempt to disfellowship an evil, but to fellowship the evildoer.

entry.ety: See Disfigure, and cf. Defiguration
entry.def: The act of disfiguring, or the state of being disfigured; defacement; deformity; disfigurement.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Disfigured; p. pr. & vb. n. Disfiguring
entry.ety: OF. desfigurer, F. défigurer; pref. des-L. dis-) + figurer to fashion, shape, fr. L. figurare, fr. figura figure. See Figure, and cf. Defiguration
entry.def: To mar the figure of; to render less complete, perfect, or beautiful in appearance; to deface; to deform.
entry.q: Disfiguring not God's likeness, but their own.

entry.def: Disfigurement; deformity.
having the appearance spoiled; as, a disfigured face; strip mining left a disfigured landscape.

sn.def: Act of disfiguring, or state of being disfigured; deformity.
That which disfigures; a defacement; a blot.
sn.q: Uncommon expressions . . . are a disfigurement rather than any embellishment of discourse.

entry.def: One who disfigures.
To reduce the flesh or obesity of.

sn.def: To disafforest.
To clear or deprive of forests or trees.

entry.def: The act of clearing land of forests.

entry.ety: Cf. Deformity
entry.def: Discordance or diversity of form; unlikeness in form.
entry.q: Uniformity or disformity in comparing together the respective figures of bodies.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Disfranchised; p. pr. & vb. n. Disfranchising
entry.ety: Cf. Diffranchise
entry.def: To deprive of a franchise or chartered right; to dispossess of the rights of a citizen, or of a particular privilege, as of voting, holding office, etc.
entry.q: Sir William Fitzwilliam was disfranchised.
He was partially disfranchised so as to be made incapable of taking part in public affairs.

entry.def: deprived of the rights of citizenship especially the right to vote. Opposite of enfranchised.
The act of disfranchising, or the state of being disfranchised; deprivation of privileges of citizenship or of chartered immunities.
entry.q: Sentenced first to dismission from the court, and then to disfranchisement and expulsion from the colony.

entry.def: To depose or withdraw from the condition of a friar.
entry.q: Many did quickly unnun and disfriar themselves.

entry.def: To unfrock.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Disfurnished; p. pr. & vb. n. Disfurnishing
entry.ety: Pref. dis- + furnish
entry.def: To deprive of that with which anything is furnished (furniture, equipments, etc.); to strip; to render destitute; to divest.
entry.q: I am a thing obscure, disfurnished of All merit, that can raise me higher.

entry.def: The act of disfurnishing, or the state of being disfurnished.
The act of disfurnishing, or the state of being disfurnished.
To disfurnish.
To free from a gage or pledge; to disengage.
To deprive of gallantry.
To strip of a garland.
entry.q: Thy locksdisgarland.

entry.ety: Pref. dis- + garnish. See Degarnish
entry.def: To divest of garniture; to disfurnish; to dismantle.
To deprive of a garrison.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Disgaveled or Disgaveled; p. pr. & vb. n. Disgaveling
entry.ety: See Gavelkind
entry.def: To deprive of that principal quality of gavelkind tenure by which lands descend equally among all the sons of the tenant; -- said of lands.
To digest.
Digestion.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Disglorified; p. pr. & vb. n. Disglorifying
entry.def: To deprive of glory; to treat with indignity.
entry.q: Disglorified, blasphemed, and had in scorn.

entry.def: Dishonor.
entry.q: To the disglory of God's name.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Disgorged; p. pr. & vb. n. Disgorging
entry.ety: F. dégorger, earlier desgorger; pref. dé- des-L. dis-) + gorge. See Gorge

sn.def: To eject or discharge by the throat and mouth; to vomit; to pour forth or throw out with violence, as if from the mouth; to discharge violently or in great quantities from a confined place.
sn.q: This mountain when it rageth, . . . casteth forth huge stones, disgorgeth brimstone.
They loudly laughed To see his heaving breast disgorge the briny draught.

sn.def: To give up unwillingly as what one has wrongfully seized and appropriated; to make restitution of; to surrender; as, he was compelled to disgorge his ill-gotten gains.

entry.def: To vomit forth what anything contains; to discharge; to make restitution.
entry.q: See where it flows, disgorging at seven mouths Into the sea.

entry.ety: Cf. F. dégorgement
entry.def: The act of disgorging; a vomiting; that which is disgorged.
To be inconsistent with, or act contrary to, the precepts of the gospel; to pervert the gospel.

entry.ety: F. disgrâce; pref. dis-L. dis-) + grâce. See Grace

sn.def: The condition of being out of favor; loss of favor, regard, or respect.
sn.q: Macduff lives in disgrace.

sn.def: The state of being dishonored, or covered with shame; dishonor; shame; ignominy.
sn.q: To tumble down thy husband and thyself From top of honor to disgrace's feet?

sn.def: That which brings dishonor; cause of shame or reproach; great discredit; as, vice is a disgrace to a rational being.
An act of unkindness; a disfavor.
sn.q: The interchange continually of favors and disgraces.
sn.syn: Disfavor; disesteem; opprobrium; reproach; discredit; disparagement; dishonor; shame; infamy; ignominy; humiliation.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Disgraced; p. pr. & vb. n. Disgracing
entry.ety: Cf. F. disgracier. See Disgrace n.

sn.def: To put out of favor; to dismiss with dishonor.
sn.q: Flatterers of the disgraced minister.
Pitt had been disgraced and the old Duke of Newcastle dismissed.

sn.def: To do disfavor to; to bring reproach or shame upon; to dishonor; to treat or cover with ignominy; to lower in estimation.
sn.q: Shall heap with honors him they now disgrace.
His ignorance disgraced him.

sn.def: To treat discourteously; to upbraid; to revile.
sn.q: The goddess wroth gan foully her disgrace.
sn.syn: To degrade; humble; humiliate; abase; disparage; defame; dishonor; debase.

entry.def: suffering shame or dishonor.
Bringing disgrace; causing shame; shameful; dishonorable; unbecoming; as, profaneness is disgraceful to a man.
entry.q: The Senate have cast you forth disgracefully.

entry.def: One who disgraces.

entry.ety: Cf. F. disgracieux
entry.def: Wanting grace; unpleasing; disagreeable.
Disgracing.
Degradation; a stripping of titles and honors.
To degrade.
To degrade; to reduce in rank.

entry.ety: L. disgregare; dis- + gregare to collect, fr. grex gregis, flock or herd

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Disguised; p. pr. & vb. n. Disguising
entry.ety: OE. desguisen disgisen degisen, OF. desguisier, F. déguiser; pref. des-L. dis-) + guise. See Guise

sn.def: To change the guise or appearance of; especially, to conceal by an unusual dress, or one intended to mislead or deceive.

sn.def: To hide by a counterfeit appearance; to cloak by a false show; to mask; as, to disguise anger; to disguise one's sentiments, character, or intentions.
sn.q: All God's angels come to us disguised.

sn.def: To affect or change by liquor; to intoxicate.
sn.q: I have just left the right worshipful, and his myrmidons, about a sneaker of five gallons; the whole magistracy was pretty well disguised before I gave them the ship.
sn.syn: To conceal; hide; mask; dissemble; dissimulate; feign; pretend; secrete. See Conceal.

sn.def: A dress or exterior put on for purposes of concealment or of deception; as, persons doing unlawful acts in disguise are subject to heavy penalties.
sn.q: There is no passion which steals into the heart more imperceptibly and covers itself under more disguises, than pride.

sn.def: Artificial language or manner assumed for deception; false appearance; counterfeit semblance or show.
sn.q: That eye which glances through all disguises.

sn.def: Change of manner by drink; intoxication.
A masque or masquerade.
sn.q: Disguise was the old English word for a masque.

entry.def: In disguise.
The state of being disguised.
Disguise.

sn.def: One who, or that which, disguises.
One who wears a disguise; an actor in a masquerade; a masker.

entry.def: A masque or masquerade.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Disgusted; p. pr. & vb. n. Disgusting
entry.ety: OF. desgouster, F. dégoûter; pref. des-L. dis-) + gouster to taste, F. goûter, fr. L. gustare, fr. gustus taste. See Gust to taste
entry.def: To provoke disgust or strong distaste in; to cause (any one) loathing, as of the stomach; to excite aversion in; to offend the moral taste of; -- often with at with, or by.
entry.q: To disgust him with the world and its vanities.
Ærius is expressly declared . . . to have been disgusted at failing.
Alarmed and disgusted by the proceedings of the convention.

entry.ety: Cf. OF. desgoust, F. dégoût. See Disgust v. t.
entry.def: Repugnance to what is offensive; aversion or displeasure produced by something loathsome; loathing; strong distaste; -- said primarily of the sickening opposition felt for anything which offends the physical organs of taste; now rather of the analogous repugnance excited by anything extremely unpleasant to the moral taste or higher sensibilities of our nature; as, an act of cruelty may excite disgust .
entry.q: The manner of doing is more consequence than the thing done, and upon that depends the satisfaction or disgust wherewith it is received.
In a vulgar hack writer such oddities would have excited only disgust.
entry.syn: Nausea; loathing; aversion; distaste; dislike; disinclination; abomination. See Dislike.

entry.def: having a strong distaste from surfeit.
entry.syn: fed up(predicate), sick of(predicate), tired of(predicate).

entry.def: Provoking disgust; offensive to the taste; exciting aversion; disgusting.
entry.q: That horrible and disgustful situation.

entry.def: The state of being disgustful.
That causes disgust; sickening; offensive; revolting.

cs.cd: a dish antenna used to receive signals from or to transmit signals to a satellite which transmits or receives radio signals. In most common usage, it refers to small dish antennas used to receive television programs broadcast from geostationary satellites.

entry.ety: AS. disc, L. discus dish, disc, quoit, fr. Gr. di`skos quoit, fr. dikei^n to throw. Cf. Dais Desk Disc Discus

sn.def: A vessel, as a platter, a plate, a bowl, used for serving up food at the table.

sn.def: The food served in a dish; hence, any particular kind of food, especially prepared food; as, a cold dish; a warm dish; a delicious dish. “A dish fit for the gods.”
sn.q: Home-home dishes that drive one from home.

an electronic device with a concave reflecting surface which focuses reflected radio waves to or from a point, used as a receiving or transmitting antenna; also called dish antenna . The dish is often shaped as a paraboloid so as to achieve a high sensitivity and enable reception of weak signals when used as a receiving antenna, or to focus transmitted signals into a narrow beam when used as a transmitting antenna.
a very attractive woman or young lady, especaially one sexually attractive; -- sometimes considered offensive and sexist; as, the departmental secretary is quite a dish .
a favorite activity, or an activity at which one excels.
the quantity that a dish will hold, or a dish filled with some material.

entry.cs: To dish out. To serve out of a dish; to distribute in portions at table. Arch To hollow out, as a gutter in stone or wood. to dispense freely; -- also used figuratively; as, to dish out punishment; to dish out abuse or insult. To dish up to take (food) from the oven, pots, etc., and put in dishes to be served at table.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Dished; p. pr. & vb. n. Dishing

sn.def: To put in a dish, ready for the table.

To frustrate; to beat; to ruin.
to talk about (a person) in a disparaging manner; to gossip about (a person); as, the secretaries spent their break time dishing the newest employee.

entry.ety: Cf. Disability

entry.def: Causing loss of hope or enthusiasm.

entry.ety: Cf. Disherit
entry.def: To disinherit.

entries.entry: Dish"ful n.; pl.Dishfuls. As much as a dish holds when full.

entry.ety: Pref. dis- + honest: cf. F. déshonnête, OF. deshoneste

entry.def: To free from infectious or contagious matter; to destroy putrefaction; to purify; to make innocuous.

entry.def: To separate into integrant parts; to reduce to fragments or to powder; to break up, or cause to fall to pieces, as a rock, by blows of a hammer, frost, rain, and other mechanical or atmospheric influences.

entry.def: To decompose into integrant parts; as, chalk rapidly disintegrates .

entries.entry: Dis*in`te*gra"tion n. The process by which anything is disintegrated; the condition of anything which is disintegrated. Specifically Geol The wearing away or falling to pieces of rocks or strata, produced by atmospheric action, frost, ice, etc. Society had need of further disintegration before it could begin to reconstruct itself locally.

entry.def: A machine for grinding or pulverizing by percussion.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Disjoined dĭs*joind"; p. pr. & vb. n. Disjoining
entry.ety: OF. desjoindre, F. disjoindre déjoindre, fr. L. disjungere; dis- + jungere to join. See Join, and cf. Disjoint Disjunct

sn.q: Yet what could swords or poisons, racks or flame, But mangle and disjoint the brittle frame?

a proposition in which the parts are connected by disjunctive conjunctions, specifying that one of two or more propositions may hold, but that no two propositions may hold at the same time; as it is either day or night.
one in which the major proposition is disjunctive; as, the earth moves in a circle or an ellipse; but in does not move in a circle, therefore it moves in an ellipse.

entries.entry: Disk clutch. Engin A friction clutch in which the gripping surfaces are disks or more or less resemble disks.

entry.def: a data-storage medium consisting of a small plastic disk coated with a thin layer of magnetizable material on one or both sides, enclosed in a stiff envelope with a radial slit. It is used in a specially designed disk drive, in which the disk is rotated at high speed, and which stores data on the disk by causing changes in the direction of magnetization of the magnetic layer as the disk spins and as sequential locations on the disk pass under the read-write head of the drive. Reading of the data occurs in the reverse process, by detection of the patterns of magnetization of the disk. Such disks are used to store data or programs for a microcomputer.
Unkindness; disservice.
Having no disk; appearing as a point and not expanded into a disk, as the image of a faint star in a telescope.
resembling a disk in shape; circular and having a height considerably smaller than the diameter.
To unlade.

entry.ety: See Disloyal Leal
entry.def: Disloyal; perfidious.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Disliked; p. pr. & vb. n. Disliking

sn.def: A feeling of positive and usually permanent aversion to something unpleasant, uncongenial, or offensive; disapprobation; repugnance; displeasure; disfavor; -- the opposite of liking or fondness.
sn.q: God's grace . . . gives him continual dislike to sin.
The hint malevolent, the look oblique, The obvious satire, or implied dislike.
We have spoken of the dislike of these excellent women for Sheridan and Fox.

sn.def: Discord; dissension.
sn.syn: Distaste; disinclination; disapprobation; disfavor; disaffection; displeasure; disrelish; aversion; reluctance; repugnance; disgust; antipathy.Dislike Aversion Reluctance Repugnance Disgust Antipathy. Dislike is the more general term, applicable to both persons and things and arising either from feeling or judgment. It may mean little more than want of positive liking; but antipathy repugnance disgust, and aversion are more intense phases of dislike. Aversion denotes a fixed and habitual dislike; as, an aversion to or for business. Reluctance and repugnance denote a mental strife or hostility something proposed (repugnance being the stronger); as, a reluctance to make the necessary sacrifices, and a repugnance to the submission required. Disgust is repugnance either of taste or moral feeling; as, a disgust at gross exhibitions of selfishness. Antipathy is primarily an instinctive feeling of dislike of a thing, such as most persons feel for a snake. When used figuratively, it denotes a correspondent dislike for certain persons, modes of acting, etc. Men have an aversion to what breaks in upon their habits; a reluctance and repugnance to what crosses their will; a disgust at what offends their sensibilities; and are often governed by antipathies for which they can give no good reason.

entry.def: Full of dislike; disaffected; malign; disagreeable.
The want of likelihood; improbability.
To make unlike; to disguise.
Unlikeness.
One who dislikes or disrelishes.
To tear limb from limb; to dismember.

entry.ety: Pref. dis- + limn
entry.def: To efface, as a picture.
To unlink; to disunite; to separate.
To deprive of life.
entry.q: Telemachus dislived Amphimedon.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Dislocated; p. pr. & vb. n. Dislocating
entry.ety: LL. dislocatus, p. p. of dislocare; dis- + locare to place, fr. locus place. See Locus
entry.def: To displace; to put out of its proper place. Especially, of a bone: To remove from its normal connections with a neighboring bone; to put out of joint; to move from its socket; to disjoint; as, to dislocate your bones.
entry.q: After some time the strata on all sides of the globe were dislocated.
And thus the archbishop's see, dislocated or out of joint for a time, was by the hands of his holiness set right again.

entry.ety: LL. dislocatus, p. p
entry.def: Dislocated.
separated at the joint; -- used especially of limbs; as, a dislocated knee.

entry.ety: Cf. F. dislocation

sn.def: The act of displacing, or the state of being displaced.
The displacement of parts of rocks or portions of strata from the situation which they originally occupied. Slips, faults, and the like, are dislocations.
The act of dislocating, or putting out of joint; also, the condition of being thus displaced.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Dislodged; p. pr. & vb. n. Dislodging
entry.ety: OF. deslogier, F. déloger; pref. des-L. dis-) + OF. logier, F. loger. See Lodge

sn.def: To drive from a lodge or place of rest; to remove from a place of quiet or repose; as, shells resting in the sea at a considerate depth are not dislodged by storms.
To drive out from a place of hiding or defense; as, to dislodge a deer, or an enemy.
sn.q: The Volscians are dislodg'd.

entry.def: To go from a place of rest.
entry.q: Where Light and Darkness in perpetual round Lodge and dislodge by turns.

entry.def: Dwelling apart; separation.

sn.def: forced removal from a position of advantage.
dislodgment.

entry.ety: Cf. F. délogement, OF. deslogement
entry.def: The act or process of dislodging, or the state of being dislodged.

entry.ety: OF. desloignier. See Eloign
entry.def: To put at a distance; to remove.
entry.q: Low-looking dales, disloigned from common gaze.

entry.ety: Pref. dis- + loyal: cf. OF. desloial desleal, F. déloyal. See Loyal
entry.def: Not loyal; not true to a sovereign or lawful superior, or to the government under which one lives; false where allegiance is due; faithless; as, a subject disloyal to the king; a husband disloyal to his wife.
entry.q: Without a thought disloyal.
entry.syn: Disobedient; faithless; untrue; treacherous; perfidious; dishonest; inconstant; disaffected.

entry.def: In a disloyal manner.

entry.ety: Pref. dis- + loyalty: cf. OF. desloiauté deslealté, F. déloyauté
entry.def: Want of loyalty; lack of fidelity; violation of allegiance.

entry.ety: Pref. dis- + mail: cf. OF. desmaillier
entry.def: To divest of coat of mail.

entry.ety: Formerly a noun; e. g., “I trow it was in the dismalle.” Chaucer. Of uncertain origin; but perh. (as suggested by Skeat) from OF. disme, F. dîme, tithe, the phrase dismal day properly meaning, the day when tithes must be paid. See Dime

sn.def: Fatal; ill-omened; unlucky.
sn.q: An ugly fiend more foul than dismal day.

sn.def: Gloomy to the eye or ear; sorrowful and depressing to the feelings; foreboding; cheerless; dull; dreary; as, a dismal outlook; dismal stories; a dismal place.
sn.q: Full well the busy whisper, circling round, Convey'd the dismal tidings when he frowned.
A dismal description of an English November.
sn.syn: Dreary; lonesome; gloomy; dark; ominous; ill-boding; fatal; doleful; lugubrious; funereal; dolorous; calamitous; sorrowful; sad; joyless; melancholy; unfortunate; unhappy.

entry.def: In a dismal manner; gloomily; sorrowfully; uncomfortably.
The quality of being dismal; gloominess.
To unman.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Dismantled; p. pr. & vb. n. Dismantling
entry.ety: F. démanteler, OF. desmanteler; pref: des-L. dis-) + manteler to cover with a cloak, defend, fr. mantel, F. manteau, cloak. See Mantle

sn.def: To strip or deprive of dress; to divest.
To strip of furniture and equipments, guns, etc.; to unrig; to strip of walls or outworks; to break down; as, to dismantle a fort, a town, or a ship.
sn.q: A dismantled house, without windows or shutters to keep out the rain.

sn.def: To disable; to render useless.

entry.def: To march away.

entry.ety: Pref. dis- + marry: cf. OF. desmarier, F. démarier
entry.def: To free from the bonds of marriage; to divorce.
To disarrange; to derange; to put in disorder.

entry.ety: Pref. dis- + mask: cf. F. démasquer
entry.def: To divest of a mask.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Dismasted; p. pr. & vb. n. Dismasting
entry.ety: Pref. dis- + mast: cf. F. démâter
entry.def: To deprive of a mast of masts; to break and carry away the masts from; as, a storm dismasted the ship.
The act of dismasting; the state of being dismasted.
To eject from the maw; to disgorge.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Dismayed; p. pr. & vb. n. Dismaying
entry.ety: OE. desmaien dismaien, OF. esmaier; pref. es-L. ex) + OHG. magan to be strong or able; akin to E. may. In English the pref. es- was changed to dis-L. dis-). See May v. i.

sn.def: To disable with alarm or apprehensions; to depress the spirits or courage of; to deprive or firmness and energy through fear; to daunt; to appall; to terrify.
sn.q: Be not afraid, neither be thou dismayed.
What words be these? What fears do you dismay?

sn.def: To render lifeless; to subdue; to disquiet.
sn.q: Do not dismay yourself for this.
sn.syn: To terrify; fright; affright; frighten; appall; daunt; dishearthen; dispirit; discourage; deject; depress. -- To Dismay Daunt Appall. Dismay denotes a state of deep and gloomy apprehension. To daunt supposes something more sudden and startling. To appall is the strongest term, implying a sense of terror which overwhelms the faculties.
sn.q: So flies a herd of beeves, that hear, dismayed, The lions roaring through the midnight shade.
Jove got such heroes as my sire, whose soul No fear could daunt, nor earth nor hell control.
Now the last ruin the whole host appalls; Now Greece has trembled in her wooden walls.

entry.def: To take dismay or fright; to be filled with dismay.

entry.ety: Cf. OF. esmai, F. émoi. See Dismay v. t.

sn.def: Loss of courage and firmness through fear; overwhelming and disabling terror; a sinking of the spirits; consternation.
sn.q: I . . . can not think of such a battle without dismay.
Thou with a tiger spring dost leap upon thy prey, And tear his helpless breast, o'erwhelmed with wild dismay.

sn.def: Condition fitted to dismay; ruin.
sn.syn: Dejection; discouragement; depression; fear; fright; terror; apprehension; alarm; affright.

entry.def: A state of being dismayed; dejection of courage; dispiritedness.
Terrifying.

entry.ety: OF. See Dime
entry.def: A tenth; a tenth part; a tithe.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Dismembered; p. pr. & vb. n. Dismembering
entry.ety: OF. desmembrer, F. démembrer; pref. des-L. dis) + OF. & F. membre limb. See Member

sn.def: To tear limb from limb; to dilacerate; to disjoin member from member; to tear or cut in pieces; to break up.
sn.q: Fowls obscene dismembered his remains.
A society lacerated and dismembered.
By whose hands the blow should be struck which would dismember that once mighty empire.

sn.def: To deprive of membership.
sn.q: They were dismembered by vote of the house.
sn.syn: To disjoint; dislocate; dilacerate; mutilate; divide; sever.

entry.ety: Cf. OF. desmembrement, F. démembrement
entry.def: The act of dismembering, or the state of being dismembered; cutting in piece; m�tilation; division; separation.
entry.q: The Castilians would doubtless have resented the dismemberment of the unwieldy body of which they formed the head.

entry.def: Destitute of mettle, that is, or fire or spirit.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Dismissed; p. pr. & vb. n. Dismissing
entry.ety: L. dis- + missus, p. p. of mittere to send: cf. dimittere, OF. desmetre, F. démettre. See Demise, and cf. Dimit

sn.def: To send away; to give leave of departure; to cause or permit to go; to put away.
sn.q: He dismissed the assembly.
Dismiss their cares when they dismiss their flock.
Though he soon dismissed himself from state affairs.

sn.def: To discard; to remove or discharge from office, service, or employment; as, the king dismisses his ministers; the matter dismisses his servant.
To lay aside or reject as unworthy of attentions or regard, as a petition or motion in court.

entry.def: Dismission.
Dismission; discharge.
entry.q: Officeholders were commanded faithfully to enforce it, upon pain of immediate dismissal.

entry.def: subject to dismissal.

entry.ety: Cf. L. dimissio

sn.def: The act dismissing or sending away; permission to leave; leave to depart; dismissal; as, the dismission of the grand jury.
Removal from office or employment; discharge, either with honor or with disgrace.
Rejection; a setting aside as trivial, invalid, or unworthy of consideration.

entry.def: Giving dismission.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Dismortaged; p. pr. & vb. n. Dismortgaging
entry.def: To redeem from mortgage.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Dismounted; p. pr. & vb. n. Dismounting
entry.ety: Pref. dis- + mount: cf. OF. desmonter, F. démonter

sn.def: To come down; to descend.
sn.q: But now the bright sun ginneth to dismount.

sn.def: To alight from a horse; to descend or get off, as a rider from his beast; as, the troops dismounted .
To throw or bring down from an elevation, place of honor and authority, or the like.
sn.q: Dismounted from his authority.

sn.def: To throw or remove from a horse; to unhorse; as, the soldier dismounted his adversary.
To take down, or apart, as a machine.

To throw or remove from the carriage, or from that on which a thing is mounted; to break the carriage or wheels of, and render useless; to deprive of equipments or mountings; -- said esp. of artillery.

entry.def: To make alien; to deprive of the privileges of birth.

entry.ety: Pref. dis- + nature: cf. OF. desnaturé, F. dénaturé
entry.def: Deprived or destitute of natural feelings; unnatural.
Neglect or refusal to obey; violation of a command or prohibition.
entry.q: He is undutiful to him other actions, and lives in open disobedience.

entry.def: Disobedience.

entry.ety: Pref. dis- + obedient. See Disobey Obedient

sn.def: Neglecting or refusing to obey; omitting to do what is commanded, or doing what is prohibited; refractory; not observant of duty or rules prescribed by authority; -- applied to persons and acts.
sn.q: This disobedient spirit in the colonies.
Disobedient unto the word of the Lord.

sn.def: Not yielding.
sn.q: Medicines used unnecessarily contribute to shorten life, by sooner rendering peculiar parts of the system disobedient to stimuli.

entry.def: In a disobedient manner.

entry.ety: F. désobéissance
entry.def: Disobedience.

entry.ety: F. désobéissant
entry.def: Disobedient.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Disobeyed; p. pr. & vb. n. Disobeying
entry.ety: F. désobéir; pref. dés-L. dis-) + obéir. See Obey, and cf. Disobedient
entry.def: Not to obey; to neglect or refuse to obey (a superior or his commands, the laws, etc.); to transgress the commands of (one in authority); to violate, as an order; as, refractory children disobey their parents; men disobey their Maker and the laws.
entry.q: Not to disobey her lord's behest.

entry.def: To refuse or neglect to obey; to violate commands; to be disobedient.
entry.q: He durst not know how to disobey.

entry.def: One who disobeys.

sn.def: The act of disobliging.
A disobliging act; an offense.
Release from obligation.

entry.def: Releasing from obligation.
entry.q: Disobligatorypower.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Disobliged; p. pr. & vb. n. Disobliging
entry.ety: Pref. dis- + oblige: cf. F. désobliger

sn.def: To do an act which contravenes the will or desires of; to offend by an act of unkindness or incivility; to displease; to refrain from obliging; to be unaccommodating to.
sn.q: Those . . . who slight and disoblige their friends, shall infallibly come to know the value of them by having none when they shall most need them.
My plan has given offense to some gentlemen, whom it would not be very safe to disoblige.

sn.def: To release from obligation.
sn.q: Absolving and disobliging from a more general command for some just and reasonable cause.

entry.def: Release from obligation.
One who disobliges.

sn.def: Not obliging; not disposed to do a favor; unaccommodating; as, a disobliging person or act.
Displeasing; offensive.

entry.def: To turn away from the west; to throw out of reckoning as to longitude.
The state of being unemployed; want of occupation.
Want or difference of belief; disbelief.

entry.ety: L. dis- + oppilatus, p. p. of oppilare to shut up
entry.def: To open.

entry.ety: Pref. dis- + orb
entry.def: To throw out of the proper orbit; to unsphere.
Disorder.

entry.ety: See Ordain
entry.def: Inordinate; irregular; vicious.

entry.ety: Pref. dis- + order: cf. F. désordre

sn.def: Want of order or regular disposition; lack of arrangement; confusion; disarray; as, the troops were thrown into disorder; the papers are in disorder.
Neglect of order or system; irregularity.
sn.q: From vulgar bounds with brave disorder part, And snatch a grace beyond the reach of art.

sn.def: Breach of public order; disturbance of the peace of society; tumult.
Disturbance of the functions of the animal economy or of the soul; sickness; derangement.
sn.q: Disorderin the body.
sn.syn: Irregularity; disarrangement; confusion; tumult; bustle; disturbance; disease; illness; indisposition; sickness; ailment; malady; distemper. See Disease.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Disordered; p. pr. & vb. n. Disordering

sn.def: To disturb the order of; to derange or disarrange; to throw into confusion; to confuse.
sn.q: Disordering the whole frame or jurisprudence.
The burden . . . disordered the aids and auxiliary rafters into a common ruin.

sn.def: To disturb or interrupt the regular and natural functions of (either body or mind); to produce sickness or indisposition in; to discompose; to derange; as, to disorder the head or stomach.
sn.q: A man whose judgment was so much disordered by party spirit.

sn.def: To depose from holy orders.
Thrown into disorder; deranged; as, a disordered house, judgment.
Disorderly.

entry.def: The state of being disorderly.

sn.def: Not in order; marked by disorder; disarranged; immethodical; as, the books and papers are in a disorderly state.
Not acting in an orderly way, as the functions of the body or mind.
Not complying with the restraints of order and law; tumultuous; unruly; lawless; turbulent; as, disorderly people; disorderly assemblies.
Offensive to good morals and public decency; notoriously offensive; as, a disorderly house.
sn.syn: Irregular; immethodical; confused; tumultuous; inordinate; intemperate; unruly; lawless; vicious.

entry.def: In a disorderly manner; without law or order; irregularly; confusedly.
entry.q: Withdraw yourselves from every brother that walketh disorderly.
Savages fighting disorderly with stones.

entry.def: Disarrangement; disturbance.
Inordinate; disorderly.
entry.q: Withdisordinategestures.

entry.def: Inordinately.
The state of being in disorder; derangement; confusion.

entry.ety: Cf. F. désorganisation. See Disorganize v. t.

sn.def: The act of disorganizing; destruction of system.
The state of being disorganized; as, the disorganization of the body, or of government.
sn.q: The magazine of a pawnbroker in such total disorganization, that the owner can never lay his hands upon any one article at the moment he has occasion for it.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Disorganized; p. pr. & vb. n. Disorganizing
entry.ety: Pref. dis- + organize: cf. F. désorganiser
entry.def: To destroy the organic structure or regular system of (a government, a society, a party, etc.); to break up (what is organized); to throw into utter disorder; to disarrange.
entry.q: Lyford . . . attempted to disorganize the church.

entry.def: One who disorganizes or causes disorder and confusion.

sn.def: To turn away from the east; to confuse as to which way is east; to cause to lose one's bearings.
to cause (a person) to lose one's sense of direction; to cause to lose one's bearings or way; as, the tourist was disoriented by the winding and narrow streets.
to cause one to lose one's sense of time or place, or of one's own personal identity.
to confuse (a person) by changing or removing something which has served as a standard or guide to action; as, workers were rendered unemployed and disoriented by the rapid changes in the markets.

entry.def: To turn away from the east, or (figuratively) from the right or the truth.

entry.sn:
having lost one's bearings physically or mentally. I frequently find myself disoriented when I come up out of the subway;the anesthetic left her completely disoriented
confused, lost.

sn.def: socially disoriented; withdrawn from social interactions.

entry.sn: causing disorientation: causing confusion of directions. Also See: unoriented. Antonym: orienting

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Disowned; p. pr. & vb. n. Disowning

sn.def: To refuse to own or acknowledge as belonging to one's self; to disavow or deny, as connected with one's self personally; as, a parent can hardly disown his child; an author will sometimes disown his writings.
To refuse to acknowledge or allow; to deny.
sn.q: Then they, who brother's better claim disown, Expel their parents, and usurp the throne.
sn.syn: To disavow; disclaim; deny; abnegate; renounce; disallow.

entry.def: having social connections repudiated.
the refusal to acknowledge (something or somebody) as one's own.
Act of disowning.
To deoxidate; to deoxidize.
Deoxidation.
To deprive of oxygen; to deoxidize.
Deoxidation.

entry.ety: Pref. dis- asunder, different ways, to and fro + pace
entry.def: To roam.
entry.q: In this fair plot dispacing to and fro.

entry.def: To separate (a pair).
entry.q: I have . . . dispaired two doves.

entry.ety: L. dispandere to spread out; pref. dis- + pandere pansum, to spread out
entry.def: To spread out; to expand.

entry.ety: See Dispand
entry.def: Act of dispanding, or state of being dispanded.
Removed from paradise.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Disparaged; p. pr. & vb. n. Disparaging
entry.ety: OF. desparagier, F. déparager, to marry unequally; pref. des-L. dis-) + F. parage extraction, lineage, from L. par equal, peer. See Peer

sn.def: To match unequally; to degrade or dishonor by an unequal marriage.
sn.q: Alas! that any of my nation Should ever so foul disparaged be.

sn.def: To dishonor by a comparison with what is inferior; to lower in rank or estimation by actions or words; to speak slightingly of; to depreciate; to undervalue.
sn.q: Those forbidding appearances which sometimes disparage the actions of men sincerely pious.
Thou durst not thus disparage glorious arms.
sn.syn: To decry; depreciate; undervalue; underrate; cheapen; vilify; reproach; detract from; derogate from; degrade; debase. See Decry.

entry.def: Inequality in marriage; marriage with an inferior.
entry.q: Dissuaded her from such a disparage.

entry.ety: Cf. OF. desparagement

sn.def: Matching any one in marriage under his or her degree; injurious union with something of inferior excellence; a lowering in rank or estimation.
sn.q: And thought that match a foul disparagement.

sn.def: Injurious comparison with an inferior; a depreciating or dishonoring opinion or insinuation; diminution of value; dishonor; indignity; reproach; disgrace; detraction; -- commonly with to.
sn.q: It ought to be no disparagement to a star that it is not the sun.
Imitation is a disparagement and a degradation in a Christian minister.
sn.syn: Indignity; derogation; detraction; reproach; dishonor; debasement; degradation; disgrace.

entry.def: One who disparages or dishonors; one who vilifies or disgraces.
expressing a low opinion of; same as derogatory; as, disparaging remarks about the new house.
entry.syn: belittling, depreciative, deprecatory, depreciatory, derogative, derogatory, detractive, detracting, slighting, pejorative, denigratory.

entry.def: In a manner to disparage or dishonor; slightingly.

entry.ety: L. disparatus, p. p. of disparare to part, separate; dis- + parare to make ready, prepare

sn.def: Unequal; dissimilar; separate.
sn.q: Connecting disparate thoughts, purely by means of resemblances in the words expressing them.

sn.def: Pertaining to two coördinate species or divisions.

entry.def: Things so unequal or unlike that they can not be compared with each other.

entry.ety: Cf. F. disparition
entry.def: Act of disappearing; disappearance.

entries.entry:
Dis*par"i*ty n.; pl.Disparities #. LL. disparitas, fr. L. dispar unlike, unequal; dis- + par equal: cf. F. disparité. See Par Peer
Inequality; difference in age, rank, condition, or excellence; dissimilitude; -- followed by between in of as to, etc.; as, disparity in, or of, years; a disparity as to color.
The disparity between God and his intelligent creatures. The disparity of numbers was not such as ought to cause any uneasiness. Inequality; unlikeness; dissimilitude; disproportion; difference.

sn.def: To throw (a park or inclosure); to treat (a private park) as a common.
sn.q: The Gentiles were made to be God's people when the Jews' inclosure was disparked.

sn.def: To set at large; to release from inclosure.
sn.q: Till his free muse threw down the pale, And did at once dispark them all.

entry.ety: OF. desparpeillier
entry.def: To scatter abroad.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Disparted; p. pr. & vb. n. Disparting
entry.ety: Pref. dis- + part: cf. OF. despartir
entry.def: To part asunder; to divide; to separate; to sever; to rend; to rive or split; as, disparted air; disparted towers.
entry.q: Them in twelve troops their captain did dispart.
The world will be whole, and refuses to be disparted.

entry.def: To separate, to open; to cleave.

sn.def: The difference between the thickness of the metal at the mouth and at the breech of a piece of ordnance.
sn.q: On account of the dispart, the line of aim or line of metal, which is in a plane passing through the axis of the gun, always makes a small angle with the axis.

sn.def: A piece of metal placed on the muzzle, or near the trunnions, on the top of a piece of ordnance, to make the line of sight parallel to the axis of the bore; -- called also dispart sight, and muzzle sight.
To make allowance for the dispart in (a gun), when taking aim.
sn.q: Every gunner, before he shoots, must truly dispart his piece.

sn.def: To furnish with a dispart sight.

entry.def: Freedom from passion; an undisturbed state; apathy.

sn.def: Free from passion; not warped, prejudiced, swerved, or carried away by passion or feeling; judicial; calm; composed.
sn.q: Wise and dispassionate men.

sn.def: Not dictated by passion; not proceeding from temper or bias; impartial; as, dispassionate proceedings; a dispassionate view.
sn.syn: Calm; cool; composed serene; unimpassioned; temperate; moderate; impartial; unruffled.

entry.def: Free from passion; dispassionate.
entry.q: Dispassionedmen.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Dispatched; p. pr. & vb. n. Dispatching
entry.ety: OF. despeechier, F. dépêcher; prob. from pref. des-L. dis-) + (assumed) LL. pedicare to place obstacles in the way, fr. L. pedica fetter, fr. pes pedis, foot. See Foot, and cf. Impeach Despatch

sn.def: To dispose of speedily, as business; to execute quickly; to make a speedy end of; to finish; to perform.
sn.q: Ere we put ourselves in arms, dispatch we The business we have talked of.
The] harvest men . . . almost in one fair day dispatcheth all the harvest work.

sn.def: To rid; to free.
sn.q: I had clean dispatched myself of this great charge.

sn.def: To get rid of by sending off; to send away hastily.
sn.q: Unless dispatched to the mansion house in the country . . . they perish among the lumber of garrets.

sn.def: To send off or away; -- particularly applied to sending off messengers, messages, letters, etc., on special business, and implying haste.
sn.q: Even with the speediest expedition I will dispatch him to the emperor's cou��.

sn.def: To send out of the world; to put to death.
sn.q: The company shall stone them with stones, and dispatch them with their swords.
sn.syn: To expedite; hasten; speed; accelerate; perform; conclude; finish; slay; kill.

entry.def: To make haste; to conclude an affair; to finish a matter of business.
entry.q: They have dispatched with Pompey.

cs.cd: a swift vessel for conveying dispatches; an advice boat.
a box for carrying dispatches; a box for papers and other conveniences when traveling.

entry.ety: Cf. OF. despeche, F. dépêche. See Dispatch v. t.

sn.def: The act of sending a message or messenger in haste or on important business.
Any sending away; dismissal; riddance.
sn.q: To the utter dispatch of all their most beloved comforts.

sn.def: The finishing up of a business; speedy performance, as of business; prompt execution; diligence; haste.
sn.q: Serious business, craving quick dispatch.
To carry his scythe . . . with a sufficient dispatch through a sufficient space.

sn.def: A message dispatched or sent with speed; especially, an important official letter sent from one public officer to another; -- often used in the plural; as, a messenger has arrived with dispatches for the American minister; naval or military dispatches.
A message transmitted by telegraph.
sn.syn: Haste; hurry; promptness; celerity; speed. See Haste.

entry.def: One who dispatches.
Bent on haste; intent on speedy execution of business or any task; indicating haste; quick; as, dispatchful looks.

entry.ety: Cf. OF. despechement
entry.def: The act of dispatching.

entries.entry:
Dis"pa*thy n.; pl.Dispathies #. Pref. dis- + Gr. � passion. See Pathos
Lack of sympathy; want of passion; apathy. R Many discrepancies and some dispathies between us.

entry.def: To deprive of the claim of a pauper to public support; to deprive of the privilege of suing in forma pauperis.
To free a state of pauperism, or from paupers.

entry.ety: Pref. dis- + speed
entry.def: To send off with speed; to dispatch.
entry.q: Then they dispeeded themselves of the Cid and of their mother-in-law, Do�a Ximena.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Dispelled; p. pr. & vb. n. Dispelling
entry.ety: L. dispellere; dis- + pellere to push, drive. See Pulse a beating
entry.def: To drive away by scattering, or so to cause to vanish; to clear away; to banish; to dissipate; as, to dispel a cloud, vapors, cares, doubts, illusions.
entry.q: Satan] gently raised their fainting courage, and dispelled their fears.
I saw myself the lambent easy light Gild the brown horror, and dispel the night.

entry.def: See Dispense.

entry.ety: OF. despendre, L. dispendere to weigh out, dispense; dis- + pendere to weigh. See Pension Spend, and cf. Dispense
entry.def: To spend; to lay out; to expend.
entry.q: Able to dispend yearly twenty pounds and above.

entry.def: One who dispends or expends; a steward.

entry.ety: LL. dispensabilis. See Dispense

sn.def: Capable of being dispensed or administered.
Capable of being dispensed with.

entry.def: Quality of being dispensable.

entries.entry:
Dis*pen"sa*ry n.; pl.Dispensaries #. Cf. F. dispensaire
A place where medicines are prepared and dispensed; esp., a place where the poor can obtain medical advice and medicines gratuitously or at a nominal price.
A dispensatory.

entry.ety: F. dispensation, L. dispensatio

sn.def: The act of dispensing or dealing out; distribution; often used of the distribution of good and evil by God to man, or more generically, of the acts and modes of his administration.
sn.q: To respect the dispensations of Providence.

entry.sn: That which is dispensed, dealt out, or appointed; that which is enjoined or bestowed; especially Theol A system of principles, promises, and rules ordained and administered; scheme; economy; as, the Patriarchal, Mosaic, and Christian dispensations . Neither are God's methods or intentions different in his dispensations to each private man.

sn.def: The relaxation of a law in a particular case; permission to do something forbidden, or to omit doing something enjoined; specifically, in the Roman Catholic Church, exemption from some ecclesiastical law or obligation to God which a man has incurred of his own free will (oaths, vows, etc.).
sn.q: A dispensation was obtained to enable Dr. Barrow to marry.

entry.ety: Cf. F. dispensatif
entry.def: Granting dispensation.
By dispensation.

entry.ety: L
entry.def: A distributer; a dispenser.
In the way of dispensation; dispensatively.

entry.ety: L. dispensatorius relating to management. See Dispense v. t.
entry.def: Granting, or authorized to grant, dispensations.
entry.q: Dispensatorypower.

entries.entry: Dis*pen"sa*to*ry n.; pl.Dispensatories. A book or medicinal formulary containing a systematic description of drugs, and of preparations made from them. It is usually, but not always, distinguished from a pharmacopœia in that it issued by private parties, and not by an official body or by government.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Dispensed; p. pr. & vb. n. Dispensing
entry.ety: F. dispenser, L. dispensare, intens. of dispendere. See Dispend

sn.def: To deal out in portions; to distribute; to give; as, the steward dispenses provisions according directions; Nature dispenses her bounties; to dispense medicines.
sn.q: He is delighted to dispense a share of it to all the company.

sn.def: To apply, as laws to particular cases; to administer; to execute; to manage; to direct.
sn.q: While you dispense the laws, and guide the state.

sn.def: To pay for; to atone for.
sn.q: His sin was dispensed With gold, whereof it was compensed.

sn.def: To exempt; to excuse; to absolve; -- with from.
sn.q: It was resolved that all members of the House who held commissions, should be dispensed from parliamentary attendance.
He appeared to think himself born to be supported by others, and dispensed from all necessity of providing for himself.

entry.cs: To dispense with. To permit the neglect or omission of, as a form, a ceremony, an oath; to suspend the operation of, as a law; to give up, release, or do without, as services, attention, etc.; to forego; to part with. To allow by dispensation; to excuse; to exempt; to grant dispensation to or for. Obs “Conniving and dispensing with open and common adultery.” Milton. To break or go back from, as one's word. Obs Richardson.

sn.def: To compensate; to make up; to make amends.
sn.q: One loving hour For many years of sorrow can dispense.

sn.def: To give dispensation.
sn.q: He [the pope] can also dispense in all matters of ecclesiastical law.

entry.ety: Cf. F. dispense dispensation. See Dispense v. t.
entry.def: Dispensation; exemption.

entry.ety: OF. despense, F. dépense
entry.def: Expense; profusion; outlay.
entry.q: It was a vault built for great dispense.

entry.def: distributed or weighed out in carefully determined portions; as, medicines dispensed to the sick.
One who, or that which, dispenses; a distributer; as, a dispenser of favors.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Dispeopled; p. pr. & vb. n. Dispeopling
entry.ety: Pref. dis- + people: cf. F. dépeupler
entry.def: To deprive of inhabitants; to depopulate.
entry.q: Leave the land dispeopled and desolate.
A certain island long before dispeopled . . . by sea rivers.

entry.def: One who, or that which, dispeoples; a depopulator.

entry.ety: L. dispergere. See Disperse
entry.def: To sprinkle.

entry.ety: Gr. di- = dis + spe`rma seed, fr. spei`rein to sow: cf. F. disperme
entry.def: Containing only two seeds; two-seeded.

entry.ety: OF. desparpeulier
entry.def: To scatter; to sprinkle.
entry.q: Odorous water wasDisperpled lightly on my head and neck.

entry.def: The act or result of dispersing or scattering; dispersion.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Dispersed; p. pr. & vb. n. Dispersing
entry.ety: L. dispersus, p. p. of dispergere to strew, scatter. See Sparse

sn.def: To scatter abroad; to drive to different parts; to distribute; to diffuse; to spread; as, the Jews are dispersed among all nations.
sn.q: The lips of the wise disperse knowledge.
Two lions, in the still, dark night, A herd of beeves disperse.

sn.def: To scatter, so as to cause to vanish; to dissipate; as, to disperse vapors.
sn.q: Dispersed are the glories.
sn.syn: To scatter; dissipate; dispel; spread; diffuse; distribute; deal out; disseminate.

sn.def: To separate; to go or move into different parts; to vanish; as, the company dispersed at ten o'clock; the clouds disperse.
To distribute wealth; to share one's abundance with others.
sn.q: He hath dispersed, he hath given to the poor.

cs.cd: harmony in which the tones composing the chord are widely separated, as by an octave or more.

entry.def: Scattered.
Dispersedness.
One that disperses.

cs.cd: the separation of the optic axes in biaxial crystals, due to the fact that the axial angle has different values for the different colors of the spectrum.

entry.ety: CF. F. dispersion

sn.def: The act or process of scattering or dispersing, or the state of being scattered or separated; as, the Jews in their dispersion retained their rites and ceremonies; a great dispersion of the human family took place at the building of Babel.
sn.q: The days of your slaughter and of your dispersions are accomplished.

sn.def: The separation of light into its different colored rays, arising from their different refrangibilities.

cs.cd: the relative effect of a material in separating the different rays of light by refraction, as when the substance is formed into a prism.

entry.def: Tending to disperse.
To deprive of personality or individuality.
entry.q: We multiply; we dispersonate ourselves.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Dispirited; p. pr. & vb. n. Dispiriting
entry.ety: Pref. dis- + spirit

sn.def: To deprive of cheerful spirits; to depress the spirits of; to dishearten; to discourage.
sn.q: Not dispirited with my afflictions.
He has dispirited himself by a debauch.

sn.def: To distill or infuse the spirit of.
sn.q: This makes a man master of his learning, and dispirits the book into the scholar.
sn.syn: To dishearten; discourage; deject; damp; depress; cast down; intimidate; daunt; cow.

entry.def: Depressed in spirits; deprived of cheer or enthusiasm; disheartened; discouraged; daunted.
entry.syn: depressed, down(predicate), downcast, downhearted, low, low-spirited, disheartened, discouraged, demoralized.

entry.def: causing dejection; discouraging. Opposite of encouraging.

sn.def: causing dejection or depression.

entry.def: Depression of spirits; discouragement.
entry.q: Procter, in evident distress and dispiritment, was waiting the slow conclusion of this.

entry.ety: Pref. dis- + piteous. Cf. Despiteous
entry.def: Full of despite; cruel; spiteful; pitiless.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Displaced; p. pr. & vb. n. Displacing
entry.ety: Pref. dis- + place: cf. F. déplacer

sn.def: To change the place of; to remove from the usual or proper place; to put out of place; to place in another situation; as, the books in the library are all displaced .
To crowd out; to take the place of.
sn.q: Holland displaced Portugal as the mistress of those seas.

sn.def: To remove from a state, office, dignity, or employment; to discharge; to depose; as, to displace an officer of the revenue.
To dislodge; to drive away; to banish.
sn.q: You have displaced the mirth.

entry.def: Capable of being displaced.

cs.cd: the volume of the space swept through, or weight of steam, water, etc., displaced, in a given time, by the piston of a steam engine or pump.

entry.ety: Cf. F. déplacement

sn.def: The act of displacing, or the state of being displaced; a putting out of place.
sn.q: Unnecessary displacement of funds.
The displacement of the sun by parallax.

sn.def: The quantity of anything, as water, displaced by a floating body, as by a ship, the weight of the displaced liquid being equal to that of the displacing body.
The process of extracting soluble substances from organic material and the like, whereby a quantity of saturated solvent is displaced, or removed, for another quantity of the solvent.

entry.ety: LL. displacentia, for L. displicentia, fr. displicere to displease; dis- + placere to please. See Displease, and cf. Displeasance
entry.def: Want of complacency or gratification; envious displeasure; dislike.

sn.def: One that displaces.
The funnel part of the apparatus for solution by displacement.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Di�planted; p. pr. & vb. n. Displanting
entry.ety: Pref. dis- + plant: cf. OF. desplanter, F. déplanter

sn.def: To remove (what is planted or fixed); to unsettle and take away; to displace; to root out; as, to displant inhabitants.
sn.q: I did not think a look, Or a poor word or two, could have displanted Such a fixed constancy.

sn.def: To strip of what is planted or settled; as, to displant a country of inhabitants.

entry.def: The act of displanting; removal; displacement.
To untwist; to uncurl; to unplat.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Displayed; p. pr. & vb. n. Displaying
entry.ety: OE. displaien desplaien, OF. despleier desploier, F. déployer; pref. des-L. dis-) + pleier ploier plier, F. ployer plier, to fold, bend, L. plicare. See Ply, and cf. Deploy Splay

sn.def: To unfold; to spread wide; to expand; to stretch out; to spread.
sn.q: The northern wind his wings did broad display.

sn.def: To extend the front of (a column), bringing it into line.
To spread before the view; to show; to exhibit to the sight, or to the mind; to make manifest.
sn.q: His statement . . . displays very clearly the actual condition of the army.

sn.def: To make an exhibition of; to set in view conspicuously or ostentatiously; to exhibit for the sake of publicity; to parade.
sn.q: Proudly displaying the insignia of their order.

sn.def: To make conspicuous by large or prominent type.
To discover; to descry.
sn.q: And from his seat took pleasure to display The city so adorned with towers.

sn.def: To output (results or data) in a visible manner on the screen of a monitor, CRT, or other device.
sn.syn: To exhibit; show; manifest; spread out; parade; expand; flaunt.

entry.def: To make a display; to act as one making a show or demonstration.

sn.def: An opening or unfolding; exhibition; manifestation.
sn.q: Having witnessed displays of his power and grace.

sn.def: Ostentatious show; exhibition for effect; parade.
sn.q: He died, as erring man should die, Without display, without parade.

sn.def: An electronic device on which the output signal of another electronic device may be presented in a visual form; -- also called display device. Typically the display device it is the screen of a cathode-ray tube, as in a computer monitor, but other forms of visual display such as LED or liquid crystal devices are also used. The printed output from a computer or other device is not considered as a display.
The output signal from a computer program, displayed on a display device. The displayed signal may consist of letters, numbers, or any graphical image.
a pattern of behavior, such as showing a body part to another animal, by which one animal conveys information to another, as for mating or defense.
Unfolded; expanded; exhibited conspicuously or ostentatiously.
With wings expanded; -- said of a bird of prey, esp. an eagle.
Set with lines of prominent type interspersed, to catch the eye.

entry.def: One who, or that which, displays.
To discipline; to correct.
entry.q: And bitter Penance, with an iron whip, Was wont him once to disple every day.

entry.ety: OF. desplaisance, F. déplaisance. Cf. Displacency
entry.def: Displeasure; discontent; annoyance.

entry.ety: OF. desplaisant, F. déplaisant. See Displease
entry.def: Unpleasing; offensive; unpleasant.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Displeased; p. pr. & vb. n. Displeasing
entry.ety: OF. desplaisir, whence F. déplaisir displeasure; pref. des-L. dis-) + plaisir to please. See Please, and cf. Displeasure

sn.def: To make not pleased; to excite a feeling of disapprobation or dislike in; to be disagreeable to; to offend; to vex; -- often followed by with or at. It usually expresses less than to anger vex irritate, or provoke.
sn.q: God was displeased with this thing.
Wilt thou be displeased at us forever?
This virtuous plaster will displease Your tender sides.
Adversity is so wholesome . . . why should we be displeased therewith?

sn.def: To fail to satisfy; to miss of.
sn.q: I shall displease my ends else.
sn.syn: To offend; disgust; vex; annoy; dissatisfy; chafe; anger; provoke; affront.

entry.def: To give displeasure or offense.
With displeasure.
Displeasure.
One who displeases.
Causing displeasure or dissatisfaction; offensive; disagreeable.

entry.ety: Pref. dis- + pleasure: cf. OF. desplaisir, F. déplaisir. Cf. Displease

sn.def: The feeling of one who is displeased; irritation or uneasiness of the mind, occasioned by anything that counteracts desire or command, or which opposes justice or a sense of propriety; disapprobation; dislike; dissatisfaction; disfavor; indignation.
sn.q: O Lord, rebuke me not in thine anger, neither chasten me in thy hot displeasure.
Undoubtedly he will relent, and turn From his displeasure.

sn.def: That which displeases; cause of irritation or annoyance; offense; injury.
sn.q: Hast thou delight to see a wretched man Do outrage and displeasure to himself?

sn.def: State of disgrace or disfavor; disfavor.
sn.q: He went into Poland, being in displeasure with the pope for overmuch familiarity.
sn.syn: Dissatisfaction; disapprobation; disfavor; distaste; dislike; anger; hate; aversion; indignation; offense.

entry.def: To displease.
To deprive or strip, as a house of furniture, or a barn of stock.

entry.ety: L. displicentia. See Displacency
entry.def: Dislike; dissatisfaction; discontent.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Disploded; p. pr. & vb. n. Disploding
entry.ety: L. displodere displosum; dis- + plodere plaudere, to clap, strike, beat
entry.def: To discharge; to explode.
entry.q: In posture to displode their second tire Of thunder.

entry.def: To burst with a loud report; to explode.
entry.q: Displodingengines.

entry.def: Explosion.
entry.q: The vast displosion dissipates the clouds.

entry.def: Explosive.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Displumed; p. pr. & vb. n. Displuming
entry.ety: Pref. dis- + plume: cf. OF. desplumer, F. déplumer
entry.def: To strip of, or as of, a plume, or plumes; to deprive of decoration; to dishonor; to degrade.
entry.q: Displumed, degraded, and metamorphosed.

entry.def: One of several isomeric organic bases of the quinoline series of alkaloids.
See Despond.

entry.ety: L. dispondeus, Gr. �; di- = di`s- twice + � spondee
entry.def: A double spondee; a foot consisting of four long syllables.

entry.ety: L. disponere. See Disposition

sn.def: To dispose.
To dispose of.
To make over, or convey, legally.
sn.q: He has disponed . . . the whole estate.

entry.def: The person to whom any property is legally conveyed.
One who legally transfers property from himself to another.

entries.entry:
Dis*ponge" v. t. Pref. dis- + sponge
To sprinkle, as with water from a sponge. Poetic & Rare
dispunge
O sovereign mistress of true melancholy, The poisonous damp of night disponge upon me. Shak.

entry.def: To refuse to consider as pope; to depose from the popedom.
entry.q: One whom they dispoped.

entry.ety: Pref. di- + sporous
entry.def: Having two spores.

entry.ety: OF. desport deport. See Disport v. i., and cf. Sport
entry.def: Play; sport; pastime; diversion; playfulness.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Disported; p. pr. & vb. n. Disporting
entry.ety: OF. se desporter; pref. des-L. dis-) + F. porter to carry; orig. therefore, to carry one's self away from work, to go to amuse one's self. See Port demeanor, and cf. Sport
entry.def: To play; to wanton; to move in gayety; to move lightly and without restraint; to amuse one's self.
entry.q: Where light disports in ever mingling dyes.
Childe Harold basked him in the noontide sun,Disporting there like any other fly.

entry.ety: OF. desporter. See Disport v. i.

sn.def: To divert or amuse; to make merry.
sn.q: They could disport themselves.

sn.def: To remove from a port; to carry away.

entry.def: Act of disporting; diversion; play.

entry.ety: From Dispose
entry.def: Subject to disposal; free to be used or employed as occasion may require; not assigned to any service or use.
entry.q: The great of this kingdom . . . has easily afforded a disposable surplus.

sn.def: designed to be disposed of after use; -- of articles of commerce. The term implies that it is less expensive to manufacture a new one than to clean and recycle the used item to make it fit for use again; as, disposable dishes; disposable diapers; disposable gloves. Opposite of reusable.

entry.def: that portion of income which is available for spending on discretionary purchases; for individuals, it is usually calculated as total income less taxes. National disposable income, which is the disposable income of all individuals and businesses, is calculated as total national income minus taxes plus transfer payments.

entry.ety: From Dispose

sn.def: The act of disposing, or disposing of, anything; arrangement; orderly distribution; a putting in order; as, the disposal of the troops in two lines.
Ordering; regulation; adjustment; management; government; direction.
sn.q: The execution leave to high disposal.

sn.def: Regulation of the fate, condition, application, etc., of anything; the transference of anything into new hands, a new place, condition, etc.; alienation, or parting; as, a disposal of property.
sn.q: A domestic affair of great importance, which is no less than the disposal of my sister Jenny for life.

sn.def: Power or authority to dispose of, determine the condition of, control, etc., especially in the phrase at, or in, the disposal of.
sn.q: The sole and absolute disposal of him an his concerns.
sn.syn: Disposition; dispensation; management; conduct; government; distribution; arrangement; regulation; control.

entry.cs: To dispose of. To determine the fate of; to exercise the power of control over; to fix the condition, application, employment, etc. of; to direct or assign for a use. Freedom to order their actions and dispose of their possessions and persons. Locke. To exercise finally one's power of control over; to pass over into the control of some one else, as by selling; to alienate; to part with; to relinquish; to get rid of; as, to dispose of a house; to dispose of one's time. More water . . . than can be disposed of. T. Burnet. I have disposed of her to a man of business. Tatler. A rural judge disposed of beauty's prize. Waller.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Disposed; p. pr. & vb. n. Disposing
entry.ety: F. disposer; pref. dis- + poser to place. See Pose

sn.def: To distribute and put in place; to arrange; to set in order; as, to dispose the ships in the form of a crescent.
sn.q: Who hath disposed the whole world?
All ranged in order and disposed with grace.
The rest themselves in troops did else dispose.

sn.def: To regulate; to adjust; to settle; to determine.
sn.q: The knightly forms of combat to dispose.

sn.def: To deal out; to assign to a use; to bestow for an object or purpose; to apply; to employ; to dispose of.
sn.q: Importuned him that what he designed to bestow on her funeral, he would rather dispose among the poor.

sn.def: To give a tendency or inclination to; to adapt; to cause to turn; especially, to incline the mind of; to give a bent or propension to; to incline; to make inclined; -- usually followed by to, sometimes by for before the indirect object.
sn.q: Endure and conquer; Jove will soon dispose To future good our past and present woes.
Suspicions dispose kings to tyranny, husbands to jealousy, and wise men to irresolution and melancholy.
sn.syn: To set; arrange; order; distribute; adjust; regulate; adapt; fit; incline; bestow; give.

entry.def: To bargain; to make terms.
entry.q: She had disposed with Cæsar.

sn.def: Disposal; ordering; management; power or right of control.
sn.q: But such is the dispose of the sole Disposer of empires.

sn.def: Cast of mind; disposition; inclination; behavior; demeanor.
sn.q: He hath a person, and a smooth dispose To be suspected.

cs.cd: in good condition; in good health.

sn.def: Inclined; minded.
sn.q: When he was disposed to pass into Achaia.

sn.def: Inclined to mirth; jolly.

entry.def: The state of being disposed or inclined; inclination; propensity.
Disposal.
One who, or that which, disposes; a regulator; a director; a bestower.
entry.q: Absolute lord and disposer of all things.

entry.def: In a manner to dispose.

entry.ety: See Disposition
entry.def: Disposed.

entry.ety: F. disposition dispositio, fr. disponere to dispose; dis- + ponere to place. See Position, and cf. Dispone

sn.def: The act of disposing, arranging, ordering, regulating, or transferring; application; disposal; as, the disposition of a man's property by will.
sn.q: Who have received the law by the disposition of angels.
The disposition of the work, to put all things in a beautiful order and harmony, that the whole may be of a piece.

sn.def: The state or the manner of being disposed or arranged; distribution; arrangement; order; as, the disposition of the trees in an orchard; the disposition of the several parts of an edifice.
Tendency to any action or state resulting from natural constitution; nature; quality; as, a disposition in plants to grow in a direction upward; a disposition in bodies to putrefaction.
Conscious inclination; propension or propensity.
