sn.q: How stands your disposition to be married?

sn.def: Natural or prevailing spirit, or temperament of mind, especially as shown in intercourse with one's fellow-men; temper of mind.
sn.q: A man of turbulentdisposition.
He is of a very melancholydisposition.
His disposition led him to do things agreeable to his quality and condition wherein God had placed him.

sn.def: Mood; humor.
sn.q: As I perchance hereafter shall think meet To put an antic disposition on.
sn.syn: Disposal; adjustment; regulation; arrangement; distribution; order; method; adaptation; inclination; propensity; bestowment; alienation; character; temper; mood.Disposition Character Temper. Disposition is the natural humor of a person, the predominating quality of his character, the constitutional habit of his mind. Character is this disposition influenced by motive, training, and will. Temper is a quality of the fiber of character, and is displayed chiefly when the emotions, especially the passions, are aroused.

entry.def: Pertaining to disposition.
Having (such) a disposition; -- used in compounds; as, well-dispositioned .

entry.ety: Cf. F. dispositif

sn.def: Disposing; tending to regulate; decretive.
sn.q: His dispositive wisdom and power.

sn.def: Belonging to disposition or natural, tendency.
sn.q: Dispositiveholiness.

entry.def: In a dispositive manner; by natural or moral disposition.
entry.q: Do dispositively what Moses is recorded to have done literally, . . . break all the ten commandments at once.

entry.ety: L. See Disposition

sn.def: A disposer.
The planet which is lord of the sign where another planet is.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Dispossessed; p. pr. & vb. n. Dispossessing
entry.ety: Pref. dis- + possess: cf. F. déposséder
entry.def: To put out of possession; to deprive of the actual occupancy of, particularly of land or real estate; to disseize; to eject; -- usually followed by of before the thing taken away; as, to dispossess a king of his crown.
entry.q: Usurp the land, and dispossess the swain.

entry.def: physically or spiritually homeless or deprived of security.
entry.q: made a living out of shepherding dispossessed people from one country to another

entry.ety: Cf. F. dépossession

sn.def: The act of putting out of possession; the state of being dispossessed.
The putting out of possession, wrongfully or otherwise, of one who is in possession of a freehold, no matter in what title; -- called also ouster.

entry.def: One who dispossesses.
To eject from a post; to displace.

entry.ety: From Dispose

sn.def: The act of disposing; power to dispose of; disposal; direction.
sn.q: Give up My estate to his disposure.

sn.def: Disposition; arrangement; position; posture.
sn.q: In a kind of warlike disposure.

entry.def: Blamable.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Dispraised; p. pr. & vb. n. Dispraising
entry.ety: OE. dispreisen, OF. desprisier despreisier, F. dépriser; pref. des-L. dis-) + prisier, F. priser, to prize, praise. See Praise, and cf. Disprize Depreciate
entry.def: To withdraw praise from; to notice with disapprobation or some degree of censure; to disparage; to blame.
entry.q: Dispraising the power of his adversaries.
I dispraised him before the wicked, that the wicked might not fall in love with him.

entry.ety: Cf. OF. despris. See Dispraise v. t.
entry.def: The act of dispraising; detraction; blame censure; reproach; disparagement.
entry.q: In praise and in dispraise the same.

entry.def: One who blames or dispraises.
By way of dispraise.

entry.ety: Pref. dis- + spread
entry.def: To spread abroad, or different ways; to spread apart; to open; as, the sun dispreads his beams.
To extend or expand itself.
entry.q: While tyrant Heat, dispreading through the sky.

entry.def: One who spreads abroad.
entry.q: Dispreaders both of vice and error.

entry.def: To free from prejudice.
To render unprepared.
To make unlike a prince.
entry.q: For I was drench'd with ooze, and torn with briers, . . . And, all one rag, disprinced from head to heel.

entry.def: To let loose from prison, to set at liberty.
To deprive of a privilege or privileges.

entry.ety: Cf. Dispraise
entry.def: To depreciate.
To renounce the profession or pursuit of.
entry.q: His arms, which he had vowed to disprofess.

entry.def: Loss; damage.
To be, or to cause to be, without profit or benefit.
Unprofitable.

entry.ety: Pref. dis- + proof. Cf. Disprove
entry.def: A proving to be false or erroneous; confutation; refutation; as, to offer evidence in disproof of a statement.
entry.q: I need not offer anything farther in support of one, or in disproof of the other.

entry.def: To cause to be no longer property; to dispossess of.

entry.ety: Pref. dis- + proportion: cf. F. disproportion

sn.def: Want of proportion in form or quantity; lack of symmetry; as, the arm may be in disproportion to the body; the disproportion of the length of a building to its height.
Want of suitableness, adequacy, or due proportion to an end or use; unsuitableness; disparity; as, the disproportion of strength or means to an object.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Disproportioned; p. pr. & vb. n. Disproportioning
entry.def: To make unsuitable in quantity, form, or fitness to an end; to violate symmetry in; to mismatch; to join unfitly.
entry.q: To shape my legs of an unequal size; To disproportion me in every part.
A degree of strength altogether disproportioned to the extent of its territory.

entry.def: Disproportional; unsuitable in form, size, quantity, or adaptation; disproportionate; inadequate.

Not having due proportion to something else; not having proportion or symmetry of parts; unsuitable in form, quantity or value; inadequate; unequal; as, a disproportional limb constitutes deformity in the body; the studies of youth should not be disproportional to their understanding.
The state of being disproportional.
In a disproportional manner; unsuitably in form, quantity, or value; unequally.

Not proportioned; unsymmetrical; unsuitable to something else in bulk, form, value, or extent; out of proportion; inadequate; as, in a perfect body none of the limbs are disproportionate; it is wisdom not to undertake a work disproportionate means.

entry.ety: L. dis- + propriare to appropriate, fr. proprius one's own, proper
entry.def: To cancel the appropriation of; to disappropriate.
Capable of being disproved or refuted.
Act of disproving; disproof.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Disproved; p. pr. & vb. n. Disproving
entry.ety: Pref. dis- + prove: cf. OF. desprover

sn.def: To prove to be false or erroneous; to confute; to refute.
sn.q: That false supposition I advanced in order to disprove it.

sn.def: To disallow; to disapprove of.

entry.def: One who disproves or confutes.
Not to provide; to fail to provide.
Wanting in punctilious respect; discourteous.
entry.q: That were dispunct to the ladies.

entry.ety: See 1st Dispunge
entry.def: To expunge.

entry.ety: L. dispungere to prick apart, i. e., check off the debts and credits of an account; dis- + pungere to prick
entry.def: To expunge; to erase.
See Disponge.
Without penal restraint; not punishable.
To dissuade; to frustrate; as, to dispurpose plots.
To disburse.

entry.ety: Pref. dis- + purvey: cf. OF. desporveoir, F. dépourvoir
entry.def: To disfurnish; to strip.
Want of provisions; �ack of food.

entry.ety: L. disputabilis: cf. F. disputable. See Dispute v. i.

sn.def: Capable of being disputed; liable to be called in question, controverted, or contested; or doubtful certainty or propriety; controvertible; as, disputable opinions, propositions, points, or questions.
sn.q: Actions, every one of which is very disputable.

sn.def: Disputatious; contentious.

entry.def: State of being disputable.

entry.ety: See Dispute v. i.
entry.def: Proneness to dispute.

entry.ety: L. disputants, p. pr. of disputare: cf. F. disputant. See Dispute v. i.
entry.def: Disputing; engaged in controversy.
One who disputes; one who argues in opposition to another; one appointed to dispute; a controvertist; a reasoner in opposition.
entry.q: A singularly eager, acute, and pertinacious disputant.

entry.ety: OE. desputeson disputacion, OF. desputeison, F. disputation, fr. L. disputatio. See Dispute v. i.

sn.def: The act of disputing; a reasoning or argumentation in opposition to something, or on opposite sides; controversy in words; verbal contest respecting the truth of some fact, opinion, proposition, or argument.
A rhetorical exercise in which parties reason in opposition to each other on some question proposed.

entry.def: Inclined to dispute; apt to civil or controvert; characterized by dispute; as, a disputatious person or temper.
entry.q: The Christian doctrine of a future life was no recommendation of the new religion to the wits and philosophers of that disputations period.

entry.ety: L. disputativus
entry.def: Disposed to dispute; inclined to cavil or to reason in opposition; as, a disputative temper.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Disputed; p. pr. & vb. n. Disputing
entry.ety: OE. desputen disputen, OF. desputer disputer, F. disputer, from L. disputare disputatum; dis- + putare to clean; hence, fig., to clear up, set in order, reckon, think. See Putative Pure
entry.def: To contend in argument; to argue against something maintained, upheld, or claimed, by another; to discuss; to reason; to debate; to altercate; to wrangle.
entry.q: Therefore disputedreasoned, Rev. Ver.] he in synagogue with the Jews.

sn.def: To make a subject of disputation; to argue pro and con; to discuss.
sn.q: The rest I reserve it be disputed how the magistrate is to do herein.

sn.def: To oppose by argument or assertion; to attempt to overthrow; to controvert; to express dissent or opposition to; to call in question; to deny the truth or validity of; as, to dispute assertions or arguments.
sn.q: To seize goods under the disputed authority of writs of assistance.

sn.def: To strive or contend about; to contest.
sn.q: To dispute the possession of the ground with the Spaniards.

sn.def: To struggle against; to resist.
sn.q: Dispute it [grief] like a man.
sn.syn: To controvert; contest; gainsay; doubt; question; argue; debate; discuss; impugn. See Argue.

cs.cd: indisputably; incontrovertibly.

entry.ety: Cf. F. dispute. See Dispute v. i.

sn.def: Verbal controversy; contest by opposing argument or expression of opposing views or claims; controversial discussion; altercation; debate.
sn.q: Addicted more To contemplation and profound dispute.

sn.def: Contest; struggle; quarrel.
sn.syn: Altercation; controversy; argumentation; debate; discussion; quarrel; disagreement; difference; contention; wrangling. See Altercation.

entry.def: Admitting no dispute; incontrovertible.
One who disputes, or who is given to disputes; a controvertist.
entry.q: Where is the disputer of this world?

entry.ety: See Disputation
entry.def: Dispute; discussion.

sn.def: The act of disqualifying, or state of being disqualified; want of qualification; incompetency; disability; as, the disqualification of men for holding certain offices.
That which disqualifies; that which incapacitates or makes unfit; as, conviction of crime is a disqualification of a person for office; sickness is a disqualification for labor.
sn.q: I must still retain the consciousness of those disqualifications which you have been pleased to overlook.

sn.def: rendered ineligible by law or rule or provision; as, disqualified from voting.
barred from competition for violation of rules; as, a disqualified player.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Disqualified dĭs*kwŏl"ĭ*fīd; p. pr. & vb. n. Disqualifying

sn.def: To deprive of the qualities or properties necessary for any purpose; to render unfit; to incapacitate; -- with for or from before the purpose, state, or act.
sn.q: My common illness disqualifies me for all conversation; I mean my deafness.
Me are not disqualified by their engagements in trade from being received in high society.

sn.def: To deprive of some power, right, or privilege, by positive restriction; to disable; to debar legally; as, a conviction of perjury disqualifies a man to be a witness.

entry.def: To diminish the quantity of; to lessen.
Deprived of quiet; impatient; restless; uneasy.
Want of quiet; want of tranquility in body or mind; uneasiness; restlessness; disturbance; anxiety.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Disquieted; p. pr. & vb. n. Disquieting
entry.def: To render unquiet; to deprive of peace, rest, or tranquility; to make uneasy or restless; to disturb.
entry.q: Why art thou cast down, O my soul, and why art thou disquieted within me?
As quiet as these disquieted times will permit.
entry.syn: To harass; disturb; vex; fret; excite; agitate.

entry.def: The act of disquieting; a state of disquiet.
entry.q: It] roars and strives 'gainst its disquietal.

entry.def: One who, or that which, disquiets, or makes uneasy; a disturber.
Producing inquietude or uneasiness.
Tending to disquiet.
In a disquiet manner; uneasily; as, he rested disquietly that night.
State of being disquieted; uneasiness; harassment.
Disturbance of quiet in body or mind; restlessness; uneasiness.
Causing uneasiness.
entry.q: So distasteful and disquietous to a number of men.

entry.def: Want of peace or tranquility; uneasiness; disturbance; agitation; anxiety.
entry.q: Fears and disquietude, and unavoidable anxieties of mind.

entry.ety: L. disquisitio, fr. disquirere to inquire diligently, investigate; dis- + quaerere to seek. See Quest
entry.def: A formal or systematic inquiry into, or discussion of, any subject; a full examination or investigation of a matter, with the arguments and facts bearing upon it; elaborate essay; dissertation.
entry.q: For accurate research or grave disquisition he was not well qualified.

entry.def: Pertaining to disquisition; of the nature of disquisition.
Pertaining to disquisition; disquisitional.
Relating to disquisition; fond of discussion or investigation; examining; inquisitive.
Disquisitory.
Of or pertaining to disquisition; disquisitive.

entry.ety: Pref. dis- + range: cf. OF. desrengier, F. dérangier. See Derange Disrank
entry.def: To disarrange.

entry.ety: Cf. Derange

sn.def: To degrade from rank.
To throw out of rank or into confusion.

entry.def: To reduce to a lower rating or rank; to degrade.
Disarray; -- an obsolete variant.
To divest of reality; to make uncertain.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. disregarded; p. pr. & vb. n. disregarding
entry.def: Not to regard; to pay no heed to; to omit to take notice of; to neglect to observe; to slight as unworthy of regard or notice; as, to disregard the admonitions of conscience.
entry.q: Studious of good, man disregarded fame.

entry.def: The act of disregarding, or the state of being disregarded; intentional neglect; omission of notice; want of attention; slight.
entry.q: The disregard of experience.

entry.def: One who disregards.
Neglect; negligent; heedless; regardless.
Negligently; heedlessly.

sn.def: Want of relish; dislike (of the palate or of the mind); distaste; a slight degree of disgust; as, a disrelish for some kinds of food.
sn.q: Men love to hear of their power, but have an extreme disrelish to be told of their duty.

sn.def: Absence of relishing or palatable quality; bad taste; nauseousness.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Disrelished; p. pr. & vb. n. Disrelishing

sn.def: Not to relish; to regard as unpalatable or offensive; to feel a degree of disgust at.
To deprive of relish; to make nauseous or disgusting in a slight degree.

entry.def: To fail to remember; to forget.
A state of being in bad condition, and needing repair.
entry.q: The fortifications were ancient and in disrepair.

entry.def: The state of being disreputable.

Not reputable; of bad repute; not in esteem; dishonorable; disgracing the reputation; tending to bring into disesteem; as, it is disreputable to associate familiarly with the mean, the lewd, and the profane.
entry.q: Why should you think that conduct disreputable in priests which you probably consider as laudable in yourself?
entry.syn: Dishonorable; discreditable; low; mean; disgraceful; shameful.

entry.def: In a disreputable manner.
Loss or want of reputation or good name; dishonor; disrepute; disesteem.
entry.q: Adisreputationof piety.

entry.def: Loss or want of reputation; ill character; disesteem; discredit.
entry.q: At the beginning of the eighteenth century astrology fell into general disrepute.

entry.def: To bring into disreputation; to hold in dishonor.
entry.q: More inclined to love them than to disrepute them.

entry.def: Want of respect or reverence; disesteem; incivility; discourtesy.
entry.q: Impatience of bearing the least affront or disrespect.

entry.def: To show disrespect to.
entry.q: We have disrespected and slighted God.

entry.def: Lack of respectability.
Not respectable; disreputable.
One who disrespects.
Wanting in respect; manifesting disesteem or lack of respect; uncivil; as, disrespectful behavior.
Showing lack of respect; disrespectful.
To treat irreverently or with disrespect.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Disrobed; p. pr. & vb. n. Disrobing
entry.def: To divest of a robe; to undress; figuratively, to strip of covering; to divest of that which clothes or decorates; as, autumn disrobes the fields of verdure.
entry.q: Two great peers were disrobed of their glory.

entry.def: One who, or that which, disrobes.
To unroof.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Disrooted; p. pr. & vb. n. Disrooting
entry.def: To tear up the roots of, or by the roots; hence, to tear from a foundation; to uproot.
entry.q: A piece of ground disrooted from its situation by subterraneous inundations.

entry.ety: Cf. OF. desrouter, F. dérouter
entry.def: To put to rout.
To deprive of the rudder, as a ship.
In a disorderly manner.
Unruly; disorderly.

entry.ety: L. disruptus diruptus, p. p. of disrumpere, to break or burst asunder; dis- + rumpere to break, burst. See Rupture
entry.def: Rent off; torn asunder; severed; disrupted.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Disrupted; p. pr. & vb. n. Disrupting

sn.def: To break asunder; to rend.
to destroy the continuity of, usually temporarily; as, electrical power was disrupted by the hurricane.
To interfere with or halt, especially by causing a lack of order; as, the shouting of the demonstrators disrupted the meeting.

entry.def: Not continuous in time or space. Opposite of continuous.

entry.ety: L. disruptio diruptio
entry.def: The act or rending asunder, or the state of being rent asunder or broken in pieces; breach; rent; dilaceration; rupture; as, the disruption of rocks in an earthquake; disruption of a state.
Causing, or tending to cause, disruption; caused by disruption; breaking through; bursting; as, the disruptive discharge of an electrical battery.
Disruption.
The state of being dissatisfied, unsatisfied, or discontented; uneasiness proceeding from the want of gratification, or from disappointed wishes and expectations.
entry.q: The ambitious man has little happiness, but is subject to much uneasiness and dissatisfaction.
entry.syn: Discontent; discontentment; displeasure; disapprobation; distaste; dislike.

entry.def: Causing dissatisfaction; unable to give content; unsatisfactory; displeasing.
entry.q: To have reduced the different qualifications in the different States to one uniform rule, would probably have been as dissatisfactory to some of the States, as difficult for the Convention.

entry.def: in a state of sulky dissatisfaction.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Dissatisfied; p. pr. & vb. n. Dissatisfying
entry.def: To render unsatisfied or discontented; to excite uneasiness in by frustrating wishes or expectations; to displease by the want of something requisite; as, to be dissatisfied with one's fortune.
entry.q: The dissatisfied factions of the autocracy.

entry.def: To unseat.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Dissected; p. pr. & vb. n. Dissecting
entry.ety: L. dissectus, p. p. of dissecare; dis- + secare to cut. See Section

sn.def: To divide into separate parts; to cut in pieces; to separate and expose the parts of, as an animal or a plant, for examination and to show their structure and relations; to anatomize.
To analyze, for the purposes of science or criticism; to divide and examine minutely.
sn.q: This paragraph . . . I have dissected for a sample.

sn.def: Cut into several parts; divided into sections; as, a dissected map.
Cut deeply into many lobes or divisions; as, a dissected leaf.

entry.def: Capable of being dissected, or separated by dissection.

sn.def: Dividing or separating the parts of an animal or vegetable body; as, a dissecting aneurism, one which makes its way between or within the coats of an artery.
Of or pertaining to, or received during, a dissection; as, a dissecting wound.
Used for or in dissecting; as, a dissecting knife; a dissecting microscope.

cs.cd: a poisoned wound incurred during the dissection of a dead body.

entry.ety: Cf. F. dissection

sn.def: The act of dissecting an animal or plant; as, dissection of the human body was held sacrilege till the time of Francis I.
Fig.: The act of separating or dividing for the purpose of critical examination.
Anything dissected; especially, some part, or the whole, of an animal or plant dissected so as to exhibit the structure; an anatomical so prepared.

entry.ety: Cf. F. dissecteur
entry.def: One who dissects; an anatomist.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Disseized; p. pr. & vb. n. Disseizing
entry.ety: Pref. dis- + seize: cf. F. dessaisir
entry.def: To deprive of seizin or possession; to dispossess or oust wrongfully (one in freehold possession of land); -- followed by of; as, to disseize a tenant of his freehold.
entry.q: Which savage beasts strive as eagerly to keep and hold those golden mines, as the Arimaspians to disseize them thereof.

entry.def: A person disseized, or put out of possession of an estate unlawfully; -- correlative to disseizor.

entry.ety: OF. dessaisine
entry.def: The act of disseizing; an unlawful dispossessing and ouster of a person actually seized of the freehold.
One who wrongfully disseizes, or puts another out of possession of a freehold.
A woman disseizes.
Disseizin.

entry.ety: Cf. F. dissemblance. See Dissemble
entry.def: Want of resemblance; dissimilitude.

entry.ety: Dissemble + -ance
entry.def: The act or art of dissembling; dissimulation.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Dissembled; p. pr. & vb. n. Dissembling
entry.ety: OF. dissembler to be dissimilar; pref. dis-L. dis-) + F. sembler to seem, L. simulare to simulate; cf. L. dissimulare to dissemble. See Simulate, and cf. Dissimulate

sn.def: To hide under a false semblance or seeming; to feign (something) not to be what it really is; to put an untrue appearance upon; to disguise; to mask.
sn.q: Dissemble all your griefs and discontents.
Perhaps it was right to dissemble your love, But -- why did you kick me down stairs?

sn.def: To put on the semblance of; to make pretense of; to simulate; to feign.
sn.q: He soon dissembled a sleep.
sn.syn: To conceal; disguise; cloak; cover; equivocate. See Conceal.

entry.def: To conceal the real fact, motives, intention, or sentiments, under some pretense; to assume a false appearance; to act the hypocrite.
entry.q: He that hateth dissembleth with his lips.
He [an enemydissembles when he assumes an air of friendship.

entry.usage: A person is called a dissembler with reference to his concealment of his real character, and a hypocrite with reference to his assumption of a false character. But hypocrite is the stronger word, being commonly used to characterize a person who is habitually insincere and false, especially one who makes professions of goodness when his aims are selfish and his life corrupt.
entry.def: One who dissembles; one who conceals his opinions or dispositions under a false appearance; a hypocrite.
entry.q: It is the weakest sort of politicians that are the greatest dissemblers.
Priests, princes, women, no dissemblers here.

entry.def: That dissembles; hypocritical; false.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Disseminated; p. pr. & vb. n. Disseminating
entry.ety: L. disseminatus, p. p. of disseminare to disseminate; dis- + seminare to sow, semen seed. See Seminary

sn.def: to spread around widely; to sow broadcast or as seed; to scatter for growth and propagation, like seed; to spread abroad; to diffuse; as, principles, ideas, opinions, and errors are disseminated when they are spread abroad for propagation.
To spread or extend by dispersion.
sn.q: A nearly uniform and constant fire or heat disseminated throughout the body of the earth.
sn.syn: To spread; diffuse; propagate; circulate; disperse; scatter.

entry.def: Occurring in small portions scattered through some other substance; scattered widely.
serving to diffuse, disseminate, or disperse.
entry.syn: diffusing(prenominal), diffusive, dispersive, disseminative, scattering, spreading.

entry.ety: L. disseminatio: cf. F. dissémination
entry.def: The act of disseminating, or the state of being disseminated; diffusion for propagation and permanence; a scattering or spreading abroad, as of ideas, beliefs, etc.
entry.q: The universal dissemination of those writings.

entry.def: Tending to disseminate, or to become disseminated.
entry.q: The effect of heresy is, like the plague, infectious and disseminative.

entry.ety: L
entry.def: One who, or that which, disseminates, spreads, or propagates; as, disseminators of disease.

entry.ety: L. dissensio: cf. F. dissension. See Dissent
entry.def: Disagreement in opinion, usually of a violent character, producing warm debates or angry words; contention in words; partisan and contentious divisions; breach of friendship and union; strife; discord; quarrel.
entry.q: Paul and Barnabas had no small dissension and disputation with them.
Debates, dissension, uproars are thy joy.
A seditious person and raiser-up of dissension among the people.

entry.def: Disposed to discord; contentious; dissentious.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Dissented; p. pr. & vb. n. Dissenting
entry.ety: L. dissentire dissentum; dis- + sentire to feel, think. See Sense

sn.def: To differ in opinion; to be of unlike or contrary sentiment; to disagree; -- followed by from.
sn.q: The bill passed . . . without a dissenting voice.
Opinions in which multitudes of men dissent from us.

sn.def: To differ from an established church in regard to doctrines, rites, or government.
To differ; to be of a contrary nature.
The act of dissenting; difference of opinion; refusal to adopt something proposed; nonagreement, nonconcurrence, or disagreement.
sn.q: The dissent of no small number [of peers] is frequently recorded.

sn.def: Separation from an established church, especially that of England; nonconformity.
sn.q: It is the dissidence of dissent and the protestantism of the Protestant religion.

sn.def: Contrariety of nature; diversity in quality.
sn.q: The dissent of the metals.

entry.ety: L. dissentaneus
entry.def: Disagreeing; contrary; differing; -- opposed to consentaneous.
Dissentaneous; inconsistent.
Dissension.

entry.note: ☞ “The word is commonly applied only to Protestants. The Roman Catholics are generally referred to as a distinct class.”

sn.def: One who dissents; one who differs in opinion, or declares his disagreement.
One who separates from the service and worship of an established church; especially, one who disputes the authority or tenets of the Church of England; a nonconformist.
sn.q: Dissenters from the establishment of their several countries.
Robert Brown is said to have the first formal dissenter.

entry.def: The spirit or principles of dissenters.
To throw into a state of dissent.

entry.ety: L. dissentiens, p. pr. of dissentire. See Dissent v. i.
entry.def: Disagreeing; declaring dissent; dissenting.
disagreeing, especially with a majority.
Marked by dissensions; apt to breed discord; quarrelsome; contentious; factious.
Disagreeing; inconsistent.

entry.ety: L. dissaepimentum, fr. dissaepire; dis- + saepire to hedge in, inclose

sn.def: A separating tissue; a partition; a septum.
One of the partitions which divide a compound ovary into cells.
One of the transverse, calcareous partitions between the radiating septa of a coral.

entry.ety: L. dissertus, p. p. of disserere; dis- + serere to join, connect: cf. F. disserter. See Series
entry.def: To discourse or dispute; to discuss.
entry.q: We have disserted upon it a little longer than was necessary.

entry.ety: L. dissertatus, p. p. of dissertare to discuss, intents, fr. disserere. See Dissert
entry.def: To deal in dissertation; to write dissertations; to discourse.

entry.ety: L. dissertatio: cf. F. dissertation
entry.def: A formal or elaborate argumentative discourse, oral or written; a disquisition; an essay; a discussion; as, Dissertations on the Prophecies.
Relating to dissertations; resembling a dissertation.
A writer of dissertations.

entry.ety: L.: cf. F. dissertateur
entry.def: One who writers a dissertation; one who discourses.
See Disertly.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Di�����; p. pr. & vb. n. Disserving
entry.ety: Pref. dis- + serve: cf. F. desservir
entry.def: To fail to serve; to do injury or mischief to; to damage; to hurt; to harm.
entry.q: Have neither served nor disserved the interests of any party.

entry.ety: Pref. dis- + service: cf. F. desservice
entry.def: Injury; mischief.
entry.q: We shall rather perform good offices unto truth than any disservice unto their relators.

entry.def: Calculated to do disservice or harm; not serviceable; injurious; harmful; unserviceable.
To unsettle.
The act of unsettling, or the state of being unsettled.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Dissevered; p. pr. & vb. n. Dissevering
entry.ety: OE. dessevrer; pref. des-L. dis-) + sevrer to sever, F. sevrer to wean, L. separate to separate. In this word the prefix is intensive. See Dis-, and Sever
entry.def: To part in two; to sever thoroughly; to sunder; to disunite; to separate; to disperse.
entry.q: The storm so dissevered the company . . . that most of therm never met again.
States disserved, discordant, belligerent.

entry.def: To part; to separate.

entry.ety: OF. dessevrance
entry.def: The act of disserving; separation.
The act of disserving; disseverance.

entry.ety: Cf. OF. dessevrement
entry.def: Disseverance.
To free from shadow or shade.
To become unsheathed.
To dismiss from service on board ship.
To shiver or break in pieces.

entry.ety: L. dissidentia: cf. F. dissidence. See Dissident a.
entry.def: Disagreement; dissent; separation from the established religion.
entry.q: It is the dissidence of dissent.

entry.ety: L. dissidens -entis, p. pr. of dissidere to sit apart, to disagree; dis- + sedere to sit: cf. F. dissident. See Sit
entry.def: No agreeing; dissenting; discordant; different.
entry.q: Our life and manners be dissident from theirs.

entry.def: One who disagrees or dissents; one who separates from the established religion.
entry.q: The dissident, habituated and taught to think of his dissidenc� as a laudable and necessary opposition to ecclesiastical usurpation.

entry.def: In a dissident manner.
The act of leaping or starting asunder.

entry.ety: L. dissiliens -entis, p. pr. of dissilire to leap asunder: dis- + salire to leap
entry.def: Starting asunder; bursting and opening with an elastic force; dehiscing explosively; as, a dissilient pericarp.
The act of bursting or springing apart.

entry.ety: Pref. dis- + similar: cf. F. dissimilaire
entry.def: Not similar; unlike; heterogeneous; as, the tempers of men are as dissimilar as their features.
entry.q: This part very dissimilar to any other.

entry.def: Want of resemblance; unlikeness; dissimilitude; variety; as, the dissimilarity of human faces and forms.
In a dissimilar manner; in a varied style.
entry.q: With verdant shrubs dissimilarly gay.

entry.def: To render dissimilar.
The act of making dissimilar.

entry.ety: L. dissimile, neut. of dissimilis unlike
entry.def: Comparison or illustration by contraries.

entry.ety: L. dissimilitudo, fr. dissimilis: cf. F. dissimilitude

sn.def: Want of resemblance; unlikeness; dissimilarity.
sn.q: Dissimilitude between the Divinity and images.

sn.def: A comparison by contrast; a dissimile.

entry.ety: L. dissimulatus, p. p. of dissimulare. See Dissemble
entry.def: Feigning; simulating; pretending.
To dissemble; to feign; to pretend.
concealing under a false appearance with the intent to deceive.

entry.ety: L. dissimulatio: cf. F. dissimulation
entry.def: The act of dissembling; a hiding under a false appearance; concealment by feigning; false pretension; hypocrisy.
entry.q: Let love be without dissimulation.
Dissimulation . . . when a man lets fall signs and arguments that he is not that he is.
Simulation is a pretense of what is not, and dissimulation a concealment of what is.

entry.ety: L
entry.def: One who dissimulates; a dissembler.

entry.ety: F. dissimuler. See Dissimulate
entry.def: To dissemble.
A dissembler.

entry.ety: OF. dissimuleur
entry.def: A dissembler.

entry.ety: L. dissipabilis
entry.def: Capable of being scattered or dissipated.
entry.q: The heat of those plants is very dissipable.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Dissipated; p. pr. & vb. n. Dissipating
entry.ety: L. dissipatus, p. p. of dissipare; dis- + an obsolete verb sipare supare. to throw

sn.def: To scatter completely; to disperse and cause to disappear; -- used esp. of the dispersion of things that can never again be collected or restored.
sn.q: Dissipated those foggy mists of error.
I soon dissipated his fears.
The extreme tendency of civilization is to dissipate all intellectual energy.

sn.def: To destroy by wasteful extravagance or lavish use; to squander.
sn.q: The vast wealth . . . was in three years dissipated.
sn.syn: To disperse; scatter; dispel; spend; squander; waste; consume; lavish.

sn.def: To separate into parts and disappear; to waste away; to scatter; to disperse; to vanish; as, a fog or cloud gradually dissipates before the rays or heat of the sun; the heat of a body dissipates.
To be extravagant, wasteful, or dissolute in the pursuit of pleasure; to engage in dissipation.
Squandered; scattered.
sn.q: Dissipatedwealth.

sn.def: Wasteful of health, money, etc., in the pursuit of pleasure; dissolute; intemperate.
sn.q: A life irregular and dissipated.

entry.cs: Dissipation of energy. Same as Degradation of energy, under Degradation.
entry.ety: L. dissipatio: cf. F. dissipation

sn.def: The act of dissipating or dispersing; a state of dispersion or separation; dispersion; waste.
sn.q: Without loss or dissipation of the matter.
The famous dissipation of mankind.

sn.def: A dissolute course of life, in which health, money, etc., are squandered in pursuit of pleasure; profuseness in vicious indulgence, as late hours, riotous living, etc.; dissoluteness.
sn.q: To reclaim the spendthrift from his dissipation and extravagance.

sn.def: A trifle which wastes time or distracts attention.
sn.q: Prevented from finishing them [the letters] a thousand avocations and dissipations.

cs.cd: an assumed system of matter and motions in which forces of friction and resistances of other kinds are introduced without regard to the heat or other molecular actions which they generate; -- opposed to conservative system.

entry.def: Tending to dissipate.
The rate at which palpable energy is dissipated away into other forms of energy.

entry.ety: L. dissitus
entry.def: Lying apart.
entry.q: Lands far dissite and remote asunder.

entry.ety: Pref. dis-intens.) + slander
entry.def: To slander.
Slander.
Slanderous.
Want of sociability; unsociableness.

entry.ety: L. dissociabilis, fr. dissociare: cf. F. dissociable. See Dissociate

sn.def: Not well associated or assorted; incongruous.
sn.q: They came in two and two, though matched in the most dissociable manner.

sn.def: Having a tendency to dissolve social connections; unsuitable to society; unsociable.

entry.ety: Pref. dis- + social: cf. L. dissocialis. See Dissociate v. t.
entry.def: Unfriendly to society; contracted; selfish; as, dissocial feelings.
To render unsocial.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Dissociated; p. pr. & vb. n. Dissociating
entry.ety: L. dissociatus, p. p. of dissociare to dissociate; dis- + sociare to unite, associate, socius companion. See Social
entry.def: To separate from fellowship or union; to disunite; to disjoin; as, to dissociate the particles of a concrete substance.
entry.q: Before Wyclif's death in 1384, John of Gaunt had openly dissociated himself from the reformer.

sn.def: not connected or associated.

diffusing independently in a fluid; -- said of ions or molecules which may form relatively stable associated structures; as, the products become rapidly dissociated from the active site of the enzyme. Opposite of associated.

entry.ety: L. dissociatio: cf. F. dissociation

sn.def: The act of dissociating or disuniting; a state of separation; disunion.
sn.q: It will add infinitely dissociation, distraction, and confusion of these confederate republics.

sn.def: The process by which a compound body breaks up into simpler constituents; -- said particularly of the action of heat on gaseous or volatile substances; as, the dissociation of the sulphur molecules; the dissociation of ammonium chloride into hydrochloric acid and ammonia.

entry.def: Tending or leading to dissociation.
The quality of being dissoluble; capacity of being dissoluble; capacity of being dissolved by heat or moisture, and converted into a fluid.

entry.ety: L. dissolubilis: cf. F. dissoluble. See Dissolve, and cf. Dissolvable

sn.def: Capable of being dissolved; having its parts separable by heat or moisture; convertible into a fluid.
Capable of being disunited.

entry.def: The quality of being dissoluble; dissolubility.

entry.ety: L. dissolutus, p. p. of dissolvere: cf. F. dissolu. See Dissolve

sn.def: With nerves unstrung; weak.
Loosed from restraint; esp., loose in morals and conduct; recklessly abandoned to sensual pleasures; profligate; wanton; lewd; debauched.
sn.q: A wild anddissolutesoldier.
sn.syn: Uncurbed; unbridled; disorderly; unrestrained; reckless; wild; wanton; vicious; lax; licentious; lewd; rakish; debauched; profligate.

entry.def: In a dissolute manner.
State or quality of being dissolute; looseness of morals and manners; addictedness to sinful pleasures; debauchery; dissipation.
entry.q: Chivalry had the vices of dissoluteness.

entry.ety: OE. dissolucioun dissoluteness, F. dissolution, fr. L. dissolutio, fr. dissolvere. See Dissolve

sn.def: The act of dissolving, sundering, or separating into component parts; separation.
sn.q: Dissolutions of ancient amities.

sn.def: Change from a solid to a fluid state; solution by heat or moisture; liquefaction; melting.
Change of form by chemical agency; decomposition; resolution.
sn.q: The dissolution of the compound.

sn.def: The dispersion of an assembly by terminating its sessions; the breaking up of a partnership.
sn.q: Dissolution is the civil death of Parliament.

sn.def: The extinction of life in the human body; separation of the soul from the body; death.
sn.q: We expected Immediate dissolution.

sn.def: The state of being dissolved, or of undergoing liquefaction.
sn.q: A man of continual dissolution and thaw.

sn.def: The new product formed by dissolving a body; a solution.
Destruction of anything by the separation of its parts; ruin.
sn.q: To make a present dissolution of the world.

sn.def: Corruption of morals; dissipation; dissoluteness.

entry.def: Capacity of being dissolved; solubility.

entry.ety: From Dissolve, cf. Dissoluble
entry.def: Capable of being dissolved, or separated into component parts; capable of being liquefied; soluble.
entry.q: Though everything which is compacted be in its own nature dissolvable.
Such things as are not dissolvable by the moisture of the tongue.

entry.def: Having the power to dissolve anything; solvent.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Dissolved; p. pr. & vb. n. Dissolving
entry.ety: L. dissolvere dissolutum; dis- + solvere to loose, free. See Solve, and cf. Dissolute

sn.def: To separate into competent parts; to disorganize; to break up; hence, to bring to an end by separating the parts, sundering a relation, etc.; to terminate; to destroy; to deprive of force; as, to dissolve a partnership; to dissolve Parliament.
sn.q: Lest his ungoverned rage dissolve the life.

sn.def: To break the continuity of; to disconnect; to disunite; to sunder; to loosen; to undo; to separate.
sn.q: Nothing can dissolve us.
Down fell the duke, his joints dissolved asunder.
For one people to dissolve the political bands which have connected them with another.

sn.def: To convert into a liquid by means of heat, moisture, etc.,; to melt; to liquefy; to soften.
sn.q: As if the world were all dissolved to tears.

sn.def: To solve; to clear up; to resolve.
sn.q: Dissolvedthe mystery.
Make interpretations and dissolve doubts.

sn.def: To relax by pleasure; to make powerless.
sn.q: Angels dissolved in hallelujahs lie.

sn.def: To annul; to rescind; to discharge or release; as, to dissolve an injunction.
To waste away; to be dissipated; to be decomposed or broken up.
To become fluid; to be melted; to be liquefied.
sn.q: A figure Trenched in ice, which with an hour's heatDissolves to water, and doth lose his form.

sn.def: To fade away; to fall to nothing; to lose power.
sn.q: The charm dissolves apace.

sn.def: changed from a solid to a liquid state by increase of temperature; melted. Opposite of unmelted.
sundered by divorce, separation, or desertion; -- of social bonds and relations.
diffused into a liquid of differing chemical composition, forming a stable solution; -- said of chemical substances.

entry.ety: L. dissolvens -entis, p. pr. of dissolvere
entry.def: Having power to dissolve power to dissolve a solid body; as, the dissolvent juices of the stomach.

sn.def: That which has the power of dissolving or melting other substances, esp. by mixture with them; a menstruum; a solvent.
sn.q: Melted in the crucible dissolvents.
The secret treaty of December acted as an immediate dissolvent to the truce.

sn.def: A remedy supposed capable of dissolving concretions in the body, such as calculi, tubercles, etc.

entry.def: One who, or that which, has power to dissolve or dissipate.
entry.q: Thou kind dissolver of encroaching care.

cs.cd: a picture which grows dim and is gradually replaced by another on the same field; -- an effect produced by magic lanterns.

entry.def: Melting; breaking up; vanishing.

entry.ety: L. dissonantia: cf. F. dissonance

sn.def: A mingling of discordant sounds; an inharmonious combination of sounds; discord.
sn.q: Filled the air with barbarous dissonance.

sn.def: Want of agreement; incongruity.

entry.def: Discord; dissonance.

entry.ety: L. dissonans -antis, p. pr. of dissonare to disagree in sound, be discordant; dis- + sonare to sound: cf. F. dissonant. See Sonant

sn.def: Sounding harshly; discordant; unharmonious.
sn.q: With clamor of voices dissonant and loud.

sn.def: Disagreeing; incongruous; discrepant, -- with from or to.
sn.q: Anythingdissonantto truth.
What can be dissonant from reason and nature than that a man, naturally inclined to clemency, should show himself unkind and inhuman?

entry.def: See Dispirit.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Dissuaded; p. pr. & vb. n. Dissuading
entry.ety: L. dissuadere dissuasum; dis- + suadere to advise, persuade: cf. F. dissuader. See Suasion

sn.def: To advise or exhort against; to try to persuade (one from a course).
sn.q: Mr. Burchell, on the contrary, dissuaded her with great ardor: and I stood neuter.
War, therefore, open or concealed, alike My voice dissuades.

sn.def: To divert by persuasion; to turn from a purpose by reasons or motives; -- with from; as, I could not dissuade him from his purpose.
sn.q: I have tried what is possible to dissuade him.

entry.def: One who dissuades; a dehorter.

entry.ety: L. dissuasio: cf. F. dissuasion. See Dissuade

sn.def: The act of dissuading; exhortation against a thing; dehortation.
sn.q: In spite of all the dissuasions of his friends.

sn.def: A motive or consideration tending to dissuade; a dissuasive.

entry.def: Tending to dissuade or divert from a measure or purpose; dehortatory; as, dissuasive advice.

def2.def: A dissuasive argument or counsel; dissuasion; dehortation.

entry.def: A dissuasive.
entry.q: This virtuous and reasonable person, however, has ill luck in all his dissuasories.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Dissundered; p. pr. & vb. n. Dissundering
entry.ety: Pref. dis-intens) + sunder
entry.def: To separate; to sunder; to destroy.
To deprive of sweetness.

entry.ety: Cf. F. dissyllabique. See Dissylable
entry.def: Consisting of two syllables only; as, a dissyllabic foot in poetry.
A forming into two syllables.

entry.ety: Dissyllable + -fly
entry.def: To form into two syllables.
To form into two syllables; to dissyllabify.

entry.ety: F. dissyllabe, L. disyllabus, adj., of two syllables, fr. Gr. �; di- = di`s- twice + � syllable. See Syllable
entry.def: A word of two syllables; as, pa-per.
Not having symmetry; asymmetrical; unsymmetrical.

entry.ety: Pref. dis- + symmetry
entry.def: Absence or defect of symmetry; asymmetry.
Lack of sympathy; want of interest; indifference.

entry.ety: Distal + L. ad toward
entry.def: Toward a distal part; on the distal side of; distally.

entries.entry:
Dis"taff ☞ The plural is regular, but Distaves occurs in Beaumont & Fletcher.
Descent by distaff descent on the mother's side.
Distaff DayorDistaff's Day
the morrow of the Epiphany, that is, January 7, because working at the distaff was then resumed, after the Christmas festival; -- called also Rock Day, a distaff being called a rock. Shipley.
n.; pl.Distaffs # rarely Distaves #. OE. distaf dysestafe, AS. distaef; cf. LG. diesse the bunch of flax on a distaff, and E. dizen. See Staff
The staff for holding a bunch of flax, tow, or wool, from which the thread is drawn in spinning by hand. I will the distaff hold; come thou and spin.
Used as a symbol of the holder of a distaff; hence, a woman; women, collectively. His crown usurped, a distaff on the throne. Some say the crozier, some say the distaff was too busy.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Distained; p. pr. & vb. n. Distaining
entry.ety: OE. desteinen, OF. desteindre to take away the color, F. déteindre; pref. des-L. dis-) + F. teindre to tinge, dye, L. tingere. See Tinge, and cf. Stain
entry.def: To tinge with a different color from the natural or proper one; to stain; to discolor; to sully; to tarnish; to defile; -- used chiefly in poetry.
entry.q: Distainedwith dirt and blood.
She] hath . . . distained her honorable blood.
The worthiness of praise distains his worth.

entries.entry:
Dis"tal a. From Distant
Physiol Remote from the point of attachment or origin; as, the distal end of a bone or muscle ; -- opposed to proximal. Pertaining to that which is distal; as, the distal tuberosities of a bone.

entry.def: Toward a distal part.

entry.note: ☞ In trotting matches under the rules of the American Association, the distance varies with the conditions of the race, being 80 yards in races of mile heats, best two in three, and 150 yards in races of two-mile heats. At that distance from the winning post is placed the distance post. If any horse has not reached this distance post before the first horse in that heat has reached the winning post, such horse is distanced, and disqualified for running again during that race.

☞ In a picture, the Middle distance is the central portion between the foreground and the distance or the extreme distance. In a perspective drawing, the Point of distance is the point where the visual rays meet.
entry.cs: Angular distance the distance made at the eye by lines drawn from the eye to two objects. Lunar distance. See under Lunar. North polar distance Astron the distance on the heavens of a heavenly body from the north pole. It is the complement of the declination. Zenith distance Astron the arc on the heavens from a heavenly body to the zenith of the observer. It is the complement of the altitude. To keep one's distance to stand aloof; to refrain from familiarity.
entry.ety: F. distance, L. distantia

sn.def: The space between two objects; the length of a line, especially the shortest line joining two points or things that are separate; measure of separation in place.
sn.q: Every particle attracts every other with a force . . . inversely proportioned to the square of the distance.

sn.def: Remoteness of place; a remote place.
sn.q: Easily managed from a distance.
'T is distance lends enchantment to the view.
He] waits at distance till he hears from Cato.

sn.def: A space marked out in the last part of a race course.
sn.q: The horse that ran the whole field out of distance.

sn.def: Relative space, between troops in ranks, measured from front to rear; -- contrasted with interval, which is measured from right to left.
sn.q: Distancebetween companies in close column is twelve yards.

sn.def: Space between two antagonists in fencing.
The part of a picture which contains the representation of those objects which are the farthest away, esp. in a landscape.
Ideal disjunction; discrepancy; contrariety.
Length or interval of time; period, past or future, between two eras or events.
sn.q: Ten years' distance between one and the other.
The writings of Euclid at the distance of two thousand years.

sn.def: The remoteness or reserve which respect requires; hence, respect; ceremoniousness.
sn.q: I hope your modesty Will know what distance to the crown is due.
'T is by respect and distance that authority is upheld.

sn.def: A withholding of intimacy; alienation; coldness; disagreement; variance; restraint; reserve.
sn.q: Setting them [factions] at distance, or at least distrust amongst themselves.
On the part of Heaven, Now alienated, distance and distaste.

sn.def: Remoteness in succession or relation; as, the distance between a descendant and his ancestor.
The interval between two notes; as, the distance of a fourth or seventh.
sn.q: If a man makes me keep my distance, the comfort is he keeps his at the same time.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Distanced; p. pr. & vb. n. Distancing

sn.def: To place at a distance or remotely.
sn.q: I heard nothing thereof at Oxford, being then miles distanced thence.

sn.def: To cause to appear as if at a distance; to make seem remote.
sn.q: His peculiar art of distancing an object to aggrandize his space.

sn.def: To outstrip by as much as a distance (see Distance n., 3); to leave far behind; to surpass greatly.
sn.q: He distanced the most skillful of his contemporaries.

entry.def: Distance.

entry.ety: F., fr. L. distans -antis, p. pr. of distare to stand apart, be separate or distant; dis- + stare to stand. See Stand

sn.def: Separated; having an intervening space; at a distance; away.
sn.q: One board had two tenons, equally distant.
Diana's temple is not distant far.

sn.def: Far separated; far off; not near; remote; -- in place, time, consanguinity, or connection; as, distant times; distant relatives.
sn.q: The success of these distant enterprises.

sn.def: Reserved or repelling in manners; cold; not cordial; somewhat haughty; as, a distant manner.
sn.q: He passed me with a distant bow.

sn.def: Indistinct; faint; obscure, as from distance.
sn.q: Some distant knowledge.
A distant glimpse.

sn.def: Not conformable; discrepant; repugnant; as, a practice so widely distant from Christianity.
sn.syn: Separate; far; remote; aloof; apart; asunder; slight; faint; indirect; indistinct.

entry.def: Distant.
entry.q: More distantial from the eye.

entry.def: At a distance; remotely; with reserve.

sn.def: Aversion of the taste; dislike, as of food or drink; disrelish.
Discomfort; uneasiness.
sn.q: Prosperity is not without many fears and distastes, and adversity is not without comforts and hopes.

sn.def: Alienation of affection; displeasure; anger.
sn.q: On the part of Heaven, Now alienated, distance and distaste.
sn.syn: Disrelish; disinclination; dislike; aversion; displeasure; dissatisfaction; disgust.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Distasted; p. pr. & vb. n. Distasting

sn.def: Not to have relish or taste for; to disrelish; to loathe; to dislike.
sn.q: Although my will distaste what it elected.

sn.def: To offend; to disgust; to displease.
sn.q: He thought in no policy to distaste the English or Irish by a course of reformation, but sought to please them.

sn.def: To deprive of taste or relish; to make unsavory or distasteful.

entry.def: To be distasteful; to taste ill or disagreeable.
entry.q: Dangerous conceits are, in their natures, poisons, Which at the are scarce found to distaste.

sn.def: Unpleasant or disgusting to the taste; nauseous; loathsome.
Offensive; displeasing to the feelings; disagreeable; as, a distasteful truth.
sn.q: Distasteful answer, and sometimes unfriendly actions.

sn.def: Manifesting distaste or dislike; repulsive.
sn.q: Distastefullooks.
sn.syn: Nauseous; unsavory; unpalatable; offensive; displeasing; dissatisfactory; disgusting.

entry.def: Tending to excite distaste.

def2.def: That which excites distaste or aversion.

entry.def: Something which excites distaste or disgust.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Distempered; p. pr. & vb. n. Distempering
entry.ety: OF. destemprer destremper, to distemper, F. détremper to soak, soften, slake (lime); pref. des-L. dis-) + OF. temprer tremper, F. tremper, L. temperare to mingle in due proportion. See Temper, and cf. Destemprer

sn.def: To temper or mix unduly; to make disproportionate; to change the due proportions of.
sn.q: When . . . the humors in his body ben distempered.

sn.def: To derange the functions of, whether bodily, mental, or spiritual; to disorder; to disease.
sn.q: The imagination, when completely distempered, is the most incurable of all disordered faculties.

sn.def: To deprive of temper or moderation; to disturb; to ruffle; to make disaffected, ill-humored, or malignant.
sn.q: Distemperedspirits.

sn.def: To intoxicate.
sn.q: The courtiers reeling, And the duke himself, I dare not say distempered, But kind, and in his tottering chair carousing.

sn.def: To mix (colors) in the way of distemper; as, to distemper colors with size.

entry.note: ☞ This meaning and most of the following are to be referred to the Galenical doctrine of the four “humors” in man. See Humor. According to the old physicians, these humors, when unduly tempered, produce a disordered state of body and mind.
entry.ety: See Distemper v. t., and cf. Destemprer

sn.def: An undue or unnatural temper, or disproportionate mixture of parts.
Severity of climate; extreme weather, whether hot or cold.
sn.q: Those countries . . . under the tropic, were of a distemper uninhabitable.

sn.def: A morbid state of the animal system; indisposition; malady; disorder; -- at present chiefly applied to diseases of brutes; as, a distemper in dogs; the horse distemper; the horn distemper in cattle.
sn.q: They heighten distempers to diseases.

sn.def: Morbid temper of the mind; undue predominance of a passion or appetite; mental derangement; bad temper; ill humor.
sn.q: Little faults proceeding on distemper.
Some frenzy distemper had got into his head.

sn.def: Political disorder; tumult.

sd.def: A preparation of opaque or body colors, in which the pigments are tempered or diluted with weak glue or size (cf. Tempera) instead of oil, usually for scene painting, or for walls and ceilings of rooms.
A painting done with this preparation.
sd.syn: Disease; disorder; sickness; illness; malady; indisposition; ailment. See Disease.

entry.def: Distemperature.

entry.ety: LL. distemperatus, p. p

sn.def: Immoderate.
Diseased; disordered.

entry.def: Unduly.

sn.def: Bad temperature; intemperateness; excess of heat or cold, or of other qualities; as, the distemperature of the air.
Disorder; confusion.
Disorder of body; slight illness; distemper.
sn.q: A huge infectious troop Of pale distemperatures and foes to life.

sn.def: Perturbation of mind; mental uneasiness.
sn.q: Sprinkled a little patience on the heat of his distemperature.

entry.def: Distempered state; distemperature.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Distended; p. pr. & vb. n. Distending
entry.ety: L. distendere distentum distensum; dis- + tendere to stretch, stretch out: cf. F. distendre to distend, détendre to unbend. See Tend, and cf. Detent

sn.def: To extend in some one direction; to lengthen out; to stretch.
sn.q: But say, what mean those colored streaks in heavenDistended as the brow of God appeased?

sn.def: To stretch out or extend in all directions; to dilate; to enlarge, as by elasticity of parts; to inflate so as to produce tension; to cause to swell; as, to distend a bladder, the stomach, etc.
sn.q: The warmth distends the chinks.
sn.syn: To dilate; expand; enlarge; swell; inflate.

entry.def: To become expanded or inflated; to swell.
entry.q: His heartdistendswith pride.

entry.def: The quality or capacity of being distensible.
Capable of being distended or dilated.
Same as Distention.
Distending, or capable of being distended.

entry.ety: L. distentus, p. p. See Distend
entry.def: Distended.
Breadth.

entry.ety: L. distentio: cf. F. distension

sn.def: The act of distending; the act of stretching in breadth or in all directions; the state of being Distended; as, the distention of the lungs.
Breadth; extent or space occupied by the thing distended.

entry.ety: L. dis- + terra earth, country; cf. Sp. & Pg. desterrar
entry.def: To banish or drive from a country.

entry.ety: L. disterminatus, p. p. of disterminare to limit. See Terminate
entry.def: Separated by bounds.

entry.ety: L. disterminatio
entry.def: Separation by bounds.

entry.ety: Gr. di- = di`s- twice + � force: cf. F. disthène
entry.def: Cyanite or kyanite; -- so called in allusion to its unequal hardness in two different directions. See Cyanite.

entry.ety: Pref. dis- + throne: cf. OF. desthroner, F. détroner
entry.def: To dethrone.
To dethrone.

entry.ety: L. distichon, Gr. �, neut. of � with two rows, of two verses; di- = di`s- twice + � row, verse, fr. � to ascend; akin to AS. stīgan to ascend: cf. F. distique. See Stirrup
entry.def: A couple of verses or poetic lines making complete sense; an epigram of two verses.

entry.ety: Gr. �. See Distich n.
entry.def: Disposed in two vertical rows; two-ranked.
In a distichous manner.
See Distill.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Distilled; p. pr. & vb. n. Distilling
entry.ety: F. distiller, from L. destillare destillatum; de + stillare to drop, stilla a drop, prob. fr. stiria frozen drop, icicle; prob. akin to stare, E. stand. Cf. Still n. & v. Instill

sn.def: To drop; to fall in drops; to trickle.
sn.q: Soft showers distilled, and suns grew warm in vain.

sn.def: To flow gently, or in a small stream.
sn.q: The Euphrates distilleth out of the mountains of Armenia.

sn.def: To practice the art of distillation.
To let fall or send down in drops.
sn.q: Or o'er the glebe distill the kindly rain.
The dew which on the tender grass The evening had distilled.

sn.def: To obtain by distillation; to subject to a process of evaporation and subsequent condensation; to extract by distillation, as spirits, essential oil, etc.; to rectify; as, to distill brandy from wine; to distill alcoholic spirits from grain; to distill essential oils from flowers, etc.; to distill fresh water from sea water.
sn.q: Distillingodors on me.

sn.def: To subject to distillation; as, to distill molasses in making rum; to distill barley, rye, corn, etc.
To dissolve or melt.
sn.q: Swords by the lightning's subtle force distilled.

sn.def: to extract out and present the essence of; to shorten and refine; to present the essential elements of; -- of ideas or texts.

entry.def: Capable of being distilled; especially, capable of being distilled without chemical change or decomposition; as, alcohol is distillable; olive oil is not distillable.
The product of distillation; as, the distillate from molasses.

entry.note: ☞ The evaporation of water, its condensation into clouds, and its precipitation as rain, dew, frost, snow, or hail, is an illustration of natural distillation.
entry.cs: Destructive distillation Chem the distillation, especially of complex solid substances, so that the ultimate constituents are separated or evolved in new compounds, -- usually requiring a high degree of heat; as, the destructive distillation of soft coal or of wood. Dry distillation the distillation of substances by themselves, or without the addition of water or of other volatile solvent; as, the dry distillation of citric acid. Fractional distillation. Chem See under Fractional.
entry.ety: F. distillation, L. destillatio

sn.def: The act of falling in drops, or the act of pouring out in drops.
That which falls in drops.

The separation of the volatile parts of a substance from the more fixed; specifically, the operation of driving off gas or vapor from volatile liquids or solids, by heat in a retort or still, and the condensation of the products as far as possible by a cool receiver, alembic, or condenser; rectification; vaporization; condensation; as, the distillation of illuminating gas and coal, of alcohol from sour mash, or of boric acid in steam.
The substance extracted by distilling.

entry.ety: Cf. F. distillatoire
entry.def: Belonging to, or used in, distilling; as, distillatory vessels.

sn.def: One who distills; esp., one who extracts alcoholic liquors by distillation.
The condenser of a distilling apparatus.

entries.entry:
Dis*till"er*y n.; pl.Distilleries #. F. distillerie
The building and works where distilling, esp. of alcoholic liquors, is carried on.
The act of distilling spirits. R

entry.def: Distillation; the substance obtained by distillation.

entry.ety: L. distinctus, p. p. of distinguere: cf. F. distinct. See Distinguish

sn.def: Distinguished; having the difference marked; separated by a visible sign; marked out; specified.
sn.q: Wherever thus created -- for no place Is yet distinct by name.

sn.def: Marked; variegated.
sn.q: The which [place] was dight With divers flowers distinct with rare delight.

sn.def: Separate in place; not conjunct; not united by growth or otherwise; -- with from.
sn.q: The intention was that the two armies which marched out together should afterward be distinct.

sn.def: Not identical; different; individual.
sn.q: To offend, and judge, are distinct offices.

sn.def: So separated as not to be confounded with any other thing; not liable to be misunderstood; not confused; well-defined; clear; as, we have a distinct or indistinct view of a prospect.
sn.q: Relation more particular and distinct.
sn.syn: Separate; unconnected; disjoined; different; clear; plain; conspicuous; obvious.

entry.def: To distinguish.

entry.ety: L. distinctio: cf. F. distinction

sn.def: A marking off by visible signs; separation into parts; division.
sn.q: The distinction of tragedy into acts was not known.

sn.def: The act of distinguishing or denoting the differences between objects, or the qualities by which one is known from others; exercise of discernment; discrimination.
sn.q: To take away therefore that error, which confusion breedeth, distinction is requisite.

sn.def: That which distinguishes one thing from another; distinguishing quality; sharply defined difference; as, the distinction between real and apparent good.
sn.q: The distinction betwixt the animal kingdom and the inferior parts of matter.

sn.def: Estimation of difference; regard to differences or distinguishing circumstance.
sn.q: Maids, women, wives, without distinction, fall.

sn.def: Conspicuous station; eminence; superiority; honorable estimation; as, a man of distinction .
sn.q: Your country's own means of distinction and defense.
sn.syn: Difference; variation, variety; contrast; diversity; contrariety; disagreement; discrimination; preference; superiority; rank; note; eminence.

entry.ety: Cf. F. distinctif

sn.def: Marking or expressing distinction or difference; distinguishing; characteristic; peculiar.
sn.q: The distinctive character and institutions of New England.

sn.def: Having the power to distinguish and discern; discriminating.

entry.def: With distinction; plainly.
State of being distinctive.

sn.def: With distinctness; not confusedly; without the blending of one part or thing another; clearly; plainly; as, to see distinctly .
With meaning; significantly.
sn.q: Thou dost snore distinctly; There's meaning in thy snores.

sn.def: The quality or state of being distinct; a separation or difference that prevents confusion of parts or things.
sn.q: The soul's . . . distinctness from the body.

sn.def: Nice discrimination; hence, clearness; precision; as, he stated his arguments with great distinctness .

entry.def: Distinctness.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Distinguished; p. pr. & vb. n. Distinguishing
entry.ety: F. distinguer, L. distinguere distinctum; di- = dis- + stinguere to quench, extinguish; prob. orig., to prick, and so akin to G. stechen, E. stick, and perh. sting. Cf. Extinguish

sn.def: Not set apart from others by visible marks; to make distinctive or discernible by exhibiting differences; to mark off by some characteristic.
sn.q: Not more distinguished by her purple vest, Than by the charming features of her face.
Milton has distinguished the sweetbrier and the eglantine.

sn.def: To separate by definition of terms or logical division of a subject with regard to difference; as, to distinguish sounds into high and low.
sn.q: Moses distinguished the causes of the flood into those that belong to the heavens, and those that belong to the earth.

sn.def: To recognize or discern by marks, signs, or characteristic quality or qualities; to know and discriminate (anything) from other things with which it might be confounded; as, to distinguish the sound of a drum.
sn.q: We are enabled to distinguish good from evil, as well as truth from falsehood.
Nor more can you distinguish of a man, Than of his outward show.

sn.def: To constitute a difference; to make to differ.
sn.q: Who distinguisheth thee?

sn.def: To separate from others by a mark of honor; to make eminent or known; to confer distinction upon; -- with by or for.
sn.q: Todistinguishthemselves by means never tried before.
sn.syn: To mark; discriminate; differentiate; characterize; discern; perceive; signalize; honor; glorify.

sn.def: To make distinctions; to perceive the difference; to exercise discrimination; -- with between; as, a judge distinguishes between cases apparently similar, but differing in principle.
To become distinguished or distinctive; to make one's self or itself discernible.
sn.q: The little embryo . . . first distinguishes into a little knot.

sn.def: Capable of being distinguished; separable; divisible; discernible; capable of recognition; as, a tree at a distance is distinguishable from a shrub.
sn.q: A simple idea being in itself uncompounded . . . is not distinguishable into different ideas.

sn.def: Worthy of note or special regard.

entry.def: The quality of being distinguishable.
So as to be distinguished.

sn.def: Marked; special.
sn.q: The most distinguished politeness.

sn.def: Separated from others by distinct difference; having, or indicating, superiority; eminent or known; illustrious; -- applied to persons and deeds.
sn.syn: Marked; noted; famous; conspicuous; celebrated; transcendent; eminent; illustrious; extraordinary; prominent.Distinguished Eminent Conspicuous Celebrated Illustrious. A man is eminent, when he stands high as compared with those around him; conspicuous, when he is so elevated as to be seen and observed; distinguished, when he has something which makes him stand apart from others in the public view; celebrated, when he is widely spoken of with honor and respect; illustrious, when a splendor is thrown around him which confers the highest dignity.

entry.def: In a distinguished manner.

sn.def: One who, or that which, distinguishes or separates one thing from another by marks of diversity.
One who discerns accurately the difference of things; a nice or judicious observer.

cs.cd: a special pennant by which any particular vessel in a fleet is recognized and signaled.

entry.def: Constituting difference, or distinction from everything else; distinctive; peculiar; characteristic.
entry.q: The distinguishing doctrines of our holy religion.

entry.def: With distinction; with some mark of preference.
Observation of difference; distinction.
To deprive of title or right.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. di- = di`s- twice + sto`ma mouth
entry.def: A genus of parasitic, trematode worms, having two suckers for attaching themselves to the part they infest. See 1st Fluke, 2.

entry.ety: L. distortus, p. p. of distorquere to twist, distort; dis- + torquere to twist. See Torsion
entry.def: Distorted; misshapen.
entry.q: Her face was ugly and her mouth distort.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Distorted; p. pr. & vb. n. Distorting

sn.def: To twist of natural or regular shape; to twist aside physically; as, to distort the limbs, or the body.
sn.q: Whose face was distorted with pain.

sn.def: To force or put out of the true posture or direction; to twist aside mentally or morally.
sn.q: Wrath and malice, envy and revenge, do darken and distort the understandings of men.

sn.def: To wrest from the true meaning; to pervert; as, to distort passages of Scripture, or their meaning.

entry.def: One who, or that which, distorts.

entry.ety: L. distortio: cf. F. distortion

sn.def: The act of distorting, or twisting out of natural or regular shape; a twisting or writhing motion; as, the distortions of the face or body.
A wresting from the true meaning.
The state of being distorted, or twisted out of shape or out of true position; crookedness; perversion.
An unnatural deviation of shape or position of any part of the body producing visible deformity.

entry.def: Causing distortion.

entry.ety: L. distractus, p. p. of distrahere to draw asunder; dis- + trahere to draw. See Trace, and cf. Distraught

sn.def: Separated; drawn asunder.
Insane; mad.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Distracted, old p. p. Distraught; p. pr. & vb. n. Distracting

sn.def: To draw apart or away; to divide; to disjoin.
sn.q: A city . . . distracted from itself.

sn.def: To draw (the sight, mind, or attention) in different directions; to perplex; to confuse; as, to distract the eye; to distract the attention.
sn.q: Mixed metaphors . . . distract the imagination.

sn.def: To agitate by conflicting passions, or by a variety of motives or of cares; to confound; to harass.
sn.q: Horror and doubt distract His troubled thoughts.

sn.def: To unsettle the reason of; to render insane; to craze; to madden; -- most frequently used in the participle, distracted.
sn.q: A poor mad soul; . . . poverty hath distracted her.

entry.def: Mentally disordered; unsettled; mad.
entry.q: My distracted mind.

entry.def: Disjointedly; madly.
A state of being distracted; distraction.
One who, or that which, distracts away.
Distracting.
Capable of being drawn aside or distracted.
Tending or serving to draw apart.
Tending or serving to distract.

entry.ety: L. distractio: cf. F. distraction

sn.def: The act of distracting; a drawing apart; separation.
sn.q: To create distractions among us.

sn.def: That which diverts attention; a diversion.
sn.q: Domesticdistractions.

sn.def: A diversity of direction; detachment.
sn.q: His power went out in such distractions as Beguiled all species.

sn.def: State in which the attention is called in different ways; confusion; perplexity.
sn.q: That ye may attend upon the Lord without distraction.

sn.def: Confusion of affairs; tumult; disorder; as, political distractions .
sn.q: Never was known a night of such distraction.

sn.def: Agitation from violent emotions; perturbation of mind; despair.
sn.q: The distraction of the children, who saw both their parents together, would have melted the hardest heart.

sn.def: Derangement of the mind; madness.
sn.syn: Perplexity; confusion; disturbance; disorder; dissension; tumult; derangement; madness; raving; franticness; furiousness.

entry.def: Distractive.
Causing perplexity; distracting.
entry.q: Distractivethoughts.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Distrained; p. pr. & vb. n. Distraining
entry.ety: OE. destreinen to force, OF. destreindre to press, oppress, force, fr. L. distringere districtum, to draw asunder, hinder, molest, LL., to punish severely; di- = stringere to draw tight, press together. See Strain, and cf. Distress District Distraint

sn.def: To press heavily upon; to bear down upon with violence; hence, to constrain or compel; to bind; to distress, torment, or afflict.
sn.q: Distrainedwith chains.

sn.def: To rend; to tear.
sn.q: Neither guile nor force might it [a netdistrain.

sd.def: To seize, as a pledge or indemnification; to take possession of as security for nonpayment of rent, the reparation of an injury done, etc.; to take by distress; as, to distrain goods for rent, or of an amercement.
To subject to distress; to coerce; as, to distrain a person by his goods and chattels.

entry.def: To levy a distress.
entry.q: Upon whom I can distrain for debt.

entry.def: Capable of being, or liable to be, distrained.
Same as Distrainor.
One who distrains; the party distraining goods or chattels.

entry.ety: OF. destrainte distress, force
entry.def: The act or proceeding of seizing personal property by distress.

entry.ety: F. See Distract
entry.def: Absent-minded; lost in thought; abstracted.

entry.ety: OE. distract distrauht. See Distract a.

sn.def: Torn asunder; separated.
sn.q: His greedy throat . . .distraught.

sn.def: Distracted; perplexed.
sn.q: Distraughttwixt fear and pity.
As if thou wert distraught and mad with terror.
To doubt betwixt our senses and our souls Which are the most distraught and full of pain.

entry.def: Distracted.

entry.ety: Pref. dis-intens.) + stream
entry.def: To flow.
entry.q: Yet o'er that virtuous blush distreams a tear.

entry.cs: Abuse of distress. Law See under Abuse.
entry.ety: OE. destresse distresse, OF. destresse destrece, F. détresse, OF. destrecier to distress, (assumed) LL. districtiare, fr. L. districtus, p. p. of distringere. See Distrain, and cf. Stress

sn.def: Extreme pain or suffering; anguish of body or mind; as, to suffer distress from the gout, or from the loss of friends.
sn.q: Not fearing death nor shrinking for distress.

sn.def: That which occasions suffering; painful situation; misfortune; affliction; misery.
sn.q: Affliction's sons are brothers in distress.

sn.def: A state of danger or necessity; as, a ship in distress, from leaking, loss of spars, want of provisions or water, etc.

sd.def: The act of distraining; the taking of a personal chattel out of the possession of a wrongdoer, by way of pledge for redress of an injury, or for the performance of a duty, as for nonpayment of rent or taxes, or for injury done by cattle, etc.
The thing taken by distraining; that which is seized to procure satisfaction.
sd.q: If he were not paid, he would straight go and take a distress of goods and cattle.
The distress thus taken must be proportioned to the thing distrained for.
sd.syn: Affliction; suffering; pain; agony; misery; torment; anguish; grief; sorrow; calamity; misfortune; trouble; adversity. See Affliction.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Distressed; p. pr. & vb. n. Distressing
entry.ety: Cf. OF. destrecier. See Distress n.

sn.def: To cause pain or anguish to; to pain; to oppress with calamity; to afflict; to harass; to make miserable.
sn.q: We are troubled on every side, yet not distressed.

sn.def: To compel by pain or suffering.
sn.q: Men who can neither be distressed nor won into a sacrifice of duty.

sn.def: To seize for debt; to distrain.
sn.syn: To pain; grieve; harass; trouble; perplex; afflict; worry; annoy.

sn.def: facing or experiencing financial trouble or difficulty; as, distressed companies need loans and technical advice.
sn.syn: hard-pressed, hard put, in a bad way(predicate), in trouble(predicate).

entry.sn: experienceing a generalized feeling of distress. Also See: dejected unhappy sad. Antonym: euphoric. dysphoric, unhappy.

sn.def: suffering severe physical strain or discomfort; as, he dropped out of the race, clearly distressed and having difficulty breathing.
emotionally upset.

entry.def: A state of being distressed or greatly pained.
Full of distress; causing, indicating, or attended with, distress; as, a distressful situation.
entry.q: Somedistressfulstroke.
Distressfulcries.

entry.def: the quality of causing mental anguish.
Causing distress; painful; unpleasant.
In a distressing manner.
Capable of being distributed.
Tending to distribute or be distributed; that distributes; distributive.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Distributed; p. pr. & vb. n. Distributing
entry.ety: L. distributus, p. p. of distribuere to divide, distribute; dis- + tribuere to assign, give, allot. See Tribute

sn.def: To divide among several or many; to deal out; to apportion; to allot.
sn.q: She did distribute her goods to all them that were nearest of kindred.

sn.def: To dispense; to administer; as, to distribute justice.
To divide or separate, as into classes, orders, kinds, or species; to classify; to assort, as specimens, letters, etc.

sd.def: To separate (type which has been used) and return it to the proper boxes in the cases.
To spread (ink) evenly, as upon a roller or a table.

sn.def: To employ (a term) in its whole extent; to take as universal in one premise.
sn.q: A term is said to be distributed when it is taken universal, so as to stand for everything it is capable of being applied to.
sn.syn: To dispense; deal out; apportion; allot; share; assign; divide.

entry.def: To make distribution.

entry.sn: spread from a central location to multiple points or recipients. Opposite of concentrated.Narrower terms: apportioned, dealt out, doled out, meted out, parceled out; diffuse, diffused; dispensed; dispersed, spread; divided, divided up, shared, shared out on the basis of a plan or purpose; encyclical; rationed; scattered, widespread; sparse, thin; unfocused, unfocussed Also See: distributive.

sn.def: spread among a variety of securities; -- of investments.
sn.q: Distributing to the necessity of saints.

entry.def: One who, or that which, distributes or deals out anything; a dispenser.

cs.cd: an office where the mails for a large district are collected to be assorted according to their destination and forwarded.

entry.def: That distributes; dealing out.

cs.cd: the natural arrangements of animals and plants in particular regions or districts.

entry.ety: L. distributio: cf. F. distribution

sn.def: The act of distributing or dispensing; the act of dividing or apportioning among several or many; apportionment; as, the distribution of an estate among heirs or children.
sn.q: The phenomena of geological distribution are exactly analogous to those of geography.

sn.def: Separation into parts or classes; arrangement of anything into parts; disposition; classification.
That which is distributed.
sn.q: Our charitabledistributions.

sn.def: A resolving a whole into its parts.
The sorting of types and placing them in their proper boxes in the cases.

The steps or operations by which steam is supplied to and withdrawn from the cylinder at each stroke of the piston; viz., admission, suppression or cutting off, release or exhaust, and compression of exhaust steam prior to the next admission.
sn.syn: Apportionments; allotment; dispensation; disposal; dispersion; classification; arrangement.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to distribution.
A distributer.

entry.cs: Distributive operation Math any operation which either consists of two or more parts, or works upon two or more things, and which is such that the result of the total operation is the same as the aggregated result of the two or more partial operations.
