entry.ety: L. large jar
entry.def: A genus of large univalve mollusks, including the partridge shell and tun shells.

entry.ety: A contraction of Dorothy; or less prob. an abbreviation of idol; or cf. OD. dol a whipping top, D. dollen to rave, and E. dull

sn.def: a small, usually flexible figure representing a human being, especially a toy baby for a little girl; a child's puppet.
an attractive woman or girl.
sn.q: Come along and be my party doll.

entry.note: ☞ Previous to 1837 the silver dollar had a larger amount of alloy, but only the same amount of silver as now, the total weight being 416 grains. The gold dollar as a distinct coin was first made in 1849. The eagles, half eagles, and quarter eagles coined before 1834 contained 24.75 grains of gold and 2.25 grains of alloy for each dollar.
entry.cs: Chop dollar. See under 9th Chop. Dollar fish Zoöl a fish of the United States coast (Stromateus triacanthus), having a flat, roundish form and a bright silvery luster; -- called also butterfish, and Lafayette. See Butterfish. Trade dollar a silver coin formerly made at the United States mint, intended for export, and not legal tender at home. It contained 378 grains of silver and 42 grains of alloy.
entry.ety: D. daalder, LG. dahler, G. thaler, an abbreviation of Joachimsthaler, i. e., a piece of money first coined, about the year 1518, in the valley (G. thal) of St. Joachim, in Bohemia. See Dale

sd.def: A silver coin of the United States containing 371.25 grains of silver and 41.25 grains of alloy, that is, having a total weight of 412.5 grains.
A gold coin of the United States containing 23.22 grains of gold and 2.58 grains of alloy, that is, having a total weight of 25.8 grains, nine-tenths fine. It is no longer coined.

sn.def: A coin of the same general weight and value as the United States silver dollar, though differing slightly in different countries, formerly current in Mexico, Canada, parts of South America, also in Spain, and several other European countries.

The value of a dollar; the unit of currency, differing in value in different countries, commonly employed in the United States and a number of other countries, including Australia, Canada, Hong Kong, parts of the Carribbean, Liberia, and several others.

entry.def: A paper note printed by the Treasury, or by one of the Federal Reserve Banks under authority of the treasury, having the value of one dollar. Also five dollar bill, ten dollar bill, etc.: notes with the value of five, ten, etc. dollars. Prior to 1964 such notes could be redeemed for the equivalent dollar value in silver coins, but in that year the backing of the currency with silver was discontinued. Such notes not convertible into precious metals at a fixed rate are called "fiat money", receiving their value solely from the good faith of the issuing government and the confidence of those using the currency.
A species of sunfish (Lepomis pallidus), common in the United States; -- called also blue sunfish, and copper-nosed bream.

sn.def: small food fish (Poronotus triacanthus) of the Atlantic coast.
any of several silvery marine fishes with very flat bodies.
sn.syn: moonfish, Atlantic moonfish, horsefish, horsehead, Selene setapinnis.

sn.def: a house so small that it is likened to a child's dollhouse. Sometimes used in reference to a small house with especially elaborate exterior decoration.
a small model of a house used as a toy by children, usually including miniature furniture and other objects that can be arranged inside it as the would be in a real house.

entry.def: See Dolman.

entries.entry:
Dol"ly n.; pl.Dollies.
Mining A contrivance, turning on a vertical axis by a handle or winch, and giving a circular motion to the ore to be washed; a stirrer.
Mach A tool with an indented head for shaping the head of a rivet.
In pile driving, a block interposed between the head of the pile and the ram of the driver.
A small truck with a single wide roller used for moving heavy beams, columns, etc., in bridge building.
A compact, narrow-gauge locomotive used for moving construction trains, switching, etc.

cs.cd: a shop where rags, old junk, etc., are bought and sold; usually, in fact, an unlicensed pawnbroker's shop, formerly distinguished by the sign of a black doll.

entry.def: A child's mane for a doll.

entries.entry:
Dol"ly Var"den
Dolly Varden trout Zoöl a trout of northwest America; -- called also bull trout malma, and red-spotted trout. See Malma. . A character in Dickens's novel “Barnaby Rudge,” a beautiful, lively, and coquettish girl who wore a cherry-colored mantle and cherry-colored ribbons.
A style of light, bright-figured dress goods for women; also, a style of dress.

dolma n.; pl.dolmasordolmades. Cookery a dish composed of well-seasoned rice (with nuts or currants of minced lamb) simmered or braised in stock, stuffed into tomatoes or green peppers, or wrapped in grape leaves; -- popular in the near east. stuffed grape leaves.

Dol"man dŏl"m�n n.; pl.Dolmans. Turk. dōlāmān: cf. F. doliman
A long robe or outer garment, with long sleeves, worn by the Turks.
doliman
A woman's cloak with capelike pieces instead of sleeves.
The uniform jacket of many European hussar regiments, worn like a cloak, fastened with a cord or chain, and with sleeves hanging loose.

entry.def: plural of dolma; -- sometimes used as a singular form.

entry.ety: Armor. taol tol, table + mean maen men, stone: cf. F. dolmen
entry.def: A cromlech. See Cromlech.

entry.ety: After the French geologist Dolomieu
entry.def: A mineral consisting of the carbonate of lime and magnesia in varying proportions. It occurs in distinct crystals, and in extensive beds as a compact limestone, often crystalline granular, either white or clouded. It includes much of the common white marble. Also called bitter spar.
Pertaining to dolomite.
To convert into dolomite.

entry.ety: OE. dolor dolur dolour, F. douleur, L. dolor, fr. dolere. See 1st Dole
entry.def: Pain; grief; distress; anguish.
entry.q: Of death and dolor telling sad tidings.

entry.ety: L. dolor pain + -ferous
entry.def: Producing pain.

entry.ety: LL. dolorificus; L. dolor pain + facere to make
entry.def: Causing pain or grief.

entry.ety: It
entry.def: Plaintive; pathetic; -- used adverbially as a musical direction.

entry.ety: L. dolorosus, from dolor: cf. F. douloureux. See Dolor

sn.def: Full of grief; sad; sorrowful; doleful; dismal; as, a dolorous object; dolorous discourses.
sn.q: You take me in too dolorous a sense; I spake to you for your comfort.

sn.def: Occasioning pain or grief; painful.
sn.q: Their dispatch is quick, and less dolorous than the paw of the bear or teeth of the lion.

sn.def: same as dolorous.

entry.def: a stone or rock entirely composed of the mineral dolomite.

entry.note: ☞ The dolphin of the ancients (Delphinus delphis) is common in the Mediterranean and Atlantic, and attains a length of from six to eight feet.

cs.cd: the black, bean, or collier, Aphis (Aphis fable), destructive to beans.
a short vertical spar under the bowsprit.

entry.ety: F. dauphin dolphin, dauphin, earlier spelt also doffin; cf. OF. dalphinal of the dauphin; fr. L. delphinus, Gr. delfi`s a dolphin (in senses 1, 2, 3, & 6), perh. properly, belly fish; cf. delfy`s womb, Skr. garbha; perh. akin to E. calf. Cf. Dauphin Delphine

sn.def: A cetacean of the genus Delphinus and allied genera (esp. Delphinus delphis); the true dolphin.

The Coryphæna hippuris, a fish of about five feet in length, celebrated for its surprising changes of color when dying. It is the fish commonly known as the dolphin. The term is also applied to the related Coryphaena equisetis. Called also dolphinfish and (especially in Hawaiimahimahi. See also dolphinfish and Coryphænoid.
A mass of iron or lead hung from the yardarm, in readiness to be dropped on the deck of an enemy's vessel.

sd.def: A kind of wreath or strap of plaited cordage.
A spar or buoy held by an anchor and furnished with a ring to which ships may fasten their cables.
A mooring post on a wharf or beach.
A permanent fender around a heavy boat just below the gunwale.

sn.def: In old ordnance, one of the handles above the trunnions by which a cannon was lifted.
A small constellation between Aquila and Pegasus. See Delphinus n., 2.

entry.def: A female dolphin.

either of two large slender food and game fish (Coryphaena equisetis or Coryphaena hippurus) of warm waters. They are highly esteemed as food fish, especially in Hawaii, where they are usually referred to as mahimahi. See also dolphin{2.

entry.ety: OE. dulte, prop. p. p. of dullen to dull. See Dull
entry.def: A heavy, stupid fellow; a blockhead; a numskull; an ignoramus; a dunce; a dullard.
entry.q: This Puck seems but a dreaming dolt.

entry.def: To behave foolishly.
Doltlike; dull in intellect; stupid; blockish; as, a doltish clown.

entry.ety: L., deceit; akin to Gr. �
entry.def: Evil intent, embracing both malice and fraud. See Culpa.
of Delve.

entries.entry:
-dom It is from the same root as doom meaning authority and judgment. �. See Doom.. A suffix denoting: Jurisdiction or property and jurisdiction dominion, as in kingdom earldom.
State condition, or quality of being, as in wisdom, freedom.

entry.ety: Pg. See Don

sn.def: A title anciently given to the pope, and later to other church dignitaries and to some monastic orders. See Don, and Dan.
In Portugal and Brazil, the title given to a member of the higher classes.

entry.ety: L. domabilis, fr. domare to tame
entry.def: Capable of being tamed; tamable.
Tamableness.

entry.ety: See Damage

sn.def: Damage; hurt.
Subjugation.

cs.cd: the territory belonging to a State or to the general government; public lands.

the situation or status of intellectual property which is not protected by copyright, patent or other restriction on use. Anything in the public domain may be used by anyone without restriction. The effective term of force of copyrights and patents are limited by statute, and after the term expires, the writings and inventions thus protected go into the public domain and are free for use by all.

that superior dominion of the sovereign power over all the property within the state, including that previously granted by itself, which authorizes it to appropriate any part thereof to a necessary public use, reasonable compensation being made.

entry.ety: F. domaine, OF. demaine, L. dominium, property, right of ownership, fr. dominus master, owner. See Dame, and cf Demesne Dungeon

sn.def: Dominion; empire; authority.
The territory over which dominion or authority is exerted; the possessions of a sovereign or commonwealth, or the like. Also used figuratively.
sn.q: The domain of authentic history.
The domain over which the poetic spirit ranges.

sn.def: Landed property; estate; especially, the land about the mansion house of a lord, and in his immediate occupancy; demesne.
Ownership of land; an estate or patrimony which one has in his own right; absolute proprietorship; paramount or sovereign ownership.
the set of values which the independent variable of a function may take. Contrasted to range, which is the set of values taken by the dependent variable.
a connected set of points, also called a region.

a region within a ferromagnetic material, composed of a number of atoms whose magnetic poles are pointed in the same direction, and which may move together in a coordinated manner when disturbed, as by heating. The direction of polarity of adjacent domains may be different, but may be aligned by a strong external magnetic field.

an address within the internet computer network, which may be a single computer, a network of computers, or one of a number of accounts on a multiuser computer. The domain specifies the location (host computer) to which communications on the internet are directed. Each domain has a corresponding 32-bit number usually represented by four numbers separated by periods, as 128.32.282.56. Each domain may also have an alphabetical name, usually composed of a name plus an extension separated by a period, as worldsoul.org; the alphabetical name is referred to as a domain name.
the three-dimensional structure within an immunoglobulin which is formed by one of the homology regions of a heavy or light chain.
the field of knowledge, expertise, or interest of a person; as, he had a limited domain of discourse; I can't comment on that, it's outside my domain .
a particular environment or walk of life.
people in general; especially a distinctive group of people with some shared interest.

entry.ety: L. domus house
entry.def: Pertaining to a house.
Of or relating to a domain or to domains.

entry.note: ☞ “The Italians apply the term il duomo to the principal church of a city, and the Germans call every cathedral church Dom; and it is supposed that the word in its present English sense has crept into use from the circumstance of such buildings being frequently surmounted by a cupola.”

☞ If the plane is parallel to the longer diagonal (macrodiagonal) of the prism, it is called a macrodome; if parallel to the shorter (brachydiagonal), it is a brachydome; if parallel to the inclined diagonal in a monoclinic crystal, it is called a clinodome; if parallel to the orthodiagonal axis, an orthodome.
entry.ety: F. dôme, It. duomo, fr. L. domus a house, domus Dei or Domini, house of the Lord, house of God; akin to Gr. � house, � to build, and E. timber. See Timber

sn.def: A building; a house; an edifice; -- used chiefly in poetry.
sn.q: Approach the dome, the social banquet share.

sn.def: A cupola formed on a large scale.
Any erection resembling the dome or cupola of a building; as the upper part of a furnace, the vertical steam chamber on the top of a boiler, etc.
A prism formed by planes parallel to a lateral axis which meet above in a horizontal edge, like the roof of a house; also, one of the planes of such a form.

entry.ety: See Doom
entry.def: Decision; judgment; opinion; a court decision.

entry.ety: Dome doom + book
entry.def: A book said to have been compiled under the direction of King Alfred. It is supposed to have contained the principal maxims of the common law, the penalties for misdemeanors, and the forms of judicial proceedings. Domebook was probably a general name for book of judgments.
Furnished with a dome; shaped like a dome.

cs.cd: the ancient record of the survey of most of the lands of England, made by order of William the Conqueror, about 1086. It consists of two volumes, a large folio and a quarto, and gives the proprietors' tenures, arable land, woodland, etc.

entry.def: A day of judgment. See Doomsday.

entries.entry:
Domes"man n.; pl.Domesmen #. See Doom
A judge; an umpire. Obs

entry.ety: L. domesticus, fr. domus use: cf. F. domestique. See 1st Dome

sn.def: Of or pertaining to one's house or home, or one's household or family; relating to home life; as, domestic concerns, life, duties, cares, happiness, worship, servants.
sn.q: His fortitude is the more extraordinary, because his domestic feelings were unusually strong.

sn.def: Of or pertaining to a nation considered as a family or home, or to one's own country; intestine; not foreign; as, foreign wars and domestic dissensions.
Remaining much at home; devoted to home duties or pleasures; as, a domestic man or woman.
Living in or near the habitations of man; domesticated; tame as distinguished from wild; as, domestic animals.
Made in one's own house, nation, or country; as, domestic manufactures, wines, etc.
One who lives in the family of an other, as hired household assistant; a house servant.
sn.q: The master labors and leads an anxious life, to secure plenty and ease to the domestic.

sn.def: Articles of home manufacture, especially cotton goods.

entry.def: Domestic.
entry.q: Our private and domestical matter.

entry.def: A family; a household.
In a domestic manner; privately; with reference to domestic affairs.
Forming part of the same family.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Domesticated; p. pr. & vb. n. Domesticating.
entry.ety: LL. domesticatus, p. p. of domesticare to reside in, to tame. See Domestic a.

sn.def: To make domestic; to habituate to home life; as, to domesticate one's self.
To cause to be, as it were, of one's family or country; as, to domesticate a foreign custom or word.
To tame or reclaim from a wild state; as, to domesticate wild animals; to domesticate a plant.
tame, tamed; -- of animals. Opposite of wild.
accustomed to home life; as, some men think it unmanly to be domesticated; others find gratification in it.
acclimated to a new environment; -- of plants or animals.

entry.ety: Cf. F. domestication
entry.def: The act of domesticating, or accustoming to home; the action of taming wild animals.
One who domesticates.

entry.ety: LL. domesticitas: cf. F. domesticité
entry.def: The state of being domestic; domestic character; household life.
A kind of baize of which the ward is cotton and the weft woolen.

entry.ety: Named after Domeyko, a mineralogist of Chili
entry.def: A massive mineral of tin-white or steel-gray color, an arsenide of copper.
Relating to, or shaped like, a dome.

entry.ety: L. domicilium; domus house + (prob.) root of celare to conceal: cf. F. domicile. See Dome, and Conceal

sn.def: An abode or mansion; a place of permanent residence, either of an individual or a family.
A residence at a particular place accompanied with an intention to remain there for an unlimited time; a residence accepted as a final abode.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Domiciled; p. pr. & vb. n. Domiciling
entry.ety: Cf. F. domicilier. Cf. Domiciliate
entry.def: To establish in a fixed residence, or a residence that constitutes habitancy; to domiciliate.
A member of a household; a domestic.

cs.cd: a visit to a private dwelling, particularly for searching it, under authority.

entry.ety: LL. domiciliarius
entry.def: Of or pertaining to a domicile, or the residence of a person or family.
entry.q: The personal and domiciliary rights of the citizen scrupulously guarded.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Domiciliated; p. pr. & vb. n. Domiciliating
entry.ety: See Domicile

sn.def: To establish in a permanent residence; to domicile.
To domesticate.

entry.def: The act of domiciliating; permanent residence; inhabitancy.

entry.ety: L. domus house + E. culture. See 1st Dome
entry.def: The art of house-keeping, cookery, etc.

entry.ety: L. domus + -fy: cf. F. domifier

sn.def: To divide, as the heavens, into twelve houses. See House, in astrological sense.
To tame; to domesticate.

entries.entry:
Dom"i*na‖n. L., lady. See Dame
O. Eng. Law Lady; a lady; -- a title formerly given to noble ladies who held a barony in their own right.

entry.def: Predominance; ascendency; authority.

cs.cd: the estate to which a servitude or easement is due from another estate, the estate over which the servitude extends being called the servient estate or tenement.
one who owns lands on which there is an easement owned by another.

entry.ety: L. dominans -antis, p. pr. of dominari: cf. F. dominant. See Dominate
entry.def: Ruling; governing; prevailing; controlling; predominant; as, the dominant party, church, spirit, power.
entry.q: The member of a dominant race is, in his dealings with the subject race, seldom indeed fraudulent, . . . but imperious, insolent, and cruel.
entry.syn: Governing; ruling; controlling; prevailing; predominant; ascendant.

cs.cd: the chord based upon the dominant.

entry.def: The fifth tone of the scale; thus G is the dominant of C, A of D, and so on.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Dominated; p. pr. & vb. n. Dominating
entry.ety: L. dominatus, p. p. of dominari to dominate, fr. dominus master, lord. See Dame, and cf. Domineer
entry.def: To predominate over; to rule; to govern.
entry.q: A citydominatedby the ax.
We everywhere meet with Slavonian nations either dominant or dominated.

entry.def: To be dominant.

sn.def: controlled or ruled by superior authority or power.
sn.syn: dominated by, under the thumb of(predicate).

sn.def: controlled by one's wife; -- of men.
exercising influence or control. Opposite of subordinate.
high enough to provide a clear view of the surrounding area; -- of a height or viewpoint.

entry.ety: F. domination, L. dominatio

sn.def: The act of dominating; exercise of power in ruling; dominion; supremacy; authority; often, arbitrary or insolent sway.
sn.q: In such a people, the haughtiness of domination combines with the spirit of freedom.

sn.def: A ruling party; a party in power.
A high order of angels in the celestial hierarchy; -- a meaning given by the schoolmen.
sn.q: Thrones, dominations, princedoms, virtues, powers.

entry.ety: Cf. F. dominatif
entry.def: Governing; ruling; imperious.

entry.ety: L
entry.def: A ruler or ruling power.
entry.q: Soledominatorof Navarre.
Jupiter and Mars are dominators for this northwest part of the world.

entry.ety: See Dominie

sn.def: A name given to a pastor of the Reformed Church. The word is also applied locally in the United States, in colloquial speech, to any clergyman.
A West Indian fish (Epinula magistralis), of the family Trichiuridæ. It is a long-bodied, voracious fish.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Domineered; p. pr. & vb. n. Domineering
entry.ety: F. dominer, L. dominari: cf. OD. domineren to feast luxuriously. See Dominate v. t.
entry.def: To rule with insolence or arbitrary sway; to play the master; to be overbearing; to tyrannize; to bluster; to swell with conscious superiority or haughtiness; -- often with over; as, to domineer over dependents.
entry.q: Go to the feast, revel and domineer.
His wishes tend abroad to roam, And hers to domineer at home.

entry.def: Ruling arrogantly; overbearing.
entry.q: A violent, brutal, domineering old reprobate.

cs.cd: the high altar.

the letter which, in almanacs, denotes Sunday, or the Lord's day (dies Domini). The first seven letters of the alphabet are used for this purpose, the same letter standing for Sunday during a whole year (except in leap year, when the letter is changed at the end of February). After twenty-eight years the same letters return in the same order. The dominical letters go backwards one day every common year, and two every leap year; e. g., if the dominical letter of a common year be G, F will be the dominical letter for the next year. Called also Sunday letter. Cf. Solar cycle, under Cycle n.

entry.ety: LL. dominicalis, for L. dominicus belonging to a master or lord (dominica dies the Lord's day), fr. dominus master or lord: cf. F. dominical. See Dame

sn.def: Indicating, or pertaining to, the Lord's day, or Sunday.
Relating to, or given by, our Lord; as, the dominicalor Lord's) prayer.
sn.q: Some words altered in the dominical Gospels.

entry.def: The Lord's day or Sunday; also, the Lord's prayer.

cs.cd: an order of nuns founded by St. Dominic, and chiefly employed in teaching.
the third order of St. Dominic. See Tertiary.

entry.ety: NL. Dominicanus, fr. Dominicus Dominic, the founder: cf. F. Dominicain
entry.def: Of or pertaining to St. Dominic Dominic de Guzman), or to the religious communities named from him.

One of an order of mendicant monks founded by Dominic de Guzman, in 1215. A province of the order was established in England in 1221. The first foundation in the United States was made in 1807. The Master of the Sacred Palace at Rome is always a Dominican friar. The Dominicans are called also preaching friars friars preachers black friarsfrom their black cloak), brothers of St. Mary, and in France, Jacobins.

entry.ety: L. dominus master + caedere to cut down, kill

sn.def: The act of killing a master.
One who kills his master.

entry.def: an American breed of chicken having barred gray plumage raised for meat and brown eggs.

entry.ety: L. dominus master. See Don Dame

sn.def: A schoolmaster; a pedagogue.
sn.q: This was Abel Sampson, commonly called, from occupation as a pedagogue, Dominie Sampson.

sn.def: A clergyman. See Domine, 1.

entry.ety: LL. dominio, equiv. to L. dominium. See Domain Dungeon

sn.def: Sovereign or supreme authority; the power of governing and controlling; independent right of possession, use, and control; sovereignty; supremacy.
sn.q: I praised and honored him that liveth forever, whose dominion is an everlasting dominion.
To choose between dominion or slavery.

sn.def: Superior prominence; predominance; ascendency.
sn.q: Objects placed foremost ought . . . have dominion over things confused and transient.

sn.def: That which is governed; territory over which authority is exercised; the tract, district, or county, considered as subject; as, the dominions of a king. Also used figuratively; as, the dominion of the passions.
A supposed high order of angels; dominations. See Domination, 3.
sn.q: By him were all things created . . . whether they be thrones, or dominions, or principalities, or powers.
sn.syn: Sovereignty; control; rule; authority; jurisdiction; government; territory; district; region.

entries.entry: Do*min"ion Day. In Canada, a legal holiday, July lst, being the anniversary of the proclamation of the formation of the Dominion in 1867.

entry.def: an American breed of chicken having barred gray plumage raised for meat and brown eggs.

entries.entry:
Dom"i*no
fall like dominoes. To fall sequentially, as when one object in a line, by falling against the next object, causes it in turn to fall, and that second object causes a third to fall, etc.; the process can be repeated an indefinite number of times. The phrase is derived from an entertainment using dominoes arranged in a row, each standing on edge and therefore easily knocked over; when the first is made to fall against the next, it starts a sequence which ends when all have fallen. For amusement, people have arranged such sequences involving thousands of dominoes, arrayed in fanciful patterns.
n.; pl.Dominos or esp. the pieces for a game Dominoes #. F. domino, or It. dominò, or Sp. dominó, fr. L. dominus master. The domino was orig. a hood worn by the canons of a cathedral. See Don Dame
A kind of hood worn by the canons of a cathedral church; a sort of amice.
A mourning veil formerly worn by women.
A kind of mask; particularly, a half mask worn at masquerades, to conceal the upper part of the face. Dominos were formerly worn by ladies in traveling.
A costume worn as a disguise at masquerades, consisting of a robe with a hood adjustable at pleasure.
A person wearing a domino.
pl. A game played by two or more persons, with twenty-eight pieces of wood, bone, or ivory, of a flat, oblong shape, plain at the back, but on the face divided by a line in the middle, and either left blank or variously dotted after the manner of dice. The game is played by matching the spots or the blank of an unmatched half of a domino already played
One of the pieces with which the game of dominoes is played.

Dom"i*no the"o*ry The apparent assumption was that an Asian country politically aligned with the West was as politically unstable as a domino standing on edge. It was used by some as a justification for American involvement in the Vietnam war, 1964-1972.. A political theory current in the 1960's, according to which the conversion of one country in South Asia to communism will start a sequential process causing all Asian countries to convert to Communism.
Dom"i*no whist. A game of cards in which the suits are played in sequence, beginning with a 5 or 9, the player who gets rid of his cards first being the winner.

Dom"i*nus Dom"i*nus n.; pl.Domini #. L., master. See Dame
Master; sir; -- a title of respect formerly applied to a knight or a clergyman, and sometimes to the lord of a manor.

entry.ety: L. domitare to tame, fr. domare
entry.def: That can be tamed.
A grayish variety of trachyte; -- so called from the Puy-de-Dôme in Auvergne, France, where it is found.

entry.ety: Sp. don; akin to Pg. dom, It. donno; fr. L. dominus master. See Dame, and cf. Domine Dominie Domino Dan Dom

sn.def: Sir; Mr; Signior; -- a title in Spain, formerly given to noblemen and gentlemen only, but now common to all classes.
sn.q: Don is used in Italy, though not so much as in Spain. France talks of Dom Calmet, England of Dan Lydgate.

sn.def: A grand personage, or one making pretension to consequence; especially, the head of a college, or one of the fellows at the English universities.
sn.q: The greatdonsof wit.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Donned; p. pr. & vb. n. Donning
entry.ety: Do + on; -- opposed to doff. See Do v. t., 7
entry.def: To put on; to dress in; to invest one's self with.
entry.q: Should I don this robe and trouble you.
At night, or in the rain, He dons a surcoat which he doffs at morn.

entry.ety: Sp. doña. See Duenna
entry.def: Lady; mistress; madam; -- a title of respect used in Spain, prefixed to the Christian name of a lady.

entry.ety: L. donabilis, fr. donare to donate
entry.def: Capable of being donated or given.
the Teutonic god of thunder; counterpart of Norse Thor.

entry.ety: L. donarium, fr. donare
entry.def: A thing given to a sacred use.

entry.ety: From Donatus, a famous grammarian
entry.def: A grammar.
See Donatory.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Donated; p. pr. & vb. n. Donating
entry.ety: L. donatus, p. p. of donare to donate, fr. donum gift, fr. dare to give. See 2d Date
entry.def: To give; to bestow; to present; as, to donate fifty thousand dollars to a college.
given freely especially to a cause or fund; as, the donated van made their meal-on-wheels venture possible.

cs.cd: a party assembled at the house of some one, as of a clergyman, each one bringing some present.

entry.ety: L. donatio; cf. F. donation

sn.def: The act of giving or bestowing; a grant.
sn.q: After donation there is an absolute change and alienation of the property of the thing given.

sn.def: That which is given as a present; that which is transferred to another gratuitously; a gift.
sn.q: And some donation freely to estate On the bless'd lovers.

sn.def: The act or contract by which a person voluntarily transfers the title to a thing of which be is the owner, from himself to another, without any consideration, as a free gift.
sn.syn: Gift; present; benefaction; grant. See Gift.

entry.ety: Cf. F. Donatisme
entry.def: The tenets of the Donatists.

entry.ety: LL. Donatista: cf. F. Donatiste
entry.def: A follower of Donatus, the leader of a body of North African schismatics and purists, who greatly disturbed the church in the 4th century. They claimed to be the true church.
Pertaining to Donatism.

entry.ety: L. donativum, fr. donare: cf. F. donatif. See Donate

sn.def: A gift; a largess; a gratuity; a present.
sn.q: The Romans were entertained with shows anddonatives.

sn.def: A benefice conferred on a person by the founder or patron, without either presentation or institution by the ordinary, or induction by his orders. See the Note under Benefice n., 3.

entry.def: Vested or vesting by donation; as, a donative advowson.

entry.ety: L. Cf. Donor
entry.def: One who makes a gift; a donor; a giver.
A donee of the crown; one the whom, upon certain condition, escheated property is made over.

entry.ety: Do + naught
entry.def: A lazy, good-for-nothing fellow.

entry.ety: L., reed, also a sea fish, Gr. �
entry.def: A canelike grass of southern Europe (Arundo Donax), used for fishing rods, etc.

entry.ety: Sp., lit., a maid. Cf. Damsel
entry.def: A handsome fish of Florida and the West Indies (Platyglossus radiatus). The name is applied also to the ladyfish (Harpe rufa) of the same region.

entry.cs: Done brown a phrase in cookery; applied figuratively to one who has been thoroughly deceived, cheated, or fooled. Colloq Done for tired out; used up; collapsed; destroyed; dead; killed. Colloq Done up. Wrapped up. Worn out; exhausted. Colloq
entry.def: p. p. from Do, and formerly the infinitive.

sn.def: Performed; executed; finished.
It is done or agreed; let it be a match or bargain; -- used elliptically.

entry.ety: Prob. corrupted from OF. doné, F. donné, p. p. of OF. doner, F. donner, to give, issue, fr. L. donare to give. See Donate, and cf. Donee
entry.def: Given; executed; issued; made public; -- used chiefly in the clause giving the date of a proclamation or public act.

entry.ety: OF. doné, F. donné, p. p. See the preceding word

sn.def: The person to whom a gift or donation is made.

Anciently, one to whom lands were given; in later use, one to whom lands and tenements are given in tail; in modern use, one on whom a power is conferred for execution; -- sometimes called the appointor.

entry.def: Same as Donat. Piers Plowman.

entry.ety: Tamil t�nī
entry.def: A clumsy craft, having one mast with a long sail, used for trading purposes on the coasts of Coromandel and Ceylon.

entry.ety: L. donum gift + -ferous
entry.def: Bearing gifts.

entry.ety: See Dungeon
entry.def: The chief tower, also called the keep; a massive tower in ancient castles, forming the strongest part of the fortifications. See Illust. of Castle.

entries.entry:
Don"key
Donkey engine a small auxiliary engine not used for propelling, but for pumping water into the boilers, raising heavy weights, and like purposes. Donkey pump a steam pump for feeding boilers, extinguishing fire, etc.; -- usually an auxiliary. Donkey's eye Bot the large round seed of the Mucuna pruriens, a tropical leguminous plant.
dŏṉ"k� n.; pl.Donkeys dŏṉ"kĭz. Prob. dun, in allusion to the color of the animal + a dim. termination
An ass; or (less frequently) a mule.
A stupid or obstinate fellow; an ass.

entry.def: a Mexican plant (Sedum morganianum) bearing small rose-colored flowers; called also burro's tail horse's tail, and lamb's tail.
a very long time; ages.
hard menial routine work.

cs.cd: leather made by the Dongola process.
a process of tanning goatskin, and now also calfskin and sheepskin, with a combination of vegetable and mineral agents, so that it resembles kid.
a boat race in which the crews are composed of a number of pairs, usually of men and women.

sn.def: A government of Upper Egypt.
same as Dongola kid.

entry.ety: It. donna, L. domina. See Don Dame
entry.def: A lady; madam; mistress; -- the title given a lady in Italy.

entry.ety: Corrupted from do-naught
entry.def: See Do-naught.

entries.entry: Don`née"‖n. F., fr. donner to give Lit., given; hence, in a literary work, as a drama or tale, that which is assumed as to characters, situation, etc., as a basis for the plot or story. That favorite romance donnée of the heir kept out of his own.

entry.def: of or pertaining to John Donne.
like a university don; marked by a narrow focus on or display of learning, especially its trivial aspects.

entry.ety: Don n., 2
entry.def: Self-importance; loftiness of carriage.

entry.ety: F. donneur, OF. daneor, fr. donner. See Donee, and cf. Donator

sn.def: One who gives or bestows; one who confers anything gratuitously; a benefactor. Inverse of recipient.
One who grants an estate; in later use, one who confers a power; -- the opposite of donee.
sn.q: Touching, the parties unto deeds and charters, we are to consider as well the donors and granters as the donees or grantees.

entry.def: Doing nothing; disinclined to work or exertion; inactive; idle; lazy; -- of people; as, a do-nothing policy.
entry.syn: bone-idle, bone-lazy, faineant, indolent, lazy, otiose, shiftless, slothful, workshy, work-shy.

entry.def: person who does no work.
entry.syn: idler, loafer, layabout, bum, ne'er-do-well, good-for-nothing.

The quality or rank of a don, gentleman, or knight.

entry.ety: Cf. It. donzello, Sp. doncel, OF. danzel. See Damsel Don n.
entry.def: A young squire, or knight's attendant; a page.
A dove.

entries.entry:
Doob" grass`. Hind. d�b
Bot A perennial, creeping grass (Cynodon dactylon), highly prized, in Hindostan, as food for cattle, and acclimated in the United States.
doub grass

entry.ety: Cf. Dawdle
entry.def: A trifler; a simple fellow.

entry.ety: Cf. G. dudelsack
entry.def: The Scotch bagpipe.
a person who is stupid or inept; -- used contemptuously.
Any object, usually a tool or other device, whose name is forgotten, or not known.
Sorrow; dole.

entries.entry:
Doo"ly n.; pl.Doolies #. Skr. dōla
A kind of litter suspended from men's shoulders, for carrying persons or things; a palanquin.
doolee doolie
East Indies Having provided doolies, or little bamboo chairs slung on four men's shoulders, in which I put my papers and boxes, we next morning commenced the ascent.

entry.ety: As. dōm; akin to OS. dōm, OHG. tuom, Dan. & Sw. dom, Icel. dōmr, Goth. dōms, Gr. qe`mis law; fr. the root of E. do, v. t. √65. See Do v. t., and cf. Deem -dom

sn.def: Judgment; judicial sentence; penal decree; condemnation.
sn.q: The first dooms of London provide especially the recovery of cattle belonging to the citizens.
Now against himself he sounds this doom.

sn.def: That to which one is doomed or sentenced; destiny or fate, esp. unhappy destiny; penalty.
sn.q: Ere Hector meets his doom.
And homely household task shall be her doom.

sn.def: Ruin; death.
sn.q: This is the day of doom for Bassianus.

sn.def: Discriminating opinion or judgment; discrimination; discernment; decision.
sn.q: And there he learned of things and haps to come, To give foreknowledge true, and certain doom.
sn.syn: Sentence; condemnation; decree; fate; destiny; lot; ruin; destruction.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Doomed; p. pr. & vb. n. Dooming

sn.def: To judge; to estimate or determine as a judge.
To pronounce sentence or judgment on; to condemn; to consign by a decree or sentence; to sentence; as, a criminal doomed to chains or death.
sn.q: Absolves the just, and dooms the guilty souls.

sn.def: To ordain as penalty; hence, to mulct or fine.
sn.q: Have I tongue to doom my brother's death?

sn.def: To assess a tax upon, by estimate or at discretion.
To destine; to fix irrevocably the destiny or fate of; to appoint, as by decree or by fate.
sn.q: A man of genius . . . doomed to struggle with difficulties.

entry.def: A penalty or fine for neglect.
Full of condemnation or destructive power.
entry.q: Thatdoomfuldeluge.

entries.entry:
Doom" palm`. Ar. daum dūm: cf. F. doume
Bot A species of palm tree (Hyphæne Thebaica), highly valued for the fibrous pulp of its fruit, which has the flavor of gingerbread, and is largely eaten in Egypt and Abyssinia.
doum palm

entry.cs: Doomsday Book. See Domesday Book.
entry.ety: AS. d�mes dāg. See Doom, and Day

sn.def: A day of sentence or condemnation; day of death.
sn.q: My body'sdoomsday.

sn.def: The day of the final judgment.
sn.q: I could not tell till doomsday.

entry.ety: Doom + man

Same as Dempster.

cs.cd: etc. Arch See under Blank Blind, etc.
within the house.
near to; bordering on.
cs.q: A riot unpunished is but next door to a tumult.
cs.mcol: Out of doorsorWithout doors, and, colloquially Out doors
cs.cd: out of the house; in open air; abroad; away; lost.
cs.q: His imaginary title of fatherhood is out of doors.
cs.col: To lay (a fault, misfortune, etc.) at one's door
cs.cd: to charge one with a fault; to blame for.
to be imputable or chargeable to.
cs.q: If I have failed, the fault lies wholly at my door.

entry.note: ☞ Door is used in an adjectival construction or as the first part of a compound (with or without the hyphen), as, door frame, doorbell or door bell, door knob or doorknob, door latch or doorlatch, door jamb, door handle, door mat, door panel.
entry.ety: OE. dore dure, AS. duru; akin to OS. dura dor, D. deur, OHG. turi, door, tor gate, G. thür thor, Icel. dyrr, Dan. dör, Sw. dörr, Goth. daur, Lith. durys, Russ. dvere, Olr. dorus, L. fores, Gr. �; cf. Skr. dur dvāra. √246. Cf. Foreign

sn.def: An opening in the wall of a house or of an apartment, by which to go in and out; an entrance way.
sn.q: To the same end, men several paths may tread, As many doors into one temple lead.

sn.def: The frame or barrier of boards, or other material, usually turning on hinges, by which an entrance way into a house or apartment is closed and opened.
sn.q: At last he came unto an iron door That fast was locked.

sn.def: Passage; means of approach or access.
sn.q: I am the door; by me if any man enter in, he shall be saved.

sn.def: An entrance way, but taken in the sense of the house or apartment to which it leads.
sn.q: Martin's office is now the second door in the street.

entry.def: a bell or other sounding device, actuated by a push button at an outer door; the push button activating the bell; alos, the ringing of such a bell; as, I was in the shower and didn't hear the doorbell .
The surrounding frame into which a door shuts.
The jamb or sidepiece of a door.

entry.ety: Skr. Durgā
entry.def: A Hindoo divinity, the consort of Siva, represented with ten arms.
The frame of a door.
One who guards the entrance of a house or apartment; a porter; a janitor.
a device (usually metal and ornamental) attached by a hinge to a door, which may be swung by hand against the door to make a loud knocking sound.
Without a door.
a lock on an exterior door.
someone who guards the entrance to a building.
entry.syn: doorkeeper, door guard, hall porter, porter, gatekeeper.

sn.def: a mat placed outside and exterior door for wiping the shoes before entering.
A person who is habitually abused, taken advantage of or humiliated; sometimes, one who is physically weak; as, they used him for a doormat .

entry.def: The nail or knob on which in ancient doors the knocker struck; -- hence the old saying, “As dead as a doornail.”
A plane on a door, giving the name, and sometimes the employment, of the occupant.
The jamb or sidepiece of a doorway.
The sill or threshold of a door.
Entrance or place of a door.
The stone or plank forming a step before an outer door.
The stone forming a threshold.
The block or strip of wood or similar material which stops, at the right place, the shutting of a door; any object used to stop open doors from moving.
same as doorstop.

sn.def: direct without intermediate changes of vehicle; -- of e.g. journeys or deliveries; as, the limousine offers direct door-to-door service.
omitting no one; from the door of one house to that of the next; as, a door-to-door solicitation, canvass, or campaign.

entry.def: The passage of a door; entrance way into a house or a room.
A yard in front of a house or around the door of a house.
A little copper cup in which a diamond is held while being cut.

entry.ety: Cf. Dap Dip
entry.def: To dip.
A dip; a low courtesy.
a foreign substance added to a material to alter its properties; -- a process used. e.g., in making semiconductors from pure silicon in the manufacture of semiconductor chips and integrated circuits.

cs.cd: learn the true story; get the inside information.

entry.ety: D. doop a dipping, fr. doopen to dip. Cf. Dip

sn.def: Any thick liquid or pasty preparation, as of opium for medicinal purposes, of grease for a lubricant, etc.
Any preparation, as of opium, used to stupefy or, in the case of a race horse, to stimulate.

An absorbent material; esp., in high explosives, the sawdust, infusorial earth, mica, etc., mixed with nitroglycerin to make a damp powder (dynamite, etc.) less dangerous to transport, and ordinarily explosive only by suitable fulminating caps.

Information concerning the previous performances of race horses, or other facts concerning them which may be of assistance in judging of their chances of winning future races; similar information concerning other sports; by extension, any information not generally known, especially when coming from an inside source; as, the inside dope .
an ignorant or stupid person.
To treat or affect with dope; as, to dope nitroglycerin;

sd.def: To give stupefying drugs to; to drug.
To administer a stimulant to (a horse) to increase his speed. It is a serious offense against the laws of racing.

to impregnate with a dopant.

sn.def: stupid; as, a dopy kid.
dulled or stupefied by alcohol or narcotics; sluggish or dull as though under the influence of a narcotic.
revealing stupidity; as, a dopey answer.

entry.def: A European marine fish (Zeus faber), of a yellow color. See Illust. of John Doree.
A doorpost.

entry.def: The European goatsucker; -- so called because it eats the dor beetle. See Goatsucker.

sn.def: Of or pertaining to the ancient Greeks of Doris; Doric; as, a Dorian fashion.

sn.def: Pertaining to Doris, in ancient Greece, or to the Dorians; as, the Doric dialect.
Belonging to, or resembling, the oldest and simplest of the three orders of architecture used by the Greeks, but ranked as second of the five orders adopted by the Romans. See Abacus Capital Order.
Of or relating to one of the ancient Greek musical modes or keys. Its character was adapted both to religions occasions and to war.

entry.def: The Doric dialect.
A Doric phrase or idiom.

entry.ety: L. Doris, the daughter of Oceanus, and wife of Nereus, Gr. �
entry.def: A genus of nudibranchiate mollusks having a wreath of branchiæ on the back.

entry.ety: Gr. �
entry.def: A Doric phrase or idiom.

sn.def: a person who is stupid, socially inept, or ridiculous; -- always used disparagingly.
the penis.

entries.entry: Dor"king fowl` dôr"kĭng foul`. From the town of Dorking in England Zoöl One of a breed of large-bodied domestic fowls, having five toes, or the hind toe double. There are several strains, as the white gray, and silver-gray. They are highly esteemed for the table.

entry.def: stupid, socially inept, unfashionable, or ridiculous; -- always used disparagingly.
a dormitory.

entry.ety: From Dormant
entry.def: The state of being dormant; quiescence; abeyance.

cs.cd: a partner who takes no share in the active business of a company or partnership, but is entitled to a share of the profits, and subject to a share in losses; -- called also sleeping partnerorsilent partner.
a dormer window. See Dormer.
a stationary table.

entry.ety: From Dormant
entry.def: The state of being dormant; quiescence; abeyance.
entry.q: It is by lying dormant a long time, or being . . . very rarely exercised, that arbitrary power steals upon a people.

sn.def: In a sleeping posture; as, a lion dormant ; -- distinguished from couchant.

entries.entry:
Dor"mant n. See Dormant a.
Arch A large beam in the roof of a house upon which portions of the other timbers rest or “ sleep.” Arch. Pub. Soc.Called also dormant tree dorman tree dormond, and dormer. Halliwell.

entry.ety: Literally, the window of a sleeping apartment. F. dormir to sleep. See Dormant a. & n.
entry.def: A window pierced in a roof, and so set as to be vertical while the roof slopes away from it. Also, the gablet, or houselike structure, in which it is contained.

entry.ety: Cf. F. dormitif, fr. dormire to sleep
entry.def: Causing sleep; as, the dormitive properties of opium.

def2.def: A medicine to promote sleep; a soporific; an opiate.

entries.entry:
Dor"mi*to*ry n.; pl.Dormitories #. L. dormitorium, fr. dormitorius of or for sleeping, fr. dormire to sleep. See Dormant
A sleeping room, or a building containing a series of sleeping rooms; a sleeping apartment capable of containing many beds; esp., one connected with a college or boarding school.
A burial place. Obs My sister was interred in a very honorable manner in our dormitory, joining to the parish church.

Dor"mouse n.; pl.Dormice #. Perh. fr. F. dormir to sleep (Prov. E. dorm to doze) + E. mouse; or perh. changed fr. F. dormeuse, fem., a sleeper, though not found in the sense of a dormouse
Zoöl A small European rodent of the genus Myoxus, of several species. They live in trees and feed on nuts, acorns, etc.; -- so called because they are usually torpid in winter.

entry.note: ☞ A player who is dormy can not be beaten, and at the worst must halve the match. Encyc. of Sport.
entry.ety: Origin uncertain
entry.def: Up, or ahead, as many holes as remain to be played; -- said of a player or side.

entry.ety: Cf. G. dorn thorn, D. doorn, and G. dornfisch stickleback
entry.def: A British ray; the thornback.

entry.note: ☞ Ure says that dornock, a kind of stout figured linen, derives its name from a town in Scotland where it was first manufactured for tablecloths.
entry.def: A coarse sort of damask, originally made at Tournay (in Flemish, Doornick), Belgium, and used for hangings, carpets, etc. Also, a stout figured linen manufactured in Scotland.

entry.ety: LG. & D. dorp. See Thorpe

To deafen with noise.

entry.ety: Dorsum +L. ad towards

cs.cd: a central pulsating blood vessel along the back of insects, acting as a heart.

entry.ety: F. dorsal, LL. dorsalis, fr. L. dorsualis, fr. dorsum back; cf. Gr. �, �, mountain ridge. Cf. Dorse Dorsel Dosel

sn.def: Pertaining to, or situated near, the back, or dorsum, of an animal or of one of its parts; notal; tergal; neural; as, the dorsal fin of a fish; the dorsal artery of the tongue; -- opposed to ventral.

sd.def: Pertaining to the surface naturally inferior, as of a leaf.
Pertaining to the surface naturally superior, as of a creeping hepatic moss.

entry.ety: LL. dorsale, neut. fr. dorsalis. See Dorsal a.
entry.def: A hanging, usually of rich stuff, at the back of a throne, or of an altar, or in any similar position.
Same as Dorsal n.
On, or toward, the dorsum, or back; on the dorsal side of; dorsad.

entry.ety: Cf. L. dorsum the back. See Dorsel Dosel

sn.def: Same as dorsal n.
The back of a book.
sn.q: Books, all richly bound, with gilt dorses.

sn.def: A pannier.
Same as Dorsal n.

entry.def: See Dosser.

entry.ety: NL., from L. dorsum back + branchiae gills

Having branchiæ along the back; belonging to the Dorsibranchiata.

entries.entry:
Dor*sif"er*ous,. Dorsum + -ferous; cf. F. dorsifère
Biol Bearing, or producing, on the back; -- applied to ferns which produce seeds on the back of the leaf, and to certain Batrachia, the ova of which become attached to the skin of the back of the parent, where they develop; dorsiparous.

entry.ety: Dorsum + meson
entry.def: Anat.) See Meson.

entry.ety: Dorsum + L. parere to bring forth
entry.def: Same as Dorsiferous.

entry.ety: Dorsum + ventral

sn.def: Having distinct upper and lower surfaces, as most common leaves. The leaves of the iris are not dorsiventral.
See Dorsoventral.

entry.ety: dorsum + ventral
entry.def: From the dorsal to the ventral side of an animal; as, the dorsoventral axis.

entry.ety: L

sn.def: The ridge of a hill.
The back or dorsal region of an animal; the upper side of an appendage or part; as, the dorsum of the tongue.

entry.ety: F. dortoir, fr. L. dormitorium
entry.def: A dormitory.

entries.entry:
Do"ry n.; pl.Dories #. Named from 1st color, fr. F. dorée gilded, fr. dorer to gild, L. deaurare. See Deaurate, and cf. Aureole
Zoöl A European fish. See Doree, and John Doree.
Zoöl The American wall-eyed perch; -- called also doré. See Pike perch.
Do"ry n.; pl.Dories. A small, strong, flat-bottomed rowboat, with sharp prow and flaring sides.

entry.ety: NL. See Doryphoros
entry.def: A genus of plant-eating beetles, including the potato beetle. See Potato beetle.

entry.ety: L., fr. Gr. �, lit., spear bearing; � a spear + fe`rein to bear
entry.def: A spear bearer; a statue of a man holding a spear or in the attitude of a spear bearer. Several important sculptures of this subject existed in antiquity, copies of which remain to us.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: Back to back; as, to sit dos-à-dos in a dogcart; to dance dos-à-dos, or so that two dancers move forward and pass back to back.
A sofa, open carriage, or the like, so constructed that the occupants sit back to back.

entry.ety: Cf. F. dosage. See Dose v.

sn.def: The administration of medicine in doses; specif., a scheme or system of grading doses of medicine according to age, etc.
The process of adding some ingredient, as to wine, to give flavor, character, or strength.
same as dose{1; as, 200 mg q.i.d.
the quantity of a medicine or other substance given to an animal, expressed as a quantity per body weight; as, use a dosage of 10 milligrams per kilogram
the quantity of radiation given to or absorbed by an object; as, a maximum dosage of 1 mrad per day is allowed.

entry.ety: F. dose, Gr. do`sis a giving, a dose, fr. dido`nai to give; akin to L. dare to give. See Date point of time

sn.def: The quantity of medicine given, or prescribed to be taken, at one time.
A sufficient quantity; a portion; as much as one can take, or as falls to one to receive.
Anything unpleasant that one is obliged to take; a disagreeable portion thrust upon one; also used figuratively, as to give someone a dose of his own medicine, i. e. to retaliate in kind.
sn.q: I am for curing the world by gentle alteratives, not by violent doses.
I dare undertake that as fulsome a dose as you give him, he shall readily take it down.

sn.def: a quantity of radiation which an object absorbs, or to which it is exposed.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Dosed; p. pr. & vb. n. dosing
entry.ety: Cf. F. doser. See Dose n.

sn.def: To proportion properly (a medicine), with reference to the patient or the disease; to form into suitable doses.
To give doses to; to medicine or physic to; to give potions to, constantly and without need.
sn.q: A self-opinioned physician, worse than his distemper, who shall dose, and bleed, and kill him, “secundum artem.”

sn.def: To give anything nauseous to.

entry.ety: OF. dossel; cf. LL. dorsale. See Dorsal, and cf. Dorse Dorsel
entry.def: Same as Dorsal n.

entry.ety: from dos-à-dos, back to back
entry.def: a movement in square-dancing in which two dancers move around each other in a back-to-back position, and return to their original places.

sn.def: for measuring doses of .

entry.ety: NL. dosis dose + -meter
entry.def: a device for measuring doses of radiation, especially ionizing radiation such as X-rays, gamma rays, or ionizing particles.

a dosimeter cosisting of a radiation-sensitive material, such as film, worn in a small package on a person's clothing, to record the accumulated radiation exposure of the person over a period of time; -- used to monitor the exposure of individuals, such as workers in a nuclear power plant, to ionizing radiation.

entry.ety: NL. dosis dose + -metry
entry.def: Measurement of doses; specif., a system of therapeutics which uses but few remedies, mostly alkaloids, and gives them in doses fixed by certain rules.

entry.ety: Dose + -logy
entry.def: Posology.

entry.ety: Etym. uncertain
entry.def: A place to sleep in; a bed; hence, sleep.
to sleep in a convenient place.

entries.entry: Doss house. A cheap lodging house. They [street Arabs] consort together and sleep in low doss houses where they meet with all kinds of villainy.

entry.ety: See Dosel n.
entry.def: Same as Dorsal n.

entry.ety: LL. dosserum, or F.dossier bundle of papers, part of a basket resting on the back, fr. L. dorsum back. See Dorsal, and cf. Dosel

sn.def: A pannier, or basket.
sn.q: To hire a ripper's mare, and buy new dossers.

sn.def: A hanging tapestry; a dorsal.

entry.ety: F., back of a thing, bulging bundle of papers, fr. dos back
entry.def: A bundle containing the papers in reference to some matter.

entry.ety: OE. dosil faucet of a barrel, OF. dosil duisil, spigot, LL. diciculus ducillus, fr. L. ducere to lead, draw. See Duct Duke

sn.def: A small ovoid or cylindrical roil or pledget of lint, for keeping a sore, wound, etc., open; a tent.
A roll of cloth for wiping off the face of a copperplate, leaving the ink in the engraved lines.

entry.def: of Do.
Russian author Fyodor Mikhailovich Dostoevski; born 1821, died 1881.
of or pertaining to Fyodor Dostoevski.

entry.ety: F., fr. L. dos dotis, dowry. See Dower, and cf. Dote dowry
entry.def: A marriage portion; dowry.

entry.ety: Cf. AS. dott small spot, speck; of uncertain origin

sn.def: A small point or spot, made with a pen or other pointed instrument; a speck, or small mark.
Anything small and like a speck comparatively; a small portion or specimen; as, a dot of a child.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Dotted; p. pr. & vb. n. Dotting

sn.def: To mark with dots or small spots; as, to dot a line.
To mark or diversify with small detached objects; as a landscape dotted with cottages.

entry.def: To make dots or specks.

entry.note: The Department of Transportation promulgates standards for the strength of shipping containers, and this abgreviation is often seen on cardboard boxes.
entry.def: The United States Department of Transportation.

entry.ety: From Dote v. i.

sn.def: Feebleness or imbecility of understanding or mind, particularly in old age; the childishness of old age; senility; as, a venerable man, now in his dotage .
sn.q: Capable of distinguishing between the infancy and the dotage of Greek literature.

sn.def: Foolish utterance; drivel.
sn.q: The sapless dotages of old Paris and Salamanca.

sn.def: Excessive fondness; weak and foolish affection.
sn.q: The dotage of the nation on presbytery.

entry.ety: L. dotalis, fr. dos dotis, dowry: cf. F. dotal. See Dot dowry
entry.def: Pertaining to dower, or a woman's marriage portion; constituting dower, or comprised in it.
A dotard.
One whose mind is impaired by age; one in second childhood.
entry.q: The sickly dotard wants a wife.

entry.def: Foolish; weak.
A dotard's weakness; dotage.

entry.ety: LL. dotatio, fr. L. dotare to endow, fr. dos dotis, dower: cf. F. dotation. See Dot dowry

sn.def: The act of endowing, or bestowing a marriage portion on a woman.
Endowment; establishment of funds for support, as of a hospital or eleemosynary corporation.

entry.ety: See Dot dowry

sn.def: A marriage portion. Obs See 1st Dot n.
Natural endowments.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Doted; p. pr. & vb. n. Doting
entry.ety: OE. doten; akin to OD. doten, D. dutten, to doze, Icel. dotta to nod from sleep, MHG. t�zen to keep still: cf. F. doter, OF. radoterto dote, rave, talk idly or senselessly), which are from the same source

sn.def: To act foolishly.
sn.q: He wol make him doten anon right.

sn.def: To be weak-minded, silly, or idiotic; to have the intellect impaired, especially by age, so that the mind wanders or wavers; to drivel.
sn.q: Time has made you dote, and vainly tell Of arms imagined in your lonely cell.
He survived the use of his reason, grew infatuated, and doted long before he died.

sn.def: To be excessively or foolishly fond; to love to excess; to be weakly affectionate; -- with on or upon; as, the mother dotes on her child.
sn.q: Sing, siren, for thyself, and I will dote.
What dust we dote on, when 't is man we love.

entry.def: An imbecile; a dotard.

sn.def: Stupid; foolish.
sn.q: Senseless speech and doted ignorance.

sn.def: Half-rotten; as, doted wood.

entry.def: A dotard.

sn.def: One who dotes; a man whose understanding is enfeebled by age; a dotard.
One excessively fond, or weak in love.

entry.def: The acts or speech of a dotard; drivel.
of Do.
That dotes; silly; excessively fond.
Foolish; weak; imbecile.

entry.ety: For Dotard?
entry.def: An old, decayed tree.

cs.cd: a note followed by a dot to indicate an increase of length equal to one half of its simple value; thus, a dotted semibreve is equal to three minims, and a dotted quarter to three eighth notes.
a rest lengthened by a dot in the same manner as a dotted note.

entry.note: ☞ Notes and rests are sometimes followed by two dots, to indicate an increase of length equal to three quarters of their simple value, and they are then said to be double-dotted.
entry.def: Marked with, or made of, dots or small spots; diversified with small, detached objects.

entry.ety: Cf. Dottard
entry.def: Decayed.
entry.q: Some olddottereltrees.

entry.note: ☞ The ringed dotterel (or ring plover) is Charadrius hiaticula .
entry.ety: From Dote v. i.

sn.def: A European bird of the Plover family (Eudromias morinellus, syn. Charadrius morinellus). It is tame and easily taken, and is popularly believed to imitate the movements of the fowler.
sn.q: In catching of dotterels we see how the foolish bird playeth the ape in gestures.

sn.def: A silly fellow; a dupe; a gull.

entries.entry: Dot"ting pen`. See under Pun.

entry.def: See Dotterel.

entry.ety: From 2d Dot

sn.def: Composed of, or characterized by, dots.

sn.ety: Perh. a different word; cf. Totty
sn.def: Unsteady in gait; hence, feeble; half-witted.

entry.ety: See Dottard
entry.def: Half-rotten; as, doty timber.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: A customhouse.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: An officer of the French customs.

entry.ety: F., fr. Ar. d�ār
entry.def: A village composed of Arab tents arranged in streets.

entries.entry:
Dou"ay Bi"ble. From Douay, or Douai, a town in France A translation of the Scriptures into the English language for the use of English-speaking Roman Catholics; -- done from the Latin Vulgate by English scholars resident in France. The New Testament portion was published at Rheims, A. D. 1582, the Old Testament at Douai, A. D. 1609-10. Various revised editions have since been published.
Doway Bible Rheims and Douay version
Doub" grass` d�b" grȧs.Bot Doob grass.

entry.note: ☞ Double is often used as the first part of a compound word, generally denoting two ways, or twice the number quantity force, etc., twofold, or having two.
entry.cs:
Double baseorDouble bass
Mus the largest and lowest-toned instrument in the violin form; the contrabasso or violone. Double convex. See under Convex. Double counterpoint Mus that species of counterpoint or composition, in which two of the parts may be inverted, by setting one of them an octave higher or lower. Double court Lawn Tennis a court laid out for four players, two on each side. Double dagger Print a reference mark (‡) next to the dagger (†) in order; a diesis. Double drum Mus a large drum that is beaten at both ends. Double eagle a gold coin of the United States having the value of 20 dollars. Double entry. See under Bookkeeping. Double floor Arch a floor in which binding joists support flooring joists above and ceiling joists below. See Illust. of Double-framed floor. Double flower. See Double a., 4. Double-framed floor Arch a double floor having girders into which the binding joists are framed. Double fugue Mus a fugue on two subjects. Double letter. Print Two letters on one shank; a ligature. A mail requiring double postage. Double note Mus a note of double the length of the semibreve; a breve. See Breve. Double octave Mus an interval composed of two octaves, or fifteen notes, in diatonic progression; a fifteenth. Double pica. See under Pica. Double play Baseball a play by which two players are put out at the same time. Double plea Law a plea alleging several matters in answer to the declaration, where either of such matters alone would be a sufficient bar to the action. Stephen. Double point Geom a point of a curve at which two branches cross each other. Conjugate or isolated points of a curve are called double points, since they possess most of the properties of double pointssee Conjugate). They are also called acnodes, and those points where the branches of the curve really cross are called crunodes. The extremity of a cusp is also a double point. Double quarrel. Eccl. Law See Duplex querela, under Duplex. Double refraction. Opt See Refraction. Double salt. Chem A mixed salt of any polybasic acid which has been saturated by different bases or basic radicals, as the double carbonate of sodium and potassium, NaKCO3.6H2O . A molecular combination of two distinct salts, as common alum, which consists of the sulphate of aluminium, and the sulphate of potassium or ammonium. Double shuffle a low, noisy dance. Double standard Polit. Econ a double standard of monetary values; i. e., a gold standard and a silver standard, both of which are made legal tender. Double star Astron two stars so near to each other as to be seen separate only by means of a telescope. Such stars may be only optically near to each other, or may be physically connected so that they revolve round their common center of gravity, and in the latter case are called also binary stars. Double time Mil. Same as Double-quick. Double window a window having two sets of glazed sashes with an air space between them.
entry.ety: OE. doble duble double, OF. doble duble double, F. double, fr. L. duplus, fr. the root of duo two, and perh. that of plenus full; akin to Gr. diplo`os double. See Two, and Full, and cf. Diploma Duple

sn.def: Twofold; multiplied by two; increased by its equivalent; made twice as large or as much, etc.
sn.q: Let a double portion of thy spirit be upon me.
Darkness and tempest make a double night.

sn.def: Being in pairs; presenting two of a kind, or two in a set together; coupled.
sn.q: Let] The swan, on still St. Mary's lake, Float double, swan and shadow.

sn.def: Divided into two; acting two parts, one openly and the other secretly; equivocal; deceitful; insincere.
sn.q: With a double heart do they speak.

sn.def: Having the petals in a flower considerably increased beyond the natural number, usually as the result of cultivation and the expense of the stamens, or stamens and pistils. The white water lily and some other plants have their blossoms naturally double.

entry.def: Twice; doubly.
entry.q: I was double their age.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Doubled; p. pr. & vb. n. Doubling
entry.ety: OE. doblen dublen doublen, F. doubler, fr. L. duplare, fr. duplus. See Double a.

sn.def: To increase by adding an equal number, quantity, length, value, or the like; multiply by two; as, to double a sum of money; to double a number, or length.
sn.q: Double six thousand, and then treble that.

sn.def: To make of two thicknesses or folds by turning or bending together in the middle; to fold one part upon another part of; as, to double the leaf of a book, and the like; to clinch, as the fist; -- often followed by up; as, to double up a sheet of paper or cloth.
sn.q: Then the old man Was wroth, and doubled up his hands.

sn.def: To be the double of; to exceed by twofold; to contain or be worth twice as much as.
sn.q: Thus reënforced, against the adverse fleet, Still doubling ours, brave Rupert leads the way.

sn.def: To pass around or by; to march or sail round, so as to reverse the direction of motion.
sn.q: Sailing along the coast, the doubled the promontory of Carthage.

sn.def: To unite, as ranks or files, so as to form one from each two.

cs.cd: to inclose between two fires.

sn.def: To be increased to twice the sum, number, quantity, length, or value; to increase or grow to twice as much.
sn.q: 'T is observed in particular nations, that within the space of three hundred years, notwithstanding all casualties, the number of men doubles.

sn.def: To return upon one's track; to turn and go back over the same ground, or in an opposite direction.
sn.q: Doubling and turning like a hunted hare.
Doubling and doubling with laborious walk.

sn.def: To play tricks; to use sleights; to play false.
sn.q: What penalty and danger you accrue, If you be found to double.

sn.def: To set up a word or words a second time by mistake; to make a doublet.
Twice as much; twice the number, sum, quantity, length, value, and the like.
sn.q: If the thief be found, let him pay double.

sn.def: Among compositors, a doublet (see Doublet, 2.); among pressmen, a sheet that is twice pulled, and blurred.
That which is doubled over or together; a doubling; a plait; a fold.
sn.q: Rolled up in sevenfold double Of plagues.

sn.def: A turn or circuit in running to escape pursues; hence, a trick; a shift; an artifice.
sn.q: These men are too well acquainted with the chase to be flung off by any false steps or doubles.

sn.def: A person or thing that is the counterpart of another; a duplicate; copy; Obs transcript; -- now chiefly used of persons. Hence, a wraith.
sn.q: My charming friend . . . has, I am almost sure, a double, who preaches his afternoon sermons for him.

sn.def: A player or singer who prepares to take the part of another player in his absence; a substitute; -- used especially of a person who resembles an actor and takes the actor's place in scenes requiring special skills; as, a stunt double .
Double beer; strong beer.
A feast in which the antiphon is doubled, hat is, said twice, before and after the Psalms, instead of only half being said, as in simple feasts.
A game between two pairs of players; as, a first prize for doubles .
An old term for a variation, as in Bach's Suites.

entry.def: Acting or operating in two directions or with both motions; producing a twofold result; as, a double-acting engine or pump.

cs.cd: to set two men to pulling one oar.

entry.def: To row by rowers sitting side by side in twos on a bank or thwart.
Applied to a kind of rowing in which the rowers sit side by side in twos, a pair of oars being worked from each bank or thwart.
Having two barrels; -- applied to a gun.

entries.entry: Dou"ble-beat` valve". See under Valve.

entry.def: Folding or lapping over on the breast, with a row of buttons and buttonholes on each side; as, a double-breasted coat.

sn.def: To load with a double charge, as of gunpowder.
To overcharge.

entry.def: to betray or swindle (a colleague); to promise (a collaborator) one thing and to treacherously do another, to the detriment of the collaborator.
teh act of double-crossing; the betrayal or swindling of a collaborator or colleague.
one who double-crosses another; a person who says one thing and does another.

sn.def: rendered twice as great or twice as many.
folded in two; as, doubled sheets of paper.

entries.entry: Dou"ble deal"er dou"ble-deal"er . One who practices double dealing; a deceitful, trickish person; a person who says one thing and does another. double-crosser, betrayer, traitor.

Dou"ble deal"ing dou"ble-deal"ing . False or deceitful dealing; acting in bad faith; deception by pretending to entertain one set of intentions while acting under the influence of another. See Double dealing, under Dealing. duplicity.

sn.def: given to deception especially by pretending one set of feelings and acting under the influence of another; as, they accused each other of double-dealing behavior.
A man-of-war having two gun decks.

sd.def: A tenement house having two families on each floor.
A biplane aëroplane or kite.

sn.def: anything having two decks or levels, as a bus with two levels for passengers. In older vehicles, less often today, the upper deck was open, as on street cars.

entry.def: To dye again or twice over.
entry.q: To double-dye their robes in scarlet.

entry.def: Dyed twice; thoroughly or intensely colored; hence; firmly fixed in opinions or habits; as, a double-dyed villain.
A vessel capable of moving in either direction, having bow and rudder at each end.
A locomotive with pilot at each end.

entry.ety: F. double double + entendre to mean. This is a barbarous compound of French words. The true French equivalent is double entente
entry.def: A word or expression admitting of a double interpretation, one of which is often obscure or indelicate.
Having a deceitful look.
entry.q: Deceitful meanings isdouble-eyed.

entry.ety: G. doppelgänger; doppel double + gänger walker
entry.def: An apparition or double of a living person; a doppelgänger.
entry.q: Either you are Hereward, or you are his doubleganger.

sn.def: Having two faces designed for use; as, a double-faced hammer.
Deceitful; hypocritical; treacherous.

entries.entry: Dou"ble first`. Eng. Universities A degree of the first class both in classics and mathematics. One who gains at examinations the highest honor both in the classics and the mathematics.

sn.def: Having two hands.
Deceitful; deceptive.

cs.cd: a rail whose flanges are duplicates, so that when one is worn the other may be turned uppermost.

entry.def: Having two heads; bicipital.

entry.note: A doubleheader in baseball is often scheduled between teams when a previously shceduled game is postponed, as due to rain or other interfering factors. In such cases, the admission price for the doubleheader remains that of a single game, though two games are played.
entry.def: two events, usually entertainment or sports performances, occurring immediately in succession or within a short time of each other; especially, two sports games played by the same teams on the same day, one right after another.
Having a false heart; deceitful; treacherous.
Having both sashes hung with weights and cords; -- said of a window.
To lock with two bolts; to fasten with double security.
Twice milled or fulled, to render more compact or fine; -- said of cloth; as, double-milled kerseymere.
Having different minds at different times; unsettled; undetermined.
entry.q: A double-minded man is unstable in all his ways.

sn.def: The state of being double or doubled.
Duplicity; insincerity.

entries.entry: Double pedro. Cinch (the game).

entry.def: Of, or performed in, the fastest time or step in marching, next to the run; as, a double-quick step or march.

entry.note: ☞ Double-quick time requires 165 steps, each 33 inches in length, to be taken in one minute. The number of steps may be increased up to 180 per minute.
entry.def: Double-quick time, step, or march.
To move, or cause to move, in double-quick time.

sn.def: One who, or that which, doubles.
An instrument for augmenting a very small quantity of electricity, so as to render it manifest by sparks or the electroscope.
A part of a distilling apparatus for intercepting the heavier fractions and returning them to be redistilled.
A blanket or felt placed between the fabric and the printing table or cylinder.

entry.def: A kind of coasting sled, made of two sleds fastened together with a board, one before the other.

sn.def: badminton played with two players on each side.
tennis played with two players on each side.

entry.def: To double the natural darkness of (a place).

a standard or set of principles governing conduct, which is applied more stringently or differently to one group of people than to another; -- used especially of standards of sexual behavior that condemn behavior on the part of women that is condoned or not condemned when exhibited by men.
Having two surfaces; -- said specif. of aëroplane wings or aërocurves which are covered on both sides with fabric, etc., thus completely inclosing their frames.

entry.ety: In sense 3, OF. doublet; in sense 4, F. doublet, dim. of double double. See Double a.

sn.def: Two of the same kind; a pair; a couple.
A word or words unintentionally doubled or set up a second time.
A close-fitting garment for men, covering the body from the neck to the waist or a little below. It was worn in Western Europe from the 15th to the 17th century.
A counterfeit gem, composed of two pieces of crystal, with a color them, and thus giving the appearance of a naturally colored gem. Also, a piece of paste or glass covered by a veneer of real stone.
An arrangement of two lenses for a microscope, designed to correct spherical aberration and chromatic dispersion, thus rendering the image of an object more clear and distinct.

entry.sn: pl.See No. 1Two dice, each of which, when thrown, has the same number of spots on the face lying uppermost; as, to throw doublets .

sn.def: A game somewhat like backgammon.

One of two or more words in the same language derived by different courses from the same original from; as, crypt and grot are doublets; also, guard and ward; yard and garden; abridge and abbreviate, etc.
Consisting of two threads twisted together; using two threads.
Having two screw threads instead of one; -- said of a screw in which the pitch is equal to twice the distance between the centers of adjacent threads.

entry.def: Deceit; duplicity.
entry.q: Now cometh the sin of double-tongue, such as speak fair before folk and wickedly behind.

entry.def: Making contrary declarations on the same subject; deceitful.
entry.q: Likewise must the deacons be grave, not double-tongued.

entry.def: A peculiar action of the tongue by flute players in articulating staccato notes; also, the rapid repetition of notes in cornet playing.
The bar, or crosspiece, of a carriage, to which the singletrees are attached.
See Doublet, 6 and 7.

cs.cd: etc. Naut, sailing around or passing beyond a cape, promontory, etc.

sn.def: The act of one that doubles; a making double; reduplication; also, that which is doubled.
A turning and winding; as, the doubling of a hunted hare; shift; trick; artifice.
The lining of the mantle borne about the shield or escutcheon.
The process of redistilling spirits, to improve the strength and flavor.
raising the stakes in a game, such as a card game or backgammon, by a factor of 2.

entry.ety: F. doublon, Sp. doblon. See Double a., and cf. Dupion
entry.def: A Spanish gold coin, no longer issued, varying in value at different times from over fifteen dollars to about five. See Doblon in Sup.

entry.ety: F

sn.def: The lining of a book cover, esp. one of unusual sort, as of tooled leather, painted vellum, rich brocade, or the like.
The reflexed margin of the trilobite carapace.
In twice the quantity; to twice the degree; as, doubly wise or good; to be doubly sensible of an obligation.
Deceitfully.
sn.q: A man that dealsdoubly.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Doubted; p. pr. & vb. n. Doubting
entry.ety: OE. duten douten, OF. duter doter douter, F. douter, fr. L. dubitare; akin to dubius doubtful. See Dubious

sn.def: To waver in opinion or judgment; to be in uncertainty as to belief respecting anything; to hesitate in belief; to be undecided as to the truth of the negative or the affirmative proposition; to b e undetermined.
sn.q: Even in matters divine, concerning some things, we may lawfully doubt, and suspend our judgment.
To try your love and make you doubt of mine.

sn.def: To suspect; to fear; to be apprehensive.
sn.syn: To waver; vacillate; fluctuate; hesitate; demur; scruple; question.

entry.cs: To doubt not but. I do not doubt but I have been to blame. Dryden. We doubt not nowBut every rub is smoothed on our way. Shak. That is, we have no doubt to prevent us from believing, etc. (or notwithstanding all that may be said to the contrary)but having a preventive sense, after verbs of “doubting” and “denying” that convey a notion of hindrance. E. A. Abbott.

sn.def: To question or hold questionable; to withhold assent to; to hesitate to believe, or to be inclined not to believe; to withhold confidence from; to distrust; as, I have heard the story, but I doubt the truth of it.
sn.q: To admire superior sense, and doubt their own!
I doubt not that however changed, you keep So much of what is graceful.

sn.def: To suspect; to fear; to be apprehensive of.
sn.q: Edmond [was a] good man and doubted God.
I doubt some foul play.
That I of doubted danger had no fear.

sn.def: To fill with fear; to affright.
sn.q: The virtues of the valiant Caratach More doubt me than all Britain.

cs.cd: undoubtedly; without doubt.
beyond doubt.

entry.ety: OE. dute doute, F. doute, fr. douter to doubt. See Doubt v. i.

sn.def: A fluctuation of mind arising from defect of knowledge or evidence; uncertainty of judgment or mind; unsettled state of opinion concerning the reality of an event, or the truth of an assertion, etc.; hesitation.
sn.q: Doubt is the beginning and the end of our efforts to know.

Doubt, in order to be operative in requiring an acquittal, is not the want of perfect certainty (which can never exist in any question of fact) but a defect of proof preventing a reasonable assurance of quilt.

sn.def: Uncertainty of condition.
sn.q: Thy life shall hang in doubt before thee.

sn.def: Suspicion; fear; apprehension; dread.
sn.q: I stand in doubt of you.
Nor slack her threatful hand for danger's doubt.

sn.def: Difficulty expressed or urged for solution; point unsettled; objection.
sn.q: To every doubt your answer is the same.
sn.syn: Uncertainty; hesitation; suspense; indecision; irresolution; distrust; suspicion; scruple; perplexity; ambiguity; skepticism.

entry.ety: OF. doutable, L. dubitabilis, from dubitare. Cf. Dubitable

sn.def: Capable of being doubted; questionable.
Worthy of being feared; redoubtable.

entry.ety: OF. doutance. Cf. Dubitancy
entry.def: State of being in doubt; uncertainty; doubt.
