The company assembled in such a room; also, a reception of company in it; as, to hold a drawing-room .
sn.q: He [Johnson] would amaze a drawing-room by suddenly ejaculating a clause of the Lord's Prayer.

entry.def: see drawing knife.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Drawled; p. pr. & vb. n. Drawling
entry.ety: Prob. fr. draw: cf. D. dralen to linger, tarry, Icel. dralla to loiter. See Draw, and cf. Draggle
entry.def: To utter in a slow, lengthened tone.
To speak with slow and lingering utterance, from laziness, lack of spirit, affectation, etc.
entry.q: Theologians and moralists . . . talk mostly in a drawling and dreaming way about it.

entry.def: A lengthened, slow monotonous utterance.
A housebreaker or thief.
The act of speaking with a drawl; a drawl.
Same as Drawbar.

sn.def: A kind of loom used in weaving figured patterns; -- called also drawboy.
A species of damask made on the drawloom.

cs.cd: butter melter and prepared to be used as a sort of gravy.
an eviscerated fowl.
one in which neither party wins; one equally contested.
one driven from cover.
ornamental work made by drawing out threads from fine cloth, and uniting the cross threads, to form a pattern.

entry.def: See Draw v. t. & i.
A net for catching the larger sorts of birds; also, a dragnet.
ornamental needlework done by drawing threads to form lacelike patterns.
A hardened steel plate having a hole, or a gradation of conical holes, through which wires are drawn to be reduced and elongated.
A rod which unites the drawgear at opposite ends of the car, and bears the pull required to draw the train.
See Drawing knife.
The spring to which a drawbar is attached.
A squirrel's nest.

cs.cd: a dray.
a heavy, strong horse used in drawing a dray.

entry.ety: AS. dræge a dragnet, fr. dragan. ����. See Draw, and cf. 2d Drag, 1st Dredge

sn.def: A strong low cart or carriage used for heavy burdens.
A kind of sledge or sled.
Use of a dray.
The charge, or sum paid, for the use of a dray.

entries.entry: Dray"man n.; pl.Draymen. A man who attends a dray.

entry.ety: Cf. Dross Drossel
entry.def: A slut; a vagabond wench. Same as Drossel.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Dreaded; p. pr. & vb. n. Dreading
entry.ety: AS. drǣdan, in comp.; akin to OS. drādan, OHG. trātan, both only in comp
entry.def: To fear in a great degree; to regard, or look forward to, with terrific apprehension.
entry.q: When at length the moment dreaded through so many years came close, the dark cloud passed away from Johnson's mind.

entry.def: To be in dread, or great fear.
entry.q: Dread not, neither be afraid of them.

sn.def: Great fear in view of impending evil; fearful apprehension of danger; anticipatory terror.
sn.q: The secret dread of divine displeasure.
The dread of something after death.

sn.def: Reverential or respectful fear; awe.
sn.q: The fear of you, and the dread of you, shall be upon every beast of the earth.
His scepter shows the force of temporal power, The attribute to awe and majesty, Wherein doth sit the dread and fear of kings.

sn.def: An object of terrified apprehension.
A person highly revered.
sn.q: Una, his deardread.

sn.def: Fury; dreadfulness.
Doubt; as, out of dread .
sn.syn: Awe; fear; affright; terror; horror; dismay; apprehension. See Reverence.

sn.def: Exciting great fear or apprehension; causing terror; frightful; dreadful.
sn.q: A dread eternity! how surely mine.

sn.def: Inspiring with reverential fear; awful' venerable; as, dread sovereign; dread majesty; dread tribunal.

entry.def: Worthy of being dreaded.
Armed with dreaded bolts.
entry.q: Dread-boltedthunder.

entry.def: One who fears, or lives in fear.

sn.def: Full of dread or terror; fearful.
sn.q: Withdreadfulheart.

sn.def: Inspiring dread; impressing great fear; fearful; terrible; as, a dreadful storm.
sn.q: Dreadfulgloom.
For all things are less dreadful than they seem.

sn.def: Inspiring awe or reverence; awful.
sn.q: God'sdreadfullaw.
sn.syn: Fearful; frightful; terrific; terrible; horrible; horrid; formidable; tremendous; awful; venerable. See Frightful.

entry.def: In a dreadful manner; terribly.
The quality of being dreadful.
With dread.

sn.def: Free from dread; fearless; intrepid; dauntless; as, dreadless heart.
sn.q: Thedreadlessangel.

sn.def: Exempt from danger which causes dread; secure.
sn.q: safe in hisdreadlessden.

entry.def: Without doubt.
Freedom from dread.
Dreadful.
entry.q: Dreadlyspectacle.
entry.def2: adv. With dread. Obs “Dreadly to shake.” Sylvester (Du Bartas).

sn.def: A fearless person.
Hence: A garment made of very thick cloth, that can defend against storm and cold; also, the cloth itself; fearnaught.
A dreadnought, in either sense.

A British battleship, completed in 1906 -- 1907, having an armament consisting of ten 12-inch guns mounted in turrets, and of twenty-four 12-pound quick-fire guns for protection against torpedo boats. This was the first battleship of the type characterized by a main armament of big guns all of the same caliber. She had a displacement of 17,900 tons at load draft, and a speed of 21 knots per hour.

Any battleship having its main armament entirely of big guns all of one caliber. Since the Dreadnought was built, the caliber of the heaviest guns has increased from 12 in. to 131/2 in., 14 in., and 15 in., and the displacement of the largest batteships from 18,000 tons to 30,000 tons and upwards. The term superdreadnought is popularly applied to battleships with such increased displacement and gun caliber.

entry.ety: Akin to OS. drōm, D. droom, G. traum, Icel. draumr, Dan. & Sw. dröm; cf. G. trügen to deceive, Skr. druh to harm, hurt, try to hurt. AS. dreám joy, gladness, and OS. drōm joy are, perh., different words; cf. Gr. qry^los noise

sn.def: The thoughts, or series of thoughts, or imaginary transactions, which occupy the mind during sleep; a sleeping vision.
sn.q: Dreams are but interludes which fancy makes.
I had a dream which was not all a dream.

sn.def: A visionary scheme; a wild conceit; an idle fancy; a vagary; a revery; -- in this sense, applied to an imaginary or anticipated state of happiness; as, a dream of bliss; the dream of his youth.
sn.q: There sober thought pursued the amusing theme, Till Fancy colored it and formed a dream.
It is not them a mere dream, but a very real aim which they propose.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Dreamed drēmd or Dreamtdrĕmt); p. pr. & vb. n. Dreaming
entry.ety: Cf. AS. drēman drȳman, to rejoice. See Dream n.

sn.def: To have ideas or images in the mind while in the state of sleep; to experience sleeping visions; -- often with of; as, to dream of a battle, or of an absent friend.

entry.sn: To let the mind run on in idle revery or vagary; to anticipate vaguely as a coming and happy reality; to have a visionary notion or idea; to imagine. Here may we sit and dream Over the heavenly theme. Keble. They dream on in a constant course of reading, but not digesting. Locke.

entries.entry:
Dream
To dream away To dream out To dream through, etc. to pass in revery or inaction; to spend in idle vagaries; as, to dream away an hour; to dream through life. “ Why does Antony dream out his hours?” Dryden.
v. t. To have a dream of; to see, or have a vision of, in sleep, or in idle fancy; -- often followed by an objective clause. Your old men shall dream dreams. Acts ii. 17. At length in sleep their bodies they compose, And dreamt the future fight. Dryden. And still they dream that they shall still succeed. Cowper.

sn.def: One who dreams.
A visionary; one lost in wild imaginations or vain schemes of some anticipated good; as, a political dreamer .

entry.def: Full of dreams.
entry.q: Dreamfulease.

entry.def: As if in a dream; softly; slowly; languidly.
The state of being dreamy.
In a dreamy manner.
An unreal, delightful country such as in sometimes pictured in dreams; region of fancies; fairyland.
entry.q: He] builds a bridge from dreamland for his lay.

entry.def: Free from, or without, dreams.
resembling a dream; vague or fantastic; as, night invested the lake with a dreamlike quality.
A pleasing country existing only in dreams or imagination; a fantasy land.

sn.def: Abounding in dreams or given to dreaming; appropriate to, or like, dreams; visionary.
sn.q: Thedreamydells.

sn.def: soothing; restful; as, dreamy music.
Like what one dreams of; wonderful; delightful; marvelous; ideal; as, a dreamy house and garden.
Prone to indulge in fantasy or daydreaming; as, a dreamy young girl.

entry.ety: See Dreary
entry.def: Dismal; gloomy with solitude.
entry.q: Adrearand dying sound.

entry.def: Sadness; dismalness.
Affliction; dreariness.
Gloomily; dismally.
Dreariness.

sn.def: Sorrow; wretchedness.
Dismalness; gloomy solitude.

entry.def: Sorrow.
Very dreary.

entry.ety: OE. dreori dreri, AS. dreórig, sad; akin to G. traurig, and prob. to AS. dreósan to fall, Goth. driusan. Cf. Dross Drear Drizzle Drowse

sn.def: Sorrowful; distressful.
sn.q: Drearyshrieks.

sn.def: Exciting cheerless sensations, feelings, or associations; comfortless; dismal; gloomy.
sn.q: Drearyshades.
Thedrearyground.
Full many a dreary anxious hour.
Johnson entered on his vocation in the most dreary part of that dreary interval which separated two ages of prosperity.

entry.ety: AS. dreccan dreccean

sn.def: To vex; to torment; to trouble.
sn.q: As man that in his dream is drecched sore.

entry.def: To delay.

entry.ety: F. drège dreige, fish net, from a word akin to E. draw; cf. D. dreg dregge, small anchor, dregnet dragnet. √73. See Draw

sn.def: Any instrument used to gather or take by dragging; as: A dragnet for taking up oysters, etc., from their beds. A dredging machine. An iron frame, with a fine net attached, used in collecting animals living at the bottom of the sea.
Very fine mineral matter held in suspension in water.

cs.cd: a machine (commonly on a boat) used to scoop up mud, gravel, or obstructions from the bottom of rivers, docks, etc., so as to deepen them.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Dredged drĕjd; p. pr. & vb. n. Dredging
entry.def: To catch or gather with a dredge; to deepen with a dredging machine.

entry.ety: OE. dragge, F. dragée, dredge, also, sugar plum; cf. Prov. dragea, It. treggea; corrupted fr. LL. tragemata, pl., sweetmeats, Gr. tragh`mata, fr. trw`gein to gnaw
entry.def: A mixture of oats and barley.

entry.cs: Dredging box. Same as 2d Dredger. Gun A copper box with a perforated lid; -- used for sprinkling meal powder over shell fuses. Farrow.
entry.def: To sift or sprinkle flour, etc., on, as on roasting meat.

sn.def: One who fishes with a dredge.
A dredging machine.

entry.def: A box with holes in its lid; -- used for sprinkling flour, as on meat or a breadboard; -- called also dredging box drudger, and drudging box.

entry.ety: AS. dreógan to bear, endure, complete
entry.def: To endure; to suffer.
To be able to do or endure.
Wearisome; tedious.

entry.note: ☞ Used formerly (rarely) in the singular, as by Spenser and Shakespeare, but now chiefly in the plural.
entry.ety: Prob. from Icel. dregg; akin to Sw. drägg, cf. Icel. & Sw. draga to draw. Cf. Draw
entry.def: Corrupt or defiling matter contained in a liquid, or precipitated from it; refuse; feculence; lees; grounds; sediment; hence, the vilest and most worthless part of anything; as, the dregs of society.
entry.q: We, the dregs and rubbish of mankind.

entry.def: Fullness of dregs or lees; foulness; feculence.
Foul with lees; feculent.
Containing dregs or lees; muddy; foul; feculent.

entry.ety: G., fr. drei three + bund league
entry.def: A triple alliance; specif., the alliance of Germany, Austria, and Italy, formed in 1882.

sn.def: a toy shaped somewhat like a top, but having four flat sides, each marked with one of the Hebrew letters nun gimel he, or shin. It is spun like a top, and the letter showing when it stops spinning determines the outcome of a game of chance.
a game of chance played with a dreidel{1}, most commonly by children at Hannukah.

entry.def: To drain.
p. p. of Drench to drown.

entry.ety: NL. Named after Dreyssen, a Belgian physician
entry.def: A genus of bivalve shells of which one species (Dreissena polymorpha) is often so abundant as to be very troublesome in the fresh waters of Europe.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Drenched; p. pr. & vb. n. Drenching
entry.ety: AS. drencan to give to drink, to drench, the causal of drincan to drink; akin to D. drenken, Sw. dränka, G. tränken. See Drink

sn.def: To cause to drink; especially, to dose by force; to put a potion down the throat of, as of a horse; hence. to purge violently by physic.
sn.q: As “to fell,” is “to make to fall,” and “to lay,” to make to lie.” so “to drench,” is “to make to drink.”

sn.def: To steep in moisture; to wet thoroughly; to soak; to saturate with water or other liquid; to immerse.
sn.q: Now dam the ditches and the floods restrain; Their moisture has already drenched the plain.

entry.ety: AS. drenc. See Drench v. t.
entry.def: A drink; a draught; specifically, a potion of medicine poured or forced down the throat; also, a potion that causes purging.
entry.q: Adrenchof wine.
Give my roan horse a drench.

entry.ety: AS. dreng warrior, soldier, akin to Icel. drengr
entry.def: A military vassal mentioned in Domesday Book.
To drown.
entry.q: In the sea he drenched.

sn.def: One who, or that which, west or steeps.
One who administers a drench.

entry.def: The tenure by which a drench held land.

entry.ety: See Dreinte
entry.def: Drenched; drowned.
entry.q: Condemned to bedrent.

entries.entry: Dres"den ware`. A superior kind of decorated porcelain made near Dresden in Saxony.

entry.note: ☞ Dress is used reflexively in Old English, in sense of “to direct one's step; to address one's self.”
entry.cs:
To dress uporTo dress out
to dress elaborately, artificially, or pompously. “You see very often a king of England or France dressed up like a Julius Cæsar.” Addison. To dress a ship Naut to ornament her by hoisting the national colors at the peak and mastheads, and setting the jack forward; when dressed full, the signal flags and pennants are added. Ham. Nav. Encyc.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Dressed drĕst or Drest; p. pr. & vb. n. Dressing
entry.ety: OF. drecier to make straight, raise, set up, prepare, arrange, F. dresser, (assumed) LL. directiare, fr. L. dirigere directum, to direct; dis- + regere to rule. See Right, and cf. Address Adroit Direct Dirge

sn.def: To direct; to put right or straight; to regulate; to order.
sn.q: At all times thou shalt bless God and pray Him to dress thy ways.
To Grisild again will I me dresse.

sn.def: To arrange in exact continuity of line, as soldiers; commonly to adjust to a straight line and at proper distance; to align; as, to dress the ranks.
To treat methodically with remedies, bandages, or curative appliances, as a sore, an ulcer, a wound, or a wounded or diseased part.

entry.sn:
To adjust; to put in good order; to arrange; specifically: To prepare for use; to fit for any use; to render suitable for an intended purpose; to get ready; as, to dress a slain animal; to dress meat; to dress leather or cloth; to dress or trim a lamp; to dress a garden; to dress a horse, by currying and rubbing; to dress grain, by cleansing it; in mining and metallurgy, to dress ores, by sorting and separating them.
And the Lord God took the man, and put him into the garden of Eden to dress it. When he dresseth the lamps he shall burn incense. Three hundred horses . . . smoothly dressed.
Dressing their hair with the white sea flower..If he felt obliged to expostulate, he might have dressed his censures in a kinder form.
To cut to proper dimensions, or give proper shape to, as to a tool by hammering; also, to smooth or finish.
To put in proper condition by appareling, as the body; to put clothes upon; to apparel; to invest with garments or rich decorations; to clothe; to deck.
Dressed myself in such humility. Prove that ever Idress myself handsome till thy return.
To break and train for use, as a horse or other animal. To attire; apparel; clothe; accouter; array; robe; rig; trim; deck; adorn; embellish.

cs.cd: to form alignment with reference to the soldier on the extreme right, or in the center, of the rank, who serves as a guide.

sn.def: To arrange one's self in due position in a line of soldiers; -- the word of command to form alignment in ranks; as, Dress right, dress!

entry.sn: To clothe or apparel one's self; to put on one's garments; to pay particular regard to dress; as, to dress quickly. Todressfor a ball. To flaunt, to dress, to dance, to thrum..

cs.cd: a parade in full uniform for review.

sn.def: That which is used as the covering or ornament of the body; clothes; garments; habit; apparel.
sn.q: In your soldier'sdress.

sn.def: A lady's gown; as, silk or a velvet dress .
Attention to apparel, or skill in adjusting it.
sn.q: Men of pleasure, dress, and gallantry.

sn.def: The system of furrows on the face of a millstone.

entry.def: maneuvers of a horse in response to body signals by the rider.

entries.entry: Dress circle. A gallery or balcony in a theater, generally the first above the floor, in which originally dress clothes were customarily worn.

Dress" coat`. A coat with skirts behind only, as distinct from the frock coat, of which the skirts surround the body. It is worn on occasions of ceremony. The dress coat of officers of the United States army is a full-skirted frock coat.

sn.def: same as attired.
sn.syn: appareled, attired, clad, garbed, garmented, habilimented, robed.

sn.def: covered with medication or a bandage ; -- of wounds.
trim and smooth; -- of lumber or stone.

entry.def: attired in strikingly attractive clothing; -- usually of women.

entries.entry: dressed-up adj. attired in fancy or formal clothing.Narrower terms: dressed to kill(predicate dressed to the nines(predicate), dolled up, spruced up, spiffed up.

sn.def: One who dresses; one who put in order or makes ready for use; one who on clothes or ornaments.
A kind of pick for shaping large coal.
An assistant in a hospital, whose office it is to dress wounds, sores, etc.

sn.ety: F. dressoir. See Dress v. t.

sd.def: A table or bench on which meat and other things are dressed, or prepared for use.
A cupboard or set of shelves to receive dishes and cooking utensils.
sd.q: The pewter plates on the dresser Caught and reflected the flame, as shields of armies the sunshine.

entry.ety: F. dressoir. See Dress v. t.
entry.def: A piece of chamber furniture consisting of a chest of drawers, or bureau, with a mirror.

entries.entry: Dress" goods". A term applied to fabrics for the gowns of women and girls; -- most commonly to fabrics of mixed materials, but also applicable to silks, printed linens, and calicoes.

entry.def: The state of being dressy.

cs.cd: a case of toilet utensils.
a variety of forceps, shaped like a pair of scissors, used in dressing wounds.
a light gown, such as is used by a person while dressing; a study gown.
an apartment appropriated for making one's toilet.
manure or compost spread over land and not worked into the soil.

sn.def: Dress; raiment; especially, ornamental habiliment or attire.
An application (a remedy, bandage, etc.) to cover a sore or wound.
Manure or compost over land. When it remains on the surface, it is called a top-dressing.

sd.def: A preparation, such as a sauce, to flavor food for eating; a condiment; as, a dressing for salad.
The stuffing of fowls, pigs, etc.; forcemeat.

sn.def: Gum, starch, and the like, used in stiffening or finishing silk, linen, and other fabrics.
An ornamental finish, as a molding around doors, windows, or on a ceiling, etc.
Castigation; scolding; -- often with down.

entry.def: a table, usually having a vertical back piece containing a mirror, at which a person may sit while dressing or applying makeup, and on which articles for the toilet stand. It often has drawers for toiletries, clothing, or accessories. It is also called a vanity or vanity table.
A maker of gowns, or similar garments; a mantuamaker.
The art, process, or occupation, of making dresses.
Showy in dress; attentive to dress.
entry.q: A dressy flaunting maidservant.
A neat, dressy gentleman in black.

entry.def: of Dress.
See Drecche.
To drool.
A fool; a drudge. See Drivel.
of Draw.
A squirrel's nest. See Dray.
Dry.
p. p., of Drench to drown.

entries.entry:
Drib v. t.
imp. & p. p. Dribbed; p. pr. & vb. n. Dribbing
Cf. Drip
To do by little and little; as: To cut off by a little at a time; to crop. To appropriate unlawfully; to filch; to defalcate. He who drives their bargain dribs a part. To lead along step by step; to entice. With daily lies she dribs thee into cost.

entry.def: To shoot (a shaft) so as to pierce on the descent.

sn.def: A drop.
a small portion or small amount of anything; -- used mostly in the phrase dribs and drabs.

entry.def: One who dribs; one who shoots weakly or badly.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Dribbled; p. pr. & vb. n. Dribbing
entry.ety: Freq. of drib, which is a variant of drip

sn.def: To fall in drops or small drops, or in a quick succession of drops; as, water dribbles from the eaves.
To slaver, as a child or an idiot; to drivel.
To fall weakly and slowly.
sn.q: Thedribblingdart of love.

sn.def: In basketball, football and similar games, to dribble{2} the ball.
To live or pass one's time in a trivial fashion.
To let fall in drops.
sn.q: Let the cook . . . dribble it all the way upstairs.

sn.def: In basketball and various other games, to propel (the ball) by successive slight hits or kicks so as to keep it always in control.
A drizzling shower; a falling or leaking in drops.
An act of dribbling{2} a ball.

entry.def: One who dribbles.

entry.ety: From Dribble
entry.def: A small piece or part; a small sum; a small quantity of money in making up a sum; as, the money was paid in dribblets .
entry.q: When made up in dribblets, as they could, their best securities were at an interest of twelve per cent.

entry.ety: See Dree
entry.def: To endure.
entry.q: So causeless such drede for to drie.

entry.def: imp. & p. p. of Dry. Also adj.; as, dried apples.
thoroughly dried; having no moisture remaining.
wrinkled or cracked from drying.

sn.def: having its water supply exhausted.
One who, or that which, dries; that which may expel or absorb moisture; a desiccative; as, the sun and a northwesterly wind are great driers of the earth.
Drying oil; a substance mingled with the oil used in oil painting to make it dry quickly.

entry.def: of Dry a.

entry.note: ☞ Drift is used also either adjectively or as the first part of a compound. See Drift a.
entry.cs: Drift of the forest O. Eng. Law an examination or view of the cattle in a forest, in order to see whose they are, whether they are commonable, and to determine whether or not the forest is surcharged. Burrill.]continental drift Geology the very slow (ca. 1-5 cm per year) movement of the continents and parts of continents relative to each other and to the points of upwelling of magma in the viscous layers beneath the continents; -- causing, for example, the opening of the South Atlantic Ocean by the movement of Africa and South America away from each other. See also plate tectonics.
entry.ety: From drive; akin to LG. & D. drift a driving, Icel. drift snowdrift, Dan. drift, impulse, drove, herd, pasture, common, G. trift pasturage, drove. See Drive

sn.def: A driving; a violent movement.
sn.q: The dragon drew him [self] away with drift of his wings.

sn.def: The act or motion of drifting; the force which impels or drives; an overpowering influence or impulse.
sn.q: A bad man, being under the drift of any passion, will follow the impulse of it till something interpose.

sn.def: Course or direction along which anything is driven; setting.
sn.q: Ourdriftwas south.

sn.def: The tendency of an act, argument, course of conduct, or the like; object aimed at or intended; intention; hence, also, import or meaning of a sentence or discourse; aim.
sn.q: He has made the drift of the whole poem a compliment on his country in general.
Now thou knowest my drift.

entry.sn:
That which is driven, forced, or urged along; as: Anything driven at random. Some log . . . a uselessdrift. Dryden.
A mass of matter which has been driven or forced onward together in a body, or thrown together in a heap, etc., esp. by wind or water; as, a drift of snow, of ice, of sand, and the like.
Drifts of rising dust involve the sky. We got the brig a good bed in the rushing driftof ice].
A drove or flock, as of cattle, sheep, birds. Obs Cattle coming over the bridge (with their great drift doing much damage to the high ways).

sn.def: The horizontal thrust or pressure of an arch or vault upon the abutments.
A collection of loose earth and rocks, or boulders, which have been distributed over large portions of the earth's surface, especially in latitudes north of forty degrees, by the agency of ice.
In South Africa, a ford in a river.
A slightly tapered tool of steel for enlarging or shaping a hole in metal, by being forced or driven into or through it; a broach.

sd.def: A tool used in driving down compactly the composition contained in a rocket, or like firework.
A deviation from the line of fire, peculiar to oblong projectiles.

sn.def: A passage driven or cut between shaft and shaft; a driftway; a small subterranean gallery; an adit or tunnel.

sd.def: The distance through which a current flows in a given time.
The angle which the line of a ship's motion makes with the meridian, in drifting.
The distance to which a vessel is carried off from her desired course by the wind, currents, or other causes.
The place in a deep-waisted vessel where the sheer is raised and the rail is cut off, and usually terminated with a scroll, or driftpiece.
The distance between the two blocks of a tackle.

sn.def: The difference between the size of a bolt and the hole into which it is driven, or between the circumference of a hoop and that of the mast on which it is to be driven.
One of the slower movements of oceanic circulation; a general tendency of the water, subject to occasional or frequent diversion or reversal by the wind; as, the easterly drift of the North Pacific.
The horizontal component of the pressure of the air on the sustaining surfaces of a flying machine. The lift is the corresponding vertical component, which sustains the machine in the air.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Drifted; p. pr. & vb. n. Drifting

sn.def: To float or be driven along by, or as by, a current of water or air; as, the ship drifted astern; a raft drifted ashore; the balloon drifts slowly east.
sn.q: We drifted o'er the harbor bar.

sn.def: To accumulate in heaps by the force of wind; to be driven into heaps; as, snow or sand drifts .
to make a drift; to examine a vein or ledge for the purpose of ascertaining the presence of metals or ores; to follow a vein; to prospect.
To drive or carry, as currents do a floating body.
To drive into heaps; as, a current of wind drifts snow or sand.
To enlarge or shape, as a hole, with a drift.

entry.cs:
Drift anchor. See Sea anchor, and also Drag sail, under Drag n.
Drift epoch Geol the glacial epoch. Drift net a kind of fishing net. Drift sail. Same as Drag sail. See under Drag n.
entry.def: That causes drifting or that is drifted; movable by wind or currents; as, drift currents; drift ice; drift mud.

sn.def: Deviation from a ship's course due to leeway.
Anything that drifts.

entry.def: A bolt for driving out other bolts.
Having no drift or direction; without aim; purposeless.
An upright or curved piece of timber connecting the plank sheer with the gunwale; also, a scroll terminating a rail.
A smooth drift. See Drift n., 9.

sn.def: A common way, road, or path, for driving cattle.
Same as Drift 11.

entry.def: Seaweed drifted to the shore by the wind.
A driving wind; a wind that drives snow, sand, etc., into heaps.

sn.def: Wood drifted or floated by water.
Fig.: Whatever is drifting or floating as on water.
sn.q: The current of humanity, with its heavy proportion of very useless driftwood.

entry.def: Full of drifts; tending to form drifts, as snow, and the like.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Drilled; p. pr. & vb. n. Drilling
entry.ety: D. drillen to bore, drill (soldiers); probably akin to AS. pyrlian pyrelian, to pierce. See Thrill

sn.def: To pierce or bore with a drill, or a with a drill; to perforate; as, to drill a hole into a rock; to drill a piece of metal.

To train in the military art; to exercise diligently, as soldiers, in military evolutions and exercises; hence, to instruct thoroughly in the rudiments of any art or branch of knowledge; to discipline.
sn.q: He [Frederic the Greatdrilled his people, as he drilled his grenadiers.

entry.def: To practice an exercise or exercises; to train one's self.

entry.cs:
Bow drill Breast drill . See under Bow Breast.
Cotter drillorTraverse drill
a machine tool for drilling slots. Diamond drill. See under Diamond. Drill jig. See under Jig. Drill pin the pin in a lock which enters the hollow stem of the key. Drill sergeant Mil a noncommissioned officer whose office it is to instruct soldiers as to their duties, and to train them to military exercises and evolutions. Vertical drill a drill press.

sn.def: An instrument with an edged or pointed end used for making holes in hard substances; strictly, a tool that cuts with its end, by revolving, as in drilling metals, or by a succession of blows, as in drilling stone; also, a drill press.

The act or exercise of training soldiers in the military art, as in the manual of arms, in the execution of evolutions, and the like; hence, diligent and strict instruction and exercise in the rudiments and methods of any business; a kind or method of military exercises; as, infantry drill; battalion drill; artillery drill.
Any exercise, physical or mental, enforced with regularity and by constant repetition; as, a severe drill in Latin grammar.
A marine gastropod, of several species, which kills oysters and other bivalves by drilling holes through the shell. The most destructive kind is Urosalpinx cinerea.

entry.ety: Cf. Trill to trickle, Trickle Dribble, and W. rhillio to put in a row, drill

sn.def: To cause to flow in drills or rills or by trickling; to drain by trickling; as, waters drilled through a sandy stratum.
To sow, as seeds, by dribbling them along a furrow or in a row, like a trickling rill of water.
To entice; to allure from step; to decoy; -- with on.
sn.q: See drilled him on to five-fifty.

sn.def: To cause to slip or waste away by degrees.
sn.q: This accident hath drilled away the whole summer.

sn.def: To trickle.
To sow in drills.

entry.note: ☞ Drill is used adjectively, or as the first part of a compound; as, drill barrow or drill-barrow; drill husbandry; drill plow or drill-plow.

cs.cd: a wheeled implement for planting seed in drills.
a small bow used for the purpose of rapidly turning a drill around which the bowstring takes a turn.
a harrow used for stirring the ground between rows, or drills.
a sort plow for sowing grain in drills.

sn.def: A small trickling stream; a rill.
sn.q: Springs through the pleasant meadows pour their drills.

sd.def: An implement for making holes for sowing seed, and sometimes so formed as to contain seeds and drop them into the hole made.
A light furrow or channel made to put seed into sowing.
A row of seed sown in a furrow.

entry.ety: Cf. Mandrill
entry.def: A large African baboon (Cynocephalus leucophæus).

cs.cd: a linen fabric having two threads in the warp and three in the filling.

entry.ety: Usually in pl
entry.def: Same as Drilling.
One who, or that which, drills.

sn.def: The act of piercing with a drill.
A training by repeated exercises.

entry.def: The act of using a drill in sowing seeds.

entry.ety: G. drillich, fr. L. trilix having three threads, fr. the of tres three + licium a thread of the warm. See Three, and cf. Twill
entry.def: A heavy, twilled fabric of linen or cotton.
One who teaches drill, especially in the way of gymnastics.

entries.entry: Drill" press` . A machine for drilling holes in metal, the drill being pressed to the metal by the action of a screw.

entry.def: A contrivance for holding and turning a drill.
See Dryly.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. drimy`s sharp, acrid
entry.def: A genus of magnoliaceous trees. Drimys aromatica furnishes Winter's bark.

cs.cd: to salute in drinking; to wish well to, in the act of taking the cup; to pledge in drinking.

entry.vmorph: imp. Drank drăṉk, formerly Drunk drŭṉk; & p. p. Drunk Drunken -'n; p. pr. & vb. n. Drinking. Drunken is now rarely used, except as a verbal adj. in sense of habitually intoxicated; the form drank, not infrequently used as a p. p., is not so analogical
entry.ety: AS. drincan; akin to OS. drinkan, D. drinken, G. trinken, Icel. drekka, Sw. dricka, Dan. drikke, Goth. drigkan. Cf. Drench Drunken Drown

sn.def: To swallow anything liquid, for quenching thirst or other purpose; to imbibe; to receive or partake of, as if in satisfaction of thirst; as, to drink from a spring.
sn.q: Gird thyself, and serve me, till have eaten and drunken; and afterward thou shalt eat and drink.
He shall drink of the wrath the Almighty.
Drink of the cup that can not cloy.

sn.def: To quaff exhilarating or intoxicating liquors, in merriment or feasting; to carouse; to revel; hence, to lake alcoholic liquors to excess; to be intemperate in the �se of intoxicating or spirituous liquors; to tipple.
sn.q: And they drank, and were merry with him.
Bolingbroke always spoke freely when he had drunk freely.
I drink to the general joy of the whole table, And to our dear friend Banquo.

entry.cs:
To drink down to act on by drinking; to reduce or subdue; as, to drink down unkindness. Shak. To drink in to take into one's self by drinking, or as by drinking; to receive and appropriate as in satisfaction of thirst. “Song was the form of literature which he [Burns] had drunk in from his cradle.” J. C. Shairp.
To drink offorTo drink up
to drink completely, especially at one draught; as, to drink off a cup of cordial.
To drink the health oforTo drink to the health of
to drink while expressing good wishes for the health or welfare of.

sn.def: To swallow (a liquid); to receive, as a fluid, into the stomach; to imbibe; as, to drink milk or water.
sn.q: There lies she with the blessed gods in bliss, There drinks the nectar with ambrosia mixed.
The bowl of punch which was brewed and drunk in Mrs. Betty's room.

sn.def: To take in (a liquid), in any manner; to suck up; to absorb; to imbibe.
sn.q: And let the purple violets drink the stream.

sn.def: To take in; to receive within one, through the senses; to inhale; to hear; to see.
sn.q: To drink the cooler air,
My ears have not yet drunk a hundred words Of that tongue's utterance.
Let me . . . drink delicious poison from thy eye.

sn.def: To smoke, as tobacco.
sn.q: And some men now live ninety years and past, Who never drank to tobacco first nor last.

entry.cs:
Drink moneyorDrink penny
an allowance, or perquisite, given to buy drink; a gratuity. Drink offering Script an offering of wine, etc., in the Jewish religious service. In drink drunk. “The poor monster's in drink.” Shak. Strong drink intoxicating liquor; esp., liquor containing a large proportion of alcohol. “ Wine is a mocker, strong drink is raging.” Prov. xx. 1.

sn.def: Liquid to be swallowed; any fluid to be taken into the stomach for quenching thirst or for other purposes, as water, coffee, or decoctions.
sn.q: Give me some drink, Titinius.

sn.def: Specifically, intoxicating liquor; as, when drink is on, wit is out.

entry.def: Capable of being drunk; suitable for drink; potable. Macaulay. Also used substantively, esp. in the plural.
State of being drinkable.

cs.cd: a large British moth (Odonestis potatoria).

entry.def: One who drinks; as, the effects of tea on the drinker ; also, one who drinks spirituous liquors to excess; a drunkard.

entry.note: ☞ Drinking is used adjectively, or as the first part of a compound; as, a drinking song, drinking cup, drinking glass, drinking house, etc.

cs.cd: a drinking vessel made of a horn.

sn.def: The act of one who drinks; the act of imbibing.
The practice of partaking to excess of intoxicating liquors.
An entertainment with liquors; a carousal.

entry.def: Destitute of drink.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Dripped or Dript; p. pr. & vb. n. Dripping
entry.ety: Akin to LG. drippen, Dan. dryppe, from a noun. See Drop

sn.def: To fall in drops; as, water drips from the eaves.
To let fall drops of moisture or liquid; as, a wet garment drips .
sn.q: The dark round of the dripping wheel.

entry.def: To let fall in drops.
entry.q: Which from the thatch drips fast a shower of rain.

cs.cd: an easement or servitude by which a man has the right to have the water flowing from his house fall on the land of his neighbor.

sn.def: A falling or letting fall in drops; a dripping; that which drips, or falls in drops.
sn.q: The light drip of the suspended oar.

sn.def: That part of a cornice, sill course, or other horizontal member, which projects beyond the rest, and is of such section as to throw off the rain water.
treated so as to be easily or quickly washed and dried and requiring little or no ironing; -- of clothing.
requiring no ironing; -- used of fabrics and clothing; as, drip-dry shirts for travel.

cs.cd: a pan for receiving the fat which drips from meat in roasting.

sn.def: A falling in drops, or the sound so made.
That which falls in drops, as fat from meat in roasting.

entry.ety: From Drip, cf. Dribble
entry.def: Weak or rare.
persistently dripping even when shut; as, a drippy faucet.
A drip, when made of stone. See Drip, 2.

entry.vmorph: imp. Drove drōv, formerly Dravedrāv); p. p. Driven drĭv'n; p. pr. & vb. n. Driving
entry.ety: AS. drīfan; akin to OS. drīban, D. drijven, OHG. trīban, G. treiben, Icel. drīfa, Goth. dreiban. Cf. Drift Drove

sn.def: To impel or urge onward by force in a direction away from one, or along before one; to push forward; to compel to move on; to communicate motion to; as, to drive cattle; to drive a nail; smoke drives persons from a room.
sn.q: A storm came on and drove them into Pylos.
Shield pressed on shield, and man drove man along.
Go drive the deer and drag the finny prey.

sn.def: To urge on and direct the motions of, as the beasts which draw a vehicle, or the vehicle borne by them; hence, also, to take in a carriage; to convey in a vehicle drawn by beasts; as, to drive a pair of horses or a stage; to drive a person to his own door.
sn.q: How . . . proud he was to drive such a brother!

sn.def: To urge, impel, or hurry forward; to force; to constrain; to urge, press, or bring to a point or state; as, to drive a person by necessity, by persuasion, by force of circumstances, by argument, and the like.
sn.q: Enough todriveone mad.
He, driven to dismount, threatened, if I did not do the like, to do as much for my horse as fortune had done for his.

sn.def: To carry or; to keep in motion; to conduct; to prosecute.
sn.q: The trade of life can not be driven without partners.

sn.def: To clear, by forcing away what is contained.
sn.q: To drive the country, force the swains away.

sn.def: To dig Horizontally; to cut a horizontal gallery or tunnel.
To pass away; -- said of time.
Specif., in various games, as tennis, baseball, etc., to propel (the ball) swiftly by a direct stroke or forcible throw.
to operate (a vehicle) while it is on motion, by manipulating the controls, such as the steering, propulsion, and braking mechanisms.

entry.note: ☞ Drive, in all its senses, implies forcible or violent action. It is the reverse of to lead. To drive a body is to move it by applying a force behind; to lead is to cause to move by applying the force before, or in front. It takes a variety of meanings, according to the objects by which it is followed; as, to drive an engine, to direct and regulate its motions; to drive logs, to keep them in the current of a river and direct them in their course; to drive feathers or down, to place them in a machine, which, by a current of air, drives off the lightest to one end, and collects them by themselves. “My thrice-driven bed of down.”

sn.def: In various games, as tennis, cricket, etc., the act of player who drives the ball; the stroke or blow; the flight of the ball, etc., so driven.
A stroke from the tee, generally a full shot made with a driver; also, the distance covered by such a stroke.

entry.cs: To let drive to aim a blow; to strike with force; to attack. “Four rogues in buckram let drive at me.” Shak.

sn.def: To rush and press with violence; to move furiously.
sn.q: Fierce Boreas drove against his flying sails.
Under cover of the night and a driving tempest.
Time driveth onward fast, And in a little while our lips are dumb.

sn.def: To be forced along; to be impelled; to be moved by any physical force or agent; to be driven.
sn.q: The hull drives on, though mast and sail be torn.
The chaise drives to Mr. Draper's chambers.

sn.def: To go by carriage; to pass in a carriage; to proceed by directing or urging on a vehicle or the animals that draw it; as, the coachman drove to my door.
To press forward; to aim, or tend, to a point; to make an effort; to strive; -- usually with at.
sn.q: Let them therefore declare what carnal or secular interest he drove at.

sn.def: To distrain for rent.
To make a drive, or stroke from the tee.
to go from one place to another in a vehicle, serving as the operator of the vehicle; to drive{9} a vehicle from one location to another.
sn.illu: He drove from New York to Boston in four hours.

entry.def: Driven.

sn.def: The act of driving; a trip or an excursion in a carriage, as for exercise or pleasure; -- distinguished from a ride taken on horseback.
A place suitable or agreeable for driving; a road prepared for driving.
Violent or rapid motion; a rushing onward or away; esp., a forced or hurried dispatch of business.
sn.q: The Murdstonian drive in business.

sn.def: In type founding and forging, an impression or matrix, formed by a punch drift.
A collection of objects that are driven; a mass of logs to be floated down a river.
a private road; a driveway.
a strong psychological motivation to perform some activity.
a device for reading or writing data from or to a data storage medium, as a disk drive, a tape drive, a CD drive, etc.
an organized effort by a group to accomplish a goal within a limited period of time; as, a fund-raising drive .
a physiological function of an organism motivating it to perform specific behaviors; as, the sex drive .
the period during which one team sustains movement of the ball toward the opponent's goal without losing possession of the ball; as, a long drive downfield.
an act of driving a vehicle, especially an automobile; the journey undertaken by driving an automobile; as, to go for a drive in the country.
the mechanism which causes the moving parts of a machine to move; as, a belt drive .
the way in which the propulsive force of a vehicle is transmitted to the road; as, a car with four-wheel drive, front-wheel drive, etc.

entry.def: A drift; a tool for setting bolts home.
accomplished while driving past in a vehicle; as, a drive-by shooting.
any installation designed to accommodate patrons while staying in their automobiles; especially an outdoor movie theater in which patrons park in their vehicles to watch the movie.
arranged to allow business to be transacted while patrons remain in their vehicles; as, a drive-in window at a bank.

a window at a business establishment, such as a bank or restaurant, where patrons may transact business or order goods while staying in their automobiles; as, to cash a check at the drive-in window of the bank.
a rotating shaft that transmits power from the engine to the point of application.
arranged to allow business to be transacted or sights to be seen while patrons remain in their vehicles; as, a drive-through car wash; a drive-through safari park.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Driveled or Drivelled; p. pr. & vb. n. Driveling or Drivelling
entry.ety: Cf. OE. dravelen drabelen drevelen drivelen, to slaver, and E. drabble. Cf. Drool

sn.def: To slaver; to let spittle drop or flow from the mouth, like a child, idiot, or dotard.

sn.ety: Perh. a different word: cf. Icel. drafa to talk thick
sn.def: To be weak or foolish; to dote; as, a driveling hero; driveling love.
Slaver; saliva flowing from the mouth.
Inarticulate or unmeaning utterance; foolish talk; babble.
A driveler; a fool; an idiot.
A servant; a drudge.

entry.def: A slaverer; a slabberer; an idiot; a fool.

cs.cd: a well made by driving a tube into the earth to an aqueous stratum; -- called also drive well.

entry.def: of Drive. Also adj.
A pipe for forcing into the earth.

cs.cd: a species of African stinging ant; one of the visiting ants (Anomma arcens); -- so called because they move about in vast armies, and drive away or devour all insects and other small animals.

entry.ety: From Drive

sn.def: One who, or that which, drives; the person or thing that urges or compels anything else to move onward.
The person who drives beasts or a carriage; a coachman; a charioteer, etc.; hence, also, one who controls the movements of a any vehicle.
An overseer of a gang of slaves or gang of convicts at their work.

A part that transmits motion to another part by contact with it, or through an intermediate relatively movable part, as a gear which drives another, or a lever which moves another through a link, etc. Specifically:

sd.def: The driving wheel of a locomotive.
An attachment to a lathe, spindle, or face plate to turn a carrier.
A crossbar on a grinding mill spindle to drive the upper stone.

sn.def: The after sail in a ship or bark, being a fore-and-aft sail attached to a gaff; a spanker.

entry.sn:
An implement used for driving; as: A mallet.
A tamping iron.
A cooper's hammer for driving on barrel hoops.
A wooden-headed golf club with a long shaft, for playing the longest strokes.

entry.def: A passage or way along or through which a carriage may be driven.

cs.cd: the axle of a driving wheel, as in a locomotive.
the journal box of a driving axle. See Illust. of Locomotive.
a syncopated note; a tone begun on a weak part of a measure and held through the next accented part, thus anticipating the accent and driving it through.
a spring fixed upon the box of the driving axle of a locomotive engine to support the weight and deaden shocks.
a wheel that communicates motion; one of the large wheels of a locomotive to which the connecting rods of the engine are attached; -- called also, simply, driver. See Illust. of Locomotive.

sn.def: Having great force of impulse; as, a driving wind or storm.
Communicating force; impelling; as, a driving shaft.
The act of forcing or urging something along; the act of pressing or moving on furiously.
Tendency; drift.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Drizzled; p. pr. & vb. n. Drizzling
entry.ety: Prop. freq. of AS. dreósan to fall. See Dreary
entry.def: To rain slightly in very small drops; to fall, as water from the clouds, slowly and in fine particles; as, it drizzles; drizzling drops or rain.
entry.q: Drizzlingtears.

entry.def: To shed slowly in minute drops or particles.
entry.q: The air dothdrizzledew.

entry.def: A fine rain or mist.
raining lightly in a fine mist.
Characterized by small rain, or snow; moist and disagreeable.
entry.q: Winter'sdrizzlyreign.

entry.def: A water course.

entry.ety: See Drove
entry.def: An ancient yearly payment made by some tenants to the king, or to their landlords, for the privilege of driving their cattle through a manor to fairs or markets.

entry.ety: Cf. Drag
entry.def: A small craft used in the West India Islands to take off sugars, rum, etc., to the merchantmen; also, a vessel for transporting lumber, cotton, etc., coastwise; as, a lumber drogher .
See Dragoman.

sn.def: See Drag n., 6, and Drag sail, under Drag n.
a small parachute dragged behind a vehicle as a means of stabilizing it, or deployed first so as to assist opening of a larger parachute.

a funnel-shaped attachment at the end of a hose suspended from a tanker airplane in flight, to which the probe of another airplane may connect, so as to complete a connecting hose line through which fuel may be transferred from the tanker to the following airplane. It is used for in-flight refueling.

entry.def: of Draw.

entry.ety: D. druilen to mope
entry.def: To work sluggishly or slowly; to plod.

entry.ety: D. druil sluggard. Cf. Droll

sn.def: A drudge.
Mean labor; toil.

entry.cs: ‖Droit d'aubaine. See under Aubaine. Droits of the Admiralty Eng. Law rights or perquisites of the Admiralty, arising from seizure of an enemy's ships in port on the breaking out of war, or those coming into port in ignorance of hostilities existing, or from such ships as are taken by noncommissioned captors; also, the proceeds of wrecks, and derelict property at sea. The droits of admiralty are now paid into the Exchequer for the public benefit.
entry.ety: F. See Direct
entry.def: A right; law in its aspect of the foundation of rights; also, in old law, the writ of right.
relating to the mere right of property, as distinguished from the right of possession; as, droitural actions.
See Drosky.

entry.ety: F. drôle; cf. G. & D. drollig, LG. drullig, D. drol a thick and short person, a droll, Sw. troll a magical appearance, demon, trolla to use magic arts, enchant, Dan. trold elf, imp, Icel. tröll giant, magician, evil spirit, monster. If this is the origin, cf. Trull
entry.def: Queer, and fitted to provoke laughter; ludicrous from oddity; amusing and strange.
entry.syn: Comic; comical; farcical; diverting; humorous; ridiculous; queer; odd; waggish; facetious; merry; laughable; ludicrous.Droll Laughable Comical. Laughable is the generic term, denoting anything exciting laughter or worthy of laughter; comical denotes something of the kind exhibited in comedies, something humorous of the kind exhibited in comedies, something, as it were, dramatically humorous; droll stands lower on the scale, having reference to persons or things which excite laughter by their buffoonery or oddity. A laughable incident; a comical adventure; a droll story.

sn.def: One whose practice it is to raise mirth by odd tricks; a jester; a buffoon; a merry-andrew.
Something exhibited to raise mirth or sport, as a puppet, a farce, and the like.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Drolled; p. pr. & vb. n. Drolling
entry.def: To jest; to play the buffoon.

sn.def: To lead or influence by jest or trick; to banter or jest; to cajole.
sn.q: Men that will not be reasoned into their senses, may yet be laughed or drolled into them.

sn.def: To make a jest of; to set in a comical light.
sn.q: This drolling everything is rather fatiguing.

entry.def: A jester; a droll.

entries.entry:
Droll"er*y n.; pl.Drolleries #. F. drôlerie. See Droll
The quality of being droll; sportive tricks; buffoonery; droll stories; comical gestures or manners. The rich drollery of “She Stoops to Conquer.”
Something which serves to raise mirth; as: A puppet show; also, a puppet. Obs Shak.
A lively or comic picture. Obs I bought an excellent drollery, which I afterward parted with to my brother George of Wotton.

entry.def: In a jesting manner.
Somewhat droll.
A droll.

entry.ety: NL. dromaius emu + Gr. gna`qos jaw
entry.def: Having the structure of the palate like that of the ostrich and emu.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. droma`s running + qhri`on beast. See Dromedary
entry.def: A small extinct triassic mammal from North Carolina, the earliest yet found in America.

entry.ety: F., fr. Gr. droma`s running. See Dromedary
entry.def: The crab plover (Dromas ardeola), a peculiar North African bird, allied to the oyster catcher.
Short for Aërodrome.

entries.entry: Drom"e*da*ry ☞ In Arabia and Egypt the name is restricted to the better breeds of this species of camel. See Deloul. drŭm"�*d�*r� n.; pl.Dromedaries -rĭz. F. dromadaire, LL. dromedarius, fr. L. dromassc. camelus), fr. Gr. droma`s running, from dramei^n, used as aor. of tre`chein to run; cf. Skr. dram to run Zoöl The Arabian camel (Camelus dromedarius), having one hump or protuberance on the back, in distinction from the Bactrian camel, which has two humps.

Drom"ondorDrom"on . OF. dromont, L. dromo, fr. Gr. dro`mwn light vessel, prob. fr. dramei^n to run. See Dromedary
In the Middle Ages, a large, fast-sailing galley, or cutter; a large, swift war vessel. Hist. or Archaic The great dromond swinging from the quay.

entry.ety: OE. drane a dronebee, AS. drān; akin to OS. drān, OHG. treno, G. drohne, Dan. drone, cf. Gr. � a kind of wasp, dial. Gr. � drone. Prob. named fr. the droning sound. See Drone v. i.

sn.def: The male of bees, esp. of the honeybee. It gathers no honey. See Honeybee.
sn.q: All with united force combine to drive The lazy drones from the laborious hive.

sn.def: One who lives on the labors of others; a lazy, idle fellow; a sluggard.
sn.q: By living as a drone,to be an unprofitable and unworthy member of so noble and learned a society.

sn.def: That which gives out a grave or monotonous tone or dull sound; as: A drum. Obs Halliwell. The part of the bagpipe containing the two lowest tubes, which always sound the key note and the fifth.
A humming or deep murmuring sound.
sn.q: The monotonous drone of the wheel.

sn.def: A monotonous bass, as in a pastoral composition.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Droned; p. pr. & vb. n. Droning
entry.ety: Cf. (for sense 1) D. dreunen, G. dröhnen, Icel. drynja to roar, drynr a roaring, Sw. dröna to bellow, drone, Dan. dröne, Goth. drunjus sound, Gr. � dirge, � to cry aloud, Skr. dhran to sound. Cf. Drone n.

sn.def: To utter or make a low, dull, monotonous, humming or murmuring sound.
sn.q: Where the beetle wheels his droning flight.

sn.def: To love in idleness; to do nothing.
sn.q: Race ofdroningkings.

entries.entry: Drone" bee`. Zoöl The male of the honeybee; a drone.
Drone" fly`. Zoöl A dipterous insect (Eristalis tenax), resembling the drone bee. See Eristalis.

entry.def: One of the low-toned tubes of a bagpipe.

entries.entry: Dron"go n.; pl.Drongos. Zoöl A passerine bird of the family Dicruridæ. They are usually black with a deeply forked tail. They are natives of Asia, Africa, and Australia; -- called also drongo shrikes.

entry.def: Like a drone; indolent; slow.

entry.ety: See Drink
entry.def: Given to drink; drunken.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: The dodo.
Like a drone; sluggish; lazy.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Drooled; p. pr. & vb. n. Drooling
entry.ety: Contr. fr. drivel
entry.def: To drivel, or drop saliva; as, the child drools .
entry.q: His mouth drooling with texts.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Drooped; p. pr. & vb. n. Drooping
entry.ety: Icel. drūpa; akin to E. drop. See Drop

sn.def: To hang bending downward; to sink or hang down, as an animal, plant, etc., from physical inability or exhaustion, want of nourishment, or the like.
sn.q: The purple flowersdroop.
Above herdroopeda lamp.
I saw him ten days before he died, and observed he began very much to droop and languish.

sn.def: To grow weak or faint with disappointment, grief, or like causes; to be dispirited or depressed; to languish; as, her spirits drooped .
sn.q: I'll animate the soldier's drooping courage.

sn.def: To proceed downward, or toward a close; to decline.
sn.q: Then daydrooped.

entry.def: To let droop or sink.
entry.q: Like to a withered vine That droops his sapless branches to the ground.

entry.def: A drooping; as, a droop of the eye.
One who, or that which, droops.
In a drooping manner.
bending downward due to lack of tautness; -- of lines.

entry.cs: Ague drop Black drop . See under Ague Black. Drop by drop in small successive quantities; in repeated portions. “Made to taste drop by drop more than the bitterness of death.” Burke. Drop curtain. See Drop n., 4. . Drop forging. Mech A forging made in dies by a drop hammer. The process of making drop forgings. Drop hammer Mech a hammer for forging, striking up metal, etc., the weight being raised by a strap or similar device, and then released to drop on the metal resting on an anvil or die. Drop kick Football a kick given to the ball as it rebounds after having been dropped from the hands. Drop lake a pigment obtained from Brazil wood. Mollett. Drop letter a letter to be delivered from the same office where posted. Drop press Mech a drop hammer; sometimes, a dead-stroke hammer; -- also called drop. Drop scene a drop curtain on which a scene is painted. See Drop n., 4. . Drop seed. Bot See the List under Glass. Drop serene. Med See Amaurosis.
entry.ety: OE. drope, AS. dropa; akin to OS. dropo, D. drop, OHG. tropo, G. tropfen, Icel. dropi, Sw. droppe; and Fr. AS. dreópan to drip, drop; akin to OS. driopan, D. druipen, OHG. triofan, G. triefen, Icel. drjūpa. Cf. Drip Droop

sn.def: The quantity of fluid which falls in one small spherical mass; a liquid globule; a minim; hence, also, the smallest easily measured portion of a fluid; a small quantity; as, a drop of water.
sn.q: With minute drops from off the eaves.
As dear to me as are the ruddy drops That visit my sad heart.
That drop of peace divine.

sn.def: That which resembles, or that which hangs like, a liquid drop; as a hanging diamond ornament, an earring, a glass pendant on a chandelier, a sugarplum (sometimes medicated), or a kind of shot or slug.

sd.def: Same as Gutta.
Any small pendent ornament.

entry.sn:
Whatever is arranged to drop, hang, or fall from an elevated position; also, a contrivance for lowering something; as: A door or platform opening downward; a trap door; that part of the gallows on which a culprit stands when he is to be hanged; hence, the gallows itself.
A machine for lowering heavy weights, as packages, coal wagons, etc., to a ship's deck.
A contrivance for temporarily lowering a gas jet.
A curtain which drops or falls in front of the stage of a theater, etc.
A drop press or drop hammer.
Mach The distance of the axis of a shaft below the base of a hanger.

sn.def: Any medicine the dose of which is measured by drops; as, lavender drops .
The depth of a square sail; -- generally applied to the courses only.
Act of dropping; sudden fall or descent.

cs.cd: to leave it astern in a race or a chase; to outsail it.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Dropped or Dropt; p. pr. & vb. n. Dropping
entry.ety: OE. droppen, AS. dropan, v. i. See Drop n.

sn.def: To pour or let fall in drops; to pour in small globules; to distill.
sn.q: The treesdropbalsam.
The recording angel, as he wrote it down, dropped a tear upon the word and blotted it out forever.

sn.def: To cause to fall in one portion, or by one motion, like a drop; to let fall; as, to drop a line in fishing; to drop a courtesy.
To let go; to dismiss; to set aside; to have done with; to discontinue; to forsake; to give up; to omit.
sn.q: They suddenly drop't the pursuit.
That astonishing ease with which fine ladies drop you and pick you up again.
The connection had been dropped many years.
Dropping the too rough H in Hell and Heaven.

sn.def: To bestow or communicate by a suggestion; to let fall in an indirect, cautious, or gentle manner; as, to drop hint, a word of counsel, etc.
To lower, as a curtain, or the muzzle of a gun, etc.
To send, as a letter; as, please drop me a line, a letter, word.
To give birth to; as, to drop a lamb.
To cover with drops; to variegate; to bedrop.
sn.q: Show to the sun their waved coats dropped with gold.

cs.cd: to go astern of another vessel; to be left behind; to slacken the speed of a vessel so as to fall behind and to let another pass a head.
to sail, row, or move down a river, or toward the sea.
to fall asleep gently; also, to die.

sn.def: To fall in drops.
sn.q: The kindly dew drops from the higher tree, And wets the little plants that lowly dwell.

sn.def: To fall, in general, literally or figuratively; as, ripe fruit drops from a tree; wise words drop from the lips.
sn.q: Mutilations of which the meaning has dropped out of memory.
When the sound of dropping nuts is heard.

sn.def: To let drops fall; to discharge itself in drops.
sn.q: The heavens . . . dropped at the presence of God.

sn.def: To fall dead, or to fall in death; as, dropping like flies.
sn.q: Nothing, says Seneca, so soon reconciles us to the thoughts of our own death, as the prospect of one friend after another dropping round us.

sn.def: To come to an end; to cease; to pass out of mind; as, the affair dropped .
To come unexpectedly; -- with in or into; as, my old friend dropped in a moment.
sn.q: Takes care to drop in when he thinks you are just seated.

sn.def: To fall or be depressed; to lower; as, the point of the spear dropped a little.
To fall short of a mark.
sn.q: Often it drops or overshoots by the disproportion of distance.

sn.def: To be deep in extent; to descend perpendicularly; as, her main topsail drops seventeen yards.

entry.def: a sheet of material used to cover objects or surfaces while painting a ceiling or wall of a house, so as to protect objects from being marred by drops of paint splashed inadvertantly in the painting process. Originally such drop cloths were made of cloth, but more recently paper or plastic have also commonly been used.
a device for making large forgings, in which a heavy hammer drops onto the metalwork to be forged, pressing it into a form or anvil underneath, or between dies.
to forge with a drop forge; -- of metals.
an act of kicking a football (as for a field goal) in which the football is dropped and kicked as it touches the ground.
a football kicker who drops the ball and kicks it just as it reaches the ground.
A little drop; a tear.

An electric or gas light suspended from the ceiling by a flexible cord or tube, allowing artificial light to be brought down from a chandelier nearer to a table or desk; a pendant; also, an electric light bulb in a small holder, which can be held in the hand or hung from a hook, and attached to a long electric cord, allowing light to be brought close to work in dark areas of a room.

entry.ety: AS. drop-mǣlum; dropa drop + mǣl portion. Cf. Piecemeal
entry.def: By drops or small portions.
entry.q: Distilling dropmeal, a little at once.

sn.def: a noticeable decline in performance; as, a drop-off in attendance.
a steep high face of rock.
a change downward; as, there was a sharp drop-off in sales.

entry.def: born; -- used of an animal. Opposite of unborn.

sn.def: One who, or that which, drops.
A fly that drops from the leader above the bob or end fly.

A dropping tube, usually of glass or plastic with a narrow opening at the tip and a rubber bulb at the top which can be squeezed to control intake or outflow of the fluid. The word is used in combinations with obvious significance, as eye dropper medicine dropper, etc.
A branch vein which drops off from, or leaves, the main lode.
A dog which suddenly drops upon the ground when it sights game, -- formerly a common, and still an occasional, habit of the setter.

cs.cd: an instrument used to supply small quantities of a fluid to a test tube or other vessel.
a continued irregular discharge of firearms.
a tube for ejecting any liquid in drops.

sn.def: The action of causing to drop or of letting drop; falling.
That which falls in drops; the excrement or dung of animals; -- often used in the plural.

entry.def: fecal matter of animals; plural of dropping{2.
In drops.

entry.ety: From Dropsy

sn.def: Diseased with dropsy; hydropical; tending to dropsy; as, a dropsical patient.
Of or pertaining to dropsy.

entry.def: State of being dropsical.
Diseased with drops.

entries.entry:
Drop"sy n.; pl.Dropsies #. OE. dropsie dropesie, OF. idropisie, F. hydropisie, L. hydropisis, fr. Gr. � dropsy, fr. � water. See Water, and cf. Hydropsy
Med An unnatural collection of serous fluid in any serous cavity of the body, or in the subcutaneous cellular tissue.

entry.def: imp. & p. p. of Drop v.
After the manner of a drop; in the form of drops.
entry.q: Trickling dropwise from the cleft.

entry.def: The larva of any geometrid moth, which drops from trees by means of a thread of silk, as the cankerworm or inchworm. See inchworm and geometrid.
An Old World species of Spiræa Spiræa filipendula), with finely cut leaves.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. drosero`s dewy
entry.def: A genus of low perennial or biennial plants, the leaves of which are beset with gland-tipped bristles. See Sundew.
a natural family of carnivorous herbs and shrubs.
same as drosky.

entries.entry:
dros"ky drŏs"k� n.; pl.Droskies drŏs"kĭz. Russ. drojki, dim. of drogi a kind of carriage, prop. pl. of droga shaft or pole of a carriage A low, four-wheeled, open carriage, formerly used in Poland and Russia, consisting of a kind of long, narrow bench, on which the passengers ride as on a saddle, with their feet reaching nearly to the ground. Other kinds of vehicles have been so called, esp. a kind of victoria drawn by one or two horses, and used as a public carriage in German cities.
droitzschka droshky droschke

entry.ety: Gr. dro`sos dew + -meter: cf. F. drosomètre
entry.def: An instrument for measuring the quantity of dew on the surface of a body in the open air. It consists of a balance, having a plate at one end to receive the dew, and at the other a weight protected from the deposit of dew.
a natural family of insects including some of those called fruit flies.
a genus of dicotyledonous plants having only one species.

entry.ety: AS. dros, fr. dreósan to fall. See Dreary

sn.def: The scum or refuse matter which is thrown off, or falls from, metals in smelting the ore, or in the process of melting; recrement.
Rust of metals.
Waste matter; any worthless matter separated from the better part; leavings; dregs; refuse.
sn.q: All world's glory is but dross unclean.
At the devil's booth are all things sold, Each ounce of dross coats its ounce of gold.

entry.ety: Cf. Drazel
entry.def: A slut; a hussy; a drazel.
Free from dross.
Of, pertaining to, resembling, dross; full of dross; impure; worthless.
entry.q: Drossygold.
Drossyrhymes.

entry.def: See Drossel.
of Draw.

entry.ety: OE. droght drougth druȝð, AS. drugað, from drugian to dry. See Dry, and cf. Drouth, which shows the original final sound

sn.def: Dryness; want of rain or of water; especially, such dryness of the weather as affects the earth, and prevents the growth of plants; aridity.
sn.q: The drought of March hath pierced to the root.
In a drought the thirsty creatures cry.

sn.def: Thirst; want of drink.
Scarcity; lack.
sn.q: A drought of Christian writers caused a dearth of all history.

entry.def: A state of dryness of the weather; want of rain.

sn.def: Characterized by drought; wanting rain; arid; adust.
sn.q: Droughty and parched countries.

sn.def: Dry; thirsty; wanting drink.
sn.q: Thy droughty throat.

entry.ety: Cf. Scot. drum dram, melancholy, Icel prumr a moper, W. trwm heavy, sad
entry.def: Troubled; muddy.
Same as Drought.
entry.q: Another ill accident is drouth at the spindling of corn.
One whose drouththirst], Yet scarce allayed, still eyes the current stream.
In the dust and drouth of London life.

entry.def: Droughty.
of Drive.

entry.ety: AS. drāf, fr. drīfan to drive. See Drive

sn.def: A collection of cattle driven, or cattle collected for driving; a number of animals, as oxen, sheep, or swine, driven in a body.
Any collection of irrational animals, moving or driving forward; as, a finny drove .
A crowd of people in motion.
sn.q: Where droves, as at a city gate, may pass.

sn.def: A road for driving cattle; a driftway.
A narrow drain or channel used in the irrigation of land.

sd.def: A broad chisel used to bring stone to a nearly smooth surface; -- called also drove chisel.
The grooved surface of stone finished by the drove chisel; -- called also drove work.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Droved; p. pr. & vb. n. Droving
entry.ety: Cf. Drove n., and Drover

sn.def: To drive, as cattle or sheep, esp. on long journeys; to follow the occupation of a drover.
sn.q: He's droving now with Conroy's sheep along the Castlereagh.

sn.def: To finish, as stone, with a drove or drove chisel.

entry.def: of Drive.

sn.def: One who drives cattle or sheep to market; one who makes it his business to purchase cattle, and drive them to market.
sn.q: Why, that's spoken like an honest drover; so they sell bullocks.

sn.def: A boat driven by the tide.

entry.ety: AS. drōf dirty; cf. D. droef, G. trübe, Goth. drōbjan to trouble
entry.def: Turbid; muddy; filthy.
of Draw.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Drowned; p. pr. & vb. n. Drowning
entry.ety: OE. drunen drounen, earlier drunknen druncnien, AS. druncnian to be drowned, sink, become drunk, fr. druncen drunken. See Drunken Drink
entry.def: To be suffocated in water or other fluid; to perish in water.
entry.q: Methought, what pain it was to drown.

cs.cd: to swallow up.

sn.def: To overwhelm in water; to submerge; to inundate.
sn.q: Theydrownthe land.

sn.def: To deprive of life by immersion in water or other liquid.
To overpower; to overcome; to extinguish; -- said especially of sound.
sn.q: Most men being in sensual pleasures drowned.
My private voice is drowned amid the senate.

entry.def: The act of drowning.
One who, or that which, drowns.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Drowsed drouzd; p. pr. & vb. n. Drowsing
entry.ety: AS. drūsian drūsan, to sink, become slow or inactive; cf. OD. droosen to be sleepy, fall asleep, LG. drūsen druusken, to slumber, fall down with a noise; prob, akin to AS. dreósan to fall. See Dreary
entry.def: To sleep imperfectly or unsoundly; to slumber; to be heavy with sleepiness; to doze.
entry.q: Hedrowsedupon his couch.
In the pool drowsed the cattle up to their knees.

entry.def: To make heavy with sleepiness or imperfect sleep; to make dull or stupid.
A slight or imperfect sleep; a doze.
entry.q: But smiled on in a drowse of ecstasy.

entry.def: Drowsiness.
Drowsihead.
In a drowsy manner.
State of being drowsy.
sleeping lightly.

sn.def: Inclined to drowse; heavy with sleepiness; lethargic; dozy.
sn.q: When I amdrowsy.
Dapples the drowsy east with spots of gray.
To our age's drowsy blood Still shouts the inspiring sea.

sn.def: Disposing to sleep; lulling; soporific.
sn.q: The drowsy hours, dispensers of all good.

sn.def: Dull; stupid.
sn.q: Drowsyreasoning.
sn.syn: Sleepy; lethargic; dozy; somnolent; comatose; dull heavy; stupid.

entry.def: See Drought.
See Droil.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Drubbed; p. pr. & vb. n. Drubbing
entry.ety: Cf. Prov. E. drab to beat, Icel. & Sw. drabba to hit, beat, Dan. dræbe to slay, and perh. OE. drepen to strike, kill, AS. drepan to strike, G. & D. freffen to hit, touch, Icel. drepa to strike, kill
entry.def: To beat with a stick; to thrash; to cudgel.
entry.q: Soundly Drubbed with a good honest cudgel.

entry.def: A blow with a cudgel; a thump.
One who drubs.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Drudged; p. pr. & vb. n. Drudging
entry.ety: OE. druggen; prob not akin to E. drag, v. t., but fr. Celtic; cf. Ir. drugaire a slave or drudge
entry.def: To perform menial work; to labor in mean or unpleasant offices with toil and fatigue.
entry.q: He gradually rose in the estimation of the booksellers for whom he drudged.

entry.def: To consume laboriously; -- with away.
entry.q: Rise to our toils and drudge away the day.

entry.def: One who drudges; one who works hard in servile employment; a mental servant.

sn.def: One who drudges; a drudge.
A dredging box.

entry.def: The act of drudging; disagreeable and wearisome labor; ignoble or slavish toil.
entry.q: The drudgery of penning definitions.
Paradise was a place of bliss . . . without drudgery and with out sorrow.

entries.entry: Drudg"ing box`. See Dredging box.

entry.def: In a drudging manner; laboriously.

entry.ety: OF. druerie
entry.def: Courtship; gallantry; love; an object of love.

entry.ety: See 1st Drudge
entry.def: To drudge; to toil laboriously.
entry.q: Todruggeand draw.

entry.def: A drudge (?).

entry.ety: F. drogue, prob. fr. D. droog; akin to E. dry; thus orig., dry substance, hers, plants, or wares. See Dry

sn.def: Any animal, vegetable, or mineral substance used in the composition of medicines.
sn.q: Whence merchants bring Their spicy drugs.

sn.def: Any commodity that lies on hand, or is not salable; an article of slow sale, or in no demand; -- used often in the phrase “a drug on the market”.
sn.q: But sermons are meredrugs.
And virtue shall a drug become.

sn.def: any stuff used in dyeing or in chemical operations.
any substance intended for use in the treatment, prevention, diagnosis, or cure of disease, especially one listed in the official pharmacopoeia published by a national authority.

any substance having psychological effects, such as a narcotic, stimulant, or hallucinogenic agent, especially habit-forming and addictive substances, sold or used illegally; as, a drug habit; a drug treatment program; a teenager into drugs; a drug bust; addicted to drugs; high on drugs.

q.au: Christopher S. Wren (N Y. Times, June 10, 1998, p. A5)

sn.q: They [smaller and poorer nations] have lined up to recount how drug trafficking and consumption have corrupted their struggling economies and societies and why they are hard pressed to stop it.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Drugged; p. pr. & vb. n. Drugging
entry.ety: Cf. F. droguer
entry.def: To prescribe or administer drugs or medicines.

sn.def: To affect or season with drugs or ingredients; esp., to stupefy by a narcotic drug. Also Fig.
sn.q: The laboring masses . . . [weredrugged into brutish good humor by a vast system of public spectacles.
Drug thy memories, lest thou learn it.

sn.def: To tincture with something offensive or injurious.
sn.q: Drugged as oft, With hatefullest disrelish writhed their jaws.

sn.def: To dose to excess with, or as with, drugs.
sn.q: With pleasure drugged, he almost longed for woe.

entry.def: under the influence of narcotics or hypnotic drugs.
the administration of a sedative agent or drug.
A druggist.

entry.ety: F. droguet, prop. dim. of drogue trash, stuff, perh, the same word as drogue drug, but cf. also W. drwg evil, bad, Ir. & Gael. droch, Arm. droug drouk. See 3d Drug
entry.def: A coarse woolen cloth dyed of one color or printed on one side; generally used as a covering for carpets.
By extension, any material used for the same purpose.

entry.note: ☞ The same person often serves as both pharmacist and retail seller of drugs. See the Note under Apothecary.
entry.ety: F. droguiste, fr. drogue. See 3d Drug

sn.def: One who deals in drugs; especially, one who buys and sells drugs without compounding them; one who owns or operates a drugstore.
one who compounds drugs or distributes drugs into containers for distribution to customers; a pharmacist or apothecary.

entry.def: A druggist.
a retail shop where medicine and other articles are sold.
entry.syn: apothecary's shop, chemist's, chemist's shop, dispensary, pharmacy.

entry.note: ☞ The Druids superintended the affairs of religion and morality, and exercised judicial functions. They practiced divination and magic, and sacrificed human victims as a part of their worship. They consisted of three classes; the bards, the vates or prophets, and the Druids proper, or priests. Their most sacred rites were performed in the depths of oak forests or of caves.

cs.cd: a name given, in the south of England, to weatherworn, rough pillars of gray sandstone scattered over the chalk downs, but in other countries generally in the form of circles, or in detached pillars.

entry.ety: L. Druides; of Celtic origin; cf. Ir. & Gael. draoi druidh, magician, Druid, W. derwydd Druid

sn.def: One of an order of priests which in ancient times existed among certain branches of the Celtic race, especially among the Gauls and Britons.

A member of a social and benevolent order, founded in London in 1781, and professedly based on the traditions of the ancient Druids. Lodges or groves of the society are established in other countries.

entry.def: A female Druid; a prophetess.

entry.cs: Druidical circles. See under Circle.
entry.def: Pertaining to, or resembling, the Druids.
Druidic.
The system of religion, philosophy, and instruction, received and taught by the Druids; the rites and ceremonies of the Druids.

entry.note: ☞ There were also drum major rout tempest, and hurricane, differing only in degrees of multitude and uproar, as the significant name of each declares.
entry.cs: Bass drum. See in the Vocabulary. Double drum. See under Double.
entry.ety: Cf. D. trom trommel, LG. trumme, G. trommel, Dan. tromme, Sw. trumma, OHG. trumba a trumpet, Icel. pruma a clap of thunder, and as a verb, to thunder, Dan. drum a booming sound, drumme to boom; prob. partly at least of imitative origin; perh. akin to E. trum, or trumpet

sn.def: An instrument of percussion, consisting either of a hollow cylinder, over each end of which is stretched a piece of skin or vellum, to be beaten with a stick; or of a metallic hemisphere (kettledrum) with a single piece of skin to be so beaten; the common instrument for marking time in martial music; one of the pair of tympani in an orchestra, or cavalry band.
sn.q: The drums cry bud-a-dub.

entry.sn:
Anything resembling a drum in form; as: A sheet iron radiator, often in the shape of a drum, for warming an apartment by means of heat received from a stovepipe, or a cylindrical receiver for steam, etc.
A small cylindrical box in which figs, etc., are packed.
Anat The tympanum of the ear; -- often, but incorrectly, applied to the tympanic membrane.
Arch One of the cylindrical, or nearly cylindrical, blocks, of which the shaft of a column is composed; also, a vertical wall, whether circular or polygonal in plan, carrying a cupola or dome.
Mach A cylinder on a revolving shaft, generally for the purpose of driving several pulleys, by means of belts or straps passing around its periphery; also, the barrel of a hoisting machine, on which the rope or chain is wound.

sn.def: See Drumfish.
A noisy, tumultuous assembly of fashionable people at a private house; a rout.
sn.q: Not unaptly styled a drum, from the noise and emptiness of the entertainment.

sn.def: A tea party; a kettledrum.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Drummed; p. pr. & vb. n. Drumming

sn.def: To beat a drum with sticks; to beat or play a tune on a drum.
To beat with the fingers, as with drumsticks; to beat with a rapid succession of strokes; to make a noise like that of a beaten drum; as, the ruffed grouse drums with his wings.
sn.q: Drumming with his fingers on the arm of his chair.

sn.def: To throb, as the heart.
To go about, as a drummer does, to gather recruits, to draw or secure partisans, customers, etc,; -- with for.
To execute on a drum, as a tune.
With out) To expel ignominiously, with beat of drum; as, to drum out a deserter or rogue from a camp, etc.
With up) To assemble by, or as by, beat of drum; to collect; to gather or draw by solicitation; as, to drum up recruits; to drum up customers.

entry.def: The sound of a beaten drum; drum music.
entry.q: Whose morning drumbeat, following the sun, and keeping company with the hours, circles the earth with one continuous and unbroken strain of the martial airs of England.

entry.ety: See Drumly

sn.def: To be sluggish or lazy; to be confused.
To mumble in speaking.

entry.note: ☞ The common drumfish (Pogonias chromis) is a large species, common south of New Jersey. The southern red drum or red horse (Sciæna ocellata), and the fresh-water drum or croaker (Aplodionotus grunniens), are related species.
entry.def: Any fish of the family Sciænidæ, which makes a loud noise by means of its air bladder; -- called also drum.

cs.cd: a summary court-martial called to try offenses on the battlefield or the line of march, when, sometimes, a drumhead has to do service as a writing table.

sn.def: The parchment or skin stretched over one end of a drum.
