The top of a capstan which is pierced with sockets for levers used in turning it. See Illust. of Capstan.

entry.ety: Gael. druim the ridge of a hill
entry.def: A hill of compact, unstratified, glacial drift or till, usually elongate or oval, with the larger axis parallel to the former local glacial motion.

entry.ety: Cf. Droumy
entry.def: Turbid; muddy.

sn.def: The chief or first drummer of a regiment; an instructor of drummers.
The marching leader of a military band.
A noisy gathering. R See under Drum n., 4.
One whose office is to best the drum, as in military exercises and marching.
One who solicits custom; a commercial traveler.

entry.sn:
Zoöl A fish that makes a sound when caught; as: The squeteague.
A California sculpin.

sn.def: A large West Indian cockroach (Blatta gigantea) which drums on woodwork, as a sexual call.

entry.def: The act of beating upon, or as if upon, a drum; also, the noise which the male of the ruffed grouse makes in spring, by beating his wings upon his sides.

entries.entry: Drum"mond light` ☞ The name is also applied sometimes to a heliostat, invented by Drummond, for rendering visible a distant point, as in geodetic surveying, by reflecting upon it a beam of light from the sun.. From Thomas Drummond, a British naval officer A very intense light, produced by turning two streams of gas, one oxygen and the other hydrogen, or coal gas, in a state of ignition, upon a ball of lime; or a stream of oxygen gas through a flame of alcohol upon a ball or disk of lime; -- called also oxycalcium light, or lime light.

sn.def: A stick with which a drum is beaten.
Anything resembling a drumstick in form; -- applied especially to the tibiotarsus, or second joint, of the leg of a fowl, when cooked and served at the table.

entries.entry: Drum winding. Elec A method of armature winding in which the wire is wound upon the outer surface of a cylinder or drum from end to end of the cylinder; -- distinguished from ring winding, etc.

entry.ety: OE. dronke drunke dronken drunken, AS. druncen. Orig. the same as drunken, p. p. of drink. See Drink

sn.def: Intoxicated with, or as with, strong drink; inebriated; drunken; -- never used attributively, but always predicatively; as, the man is drunknot, a drunk man.
sn.q: Be not drunk with wine, where in is excess.
Drunk with recent prosperity.

sn.def: Drenched or saturated with moisture or liquid.
sn.q: I will make mine arrows drunk with blood.

entry.def: A drunken condition; a spree.

entry.ety: Drunk + -ard
entry.def: One who habitually drinks strong liquors immoderately; one whose habit it is to get drunk; a toper; a sot.
entry.q: The drunkard and glutton shall come to poverty.

entry.ety: AS. druncen, prop., that has drunk, p. p. of drincan, taken as active. See Drink v. i., and cf. Drunk

sn.def: Overcome by strong drink; intoxicated by, or as by, spirituous liquor; inebriated.
sn.q: Drunken men imagine everything turneth round.

sn.def: Saturated with liquid or moisture; drenched.
sn.q: Let the earth be drunken with our blood.

sn.def: Pertaining to, or proceeding from, intoxication.
sn.q: The drunken quarrels of a rake.

entry.def: Drunkenness.
In a drunken manner.

sn.def: The state of being drunken with, or as with, alcoholic liquor; intoxication; inebriety; -- used of the casual state or the habit.
sn.q: The Lacedemonians trained up their children to hate drunkenness by bringing a drunken man into their company.

sn.def: Disorder of the faculties, resembling intoxication by liquors; inflammation; frenzy; rage.
sn.q: Passion is the drunkenness of the mind.
sn.syn: Intoxication; inebriation; inebriety.Drunkenness Intoxication Inebriation. Drunkenness refers more to the habit; intoxication and inebriation, to specific acts. The first two words are extensively used in a figurative sense; a person is intoxicated with success, and is drunk with joy. “This plan of empire was not taken up in the first intoxication of unexpected success.”

entry.def: The state of being drunk; drunkenness.

entry.ety: Cf. F. drupacé
entry.def: Producing, or pertaining to, drupes; having the form of drupes; as, drupaceous trees or fruits.
Drupaceous.

entry.ety: F. drupe, L. drupa an overripe, wrinkled olive, fr. Gr. dry`ppa
entry.def: A fruit consisting of pulpy, coriaceous, or fibrous exocarp, without valves, containing a nut or stone with a kernel. The exocarp is succulent in the plum, cherry, apricot, peach, etc.; dry and subcoriaceous in the almond; and fibrous in the cocoanut.

entry.ety: Dim. of Drupe
entry.def: A small drupe, as one of the pulpy grains of the blackberry.

entry.ety: Cf. G. druse bonny, crystallized piece of ore, Bohem. druza. Cf. Dross
entry.def: A cavity in a rock, having its interior surface studded with crystals and sometimes filled with water; a geode.
One of a people and religious sect dwelling chiefly in the Lebanon mountains of Syria.
entry.q: The Druses separated from the Mohammedan Arabs in the 9th century. Their characteristic dogma is the unity of God.

entry.def: Covered with a large number of minute crystals.

entry.ety: Etymol. uncertain
entry.def: Having decayed spots or streaks of a whitish color; -- said of timber.

entry.cs: Dry area Arch a small open space reserved outside the foundation of a building to guard it from damp. Dry blow. Med A blow which inflicts no wound, and causes no effusion of blood. A quick, sharp blow. Dry bone Min Smithsonite, or carbonate of zinc; -- a miner's term. Dry castor Zoöl a kind of beaver; -- called also parchment beaver. Dry cupping. Med See under Cupping. Dry dock. See under Dock. Dry fat. See Dry vatbelow). Dry light pure unobstructed light; hence, a clear, impartial view. Bacon. The scientific man must keep his feelings under stern control, lest they obtrude into his researches, and color the dry light in which alone science desires to see its objects. J. C. Shairp. Dry masonry. See Masonry. Dry measure a system of measures of volume for dry or coarse articles, by the bushel, peck, etc. Dry pile Physics a form of the Voltaic pile, constructed without the use of a liquid, affording a feeble current, and chiefly useful in the construction of electroscopes of great delicacy; -- called also Zamboni's, from the names of the two earliest constructors of it. Dry pipe Steam Engine a pipe which conducts dry steam from a boiler. Dry plate Photog a glass plate having a dry coating sensitive to light, upon which photographic negatives or pictures can be made, without moistening. Dry-plate process the process of photographing with dry plates. Dry point. Fine Arts An engraving made with the needle instead of the burin, in which the work is done nearly as in etching, but is finished without the use acid. A print from such an engraving, usually upon paper. Hence: The needle with which such an engraving is made. Dry rent Eng. Law a rent reserved by deed, without a clause of distress. Bouvier. Dry rot a decay of timber, reducing its fibers to the condition of a dry powdery dust, often accompanied by the presence of a peculiar fungus (Merulius lacrymans), which is sometimes considered the cause of the decay; but it is more probable that the real cause is the decomposition of the wood itself. D. C. Eaton. Called also sap rot, and, in the United States, powder post. Hebert. Dry stove a hothouse adapted to preserving the plants of arid climates. Brande & C. Dry vat a vat, basket, or other receptacle for dry articles. Dry wine that in which the saccharine matter and fermentation were so exactly balanced, that they have wholly neutralized each other, and no sweetness is perceptible; -- opposed to sweet wine, in which the saccharine matter is in excess.
entry.ety: OE. druȝe druye drie, AS. dryge; akin to LG. dröge, D. droog, OHG. trucchan, G. trocken, Icel. draugr a dry log. Cf. Drought Drouth, 3d Drug

sn.def: Free from moisture; having little humidity or none; arid; not wet or moist; deficient in the natural or normal supply of moisture, as rain or fluid of any kind; -- said especially: Of the weather: Free from rain or mist.
sn.q: The weather, we agreed, was too dry for the season.

sd.def: Of vegetable matter: Free from juices or sap; not succulent; not green; as, dry wood or hay.
Of animals: Not giving milk; as, the cow is dry .
Of persons: Thirsty; needing drink.
sd.q: Give the dry fool drink.

sd.def: Of the eyes: Not shedding tears.
sd.q: Not a dry eye was to be seen in the assembly.

sd.def: Of certain morbid conditions, in which there is entire or comparative absence of moisture; as, dry gangrene; dry catarrh.

sn.def: Destitute of that which interests or amuses; barren; unembellished; jejune; plain.
sn.q: These epistles will become less dry, more susceptible of ornament.

sn.def: Characterized by a quality somewhat severe, grave, or hard; hence, sharp; keen; shrewd; quaint; as, a dry tone or manner; dry wit.
sn.q: He was rather a dry, shrewd kind of body.

sn.def: Exhibiting a sharp, frigid preciseness of execution, or the want of a delicate contour in form, and of easy transition in coloring.

entry.cs:
To dry up. To scorch or parch with thirst; to deprive utterly of water; to consume. Their honorable men are famished, and their multitude dried up with thirst. Is. v. 13. The water of the sea, which formerly covered it, was in time exhaled and dried up by the sun. Woodward. To make to cease, as a stream of talk. Their sources of revenue were dried up. Jowett (Thucyd.
To dry a coworTo dry up a cow
to cause a cow to cease secreting milk. Tylor.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Dried; p. pr. & vb. n. Drying
entry.ety: AS. drygan; cf. drugian to grow dry. See Dry a.
entry.def: To make dry; to free from water, or from moisture of any kind, and by any means; to exsiccate; as, to dry the eyes; to dry one's tears; the wind dries the earth; to dry a wet cloth; to dry hay.

sn.def: To grow dry; to become free from wetness, moisture, or juice; as, the road dries rapidly.
To evaporate wholly; to be exhaled; -- said of moisture, or a liquid; -- sometimes with up; as, the stream dries, or dries up.
To shrivel or wither; to lose vitality.
sn.q: And his hand, which he put forth against him, dried up, so that he could not pull it in again to him.

entry.ety: L. dryas, pl. dryades, Gr. �, pl. �, fr. � oak, tree. See Tree
entry.def: A wood nymph; a nymph whose life was bound up with that of her tree.

a genus of plants comprising tropical American species usually placed in the genus Masdevallia; they are very dwarf plants having short tufted and usually unifoliate stems with usually solitary flowers.

entry.ety: NL. Named after J. Dryander
entry.def: A genus of shrubs growing in Australia, having beautiful, hard, dry, evergreen leaves.

entries.entry:
Dry"as Dry"as n.; pl.Dryades #. L. See Dryad
Class. Myth A dryad.

entry.def: To beat severely.
Having dry bones, or bones without flesh.
to clean without the use of water; -- usually by immersing in an organic solvent to remove grease.
cleaned without the use of water; -- usually by immersing in an organic solvent to remove grease.

entries.entry: Dry" dock`. Naut See under Dock.

entry.def: See Drier.
Not having tears in the eyes. Opposite of tearful.
Niggardly.
The scent of the game, as far as it can be traced.

entries.entry: Dry" goods`. A commercial name for textile fabrics, cottons, woolens, linen, silks, laces, etc., -- in distinction from groceries. U.S

cs.cd: an oil which, either naturally or after boiling with oxide of lead, absorbs oxygen from the air and dries up rapidly. Drying oils are used as the bases of many paints and varnishes.

sn.def: Adapted or tending to exhaust moisture; as, a drying wind or day; a drying room.
Having the quality of rapidly becoming dry.

entry.def: In a dry manner; not succulently; without interest; without sympathy; coldly.
a genus of epiphytic ferns of Madagascar to tropical Asia and New Guinea.
a genus of large robust epiphytic ferns of tropical forest and scrub; Africa and Asia and Australia.
The state of being dry. See Dry.

entries.entry: Dry" nurse`. A nurse who attends and feeds a child by hand; -- in distinction from a wet nurse, who suckles it.

entry.def: To feed, attend, and bring up without breastfeeding it.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. dry^s oak + ba`lanos acorn + 'o`psis appearance. The fruit remotely resembles an acorn in its cup
entry.def: The genus to which belongs the single species Dryobalanops Camphora, a lofty resinous tree of Borneo and Sumatra, yielding Borneo camphor and camphor oil.
a spiny-leaved perennial herb of southern Europe having terminal clusters of small flowers.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Dry-rubbed; p. pr. & vb. n. Dry-rubbing
entry.def: To rub and cleanse without wetting.

A dealer in salted or dried meats, pickles, sauces, etc., and in the materials used in pickling, salting, and preserving various kinds of food Hence drysalters usually sell a number of saline substances and miscellaneous drugs.
The articles kept by a drysalter; also, the business of a drysalter.
Without wetting the feet; having or keeping the feet or shoes dry; as, a land bridge over which man and beasts could have crossed dry-shod .
Constructed of uncemented stone.
entry.q: Dry-stonewalls.

entry.def: Drought.

entry.ety: See Dyad
entry.def: A union of two; duality.

entry.ety: L. dualis, fr. duo two. See Two
entry.def: Expressing, or consisting of, the number two; belonging to two; as, the dual number of nouns, etc. , in Greek.
entry.q: Here you have one half of our dual truth.

entry.def: An explosive substance consisting essentially of sawdust or wood pulp, saturated with nitroglycerin and other similar nitro compounds. It is inferior to dynamite, and is more liable to explosion.

entries.entry:
Du"al*ism n. Cf. F. dualisme
State of being dual or twofold; a twofold division; any system which is founded on a double principle, or a twofold distinction; as: Philos A view of man as constituted of two original and independent elements, as matter and spirit. Theol A system which accepts two gods, or two original principles, one good and the other evil. The doctrine that all mankind are divided by the arbitrary decree of God, and in his eternal foreknowledge, into two classes, the elect and the reprobate. Physiol The theory that each cerebral hemisphere acts independently of the other. An inevitable dualism bisects nature, so that each thing is a half, and suggests another thing to make it whole.

entry.ety: Cf. F. dualiste

sn.def: One who believes in dualism; a ditheist.
One who administers two offices.

cs.cd: an old theory, originated by Lavoisier and developed by Berzelius, that all definite compounds are binary in their nature, and consist of two distinct constituents, themselves simple or complex, and possessed of opposite chemical or electrical affinities; -- superseded by later developments in chemical bonding theory, especially quantum mechanics.

entry.def: Consisting of two; pertaining to dualism or duality.

entry.ety: L. dualitas: cf. F. dualité
entry.def: The quality or condition of being two or twofold; dual character or usage.

entry.ety: Gael. & Ir
entry.def: A division of a poem corresponding to a canto; a poem or song.

entry.ety: Gr. � two + -archy
entry.def: Government by two persons.

entry.note: ☞ The conclusion of the ceremony was marked by a tap on the shoulder with the sword.

cs.cd: to dress a fishing fly.
to fill out, as an uneven surface, to a plane, or to carry out a series of small projections.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Dubbed dŭbd; p. pr. & vb. n. Dubbing
entry.ety: AS. dubban to strike, beat (“dubbade his sunu . . . to rīdere.” AS. Chron. an. 1086); akin to Icel. dubba; cf. OF. adouberprob. fr. Icel.) a chevalier, Icel. dubba til riddara

sn.def: To confer knighthood upon; as, the king dubbed his son Henry a knight.
To invest with any dignity or new character; to entitle; to call.
sn.q: A man of wealth is dubbed a man of worth.

sn.def: To clothe or invest; to ornament; to adorn.
sn.q: His diadem was dropped downDubbed with stones.

sn.def: To strike, rub, or dress smooth; to dab;

sd.def: To dress with an adz; as, to dub a stick of timber smooth.
To strike cloth with teasels to raise a nap.
To rub or dress with grease, as leather in the process of cyrrying it.
To prepare for fighting, as a gamecock, by trimming the hackles and cutting off the comb and wattles.

entry.def: To make a noise by brisk drumbeats.
entry.q: Now the drumdubs.

sn.def: to add sound to an existing recording, audio or video; -- often used with in. The sound may be of any type or of any duration.
to mix together two or more sound or video recordings to produce a composite recording.

entry.def: A blow.

entry.ety: Cf. Ir. dób mire, stream, W. dwvr water
entry.def: A pool or puddle.

entry.ety: Ar
entry.def: The Syrian bear. See under Bear.
One who, or that which, dubs.

entry.ety: Hind. dabbah
entry.def: A globular vessel or bottle of leather, used in India to hold ghee, oil, etc.

sn.def: The act of dubbing, as a knight, etc.
The act of rubbing, smoothing, or dressing; a dressing off smooth with an adz.
A dressing of flour and water used by weavers; a mixture of oil and tallow for dressing leather; daubing.
The body substance of an angler's fly.

entries.entry:
Du*bi"e*ty n.; pl.Dubieties #. L. dubietas, fr. dubius. See Dubious
Doubtfulness; uncertainty; doubt. R Lamb. Thedubietyof his fate.

Du`bi*os"i*ty n.; pl.Dubiosities #. L. dubiosus
The state of being doubtful; a doubtful statement or thing. R Men often swallow falsities for truths, dubiosities for certainties, possibilities for feasibilities.

entry.ety: L. dubius dubiosus, fr. duo two. See Two, and cf. Doubt

sn.def: Doubtful or not settled in opinion; being in doubt; wavering or fluctuating; undetermined.
sn.q: Dubiouspolicy.
A dubious, agitated state of mind.

sn.def: Occasioning doubt; not clear, or obvious; equivocal; questionable; doubtful; as, a dubious answer.
sn.q: Wiping the dingy shirt with a still more dubious pocket handkerchief.

sn.def: Of uncertain event or issue; as, in dubious battle.
sn.syn: Doubtful; doubting; unsettled; undetermined; equivocal; uncertain. Cf. Doubtful.

entry.def: In a dubious manner.
State of being dubious.

entry.ety: L. dubitabilis. Cf. Doubtable
entry.def: Liable to be doubted; uncertain.

entry.ety: LL. dubitantia
entry.def: Doubt; uncertainty.

entry.ety: L. dubitatus, p. p. of dubitare. See Doubt
entry.def: To doubt.
entry.q: If he . . . were to loiter dubitating, and not come.

entry.ety: L. dubitatio
entry.def: Act of doubting; doubt.

entry.ety: L. dubitativus: cf. F. dubitatif
entry.def: Tending to doubt; doubtful.

entry.ety: NL
entry.def: Same as Duboisine.
An alkaloid obtained from the leaves of an Australian tree (Duboisia myoporoides), and regarded as identical with hyoscyamine. It produces dilation of the pupil of the eye.

entry.ety: F. ducal. See Duke
entry.def: Of or pertaining to a duke.
entry.q: His ducal cap was to be exchanged for a kingly crown.

entry.def: In the manner of a duke, or in a manner becoming the rank of a duke.

entry.note: ☞ The gold ducat is generally of the value of nine shillings and four pence sterling, or somewhat more that two dollars. The silver ducat is of about half this value.
entry.ety: F. ducat, It. ducato, LL. ducatus, fr. dux leader or commander. See Duke
entry.def: A coin, either of gold or silver, of several countries in Europe; originally, one struck in the dominions of a duke.

entry.ety: F. or Sp. ducaton, fr. ducat
entry.def: A silver coin of several countries of Europe, and of different values.

entries.entry: Du"ces te"cum Du"ces te"cum. L., bring with thee A judicial process commanding a person to appear in court and bring with him some piece of evidence or other thing to be produced to the court.

entry.ety: F. duchesse, fr. duc duke
entry.def: The wife or widow of a duke; also, a lady who has the sovereignty of a duchy in her own right.

entries.entry: Du`chesse" d'An`gou`lême" Du`chesse" d'An`gou`lême". F Bot A variety of pear of large size and excellent flavor.

Du`chesse" lace. A beautiful variety of Brussels pillow lace made originally in Belgium and resembling Honiton guipure. It is worked with fine thread in large sprays, usually of the primrose pattern, with much raised work.

Duch"y dŭch"� n.; pl.Duchies #. F. duché, OF. duchée, (assumed) LL. ducitas, fr. L. dux. See Duke
The territory or dominions of a duke; a dukedom.

entry.ety: Cf. Dan. dukke, Sw. docka, OHG. doccha, G. docke. Cf. Doxy
entry.def: A pet; a darling.

entry.ety: D. doek cloth, canvas, or Icel. dūkr cloth; akin to OHG. tuoh, G. tuch, Sw. duk, Dan. dug

sn.def: A linen (or sometimes cotton) fabric, finer and lighter than canvas, -- used for the lighter sails of vessels, the sacking of beds, and sometimes for men's clothing.
The light clothes worn by sailors in hot climates.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Ducked; p. pr. & vb. n. Ducking
entry.ety: OE. duken douken, to dive; akin to D. duiken, OHG. t�hhan, MHG. tucken tücken t�chen, G. tuchen. Cf. 5th Duck

sn.def: To thrust or plunge under water or other liquid and suddenly withdraw.
sn.q: Adams, after ducking the squire twice or thrice, leaped out of the tub.

sn.def: To plunge the head of under water, immediately withdrawing it; as, duck the boy.
To bow; to bob down; to move quickly with a downward motion.
sn.q: Willduckhis head aside.

sn.def: To go under the surface of water and immediately reappear; to dive; to plunge the head in water or other liquid; to dip.
sn.q: In Tiber ducking thrice by break of day.

sn.def: To drop the head or person suddenly; to bow.
sn.q: The learned pateDucks to the golden fool.

entry.note: ☞ The genera and species are numerous. They are divided into river ducks and sea ducks. Among the former are the common domestic duck (Anas boschas); the wood duck (Aix sponsa); the beautiful mandarin duck of China (Dendronessa galeriliculata); the Muscovy duck, originally of South America (Cairina moschata). Among the sea ducks are the eider, canvasback, scoter, etc.
entry.cs:
Bombay duck Zoöl a fish. See Bummalo.
Buffel duck Spirit duck . See Buffel duck. Duck ant Zoöl a species of white ant in Jamaica which builds large nests in trees. Duck barnacle. Zoöl See Goose barnacle. Duck hawk. Zoöl In the United States: The peregrine falcon. In England: The marsh harrier or moor buzzard. Duck mole Zoöl a small aquatic mammal of Australia, having webbed feet and a bill resembling that of a duck (Ornithorhynchus anatinus). It belongs the subclass Monotremata and is remarkable for laying eggs like a bird or reptile; -- called also duckbill platypus mallangong mullingong tambreet, and water mole. To make ducks and drakes to throw a flat stone obliquely, so as to make it rebound repeatedly from the surface of the water, raising a succession of jets
; hence: To play at ducks and drakes, with property, to throw it away heedlessly or squander it foolishly and unprofitably. Lame duck. See under Lame.
entry.ety: OE. duke doke. See Duck v. t.

sn.def: Any bird of the subfamily Anatinæ, family Anatidæ.
A sudden inclination of the bead or dropping of the person, resembling the motion of a duck in water.
sn.q: Here be, without duck or nod, Other trippings to be trod.

entry.def: See Duck mole, under Duck n.

sn.def: having a beak resembling that of a duck.

entries.entry: Duck"-billed` a. Having a bill like that of a duck; as, a duck-billed dinosaur..
Duck"-billed` plat"y*pus a. same as Duck Mole, under Duck..

sn.def: One who, or that which, ducks; a plunger; a diver.
A cringing, servile person; a fawner.

cs.cd: a stool or chair in which common scolds were formerly tied, and plunged into water, as a punishment. See Cucking stool. The practice of ducking began in the latter part of the 15th century, and prevailed until the early part of the 18th, and occasionally as late as the 19th century.

entry.def: n. & a., from Duck v. t. & i.
Having short legs, like a waddling duck; short-legged.
A young or little duck.
Duckweed.

cs.cd: a limpet of the genus Parmaphorus; -- so named from its shape.

entry.def: Having the form of a duck's bill.
The May apple (Podophyllum peltatum).
A genus (Lemna) of small plants, seen floating in great quantity on the surface of stagnant pools fresh water, and supposed to furnish food for ducks; -- called also duckmeat.

sn.def: fine; satisfactory; excellent.
charming; cute.

entry.def: a special loved one; a darling; -- used as a term of endearment.
entry.syn: darling, favorite, favourite, pet, dearie, deary.

entry.note: ☞ Ducts are classified, according to the character of the surface of their walls, or their structure, as annular, spiral, scalariform, etc.
entry.ety: L. ductus a leading, conducting, conduit, fr. ducere ductum, to lead. See Duke, and cf. Douche

sn.def: Any tube or canal by which a fluid or other substance is conducted or conveyed.
One of the vessels of an animal body by which the products of glandular secretion are conveyed to their destination.
A large, elongated cell, either round or prismatic, usually found associated with woody fiber.
Guidance; direction.

entry.def: Capable of being drawn out

entry.ety: L. ductilis, fr. ducere to lead: cf. F. ductile. See Duct

sn.def: Easily led; tractable; complying; yielding to motives, persuasion, or instruction; as, a ductile people.
sn.q: Forms their ductile minds To human virtues.

sn.def: Capable of being elongated or drawn out, as into wire or threads.
sn.q: Gold . . . is the softest and most ductile of all metals.

entry.ety: Ductile + -meter
entry.def: An instrument for accurately determining the ductility of metals.

entry.ety: Cf. F. ductilité

sn.def: The property of a metal which allows it to be drawn into wires or filaments.
Tractableness; pliableness.

entry.ety: L. ductio, fr. ducere to lead
entry.def: Guidance.
Having to duct or outlet; as, a ductless gland.

cs.cd: the roller which conveys or supplies ink to another roller.

entry.ety: L., fr. ducere to lead

sn.def: One who leads.
A contrivance for removing superfluous ink or coloring matter from a roller. See Doctor, 4.

entry.def: Guidance.

entry.ety: In Suffolk, Eng., to shiver, shake, tremble; also written dodder
entry.def: To confuse or confound with noise.
To shiver or tremble; to dodder.
entry.q: I dudder and shake like an aspen leaf.

entry.ety: From Duds
entry.def: A peddler or hawker, especially of cheap and flashy goods pretended to be smuggled; a duffer.
A place where rags are bought and kept for sale.
A kind of dandy; especially, one characterized by an ultrafashionable style of dress and other affectations.
entry.q: The social dude who affects English dress and English drawl.

entry.def: A short tobacco pipe.

sn.def: The root of the box tree, of which hafts for daggers were made.
The haft of a dagger.
A dudgeon-hafted dagger; a dagger.

entry.ety: W. dygen anger, grudge
entry.def: Resentment; ill will; anger; displeasure.
entry.q: I drink it to thee in dudgeon and hostility.
Sir T. Scott.

entry.def: Homely; rude; coarse.
entry.q: By my troth, though I am plain and dudgeon, I would not be an ass.

entry.def: Like, or characterized of, a dude.

entry.ety: Scot. dud rag, pl. duds clothing of inferior quality

sn.def: Old or inferior clothes; tattered garments.
Effects, in general.

entry.ety: OF. deu, F. dû, p. p. of devoir to owe, fr. L. debere. See Debt Habit, and cf. Duty

sn.def: Owed, as a debt; that ought to be paid or done to or for another; payable; owing and demandable.
Justly claimed as a right or property; proper; suitable; becoming; appropriate; fit.
sn.q: Her obedience, which is due to me.
With dirges due, in sad array, Slow through the churchway path we saw him borne.

sn.def: Such as (a thing) ought to be; fulfilling obligation; proper; lawful; regular; appointed; sufficient; exact; as, due process of law; due service; in due time.
Appointed or required to arrive at a given time; as, the steamer was due yesterday.
Owing; ascribable, as to a cause.
sn.q: This effect is due to the attraction of the sun.

entry.def: Directly; exactly; as, a due east course.

sn.def: That which is owed; debt; that which one contracts to pay, or do, to or for another; that which belongs or may be claimed as a right; whatever custom, law, or morality requires to be done; a fee; a toll.
sn.q: He will give the devil his due.
Yearly little dues of wheat, and wine, and oil.

sn.def: Right; just title or claim.
sn.q: The key of this infernal pit by due . . . I keep.

entry.def: To endue.
A brief written acknowledgment of a debt, not made payable to order, like a promissory note.
Fit; becoming.

cs.cd: a combat between two persons for proving a cause; trial by battel.

entry.ety: It. duello, fr. L. duellum, orig., a contest between two, which passed into the common form bellum war, fr. duo two: cf. F. duel. See Bellicose Two, and cf. Duello
entry.def: A combat between two persons, fought with deadly weapons, by agreement. It usually arises from an injury done or an affront given by one to the other.
To fight in single combat.
One who engages in a duel.
The act or practice of fighting in single combat. Also adj.

entry.ety: F. duelliste
entry.def: One who fights in single combat.
entry.q: A duelist . . . always values himself upon his courage, his sense of honor, his fidelity and friendship.

entry.ety: It. See Duel
entry.def: A duel; also, the rules of dueling.

entry.ety: Sp
entry.def: See Doña.
Quality of being due; debt; what is due or becoming.

entries.entry:
Du*en"na n.; pl.Duennas #. Sp. dueña doña, fr. L. domina. See Dame
The chief lady in waiting on the queen of Spain.
An elderly lady holding a station between a governess and companion, and appointed to have charge over the younger ladies in a Spanish or a Portuguese family.
Any old woman who is employed to guard a younger one; a governess.

entry.def: A composition for two performers, whether vocal or instrumental.

entry.ety: It ., dim. fr. duetto a duet
entry.def: A duet of short extent and concise form.

entry.ety: It., fr. It & L. duo two. See Two
entry.def: See Duet.

entry.ety: From OE. dagh. √67. See Dough

sn.def: Dough or paste.
A stiff flour pudding, boiled in a bag; -- a term used especially by seamen; as, plum duff .

entry.def: the buttocks; as, get off your duff and get to work.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Duffed; p. pr. & vb. n. Duffing
entry.ety: Etym. uncertain

sn.def: To treat or manipulate so as to give a specious appearance to; to fake; hence, to cheat.
In Australia, to alter the brands on (cattle, horses, etc.); to steal (cattle, etc.), and alter their brands.

entry.ety: D. duffel, from Duffel, a town not far from Antwerp

sn.def: A kind of coarse woolen cloth, having a thick nap or frieze.
sn.q: Good duffel gray and flannel fine.

sn.def: Outfit or suppplies, collectively; kit.

entries.entry: Duffel bag. A sack to hold miscellaneous articles, as tools, supplies, or the like.

sn.def: A peddler or hawker, especially of cheap, flashy articles, as sham jewelry; hence, a sham or cheat.
A stupid, awkward, inefficient person.
See Shicer.
Any common domestic pigeon.

entry.def: One who duffs cattle, etc.
entry.q: Unluckily, cattle stealers are by no means so rare as would be desirable; they are locally known as duffers.

entry.def: See Duffel.

entry.ety: From ��ierre Armand Dufrénoy, a French geologist
entry.def: A mineral of a blackish green color, commonly massive or in nodules. It is a hydrous phosphate of iron.

entry.ety: Akin to Sw. dägga to suckle (a child), Dan. dægge, and prob. to Goth. daddjan. √66
entry.def: A teat, pap, or nipple; -- formerly that of a human mother, now that of a cow or other beast.
entry.q: With mother's dug between its lips.

entry.def: imp. & p. p. of Dig.

entry.ety: Malayan dūyōng, or Javan. duyung
entry.def: An aquatic herbivorous mammal (Halicore dugong), of the order Sirenia, allied to the manatee, but with a bilobed tail. It inhabits the Red Sea, Indian Ocean, East Indies, and Australia.

sn.def: A canoe or boat dug out from a large log.
sn.q: A man stepped from his slender dugout.

sn.def: A place dug out.
A house made partly in a hillside or slighter elevation.

a structure on the edge of the playing field in foul territory, partly below ground and partly above ground, open toward the playing field but roofed and with the other three sides closed. It is typically long and narrow, having benches where the players may sit when not on the playing field; as, the foul ball was tipped into the dugout .

entry.def: A way or road dug through a hill, or sunk below the surface of the land.

entry.cs: Duke's coronet. See Illust. of Coronet. To dine with Duke Humphrey to go without dinner. See under Dine.
entry.ety: F. duc, fr. L. dux ducis, leader, commander, fr. ducere to lead; akin to AS. teón to draw; cf. AS. heretoga here army) an army leader, general, G. herzog duke. See Tue, and cf. Doge Duchess Ducat Duct Adduce Deduct

sn.def: A leader; a chief; a prince.
sn.q: Hannibal, duke of Carthage.
All were dukes once, who were “duces” -- captains or leaders of their people.

sn.def: In England, one of the highest order of nobility after princes and princesses of the royal blood and the four archbishops of England and Ireland.
In some European countries, a sovereign prince, without the title of king.
The fists; as, put up your dukes .

entry.def: To play the duke.
entry.q: Lord Angelo dukes it well in his absence.

cs.cd: to fight; -- usually implying, to fight with the fists; to settle a dispute by fighting with the fists. See duke n. sense 4.

entry.def: To beat with the fists.

sn.def: The territory of a duke.
The title or dignity of a duke.

entry.def: A little or insignificant duke.
The quality or condition of being a duke; also, the personality of a duke.

entry.ety: Russ. dukhobortsy spirit wrestlers; dukh spirit + bortsy wrestlers
entry.def: A Russian religious sect founded about the middle of the 18th century at Kharkov. They believe that Christ was wholly human, but that his soul reappears from time to time in mortals. They accept the Ten Commandments and the “useful” portions of the Bible, but deny the need of rulers, priests, or churches, and have no confessions, icons, or marriage ceremonies. They are communistic, opposed to any violence, and unwilling to use the labor of animals. Driven out of Russia proper, many have emigrated to Cyprus and Canada. See Raskolnik, below.

entry.ety: NL., fr. L. dulcis sweet + amarus bitter
entry.def: A plant (Solanum Dulcamara). See Bittersweet n., 3 .
A glucoside extracted from the bittersweet (Solanum Dulcamara), as a yellow amorphous substance. It probably occasions the compound taste. See Bittersweet, 3.
To make sweet; to soothe.
Sweetness.

entry.ety: OF. doucet, dim. of dous sweet, F. doux, L. dulcis; akin to Gr. � . Cf. Doucet

sn.def: Sweet to the taste; luscious.
sn.q: She tempers dulcet creams.

sn.def: Sweet to the ear; melodious; harmonious.
sn.q: Their dainty lays and dulcet melody.

entry.ety: NL., fr. L. dulcis sweet
entry.def: A sweet-toned stop of an organ.

entry.ety: Cf. F. dulcification
entry.def: The act of dulcifying or sweetening.

cs.cd: a compound of alcohol with mineral acids; as, dulcified spirits of niter.

entry.def: Sweetened; mollified.

entry.ety: L. dulcis sweet + fluere to flow
entry.def: Flowing sweetly.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Dulcified; p. pr. & vb. n. Dulcifying
entry.ety: L. dulcis sweet + -fy: cf. F. dulcifier

sn.def: To sweeten; to free from acidity, saltness, or acrimony.
Fig. : To mollify; to sweeten; to please.
sn.q: As she . . . was further dulcified by her pipe of tobacco.

entry.ety: L. dulcis sweet + loqui to speak
entry.def: A soft manner of speaking.

entry.ety: It. dolcemele,r Sp. dulcemele, fr. L. dulcis sweet + melos song, melody, Gr. �; cf. OF. doulcemele. See Dulcet, and Melody
entry.def: An instrument, having stretched metallic wires which are beaten with two light hammers held in the hands of the performer.
An ancient musical instrument in use among the Jews. Dan. iii. 5. It is supposed to be the same with the psaltery.

entry.ety: Sp., from Dulcinea del Toboso the mistress of the affections of Don Quixote
entry.def: A mistress; a sweetheart.
entry.q: I must ever have some Dulcinea in my head.

entry.def: See Dulceness.
See Dolcino.

entry.ety: Cf. F. dulcite, fr. L. dulcis sweet
entry.def: A white, sugarlike substance, C6H8.(OH)2, occurring naturally in a manna from Madagascar, and in certain plants, and produced artificially by the reduction of galactose and lactose or milk sugar.

entry.ety: L. dulcitudo, fr. dulcis sweet.
entry.def: Sweetness.

entry.ety: L. dulcoratus, p. p. of dulcorare, fr. dulcor sweetness, fr. dulcis sweet
entry.def: To sweeten; to make less acrimonious.

entry.ety: LL. dulcoratio
entry.def: The act of sweetening.
One of the dowels joining the ends of the fellies which form the circle of the wheel of a gun carriage.

entry.ety: LL., fr. Gr. � servitude, fr. � slave
entry.def: An inferior kind of veneration or worship, given to the angels and saints as the servants of God.

entry.ety: AS. dol foolish; akin to gedwelan to err, D. dol mad, dwalen to wander, err, G. toll mad, Goth. dwals foolish, stupid, cf. Gr. � turbid, troubled, Skr. dhvr to cause to fall. Cf. Dolt Dwale Dwell Fraud

sn.def: Slow of understanding; wanting readiness of apprehension; stupid; doltish; blockish.
sn.q: Dullat classical learning.
She is not bred so dull but she can learn.

sn.def: Slow in action; sluggish; unready; awkward.
sn.q: This people's heart is waxed gross, and their ears are dull of hearing.
O, help my weak wit and sharpen my dull tongue.

sn.def: Insensible; unfeeling.
sn.q: Think me not So dull a devil to forget the loss Of such a matchless wife.

sn.def: Not keen in edge or point; lacking sharpness; blunt.
sn.q: Thy scythe isdull.

sn.def: Not bright or clear to the eye; wanting in liveliness of color or luster; not vivid; obscure; dim; as, a dull fire or lamp; a dull red or yellow; a dull mirror.
Heavy; gross; cloggy; insensible; spiritless; lifeless; inert.
sn.q: Thedullearth.
As turning the logs will make a dull fire burn, so changes of study a dull brain.

sn.def: Furnishing little delight, spirit, or variety; uninteresting; tedious; cheerless; gloomy; melancholy; depressing; as, a dull story or sermon; a dull occupation or period; hence, cloudy; overcast; as, a dull day.
sn.q: Along life's dullest, dreariest walk.
sn.syn: Lifeless; inanimate; dead; stupid; doltish; heavy; sluggish; sleepy; drowsy; gross; cheerless; tedious; irksome; dismal; dreary; clouded; tarnished; obtuse. See Lifeless.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Duller; p. pr. & vb. n. Dulling

sn.def: To deprive of sharpness of edge or point.
sn.q: This . . .dulledtheir swords.
Borrowing dulls the edge of husbandry.

sn.def: To make dull, stupid, or sluggish; to stupefy, as the senses, the feelings, the perceptions, and the like.
sn.q: Those [drugs] she has Will stupefy and dull the sense a while.
Use and custom have so dulled our eyes.

sn.def: To render dim or obscure; to sully; to tarnish.
sn.q: Dullsthe mirror.

sn.def: To deprive of liveliness or activity; to render heavy; to make inert; to depress; to weary; to sadden.
sn.q: Attention of mind . . . wasted or dulled through continuance.

entry.def: To become dull or stupid.

entry.ety: Dull + -ard
entry.def: A stupid person; a dunce.
Stupid; doltish.
Having a gloomy look.
One who, or that which, dulls.
Having eyes wanting brightness, liveliness, or vivacity.
A blockhead; a dolt.
Somewhat dull; uninteresting; tiresome.
entry.q: A series ofdullishverses.

entry.def: The state of being dull; slowness; stupidity; heaviness; drowsiness; bluntness; obtuseness; dimness; want of luster; want of vividness, or of brightness.
entry.q: And gentle dullness ever loves a joke.

entry.def: Having poor eyesight.
Dull.
Stupid.
In a dull manner; stupidly; slowly; sluggishly; without life or spirit.
entry.q: Supinely calm and dully innocent.

entry.def: See Doulocracy.

entry.ety: Cf. Gael. duileasg; duille leaf + uisge water. Cf. Whisky
entry.def: A seaweed of a reddish brown color, which is sometimes eaten, as in Scotland. The true dulse is Sarcophyllis edulis; the common is Rhodymenia. dillisk.
entry.q: The crimson leaf of the dulse is seen To blush like a banner bathed in slaughter.

entry.ety: Prob. imitative
entry.def: The ring plover.
In a due, fit, or becoming manner; as it (anything) ought to be; properly; regularly.

entry.ety: L. dumus bramble
entry.def: Pertaining to, or set with, briers or bushes; brambly.

entry.cs:
Deaf and dumb. See Deaf-mute.
Dumb agueorDumb chill
a form of intermittent fever which has no well-defined “chill.” U.S Dumb animal any animal except man; -- usually restricted to a domestic quadruped; -- so called in contradistinction to man, who is a “speaking animal.” Dumb cake a cake made in silence by girls on St. Mark's eve, with certain mystic ceremonies, to discover their future husbands. Halliwell. Dumb cane Bot a west Indian plant of the Arum family (Dieffenbachia seguina), which, when chewed, causes the tongue to swell, and destroys temporarily the power of speech. Dumb crambo. See under crambo. Dumb show. Formerly, a part of a dramatic representation, shown in pantomime. “Inexplicable dumb shows and noise.” Shak. Signs and gestures without words; as, to tell a story in dumb show. To strike dumb to confound; to astonish; to render silent by astonishment; or, it may be, to deprive of the power of speech.
entry.ety: AS. dumb; akin to D. dom stupid, dumb, Sw. dumb, Goth. dumbs; cf. Gr. � blind. See Deaf, and cf. Dummy

sn.def: Destitute of the power of speech; unable; to utter articulate sounds; as, the dumb brutes.
sn.q: To unloose the very tongues even of dumb creatures.

sn.def: Not willing to speak; mute; silent; not speaking; not accompanied by words; as, dumb show.
sn.q: This spirit, dumb to us, will speak to him.
To pierce into the dumb past.

sn.def: Lacking brightness or clearness, as a color.
sn.q: Her stern was painted of a dumb white or dun color.

entry.def: To put to silence.
An exercising weight, consisting of two spheres or spheroids, connected by a short bar for a handle; used (often in pairs) for gymnastic exercise.

sn.def: an ignorant or foolish person.

entry.def: same as dumfound.
entry.syn: confuse, perplex, throw, fox, befuddle, fuddle, bedevil, puzzle, mystify, baffle, bewilder, flummox, stupefy, stupify, nonplus, gravel, amaze, trounce, confound, be confusing to, make confused.

sn.def: same as astounded.
sn.syn: amazed, astonied, astonished, astounded, flabbergasted, stunned, stupefied, thunderstruck.

sn.def: astonished and confounded.

entries.entry: dumbfounding adj. causing astonishment.Narrower terms: incredible (vs. credible), unbelievable astonishing, astounding, dumfounding.

entry.ety: The first part is prob. of imitative origin. See Dor a beetle
entry.def: A bumblebee; also, a cockchafer.
In silence; mutely.
The quality or state of being dumb; muteness; silence; inability to speak.
A framework on which dishes, food, etc., are passed from one room or story of a house to another; a lift for dishes, etc.; also, a piece of furniture with movable or revolving shelves.

entries.entry: Dum"dum bul"let. Mil A kind of man-stopping bullet, designed to fragment inside the body and thus inflict a severed and painful wound; -- so named from Dumdum, in India, where bullets are manufactured for the Indian army.

entry.ety: From L. dumetum a thicket
entry.def: Dumose.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Dumfounded; p. pr. & vb. n. Dumfounding
entry.def: To strike dumb; to confuse with astonishment.
same as dumbfounded.
entry.syn: amazed, astonied, astonished, astounded, flabbergasted, stunned, stupefied, thunderstruck.

entry.def: To dumfound; to confound.
same as dumbfounding.
A dumbledor.
One who feigns dumbness.

entry.cs: Dummy car. See under Car.
entry.ety: See Dumb

sn.def: Silent; mute; noiseless; as a dummy engine.
Fictitious or sham; feigned; as, a dummy watch.

entries.entry:
Dum"my
To play dummy to play the exposed or dummy hand in cards. The partner of the dummy plays it.
n.; pl.Dummies.
One who is dumb.
A sham package in a shop, or one which does not contain what its exterior indicates.
An imitation or copy of something, to be used as a substitute; a model; a lay figure; as, a figure on which clothing is exhibited in shop windows; a blank paper copy used to show the size of the future book, etc.
Drama One who plays a merely nominal part in any action; a sham character.
A thick-witted person; a dolt. Colloq
Railroad A locomotive with condensing engines, and, hence, without the noise of escaping steam; also, a dummy car.
Card Playing The fourth or exposed hand when three persons play at a four-handed game of cards.
A floating barge connected with a pier.

entry.ety: L. dumosus, fr. dumus a thornbush, a bramble

sn.def: Abounding with bushes and briers.
Having a compact, bushy form.

entry.ety: See Dumpling
entry.def: A thick, ill-shapen piece; a clumsy leaden counter used by boys in playing chuck farthing.

entry.note: ☞ The ludicrous associations now attached to this word did not originally belong to it. “Holland's translation of Livy represents the Romans as being `in the dumps' after the battle of Cannæ.”
entry.ety: Cf. dial. Sw. dumpin melancholy, Dan.dump dull, low, D. dompig damp, G. dumpf damp, dull, gloomy, and E. damp, or rather perh. dump, v. t. Cf. Damp, or Dump v. t.

sn.def: A dull, gloomy state of the mind; sadness; melancholy; low spirits or a mild depression; despondency; ill humor; -- now used only in the plural.
sn.q: March slowly on in solemn dump.
Doleful dumps the mind oppress.
I was musing in the midst of my dumps.

sn.def: Absence of mind; revery.
A melancholy strain or tune in music; any tune.
sn.q: Tune a deploringdump.
Play me some merrydump.

sn.def: An old kind of dance.

cs.cd: a railway car, or a cart, the body of which can be tilted to empty the contents; -- called also dump car, or dump cart.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Dumped; p. pr. & vb. n. Dumping
entry.ety: OE. dumpen to throw down, fall down, cf. Icel. dumpa to thump, Dan. dumpe to fall suddenly, rush, dial. Sw. dimpa to fall down plump. Cf. Dump sadness

sn.def: To knock heavily; to stump.
To put or throw down with more or less of violence; hence, to unload from a cart by tilting it; as, to dump sand, coal, etc.
A car or boat for dumping refuse, etc.
A ground or place for dumping ashes, refuse, etc.
That which is dumped.
A pile of ore or rock.

entry.def: a coarse term for defecation.

sn.def: The act of dumping loads from carts, especially loads of refuse matter; also, a heap of dumped matter.
A fee paid for the privilege of dumping loads; called in some cases tipping fee.

entry.def: a cart that can be tilted to empty the contents without handling them.
same as dump car.

sn.def: p. p. of dump v. t.; as, The money was there, dumped all over the floor.

entry.def: same as dump truck.
The state of being dumpy.
Dull; stupid; sad; moping; melancholy.
entry.q: A . . .dumpishand sour life.

entry.ety: See Dumpling
entry.def: To make dumpy; to fold, or bend, as one part over another.
entry.q: He was a little man, dumpled up together.

entry.ety: Dimin. of dump an illshapen piece; cf. D. dompelen to plunge, dip, duck, Scot. to dump in to plunge into, and E. dump, v. t
entry.def: A roundish mass of dough boiled in soup, or as a sort of pudding; often, a cover of paste inclosing an apple or other fruit, and boiled or baked; as, an apple dumpling .
a gloomy mental state; same as 2nd dump{1; -- used mostly in the phrase “in the dumps”.
a truck, usually with an open top, the carrying bopdy of which can be tilted so as to emptied its contents without handling.

entry.ety: From Dump a short ill-shapen piece. From Dump sadness

sn.def: Short and thick; of low stature and disproportionately stout.
Sullen or discontented. See 2nd dump{1.

entries.entry: Dump"y lev"el. Surv A level having a short telescope (hence its name) rigidly fixed to a table capable only of rotatory movement in a horizontal plane. The telescope is usually an inverting one. It is sometimes called the Troughton level , from the name of the inventor, and a variety improved by one Gavatt is known as the Gavatt level .

entry.def: the Sumerian and Babylonian god of pastures and vegetation; consort of Inanna.

entry.ety: See Dune
entry.def: A mound or small hill.
To cure, as codfish, in a particular manner, by laying them, after salting, in a pile in a dark place, covered with salt grass or some like substance.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Dunned dŭnd; p. pr. & vb. n. Dunning dŭn"nĭng
entry.ety: AS. dyne noise, dynian to make a noise, or fr. Icel. dynr duna, noise, thunder, duna to thunder; the same word as E. din. √74. See Din
entry.def: To ask or beset (e.g., a debtor), for payment; to urge importunately.
entry.q: Hath she sent so soon to dun?

sn.def: One who duns; a dunner.
sn.q: To be pulled by the sleeve by some rascally dun.

sn.def: An urgent request or demand of payment; as, he sent his debtor a dun .

cs.cd: the hooded crow; -- so called from its color; -- also called hoody, and hoddy.
the goosander or merganser.

entry.ety: AS. dunn, of Celtic origin; cf. W. dwn, Ir. & Gael. donn
entry.def: Of a dark color; of a color partaking of a brown and black; of a dull brown color; swarthy.
entry.q: Summer's dun cloud comes thundering up.
Chill and dun Falls on the moor the brief November day.

entry.ety: Named from its color
entry.def: The pochard; -- called also dunair, and dunker, or dun-curre.
An American duck; the ruddy duck.

entry.note: ☞ The schoolmen were often called, after their great leader Duns Scotus, Dunsmen or Duncemen. In the revival of learning they were violently opposed to classical studies; hence, the name of Dunce was applied with scorn and contempt to an opposer of learning, or to one slow at learning, a dullard.
entry.ety: From Joannes Duns Scotus, a schoolman called the Subtle Doctor, who died in 1308. Originally in the phrase “a Duns man”. See Note below
entry.def: One backward in book learning; a child or other person dull or weak in intellect; a dullard; a dolt.
entry.q: I never knew this town without dunces of figure.

entry.def: The realm or domain of dunces.
Dullness; stupidity.
Like a dunce; duncish.
entry.q: The most dull and duncical commissioner.

entry.ety: Dunce + -fy
entry.def: To make stupid in intellect.
Somewhat like a dunce.

entry.ety: Cf. Sp. redundar to overflow
entry.def: The lees or dregs of cane juice, used in the distillation of rum.
entry.q: The use of dunder in the making of rum answers the purpose of yeast in the fermentation of flour.

entry.ety: Prov. Eng. also dunderpoll, from dunder, same as thunder
entry.def: A dunce; a numskull; a blockhead.
Thick-headed; stupid.
See Dunderhead.

entry.ety: The same word as down: cf. D. duin. See Down a bank of sand
entry.def: A low hill of drifting sand usually formed on the coats, but often carried far inland by the prevailing winds.
entry.q: Three great rivers, the Rhine, the Meuse, and the Scheldt, had deposited their slime for ages among the dunes or sand banks heaved up by the ocean around their mouths.

entry.def: Codfish cured in a particular manner, so as to be of a superior quality.

entry.ety: AS. dung; akin to G. dung dünger, OHG. tunga, Sw. dynga; cf. Icel. dyngja heap, Dan. dynge, MHG. tunc underground dwelling place, orig., covered with dung. Cf. Dingy
entry.def: The excrement of an animal.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Dunged; p. pr. & vb. n. Dunging

sn.def: To manure with dung.
To immerse or steep, as calico, in a bath of hot water containing cow dung; -- done to remove the superfluous mordant.

entry.def: To void excrement.

sn.def: A coarse kind of unbleached cotton fabric; blue denim.
Trousers, overalls or similar work clothes made of blue denim.
Same as blue jeans.

entry.ety: OE. donjoun highest tower of a castle, tower, prison, F. donjon tower or platform in the midst of a castle, turret, or closet on the top of a house, a keep of a castle, LL. domnio, the same word as LL. dominus lord. See Dame Don, and cf. Dominion Domain Demesne Danger Donjon
entry.def: A close, dark prison, commonly, under ground, as if the lower apartments of the donjon or keep of a castle, these being used as prisons.
entry.q: Down with him even into the deep dungeon.
Year after year he lay patiently in a dungeon.

entry.def: To shut up in a dungeon.
A fork for tossing dung.

cs.cd: a domestic fowl of common breed.

sn.def: A heap of dung.
Any mean situation or condition; a vile abode.
sn.q: He . . . lifteth up the beggar from the dunghill.

entry.ety: Dung + (probmeer a pool
entry.def: A pit where dung and weeds rot for manure.
Full of dung; filthy; vile; low.
A yard where dung is collected.

entry.note: ☞ The denomination was founded in Germany in 1708, but after a few years the members emigrated to the United States; they were opposed to military service and taking legal oaths, and practiced trine immersion.

cs.cd: a sect which separated from the Dunkers and formed a community, in 1728. They keep the seventh day or Saturday as the Sabbath.

entry.ety: G. tunken to dip
entry.def: One of a religious denomination whose tenets and practices are mainly those of the Baptists, but partly those of the Quakers; -- called also Tunkers Dunkards Dippers, and, by themselves, Brethren, and German Baptists, and they call their denomination the Church of the Brethren.

the name of a town and a battle fought there, in World War II (1940) when 330,000 Allied troops had to be evacuated from the beaches at Dunkirk in a desperate retreat under enemy fire. Most of the forces were safely evacuated to England.

the name of a town and a battle fought there, in World War II (1940) when 330,000 Allied troops had to be evacuated from the beaches at Dunkirk in a desperate retreat under enemy fire. Most of the forces were safely evacuated to England.

entry.ety: Prob. of Celtic origin; cf. Gael. dun hill (E. dune), and linne pool, pond, lake, E. lin
entry.def: A species of sandpiper (Tringa alpina); -- called also churr dorbie grass bird, and red-backed sandpiper. It is found both in Europe and America.

entry.ety: Cf. Dun a mound
entry.def: Fagots, boughs, or loose materials of any kind, laid on the bottom of the hold for the cargo to rest upon to prevent injury by water, or stowed among casks and other cargo to prevent their motion.

entry.ety: From Dun to ask payment from
entry.def: One employed in soliciting the payment of debts.
Inclined to a dun color.

entry.ety: Cf. Dun,a.
entry.def: The hedge sparrow or hedge accentor.
Deaf; stupid.
entry.q: My old dame Joan is something dunny, and will scarce know how to manage.

entry.def: A blow.
Beaten; hence, blunted.
entry.q: Fencer's swords . . . having the edge dunted.

cs.cd: the eider duck.

entry.def: A porpoise.

entry.ety: It. duo, fr. L. duo two. See Duet
entry.def: A composition for two performers; a duet.
See Dodecahedral, and Dodecahedron.

entry.ety: L. duodecennis; duodecim twelve + annus year
entry.def: Consisting of twelve years.

entry.ety: L. duodecim twelve. See Dozen
entry.def: Proceeding in computation by twelves; expressed in the scale of twelves.

sn.def: A twelfth part; as, the duodecimals of an inch.
A system of numbers, whose denominations rise in a scale of twelves, as of feet and inches. The system is used chiefly by artificers in computing the superficial and solid contents of their work.

entry.ety: L. duodecim twelve + findere to cleave
entry.def: Divided into twelve parts.

entry.ety: L. in duodecimo in twelfth, fr. duodecimus twelfth fr. duodecim twelve. See Dozen
entry.def: Having twelve leaves to a sheet; as, a duodecimo from, book, leaf, size, etc.

entries.entry: Du*o*dec"i*mo n.; pl.Duodecimos. A book consisting of sheets each of which is folded into twelve leaves; hence, indicating, more or less definitely, a size of a book; -- usually written 12mo or 12°.

entry.ety: L. duo two + � decuple
entry.def: Consisting of twelves.

entry.ety: Cf. F. duodénal
entry.def: Of or pertaining to the duodenum; as, duodenal digestion.

entry.ety: L. duodenarius, fr. duodeni twelve each: cf. F. duodénaire
entry.def: Containing twelve; twelvefold; increasing by twelves; duodecimal.

entry.ety: NL., fr. duodeni twelve each: cf. F. duodenum. So called because its length is about twelve fingers' breadth
entry.def: The part of the small intestines between the stomach and the jejunum. See Illust. of Digestive apparatus, under Digestive.

entry.ety: L. duo two + -graph
entry.def: A picture printed from two half-tone plates made with the screen set at different angles, and usually printed in two shades of the same color or in black and one tint.

entry.ety: L. duo two + E. literal
entry.def: Consisting of two letters only; biliteral.

entry.ety: It. See Done
entry.def: A cathedral. See Dome, 2.
entry.q: Of tower or duomo, sunny sweet.

entry.ety: L. duo two + tone
entry.def: Any picture printed in two shades of the same color, as duotypes and duographs are usually printed.

entry.ety: L. duo two + type
entry.def: A print made from two half-tone plates made from the same negative, but etched differently.

entry.ety: Contr. fr. do up, that is, to lift up the latch. Cf. Don Doff
entry.def: To open; as, to dup the door.
Capable of being duped.

entry.ety: F., prob. from Prov. F. dupe dube; of unknown origin; equiv. to F. huppe hoopoe, a foolish bird, easily caught. Cf. Armor. houpérik hoopoe, a man easily deceived. Cf. also Gull Booby
entry.def: One who has been deceived or who is easily deceived; a gull; as, the dupe of a schemer.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Duped dūpt; p. pr. & vb. n. Duping
entry.ety: Cf. F. duper, fr. dupe. See Dupe n.
entry.def: To deceive; to trick; to mislead by imposing on one's credulity; to gull; as, dupe one by flattery.
entry.q: Ne'er have I duped him with base counterfeits.

entry.def: One who dupes another.

entry.ety: F. duperie, fr. duper
entry.def: The act or practice of duping.

entry.ety: F. doupion, It. doppione, fr. doppio double, L. duplus. See Double, and cf. Doubloon
entry.def: A double cocoon, made by two silkworms.

cs.cd: that in which the antecedent term is double the consequent, as of 2 to 1, 8 to 4, etc.

entry.ety: L. duplus. See Double
entry.def: Double.

cs.cd: a peculiar kind of watch escapement, in which the scape-wheel has two sets of teeth. See Escapement.
one for turning off, screwing, and surfacing, by means of two cutting tools, on opposite sides of the piece operated upon.
a steam pump in which two steam cylinders are placed side by side, one operating the valves of the other.
a complaint in the nature of an appeal from the ordinary to his immediate superior, as from a bishop to an archbishop.
a system of telegraphy for sending two messages over the same wire simultaneously.
one with a duplex escapement.
arranged so that the information may be transmitted in both directions, but only in one direction at a time; -- of communications channels between computers; contrasted with full duplex(a.
arranged so that the information transmitted to the remote computer also appears on the local terminal; -- of communications channels between computers; contrasted with full duplex(b.
arranged so that the information may be transmitted in both directions simultaneously; -- of communications channels between computers; contrasted with half duplex(a.
arranged so that the information transmitted to the remote computer does not appear on the local terminal; -- of communications channels between computers; contrasted with half duplex(b.

entry.ety: L., fr. duo two + plicare to fold. See Two, and Complex

sn.def: Double; twofold.
organized so that data may be transmitted in two opposite directions over the same channel; -- of communications channels, such as data transfer lines between computers.

entry.ety: See Duplex a.
entry.def: To arrange, as a telegraph line, so that two messages may be transmitted simultaneously; to equip with a duplex telegraphic outfit.

entry.ety: See Duplex a.

sn.def: something which is duplex; -- used mostly in reference to a living unit, such as an apartment, in a building having two similar living units.
a double-stranded region in a nucleic acid molecule. See deoxyribonucleic acid.

entry.def: a device which switches electronic circuitry so that a radio antenna can function as either a transmitting or receiving antenna.
the quality of being reproducible.
capable of being duplicated.

cs.cd: the proportion or ratio of squares. Thus, in geometrical proportion, the first term to the third is said to be in a duplicate ratio of the first to the second, or as its square is to the square of the second. Thus, in 2, 4, 8, 16, the ratio of 2 to 8 is a duplicate of that of 2 to 4, or as the square of 2 is to the square of 4.

entry.ety: L. duplicatus, p. p. of duplicare to double, fr. duplex double, twofold. See Duplex
entry.def: Double; twofold.

sn.def: That which exactly resembles or corresponds to something else; another, correspondent to the first; hence, a copy; a transcript; a counterpart.
sn.q: I send a duplicate both of it and my last dispatch.

sn.def: An original instrument repeated; a document which is the same as another in all essential particulars, and differing from a mere copy in having all the validity of an original.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Duplicated; p. pr. & vb. n. Duplicating

sn.def: To double; to fold; to render double.
To make a duplicate of (something); to make a copy or transcript of.
To divide into two by natural growth or spontaneous action; as, infusoria duplicate themselves.

cs.cd: the operation of finding a cube having a volume which is double that of a given cube.

entry.ety: L. duplicatio: cf. F. duplication

sn.def: The act of duplicating, or the state of being duplicated; a doubling; a folding over; a fold.
The act or process of dividing by natural growth or spontaneous action; as, the duplication of cartilage cells.
Having the quality of duplicating or doubling.
Having the quality of subdividing into two by natural growth.
sn.q: Duplicativesubdivision.

entry.ety: Cf. F. duplicature
entry.def: A doubling; a fold, as of a membrane.
exhibiting duplicity{2}; deceitful; double-dealing.

entries.entry:
du*plic"i*ty n.; pl.duplicities #. F. duplicité, L. duplicitas, fr. duplex double. See Duplex
Doubleness; a twofold state. Archaic Do not affect duplicities nor triplicities, nor any certain number of parts in your division of things.
Doubleness of heart or speech; insincerity; a sustained form of deception which consists in entertaining or pretending to entertain one set of feelings, and acting as if influenced by another; bad faith. Far from the duplicity wickedly charged on him, he acted his part with alacrity and resolution.
Law
The use of two or more distinct allegations or answers, where one is sufficient. Blackstone.
In indictments, the union of two incompatible offenses. Double dealing; dissimulation; deceit; guile; deception; falsehood.

entry.def: See 2d Dubber.

entry.ety: G., fr. L. durus hard, firm, vigorous
entry.def: Major; in the major mode; as, C dur, that is, C major.
Short form for Dura mater.

entry.ety: L. durabilitas
entry.def: The state or quality of being durable; the power of uninterrupted or long continuance in any condition; the power of resisting agents or influences which tend to cause changes, decay, or dissolution; lastingness.
entry.q: A Gothic cathedral raises ideas of grandeur in our minds by the size, its height, . . . its antiquity, and its durability.

entry.ety: L. durabilis, fr. durare to last: cf. F. durable. See Dure
entry.def: Able to endure or continue in a particular condition; lasting; not perishable or changeable; not wearing out or decaying soon; enduring; as, durable cloth; durable happiness.
entry.q: Riches and honor are with me; yea, durable riches and righteousness.
An interest which from its object and grounds must be so durable.
entry.syn: Lasting; permanent; enduring; firm; stable; continuing; constant; persistent. See Lasting.

entry.def: Power of lasting, enduring, or resisting; durability.
entry.q: The durableness of the metal that supports it.

entry.def: In a lasting manner; with long continuance.
Pertaining to the dura, or dura mater.

entry.ety: a trademark
entry.def: an aluminum-based alloy which is both light and strong, containing 4 per cent of copper and 0.5 per cent of magnesium and smaller amounts of iron, manganese, and silicon. It hardens with aging at room temperature.

entries.entry: Du"ra ma"ter Du"ra ma"ter. L., lit., hard mother. The membrane was called mater, or mother, because it was formerly thought to give rise to every membrane of the body Anat The tough, fibrous membrane, which lines the cavity of the skull and spinal column, and surrounds the brain and spinal cord; -- frequently abbreviated to dura.

entry.ety: L., hardness, a hardened, i. e., ligneous, vine branch, fr. durare to harden. See Dure
entry.def: The heartwood of an exogenous tree.

entry.ety: OF. durance duration, fr. L. durans -antis, p. pr. durare to endure, last. See Dure, and cf. Durant

sn.def: Continuance; duration. See Endurance.
sn.q: Of how short durance was this new-made state!

sn.def: Imprisonment; restraint of the person; custody by a jailer; duress. Shak.
sn.q: Durancevile.
In durance, exile, Bedlam or the mint.

sd.def: A stout cloth stuff, formerly made in imitation of buff leather and used for garments; a sort of tammy or everlasting.
sd.q: Where didst thou buy this buff? let me not live but I will give thee a good suit of durance.

sd.def: In modern manufacture, a worsted of one color used for window blinds and similar purposes.

entry.def: Duration.

entry.ety: F. durant, p. pr. of durer to last. Cf. Durance
entry.def: See Durance, 3.

entry.ety: L., abl. case of the p. pr. of durare to last
entry.def: During; as, durante vita, during life; durante bene placito, during pleasure.

entry.ety: OF. duration. See Dure
entry.def: The state or quality of lasting; continuance in time; the portion of time during which anything exists.
entry.q: It was proposed that the duration of Parliament should be limited.
Soon shall have passed our own human duration.

entry.def: Continuing; not completed; implying duration.
entry.q: Its durative tense, which expresses the thought of it as going on.

entry.ety: Hind. darbār, fr. Per dar�ār house, court, hall of audience; dar door, gate + bār court, assembly
entry.def: An audience hall; the court of a native prince; a state levee; a formal reception of native princes, given by the governor general of India.

entry.ety: L. durus; akin to Ir. & Gael. dur �, stubborn, W. dir certain, sure, cf. Gr. � force
entry.def: Hard; harsh; severe; rough; toilsome.
entry.q: The winter is severe, and life is dure and rude.

entry.ety: F. durer, L. durare to harden, be hardened, to endure, last, fr. durus hard. See Dure a.
entry.def: To last; to continue; to endure.
entry.q: Yet hath he not root in himself, but dureth for a while.

entry.def: Lasting.
Not lasting.

entry.ety: L. durus hard; -- so called because solid at ordinary temperatures.]
entry.def: A colorless, crystalline, aromatic hydrocarbon, C6H2(CH3)4, off artificial production, with an odor like camphor.

entry.ety: OF. duresse du�, hardship, severity, L. duritia durities, fr. durus hard. See Dure

sn.def: Hardship; constraint; pressure; imprisonment; restraint of liberty.
sn.q: The agreements . . . made with the landlords during the time of slavery, are only the effect of duress and force.

sn.def: The state of compulsion or necessity in which a person is influenced, whether by the unlawful restrain of his liberty or by actual or threatened physical violence, to incur a civil liability or to commit an offense.

entry.def: To subject to duress.
entry.q: The partyduressed.

entry.def: One who subjects another to duress
Same as Doorga.
One or a breed of short-horned cattle, originating in the county of Durham, England. The Durham cattle are noted for their beef-producing quality.

The fruit of the durio. It is oval or globular, and eight or ten inches long. It has a hard prickly rind, containing a soft, cream-colored pulp, of a most delicious flavor and a very offensive odor. The seeds are roasted and eaten like chestnuts.

entry.ety: Orig., p. pr. of dure
entry.def: In the time of; as long as the action or existence of; as, during life; during the space of a year.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Malay d�ri thorn
entry.def: A fruit tree (Durio zibethinus, the only species known) of the Indian Archipelago. It bears the durian.

entry.ety: L. duritas, fr. durus hard

sn.def: Hardness; firmness.
Harshness; cruelty.

entry.ety: L. durus hard + -meter
entry.def: An instrument for measuring the degree of hardness; especially, an instrument for testing the relative hardness of steel rails and the like.

entry.ety: L. durus
entry.def: Hard.

entry.ety: Ar. dhorra
entry.def: A kind of millet, cultivated throughout Asia, and introduced into the south of Europe; a variety of Sorghum vulgare; -- called also Indian millet, and Guinea corn.
of Dare. See Dare v. i.
A small, nocturnal, South American monkey of the genus Aotusformerly Nyctipthecus trivirgatus). The owl monkey. See douroucouli.
Pertaining to, allied to, or derived from, durene; as, durylic acid.
A demon or spirit. See Deuce.

entry.ety: OE. dusc dosc deosc; cf. dial. Sw. duska to drizzle, dusk a slight shower. ���
entry.def: Tending to darkness or blackness; moderately dark or black; dusky.
entry.q: A pathless desert, dusk with horrid shades.

sn.def: Imperfect obscurity; a middle degree between light and darkness; twilight; as, the dusk of the evening.
A darkish color.
sn.q: Whose duck set off the whiteness of the skin.

entry.def: To make dusk.
entry.q: After the sun is up, that shadow which dusketh the light of the moon must needs be under the earth.

entry.def: To grow dusk.
To make dusk or obscure.
entry.q: Not utterly defaced, but only duskened.

entry.def: In a dusky manner.
The state of being dusky.
Somewhat dusky.
entry.q: Duskishsmoke.

entry.def: Duskiness.

sn.def: Partially dark or obscure; not luminous; dusk; as, a dusky valley.
sn.q: Through dusky lane and wrangling mart.

sn.def: Tending to blackness in color; partially black; dark-colored; not bright; as, a dusky brown.
sn.q: When Jove in dusky clouds involves the sky.
The figure of that first ancestor invested by family tradition with a dim and dusky grandeur.

sn.def: Gloomy; sad; melancholy.
sn.q: This dusky scene of horror, this melancholy prospect.

sn.def: Intellectually clouded.
sn.q: Though dusky wits dare scorn astrology.

entry.cs:
Down with the dust deposit the cash; pay down the money. Slang “My lord, quoth the king, presently deposit your hundred pounds in gold, or else no going hence all the days of your life. . . . The Abbot down with his dust, and glad he escaped so, returned to Reading.” Fuller. Dust brand Bot a fungous plant (Ustilago Carbo); -- called also smut. Gold dust fine particles of gold, such as are obtained in placer mining; -- often used as money, being transferred by weight. In dust and ashes. See under Ashes. To bite the dust. See under Bite v. t.
To raise dustorTo kick up dust to make a commotion. Colloq To throw dust in one's eyes to mislead; to deceive. Colloq
entry.ety: AS. dust; cf. LG. dust, D. duist meal dust, OD. doest donst, and G. dunst vapor, OHG. tunist dunist, a blowing, wind, Icel. dust dust, Dan. dyst mill dust; perh. akin to L. fumus smoke, E. fume. √71

sn.def: Fine, dry particles of earth or other matter, so comminuted that they may be raised and wafted by the wind; that which is crumbled to minute portions; fine powder; as, clouds of dust; bone dust.
sn.q: Dust thou art, and unto dust shalt thou return.
Stop! -- for thy tread is on an empire's dust.

sn.def: A single particle of earth or other matter.
sn.q: To touch adustof England's ground.

sn.def: The earth, as the resting place of the dead.
sn.q: For now shall sleep in the dust.

sn.def: The earthy remains of bodies once alive; the remains of the human body.
sn.q: And you may carve a shrine about my dust.

sn.def: Figuratively, a worthless thing.
sn.q: And by the merit of vile gold, dross, dust.

sn.def: Figuratively, a low or mean condition.
sn.q: God] raiseth up the poor out of the dust.

entry.sn: Gold dust; hence: (Slang Coined money; cash.

cs.cd: to give one a flogging.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Dusted; p. pr. & vb. n. Dusting

sn.def: To free from dust; to brush, wipe, or sweep away dust from; as, to dust a table or a floor.
To sprinkle with dust.
To reduce to a fine powder; to levigate.

entry.def: a bin that holds rubbish until it is collected.
entry.syn: ashcan, trash can, garbage can, wastebin, ashbin, trash barrel, trash bin.

entry.def: A brush of feathers, bristles, or hair, for removing dust from furniture.
a truck for collecting domestic refuse; as, in England a garbage truck is called a dustcart .
A piece of cloth used for wiping dust from objects or surfaces.

sn.def: One who, or that which, dusts; a utensil that frees from dust.

sd.def: A revolving wire-cloth cylinder which removes the dust from rags, etc.
A blowing machine for separating the flour from the bran.
A dustcloth or a brush used for removing dust from objects or surfaces.

sn.def: A long light overgarment;

sd.def: a light over-garment, formerly worn when traveling in open vehicles to protect the clothing from dust.
A light housecoat worn by women.
A light overcoat worn by women, often having no lining.

sn.def: A device for spreading a powder, especially one for spreading insecticide on plants.
A pitch intentionally thrown by a pitcher directly at or very close to the batter, intended to make the batter stand further away from home plate; also called a dust-back pitch or a dust-back.
A dust storm.

entry.def: The state of being dusty.
Without dust; as a dustless path.

entries.entry: dust"man dŭst"măn n.; pl.dustmen dŭst"mĕn. One whose employment is to remove dirt and refuse; a garbage man.

entry.def: a dry mop for dusting floors.
A shovel-like utensil with a short handle used for conveying away dust brushed from the floor.
An old rural game.
entry.q: With any boy at dust-point they shall play.

entry.def: A strong windstorm that lifts particles of dust or dry soil into the air and blows them around, covering land or objects with a thick layer of dust. Dust storms may occur in arable areas during periods of drought; when a similar storm occurs in a desert area, such a storm is called a sandstorm.
an angry dispute.

cs.cd: a plant (Cineraria maritima); -- so called because of the ashy-white coating of its leaves.

entry.amorph: Compar. Dustier dŭst"ĭ*ẽr; superl. Dustiest dŭst"ĭ*ĕst
entry.ety: AS. dystig. See Dust

sn.def: Filled, covered, or sprinkled with dust; clouded with dust; as, a dusty table; a dusty attic; also, reducing to dust.
sn.q: And all our yesterdays have lighted fools The way to dusty death.

sn.def: Like dust; of the color of dust; as, a dusty white.

entry.cs:
Dutch auction. See under Auction. Dutch cheese a small, pound, hard cheese, made from skim milk. Dutch clinker a kind of brick made in Holland. It is yellowish, very hard, and long and narrow in shape. Dutch clover Bot common white clover (Trifolium repens), the seed of which was largely imported into England from Holland. Dutch concert a so-called concert in which all the singers sing at the same time different songs. Slang Dutch courage the courage of partial intoxication. Slang Marryat. Dutch door a door divided into two parts, horizontally, so arranged that the lower part can be shut and fastened, while the upper part remains open.
Dutch foil Dutch leaforDutch gold
a kind of brass rich in copper, rolled or beaten into thin sheets, used in Holland to ornament toys and paper; -- called also Dutch mineral Dutch metal brass foil, and bronze leaf. Dutch liquid Chem a thin, colorless, volatile liquid, C2H4Cl2, of a sweetish taste and a pleasant ethereal odor, produced by the union of chlorine and ethylene or olefiant gas; -- called also Dutch oil. It is so called because discovered (in 1795) by an association of four Hollandish chemists. See Ethylene, and Olefiant.
Dutch oven a tin screen for baking before an open fire or kitchen range; also, in the United States, a shallow iron kettle for baking, with a cover to hold burning coals. Dutch pink chalk, or whiting dyed yellow, and used in distemper, and for paper staining. etc. Weale. Dutch rush Bot a species of horsetail rush or Equisetum Equisetum hyemale) having a rough, siliceous surface, and used for scouring and polishing; -- called also scouring rush, and shave grass. See Equisetum. Dutch tile a glazed and painted ornamental tile, formerly much exported, and used in the jambs of chimneys and the like.
entry.note: ☞ Dutch was formerly used for German.
entry.ety:
D. duitsch German; or G. deutsch, orig., popular, national, OD. dietsc, MHG. diutsch tiutsch, OHG. diutisk, fr. diot diota, a people, a nation; akin to AS. peód, OS. thiod thioda, Goth. piuda; cf. Lith. tauta land, OIr. tuath people, Oscan
touto. The English have applied the name especially to the Germanic people living nearest them, the Hollanders. Cf. Derrick Teutonic
entry.def: Pertaining to Holland, or to its inhabitants.
entry.q: Germany is slandered to have sent none to this war [the Crusades] at this first voyage; and that other pilgrims, passing through that country, were mocked by the Dutch, and called fools for their pains.

sn.def: The people of Holland; Dutchmen.
The language spoken in Holland.

entries.entry:
Dutch"man
Dutchman's laudanum Bot a West Indian passion flower (Passiflora Murucuja); also, its fruit. Dutchman's pipe Bot .
n.; pl.Dutchmen. A native, or one of the people, of Holland.

entry.def: a delicate perennial spring-flowering herb (Dicentra cucullaria) of eastern U.S., having peculiar double-spurred white flowers. See Illust. of Dicentra

a hardy deciduous American vine (Aristolochia durior) having large, heart-shaped leaves and bearing brownish-purple flowers which have their calyx tubes curved like the bowl of a tobacco pipe. Formerly classified as Aristolochia Sipho.
entry.syn: pipe vine, Aristolochia macrophylla Aristolochia durior.

entry.ety: From Duty

sn.def: Fulfilling duty; dutiful; having the sentiments due to a superior, or to one to whom respect or service is owed; obedient; as, a duteous son or daughter.
Subservient; obsequious.
sn.q: Duteous to the vices of thy mistress.

entry.ety: From Duty
entry.def: Subject to the payment of a duty; as dutiable goods.
entry.q: All kinds of dutiable merchandise.

entry.def: Subjected to a duty.

sn.def: Performing, or ready to perform, the duties required by one who has the right to claim submission, obedience, or deference; submissive to natural or legal superiors; obedient, as to parents or superiors; as, a dutiful son or daughter; a dutiful ward or servant; a dutiful subject.
Controlled by, proceeding from, a sense of duty; respectful; deferential; as, dutiful affection.
sn.syn: Duteous; obedient; reverent; reverential; submissive; docile; respectful; compliant.

entries.entry:
Du"ty ☞ An impost on land or other real estate, and on the stock of farmers, is not called a duty, but a direct tax. U.S
Ad valorem duty a duty which is graded according to the cost, or market value, of the article taxed. See Ad valorem. Specific duty a duty of a specific sum assessed on an article without reference to its value or market. On duty actually engaged in the performance of one's assigned task.
n.; pl.Duties #. From Due
