That which is due; payment. Obs. as signifying a material thing When thou receivest money for thy labor or ware, thou receivest thy duty.
That which a person is bound by moral obligation to do, or refrain from doing; that which one ought to do; service morally obligatory. Forgetting his duty toward God, his sovereign lord, and his country.
Hence, any assigned service or business; as, the duties of a policeman, or a soldier; to be on duty.
With records sweet of duties done. To employ him on the hardest and most imperative duty.
Duty is a graver term than obligation. A duty hardly exists to do trivial things; but there may be an obligation to do them.
Specifically, obedience or submission due to parents and superiors.
Respect; reverence; regard; act of respect; homage. Mydutyto you.
Engin The efficiency of an engine, especially a steam pumping engine, as measured by work done by a certain quantity of fuel; usually, the number of pounds of water lifted one foot by one bushel of coal (94 lbs. old standard), or by 1 cwt. (112 lbs., England, or 100 lbs., United States).
Com Tax, toll, impost, or customs; excise; any sum of money required by government to be paid on the importation, exportation, or consumption of goods.
Du*um"vir Du*um"vir n.; pl. E. Duumvirs #, L. Duumviri #. L., fr. duo two + vir man Rom. Antiq One of two Roman officers or magistrates united in the same public functions.

entry.ety: L. duumviralis
entry.def: Of or belonging to the duumviri or the duumvirate.

entry.ety: L. duumviratus, fr. duumvir
entry.def: The union of two men in the same office; or the office, dignity, or government of two men thus associated, as in ancient Rome.

entry.ety: L., leader
entry.def: The scholastic name for the theme or subject of a fugue, the answer being called the comes, or companion.

entry.ety: D. duiker diver + bok a buck, lit., diver buck. So named from its habit of diving suddenly into the bush
entry.def: A small South African antelope (Cephalous mergens); -- called also impoon, and deloo.
See Dugong.

entries.entry: D" valve`. Mech A kind of slide valve. See Slide valve, under Slide.

Dver"gr Dver"gr n.; pl.Dvergar #. See Dwarf
Scand. Myth A dwarf supposed to dwell in rocks and hills and to be skillful in working metals.

entry.ety: OE. dwale dwole, deception, deadly nightshade, AS. dwala dwola, error, doubt; akin to E. dull. See Dull a.

sn.def: The deadly nightshade (Atropa Belladonna), having stupefying qualities.
The tincture sable or black when blazoned according to the fantastic system in which plants are substituted for the tinctures.
A sleeping potion; an opiate.

entry.ety: Cf. D. dwingen to force, compel

sn.def: A piece of wood set between two studs, posts, etc., to stiffen and support them.

sd.def: A kind of crowbar.
A large wrench.

entries.entry:
Dwarf ☞ During the Middle Ages dwarfs as well as fools shared the favor of courts and the nobility.
Dwarf is used adjectively in reference to anything much below the usual or normal size; as, a dwarf pear tree; dwarf honeysuckle.
Dwarf elder Bot danewort. Dwarf wall Arch a low wall, not as high as the story of a building, often used as a garden wall or fence. Gwilt.
n.; pl.Dwarfs #. OE. dwergh dwerf dwarf, AS. dweorg dweorh; akin to D. dwerg, MHG. twerc, G. zwerg, Icel. dvergr, Sw. & Dan. dverg; of unknown origin
An animal or plant which is much below the ordinary size of its species or kind.
Especially: A diminutive human being, small in stature due to a pathological condition which causes a distortion of the proportions of body parts to each other, such as the limbs, torso, and head. A person of unusually small height who has normal body proportions is usually called a midget.
Folklore A small, usually misshapen person, typically a man, who may have magical powers; mythical dwarves were often depicted as living underground in caves.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Dwarfed; p. pr. & vb. n. Dwarfing
entry.def: To hinder from growing to the natural size; to make or keep small; to stunt.
entry.q: Even the most common moral ideas and affections . . . would be stunted and dwarfed, if cut off from a spiritual background.

entry.def: To become small; to diminish in size.
entry.q: Strange power of the world that, the moment we enter it, our great conceptions dwarf.

entry.def: Like a dwarf; below the common stature or size; very small; petty; as, a dwarfish animal, shrub.
A diminutive dwarf.
Much undersized.

entry.ety: See Dull Dwell
entry.def: To be delirious.

entry.cs:
To dwell in to abide in (a place); hence, to depend on. “My hopes in heaven to dwell.” Shak.
To dwell onorTo dwell upon
to continue long on or in; to remain absorbed with; to stick to; to make much of; as, to dwell upon a subject; a singer dwells on a note. They stand at a distance, dwelling on his looks and language, fixed in amazement. Buckminster.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Dwelled, usually contracted into Dwelt�); p. pr. & vb. n. Dwelling
entry.ety: OE. dwellen dwelien, to err, linger, AS. dwellan to deceive, hinder, delay, dwelian to err; akin to Icel. dvelja to delay, tarry, Sw. dväljas to dwell, Dan. dvæle to linger, and to E. dull. See Dull, and cf. Dwale

sn.def: To delay; to linger.
To abide; to remain; to continue.
sn.q: I 'll rather dwell in my necessity.
Thy soul was like a star and dwelt apart.

sn.def: To abide as a permanent resident, or for a time; to live in a place; to reside.
sn.q: The parish in which I was born, dwell, and have possessions.
The poor man dwells in a humble cottage near the hall where the lord of the domain resides.
sn.syn: To inhabit; live; abide; sojourn; reside; continue; stay; rest.

entry.def: To inhabit.
An inhabitant; a resident; as, a cave dweller .
entry.q: Dwellersat Jerusalem.

cs.cd: a house intended to be occupied as a residence, in distinction from a store, office, or other building.
place of residence.

entry.def: Habitation; place or house in which a person lives; abode; domicile.
entry.q: Hazor shall be a dwelling for dragons.
God will deign To visit oft the dwellings of just men.
Philip's dwelling fronted on the street.

entry.def: of Dwell.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Dwindled; p. pr. & vb. n. Dwindling
entry.ety: From OE. dwinen to languish, waste away, AS. dwīnan; akin to LG. dwinen, D. dwijnen to vanish, Icel. dvīna to cease, dwindle, Sw. tvina; of uncertain origin. The suffix -le, preceded by d excrescent after n, is added to the root with a diminutive force
entry.def: To diminish; to become less; to shrink; to waste or consume away; to become degenerate; to fall away.
entry.q: Weary sennights nine times nine Shall he dwindle, peak and pine.
Religious societies, though begun with excellent intentions, are said to have dwindled into factious clubs.

sn.def: To make less; to bring low.
sn.q: Our drooping days are dwindled down to naught.

sn.def: To break; to disperse.

entry.def: The process of dwindling; dwindlement; decline; degeneracy.
The act or process of dwindling; a dwindling.
gradually decreasing until little remains.
the act or process of becoming gradually less until little remains; as, there is no greater sadness that the dwindling away of a family.

entry.ety: See Dwindle
entry.def: To waste away; to pine; to languish.
the chemical symbol for dysprosium, a rare earth element of atomic number 66.

entry.ety: L. dyas dyadis, the number two. Gr. �: cf. F. dyade. See two, and cf. Duad

sn.def: Two units treated as one; a couple; a pair.
An element, atom, or radical having a valence or combining power of two.

entry.def: Having a valence or combining power of two; capable of being substituted for, combined with, or replaced by, two atoms of hydrogen; as, oxygen and calcium are dyad elements. See Valence.

cs.cd: the same as binary arithmetic.

entry.ety: Gr. �, fr. � two
entry.def: Pertaining to the number two; of two parts or elements.

entries.entry: Dy"aks n. pl.; sing. Dyak. Ethnol The aboriginal and most numerous inhabitants of Borneo. They are partially civilized, but retain many barbarous practices.

entry.ety: L. dyas the number two
entry.def: A name applied in Germany to the Permian formation, there consisting of two principal groups.
the Hindu god of the sky.
the Hindu god of the sky; same as Dyaus.

entries.entry: dyb"buk dĭb"bŭk; Hebrew dē*b�k" n.; pl.dybbuks; Hebr. dybbukim dē`b�k*ēm". Jewish folklore the wandering soul of a dead person, or a demon, that enters the body of a living person and controls that body's behavior. It may be exorcised by religious rites. dibbuk.

entry.cs:
To dye in the grain To dye in the wool
Fig.), to dye firmly; to imbue thoroughly. He might truly be termed a legitimate son of the revenue system dyed in the wool. Hawthorne.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Dyed dīd; p. pr. & vb. n. Dyeing
entry.ety: OE. deyan dyen, AS. deágian
entry.def: To stain; to color; to give a new and permanent color to, as by the application of dyestuffs.
entry.q: Cloth to be dyed of divers colors.
The soul is dyed by its thoughts.

sn.def: Color produced by dyeing.
Material used for dyeing; a dyestuff.

entry.def: Same as Die, a lot.

entry.sn: colored or impregnated with dye.Narrower terms: dyed-in-the-wool, yarn-dyed; hennaed undyed tinted.
having a new color imparted by impregnation with dye; having an artificially produced color; not naturally colored.Narrower terms: bleached colored.

sn.def: thoroughly imbued; thoroughgoing; uncompromising; complete; unmitigated; through-and-through.
dyed before being spun or woven into cloth.

entry.def: A building in which dyeing is carried on.
The process or art of fixing coloring matters permanently and uniformly in the fibers of wool, cotton, etc.

entry.cs: dyer's rocket Dyer's weed . Same as Dyer's broom.
entry.def: One whose occupation is to dye cloth and the like.
small Eurasian shrub (Genista tinctoria) having clusters of yellow flowers that yield a dye; common as weed in England and U.S.; sometimes grown as an ornamental.
entry.syn: woodwaxen, dyer's greenweed, dyer's weed, dyer's rocket, dyeweed, greenweed, whin, woadwaxen, Genista tinctoria.

entry.def: A material used for dyeing.
Any wood from which coloring matter is extracted for dyeing.

sn.def: In the act of dying; destined to death; mortal; perishable; as, dying bodies.
Of or pertaining to dying or death; as, dying bed; dying day; dying words; also, simulating a dying state.

entry.def: The act of expiring; passage from life to death; loss of life.
In a dying manner; as if at the point of death.
The state of dying or the stimulation of such a state; extreme languor; languishment.
entry.q: Tenderness becomes me best, a sort of dyingness; you see that picture, Foible, -- a swimmingness in the eyes; yes, I'll look so.

entry.def: See Dike. The spelling dyke is restricted by some to the geological meaning.

entry.ety: Gr. � power + E. actinometer
entry.def: An instrument for measuring the intensity of the photogenic (light-producing) rays, and computing the power of object glasses.

entry.ety: Cf. F. dyname. See Dynamic
entry.def: A unit of measure for dynamical effect or work; a foot pound. See Foot pound.

entry.ety: Gr. � power + -meter: cf. F. dynamètre. Cf. Dynamometer

sn.def: A dynamometer.

An instrument for determining the magnifying power of telescopes, consisting usually of a doubleimage micrometer applied to the eye end of a telescope for measuring accurately the diameter of the image of the object glass there formed; which measurement, compared with the actual diameter of the glass, gives the magnifying power.

entry.def: Pertaining to a dynameter.

entry.cs: Dynamical electricity. See under Electricity.
entry.note: WordNet lists a number of narrower terms for dynamic and dynamical adj.Narrower terms: can-do; driving; energizing, energising, kinetic; forceful, slashing, vigorous; projectile; propellant, propellent, propelling, propulsive; renascent, resurgent; self-propelled, self-propelling; high-octane, high-powered, high-power, high-voltage
entry.ety: Gr. � powerful, fr. � power, fr. � to be able; cf. L. durus hard, E. dure: cf. F. dynamique

sn.def: Of or pertaining to dynamics; belonging to energy or power; characterized by energy or production of force.
sn.q: Science, as well as history, has its past to show, -- a past indeed, much larger; but its immensity is dynamic, not divine.
The vowel is produced by phonetic, not by dynamic, causes.

sn.def: Relating to physical forces, effects, or laws; as, dynamical geology.
sn.q: As natural science has become more dynamic, so has history.

entry.def: In accordance with the principles of dynamics or moving forces.

entry.note: dynamic RAM is cheaper to manufacture, but because of the need for a refresh cycle, is generally slower to access than static RAM. It is usually implemented in integrated rircuit chips containing thousands to millions of bits of information storage capacity, and is commonly used as the main type of memory circuit in personal computers.
entry.ety: Random Access Memory
entry.def: a type of random access memory using circuits that require periodic refresh cycles in order to retain the stored information. Contrasted to static ram, which maintains the memory state as long as the power is still applied.

sn.def: That branch of mechanics which treats of the motion of bodies Kinematics and the action of forces in producing or changing their motion kinetics. Dynamics is held by some recent writers to include statics and not kinematics.
The moving moral, as well as physical, forces of any kind, or the laws which relate to them.
That department of musical science which relates to, or treats of, the power of tones.

entry.ety: Cf. F. dynamisme. See Dynamics
entry.def: The doctrine of Leibnitz, that all substance involves force.
One who accounts for material phenomena by a theory of dynamics.
entry.q: Those who would resolve matter into centers of force may be said to constitute the school of dynamists.

entry.def: A political dynamiter. A form found in some newspapers

entry.ety: Gr. � power. See Dynamic
entry.def: An explosive substance consisting of nitroglycerin absorbed by some inert, porous solid, as infusorial earth, sawdust, etc. It is safer than nitroglycerin, being less liable to explosion from moderate shocks, or from spontaneous decomposition.
One who uses dynamite; esp., one who uses it for the destruction of life and property.
Destroying by dynamite, for political ends.
entry.q: Dynamiting is not the American way.

entry.def: The work of dynamiters.

entry.ety: Gr. � power. See Dynamic
entry.def: The act of setting free the dynamic powers of a medicine, as by shaking the bottle containing it.
A dynamo-electric machine.

entry.ety: Gr. � power + E. electric. See Dynamic
entry.def: Pertaining to the development of electricity, especially electrical currents, by power; producing electricity or electrical currents by mechanical power.

entry.ety: Gr. � power + -graph. See Dynamic
entry.def: A dynamometer to which is attached a device for automatically registering muscular power.

entry.note: ☞ It usually embodies a spring to be compressed or weight to be sustained by the force applied, combined with an index, or automatic recorder, to show the work performed.
entry.ety: Cf. F. dynamomètre. See Dynameter
entry.def: An apparatus for measuring force or power; especially, muscular effort of men or animals, or the power developed by a motor, or that required to operate machinery.
Relating to a dynamometer, or to the measurement of force doing work; as, dynamometrical instruments.
The art or process of measuring forces doing work.

entry.ety: L. dynastes, Gr. �, fr. � to be able or strong: cf. F. dynaste. See Dynamic

sn.def: A ruler; a governor; a prince.
A dynasty; a government.

entry.ety: NL. See Dynast
entry.def: A tyrant.

entry.ety: Gr. � of a dynast, fr. �: cf. F. dunastique
entry.def: Of or relating to a dynasty or line of kings.
Dynastic.

entry.ety: Gr. �, fem. of �. See Dynast. The name alludes to the immense size of some species
entry.def: One of a group of gigantic, horned beetles, including Dynastus Neptunus, and the Hercules beetle Dynastus Hercules) of tropical America, which grow to be six inches in length.

entries.entry:
Dy"nas*ty dī"n�s*t� or dĭn"�s*t�; 277 n.; pl.Dynasties -tĭz. Gr. dynastei`a lordship, fr. dynastey`ein to hold power or lordship, fr. dyna`sths: cf. F. dynastie dynasty. See Dynast
Sovereignty; lordship; dominion.
A race or succession of kings, of the same line or family; the continued lordship of a race of rulers.

entry.ety: Formed fr. Gr. � power. See Dynamic
entry.def: The unit of force, in the C. G. S. (Centimeter Gram Second) system of physical units; that is, the force which, acting on a gram for a second, generates a velocity of a centimeter per second.

entries.entry: Dys-. An inseparable prefix, fr. the Greek dys- hard, ill, and signifying ill bad hard difficult, and the like; cf. the prefixes, Skr. dus-, Goth. tuz-, OHG. zur-, G. zer-, AS. to-, Icel. tor-, Ir. do-.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. dys- ill, bad + � to perceive, to feel
entry.def: Impairment of any of the senses, esp. of touch.

entry.ety: NL. dyscrasia, fr. Gr. dyskrasi`a; dys- bad + kra^sis mixture, fr. keranny`nai to mix: cf. F. dycrasie
entry.def: An ill habit or state of the constitution; -- formerly regarded as dependent on a morbid condition of the blood and humors.

entry.ety: Gr. � bad + � compound
entry.def: A mineral consisting of antimony and silver.

entries.entry: Dys"cra*sy n.; pl.Discrasies. Dycrasia. Sin is a cause of dycrasies and distempers.

entry.ety: L. dysentericus, Gr. �; cf. F. dysentérigue
entry.def: Of or pertaining to dysentery; having dysentery; as, a dysenteric patient.
entry.q: Dysentericsymptoms.

entry.note: ☞ When acute, dysentery is usually accompanied with high fevers. It occurs epidemically, and is believed to be communicable through the medium of the alvine discharges.
entry.ety: L. dysenteria, Gr. �; dys- ill, bad + �, pl. �, intestines, fr. 'ento`s within, fr. � in, akin to E. in: cf. F. dysenterie. See Dys, and In
entry.def: A disease attended with inflammation and ulceration of the colon and rectum, and characterized by griping pains, constant desire to evacuate the bowels, and the discharge of mucus and blood.

sn.def: impaired in function; especially of a bodily system or organ.
failing to serve an adjustive purpose; -- of a trait or condition; as, dysfunctional behavior.

entry.def: Not procreating or breeding freely; as, one race may be dysgenesic with respect to another.

entry.ety: Pref. dys- + genesis
entry.def: A condition of not generating or breeding freely; infertility; a form of homogenesis in which the hybrids are sterile among themselves, but are fertile with members of either parent race.
of or pertaining to dysgenics.
the study of the operation of factors causing degeneration in the type of offspring produced.
an abnormality in performing voluntary muscle movements.
having impaired ability to comprehend written words; a condition usually associated with a neurologic disorder.
an impaired ability to read.

sn.def: of or pertaining to dyslexia.
same as dyslectic.

entry.ety: Gr. dys- ill, bad, + � discourse, fr. � to speak
entry.def: Unfavorable; not commendatory; -- opposed to eulogistic.
entry.q: There is no course of conduct for which dyslogistic or eulogistic epithets may be found.
The paternity of dyslogisticno bantling, but now almost a centenarian -- is adjudged to that genius of common sense, Jeremy Bentham.

entry.ety: Gr. dys- ill, hard + � to loose, dissolve
entry.def: A variety of the zinc spinel or gahnite.

entry.ety: Gr. dys- ill, hard + � a loosing
entry.def: A resinous substance formed in the decomposition of cholic acid of bile; -- so called because it is difficult to solve.

entry.ety: Gr. dys- ill, hard + � month + � to flow
entry.def: Difficult and painful menstruation.

entry.ety: Gr. �; dys- ill, bad + � law
entry.def: Bad legislation; the enactment of bad laws.

entry.ety: Gr. � ill smell, from � ill-smelling; dys- ill, bad + � to smell
entry.def: An impure earthy or coaly bitumen, which emits a highly fetid odor when burning.

entry.ety: L. dyspepsia, Gr. �, fr. � hard to digest; dys- ill, hard + � to cook, digest; akin to E. cook: cf. F. dyspepsie. See Dys-, and 3d Cook
entry.def: A kind of indigestion; a state of the stomach in which its functions are disturbed, without the presence of other diseases, or, if others are present, they are of minor importance. Its symptoms are loss of appetite, nausea, heartburn, acrid or fetid eructations, a sense of weight or fullness in the stomach, etc.
Pertaining to dyspepsia; having dyspepsia; as, a dyspeptic or dyspeptical symptom.
A person afflicted with dyspepsia.

entry.ety: Pref. dys- + peptone
entry.def: An insoluble albuminous body formed from casein and other proteid substances by the action of gastric juice.

entry.ety: NL. dysphagia, fr. Gr. dys- ill, hard + � to eat
entry.def: Difficulty in swallowing.

entry.ety: NL. dysphonia, Gr. �; dys- ill, hard + � sound, voice: cf. F. dysphonie
entry.def: A difficulty in producing vocal sounds; enfeebled or depraved voice.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. �, fr. � hard to bear; dys- ill, hard + fe`rein to bear: cf. F. dysphorie
entry.def: Impatience under affliction; morbid restlessness; dissatisfaction; the fidgets.

entry.ety: L., fr. Gr. �, fr. � short of breath; pref. dys- ill, hard + �, �, breathing, � to blow, breathe: cf. F. dyspnée
entry.def: Difficulty of breathing.
Affected with shortness of breath; relating to dyspnœa.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. dyspro`sitos hard to get at
entry.def: An element of the rare earth-group. Symbol Dy; at. wt., 162.5.

entry.ety: Pref. dys- + teleology
entry.def: The doctrine of purposelessness; a term applied by Haeckel to that branch of physiology which treats of rudimentary organs, in view of their being useless to the life of the organism.
entry.q: To the doctrine of dysteleology, or the denial of final causes, a proof of the real existence of such a thing as instinct must necessarily be fatal.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. �; dys- ill, hard + to`kos delivery
entry.def: Difficult delivery pr parturition.

entry.note: ☞ Datolite was called dystome spar by Mohs.
entry.ety: Gr. dys- ill, hard + tomo`s cutting, diate`mnein to cut
entry.def: Cleaving with difficulty.

entry.ety: L. dysuria, Gr. �; dys- + � urine: cf. F. dysurie
entry.def: Difficult or painful discharge of urine.

entry.ety: Gr. dys-: cf. F. dysurique
entry.def: Pertaining to, or afflicted with, dysury.
The Chinese yellow antelope (Procapra gutturosa), a remarkably swift-footed animal, inhabiting the deserts of Central Asia, Tibet, and China.

entry.note: ☞ The name is sometimes applied also to the koulan or onager. See Koulan.
entry.def: The kiang, a wild horse or wild ass of Tibet (Asinus hemionus).
